description:
There is usually a line here because the only seating they have is a bar which fits around 10 people, so it's pretty small. Your best chances of getting something from Yamo is if you get take out or if you come off peak eating hours.

The reason I love this place is because the value is really good for what you can get. I usually get the Yamo House Noodles which comes with a choice of chicken, beef, pork and something else. The house noodles are prepared in a simple manner. It is noodles, fried garlic, green onions with your choice of meat and is fried together really quickly. When you sit down, they have a variety of sauces to spice up your dish.

They serve various other noodle and rice dishes. Their tea salad is also pretty good too! I'd say this place is a mix of Burmese and Chinese food.

Yeah the prices are really good too, with most dishes costing less than $7 and they have appetizers for $3 - 5! So cheap! I come here when I want something quick, cheap and good to eat.

I've been here a few times and it used to be better before! I think it's gotten slightly worse since they've grown in popularity, but is still a decent place.
author: Christopher L.

description:
I was told that this place had good, cheap food, but the people working there didn't speak English. I came by with my friends twice but there was a wait so we decided to come back the next day at 2pm... there was still a wait. After ten or so mins, the ladies working asked us what we wanted (in English) and were pretty friendly. So we put in our orders while we were still waiting which is pretty efficient of them. We asked for the tea salad, fish chowder noodle soup, and yamo house noodles. Each dish was $6.50. 

The only dish that stood out to me was the tea leaf salad. It was very fragrant. It's hard to describe but had two types of crunchiness one from some fried beans and some from the cabbage. The salad was slightly sweet, incredibly spicy but not too bad. There was a slight herbaciousness and had smokey Jasmine flavors. I really enjoyed this dish so extra stars for that. The others... not so much. I thought the house noodles were a bit bland but my friend really liked them. I remember it being a little light on the protein. The fish chowder soup had a weird flavor that I didn't quite enjoy nor could I place what was off about it. It was topped with some kind of crispy crackers? There was no actual fish in this dish. I wouldn't order this again

In all a pretty enjoyable experience but I wouldn't want to wait more than 10 mins for it... It really depends on how fast the people eat because this place is TINY. Hardly any space between the barline counter and the wall to exit the restaurant.
author: Justin C.

description:
I'm Asian and the circus wheel of random moody service is Asian rudeness, that is close to best!  That day may come, when one or both of those ladies will throw my food order at me and, then, have the bad ass view to charge me for it!  Because, it was my fault.

The food is good considering their low prices relative to eating out in SF.  Classic hole in the wall.  Some of these places have ambiance and charm, particularly if the cooks can add to the vibe.  Bring your patience along, as a smiley guest.
author: Zeoki A.

description:
I don't understand how this place can be so cheap and so tasty at the same time. We came at 8:15pm, and there were two empty seats! There are only 7-8 seats total. I was planning on getting takeout if there were no seats. 

Tea leaf salad is super good. Next time I would order it "not-spicy," but only because I can't handle spice. Nate got Fish Curry over Noodles, which was fine but not spectacular. My chicken noodle soup on the other hand, was fantastic. 

Their tofu looks fantastic. I think it was the House Special Noodles with Tofu. They also have spinach noodles, which is interesting. Things to try next time!
author: Julia C.

description:
"What do you want?" I kept hearing, and wondered who was saying this.  I stood outside, and viewed the menu while watching for someone to leave the small counter so I could grab a seat. One could order food to go at the counter next to the door. 

I noticed someone I know leaving, who advised me what to eat. I previously ate the tea leaf salad (to go), and thought it was good. I wanted to try something new. She said to try the cold noodles over the house noodles for its combination of spices and textures. Since it was getting cold, I decided on the vegetable curry when I found a seat. There are a good amount of vegetarian options. Note: try to avoid the far corner of the counter, since one won't really have much counter space.

I was asked "What do you want?" by the server/prep cook/busser and told her. I watched the speediness of the cook, and my food arrived quickly. The curry had a good variety of vegetables, and flavorful sauce plus noodles. The guest next to me reached for a water bottle for me from the fridge. I learned that hot tea wasn't available when someone asked for it. A food item (perhaps #3) also wasn't available. 

What do you want? Cheap, good food is what you'll receive at Yamo.
author: Carol W.

description:
A lot of these reviews seem lower than average because of the rushed service / not cheerful waitstaff but I had a pleasant experience with the woman who rang me up for my takeout. She was smiley and kind, I guess if you dine in they rush you but considering the wait I've seen outside you should be considerate that they're just trying to optimize for profits and feed as many hungry folks as possible. 

I got the house noodles with beef and was a little disappointed by the amount of beef I got, but $6.50 for a takeout order of noodles = one of the more affordable meals you can get in this area now.
author: Hana S.

description:
This place is quite charming. It's like a tiny Asian diner. While the prices are cheap, it's mostly because there's not that much meat in dishes. 

The service here is really rude, but comically rude. Think Seinfeld Soup Nazi. Theres one mean lady that doesnt give a shit, she's the one that takes orders and serves you. The other lady is cooking, she's vaguely nicer but doesn't speak much English.

The House Noodle with Beef was actually very tasty. It was mostly egg noodles but it was very flavorful with garlic and soy. It tasted even better with pickled chilies!

Samosas were crispy and fresh out of the fryer. The filling and flavor were just alright.

The Chicken Curry was okay, bordering on mediocre. It was mostly fried potatoes in a basic curry sauce. The little chicken pieces that were there were clearly just hacked up bits.

I tried asking for a spoon in Mandarin, but the lady gave me a glare that made me think that they don't speak it. The strange thing was that they were alternating between Mandarin and Toisan/Cantonese. 

I'm not sure I'd come here again. I enjoyed the noodles, and the prices were cheap, but I do think I'd get more bang for my buck (and more protein) just getting a carne Asada Mission burrito.
author: Gabriel H.

description:
I have no idea why this place does not have better reviews. The food is great, the prices are the cheapest I have ever seen and the service is super fast. 

I am giving it 4 stars instead of 5 because the space is small and you have to wait in line. But that's the proof that the food is awesome
author: Varun P.

description:
Inexpensive Chinese food. You get what you pay for. The beef and garlic noodle was tasty but where's the beef. It was 90% noodle and 10% beef. We also got the mango chicken and one other dish that wasn't memorable. It was decent and probably good for a weekday lunch. Portions are a bit on the small side but for $6/each what can expect. They were sold out of a lot of the seafood too. 

I'd prefer Panda Express but if you're in the area and want cheap eats. This is your spot.
author: Lindsay C.

description:
When I think of cheap eats w/ great flavors in the Mission, Yamo comes to mind.  Literally a hole-in-the wall place with only counter seats and barely enough room to fit a backpack/purse, this place is meant for single diners/small groups or take out only.

The 3 ladies running this operation is not the friendliest nor do they care much about customer service, but they sure have a lot of fun and chemistry working with each other.  I often see them laughing and joking with each other so they do seem to enjoy what they do but don't annoy them thought or else you will endure stone cold faces and feisty attitude with your meal.  It is pretty much expected that you know what you would like to order the moment you sit down.

Service aside, their food is delicious!  A mixture of both Chinese and Burmese offerings, I love coming here for their Mohinga (fish chowder soup), Coconut Chicken soup, or Yano House Boodles w/ Beef.  Yes, some dishes are greasy but they come out piping hot and bursting w/ some nice wok flavors.  At prices of no more than $6.25 a dish, it's a freaking steal in SF!!
author: Janetto L.

description:
A 10 seater, ultra cheap asian fast food joint!
I do not think they are serving any Burmese food here but everything we saw on the menu looked relatable and delicious.
We got the day special papaya salad, yamo special cold noodles and mango curry with rice.
Everything delicious and quickly prepared.
author: Garima K.

description: It's been a couple months since I first tried this place and decided to go today for some beef-noods and tea salad. Sat at the counter with a friend waiting for our order. I decided to snap a photo of my food and a nice big flame from the wok. So, Asian auntie decided to yell at me... "HEYYYY WHAT ARE YOU DOING?!!!?!" I casually and calmly respond.. "Taking a picture" she gives me a mean mug for a good 30secs. The old me would've fed into her anger and yell back but, nah. I just kept eating as I thought it was amusing you would get so heated over a photo ‍. Payed the bill and as my friend and I get up from the counter to exit the premises. She mumbles in anger and in a good volume tells us GET OUT!!  Ok! Bye, Felecia!! I guess I got the full dining experience LOL.
author: Glyde W.

description:
My friend and I were trying to find a cost-affordable take-out spot for our small group, and since Yamo was nearly, dropped by here. The seating area is small, so I would suggest take-out if you're a larger group. We were just coming to pick up food. We placed our order over the phone, and the lady was pretty abrupt with all our orders. Entering in, we saw that it was basically a two person show for taking orders and cooking, so can understand the abruptness especially during a busy dinner time.

We ordered the tea salad, yamo house noodles with beef, and curry chicken. I am giving Yamo 2 stars for the food. The tea salad was covered with too much sauce, so couldn't really figure out what I was eating with all the sweetness. And it was a pretty small portion for tea salad. The house noodles were a bit too stuck together, but the beef was pretty tasty. And the curry chicken was a bit too bland for my taste. But it was extremely cost affordable. It was only $6 per dish..so think it averaged $19? So if you want a cost affordable meal, come here. But if you want some good Burmese food, then I suggest going elsewhere. Overall, a one time meal and will be getting my Burmese food elsewhere next time.
author: Jackie C.

description:
I've been going here for a while because of the price. But I'm going to stop after today.
This place is very UNSANITARY!! The lady is extremely rude and ignored me even when I asked if they got my order from when I called 15minutes a go. They had not even started when I got there, and kept my noodles half finished. Then she touched RAW CHICKEN before adding vegetables to my noodles. I feel sick now.....
Not worth it.
author: Nina S.

description: Best tea salad in San Francisco.  The other dishes are OK.  The cooks are priceless!
author: Jamie T.

description:
This place is like the "Soup Nazi" from Seinfeld TV Show. Horrible service, long wait, hope in the wall type of place that takes only Cash.

On the positive, the prices are relatively low, food tastes decent and you get served on the bar.
author: S J.

description: Curry Beef over rice and House Noodles are my favs... but everything on the menu is good. Great ladies behind the counter cooking/preparing your food too! Also, don't be that person that tries to substitute ingredients because they ain't havin' it! One of a kind place here in SF, and I plan to frequent as long as I can!
author: Ryan A.

description:
A little disappointed the last time I came since I always rave about this place and have been bringing friends for the last ten years. Props for maintaining the prices after all these years and being a great quality quick food place! However, I was a little disappointed with the flavors recently. It's just shifting from authentic flavors and when there's so much competition in the Bay Area, you can't slack on flavor. 
However, I'm giving four stars because I want to keep supporting them, and they are a rare small hole in the wall local business that's been around forever, it would be a pity to see them disappear. I do recommend them revisiting their recipes though.
Otherwise, it's a great small joint to come and grab a bite or get takeout.
There isn't much seating available but that's the nice attraction about this place. Don't change that part! Just maybe revisiting the recipes.
author: Alicia C.

description:
My friend recommended this place to me because I had never had Burmese food before. This hole in the wall has managed to survive for decades in the Mission without raising their prices. I got an incredible beef curry for $6.50!! If I ate anywhere else in the neighborhood, I'd absolutely be paying twice as much for food. 

Just be aware that small restaurants like this won't give you the same customer service as, say, the Thai restaurant down the street. The owner is very distant and typically only responds in grunts. Don't order a glass of water unless you want it bottled. Be a patient customer and you'll have a quality experience.
author: Calvin H.

description: I love this place and go here every time I'm around. The prices are unbeatable and the portions are perfect. My favorite is the cold noodle because of all the spices and flavors in it. The house noodles are pretty great and garlicky as well. All the appetizers are highly recommended too. You can replace any of the meat with tofu! Also the seating is quite limited but the ladies that work there make sure to move people through fast so you will find a seat if you wait. Don't come after 9pm because there's a chance they won't serve you.
author: Kalani R.

description:
Yuck!! Part of me feels horrible for writing this review but honestly I wish this review existed before I walked way too far for this.

Food is tasteless. Burmese is one of my favorite foods and I love it for its rich flavors. This place was so so so bland. 

Service is horrendous. The girl at the counter is flat out rude and dismissive, almost as if it's her schtick. But it's off putting and really not cute.

The place is filthy. I by no means have high standards for ambiance when there is good food involved (my favorite Burmese place is nothing fancy at all) but this place is dirty. You can watch them prepare all the food and I literally saw utensils being reused and put back in little nooks. THEN an exterminator came in and started doing a routine inspection and collection, so disgusting. 

It's cheap, and that might be the only upside but definitely not cheap enough to make up for everything else.
author: Sarah G.

description:
My friend and I recently went because we heard so many cool things about this hole-in-the-wall! The fact that this mom and pop restaurant is operated by all women was also such a huge + factor. 

We went on a Thursday night and the line was still very much long! So go with a hungry stomach and a will to wait. (The inside is very NYC diner-esque, so not much seating). 

Every dish is $6.50 so you can order a lot of food and on a budget, just be wary because it's a Cash Only joint. 

As we were waiting my friend saw a cockroach scurrying across the counter and hide underneath the soy sauce container! She was visibly disgusted and the other patrons also suddenly stopped eating. We both lost our appetite but took the food to-go and paid respectfully. 

I understand that things can get super busy and cleaning might get hard to prioritize, but it was really sad to wait for that long and suddenly lose our appetite because of that. I hope this restaurant takes note of this review and take some action.
author: Rosa K.

description: Yamo is my go-to place for quick grab Burmese food. It's a hole in a wall type of restaurant with open kitchen (3 people preparing/getting orders in the kitchen) and counter seating- can sit maybe 8-10 max. There's always a line but people come and go pretty quickly so waiting isn't that bad. You can take food to go home and eat, which I do sometimes. Signature dish is yamo house special noodles, tea leaf salad, and chicken noodle soup but other things on the menu are delicious too. Best thing about this restaurant is the price- tea leaf salad $5, house noodle $6.25. Portion can be slightly smaller so I would recommend ordering 2 main dishes with 1-2 appetizers (or tealeaf salad for each person). *CASH ONLY!!  Don't forget to bring cash with you. Ladies working there are not too friendly but I like how they are- it adds to the experience. Once I heard one of them saying "thank you" back I felt so happy lol
author: Adel A.

description:
Probably one of the cheapest meals you will ever eat when you're in SF, unless you're eating at a fast food joint, but you know what I mean!

Came here on a Wednesday evening at work and was surprised to see how TINY the shop was. It literally is a hole in the wall with 2 ladies working the kitchen/cashier and a counter space that can only fit 8 people. The ladies working in the kitchen really know how to cook fast and efficiently so getting a seat shouldn't take too long!

The Tea Leaf Salad ($6.25) was my favorite dish of the night and I found it really flavorful with the various nuts. This dish is definitely a must order if you're going to eat here! The Yamo House Noodles with Beef ($6.25) was also tasty and a really good bang for your buck!

I would suggest coming here with only one other person since this restaurant is so small and can't accommodate big groups. Also don't be thrown off if you hear the ladies working the kitchen yelling you at some foreign language. It's just a part of the experience eating here!
author: MyTien P.

description:
Can't believe it took me 3 years in SF to try this. Yes, waiting to get a bar seat isn't so fun but dang those two ladies cook fast. I have never been happier to get yelled at to grab a seat. 

The tea salad is something I've never tried before, with crunchy pieces of what I believe were garlic cloves and shredded veggies. The papaya salad is more standard but still very good. We also ordered curry fish, which was not as flavorful to me, but the texture was soft and creamy. My friends seemed to really enjoy their red meat dishes.

All in all I hope to return ASAP. If you're in a rush, take out is quick!
author: Urmila J.

description:
The tiniest yet, the most comforting hole-in-the-wall Burmese goodness! Fast, cheap, and delicious, Yamo offers the most satisfying bowl of noodles for as less $6, which is unheard of in this city with skyrocketing prices. Mission Gem! 

Note: This place is *CASH ONLY*.

MUST HAVE:
Yamo house noodles with pork 
Potstickers
Mohinga (fish chowder soup)

No-frills-and-get-down-to-business kinda place.
The place is tiny, with just 10 countertop stools. 
So be prepared to wait in line. However, the line moves fast.
Not good for large groups, ideal for 1 or 2.
This place is run by two older ladies who speaks little English and not the best with manners. But don't let this scare you off. 
Service is fast and food will hit the right spot. 
The menu is limited, and the dishes are for $6.
author: Payal B.

description:
This place must accompany the dictionary entry for hole in the wall. You sit at a counter, elbow-to-elbow, with up to 8 other patrons; the food is made right in front of you; and the decor is, well, a mix of peeling paint and smoke stains.

But the food is probably some of the cheapest in the city. For $6.25 I had the House Noodles with Beef. (You have a choice of chicken or pork instead.) Filling with simple flavours: a combination of garlic, oil, and salt that will leave you wishing they didn't charge for bottled water. The meat portion is relatively small but the generous portion of noodles left me satisfied.

The service wasn't terrible so much as it was nonexistent. I felt largely ignored by the ladies working there... which was fine, since it let me focus on the food. I didn't experience being yelled at for having my phone out, as some reviews suggest, but I made sure to only take a photo of my food when their backs were turned.

Expect a 5-10 minute wait during lunch rush. Cash only.
author: Yves L.

description: Great food for amazing prices. Not enough space to sit at all so I'd encourage take out and service is really bad but I feel like you pay for what you get.
author: Ritika R.

description:
I'm not afraid of germs. But even I noticed this would make most people say to themselves, "uh, where are we eating." Let's start with the good.

The food is cheap. You could get an entree for less than $7. The food is tasty. Not great, not bad. But it tastes fine. 

Now for the rest of the review: 8 seats at a counter. OK, I can deal with that. We sat down just as other customers left. So we saw their dirty dishes, their discarded, cheap napkins, and soup dribbles on the counter. that is understandable, they just left. The lady (I am not going to call her a waitress), picks up the dirty dishes, uses the discarded napkins to kind of wipe some of the dribbles on the counter away. I thought, "huh, she'll be back with a rag, right?" Ah, no. The next thing she said was What do you want? We ordered. She said, "That's all?" yes. We sat at the end of the counter, farthest from the door. There was an open garbage bin near us, and it did not have a cover. We could smell garbage our whole time there. This paired with the rude service, dirty countertop, just had me saying, I'm not coming back here. The way I figure, if they don't care about cleaning what the customer is eating on, it makes me wonder how much they care about cleaning things the customer may not see. I don't care how cheap the food is, I'm not going back. You can go if you're curious. Don't take a date.
author: Jason P.

description:
Fast, cheap, and delicious! Coming here reminds me of being back in Asia. The lady is very efficient albeit not the MOST friendly. (Don't take it personally!) The place has very limited seating as it is a super small hole-in-the-wall. 

Cash only / no credit cards.

I recommend ordering:
1) tea leaf salad
2) house noodles w/ beef
3) dumplings/gyoza

Very authentic and refreshing. Flavors are on point and it feels very homemade.
author: Alicia L.

description:
I have to admit, the food are really delicious.
but I also have to warn you, the ladies inside are feisty and downright brutal.
don't you dare to take pictures, they (especially the one in the middle) will chew you and swallow you alive.
truly a definition of a** hole in the wall.
6 stools, no manners, and whole lotta flavors & hella attitude!
Punk Rock Never Die!
author: Rudy H.

description:
Came here on a random day for lunch and was pleasantly surprised. 

Some things to note: 
-Super tiny hole in the wall, pretty easy to miss if you don't look up. 
-Cash only! The lady who works there explicitly said, "no money, then you can leave" as she waves her hand towards the door. Pretty hilarious. NO SHAME. 
-Menu is pretty small, couple appetizers for $4.50 a plate, rice plates and noodles for $6.25.
-They give good portions of noodles, but proteins they're pretty selfish with.

Ordered...
-Fresh spring rolls: 1 order comes with 2 full rolls. These were decent, nothing to rave about. The peanut sauce was a bit bland and lacked that thick, sweet yet nutty flavor. But for $4.50? Can't complaint that much.
-House noodles with beef: these were delicious, I'd order them again. Noodles were cooked perfectly, sprigs of cilantro and green onion for the fresh crunch. Beef was salty but paired really well with the plain noodles. I do have to point out that these are a bit on the oiler side, and the amount of beef they gave was nowhere near proportionate to the amount of noodles.

Just a heads up to anyone who ventures in here, this place is run by two older ladies who speak just enough English. They're not the best with manners and won't greet you with a welcoming hello, nor a friendly goodbye. You will literally walk in, cramp yourself down at the bar, and order. When you're done eating, they will shoo you away so that other customers can grab a seat. 

I didn't mind the nature of their actions. I came for the cheap delicious food, filled my stomach, and left.
author: Ava F.

description:
I've had garlic noodles at Thanh Long.  They're so good, they're habit forming.

Yamo's House Noodles aren't quite as good, but they're a close second - and you can get them topped with beef, chicken or pork.

I had the chicken: nugget-sized pieces of salted, garlicky chicken, a generous handful of fried garlic and a few leaves of bright green cilantro.

They're even better the next day!

Also tried tea leaf salad (Yamo is Burmese and Chinese).  This had more lime and less tea flavors than it's cousin at Burma Superstar, but was refreshing and crunchy with nuts and fried beans.
author: Sondra H.

description:
I heard the hype. Amazing food and terrible service. In the end, it was decent food and terrible service.

Like other reviews have mentioned, it's a no-nonsense lady who provides service and cooks. If you come here, come for the food and don't have any expectations for the service. Best to know what you want before you even walk in.

Food:
Mango Chicken: Honestly just a ton of rice with some snap peas, mango and chicken. The stir fry wasn't even that flavorful and there wasn't enough sauce to pair with the rice so it honestly ended up being kind of dry and flavorless. If you're looking for something really light to eat this is a good choice.

House Noodles with Beef: Now this dish actually has some flavor even though it's a bit on the salty side. The beef is seasoned well albeit there's very little of it and the noodles have a good bite too it. The oil it's tossed in is a good balance of smoky and savory. However, they do not hold back on the oil. By the end, I was quietly dabbing away at the pool of oil at the bottom of the bowl with a napkin. 

At $6.25, the dishes are quite cheap; there's no doubt about that. But even at that price, and given the hype, the food really doesn't measure up and it doesn't merit a return visit for me.
author: Jason W.

description:
Tiny hole-in-the-wall delightful place (if you like holes in the wall) where I went for lunch on my last day in SF, because I am obsessed with tea leaf salad (laphet thoke), thanks to Burma Superstar. The potstickers were nothing to write home about, but the tea salad was excellent. The women next to me (who were Burmese-American) all ordered the chicken noodle soup and it looked and smelled delicious; they seemed to be really enjoying it. 

Next time I'd get the salad and soup. Always the salad!
author: Rachel G.

description: *cash only! Learned it after I had placed the order. Found this place on a whim while in yelp. I ordered the garlic noodles with beef. It honestly wasn't that good. It was bland in a way. The beef was a little beef jerky ish which didn't taste good. Nothing special. Don't think I'll be ordering from here again.
author: Nessa H.

description:
PROS: 
- good food (got the house special with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and tea salad) 
- CHEAP food (everything was $6.75....WTF) 
- authentic 

CONS:
- rude Asian lady (but I'm sure she doesn't mean to be rude. That's just their culture)
- cash only 

The space is extremely small that can probably only seat like 11 people. I didn't know if it was a pro or con, because pro it gives it the Asian atmosphere of small hole-in-the-wall authentic restaurant, and con because well, it's tiny af. Hence, a wait. 

All the food was good and cheap though. I definitely liked how unique the fish chowder noodle soup was, never tasted anything like it. The house special noodles with pork tasted like typical garlic chow mein noodles, though the pork was bomb. And tea salad was tasty with a kick to it. 

If there's a long wait, probably best to get to go. And don't get offended if the Asian lady yells at you! That's just how she normally talks lol.
author: Raquel Y.

description: This place is fast, cheap, and completely delicious. One of those hole in the wall places you dream of discovering in your neighborhood. Garlic noodles are what's up. Limited seating and small space, so you have to wait outside.
author: C Y.

description:
Walking to Ken Ken Ramen, my girlfriend and I saw Yamo. Intrigued by this epitome of a hole-in-wall local eatery with limited seating, and more importantly delicious-looking menu items, we diverted our plans of eating ramen to eating noodles without soup and tea leaf salad.

The most memorable thing about this joint is the 2 Asian aunties cooking and interacting (or lack of interacting) with guests intentionally (and unintentionally). My girlfriend was just looking through her phone but one of the cooks thought she was taking a picture of her and she said, "no pictures please." Then, while somewhat smack-talking with some other random customers, the meaner-appearing Asian lady was like, "I can hear you!" We weren't sure if they just like to make witty remarks or they're mad. Their blank but fickle body language was difficult to interpret. Lastly, after we ordered 3 dishes for the 2 of us, the meaner lady said, "that's it?" Is this a rude or funny auntie? Maybe both. Who cares though--made for a good experience. Anyway, I share this story more for humor than annoyance.

Anyway, if you're going to get anything here, holler at the House Noodles with Beef--flavorful/tasty/filling. The menu items are cheap (about $6.25 each) and for a moderately hungry person, 2 dishes would suffice.

If you can easily grab a seat and you're in the area, this is a cool spot for its charm of Asian cuisine served by some characters in the middle of the Mission district. No need to leap bounds to come here, but it will be worth your while for one of those random nights you just want something local, good, and cheap.
author: Marlon T.

description: Good food, cheap meal but comically rude cook and server. It's one of those places where you just accept and don't mind the rude service. It's $6.5 for a bowl of noodle in the city so you know there must be a trade-off.
author: Manuel H.

description:
This was the best meal I had in SF.

Such a deal. So delicious. I think I may go back again!!!

Get the Tea leaf salad, house noodle, and potsticker!
author: Matthew T.

description:
A lot of the poor reviews of this restaurant do not contend with the food (which is excellent) but rather comment on the service. To address this, I think one should consider what David Chang refers to in the 'fried rice' episode of his show, Ugly Delicious, as a problem of perception between Asian and American service cultures. In America, a diner's perception of a hospitable waiter is often constructed around things like pleasantries, chit-chat, and a happy demeanor. In Asian dining culture, a good waiter is thought about in terms of efficiency under which conversational qualities such as directness and terse exchange are deemed perfectly normal, if not positive traits.

This is all to say that when get to the front of the line at Yamo and the lady who is about to prepare your food asks, "What do you want?", she is not trying to be rude or abrasive. This is simply the most direct way to receive the necessary information to place delicious food into your hands. Similarly, when you ask this lady if you and your friend(s) can eat inside and she says,"no," she is not trying to be rude. This is simply the shortest way of saying she can't grant your request because there are no more seats available inside. 

So relax with the 'service sucks' rating bashes because they are the product of a cultural misunderstanding in food service culture. Concentrate instead on the food which, I would argue, is one of the tastiest and most affordable meals in the city.
author: Gunther P.

description:
Average fast-chinese food, great pricing (cash only), small venue (8 seats only), angry burmese grandmas(cooking with fire~).

Noodle-topping ratio is high unfortunately but noodles are very QQ and thicc. The best dishes (4-star for me) are the yamo house special (delicious beef and chicken) and the tea salad (soo flavorful). The fish chowder is weird--no real fish, lots of corn, and not very creamy or flavorful. Cold noodle is not that spicy. I'm afraid of trying their other dishes since they either "run out" or it just sounds like store-bought/microwavable options. 

Also, you gotta think on your toes, grab your order and run, don't be confused or else they'll yell at you.
author: Lydia Z.

description: This place like the soup nazi, it's super tiny and the service is curt, however the food is really good.  Their tea leaf salad is cabbage not fermented tea leaves, but the flavour is good.  Take-out is the way to go.
author: Anna S.

description:
This is truly a grimy, dark hole-in-the-wall with limited seats at a counter and a line out the door. It's cash only and there's no bathroom. On top of it all, the ladies behind the counter are grouchy and hate it when you ask too many questions. And NEVER EVER take pictures of them while they're cooking. In fact, hide your camera. 

This may sound like a terrible place BUT people keep coming back for the amazing food! I love the coconut milk based chicken noodle soup, the house noodles w beef/chicken/or pork, and the tea leaf salad. 3 people can eat for less than $25 and each dish has a spicy flavorful punch. 

Try it at least once. 
They have a Facebook page but no website. Other reviews are pretty funny and are mostly stories about how they've been yelled at or abused. And yet, I risked my life to get pictures for you. Enjoy!
author: Mitzi G.

description: Love this spot, it is a go to quick meal in my neighborhood that never disappoints. The black bean fish with noodles and a tea salad are hard to beat! It is a very casual space and the women who work here make it a very homey atmosphere in a way where people are so comfortable with each other that they don't need to be polite. If you bring outside beverages, sit too long (there's only a few bar stools and always a line of people waiting to sit), or do something else that isn't Yamo approved, then you will get yelled at to correct your behavior! I personally love it and think they're doing a great job. I always eat in vs getting take out to enjoy the experience. The prices can't be beat for a big plate of tasty food.
author: Annelise P.

description:
A hole in the wall, in every sense of the phrase. In a nondescript grimy alley you could unknowingly pass by a real gem of Burmese deliciousness. A tiny cave of a restaurant that sits about eight people directly in front of the kitchen.

All the food is inexpensive and tasty, especially the Yamo House Noodles! Juicy beef atop golden garlic noodles bursting with flavor! A little bit too much sodium but not a deal breaker. More than one customer ordered multiple servings of the house noodles while I was there.
The food comes ridiculously fast. Many people walked in, ordered to go, and left with their food in times that would put fast-food chains to shame.

A star gets docked for service. I suppose I shouldn't be too surprised that these ladies are only here to cook, serve, take your money, and move on. Don't expect a friendly demeanor. They are masters of the minimally civil passive aggressive attitude. "NO PICTURES!" the cashier screams deafeningly as I raise my camera to my food. The cook shrieks too, but not in any language I understand. All of the patrons in the restaurant and a passerby turn their focus to the commotion. Okay fine. Yes, chef. The camera is going away but couldn't you at least put a sign up or something? Not every picture taker wants to experience a Gordan Ramsay episode.
I took one anyway.
author: Stephen C.

description:
You eat fast cheap delicious noodles and then you leave. I find the women cooking quite pleasant.
Was very hung over, Yamo hit the spot. Ordered house chicken noodles and an ice cold sprite for $8.50. Cash only.
author: Joe R.

description:
This is amazing food!! My brother refers to the chef as the noodle Nazi. (noodles not soup... see what he did there?!) 

Here is your Yamo survival guide: don't save seats. Not even for a microsecond. Don't take pics. Really, don't. Order the house noodles and papaya salad.
author: Julie Z.

description:
Horrible service. I initially ordered to go and already paid and tipped. After seats opened up, I asked the chef if I can eat inside and she said yes. Apparently I asked the wrong person as I was given the to go containers by the other lady and when asked if I can sit and eat, I was told to leave as I ordered to go. The chef then asked to confirm if I already paid, and when I said yes, she suggested nicely for me to leave too. I wished I took back my tip. Same lady that told me to leave doesn't wash her hands after touching cash (cash only) and can be seen using hands to prepare the noodles... Attention San Francisco Department of Public Health.

Mohinga (Fish Chowder Noodle Soup) isn't even that good. Burma Superstar is much much better!
author: Nicholas N.

description:
Delicious food, fast service, and cheap!

Small place--only about 9 seats at the counter--but it's worth the wait and perfect to-go food. I love the tea leaf salad, curries, and house noodles!
author: Aja D.

description: Everything is just okay. We've tried couple times here, the price is cheap but the noodles are really not special. I would say bad quality food but considering prices are cheaper than everywhere else, this is the quality you get.
author: Choco W.

description: Used to love this place for a quick, delicious bite. Unfortunately, have decided not to return because the rude service has begun to outweigh the food.
author: Lucy Z.

description:
A few seats and a few selections from the menu to kick off a great night. I absolutely love Burmese food and every time I'm back in the Bay, it's on my list. While I would have normally gone full out at a larger sit down, Yamo was a perfect drop by and have a quick meal full of flavor. 

We got the samusas, mango chicken, fish chowder, and tea leaf salad. 

I will saw everything was exceptional with the exception of the fish chowder. In general, this is one of my top favorite dishes but it was just alright here. Otherwise, I'd still highly recommend for food, price point, and quickness.
author: Leslie L.

description:
I was adventuring by myself around San Fran and stumbled upon this hole in the wall. Despite it only being 3.5 stars on Yelp, the place has a lot of reviews and looked like a really authentic place, so it appeared potentially promising. Key word: APPEARED. Because let me tell you, it really does deserve its not-so-spectacular rating.

The instance I walked in, I was not greeted, but rather, I felt a really tense and extremely unwelcoming vibe throughout the restaurant. The place is extremely small and probably only has about 7-8 high chair seats directly facing the kitchen where 2 Asian women are cooking. 

NOTE: Do NOT attempt to take a picture in the restaurant, especially a shot directly facing the women or else you will feel the wrath and rage from them. It was so awkward when the head lady yelled on the top of her lungs, "NO PICTURE"! You know that one gif where Homer Simpson backs up into the bush and hides from the entire world? THAT WAS ME! Trust me, I went through war and anxiety to take the picture of my curry chicken. 

Anywho, the food is very affordable and cheap, so the 1 $ on Yelp is very accurate. I asked the head lady what a good recommendation is and she was pissed at me. At that point, I felt like me breathing honestly pissed her off. I eventually decided on the Curry Chicken and it wasn't bad or anything, but it also wasn't amazing either. It tasted really buttery to me and there were barely any chicken pieces within the plate. Also, bottled water is $1 here if you ask them for some water too. 

Overall, I felt really weird at this restaurant and felt like I was being judged left and right. I could tell the other customers with me all felt the same.
author: Tiffany T.

description: Best Burmese food in the city. This is my favorite SF restaurant. It's authentic, it's delicious, cheap and fast. It's not a date spot. It's not a spot to hang and chat. It's just about the food. A M A Z I N G
author: Benjamin D.

description:
My friend Jenna introduced me to Yamo years ago. I went back today. Good memories of my younger years, not that I'm over the hill. 

Here, you almost feel as though you're away from home, in terms of vibe and prices. The flavors and portions are good. The menu is smaller than typical at the standard Chinese/Burmese joint, but, IMO, this is a place you order your couple preferred dishes every time.
author: Paulina F.

description:
"If you don't leave deaf and emotionally battered then it's not authentic" -allie wong.

To be honest it's decent food at extremely reasonable prices, flavors are typically on point. My usual go to for quick eats in the area. I understand San Francisco is a hot bed of privileged and opinionated.. people with severe CrossFit vegan lifestyles. So you have to understand you're walking into a restaurant with cuisine not from America. Some cultures don't want to bend to your American ideals.
author: Jon I.

description:
First off... Never ever take a picture. The old asian lady will yell at you like no tomorrow. The scolding was REAL. We were scared she'd kick my boyfriend out. But i would totally stay and bring his food out if that happened because I have to finish this food first!
The food is like no other. Everyone talks about the tea leaf salad at this other place in sf. which btw, news has reported their workers don't get paid ideal wages. I digress.
This tea leaf salad is tiny compared to what i have had, so i'd order yourself one. but because it was our first time, we tried the salad and the house noddles. We should have each had our own because we were immediately left wanting more. The flavors are so amazing, not greasy, not alot of sauce, just right. Spicy.
The space is small, so you are super packed and cash only. you can order out to avoid the line because she only seats about 7 people.
author: francis c.

description: Hidden in a tiny hallway behind a smoke shop on mission with bomb plates of food for 6 bucks. I ordered the tea leaf salad and house noodles with beef. The salad was crunchy and very flavorful and the noodles while basically lo mein with beef and vegies but were tasty and filling. Other posters are right half the fun is getting jokingly yelled at by the Cambodian grandma who runs the place as you pack into a hallway sized dive. Definitly go here next time your on the mission strip.
author: Sean G.

description:
After reading reviews that the best tea leaf salad in the city is at Yamo, I decided I HAD to come check it out. I had already been forewarned that the service here is subpar, so I knew I would just be coming to pick up the salad, pay the easy-on-my-wallet $6.25 and leave. 

Fair warning: I've had the tea leaf salad at Mandalay, Burma Love, and Burma Superstar and I absolutely love how each place makes it, albeit a bit differently across. So, I guess I had high standards coming in to Yamo and expecting that beautiful tanginess from the fermented tea leaves and overall explosion of flavors from the crispy garlic to the jalapeños. 

I got home super excited and sat down on my couch, wide-eyed and ready to try this dish. I took a bite and my first feeling was of disappointment. This tasted nothing like tea leaf salad and really just had a strong onion taste from the large quantity of onion immersed in the dish. The flavors were just okay, but when you're expecting a tea leaf salad, this paled in comparison. If you guys have ever had Indian bhel (common street food snack), this salad kind of tasted like that. If I had ordered bhel, it would have been fine, but I hadn't. 

Overall, I wasn't impressed with Yamo. I don't think the cheap prices make up for the quality of food that you get. I may return to try the noodles or other entrees, but I don't have high hopes at this point. I will stick to what's tried and true and revert to the other much better Burmese establishments in SF where the flavors are really well-developed and I leave feeling happy and satiated.
author: Sabina S.

description:
Straight up rude. 

I first went here over five years ago- their salads and noodles used to be legit. One of my friends was even from Burma and always love to visit here when n SF. Not. Any. More.

I will never set foot n this place again. I was given a tea leaf salad that consisted garlic chips, shredded cabbage, a few nuts seeds and lots of sweet chili garlic sauce. No tea leaf to be found (she tried to tell us: it's a ground into the sauce- well I call BS!! Not to mention tea leaf salad is not made with chili sauce. Hipsters of the mission, believe me when I tell you this is not what tea leaf salad is supposed to taste like.

In fact it's one of the dishes I know I can safely order because it doesn't have chili in it. Chills make me break out in hives. When I had to return the salad I was confronted and mocked. Would you like some verbal abuse to go with your dinner? 

If you're looking for a soup Nazi type experience with declining food quality and portion sizes- look no further. Really disappointing and a little disgusted. Where do you go after you go this downhill...?
author: Coco J.

description:
I randomly stumbled upon Yamo one evening as I was looking for a quick bite in the area. Yamo is probably one of the few dive restaurants left in the city, and the experience does not disappoint. There are probably only 8 seats along a bar facing the "kitchen". It's seriously a hole in the wall. A few women are working behind the counter, and if you don't order when they come by, expect to wait another 5-10 minutes. Thankfully, I already knew what I wanted to order having stared at the menu during my 10 minutes in line. I started with the tea salad, and I was so surprised by the great flavors. It's seriously one of the best tea salads I've had in the city. I also ordered the house noodles with beef. The big bowl of steaming noodles is carb heaven, but don't expect anything more than a kick of garlic in terms of flavor. The dish is simple but satisfying. 

The restaurant is certainly not the cleanest, and the staff is definitely not the friendliest, but the price really can't be beat. It's a great spot for a quick meal or takeout. I will definitely come back to try other items on the menu.
author: Regina L.

description: Definitely a diamond in the rough. Very small and only seats a few people in the restaurant. Would definitely recommend take out for this place. Everything on the menu is pretty cheap, but really good and full of flavor. Their yamo house noodles were pretty good with pork and we also tried their mango chicken along with it. Definitely going to make my way back to this place again.
author: Luis T.

description: Good food don't take the attitude personal there small and just want to get you in and out... they are super nice if you know what you want and just order.. good prices too for the neighborhood there in .. Thanks Yamo for the delicious lunch
author: Anna A.

description: Love yamo! Quick inexpensive and quality! The mango chicken is so good to! I can do a Mango chicken and house noodles any day! The staff is moms and Pops style they give you a awesome attitude lol gotta love them!
author: Brian K.

description: This hole in the wall is my favorite place to eat in SF. Cheap, delicious, fast, no-fuss. Closest thing to street food in Asia. My go-to's: tea leaf salad, house noodles with beef, chicken noodle soup.
author: Michelle L.

description:
All I have to say is this is my favorite place so far, I had the house noodles two days in a row and hope to get my hands on some more before I leave town. Quick simple and delicious! 

I didn't get to take pictures of the food but if you're around the are you should definitely try it! 

Also make sure you know what you want and be ready to order, there is limited seating inside but you should just get it to go and go hang out at the Dolores park! 

It's a cash only place.
author: Carlos G.

description:
I come here for the house noodles with beef. Cheap, reliable and satisfying. Cash only. Be quick with your order, eat, and don't linger. 

Tea lead salad is okay but there are plenty of others who like getting it here. Next time, I think I'll try out the lomein and pot stickers.
author: Jay K.

description:
One of my favorites. I would almost not tell anyone about it. But, everyone knows about it. Because it is that good.

CASH ONLY 

Good -- Different -- Food with many vegetarian options.
author: BigJohnS F.

description:
Chinese mom meets Seinfield's soup nazi. If you don't understand my Seinfield reference, go youtube this now. I assure you, it's hilarious. 

The Yamo experience is a mix of PTSD of every confusing childhood memory of being scolded combined with the pleasant memory of home cooked meals prepared by your Chinese mom. 

The food ranged from good to great (review below), but the experience of eating at Yamo was absolutely terrifying with a squeeze of comical. Upon entering the restaurant you'll be greeted by a very angry mama cook who seemly appears to yell at everyone: her daughter, the other mama cook and all patrons. Service is quick - you enter, you order your food while you wait to be seated - you get seated, and immediately the dishes you previously ordered are flung at you.  Yes, dishes are airborne for a few seconds before clattering loudly in front of you - maybe safe to have a napkin ready for the splash zone. 

Oh did you want to take a photo of your food? You better take it ninja style or ask permission to take "food photos only" because mama cook will scream at you from across the restaurant " NO PHOTOS". 

Did you want to enjoy your food over good conversation? Hopefully you've mastered the art of talking and inhaling food at the same time, otherwise, you'll get the stare down from mama cook if your chopsticks aren't forking food into your mouth while you're swallowing forcefully. Take a tip and skip the chewing because your bill will arrive in front of you shortly. After you pay - and remember cash only - you're thanked very loudly, but if you listen between the lines, mama cook's real thoughts are GTFO because you're holding up her business. 

We ate (each dish ~$6.25 pre tax): 

1. Tea Salad (2/5) - Burmese style salad mixed with fermented tea leaves. Salad comes premixed.The salad was more spicy and lemony than a typical Burmese tea salad, and peanuts were roasted/fried, but no longer crunchy. It was clear the salad was pre made and sitting in the fridge ready to be served. 

2. Mango Chicken (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with mango and chicken, served with a bed of white rice. The "wok hei" or in english, "the breath of the wok"  was real- this dish had a complex smoky flavor that is only achieved by cooking fresh ingredients over extreme heat. The flavors of the chicken coated in sauce were deep, and the bell peppers and mango retained the textural crunch. Would have liked more than 3 pieces of chicken. 

3. Black Bean Fish (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with black bean white fish, served with a bed of white rice. As above, the wok hei flavor was legit. Flavors were on deep and smokey. Texture was crunchy and crispy. Fish portion was could be larger. 

4. Yamo House Noodles (3/5) noodles mixed with garlic and a choice of beef, chicken or pork - ours was beef. Noodles were cooked almost al dante and heavily coated in oil, mixed with garlic and topped with a pinch of extremely salty beef crumbles. 

Overall: 

Food - 3.5/5 - Food here definitely has potential. On one hand the wok hei flavor is on point, on the other, portion sizes of protein is minimal and often too salty. Prices are cheap, which makes the value for food was a good bang for the buck in SF. 

Service 1/5- From my notes above, the experience at Yamo was conflicting. I was terrified from the moment I walked in, but also couldn't help uncontrollably laugh at the situation. There were some frequenters who came for take out and you can tell they've experienced the PTSD themselves and have learned better to just get take out. One after one, they'll come in and skip the banter, and just say the numbers of the dishes they wanted to order. Put down the money and with a slight bow retreat backwards out the door where they waited patiently until their meal was prepared. Pro tip: if you want to experience yamo without the PTSD, just come for take out. 

Environment 1/5- This rating is likely skewed from the notes above - but hard to enjoy a meal when you're feeling afraid. Minimal seating ~ 10, expect to wait 30+ mins if you come during regular meal hours. Definitely come on a pre laundry day because you'll walk out smelling like Yamo. 

Eat take out from here.
author: Janice K.

description: It's funny that people are complaining about tiny stuff because for sure those ladies don't give a shit about what we say. But that is the whole vibe we want from hole in the wall (people who do not give a shit). You go, get your food and leave. This is not a place where you demand for a service or a nice gesture. Food is good, affordable price and that is that. If you want someone to serve you and make you feel like a royalty, you better go somewhere where an entree is $20 and up. For me, this place gives me what I pay for.
author: Kushal G.

description:
You don't come here for the service. In fact, don't eat here at all. The line is long and the place is super cramped. The best way to enjoy Yamo is by ordering for pickup or if you must eat at the restaurant, go on your own. 

Must haves: tea leaf salad, samosas, and the house noodle with pork. Probably the most affordable noodle place in the mission!
author: John L.

description:
Yamo, the smallest, most delightful little hole-in-the-wall in the Mission that churns out fresh, hand-made noodles and has a counter that seats maybe 6 people total, is a complete gem. While I can't say I would wait in a long line to snag a seat at their counter, knowing take-out is an option makes me very happy.

THE OVERVIEW.
~ Very limited seating
+ High quality control and absolutely fantastic dishes
+ An entirely delicious tea leaf salad that rivals that of Burma Superstar's, easy
- Cash only

Given the trendy-trend feeling the Mission has been moving towards, it's nice to have down-to-earth, old school eats around.
author: Claire S.

description: My favorite small cozy no frills kinda place. Only really started appreciating it after the 3rd visit. The food is always delicious! My favorite is the chicken noodle soup! The seafood chowder is also very tasty. The low prices are an added bonus.
author: Dan B.

description: A surprising hole in the wall with tasty Burmese  food made to order! I went there for lunch, and was amazed at the quality and flavor. Definitely not the restaurant to model after for cleanliness, but it was a delightful little place! Try their chicken noodle soup and Yamo chili spinach noodles!
author: Katy L.

description: I think the food was just okay. Service was not there. I guess they were busy all the time and didn't like to interact with their customers.  The price was okay. The portion was just enough for one person and not enough to share. I ordered the tea leaf and two other dishes which was highly recommended by previous customers.
author: Diane T.

description: In a word a gem. An Asian diner. You a grab a seat at the counter or you order takeout. I usually notice restaurant workers coming here at the end of their shift, hungry. My advise for a smooth experience is to order your food and wait, refrain from questions to the management. Enjoy the food.
author: Alex B.

description:
I wholeheartedly give this place five stars even though it's cash only because it simply is so fresh, so affordable, and downright delicious. The menu has something for everyone and is vegetarian/vegan-friendly. I got the cold noodles and the only complaint I would have is that they were not cold; the reason being the chicken was cooked on the spot and this made the noodles warm.

When I visited a second time, it was one woman operating the kitchen with another lady at the cash register. It was super hot, but the service was still personable. If I had to be in a space that small under 90° weather, I would have been very irritable! Usually many people get the food to go, but eating in is also an experience. The place only offers seating for around 10 people. There are also hooks on the wall to accommodate for backpacks and jackets. Though the place is small and a hole in the wall, it's clean and a neighborhood staple.
author: Katherine L.

description:
"Get out!" the owner barked, index finger jabbing towards the door. I had just sat down after 40 minutes of waiting.

They treated me like this because my boyfriend had gone to put our bags in the car, as there was no space in the stuffy-squishy-dirty interior. His butt wasn't physically in the seat I saved for him because he was busy being considerate to the other patrons. As soon as I got to the door (which was 5 steps away because the space so tiny), my boyfriend returned. The owner still wouldn't let us be seated.

I'm glad that Yamo's business is so great that they can afford to treat their customers like mangy dogs begging for scraps, and kick them out with a snarl and a rude finger. What disrespectful arrogance. I'm sure their food must be delish, but I'll never know because I can't stomach the side of attitude.
author: Cathy X.

description:
How does a hole in the wall on 18th get 4 - 5 stars?

When I go to the new place in town everyone's talking about, I normally end up giving it 3 stars. What was it missing, character, ambiance, flavor?  All of that. 

It can get crowded and hot, I end up smelling like the place after I leave. You might have to wait for the opportunity to smell like the place. The noodles are delicious, the veggies are fresh and the fried foods arn't overly greasy. 

People have expectations that are unreasonable, make comparisons they shouldn't and fail to recognize authenticity. 

This lady cracks me up,  she's not trying to make my day, she works hard and I respect that. She takes pride in here work and that makes me happy. The pride and the love she puts in to her work makes the food amazing. 
Yamo has mad flavor. It has more character then any new resturant could ever hope for (with a couple exceptions) 

Places like this are the backbone of our city. The people who run them are my heroes.
author: Ben M.

description:
Decent garlic noodles and low prices save this hole-in-a-wall from a 1-star rating. 

I'm used to negligent service at small restaurants, but this place is downright rude. The owners more or less yell at customers rather than ask or serve them. Dishes are shoved or dropped in front of your face, and the folks working there act almost annoyed to be serving you. 

I've been here twice, and the treatment today was awful. I met up with two friends who were eating there, but I was just planning to sit and chat with them. They asked what I wanted to order, and when I said I wasn't eating, they told me to wait outside even though half the restaurant was empty. Thankfully, my friends had ordered three entrees, so I picked at a few bites and shared with them, all the while enduring dirty looks from the owners.

The food isn't so good that it makes up for the terrible service. It's greasy but cheap. If I ever come here again, I'll be getting the food to go. Not a fan of getting abused while eating, thank you very much.
author: Tim X.

description: Bomb food, fast service, not much seating inside so call ahead and pick up. Cheap prices too!
author: Parasto S.

description:
I was such a Yamo fan until today. Something changed.. something happened. 

I ordered my usual house noodle with chicken to go. Yes, the Asian ladies are still not known for their service but I didn't mind. They were able to get me my order quickly.  

When I got home and opened the container, I was very disappointed to see only 5 pieces - not to mention, small pieces- of chicken.  The noodle was greasier than usual. The whole dish also just tasted saltier - had to down several glasses of water after. Not sure what happened, Yamo, but I don't think you're my favorite hole in the wall anymore.  Or maybe my palate changed now that I'm in my 30s?!
author: Cassy H.

description:
"NO PICTURE!!!", barked one of the cooks as I attempted to capture the hustle and bustle of this hole-in-the-wall establishment. As a result, I wasn't able to control myself from laughing throughout our meal - to say I was nervous while eating was definitely an understatement! Admittedly, it was not so easy to enjoy my meal.

My second visit to this joint was just as entertaining. I called for a pickup order ahead of time and let them know, in Mandarin, I was 10 mins away. When I arrived 5 minutes late, the head cook sarcastically said she had nothing prepared for me - even though my takeout was right in front of my eyes. I joked around with her and the other cook just laughed along with me, lol.

Come here for the entertainment and banter. If you're easily offended, this is not the place for you. Also, it helps if you speak Mandarin / Burmese / Cantonese. They'll be way nicer to you!

5* for entertainment
3* for the food (Burma Superstar is way better)
author: Junaedy L.

description: This place is the bomb! The workers a polite & to the point which is the kind of service I love, food is cheap & delicious but remember you get what you pay for. This hole in the wall is a gem!
author: Jasmine T.

description:
**LIMITED SEATING***
*SERVICE BASICALLY NON EXISTENT*

However, food=yummy!!!

Came here since I was nearby, hungry, and hadn't had a tea leaf salad in awhile!!

$6.25 

Small plate, but def worth it!

Flavor is on point!

There's basically no service, besides what do you want to eat.... and pay... asked for restroom since sign said restroom for customers and the lady helping me mumbled something along the line of no.....?  

Not sure however I would be back if in the area, this place is good for solos, or groups of 2 MAX 3 don't be those people who show up with 6 others and take up all the seating... 

Everything is pretty cheap on the menu, would possibly try other items but the tea leaf salad was great so might just stick to what I already know won't disappoint. 

Btw: salad is at a medium / hot spicy level depending on your tolerance. I'd say around medium but others might say pretty spicy
author: Janessa H.

description:
* Cash only; supermarket across the street has an ATM. $7 per dish. One dish per person is enough. 

Yamo is a San Francisco classic in the Mission. It's a hole in the wall with two older (Burmese) ladies working the small kitchen to whip up quick, friend meals. There are about six stools at the counter of the kitchen that keep you up to date with the status of your meal - and a fridge in the back with bottled beverages. Wait time when the restaurant is full is about 15 - 20 minutes for your food. Food comes to the counter, as it's ready. 

The best options, of the 10 on the menu, are noodles and friend meats. Rely less on options like the Burmese salad (or adding in meat, if you're a snob about quality). Each dish had a unique flavor palate 

Stick to noodles and friend foods here, and rely less on options like Burmese salad. Also, if you're a snob about meat quality - then this isn't your place either. There are about ten options, of the four I've had, all were fantastic. Each dish was flavorful and unique.
author: Qurat K.

description:
Definition of hole in the wall. 

Simple. Quick. Hassle-free. 

If you want a simple meal that is priced reasonably, this is the place for you! There are about 10ish seats available inside the restaurant but people hop in and out pretty quickly. The cooks cook in front of you and is served freshly promptly.
author: Christa L.

description:
Come for a meal if price is what matters most to you, because there will be trade offs in the quality and service. The dishes here are cheap, but remember that you always get what you pay for. 

The tea salad, while tasty, was small-- about the size of a fist. Toppings for the house noodles were stingy. It had a few pieces of beef, green onions, and nothing more. The noodles were bland, but I did enjoy the taste of the beef, even if it was a little dry. The chicken curry was probably my favorite dish of the night. I liked the sauce, but the dish would've been more aptly named "potato curry" because it was 80% potatoes, 10% chicken, and 10% everything else.

The service and cleanliness of the restaurant is the main reason why I won't be coming back. I was disappointed to see the lady behind the counter grabbing the cooked noodles with her bare hands-- the same hands that take cash from customers and clean up the dishes. Additionally, she throughout the entire meal, she kept on muttering "No talking, just eat" while I was trying to catch up with my friend. The restaurant is a bit too warm and cramped for comfort, but that aspect adds to the hole-in-the-wall experience.
author: Amy C.

description:
i used to hit up yamo at least twice a month when i lived in the city. LOVED this place. but now i live in oakland and don't get to go often. recently i came over to the city and carved out a special date with my go to tea salad and house noodle with beef. these items were the dopest and made the hella mean asian lady (i'm asian. don't get this twisted) tolerable. greasy kitchen like my mama's. 

but daaaang. meat portion and quality going down, flavor watering out, and WHY DOES THE TEA SALAD ALWAYS GET TO ME AFTER MY NOODLES?? you feel me, lady?! 

anyway. it's a popular local jaunt that has a cult following... but for me... RIP yamo.
author: S S.

description:
I pass this place every time I go to DP. I've had the Tea Salad before and thought it was really good and different. Today I decided to try other things. First they opened 50 minutes late today. Such is a small mom and pop place. 

I tried the Hot Ramen with Pork. I watched how everything was made. I noticed the noodles were heated very quickly and put in the to go container. It sat for 10 minutes while the rest was cooked. Thought that was weird. Tasted good but not close to warm when I ate it. 

I also had the egg rolls. A favorite everywhere I go I thought "let's see what they do". I watched as they took four egg rolls that were frozen and placed them in the deep fryer. Now I can't imagine why they would freeze their eggs roils. Of course they didn't make them as they were exactly like the next one. I'm very disappointed because I wanted to see something new, not something old. 

Pluses:

Tea a salad is really good
Noodles were tasty but cold, better eaten at the counter. 

Minuses:

Egg rolls were bought not made. 
They need a better way to keep food warm.
author: Mark T.

description: I just came from this place again because I was in the area and hungry and thought I give it another chance big mistake on my part!!! The elder Asian lady was rude as can be and made me wait after everyone else to get my food after I set down before four other people, as I mentioned before she treats blacks different than her Asian or White customers and it's sad that discrimination still goes on in America let alone SF. My food was cold and missing normal vegetables that come with the meal my second order I canceled because she acted like I wasn't even at the table waiting for my food.. As I ask about my food and to see what was going on she curse me out in her language and told me to sit down! I explained to her I'm not a child I'm a grown man and you need some show some respect! She's an evil person that is rude, un clean and the food is Major un-healthy with cake up grease that's just been sitting in a jar for days and weeks !! Not to mention the same spinach and egg noodles all sitting in a card board box touching each other while she uses her bare hands to pick up food and then wipes on her dirty clothes!! This place is un sanitary!! She will never get a dime of my $$$----RACISTS!!!!
author: Mr. Q.

description:
Amazing and cheap. The place is small, maybe 10 seats. Easiest to take your food to go. My favorites are the spring rolls, garlic noodles with tofu, and tea leaf salad. The food is consistently yummy.

But if you're so entitled that you believe the hardworking women behind the counter must cater to your whims and be aware of your requirements for spaced out appetizer and entree dishes, do everyone a favor and go elsewhere. These women have been doing their thing for years and years, and if you're annoying, I hope they DO yell at you. They make solid food on the cheap in a hole in the wall restaurant. Leave them be. Cheers.
author: Angela G.

description:
Came here on a Thursday night with a friend and was super surprised by the price point of Yamo! 

Yamo is this tiny restaurant in the Mission, about an 8 minute walk from the 16th St. Bart station. There are probably 6 counter seats in Yamo and that's it. A lot of people order to-go. The inside of Yamo is super cramped -- as we were sitting and eating, when people walked in and out of Yamo, they'd brush against our backs, need to squeeze through, or people waiting in line would need to back out of the door to make room for others to walk through. 

Yamo's no-frills interior is mirrored with its price point, however. Both my friend and I ordered the house beef noodles, which is a whopping $6.25. Service was brusque and the food didn't come as quickly as I would have expected (given how small Yamo is and how they need to have quite fast turnaround to open their 6 seats for others waiting in line), but again, considering the price, I wasn't complaining. 

The food itself was decent. The bowl of noodles was decently sized and tasty. 

Yamo is cash only, so be prepared for that.
author: Jackie Y.

description:
Best tea leaf salad I've ever had in my life & I know my way around a tea leaf salad. I think about this salad on a daily basis. Get the cold noodles. Melt in your mouth. How is it possible to eat well for less than $7 here? Idk but it is possible. Amazing. 

The girls behind the counter are quite rude, even if you're a regular. 

My husband got the curry chicken, I got the black bean fish. Both good but nothing to write home about. 

I'll be back next time I'm in town. Must visit!
author: Jaki F.

description: Ok, another great spot but theres always a long line, go on weekdays to avoid it. The food is totally worth it!
author: Alf D.

description:
I have lived here in SF for almost 2 years now, and this is by far my favorite place to eat. Tucked away behind a rather loud smoke shop on Mission st & 18th is Yamo, a cozy Burmese eatery that I have come to love. From the moment you see their sign to the moment you leave smiling, this experience is one you will soon not forget. The menu is small, the prices are beyond reasonable, and the taste is unmatched. There is little seating available and it won't always seem welcoming, usually due to people crowding the door and not being bold enough to have a seat. Do not hesitate to ask to sit down, they definitely value people who take initiative. 

In my dealings with SF and food, usually the more packed a spot is, the better. The same applies here, so please don't be worried about waiting a long time as it always seems to clear out just as quickly as it fills up. The ladies who work there are tough, can appear short tempered, and are usually in a rush. This is not to be mistaken as rude, for they greatly care about the product they're delivering. They will usually smile and chat should you ask them how they're doing. It took close to a year for the lovely ladies there to remember me, and to be honest I'm proud I earned their trust. So keep smiling and remember your manners. 

I have only ever ordered the House Special Noodles with Beef/Chicken/Pork. Each one of the meat choices are different, and taste simply amazing. I have taken everyone of my friends there and they all leave astounded. It will truly open your mind as well as your eyes to a different culture. 

This place makes me feel like a bootleg version of Anthony Bourdain, discovering some hole in the wall halfway across the globe that's probably run out of someone's home. The meal is simple, tasty, and above all cheaper then $7. I highly recommend trying this place out. Believe me when I say that you will not leave disappointed in the slightest.
author: Michael L.

description:
So I bookmarked this spot because I have always wanted to try it. There is always a line so my expectations were high. The verdict was my expectations may have been too high because I wasn't very impressed.

Tasty, affordable food. The tea leaf salad is tiny but pretty tasty and unlike other tea leaf salads. It is pretty spicy too! The homemade noodles (we got it with beef) was good but I've had better tasting noodles before. Nothing special. Samosas also were nothing special. 

Small restaurant (which I normally don't mind) but at this place, the lady behind the counter was very aggressive in having us pay and leave, probably because there was a line outside. It was not very comforting at all. Cash only although that is very typically of hole in the wall places.
author: Cicely T.

description:
I used to live across the street and would pay a visit to Yamo every other month or so craving a cheap, oily meal.

While Yamo is famed for (and perhaps prides itself on) its low prices and rude service (both of which are true in practice), I've never finished a meal that made me feel particularly happy with my decision.

Personally, I'm fine with the service - it's an Asian restaurant, and having spent a large amount of time throughout Asia, that's understandable. Do not ask for recommendations, do not take photos, etc. Makes sense, fine.

However, I've never been really happy with the food. When you buy cheap Asian food in an authentic place, you expect it to be simple and delicious, regardless of the price. No dish I've ever ordered here has come to be remotely satisfying, let alone cheap (as the plates are small and they rush you to finish).

For low cost, delicious Asian food, look elsewhere in the Tenderloin.
author: Jeremy C.

description:
Oh yamo. I do love what you cook but I feel like I'm always disappointed by the portion size. They only charge $7 for a bowl of noodles but it's like half the size of a regular bowl of noodles and not filling at all. And pretty greasy imo.

Yamo has a total of 6ish seats so this is a place where you order to go. I believe it's cash only too. Run by these older asian women.
author: Mimi T.

description:
Definitely super late to the punch but I'll chalk up growing up in LA as defense for coming to Yamo so late. I need this bastion of cooking way more than it needs me. It's literally listed on Google Maps as cheap eats and I feel like that doesn't betray how good it actually is.

Small and intimate, it is a restaurant that focuses solely on the thing that ultimately matters: food and your love for it. There are no TVs to watch or live entertainment, rather just the display of aptitude and skill by the people who cook here and remind me of my iron chef grandmother. 

The food is at one time incredibly complex and simple. To them its just another day and the techniques they've mastered but to me it'd something easily screwed up. 
We got the house noodles, chicken noodle soup, and tea salad. Not as big or flashy as the other burmese titans in SF but just as good if not better. Super fresh and flavorful noodles, soup, and meat. The tea salad is somewhat small but still very good and something I'd totally get again.

We came on a Sunday at 3-4 and it was empty. Such a bittersweet joy that we made it in without a wait but that so many people were missing out.
author: Charles M.

description:
WANNA KNOW WHAT TOUGH LOVE FEELS LIKE? THIS. Please walk into this hole-in-the-wall that will not leave a hole in your wallet. Leave your expectations and your dignity at the door. 

Service Situation: It was an experience like no other. I loved everything about it and I'm not sure if I can describe it. It was like walking into a kitchen where your mom, grandma and older sister were all mad at you for something you're not exactly sure. And you're hungry but because they love you, they're going to cook you whatever you want while giving you the side eye and not talk to you.

Seating Situation: 10 more or less stools at a bar. We sat at the corner and was near the beverage fridge where we literally helped ourselves to some grass jelly drink ($1). 

Ordered: Beef House Noodles(~$6). So good, so cheap and I can't complain. The portion was perfect for the price and it tasted like a home cooked meal.
author: Amy N.

description: The worst customer service!! I have never experienced service like this before. The woman taking my order was literally screaming at me because I couldn't understand her. I tried listening more carefully when she repeated the same thing but she just kept screaming more and began rolling her eyes at me. I instead left and decided to not purchase anything from here.
author: Kimberly R.

description:
Once again had a very solid experience with Yamo. We got the beef noodle bowl. Noodles were well executed. The sauce is savoury and very salty, a bit overseasoned. 

Noodles are typical yellow lomein style with a slight upgrade in condiments. Beef was tender and crispy. Cilantro balanced out the savouryness. Shaved peanuts gave the mouthfeel some depth. 

Overall a nice cheap bowl of noodles.

Service was unfriendly about us splitting a dish and didn't seem to be English -speaking.
author: Jack M.

description: YAMO! Little secret in the mission. Very small spot with limited seating and authentic tasting food
author: Lauren N.

description:
I always get chicken soup and tea salad .
Is small and crowded but I like it because has personality. The food is authentic, and cheap. Cash only but who care. 
I love when the lady ask me: what do you want?!
author: Érica T.

description:
Vegans BEWARE and Vegetarians BEWARE of this place. 

They use oyster or fish sauce in their veg curries. As soon as I asked about this, after that the lady was super rude to me. I politely asked if she could use soy sauce instead and she shouted at me NO.
