I had already ordered the samosa appetizers - they came and were very ordinary - and I didn't feel that great after. 

Stay away from this rude & mediocre establishment.
author: Shaun A.

description:
I went here last night to have dinner with a friend. We got the house noodles and the samosas. This is the most hole in the wall place I have ever been too. As we were walking to door there was a group of cops outside talking to some guy bleeding from the face. We took a seat at the bar set up. The room is just about 8 chairs lined up right against a bar. Two women were manning the counter. One of them was the cook making noodles right in front of us. The air in the room is sweltering hot. You are pretty much incased in smells of the food the entire time. I got my noodles with the tofu and it was really well done tofu. Right as I get my food a firefighter walks in and says, "hey did anyone get punch in the eye here that needs help?" The woman behind the counter replies, "no there was someone punch in the eye, but he left" Firefighter replies, "oh awesome. Okay, bye."  and walks out. Kind of awesome and horrific at the same time?

Food was amazing. Those garlic noodles are delicious. Super cheap too, every plate is around 6 bucks. Cash only though. I like the girl behind the counter. She's spunky sweet sass. 

Definitely coming back.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
Food 5/5 stars 
Service 2-3/stars

That about sums up the place, if you can deal with the old ladies yelling at you about your order for the delicious food then you have yourself a solid lunch/dinner option. 
Also the restaurant is the definition of hole in the wall and cleanliness could be better. However it reminds me of eating good food in Asia so I'm not complaining. 

All the food here is mostly under $10 and is scrumptious. 
I'd highly recommend the tea leaf salad and Yamo house noodles!
author: Sean S.

description: Well I tried the vegetable curry today & it is terrible here. The first dish I really don't like.  Tea salad still rocked. The service is still wacky. And the price is still $6.25.
author: Scott F.

description:
Don't get any of the appetizers (the tea leaf salad didn't have any actual tea leaves in it, and the samosa was overcooked and nothing special). Just go straight for what their known for which is the house noodles with beef. It looks really bland without flavor but trust me it's really tasty. The meat is also very tender and has no fat on it. If you're a guy one bowl of noodles probably won't fill you up however. Might need to head somewhere else after or order two bowls.

Pro-tip: Bring cash as this is a cash-only place.
author: Tom P.

description: Never fail.  My go-to choice is delicious house noodle with pork and tea salad.  Happy customer everytime I come out.
author: Nadia S.

description: One of my favorite places in the city to eat. It has great service though a little terse lol. Everything on the menu is under 10 and you can easily get a great lunch for 7. My favorites on the menu are the House noddles, tea leave salad (very spicy and delicious), black bean tofu, and black bean fish, but have to say I haven't tried much I didn't like here. The simple meals and environment makes this one of the best place to grab a bite with anyone.
author: Rad R.

description: Cheap and cash only. Growing up on Burmese food my whole life, I say they are legit. Better than all the fancy Burmese restaurants I've been to out here (Burma Love, Rangoon Ruby, Burma Superstar, etc). Closest it's come to spice/heat in terms of authentic Burmese cooking. The women/cooks there seem rude, but that's just the culture. I hear them speaking (Asian yelling) to each other. Lol They're talking about orders and getting food out the quickest. They're actually really sweet when they're not busy hustling to get food out.
author: Priscilla S.

description:
Extremely rude service! I was picking up a to-go order but asked them if I could take a seat till I was waiting and the lady screamed at me saying "No". She then angrily told me to wait outside instead. 

When I reached home I found that they gave me a wrong order. And the food was very average. This place does not deserve 3.5 stars. I've had much much better cheap Asian food at other places.
author: Disha S.

description: Yamo's is dope. Hidden gem in SF, just wished they were open Sundays. Noodles are cooked perfect with choice of meat. Best Tea Leaf Salad in the bay... gotta try everything on the menu atleast once. It has a bar setup with about 6-8 seats. Very enclosed, can be a wait at times but it's worth it.
author: Tedrik L.

description:
I loved the experience of Yamo. The restaurant is more a food bar with barley 7 seats. The food is made straight in front of you by a woman and what seems to be here mother. The place is always packed and has had a queue outside every time I've been. The inside is loud and bustling. If you want a drink, you're instructed to get either a bottle of water, Coke or Sprite from the fridge (no alcohol served here)! We were asked nicely if we could move seats to accommodate a group of others. The whole atmosphere feels extremely authentic.

The food was good but neither of the two meals we had ordered between us was particularly incredible. Still would come again!
author: Michael C.

description: Easily my favorite take out place - food is cheap and very tasty. About the service : hahahaha, there is no such thing as service, deal with it
author: Balu V.

description: Horrible food and even worse service. They will not answer any questions and yelled at multiple customers while I was in there. Their food made me extremely sick the next day and I will never go back. I do not recommend this place at all and don't understand how they are in business.
author: Stacie B.

description:
Incredibly HORRIBLE service. I walked in for lunch and the small place was packed. The old lady asked me if I want to eat in or to go. I asked how long the wait would be for eat in and she proceeded to yell at me. Saying "I ask you a question and you answer! Not ask me a question!" She then proceeded to continue to say bad things in cantonese which I can understand. I wanted to leave at that point really!! WHAT HORRIBLE ATTITUDE. 

The noodles took forever to make and they were nothing special. A few pieces of beef and the noodles were trenched in oil. She also threw our take outs at us and gave us a glare.

I will NEVER be back. $6 for a small bowl of noodle is not even that cheap! This is a wake up call for all the people hyping this place up. Not worth such high reviews on Yelp!
author: Hoyan L.

description: This a cozy hole in the wall for people who actually wanna eat good food with a reasonable price. Chicken noodle soup is my go to item.
author: Nima N.

description: I really loved their chicken noodle soup. It's perfect for a cold day or fighting off a cold. I'll definitely come back for it again and more dishes!
author: Elaine L.

description:
Customer Service was poor
The lady at the register didn't follow up with us and took three other people that came in after us 
When we first sat down and only took 5min. to decide what we wanted 
Once we ordered we looked over to see if our food was ready- to our dismay our order wasn't being cooked and canceled our order-  will not be back

I understand the small setting but if you're going to have an intimate small setting make sure your employees have strong customer service skills - the kitchen is right behind you, like less than a foot no need for communicating by projecting your voice a couple feet away 
Not a good environment for what was thought to be a calm meal with a bowl of warmth
author: Asmara V.

description:
a regular little place. seats 7? at a, small counter. completely no  frills place... i saw two people waiting food so i walked in,  unsure if I'm getting anything just yet.  after i walked in,  someone else walked in to sit.  another walked in also to sit.  i ordered.  someone walked in to order a take out order.  a woman walked in to sit.  another woman came in to pick up her phone in order.  two people were waiting to sit as i left.  

i bring that up because it appears this place is a neighborhood favorite.  i didn't order spring rolls but i might need to,  since it sold out as i was there.  

i was a little sad to see they removed chow fun from their menu,  as I'm poultry intolerant.  as in i could stop breathing if ingested,  so rice noodles are safer than chow mein noodles. 

i ordered the mushroom tofu. i liked the flavors. it was very well prepared.  can't complain about the food at all,  served with rice,  $6.50. what a bargain! no wonder the neighbors flock here...

i would recommend you watch how they cook your food if you have any allergy.  i didn't mention mine but next time i certainly will. the cross contamination is a possibility with the chef using the same utensils on all the orders.  at the time i was there,  2 chicken orders!  but my tofu was simmering on its own and didn't use that cooking utensil,  yikes!

I'm forever wary of new places but i think I'll be back,  as long as i tell the chef about my allergy...

i liked the food.  i just need to tell the chef.  I'll be back.  4 stars for this little hidden find!
author: cindy c.

description:
Total hole in the wall goodness. 

If you get claustrophobic this place might not be for you but they do takeout. 

Has the Yamo house noodles with pork - super tasty pork and the noodles were like garlic noodles. I added some sriracha sauce to give it some spice. 

The fish chowder noodles were like a bowl of flavorful soup with rice noodles. 

Potstickers were super plump homemade tasting potstickers. Too much cabbage for my liking but you can't turn down homemade flavor (at least it tasted like it)

I want to try the cold noodles next time and the curry!

Super tiny spot on 18th that if there's no seats you'll be waiting out on the street

Drinks are from the fridge only, including bottled water (eg no water service)

Maybe 12 seats at the counter. So you watch them cook and do everything. Is it the most spotless kitchen well maybe not but if you have major food allergies you probably shouldn't go to little spots like this. 

I think there was a sign for the restroom but I didn't venture back there. 

Cash only.
author: Traci H.

description: You wont believe this place exist tho but the FOOD is excellent...CHEAP AND TASTEFUL..i always have my togo lunch or dinner from here
author: Jaceymarie M.

description:
I was very saddened by my dinner that night. The service I can tolerate, but the amount of salt in my noodles was unacceptable. I can understand you can be rude and talk the talk when your food can walk the walk.....but no. The food was so salty that my tongue was actually numb by it. I didn't finish my food, and I ALWAYS finish my food! I tried to finish it, but my heart rate was racing from all the sodium that I had to just leave it. There was no water to be served, you must buy it. Is that even legal? 

The worst part about this whole experience was that we actually stood in line and waited 30 mins to eat this g...bage. From the outside, it had a NY feel where there are limited seats and a line out the door...I will never fall for a line again.
author: kim w.

description:
I ordered a tea leaf salad and my friend ordered a mango chicken, but I was hungry enough that we ended up ordering a second mango chicken and splitting our tea salad. The total came out to about $18, and we even had a bit left over.
 
The tea leaf salad was a smaller amount, but a good price for the ingredients - fragnant and nutty. The mango chicken was tart, but smothered over rice, it felt like California comfort food.
author: Heidi L.

description:
I used to love the food here but they've been skimping on the meat.  Now they only put a few tiny pieces of meat so it feels like you're just eating plain noodles.

Also, they don't longer let you have water, which is free from the tap, now you have to pay for bottled water.

Service has never been good, though this time there wasn't any yelling or screaming, and was relatively quiet, which was shocking.

I used to come here a lot because of the cheap food, but the crappy service gets old, skimping on the meat makes it feel like all you're eating is noodle, and not being given something as simple and free as a tiny cup of water tips it over to me not really coming back- maybe every once in a while if I'm really craving cheap noodles, but I wouldn't go out of my way to come here.  Not to mention there's rarely an open seat, and waiting for a seat when you just wanna grab something quick is annoying.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Came here on Friday night, as my husband and I were randomly walking by looking for food options  for dinner. I had been here years ago with my sister and girlfriend, however had not remembered much about the food. 

Well, the husband and I decided to give this a try. I ordered the fish chowder, and he ordered the house special noodle dish along with a side of samusas. This was better than some other Burmese spots we've been to. Both our foods came out quick as it was made to order. Overall the food was alright. We may/may not come back in the near future as there are other options around the hood' that we'd want to try.
author: Tracy C.

description: This place is an absolutely amazing, hole-in-the-wall place by 17th and Mission. The mother daughter combo cook up a storm and absurdly cheap offices. Hidden gem of the Mission!
author: Sumeru C.

description:
Their house noodle is great and almost everything is under 6$. There was a line to get in and the wait was around 20 mins for two people at 6pm. It is a tiny space which only hosts eight people. If you order just one dish, I think it is unlikely that you'll get full. So be generous with your choices :) 

Also didnt like the spring rolls. My favs were house noodle and tealeaf salad.
author: Birce G.

description:
Hey, if you're in the Mission and want a singular experience akin to meeting someone like the Soup Nazi in San Francisco, then you have to eat at Yamo! But really, the lady that people are dubbing the "Angry Asian Lady" is not very bad, so don't be scared.  As in most Asian restaurants, service is not going to be super friendly, but the food is good and inexpensive. 

And you really have to see this place to believe it. It is TINY! One counter, 10 stools and that's about it. You can see all the kitchen action from your seat! There is a refrigerator at the end of the counter with water and sodas, so help yourself with the water/soda and that will be added to your bill. 

We both ordered the House Noodle dish, with pork as my protein of choice and beef for the hubby. We also ordered the egg roll which was just okay. I wouldn't order that next time. It's a little greasy and could be tastier. We both liked the house noodle dish though. The noodles were nicely cooked and garnished with scallions, fried garlic and cilantro. The bits of pork were tasty but it wasn't very much. The hubby liked the bits of beef on top of his noodles too. If you have a big appetite, definitely order something else other than the noodles. A bowl of it may not be enough to alleviate your hunger, and with most dishes priced at $6, one can certainly afford another dish. Just make sure you have enough cash. They only accept CASH! 

When we left the restaurant, there were lots of  people outside waiting for seats and waiting for their to go orders. Popular place! If we're in the Mission again and are craving Asian noodles and we happen to have cash in our wallets, maybe we'll eat here again. Perhaps I'll try their Tea Leaf salad next time and more of those noodles!
author: Hazel C.

description:
The restaurant is very dirty with rats... One of the people there is very rude, she disrespects us with no reason. She used her language to say something bad about us... The service need to be improved.
Wayyyy to overrated.  They don't even deserve a star ... I'm so sorry for her ... She is the fat one there and so mean.
author: Penny L.

description:
I'm all for awesome hole-in-the-wall spots.  I can overlook indifferent to bad service for amazing food.  This place couldn't deliver on almost any of its promises.

After waiting 30 minutes on a Tuesday at 8:30pm for two seats at the bar, we had pretty high hopes.  The restaurant doesn't look or smell clean, and you'll definitely walk out reeking of cooking oil....but that can all be forgiven for an amazing meal.  This was not an amazing meal.  

We started with the tea leaf salad, which was quite good.  It's certainly very different than the Westernized versions you'll get at Burma Superstar and others, but not in a bad way.  I'd eat either style for different reasons and be happy.  HOWEVER, our main course is where it fell apart.

I ordered the house noodles with pork.  My boyfriend ordered the same, but with beef.  I was served a bowl with chicken.  Then, this real conversation happened:

Me: "Oh, excuse me, I think maybe I got someone else's order?  This is a chicken bowl; I ordered the pork."
Grumpy Waitress/Cook: "Oh ok."
*PAUSE*
Grumpy Waitress/Cook: "No pork.  Eat."
Me: "Um, no I think this is chicken."
*WAITRESS WALKS AWAY*

So, I proceed to try it.  My boyfriend proceeded to try it.  It's chicken.  Like, no question.  She refused to come back over and speak to us, so I decided to just eat it - I mean, it's wrong ok, but how bad could the dish be?  Bad.  It was just so, so bad.  

The couple next to me ordered this dish and there was sauce and good stuff coating the noodles and pooling at the bottom of their bowls when they were done.  Mine had literally none of that.  My boyfriend's had some, but not nearly so much.  My bowl was literally just gummy, very starchy-tasting noodles, a few green onions, and a handful of WAY over-salted pieces of chicken (maybe a chicken thigh-worth).  I ate the chicken and left the rest.

I definitely won't come back here.  It's one thing to mess up an order - but then to refuse to correct it.  No.
author: Tay H.

description:
Yamo is a "quick-fix" Burmese eatery with a limited menu, almost the opposite of Zagat-rated Burmese restaurants in the area like Mandalay and Burma Superstar. It's small, cramped, family-owned, not very sanitary, has an open kitchen, offers simple comfort food, and everything on the menu is under $10. Yamo fits all the criteria of a "hole in the wall". 

If you're lucky to find an empty spot on the 8 seat counter, go hang up your backpack on the wall, take a seat on the bar stool, read the sticky menu, and better order within a minute or else you will get on the bad side of Yamo's impatient waitstaff. Between three people, we shared the samusa, tea leaf salad, and a Yamo chicken house noodle. That's not enough food for a real meal here, so we got scolded by the waitress. If only she knew we chose to eat light because we had a dinner reservation 3 hours later...

The samusas were generic, they reminded me of deep fried hot pockets stuffed with a mild meat filling. Based on its texture, the samuas was definitely a frozen food product and not homemade. The supplied dipping sauce was the sweet and sour type that accompanies egg rolls. 

Tea leaf salad (lahpet thoke) was not very memorable. Actually, it tasted even worse than the ones I've eaten at Burmese restaurants in LA. Yamo's salad was overall crunchy which I found satisfying but the flavors were very very mellow. It sorely lacked the pungent and bittersweet flavors that I expected from mixing fermented tea leaves with other ingredients in the salad, which is what makes this Burmese salad so unique. Instead, the salad tasted sweet and garlicky more than anything else.

Finally, Yamo's house noodle was simplistic and ordinary, yet almost everyone else in this hole in the wall had a bowl in front of them. Egg noodles were boiled in some oily broth, then batched drained, served with some pan fried boneless chicken, peanuts, and green onions. What's so special about it? What's Burmese about it? Even after the chef drained the oil, the bowl of noodles was still a grease bomb. Not worth the $6.

As others have already mentioned, you won't find service here. The three ladies who prepare your meal are not very friendly, so it's best to eat fast and get out ASAP. The chefs appear to speak Taishanese, a Cantonese dialect, to each other and joke around. Well, the damage was $19 for this disappointing meal. Not worth it for the snack-size portions and uninspiring flavors, not worth a detour to come here. I would only recommend this place as a cheap introduction to Burmese food.
author: Felix L.

description:
3.5 stars for food. Tea leaf salad was perfectly delicious but for $6, I got what was a $3 portion. Grumble grumble but okay... 

The fish chowder portion size is generous but served lukewarm.... okay.... :-/

But what really turned me off was the service. Ugh... the two ladies serving me were so rude and told me I couldn't take pictures (of my food ... really???). I also had to run out to pick up cash (yeah I was that person, my bad) and the lady shouted at me: No I will not watch your things! (Did I even ask you?)

Yeah -- definitely not a great customer service experience if you're about that but hey it's cheap, it's decently good.
author: Cindy W.

description:
This place could not be worse. The lady who does the cooking / greeting is EXTREMELY rude; it's unreal. Something straight out of kitchen nightmares.

And it's not one of those places where the food makes up for it in any way. The tea salad was so heavily drenched in dressing, and the flavor was like some cheap sweet and sour sauce from Safeway. The mixed vegetables and stir fried noodles were almost as bad, and VERY oily.

I live for places like this - the holes in the wall that have been around forever, and are known for their authenticity. But I recommend staying away from this place at all costs!
author: Jessica C.

description: I LOVE YAMO! You better know what you're getting when you order to-go, and be there when it's time to pick up! There is limited seating, but it's so worth it.
author: Bonnie E.

description:
Bad food, unhygienic, and rudest staff. If you want Burmese food, go somewhere else. This is San Francisco, and there are plenty other choices, don't feed your money to this place. 

Unhygienic: the ladies use her bare hands to deal with money notes (at the cashier, with receipts and changes) then turned to put RAW food (including raw meat and raw salad) to the bowl so the chef can cook them. For godsake, this restaurant needs to get inspected by the city/govt!!!

Service: I understand you have a different expectations in terms of service while going to some Chinese restaurants, but this is just plain rude. I'm not only talking yelling, and being crude, they talked shit behind me and my boyfriend's back when we walked into the restaurant (they were talking in Cantonese) and gave us the biggest up-and-down look. I'm sorry, you can be crude, but commenting about the guests thinking they don't understand? That's a whole new level.

Food: super cheap, but you are paying for MSGs and salt, period. I ordered 90% of the menu and honestly this is an insult to Burmese cuisine. Everything was salty, and the ingredients were defo not fresh. Portion was not decent at all. 

Save yourself some time. Never left such a place feeling so angry.
author: Connie T.

description: I love this place. It is just... delicious. Hands down.
author: Anthony G.

description:
My Number One restaurant in SF. The place I recommend to all my friends & family if they're visiting SF. It's a true city experience.1600+ reviews really tells all. I'm not going to add to the noise, so take in my short, but sweet review. 

Order: Beef house noodle, tea leaf salad, samusas, and curry prawn. 

Why Go? The only place in the nation, at least from the places I've traveled to, where the workers speak 3 different dialects yet move like a symphony. You'll hear Burmese, Mandarin, and Cantonese all being thrown out to push orders out the door. The space allows for 11, all counter seats, as you watch the 4 women work head to toe and yakking at customers that order too slow or eat too slowly. You're almost guaranteed to wait at all peak hours, but people know to hustle so 25 minutes is the max. 

And....It's cheap, and just damn delicious.
author: Jocelyn C.

description:
The garlic chicken noodles and the tea leaf salad was bomb diggity. 

Not only the price is very inexpensive, the portion was good, and the taste was extraordinary!

I was addicted to the garlic chicken noodles that I seriously had it once a week for 8 consecutive weeks!

Unfortunately, parking sucks here ( the meter was ridiculous expensive around here), and the location is insanely small. To really enjoy your experience, order to go and enjoy eating in comfort!

Can't wait to eat the garlic chicken noodles again!!
author: Josie H.

description: Great food for a great price. I got the stir-fry with rice and it was just $6. Really great when you're on a budget. Serving size is pretty large, definitely left satisfied. I recommend this place to all my friends and can't wait to go back.
author: Nicole M.

description: I spent $6 on garlic noodles. I spent another $6 on a tea leaf salad. I left completely full, satisfied, and the whole process took ~20 minutes. This place is all business, so don't go here if you want to linger. It's for eating, and eating good, then moving on with your day. Would recommend it for 1-2 people, more than that is going to mean a hefty wait because there are only a dozen seats. But if you can't sit, you can always order to go.
author: Charlie R.

description:
New favorite take out spot in the Mission that won't break the bank!
Found Yamo while my fiance and I were out drinking in the Mission and wanted some delicious food to soak it all up.  Yamo had some vegetarian/vegan options so we decided to do some take out to share.  Walking up, this place is smalllll, a total hole in the wall with maybe 8 seats at the counter and always a line out the door (a good sign).  The menu is printed outside and the ladies workin here are quick to get your order and greet you with a smile. I like that you can watch what is goin on while you're food is being made and its a little entertaining while you wait. 
We grabbed the following to share for dinner: vegetarian spring rolls (4.50), vegetarian samusas (4.50), tea salad (6.25), and house noodles (6.25). Everything was made in about 10 minutes and for under $25 for a solid dinner in the Mission that ain't too bad. The dishes aren't huge, but for the price I think they are perfect. Everything was super flavorful without being greasy or heavy like a lot noodles are at times. Totally a place I'll be back to and make sure to grab a seat at the counter next time!
author: Kelsey B.

description: Great for takeout.  Blink and you'll miss it, but it is worth your time.  We had noodles and tea salad, and it made for a fantastic lunch.  Not the fanciest but Quick and Easy.
author: Sara M.

description:
BEWARE of an Asian place that no Asians eat at!!!

The food is not good and that's the bottom line. I got the Yamo House Noodles w/Beef. They should rename it "Noodles from a box with beef jerky on top." The noodles were overly cooked and mushy and cup o' noodles that were drained and stir fried would have tasted better. The beef it came with could be compared to 5 tiny pieces of beef jerky. Just not good.......

Cherry on top? Expect 0 customer service. The ladies working there must hate life or something because they are pretty much rude to everyone that steps into that place. I am used to bad service in Asian restaurants, but Yamo takes it to a whole other level. They pretty much not only hate you, each other, they hate life in general.

You should pass on Yamo.
author: Jennifer T.

description:
Food = yummy greasy noodles and a great little condiment plate. 
Tea leaf salad = rivals fancy spots

Affordability is through the roof

Don't go at peak hours or you wait and it's kinda silly.

Service = Shitttttttty

The main queen bee is a grumpy ass hole. Think soup nazi but not as cute.

Other than that I say go, it's solid and simple and affordable
author: Sharon S.

description:
I'll keep this review nice and short! 

Pretty tasty food at a very affordable price-- in San Francisco, finding a good dine-in meal at $6.25 is almost nonexistant. You order while you wait in line and are served your food right as you sit. It's a very small restaurant so you eat for about 15 minutes then you get out. Simple as that. No pictures of the kitchen are allowed since it is quite dirty and unkempt, however it is quite the experience! Ps: No tax on the bill!! 

Chicken Noodle Soup ($6.25): 7.5/10
Beef House Noodles ($6.25): 7/10
author: Emily L.

description:
Waited about 15 minutes for our food which I think was pretty good considering there were 4 people ahead of me and I had ordered 4 different items (6 orders altogether). We got the yamo beef house noodles, the chicken noodle soup, the catfish chowder with noodles, and tofu and mushroom. The house noodles and chicken noodle soup were both really good. The catfish noodles I would say I still prefer mohinga as the broth wasn't as flavorful as when I got it last time. The tofu and mushroom is alright, you can probably get those at any other Chinese restaurant.
Food is extremely affordable as dishes are average $6 each. Perfect for broke college students like me though it was a little hard finding parking.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
I live in the neighborhood and a regular here. Yamo's is a bit polarizing with 1 star and 5 star reviews and I agree with both sides. But I think expectations should be set before coming here. 

1. If you're easily offended by rude service, this is not the place for you. The ladies are plain rude. I see some people refer to them as "sassy" and I think that's the absolute nicest way to put it. It's somewhat endearing in a way you uncomfortably laugh at racist jokes at a comedy show but to be frank, they are just rude. I don't even understand Cantonese and I know they were trash talking the customers. Don't expect small talk or really any conversation, if you get your food without them throwing it in your face, you're good. 

2. So cheap. My go to is mango chicken and it's $6.50 cash only (includes tax). 

3. Cuisine is mostly chinese. I see some Burmese items on the menu.. like the tea salad is tasty and a great value, but to me the rest of the menu seems like a mix of Chinese style dishes. 

4. It's a hole in the wall with 8 or so bar stools. First come, first serve. Can get smoky inside, space is small and woks usage is abundant. 

There really is no other restaurant like this in this neighborhood, especially in this price range. They are small business owners putting out good food at a good price and I respect that. The rudeness is not an issue for me whatsoever. Take out is also extremely popular and what we typically do now. Food comes out in under 10 minutes.
author: Leslie W.

description:
Was it 5 stars? I don't know. Was the tea leaf salad good? NO. Was it better than Burma Superstar? ... no.

So why am I giving this place 4 stars? Well ... for starters they have killer house noodles. Yes I would come here, brave lines and nasty old Asian ladies (and by nasty I mean attitude ...) for the house noodles. Actually I'd just get them to go, same thing, but still ... these house noodles are DEEEELICIOUS. A++++++++++++

Everything else was subpar, as was their complaining in Chinese about their next door neighbor who was white who likes Italian food. Yeah, I understood that. #ChineseYo.

Come here for the house noodles, skip everything else, leave happy. Bring cash.
author: Lorrie M.

description:
Food was good. Service was so terrible all I can say is do not come here if you understand Chinese or Cantonese lol. Unfortunately I do and I know what one of the owner was saying about everyone... like: I don't want to serve them, why did they order this, crazy people , etc.. she was really angry I was not sure why... my boyfriend does not understand Chinese so he was happily unaware and liked the food and tipped. 

Also usually I like hole in wall places which Is why I went in the first place, I understand tiny places get really busy, and the prices are so low I wouldn't expect any services. But going to a restaurant and being sweared at is something completely different.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I ate at Yamo twice. If I could give it a negative star, I would. 

Customer service. (-10)/5 star
Food.  2/5 star
Environment 1/5 star

At the first time, my frds and I decide to give Yamo a try because we saw the 4 star reviews 1500+. It can't be bad right? We were unpleasantly surprised by the small and smelly restaurant. The food was okay. We didn't think it was 4 star quality at all because the food was greasy and small in portion. 

As a well-traveled and well-educated foodie, I can only give it a maximum 2 star if you ask me. 
I think yelpers rate it higher than it should, probably because the food is cheap and they are surprised by the food made by two old burmese ladies working in a shitty-looking dump hole. 

Today in the afternoon, I was running errands in the mission district. I walked by Yamo and ordered takeout before I drove back to my studio. 

I was completely pissed off and upset about the customer service there. 

Originally I wanted to order curry chicken with noodles, but after 10 seconds, I changed my mind and ordered black bean fish with rice, before they started cooking anything.

The burmese lady with short gray hair was talking shit about me in burmese.  "Do you think he is chinese or taiwanese?" " He must be taiwanese because he was so annoying and troublesome." Shit talk went on.

I was completely shocked by how rude she was. Did I do something wrong? Did I do something unforgivable that she had to insult my ethnical background in Burmese? It was funny. They kept talking shit about customers because they thought I didn't understand their dialogue. 

I patiently waited outside Yamo for my food. When she was handing my takeout, I told her quietly,  "I actually understood what you said earlier. It was very rude." She rolled her eyes and gave me an offensive hand gesture. 
A middle-aged white customer asked me what happened. I told him briefly about what I heard and experienced from the burmese ladies.

The customer service was highly unprofessional, disrespectful and unbelievable. In the end, I was proud of myself confronting her in a polite manner. 

Food is supposed to bring happiness to people, not upset them. 

Never coming again.
author: Jay J.

description:
We came on a Saturday around 6pm and didn't have to wait long. Lots of people order to go and then stand around near the entrance, which confuses newcomers since we think they are waiting for a spot. Just walk right in and grab a spot if it's open. 

For the first few minutes while we were seated, we just watched the youngest worker shouting at people over the phone and furiously taking down to-go orders. We were too hungry to wait any longer so we flagged her down and put in our order. 

tea leaf salad - I can't get enough of it and I feel like I can eat it all day.
house noodles - quite tasty
mango chicken - also tasty

Prices here include taxes and are super low. The service here is rough..., but at least it was fast. This was an eye opening experience and I'm glad we tried it.
author: Edward W.

description:
You are the audience and part of the kitchen. 

The restaurant title is clear visible. 

$6.25 for most entrées.  

You can't eat here more than twice a year. It's that good.
author: J L.

description: Quick, friendly and inexpensive Burmese food. Sit and the counter and grab a bite. It's super good!
author: Valerie I.

description: Dude. Salted to death. Tiniest portions of meat. Laughably terrible service. Go here if you're a hipster and you think it's cool paying money to be treated like shit.
author: Brandileigha S.

description:
Stopped here on my way home from an exercise class because I had been reading reviews about it the other day. As other people have said, it's super small inside and is a literal hole in the wall. I got takeout, so I walked inside to order and then was asked to wait outside while they made it. It took maybe 15 minutes and I was a little chilly so I was kind of standing half inside and looking at everyone else's food, getting excited.

I got the house noodles with beef and a mango salad. Mango salad was AWESOME! Crunchy and sweet and salty and a little sour. Hit all of the right notes and had a great balance of flavors. I don't normally get excited for salads, but this one was very tasty. The noodles were also good. Very simple, just handmade noodles with garlic and a few pieces of beef. I LOVE me a solid bowl of noodles and can really eat them plain, which was good because the beef was a bit sparse. In my head I was envisioning the big beef chunks found in beef noodle soup, but these were smaller pieces of salty beef. I liked them, but I recognized that they could be too salty for the less salt-tolerant. Definitely give the noodles a good mix to make sure everything gets all over the noodles though!

Not for people who don't like cilantro and can't handle moderate levels of salt, but I loved it and you can't beat the prices. Will definitely be back!
author: Christine U.

description:
Wow! Their health inspection is 85/100? 

I'm so surprised and oddly, happy to see that. I think Yamo's food is great...but I can't eat it that often. This is the kind of "restaurant" (...if you can call the 10-seated bar that?) that I could never take my parents to, or if I did, they'd think it's some kind of millennial experience. The food is pretty greasy, and sometimes when I think too much about the space and the cleanliness (or lack there of), I start getting nervous. 

The ladies working here don't take any BS, and want you to get in, order, eat, and get out. The portion sizes are quite small, however the food is so cheap that you can order 2 dishes and not feel bad about it. 

A surprising favorite was the chicken curry noodle soup.
author: Liz Y.

description:
So glad I finally got to try this place. Small, definitely your "HOLE IN THE WALL", about 10 seats at the counter. As I was dining, I notice they mostly do take outs. FYI, if you expect good services, don't come here. Don't complain, they really don't care. I didn't think services is awful, well at least not to me. She smile once at me. They do charge you for everything when it's to go. Don't expect anything free here and it's CASH ONLY.  I wish I lived close by, it would be my go to restaurant. 

Food is YUMMY and you can't beat the price. Smaller portions but who needs super big ones anyways. Better for the waist. haha And you can try more things. I prefer more varieties anyways. "ASIA" style and I love it. 

**Potstickers are filled with pork, cabbage, and carrots. My friend was so amaze by them. Very soft and juicy on the inside. Not crispy, just a little to add in some texture. 
** Tea Salad are made with tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds. - Super small dish but love the flavors. It was really good but I think way too much onions. If you want more for the money, the other two salads are bigger in portion. 
** Yamo House Noodles made with noodles mixed with fried garlic, and a choice of meat. I got the BEEF. My favorite dish. It's like garlic noodles topped with beef for a good price. So YUMMY! I can eat that everyday. 
**Yamo Cold Noodles made with cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken. - FYI its not really cold noodle. Because they stir fry the chicken and veggies and place it on top of the noodles. Therefore making the noodles warm. I know but its so good. The sauce they use is amazing. And I notice lots of people do order that for take out.

I'm coming back for sure and try everything else. Everything I had was DELICIOUS! Drinks are like self serve, bottles and cans. $1.50 each. There can be a wait but not too bad because mostly everyone orders take out. It's hot inside and I went yesterday when it was 85 degrees at 730pm. I sat by the door but still hot. Can't wait to come back.
author: Sandy B.

description: The best Burmese food but be ready to leave your dignity behind before entering their door. It's like North Korea in there, no taking pictures, no follow up questions allowed.
author: Jomilyn T.

description: Fxxking bitch was rude AF, treats customer like shit. Food is ok. Will not go back again.
author: Yue L.

description:
4 stars, mainly because I'm really confused on how I'm supposed to feel after leaving. Let me explain.

I love the hole in the wall atmosphere. This place is maybe 6 feet wide and 15 feet deep, only able to sit 9 people on a bartop. I walked up to Yamo and tried to take a picture. Immediately I get snapped at by one of the employees, yelling "NO PICTURES!". I looked at my girlfriend and she just laughed (she used to be a regular here). From the minute I tried taking the picture, to the minute I left, that same employee just stared daggers at me. To be honest, I thought it was kind of entertaining, especially knowing how old, foregin asian women can be sometimes. Also, it's a hole in the wall... you should expect weird, quirky behavior, right? (This is me justifying why they are so angry).

Then we order and the food comes out - delicious! Noodles, curry, apps... you can't go wrong here. Love me some cheap asian food. 

But then, as I was eating, I kept thinking to myself, "eat faster, people are waiting". So I then start shoving the food in my mouth and swallowing without even chewing. Again, girlfriend just laughs.

So you see why I was so confused. Food - great. Atmosphere - confusing. Service - confusing. Let's just say that when you come here, expect the unexpected. Except for the food, cause that was really good.
author: Stephen L.

description:
Honestly I completely don't understand the high rating for this tiny dirty place at all! First I walked in and immediately felt unwelcomed by the rude owner lady's greeting, or a lack thereof. I would walk right out if it wasn't for the great Yelp review, because the place is oh so tiny and cramped. Don't get me wrong I would never refuse to eat at a small place as long as food is good. Well, this place offers nothing good including the food. 

I mean what place serves NO WATER first of all. You would have to purchase a bottle of water if you are thirsty. 

Food: I'll keep it simple. The house noodle dish that everyone seems to be raving about for some odd unknown reason, there is absolutely nothing special about it. It's just thick starchy noodle over-flavored with sugary soy sauce or fish sauce. They put very minimal amount of meat, probably about 7 tiny pieces at top.

I was starving when I came in, but left still hungry because I didn't even finish the dish. 

I guess if you are looking for a very cheap meal and love unhealthy carb saturated with oil and sauce, don't care about super rude services and dirty atmosphere, then this place would be perfect. But if you actually care about quality of food, do not waste your time. 

I would never ever come back here again. One of the worst in the city over all.
author: Cartman P.

description: This lady treat's me like shit, but dammit I still eat here. This food is some of the best hands down. Ive had it all here.
author: Jon J.

description: To be honest, the noodles here are cheap and tasty but the servers have consistently been abrupt and nasty, whether intentional or not. I hate to detract based on someone having a bad day, but after witnessing it each of the three times I've come here over the past two months I feel compelled to adjust this review.
author: Michael S.

description:
Honestly I was a bit underwhelmed by Yamo. 

Yamo is the definition of a hole in the wall. Stepping in takes you instantly to the bar with a handful of bar stools opposite the kitchen where two cooks take orders and cook away. As many reviews note, this isn't really the place to go if you want fine dining or exceptional service. Odds are that your order will be taken by an expressionless cook who'll give you snappy, terse replies. 

That said, I came to Yamo for the food, and just the food. My expectations for the food were a teensy bit high based on most Yelp reviewers loving it, and the line that forms through the door within 15 minutes of opening. The menu isn't huge, but it has a fair selection of appetizers and entrees. Everything is affordable, averaging around $6-7. I opted for the simple veggie stir fry with rice and split an order or spring rolls with a friend. Our food didn't take too long to come out, but it wasn't exceptionally fast either. Both my entree and spring rolls were absolutely average. Maybe the meat options are better? My friend seemed to enjoy her mango dish. 

Anyway, Yamo isn't really a place I'd go out of my way for, or wait in line for. But it isn't terrible, and it is by no means expensive. It's just average.
author: Umeet S.

description:
The real travesty is that even after all the times I've been to Yamo, I never gave this hole-in-the-wall the proper review. But I'm glad it's not too late.

Yamo is one of those unique food shops in the Mission district that give you that wonderful street food vibe. Right when you walk in you will feel like you've been transported out of California and into Asia. The claustrophobic environment where you only have 10 seats on a counter, the humidity in the air along with the high temperatures, and the "friendly" ladies who make your food all make up this wonderful experience in the middle of San Francisco.

I understand that some people might not like Yamo. You may have crossed the cooks at the wrong time or you aren't into the whole idea of waiting to sit at the counter. But if you're willing to open your senses to a different eating experience, Yamo is for you.

Food 
Contrary to what a lot of people say, the food at Yamo is amazing in every right. 

House Special Noodle: 5/5
For 6$, you will NOT be able to find a noodle dish so simple yet so tasty. I actually dare you to bring me an equivalent. Though the portion size is small, every bite is filled with garlicky goodness. I can eat this every day of my life.

Tea Leaf Salad: 3.5/5
Tea leaf salad here is a lot different than what you would expect. Please don't come here thinking you're gonna get some Burma Superstar dish; if you haven't noticed, Yamo isn't that type of "restaurant." The tea leaf salad is much simpler here. In fact it reminds me of Vietnamese Goi. It's not bad, but don't get your hopes up; it won't "blow your mind" because it isn't supposed to be something that does. It's a nice compliment to any meal. It's not something you get as a standalone.

Mango Leaf Salad: 4/5
This one actually resembles more of the Viet salad I eat at home. It's a lot spicier so beware. I do prefer it over the tea leaf salad because of the extra ingredients and the extra kick. Like the tea leaf salad, this is supposed to go hand in hand with another dish.

Cold Noodle: 5/5
Another steal! Who knew that eating cold noodles would actually taste great? Well Yamo knows how to do it right. Be aware that it is kinda spicy for those who don't have a tolerance. Id get the house noodle over this, but this still deserves great praise. 


Atmosphere 
The environment at Yamo is unforgettable. I get why people may think that the cooks are cranky all the time, but really? When you're working all day and night in a small room, it's very hard to stay positive. Trust me, I've gone on days where the ladies are sweethearts and have come on days where they seemed pissed off. But that's the type of service you'll get at any food location. 

I'm the type of person who doesn't mind sitting closely with strangers in a tight location. Yamo is that one place where you get in. Talk to some people while you wait, and get out. It's like a transaction with random surprises here and there. 

Oh yah, the ladies will try to get you in and out as soon as possible too. This is very helpful to customers since it can get cramped and people are always busy. 

Location
Place is on 18th and Mission right across from the Asian supermarket. You'll miss it if you walk too fast. Yamo just creeps up on you.
author: Bryan W.

description:
Amazing food (chicken noodle soup especially!), cheapest prices for Burmese you'll find, and the place a warm and calm vibe.

Yes, the ladies may be a bit brash and there may be a wait since there's only 10 seats, but that adds to the charm. It's an experience you won't get most other places. Relish in it and appreciate the great food.
author: C B.

description:
You know how certain establishments have developed certain themes? Hipster, luxurious, casual, romantic, etc. Yamo has fully embraced the theme of Rage. 

This thematic rage centers around the owner, who is an angry asian lady with a perma-furrow between her eyebrows and a sharp berating voice. You can quickly separate the crowd dining in: those who did not grow up in an asian household with looks of terrified confusion on their faces and those who don't bat an eye because they were raised by a doppleganger in the form of an angry tiger mother. 

Despite the dinginess of the cramped space and the uninterrupted din of an angry asian lady taking orders over the phone ("WHAT DO YOU WANT?!"), the food is a bang for the buck. Delicious noodles at ridiculously cheap prices. My go to order is the house noodles with pork (chewy bouncy noodles, crispy roasted garlic, fresh generous cilantro), a tea salad (watch that spice), and a grass jelly drink to wash down the dryness of the food. 

Make sure you stop at an ATM on the way - cash only. 

And 10 points if you can catch a rare chuckle or smile from Lady Rage herself before she remembers she's fury incarnate and puts her mask of anger back on.
author: Jenni H.

description:
Here are the things for which you don't go to Yamo:

* spotlessness (the counter was dirty, and so were our paper placemats)
* ambiance (there are eight counter seats total and you will have to squeeze your body between them and the bare wall to get inside)
* frills (small menu, no alcohol, no so-called "service with a smile")

Here are the things for which you do go to Yamo:

* cheap food ($4-8 per menu item, exclusive of drinks)
* delicious food (including freshly-cooked, freshly-chopped fresh produce and meat)
* no, DELICIOUS food (including noodles of various thicknesses tossed with said fresh produce and topped with savory meats and flavorful sauces and fresh garnishes)
* efficient attention (my water glass was constantly filled immediately, and for being cooked up literally right before my very eyes, it didn't take long to be fed)
* did I mention that you just don't underestimate the amazing food!?

I saw an informative and glowing write-up on Yamo in the paper this week, and knew exactly what kind of experience to expect: an awesome one. I don't need frills. I don't need you to remember my soda order, especially when you bring me endless free water. I don't need a "smile" or any kindnesses or creature comforts. I need food that makes me weep inside at its perfection, and I need it to be unpretentious in price and execution, and I need it to exist long before I got there, long after I leave, and to give exactly zero forks as to whether I was ever there at all. This is Yamo. Little joints like this are my life, and if I could give them a basket of stars every day, I would. 

Please don't let the three stars of my review mislead or misguide you. Please. It wouldn't be fair for me to write an inaccurately-starred review, and after all, Yamo has its shortcomings in a traditional sort of scale. Think of my three stars as a way of letting you know that you need to go into Yamo prepared, fully aware of the kind of experience you're about to have, and that if you anchor your expectations appropriately, you'll have an unbelievable taste adventure. Like me, you'll probably be glad that it's the kind of place where you can drink noodle sauce right from the bowl (or you'll be glad that you don't care about manners when the payoff is so tasty). Or just get take-out and bring Yamo somewhere more highfalutin. 

I got #15 (Yamo house special hot-as-in-temperature noodles with pork) and #17 (chicken chow mein). The pork was ridiculous, so perfectly cooked with its slightly-crispy edges and its heady marinade aroma and its prolific appearance throughout my soba-thick noodles. #15 was garnished with crushed peanuts and chopped cilantro, and the slender slices of cooked green onion were beautiful as well as tasty against the thick sauce. #17 was appropriately-oiled, resplendent with half-mushrooms, carrots, and bok choy. The chicken was soft, in contrast to the pork, which had some appropriate tooth, and the chow mein noodles were spaghetti-thick. These were goodly-sized portions and yet not a speck of food remained behind on my dishware. Nothing about the food here feels superfluous; not one element traveled over the barrier of necessity. As in, let's reiterate that I cleaned my PLATES.

One thing that was atmospherically intriguing about Yamo was that the ceiling was high and the pendant lights were low to the counter, making the steamy, griddle-smoky space between them seem infinite. An observation born from being drunk on noodles? Possibly. Possibly. Or, more likely, a brief and touching communion with the noodly infinite.
author: Austin J. A.

description:
Yamo is probably one of my favourite discoveries living in the Mission. It's the definition of hole in the wall. I honestly passed by it three or four times without realizing it was a restaurant. It's directly across from the Duc Loi Supermarket.

For about $6.50 plus tax, you can get a tasty meal that is very filling. I've tried multiple rice and noodle dishes, and haven't had a complaint about any.

I have not tried to get a seat inside, as there's usually a lineup and only 5 or so seats inside. Instead, you just step inside of the door and tell one of the ladies cooking what you want to order. Then you wait outside and they'll shout through the window/door when it's ready. Cash only.
author: Rajeev S.

description:
I get that it's a dive, and that it's cheap, but there are still some fundamentals that you can't ignore. Like salt. 

Was really excited to finally try Yamo out for myself but left feeling pretty disappointed. The curry beef noodle was incredibly bland. I never thought I would ever describe a curry as being bland but it lacked spice, heat, and even salt. It's also a pretty greasy dish to boot so overall a letdown. The samosas were ok but forgettable. Like before, they lacked salt and spice but at least they were crispy. My friend had the house noodles and while they weren't the complete failure that my curry noodles were, they still left much to be desired flavor wise.  

Not completely giving up on Yamo but doubt I'll be in a hurry to rush back. I get the overall hype for the price and hipster-dive appeal but flavor trumps both in my opinion and it begins with salt.
author: Jon L.

description:
YAMO IS YUM-O! Hehe, had to do it. Stopped by last night based on a friend's recommendation. Really delicious - asian comfort food at its best. I don't have much to add other than to highlight that it's cash-only, definitely order the house noodle (small portion, I ended up splitting another order with said friend) + tea leaf salad, and expect to wait as this place is teeny tiny. 

P.S. The picture on the back of the menu is the most adorable. Look for it! ;)
author: Corrina S.

description:
This was definitely one of the cheapest eateries I've tried in the city so far. It is a TINY hole in the wall with very few seating. Cash only as well.

On the up side, food comes out fast especially if you order takeaway. My bf and I ordered the garlic noodles w/ chicken and mango chicken. The noodles were definitely the winner. The dish was really tasty and a decent portion for $6. My only slight complaint might be that it's also very oily.

The mango chicken was decent too, but way too spicy and we weren't expecting it. I wish they made a note of how intense the spice is for that dish. It was pretty average overall and also pretty oily.

Overall I'd definitely like to return to sit in and try some of the noodle soups they have. It was a bit harder to order than with take out.
author: Sophia H.

description:
Tiny, hole-in-wall place where you squeeze in, they whisk dishes away to signal for you to eat faster and 15 mins later you squeeze out.

Not as high quality food as the other famous Burmese restaurants in SF, but it's only $6 per dish. I also like that they have grass jelly drink!


---- DISHES ----

Tea Leaf Salad: 2.5 stars
Definitely not as good as Burma Love, Superstar. The good places use a concentrated tea leaf paste chock full of umami, this one was a watery tangy spicy sauce that missed the mark for me.

Fish Noodle Soup: 4.5 stars
(Mohinga curry) Comforting home cooked food.

Black Bean Fish: 3.5 stars
Pretty standard similar to Chinese restaurants, comforting. Would eat if ill.

Vegetable Curry: 3 stars
Bland but nice cardamom spice flavour. Good selection of veggies from zucchini to eggplant, mushroom okra cabbage broccoli carrot and green beans.

Cold Noodles: 3.5 stars
Spicy.
author: Letitia L.

description: Came in with a friend's recommendation. I had already heard about the service being bad, im not much of a stickler when it comes to service. Definitely some of the worst service ive ever had dining out. But for a $6 noodle bowl, i could care less.......I can bypass service when the food is good, this wasnt the case. Crappy service, bland food, & uncomfortable bar-style seating, i wouldve been better off with an instant ramen cup
author: Yokasta P.

description:
Great tasting dishes, simple from the outside but packed with strong great flavors. Thy have the restaurant I wish I would have in life :) 
I like this place so much I wish it would not be popular
author: Javier L.

description: Cheap food, sign me up! We came on a Thursday night so there was a bit of a wait but we talked to our line neighbors and I definitely felt like I was in SF with all the quirky characters around.  As is mentioned in all the reviews, they are not friendly here, we got shooed for talking too much during our meal, but that is part of the ambiance and what can you expect for a place that only seats 6 people at a time. I enjoyed my house noodles- tasted home made and delicious. The tea leaf salad was very very spicy but enjoyable. I would definitely come back. Cash only!
author: Vivian D.

description:
The Yamo Cold Noodles and Fish Chowder Noodle Soup had visually stimulating color palette and great flavor! The fish chowder could have used a little more fish, because I was fishing for fish the whole time, but I really liked the broth! The people who were eating Garlic Noodles next to me made me want to get that next time. The ladies who run this place may seem stand-offish to others, but once you get over that, it's just a bit hilarious the wacky things they say and do. 

Customer next to me: " Can I have another plate to share this bowl of food?" 
Yamo lady: "No, you already have bowl."

Yamo lady *cutting carrots with her back to me*
Me *taking pictures of my surroundings*
Yamo lady without turning "No pictures."

Customer 2: "Can I have some water."
Yamo lady: "No water, only bottled water, $2."
author: Shelley C.

description:
When I came here, I went in knowing that it was a small, hole-in-the-wall place, known for its angry, old chefs/owners, unclean kitchen, cramped bar seating, but most of all, it's apparently delicious and authentic Burmese noodles. All of these expectations were met in terms of service and ambience; however, the food was downright mediocre. For the price, it isn't terrible, but I wouldn't go in with high hopes. 

I tried the house noodles-- they were quite simple, noodles quickly sauteed in a mix of sauces and oil with some chicken and veggies thrown in. The first bite left my mouth dry from the unneeded salt, my stomach grumbling from the excessive grease, and expectations hoping that the next bite might live up to the hype. Overall, the noodles were nothing exceptional, in terms of flavor, fullness, or bang for buck. Not sure where all the hype is coming from, maybe my palette is a bit too sensitive to the greasiness-- don't think I'll be returning.
author: Sharath R.

description:
There are about 10 seats at the counter so you might have to wait a bit but this place is cheap, has great noodles, and a chill atmosphere. 

The food is cooked by little Burmese grandmas so you know it's legit, then they'll kick you out when you start slowing down haha.
author: Mandi W.

description:
If you'd like to experience a shit show, COME ON IN!
I decided to make the trip over to Yamo because not only do I love noodles, but i also like to support small businesses and this one seemed to have high ratings. I came on a weekday during lunchtime and there were a couple open seats so I sat myself. Theres only 9 seats in this restaurant and it wreaks like oil so i suggest you do not stop in before any major plans or with a nice outfit because you will walk out of feeling/smelling like you just took an oil bath.

FOOD: I got the house noodles because it seemed like the hottest item on the menu. The noodles took about 15 min to make and you can see everything that goes on in this kitchen since you're sitting and staring right at it.  The noodles came out with a couple of pieces of marinated meat, green onions,cilantro, and fried onion toppings. When i ordered these noodles i assumed that the noodles would be in some kind of sauce + meat ontop but i was completely wrong. These noodles were SOOO bland and soggy and it was just basically the tiny pieces of marinated meat that reminded me that i wasnt just eating bare noodles out of a strainer. I couldn't help but to grab the nearest siracha and cover my noodles in them. I instantly thought to myself.." WHY IS THIS PLACE RATED SO HIGH??!" 

now..

THE SHITSHOW: You can automatically tell that the boss lady or the master of the other workers is the old asian lady with curly hair that has a loud, rude, high pitched voice. She doesn't have any manners whatsoever or any sense of customer service for that matter. She speaks to everyone as if you're being scolded or something. The establishment is so dirty with ingredients, bowls, plates, sauces, napkins, spices, stains, oilspots, you name it- just laying around the the shelves and areas where it should be kept sanitized and I was so shocked and my friend happened to text me asking where i was while i was dining and of course i took this opportunity to try to show her where I'm at. As i lifted my phone to take a picture of the dirty kitchen, the asian lady yelled " NO PICTURES!!!" while shaking her finger in my face and giving me the dirtiest look ever. The couple next to me also sensed this awkward once in a lifetime dirty and extremely rude tension and he just looked at me with that face of " this lady is crazy.." so i knew i wasn't alone here. After the phone incident she became extra extra rude to me. after i put my chopsticks down she said " YOURE DONE!" and took away my bowl. After taking away my bowl she threw my receipt at me. THREW!!! i was in such disbelief and felt so insulted by this stupid asian lady that i slapped my money down for the meal and walked out of there. 

As I'm writing this review Im still in disbelief and pissed off about what happened. This establishment needs to get shut down. The lady handles money and then handles food right after with her bare hands (i observed her behavior carefully) without washing them, this restaurant looks like its run by a hoarder, the noodles taste like NOTHING, they don't have cups of water, it smells like shit in there, no customer service, CASH ONLY, apparently NO PICTURES, i just have nothing positive to say about this restaurant. I also question anyone who gave this place such high ratings... like... why... i wish Yelp had an option to give business's negative stars. The whole meal I was waiting for a cockroach to appear somewhere in the kitchen.
author: Samee M.

description:
I am so glad we were able to grab takeout from this place. Like all the other reviews, Yamo is a hole in the wall joint with only about 6-7 seats at the bar? It's best to grab takeout if you don't want to wait in line.

I was in a group of 8, and we basically ordered almost one of everything on the menu since we were sharing family style. My favorites were the beef noodles, mango salad, and the stir fried vegetables. I'm a little disappointed that we didn't order the tea salad because that's what they're known for, but one of us had a peanut allergy.

Nevertheless, this place is a no-nonsense hustlin' bustlin' restaurant with really good and affordable food! The dishes are pretty basic, but they are tasty and worth checking out.
author: Nina H.

description:
Perfect for last night's rainy weather.  Yamo's atmosphere is simple and to the point.  No frills, no music just quality simple Burmese food at an amazing price point.  A $20 tab for beef house noodles, tea leaf salad, samusas and two bottles of Coke 
No alcoholic beverages and cash only!  
It's location makes for great bar hopping to and from dinner.
If you're looking for authentic Burmese comfort food this is your spot.  One star off for service.  It's a simple get in, eat and get out kind of place.
author: Jenna M.

description:
Yamo is totally a hole-in-the-wall. I love how they keep the rolling street cans behind the counter without a care in the world. The health inspectors probably got paid off.

Cleanliness notwithstanding, I can totally dig the vibe of this place. With just a few stools and a long counter, it's real intimate. Dishes are whipped up posthaste, and come out fresh, if a little small. But that's ok - everything is around $6!

This is one of those places you go to when you're broke, not when you want Foreign Cinema 2.0.
author: Casey S.

description:
I've never written a review, let alone a bad one, but my experience at Yamo left me dissatisfied enough to write my first bad review. 

I grew up in an Asian household so noodles and rice is a staple in our culture, but Yamo's house special noodle and fried rice were way too greasy for my taste. If you want to skip the hour wait and still get the same quality food, go to Panda Express. 

To wrap up my subpar dining experience, our server was terrible and utterly rude. She glared at us for requesting to throw away the used chopsticks from the previous customers or when we asked for an extra plate to share our food. The worst was when she muttered how we were too "talkative" and too "slow" under her breath. Luckily we knew Cantonese so we caught on to this horrible display of customer service. 

It's safe to say that you definitely get what you pay here...both in food and service.
author: Michelle T.

description:
just leave any/all expectations of ambiance at the door and you'll have a great time.

also helps if you've been walking around the city all day and just want to devour a plate of rice and mushrooms and couldn't care less about the larger restaurant experience - because there isn't one (and it's fine). 

(get donuts from across the street for dessert)
author: Sucharitha Y.

description: Amazing food, but the staff was very rude. The house noodle was amazing. Be sure not to take pictures of anything, or they will get very angry with you.
author: Gavin S.

description: Place is super small and dingy hole in the wall.  Ladies working are not nice.  The food is ok.  Tea salad was good, noodles were tasty but very simple. Mango chicken was a little weird.  For $6 a plate you can't really expect more, you get what you pay for and this place is mediocre.
author: Jenna C.

description:
Yamo is literally a greasy hole in the wall that serves delicious food, and it's really cheap!  There are only about 10 seats at the counter, and you can watch the ladies cook up your meal while you wait. Unfortunately, you'll end up smelling like grease afterwards, but it's totally worth it.

I really like the house noodles with beef, which is essentially Chinese egg noodles topped with beef and a lot of fried garlic. It's very simple, delicious, and cheap. 

The chicken noodle soup is really unique and is probably their best dish. It's served in a coconut broth which makes it super rich and creamy. Absolutely delicious!

The portions are on the smaller side, but a single entree is satisfying, without making you feel stuffed -- the perfect size for a lunch.
author: Allen T.

description: The Yamo house noodles (chicken) and chow mein (chicken) are absolutely worth what might seem like harsh service. Actually the staff are very nice, in their own way. Do not miss this unique spot!
author: Max C.

description:
Tiny restaurant with maybe 6-8 spots at a bar. Lots of people take it to-go.

Don't be fooled by the low prices of around $6-7 per entree. The portions are pretty tiny. I got both the Yamo House Special Noodles and Tea Leaf Salad, and I easily finished both. The noodles were pretty unremarkable. Half of the noodles was coated in sauce and the other half was completely unsauced. Upside was that there was a lot of garlic. Downside was that there was only garlic, noodles, and cilantro. So whatever you imagine that tasting like, it's pretty spot on and unmemorable. The tea leaf salad was surprisingly pretty good. Spicier and more vinegary than other tea leaf salads I've had.

Yeah, service was a little intense. Make sure you are ready to order when the lady asks you. She doesn't seem like the type of person I would want to get on the wrong side of. Cash only.
author: Alice T.

description: Yamo was a great discovery. A tiny place (no, seriously it's very tiny) with a open household style kitchen. Cheap, quick and delicious. Vegetarian options were varied. I tried the samosas, the veggie curry with rice and the tea leaf salad. The veggie curry could have been more spicy, but was still very tasteful filled with the kind of veggies we like. The samosas were small and a great appetiser. For two people the meal cost 25$ and was a wholesome dinner.
author: Radhika T.

description:
Definitely my favorite Burmese spot in town (and around). I've been here twice (visited a few other Burmese spots more than once as well) and can honestly say that the food here is off the hook! Portions on some dishes aren't too big, but the price is just right! You've gotta get the tea leaf salad. Without question, this is my favorite tea leaf salad in the Bay. Their house noodles are super good and the catfish stew is pretty good, if you like catfish.

You basically wait in line outside (if you come with a party of more than 3-4, you're stupid and crazy) and wait for seats to open up on the counter. The counter seats about 8 people. And that's pushing it! You get to watch one person cook, another prepare the dishes to be served, and another "man the counter". She may not always be friendly, but you can tell she tries. As long as you're not a jerk to her and wait for her to tell you when to sit, you should be good! 

I won't name other Burmese places that I've had that I didn't like or didn't like as much, but Yamo will give you more bang for your buck for sure. And there's one other place in particular that is always super packed, was featured on food network, and is probably 3rd on my list of Burmese restaurants. Yamo takes the cake on this one folks!
author: Aaron Y.

description:
Worst service! Worst Burmese food ever. I went there for to go order on Wednesday afternoon. I was trying to take snapchat to show my friend this new place and this lady yelled at me in Burmese saying she will have to take the phone away, if I take pictures of the food!?!?? Like seriously? She could have say this in a nicer and polite way and I'm not a rude person to put my phone away immediately! 

I would give 1 star for the pricing of the food. $6.50 for most food on the menu. I ordered 2 Cold noodle (noodle salad) and 2 Garlic noodle. $26 for 4 dishes. The pricing is okay.  But the food itself taste so horrible. WORST SERVICE EVER. I've been many Chinese restaurant but this place service is worst than any restaurants in the town. Avoid this place! There are many Burmese restaurants out there that gives you big portion with good pricing.
author: Nicole P.

description:
Food: 4
Attitude: -5
Environment: 0

An old Chinese saying: 3 women, 1 drama. These three ladies (I guess one in her 50s, one 40s and one 30s) They did make it work! Love the food, even they shouted out loud to me "NO PHOTOS!! DELETE!!" twice in Chinese & English (with a spicy southeastern Asian accent tho)

It's kinda humuleating/minimal service? I should have videoed it and uploaded to Utube making it virus, anyhow, I will come back again to try all the menu, since it's really cheap as dirt.
author: Sidong H.

description: Awesome place, real food made by people who cook with sincere love.  Price is very affordable and they have a good amount of vegetarian options.
author: James F.

description: Heavenly simplicity. Beautiful food. Amazing flavors. Authentic food and service. Insanely low prices.
author: Dwayne G.

description:
You know about the food.  You know about the service.  But do you really know about the people who work there?

It's one thing to give poor service.  But don't treat your customers like the step children you abandoned.  The look of that one lady's eyes gives me the impression that she's really unhappy with the rise of property taxes or she just hates how her life turned out.  I was taking a picture of the other lady cooking and from the corner of my ear I hear a...

NO PICTUREEEEEEEEEEEE!

So I was like, "Dude...chill.  Good God."

And then she continued to cuss me out in Burmese, but didn't have the guts to say it to my face.

Like was that really necessary?
Just say, "hey, buddy.  No pictures."

I mean, just because your life looks like a war zone doesn't mean you gotta take it out on everyone else.

And what's so bad about taking a picture?  It's giving you business.

I appreciate a good hole in a wall, but the service reminds me of that one hole in the wall where the homeless drop deuces.
author: Ahn E.

description:
Yamo, with its 10 counter seats, questionable ventilation, & curt service, reminds me of how SF restaurants used to be in the 80s. If I'm being kind, I'd say its got quintessential SF character. If I'm being real, I'd say I think it's their relatively cheap prices, not the food's flavor, that's kept them in business all these decades. 

My lunch partner had nothing good to say about their house fried chow mein & curry fish (I don't think "tastes like fish nuggets" was a compliment.) 

Tea leaf salad had no actual tea leaf flavor, tasted more like a spicy, vinegary cabbage slaw. As for serving size, you absolutely get what you pay for, not that we wanted more. 

My house noodles with chicken was greasy, but oh-so-bland. Every couple bites I might get a taste of fried garlic, but it wasn't enough to lend the flavor that the noodles were sorely missing. Surprisingly my favorite part of the dish were the bits of tender chicken breast. 

If you're looking for good Burmese food, look elsewhere. If you're looking to show your out of town friends the "edgy", grimy, or unique SF food scene, I guess Yamo would suffice as a decent example (with a disclaimer that there's much better Asian food in the city.)

Cash only.
author: Fancypants X.

description: I was excited to have Burmese food again, but my excitement was short lived at Yamo. This restaurant is a small, independent restaurant with counter-only seating and an open kitchen. My friend and I ordered tea leaf salad and black bean tofu. The tea leaf salad arrived first, a paltry portion (about a 1/4-1/3 of a cup). The salad lacked any of the complexity that is found in good renditions. This salad's flavor was one-dimensional without pronounced textural contrasts. We hoped the black bean tofu would taste better, but it was just bland and under salted. Between the mediocre food, the surly service, and the dingy atmosphere, I won't return.
author: Nina C.

description:
I usually love hole in the wall places.  Yamo is definitely that.  There's a counter with about 8 seats and a line of people waiting for a spot to open (there was about a 10 min wait and I was there on a Thursday at 3pm).  

The counter wasn't super clean but it was a great place to grab a fast meal.  I tried the spring rolls and mango chicken.  The chicken was good but wasn't amazing.  I'd probably skip the spring rolls.  I had high expectations for this place: with the hole in the wall vibe and the grandmas cooking in the kitchen, it had potential to be amazing!  It was good but I probably wouldn't go back with so many other good options in SF.  Maybe I didn't order the right thing: they are known for their noodle dishes and tea leaf salad.

*They are CASH ONLY.
author: Sophie L.

description:
Super cool hole in the wall. Prices are amazing, the food is even better, and it's run by 3 authentic ladies who have a bit of a language barrier. THIS is the sort of place I hope SF never loses, and the mission continues to nurture. 

Terrible for groups because of the limited seating - takeout is a good option. They do a great job of packaging for takeout, too. But, nothing quite beats the atmosphere in person, so do that when you are able and patient. 

As noted by everyone else, the house noodles and the coconut chicken soup are outstanding. The mango chicken is quite good as well. The beef curry is pretty good, but kind of bland, would skip that just because there's better stuff here. 

One of my mainstays in the mission, and one of my fav restaurants in SF.
author: Chris S.

description: Make sure you know exactly you want with your money ready, cash only! The ladies who run the joint mean business and don't have time to wait for your wishy washy self to decide. Dine in or take out. The place is small, all counter seating only, and no you can't decide where you sit. Attempt to move and you'll get your head chewed off. The mean facade is all apart of the charm, trust! Brush that off and get ready for to eat for not a whole lotta money, which is a rare thing in the city.
author: Minh N.

description:
Came here last night because I was trying to find something that would hit the spot. Luckily there were only 4 people ahead of us and two wanted take out. We asked how long the wait was, got a cold stare and no response. Okay then!! We waited for about 25 minutes for a seat.

Let me put this into perspective. There's 8 bar stools in a cramped little location almost the size of a long hallway. There's more kitchen space than there is seating (which is understandable). So as we are waiting, we are literally standing behind other people that are eating, hovering, really.

As we waited for a table, we placed our order so once seated they could start cooking right away. 

So let's chat about something else while we wait to be seated. Service. I could not stop laughing at the way these ladies bark and yell at people. SERIOUSLY!
