Someone walks in and asks to place a to go order, "WHATYOUWANT?????" Lady taking the order writes down whatever sloppily then YELLS the dollar amount. No smile, no thank you, nothing. You don't come here for customer service. They are just outright rude, totally curt, and I find it hilarious. Forget special treatment, no one here gets any treatment! 

In the meantime, there's one stool available and this guy dining on his own asks if he could take it. Sure, we are waiting for 2 stools anyways. As soon as he sits down, another barking lady yells at him to get out and wait in line because there are others in front of him (even though everyone in front of him is ordering takeout). He's finally seated when he gets to the front of the line.

Also, there's some kind of sticky dripping substance that falls from the ceiling periodically. If it falls into your hair, pretty much plan on cutting it. I'm not joking. After repeated hair washing, it's still stuck (and this is many hours later). I'll have to cut it for him once he gets back from work.

We finally sit down, and samosas follow within ten or so minutes. So freaking delicious. I'm not a huge fan of the chunky samosas filled with globs of potato and peas. The thin, crispy, perfectly folded triangles are my favorite. They were served HOT HOT HOT with some sweet and spicy chili sauce. I could have eaten double the order!

Next up, the tea leaf salad. While not as good as Burma Superstar (a bit sweeter) it was still delicious and had an awesome crunch. 

Black bean tofu didn't really do much for me, meh. I prefer the Burmese food here more than the Chinese.

The house noodles were my favorite. Such a simple dish, yet insanely flavorful, I couldn't stop eating it (and yes, we were sharing). Fresh noodles, garlicky, light, saucy, what more can you ask for? 

Didn't try any meat dishes this time around but if the vegetarian options are THIS good, I can't wait to come back and stuff my face with some fish, beef, and chicken.

Since you're practically sitting IN a kitchen, you will smell like grease when you leave, and for hours later. We ended up getting gelato and drinks after and apologized for being smelly to the people we hung out with. Your eyes will also burn for the duration of your stay since there's no ventilation but...it's all worth it, especially watching the barking staff yell at you and everyone who wants to eat their food.  "WHAT YOU WANT?? RAAAAA"

There's no shrimp, clearly indicated by the cartoon shrimp pictures hanging in three locations. If you ask for it, you will be yelled at, "NOSHRIMP!!!!!!! BAAH!! NOO SHRIMP!!!!"

This is America, no one puts up with crappy customer service. But trust me! Here, you will, it's such a scene!

"CASH ONLY, RAAAAAAAAAA!!!!"
author: Shereen A.

description:
Don't get the hype.

I love beef chow fun so I decided to try theirs.

Portion was small, price was high, lady yelled "WHO ORDER CHOW FUN!?" The lady also seemed unhappy when I wanted hot sauce and soy sauce.

Will I come back? Maybe if I brought a date to show them a hole in the wall place, but based on the food, I probably wont.
author: Da X.

description:
Come here for a front row seat of hilariously bad service. Make a game of how bad it will be.

One example: 
- A man was ordering take out and began laughing at something he saw in the kitchen. The chef yelled out "NO LAUGHING!!!" And then she proceeded to curse about the man in Chinese. 

We ordered an extra dish and got a glare. They'll rush you out when there's a line. I feel like I'm inconveniencing them by eating there and giving them my money. They are who they are. No excuses and no apologies. 

The food was only okay. I really liked the spiciness of the tea leaf salad. The mango chicken was horrible goo- we're talking panda express style. The house noodles were okay, though we preferred the cold noodle salad (all bout that oil, mmm). 

Cash only, seats about 10 people at the counter. You can barely tell this place exists (hole-in-the-wall). Really cheap food ($5- $8 a dish). They don't have tap water- you have to get bottled water.

This place is amusing. I will leave it at that.
author: Joanna L.

description:
This place has been on my bookmark list for a while and I finally got to try it! It's very Asian fusion-y of Burmese/Chinese food. A downside would be that the flavors are kind of toned down--would've liked more flavor punch but hey, that could be too overwhelming if you're being introduced to it for the first time. Coming from a southeast Asian background, I think they could've used some work in that department. 

I had their coconut curry chicken soup (which is great btw) but would have liked it to be stronger in the coconut and curry aspect. Other than that, I could see myself coming back again to try other things
author: Victoria C.

description: I tire of hearing "Food in San Francisco is so expensive". If you grew up in a city, you know where/how to find the good inexpensive spots. Yamo is one of them. Run by three women who don't give a f** if you are there or not. Never idle, they are always cooking and tending to the stove and kitchen. The results are glorious. If good food is your number 1 determinant, I highly recommend Yamo. If you are bothered by "poor" service, well, there are other places in the mission for you.
author: Ashley C.

description:
I would come here to eat just to be in the company of the 2 most tough, "don't give a crap" genuine ladies working behind the counter, they were so hilarious and humorous. They definitely gave me their "tough love" attitude, and I respect that and them for what they do and all the folks they have deal with, its just their demeanor to this hole in the wall joint. Part of the authentic, no nonsense experience. 

House Noodles with chicken - good chewy noodles with tasty flavor and sauce, the chicken is white meat. 

Tea Leaf Salad - a bit too over dressed but the fried beans and nuts were good. Not like a true Burmese Tea Salad though, but not bad. 

   Can't beat the price, I'd come here often if I was close by. Their cold noodle salad also looks good. 

So don't be sensitive or thrown by the demeanor, it is what it is!

Thanks ladies of Yamo!
author: L V.

description:
Don't come to Yamo expecting an upscale treatment. In fact, don't come here even expecting a seat (you might score a spot at one of the ten seats at the narrow restaurant if you come early). But should you come here? Yes. Absolutely.  

This hole in the wall provided a unique atmosphere. From sitting right in front of a hot wok and flames to the grouchy lady who insists on stopping people from taking any pictures. I felt a wave of relief to eat somewhere in the city that wasn't overrun by a minimalist, hipster vibe. In a strange way, I never felt closer to this city--sitting in a dingy eatery in the heart of the Mission. 

The food is cheap and decent! I ordered the Mango chicken (comes with rice) and an order of spring rolls for about $8!! The entree was filling and flavorful. The spring rolls were delicious as well.

All in all, Yamo's food was good, not amazing, but good. Would I come back? Definitely--just for the experience itself.
author: Naveena S.

description:
Food: upper 3.5 stars
Service: 2 stars

I'm not turned off by the lack of enthusiasm in service, but I think the lady was borderline offensive and I believe it's really a mutual relationship when we go to a restaurant, pay them, and get the food we want. The way she yelled "NO PICTURES OK" to my mom, idk.. why don't you post up a sign for no pictures then? 

On top of that, I don't think the food is great. I'm not comparing it to any other Burmese place, because I realize the take is a little different; more like a street vendor kind of food. However, the tea salad was $6.5, tiny, and did not have enough cabbage. Everything was good, not amazing, and on the salty side. The cold noodles were good, $6.5, spicy, oily. The house noodles were good, oily, also $6.5. Not really a lot to be said about their flavors except "it's not bad." The samusas were delicious though, at $4.25, potatoes had a great texture and flavor.

Anyway, I probably won't be back here unless it's a cold day and I want to try their chicken noodle soup, which looked really good. All their food would be awesome with beer but no alcoholic beverages are allowed in there.
author: Maggie G.

description:
I grew up eating authentic Burmese food. This place was an utter disappointment if what you're looking for is authentic Burmese cuisine. 

Food--The fish chowder soup here barely had fish--or onion, ginger, lemongrass etc that are key Burmese ingredients. Instead it's thickened with corn starch which I have never noticed in all the other times I've had this dish elsewhere. Also the noodle salad is a JOKE. Authentic Burmese noodle salad has dried shrimp and Chana bean and tamarind at the very least. You get diluted chili sauce on your noodles here instead. You get what you pay for here. I would've gladly paid 2x for something closer to Burmese food. 

Service--I don't ask a lot in terms of service. I'm used to Chinese restaurants, where service is run ok different standards than American ones. But here? The woman really is rude. I understand Burmese and can hear her curse customers in Burmese. She literally cursed about a customer who called to change his order. Maybe it's an insecurity because her English is limited, but the day I was here, she seemed pretty upset and was taking it out on customers. Someone asked for more cabbage in her tea lead salad because it was too spicy for her and the woman behind the counter literally said "no."
author: Alias A.

description: If you're interested in great food without the frills, then look no further. Yamo is great for quick Burmese food in the City. The tea salad and house noodles are definitely a must try! Seating is limited, so be prepared to wait, but take out is also available.
author: Brody M.

description:
I officially cannot stand the angry Asian lady with the fro and refuse to patron here again. She completely ignored us purposely when we sat down at the bar area because she got pissed off that we wanted to wait for a couple to finish eating so we could sit in their seats. Completely unprofessional and rude. We literally sat there for half an hour as she took other people's orders and not ours. We patiently waited for her this entire time, but she willfully ignored us and scowled. Needless to say, we walked out. I'm not expecting good service at a hole-in-the-wall that has been due for renovations a decade or two ago, but I do expect basic human courtesy for your customers. So disappointing.

I highly recommend you order for pick up, the service is 0 stars because it's non existent and the place is really dirty (just watch them cook and handle ingredients, and then take a look at their sad excuse of a kitchen). I honestly don't even know why people bother tipping someone like her. That's just validating her terrible attitude towards people who pay HER for food and service. Ridiculous! 

If you must come here for food, you do get what you pay for. The only reason I used to come here was for the prices (seriously unbeatable), but again you get what you pay for. If something seems too good to be true, it probably is.
author: Claudia C.

description: Pleasantly surprised by this hole-in-the-walk Burmese restaurant. To be clear, this is truly a hole in SF. There was only space to seat about 7-8 people along a bar right in front of the kitchen. I tried both the Yamo House Noodles and the Fish Noodle Soup. Both dishes were well done and prepared quickly. The wait was not too long, but I came here around 1:30PM. However, the prices were incredibly cheap! For less than $7, I left here with both a full and happy belly, and smelling like noodles. So if you are not prepared to smell like food for the rest of the day, I would save coming here for another time. Otherwise, this place does a great job making classic Burmese dishes when compared to more popular restaurants like Burmese Superstar.
author: Adeline C.

description: The owner is extremely rude. Talked rude, actions rude.  She talks can like people in need of her food and she acts like dont care customers.  She even told customer that u sit here too long, leave.  She threw the chopsticks on the table  like i am a homeless and she generous gave me food.  Talk loud.  Gezz, i have never seen a restaurant with an owner like this.  Rude, rude,rude.
author: Mary M.

description:
So,  I found this place because of its high rating/reviews on yelp. According to yelp it's a 4 star, but my taste buds say its a 1.  I walked 2 miles and waited 1.5 hours to try this place only to feel disappointed and confused after trying the tasteless House Noodles with Chicken and  disgusting Cold Noodles.  What the...?!  I'm so confused.  What is this.. "great food" you all speak of?! 

WARNING: The place is greasy, hot, and dirty.  So, if you plan on eating here, don't wear anything nice AND don't expect a lot.

:( Sad sad day.
author: Novi C.

description:
My friend and I were in search of a dinner that wouldn't leave our wallets bleeding. We were near by when he remembered he had passed by here the other day and wanted to come! Cheap & greasy was what we wanted, and cheap & greasy is also what we got.

It's a very small place - maybe 8 bar stools? Hooks on the wall behind them so your bags/coats have a place off the floor. There are about 4 appetizers (rolls, gyoza, etc.), some salads, soups, and maybe 10 different entrees - noodles, curries, and rice dishes. The appetizers are $4.50 & all the entrees are $6.25 (don't know about salads and soups). We got the gyoza, mango chicken, and garlic fried noodles with beef. All the food was pretty solid and a decent portion (but it's only $6!). I thought the garlic noodles were good but not amazing. Definitely glad I had other food to balance out the noodles since they got a little salty. Hot sauce also helped temper the flavor. I was a good level of full, but I can see how a lot of bigger guys might not be happy with just one dish.

Some call the ladies rude, but I think they were fine. The younger server was a little sassy but in an entertaining way, and the older lady *was* yelling a lot... but just in a way that's normal for little old asian grandma's who just dgaf. I would say endearing more than rude, but maybe it's cause it's what I expect anyway. 

Would go back, but would probably never seek it out. But hey, when most other meals in SF are $10+ and follow the health-craze trend, it's nice to know options like this exist!
author: Mina C.

description:
This is my all time favorite hole in the wall. So far everything I had was absolutely delicious. 
The house noodles with beef are my favorite. I can also recommend the tea leaf salad and the spring rolls
author: Dario S.

description:
Take note: be very wary of any Asian restaurant with no Asians eating in it. Limited menu restaurant.  Burmese and Chinese food advertised,  but it seemed more Chinese than Burmese. Ordered the "Beef Curry," but it did not even taste spicy or have any curry in it.  It seems more like a beef Szechuan dish.

I love supporting family owned restaurants,  but this place will be an exception. Wish it had redeeming qualities that make the "Soup Nazi" ambiance worth the experience,  but the food is bland and the portions aren't even worth the hassle... despite the price. The dirty divey noodle house appearance has its certain appeal,  especially if you are some transplant looking for something different that makes you seem cool and edgy.  BUT nothing about this food is cool,  edgy, or tasty. 

Lastly,  they have a problem with photography in the restaurant (esp. Of them)... yet they don't have a sign that says,  " no photos." Don't worry they will shout at you instead. So go ahead, take the a photo
author: Mike L.

description: Yamo is delicious. I mean, that's undeniable. Even thinking about it makes my mouth water. The house noodles and cold noodles are both incredible, and I would definitely go much more often if it weren't 1) cash only 2) always crowded around lunch and dinner time and 3) cramped to the point where you feel guilty about not scarfing down your food as fast as possible (which, to be fair, I do anyway) because someone else is always waiting for your seat.
author: Ava H.

description: Have you ever been yelled at ? This lady will give you the taste of it. I think this place is superbly overrated. I been to several Burmese restaurants in Bay Area and found food in this spot way lower in quality. Tea leaf salad did not have a single tea leaf!!!!
author: The Food L.

description: This isn't the type of place to sit and chit chat with friends. You come, you order, sit, eat and leave. The lady in the kitchen yells at the customers, food is decent. If only the customer service was worth coming here again. You don't feel a sense of being relaxed or in peace.
author: Sandra J.

description: Food is delicious and cheap as heck for SF restaurants. Be prepared to wait in line for a seat, sit in a cramped hallway and try not to bring a big backpack. Order to go to make it quick. But do not bother calling because they do not pick up the phone. The lady here is like a soup nazi. I tried to order extra noodles but she refused. She hurts your feelings by yelling at you. I tried speaking Chinese to get better treatment but the lady behind the counter is indiscriminate. One star ding for how cramped and mean it is when she raises her voice. Another star dinged for the lady using her bare hands to pull the noodles from the colander. Unfortunately I do not think I will be back.
author: Carina L.

description:
Had high expectations coming into this place after all the hype... and it definitely met up with my expectations! If you go into your meal mentally prepared that the service would be horrible.. it's actually not too bad and kind of funny. Only about 8 seats in the whole restaurant and 3 old ladies working. One cooked, one cut vegetables and the other one (lady with the fro) is the one that like to yell at everyone for being slow and telling people they are "annoying" in Burmese ( I only understood because it's similar to Cantonese) as she takes the orders and quickly cleans the tables... 

As for the food, I ordered 2 entrees... (and got yelled at for ordering 2 because the lady thought I wouldn't be able to finish both... which I did :) )
I got the Yamo House noodle with pork which was absolutely AMAZING! the noodles were perfectly chewy and the roasted garlic gave it such a simple but flavorful taste. ($6.50)
I also ordered the black bean with fish over jasmine rice dish which was good but nothing to rave about.

The House Noodle though... sooo good that I had to get one TO-GO to bring to my mom in Los Angeles tomorrow. I got lucky as they are cash only and I only brought a 20 dollar bill.
author: Janet L.

description:
A true hole-in-the-wall joint that serves base Burmese noodles and such. There are only 10 cramped seats at the bar and that's it. There is a bathroom but getting there is as tough as getting a seat for two at the bar (no tables).  Calling an order in will be tough as the ladies don't speak English well. 

This place is raw and basic and harkened to the days of the purely working class Mission. 

Sure, there are other places to eat but you won't get a bargain like this.
author: SF P.

description: If you're looking for good greasey food then Yamo is the place to dine at, BUT if you're looking for good service and cleanliness then Yamo is not the place for you. I LOVE coming here to eat but the service and cleanliness makes me think twice everytime I come here... The two older ladies that work there always greet people in but they NEVER clean or wipe the counter when guests come to dine in.... NASTY.. I always have to wipe the counter down when I come in to eat because they never do... Another thing I DISLIKE about Yamo is that they do false advertising on their menus.. even if it is .25 cents... still... they should correct that and put the new prices in.. I ordered the chef selection noodles that stated to be $6... as well as the spring rolls being $4.. and the bottled coke soda to be $2.... how does all this add up to $13?! suppose to be $12... Despite all this being said they also have people wait for at least 15+ minutes after you're done eating to hand you the bill.... SO.... LIKE I SAID, IF YOU WANT GOOD GREASEY FOOD COME.. BUT IF YOU WANT SERVICE AND CLEANLINESS...... DO NOT COME!!! I was just very dissappointed and had a very crappy experience.. Please don't think of this as an exaggeration.. This was my experience every single time I come here to dine....
author: Wayne C.

description:
As endless streams of brown chunks flew from my mouth into the toilet, I couldn't help but taste the fish chowder I had earlier in the day from Yamo. Having grown up in China, I've eaten bugs from street vendors and intestine skewers at the dirtiest restaurants, but my stomach had always emerged the champion. However, as I hunched over the toilet, perspiring profusely, it dawned on me that no king rules forever. I finally had food poisoning. 

Spending the whole day in bed had reminded me how fragile life can be. Thank you the sassy ladies of Yamo for teaching me humility in life, and reminding me of my mortality.
author: Joshua Z.

description:
Food 5
 Tea leaf salad is always on point!
Ambiance 2 I believe Yamo is one of the smallest, stickiest restaurants in Bay Area. 
Service 3 I kinda like their simple service
Price 5+
author: Tory T.

description:
The house noodles used to taste like magic.  I literally stepped off the plane and headed straight to Yamo with my luggage, excited to finally have a bowl of these amazing noodles once again. 

There's nothing better than savoring a dish that you so fondly remember and being transported back to the good times.  But there's nothing worse than having your memories tarnished by an unimpressive meal.

I was so disappointed. Either Yamo is not the same or 7 years of living in NYC has spoiled my taste buds.

Farewell Yamo, it was really nice knowing you.
author: Anvy A.

description: Really easy to pass by and many reviewers tone-deafly complain about service, but this place is great.  Affordable, delish Burmese
author: Erik I.

description:
YAMO has the rudest service in the whole world. Beware if you're gonna dine in and place a repeat order- they might just snatch your dish and yell at you to leave. When you say thanks they just ignore you. I am willing to sit in the hazardous ambiance to taste great food which they have but rudeness for the heck of it is just plain unacceptable. Yes the food was great the first time I went but recently there was so! Much! Oil! Entire napkins were dripping wet as I wiped my mouth. 

The tea leaf salad was too salty and as someone else mentioned before, our portions were nowhere close to what they usually serve- but boy dare we point that out! 

These guys don't give a fuck about courtesy - they know their food has its following and people will keep coming but sadly how I'm treated affects where I eat.
author: Nutcrackin C.

description: I came here expecting some Burmese eats, but the menu options seemed pretty limited. I ordered the house noodles and the curry fish - both were much closer to what I might get at an Americanized Chinese restaurant. The house noodles tasted like oily pulled noodles (a bit like your standard lo mein type dish) with a sparse few bits of well cooked meat, and the curry fish had mushrooms and bell pepper, which I don't often see in Burmese curries. Good value and generally satisfying though
author: Neal B.

description:
So you've made a horrible choice and decided to wait in the line that is Yamo's dine-in experience, and you're cruising on Yelp to find some validation of your decision. 

Poor choice. 

What may have initially lulled you into coming to Yamo is the copious amount of reviews they've commanded, or a stellar recommendation from some friends who you've listened to in the past. But let's agree on something: number of reviews on Yelp is hardly a standard-bearer anymore of qualify, and you've always questioned your friends' choice in food. 

While the angry slurs flung from one side of the dining bar to another sounds authentic, it's actually Chinese and done to play the part. The dim lighting and the food prep done in the front of the house detracts from whstever mood they were going for. Oh, and if you dine-in, be prepared to have every take-out order cut in front of you.

The tea leaf salad is comprised lima beans with zero tea leaves. The beef curry is 90% potatoes and the curry is basically a sweet-and-sour sauce. 

Nothing about Yama is redeemable, but by now you probably realized you've made a big mistake and it's too late to get out of the line. 

Poor choice indeed.
author: J Z.

description:
This place is perfect if you want to pick up good quality good portioned food for a budget, especially if you know what to get. The place had very limited seating and doesn't seem too comfortable so I opted for takeout.

Some of the items I've had:
1. Curry chicken  ($6.25 , 5 stars) over rice. This plate came with potatoes peppers and other vegetables with a delicious sauce. Tied with the chicken noodle soup, it's a great deal for your buck.
2. Chicken noodle soup ($6, 5 stars) this soup came in 2 sewers mate containers, one with the broth and the other with the ingredients.
3. Tea leaf salad ($6, 3 stars) it was very small and as expensive as an entree. It was good but I'd pass if you're looking for value.
4. Mango chicken($6.25,3 stars) over rice. a lot of people give great reviews on the mango chicken so despite it sounding weird I tried it. It was ok but I'm not a fan of sweets and missed the delicious potatoes in the curry chicken!
author: Charles M.

description:
Can't beat the food and the price.  My friend also love the food but she just can't stand "unfriendly" service.  It bothers the heck out of her.  It doesn't bother me, it's just no nonsense blunt service.   *grunt grunt*

My favorite is tofu black bean sauce with chow fun (rice noodles).   All my meat eating friends like the Chicken Curry Soup.  Too bad it can't be veg for me.
author: Veggie G.

description: This place is gross. I used to like it but now that I've gone back I realize how filthy the place is, the customer service is terrible and the food is junk. Their cold noodles were once an old favorite but even when asking to reduce the sauce and oil, you just get served their old slop with a sour puss to match.  I'll spend my shekles elsewhere.
author: Mel M.

description:
Service here is speedy, snappy and sassy. Yamo's personality is really something else, even among hole in the wall places. 

Upon arrival you'll either be greeted by a long line or a single server barking "what do you want!?" as soon as you step foot in the doorway. 

Seating is extremely limited - a single bar strip facing the kitchen so take it to go if you have more than 3 people. 

The food is flavorful and tasty! Portions are more than fair for the price but you won't be full. Recommend ordering appetizers if you're hungry. 

We ordered the Yamo House Noodles and Chicken Mango. Chicken mango was spicy and noodles were nice and chewy! 

Come here with an open mind and don't take any of the snapping at personally! They run a tight ship here and each party will get ragged on for something different. For us it was asking twice for water, for the group after us it was asking for extra chili sauce. 

You'll have to look beyond the grease / rough edges and not sweat the little things here. All part of the Yamo experience! :)
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Really?! Seriously?! 
I was in the neighborhood and saw this place has awesome reviews on Yelp.
The house noodle was so below average. Beef was too salty, noodles was soggy. Any hawker food in Singapore would be so much better. Well if you like grumpy servers, waiting in line, eating average food elbow to elbow with some stranger, this is the place to go.
author: Yvonne W.

description: Tea leaf salad was good and the noodle dish was good, but the mango chicken was bland and so was the fish soup (no fish to be seen). That would have been a 3 star review, but we were sitting next to the old proprietor, who was watching over us like a hawk and making us feel veryyy uncomfortable.
author: Ted M.

description:
I'd heard great things about this place so I wanted to check it out while I was in the mission. It's literally a hole in the wall with maybe 8 stools at the counter and 2 people cooking. It was super hot inside and all the stools were full but we wanted takeaway. Both employees completely ignored us as they sweated away behind the counter. It was shocking really. The place isn't so ig that they didn't know we were there. Finally I asked if we could order some food and they hurriedly took our order with as little eye contact and interest as possible. I was seriously questioning why I was spending my money here...

Got the food and took it to Dolores Park. My friend had the mango chicken and it was super spicy. I had the house noodles with pork and they were bland, boring and did I say bland?

Still not sure why people rave about this place. I definitely won't be back.
author: Tera K.

description:
There's bad service (unintentional) and then there's mean service (intentional).  The woman there is straight up mean. Maybe she's sick of cooking and serving all these years and needs to retire. But I'll take my money elsewhere. 

Food is just so-so, yeah prices are cheap, but definitely not good enough to overcome the vitriol of this woman.
author: A L.

description: We used to love this place for their affordable and tasty food. Lately the food has gone downhill. Service has never been the friendliest but that was fine as long as the food was good. Now, every time we order noodles, half of the dish is dry and flavorless. Obviously minimal effort is put into preparing the noodle dishes. I still love their tea leaf salad, although considerably less fresh tasting than Burma superstars, it is full of flavor. Sadly that dish alone hasn't been enough to bring us back /:
author: Brianna N.

description:
This place is disgusting. 

We ordered the house noodles to go (from the chubby lady with curly short hair) since there were no seats available. As we were waiting for our food to be cooked, we see a couple leave their seats. So we immediately asked the cook (the one who took our order) if we could dine in instead. Chubby lady doesn't even look up but proceeds to cook with a dirty look on her face, she says angrily,"No. You already said to-go!" We were just as shocked as the customer eating in front of her. So my friend and I laugh it off and accept it. Once our noodles were done, we pay. I asked another lady for some hot sauce and she slams ONE dinky container on the counter and rolled her eyes at me. As we walked out slowly, the cook gives us the world's UGLIEST, DIRTIEST, REPULSIVE, GRUESOME look ever.

Now for the house-noodles. They were drenched in oil and barely had any meat. It was like having Chinese chow-mein noodles. If you want real Burmese food, I suggest you make a trip to either one of these restaurants: Burma Cafe, Burma Super Star or B-Star.
author: Laura T.

description: Solid, no-frills Burmese food (that everyone mistakes for Thai) served in a tiny low-rent diner countertop.   One of my absolute quick faves in SF.
author: John S.

description: Prepare to get yelled at! But it's worth it. This place is an institution. Pretty decent food. 6 seats total inside. Small, cramped, but awesome and for a really decent price. I always order to go. When I call ahead she never takes my name and never repeats my order when it seems like it's complicated but has never got it wrong. This place is amazing despite doing everything for hospitality wrong sometimes. Get the pot stickers and tea leaf salad and some chicken curry. It's fantastic.
author: Zac B.

description: Good and affordable food. Restaurant is small and is a family business. Don't dare to take pictures and don't expect great service. Cash only :)
author: Richard C.

description: Rude (almost psychotic) service. Didn't even eat here since they yelled at me for walking in to wait for a friend for a few minutes. Would NEVER come back. Don't know how they survive in this city with such bad service.
author: Mike G.

description:
On atmosphere this place rocks with suspicious lookin Grandma looking at you like a home invader and girl tossing noodles continuously in this hole in the wall.

But the chowder had like no fish and the noodles at least in this dish felt like they had been soaking for a week.

Yay flavor meh texture. Cheapcheap so may try again....
author: Tatiana G.

description:
Um, "Yamo" be there, 'K? 

This is the kind of place where word has gotten out, for way too long, and now I can't eat there anymore because it's so terribly crowded. 

Not sure why everyone complains about the service--these ladies have a lot on their plates (and so do we--ha!), what with prep, cooking, taking orders, dealing with hipsters, and whatnot.  

It's cheap, it's good, it's basic, it's not fancy, it's divey, it's a slice of pre-gentrification Mission delight. Don't go. Because "Yamo" want it all to myself.
author: K C.

description:
-The epitome of "hole in the wall." Tiny shop with small door/window from the outside. Long dangling lights hanging from the ceiling. Chefs cook right in front of you. Full view of the kitchen and ingredients used. Limited seats at the counter (~7). Literally butting elbows with the customers next to you. No air conditioning so it's super hot/stuffy inside.
-Best coconut chicken noodle soup EVER. The noodles were tender and the coconut soup was super creamy and rich. $6. 
-The mango chicken has fresh mangoes. Again, $6.
-Samusas are crispy on the outside, soft on the inside.
-Portions are a little smaller than most places (to be honest). But it's reasonable considering the quality and the price.
-Inexpensive.
-Cash only.
-You can order to go! But eating here is recommended because it's truly a unique experience.
author: Vicki L.

description: This place is great.  It's 8 stools at a bar and cheap Burmese(?) street food.  When I was in the staff were a bunch of old women bantering with each other while they worked and kind of indifferent to the customers, but it was less than 10 minutes from placing my order to food being in front of me.  The food was excellent, especially the tea leaf salad
author: Kyle W.

description:
Stepping in, it reminded me of many places in Southeast Asia. A cacophony of ingredients, cooking utensils, grease and darkness. Tight counters, and very disinterested and basic service. 

We were ignored for a while, though they had nobody else to serve and were just clearing plates. Finally asked our order and nothing in response. Watched the old lady a while and she appeared to be making our food, yeah! Got a tea salad and their house noodles, each $6.25.

Tea salad turned out to be VERY small serving, probably a cup total, if that. Would take two servings to have a meal, and for about $8-9 I'd have twice this amount at a place with much higher overhead, very surprising they serve so little. As for taste, I'd say it was alright though much heavier on the sauce than it needs, and was gone in about 10 chopstick loads. Much better places in town for this dish which is delicious when done well. They make other salads which are apparently 2-1/2 times the size for the same price which made no sense...

Also we had their house noodles. Good taste, a little more generous with the serving size, and my coworker said he'd return for it. At $6.25 this was probably a good deal. 

All-in-all it's not really a gem in the rough as I had been led to believe on Yelp. It's okay, probably worth at least one visit for nostalgia sake if you've done some down and dirty traveling. But I'd only return if I was nearby and really starving for something other than burritos or yuppie fare.
author: T J.

description: Love, love LOVE this place! It's just a. Little bigger than my kitchen and looks dingy and great and unsanitary, but I think it's the best Burmese food to get on the go and quickly. Be forwarded though. If you go on a weekend (or popular weeknight, for that matter) you will be waiting. I recommend phoning in an order and going somewhere to eat (or if you want a quick veg session in front of your tv for the night, this is a great place to get a quick bite. Can't go wrong with the tea leaf salad. Although I wish it were higher, you can't beat the price ($6.50). The fish chowder is also delish. Every dish I've seen looks amazing and the constant lines speak for themselves. Customer service isn't bad at all either, especially if you don't mind that they get right to the point (no need to sugar coat!) Just goes to show that you don't have to spend a lot to get quality, delicious food!
author: Tracy T.

description:
Yamo used to be my faaavorite spot in the Mission. Super cheap, authentic Burmese fare at unbeatable prices.

 Prior to my last visit I would've given this place 4 stars. However, the last time I went was really disappointing and from that experience I would've given it 2 stars :( I went right when they opened last weekend and was one of the first customers. They were still getting food prepped so I'm gonna give them a benefit of a doubt and say it was a one bad experience. Me and my mom left our meal feeling sick and disgusting. All the flavors were off and drowned in So. Much. Oil! We decided never to go back again after, but it used to be so good before I still want to give it another chance.

There is almost always a line, but they cook really fast and the dishes are pretty small so there's a quick  turnover!

I always get the Cold Noodles with chicken. It's so refreshing on a warm day and I love the mix of flavors! 

The Fish Chowder was notttt good. I come from a  Burmese family so I've had this quite a few times. This had to be one of the worst. It didn't taste like it was supposed to and was just off. 

The salads are good! I recommend any of them. They come smaller than you expect but they are pretty cheap anyways.

House noodles are good but not my fave. The meat and noodes are flavorful!

Noodles in Coconut Broth are amazing. Get it! Authentic and super comforting. 

Service is pretty awful. There is one woman (the middle aged one) out of the three who is really nice. For the others, beware! I've seen one even yell at a customer for asking for water lol.
author: Carolyn L.

description:
Friday, 8:00PM.
Note: Cash only. 

Limited seating, be prepared to wait.

Quickie:
* Food quality
+ Service
* Hygiene
+ Turnaround
+ Menu variety

And then...?
Get in, get your grease, get out. 

**********
Stuffed my face in:
1. Mango Chicken
     + Sweet n' salty with tender meat
2. Yamo Noodles (beef)
     - Grease is strong for this one, even for a greasy spoon
3. Curry Tofu
     + Nice spice
4. Potstickers (pork)
     - Amount of dough diluted most of the flavor

Constructive comments:
*Source ingredients
*Compost
author: Chuck N.

description:
Undeniably a hole in the wall that seats about 8-10 people for yummy, homely cooked Burmese entrees!  Just bring one other person with you!  It's impossible to fit a group together in here.

I felt like a compacted sardine while dining here at this grub spot, but the food was worthy to try!

The food is so cheap here - more or less 6 bucks each for appetizers or entrees.

I love their Tea Leaf Salad!  It was crunchy, tasty and unique.  Too bad the proportion of this salad is small.  It teased my palate.

Their Stir-Fried Black Bean Fish with Rice was good.  Spice it up with their side vinegar-ed, mini, chopped jalepenos and it will be smacking delicious!

As for their Yamo House Noodles with your choice of beef, chicken or pork, it was slurping good.  

My friend and I couldn't stay a bit to chat ever more after we finished our meals- we felt rushed with the fair line waiting outside!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
For the record, I really thought I would like Yamo. I've been asked "Have you ever been to Yamo?" by fellow foodies countless times over the past several years. A few months ago, my friend Alex and I were hanging out at her place and we had to figure out what to do for dinner. She suggested Yamo so we decided to call in an order for pick-up. Alex rattled off a couple items and then asked a question about the third. The lady on the other end yelled "Yeah!" and hung up. Baffled, we called a Chinese takeout place instead. I wrote off this incident as a combination of the language barrier/how busy they are and vowed to step foot into Yamo one day and give them a try. 

That day was today. My buddy and I were hungry after an adventure at Heath Ceramics. Without pulling out my phone to Yelp something I've tried and loved, Yamo popped up from the vault deep in my memory of things to try, so off we went. 4 stars on Yelp and 1200 reviews...what could go wrong, right? It's a suuuper small place with a bar that seats less than ten. Your food is prepared literally right in front of you. It looked like a mother-daughter duo behind the scenes, and one of them told me very quickly that there is no photography allowed. Oh well, at least she apologized. 

Mo Hinga was alright. The house noodles with beef were also just okay as well, but rather salty. The coconut chicken noodle soup was better than the other two but it was super oily. Each dish was bathing in MSG, for which I have a genuine disdain. I am still thirsty after eating here in the early evening. We walked out the door paying about $20 for three items, so it is on the inexpensive end of the spectrum as far as eats go in the gentrified Mission area. As the old adage goes, however, "You get what you pay for", and in this case, it is small portions. You may pay $10 a dish at popular, albeit overhyped, Burma Superstar on Clement Street, but you get $4 more worth of food. You also don't get the urge to swallow the entire Pacific Ocean after a meal at Burma, so there's that.
author: Olivia V.

description:
This spot is my new favorite noodle house in the Mish. It has all of the things I want that I regularly complain about other places not having. It's a teeeeeny tiiiiny hole in the wall, 8 seats, maybe 10, the kitchen is right in front of you so you can see what's happening with your food (but it gets kind of smokey but no big deal), the food is simple, cheap, hella good, and service is to the point. 

We went in tonight and waited maybe 10 mins to sit at the end of the counter. This cool little kid was sitting with his dad eating and when my friend went to the bathroom, this kid started chatting with me about what I should order. He was a helpful little lad and advised that his mom likes the Chicken Noodle Soup which he and his dad had ordered for her, to go. He also said the Tea Leaf Salad was another regular choice for them, so we got that too. The House Noodles with Pork were his last suggestion and they rounded out our meal nicely. The pork was crispy, the noodles were garlicky, lots of green onions and cilantro. 

Definitely a cool place to go for a casual and inexpensive meal, in the thick of the Mission if you're trying to go out after. Everything was $18 total. Don't know if I've ever mentioned this in a review, but the other customers were just the best - or at least the ones we were seated next to on either side. Just makes me feel good to be around other people who are friendly and like good food. That is all.
author: Crystal C.

description:
What's up?

That is literally how you'll be greeted by one of the staff at Yamo. No matter if they know you or they don't, standard "greeting" goes. What's up? What do you want? Laughable service as all the other reviews have mentioned. I went in expecting that so it was all good.

Been there a couple of times and I can't seem to stay away from their house noodles. Garlicky noodly goodness. Both beef and chicken options are good. Didn't care for their samosas though. Will be back to try their other dishes if I have the willpower.
author: Fiona M.

description: This place is the definition of a hole in wall no joke. You are walking down Valencia and go through this street and if you don't look closely, you might miss this place. It truly is just a hole in the wall. There is barely any seating and there is always a line, I recommend going between lunch and dinner. The moment I stepped in here and sat down it felt like i was in Hong Kong grabbing a late night bite. Don't be discouraged by the "Rude" Asian ladies running the place, that's just how they are.  Now the food here. I ordered the noodles but this place serves food that you would definitely find at a cart in China. It tastes really good and you can really tasted the "stir-fry" in the food cooked here. Did I mention here that the food is really cheap?!
author: Jacky S.

description: Small place with just a few stool to sit at. I ordered the Yamo house noodles with beef to-go. It took less than 4 minutes and I was on my way. Noodles were tasty and I will definitely be going back to try something new.
author: Michael C.

description:
The matriarch at Yamo scares me... But something about having a perpetually grumpy Asian woman leading the helm at this incredibly popular hole-in-the-wall and simultaneously feeding and yelling at her customers makes me feel like the food is extra legit.

Prices can't be beat, and the food is tasty (although I think hunger and cheap prices are the best seasoning...).
author: Anna X.

description:
House noodles with beef. That is all you need to get! Other stuff is just okay. The house noodles are the best.

It's a hole in the wall place with really bad service, not the cleanest place but if you want a fast comfort meal this is the place! (Although there's so much fried garlic in the noodles you will taste and smell like garlic for a whole day)

The potstickers are not well done, definitely prefer Japanese gyozas. The tea salad was below average, not worth getting.

Don't expect anything from their service, the people are quite mean but no one cares, there's always people lining up out the door and people ordering for take out.
author: Rohenne L.

description:
I just don't get here as often as I should....

I first came here quite a number of years ago on a date and it was my first experience with Burmese food. It got me hooked.

I've been here quite a bit and I've never been disappointed. The food is always excellent, and the price is ridiculously cheap. Two people can eat for under twenty bucks. The place is small and they cook right in front of you so, expect to smell like a kitchen for the rest of the night.

I love the ladies that run this joint. While the whiny types think they're rude the fact is, they are working hard, making tons of orders, inside and take out, and they're just plain no-nonsense.

If you're lucky and they have fresh coconut, be careful before you order it. Seeing the little old lady hacking into it (and I mean HACKING into it) with a BIG f'ing cleaver left me with a mild case of PTSD. Holy cow!! and, I served in the Army...

My favs:

* Tea Leaf Salad, the bomb
* Mango Salad, Spicy (very much so)
* Yamo House Noodles with Pork (Heaven)
* Curry Prawns? NO SHRIMP!!!!!

Eating in, you need to have some etiquette. The place is small, really small, I mean really really small (like, you probably have a closet bigger than this restaurant). So, be prepared to scoot over to make room for people coming in. And for crying out loud, be a good sport about it. It's a down home friendly place so, you should be too.
author: Paul D.

description:
The family who works here are Chinese. Friggin awesome. 

I came to get take out for dinner, as I was too lazy to make food. First bit of ire: It says delicious oriental food. Ugh. Can I say how much I hate the word "oriental." Unless its a rug, nothing is oriental! 

I had their house noodles...and I don't get the hype. Its basically garlic noodles with chicken. Also had some of their tea leaf salad, which is SPICY! LIKE! But flavor-wise, it wasn't really that complex. Just. Spice. 

Ehh. Overall, I don't think I'd come back to order.
author: Lily W.

description:
Hole in the wall. There, I said it like everyone else and got that out of the way. Short review: it's a teeny tiny little counter with ten stools, three old ladies cooking their hearts out, cheap Burmese noodle dishes, and poor ventilation.

It's every San Francisco stereotype. It's fantastic.
author: Sean B.

description: What I haven't reviewed Yamo?  Love this place!  Cheap, quick and dirty!  It might not look like much but I'd try and hit it up at off hours b/c you can only seat like 10 people in there and it gets hot especially if you are seated towards the back.  I typically get the House Noodles and the Tea Leaf Salad and that's super filling.  The ladies that work here take no crap and you might have to speak up to get your order taken but they know what they are doing with the eats! :)
author: Gene X.

description:
My friend wanted to try this place during the slow times since there is no line. We actually were the only customers when we got there.

I will say that it felt like we were entering someone's house uninvited to ask for food. It was a unique vibe. The ladies weren't mean but weren't attentive at the same time. Again it's kind of like going to someone's house and waiting for food when you weren't expected to come. We did get our orders in and the food came out pretty quick after the ladies finished their prep.  When we were ordering, the lady made a joke that felt like it was an inside joke between the cooks about not giving me much vegetable as I requested extra. I sort of laughed but sort of got confused, so smh on that one.  I just laughed with them.

Me and my friend got vegetarian dishes which were mushroom tofu and the black bean tofu. Both were good and came with rice.  We also got the tea leaf salad which a small but good. It was a tad spicier for my friend, but we did like it. I will say despite the spiciness, I have had a better version of this salad at another place. The good thing is everything felt homemade. This place is definitely a mom and pop shop.

The biggest pro of this place is the prices are cheap, so that is what it has going. I would come back here again but not when there is a wait. If you want to try this place, I say go after 2 pm on a weekend.
author: Andrew N.

description:
Like most people mentioned. Food was ok, nothing special. But the service is terrible. If you understand Chinese they are very rude. Talking behind customers back, saying personal things about them.

I'm usually more then happy to support mom and pop spots. But the owner is plain rude for no reason.
author: hin y.

description:
Food: 
We come here for the house noodles. We have tried the: 
- fried rice (good, not great)
- tea leaf salad (its good, but nothing compared to what you get at other places)
- fish chowder soup (again, we have had better)....
But the house noodles are AMAZING! 

Location and Interior: 
Please do not expect much. They have a line outside sometimes and have just a few bar stools to sit on (and its still packed most times). But its not upscale or anything.
author: Rapunzel C.

description: I had high expectations from this place because it was recommended to me from an elite yelper friend.  Yamo definitely met those expectations.  Cheap for the quality and quantity of food that you get.  I really like the Yamo House Noodles.  It is simple but flavorful and fills you up.  The only thing that I did not like here is that it is really small and a bit cramped.  You sit on stools and eat at the counter in front of the kitchen.  It is kind of cool because you can watch them cook everything while you are waiting.  I came at that awkward hour between lunch and dinner so I got in right away.  However after I finished eating, there was a long line waiting to get in.  You get your own drinks in their refrigerator.  I would recommend getting soda because both the soda can and water bottle cost a dollar.
author: Dang L.

description: Great cheap food!! Small portions. Rude old lady... but use to her over the years lol family owned
author: Monica S.

description:
It's wrong to call it Burmese - their "mohinga" isn't. Samosas okay. 
Massively cheap, on mission burrito levels, but quite lazily done - if you care for noodle soups, try other places. If you got out from Bart, hungry, and wanna spend only 6$ go here.
author: Andy L.

description:
The hostess was a little socially awkward, but other than that, awesome place! Great food that they cook in front of you and a price you can't really beat. It was $6.25 for a plate of Curry Chicken on noodles!

Also, they only take cash, no credit/debit. And there's not too much room to sit--only 8 or so seats at the counter/bar.
author: Vasiliy M.

description:
Truth. The place doesn't look like much but the food is great. Went on a Yelp recommendation. Line was out the door on a Thursday night 30 mins before close. I didn't want to wait for one of the 5 seats so opted for take out.

Very modest prices and fair portions. Perfect size and price id say. The tea leaf salads while trendy is definitely gold at this place. It truly taste Burmese, and is only slightly under par of that from the local Burmese food truck.

The house noodles with beef were equally tastey but very simple.

It's the kind of place you know people put their heart into.

I look forward to trying the rest of the menu
author: Sarah S.

description: Really cramp space and rude customer service. The foods were okay, not good enough to get yelled at by the rude owner.
author: Matt H.

description:
What happened, Yamo?  I used to love you!  On my most recent visit, our tea leaf salad was exactly half the size as the person's sitting next to me, and everything else we ordered was greasy, greasy, greasy.  The mohinga soup was really thick and practically inedible, they put chicken atop our noodles when we asked for tofu, the egg rolls were missing their dipping sauce.  The other dishes were dripping in oil.  And it was an absolute ordeal to ask for glasses of water and tea.  I wouldn't even be writing this review if the food was still as tasty as before, but it really wasn't- the usual flavors just weren't there- it was all oil and salt.

And....when the older chefs are curt with customers?  Somewhat endearing.  When the younger employee (daughter of one of them, I believe) is blatantly rude to us and everyone else?  Not so much.
author: Joanne G.

description:
I love me a good hole-in-the-wall establishment and sadly, working in the Financial District, I don't get to go to them nearly as often as I'd like. So, I was totally looking forward to my lunch at Yamo. Heck, we even got there right as they opened because I'd read the place only seated 8 at a counter.

Luckily, we were the first people there at 11:30am and found a seat with no problem. But hot damn, I wish I'd brought a paper fan because it s HOT in there. I was sweating from the warm day, my proximity to the kitchen, and blazing stove. We threw caution to the wind and just ordered everything that looked good.

We started with the Burmese samosas and the Tea Salad. In all honesty, the wifey makes a better samosa but the tea salad was fantastic. Great textures and crunch! The portion was a bit small but for being under $6, it was great

We then went with the famed Mango Chicken and the House Noodles with Beef. Both were kinda meh. The Mango Chicken tasted like Panda Express type "Chinese" food and the noodles in the House Noodles were way overcooked. The beef was good but after dousing food in soy and sriracha, anything tastes good.

The place definitely has a Soup Nazi vibe, and it's probably worth going to at least once, but the food is not worth a repeat visit.
author: Nadeem A.

description:
My bf's favorite dinner spot in the Mission, so of course I've gotta try it! Very hole-in-the wall, very small and crowded. 

There were several people at the door waiting to get in at about 6:30pm on a Friday night that got much larger in the next 30 minutes or so that we were there. Part of the issue was there was a group of four (and I think the entire restaurant seats about 8), and even though there were 2 or 3 empty seats already, they wanted to wait until they had 4 consecutive seats together to go in. There were several groups of 2 behind them that could easily have sat down, but no, those empty seats went to waste.

As a result, we got impatient and just decided to order take-out - for that you can basically skip the line and go up to the counter to order. It took maybe 15-20 minutes, and please note that it's CASH ONLY!

For Burmese food, I generally expect it to be like Chinese but with much more intense and exotic flavors. I didn't really get from my meal - for Chinese food, it is solid and dirt cheap - great bang for your buck! But for Burmese, it let me down somewhat. Maybe my expectations were off.

* Tea Leaf Salad - 4 stars
Pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw#r0xprnCxEQGkuXWpDldz5A
Best dish of the night for me. Pretty spicy! I liked the mung beans and peanuts, which added a great crunch. This was definitely a unique dish. It could've been more fresh (it seemed kind of limp/squashed into the bottom of the takeout container - kind of sad-looking - but maybe that's because we got it to go, had to run to get cash, and then walked the 3 or 4 blocks home).

* Beef noodle - 3.5 stars
Pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw#b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw
The noodles were soft, the beef tender. Good but overall this could've used a lot more flavor.

* Tofu/veg - 3 stars
Pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw#vXwjYx5d1Tu-BZJPImZcmQ
My bf's favorite dish, and I have a hard time understanding why. This was not bad but I found it really plain and lacking in flavor. The tofu was soft and chewy, the skin chewy (not so much crispy).

* Dumplings - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw#f0DbxFv2Sh1UcV5tdApunQ
These had a really thick skin, and several of them had opened up. The filling was packed really tight, so that it made its own little densely packed ball with a lot of open space between it and the skin.

Menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=zo-creEoZpyOcqTp5dE_Pw#zo-creEoZpyOcqTp5dE_Pw
author: Ziyan C.

description:
"Yamo"? More like Ya-NO !!!
If I could give this place a negative score, I would without hesitation. 
I gave it a try because of a friends
Recommendation. I checked the Yelp reviews prior to going and thought, it says 4 stars, 1500+ reviews? Can't be bad. Well, boy was I miserably wrong. I ordered a beef and noodles plate and it was soaked in saturated oils. I could lift the plate and drain oil off the food. The taste was beyond greasy and unflavorful. I didn't want to complain to the rude chefs so I just decided to order a 2nd dish, which once again, was disgusting. I left hungry and with a pain in my stomach from the grease. I wouldn't even feed my two unfinished meals to a homeless person. 
If you are curious to try this place out, look past the 3-5 star reviews and read the 1 star reviews... They are 100% spot on.
author: Samantha R.

description:
I am so glad that I found this hole-in-the-wall from Yelp; this place really did not disappoint. First tip, it is Cash Only so make sure you bring enough but you can really get a lot of food for very cheap prices. Another tip, there really isn't much seating so I would recommend getting there early before the actual time you plan to eat or take it out. Lastly, chat it up with the waiter because she really was sassy, but in a good way!

We ordered some great dishes, everything we tried was good; some to name was the curry dish, the tea leave salad, and the house noodles. The portions are great and I was glad I came with a group of people so we ordered a number of dishes that we shared. One thing that I liked about Yamo is that it truly felt like I was eating in someone's home; the employees there were really friendly and it was truly unexpected. The food comes out really quick and it all tasted real good. Definitely will come back when I'm in the area.
author: Kevin C.

description: Tasty noodles. Small amount of meat. I wanted to pay more for mushrooms and the owner wouldn't do it. For extra money? Strange. Small portion. Owner was very rude.
author: Princess Jasmine J.

description: One of the worst noodle house experiences ever! The lady who runs this place is extremely rude and terrifying. She looks like she's constantly having a bad day. I don't get why this place has such a long line. The food is very BLAND. Save yourself the wait and find another spot.
author: Zeba K.

description:
What my friend kept referring to as "third dinner" that night, after Ssisso and Kitchen Kura. Yamo had been on my wishlist awhile, but after getting there I couldn't justify why.

The layout is like Art's Cafe but even tighter and without the love, despite a permanent Valentine's Day red wall with pink trim.

Jo from The Facts of Life (http://youtu.be/MY_bjsNkS9w) was barking orders, arguing with the other workers, and doing her part to ignore customers. Replete in a camo t-shirt, too.

I wasn't bugging about ol' Asian Jo or the stomach-turning smoke from the hoods. Bottom line is, the food wasn't all that. It wasn't even some of that. Or like a piece of that.

In fact, it was like a limit #ohsnap as x approaches infinity #whaaat of the asymptotic function f #goodlawd... yeah, you can really tell I'm trying to unscore the hipster points from this weekend.
author: Dan B.

description:
The wait for lunch on Saturday was about 15-20 minutes. Not too bad. It is a very small space with maybe 10 chairs total all lined up at the counter facing the chefs, so you need to stand in line outside the door on the sidewalk.

1) Cash only
2) No photos (the ladies will yell at you if you try to take photos of them)
3) Most dishes are only $6.25!! Awesome deal for delicious food

My friend recommended the house noodles and basically every photo on Yelp is of the house noodles so I decided to try them. I love the dish because the noodles are flavorful yet so simple at the same time. It's basically noodles, chicken, cilantro, and garlic. The chicken is also super tender and delicious even though it is chicken breast meat.
author: Rica Z.

description:
This place is the most "hole-in-the-wall" place I have been to and I'm sure I will be coming back quite often.

This place has 10 chairs max so if you come at a busy time, you may have to wait. The wait shouldn't be long, 15-20 min should get you a seat. Don't come here with a group of people, may be 2 or 3 max, because chances are you won't be able to sit together.

I ordered the tea salad and cold noodles.
Tea Salad - not sure where the tea part comes to play in this salad but it is delicious! Also spicy! I'm not the best at spicy food but I will definitely be ordering this again!
Cold Noodles - not what I was expecting. The sauce is thicker so its not as refreshing as I had hoped but it was still good! This was spicier than the salad so keep that in mind if you're not a spicy food type of person. 

Overall, this place is a good spot for a quick lunch lunch for one or two people.
author: Renee W.

description: I really like this place. This place is a place to eat and leave. Don't expect great service. Waited in line for this place and ordered even before sitting down. You kind of even feel rushed to eat. It's not a place to take your time to eat. However, it was delicious! Ordered the tea leaf salad and the house noodles. Goodness so good. Was just sad they were out of grass jelly drinks. They are also cash only and there is very limited seating. Be prepared to wait if you're coming during normal meal hours.
author: Julie L.

description:
There's Burma Love, which is a pricey hipster amazing Burmese place in the Mission. A few blocks away: Burma Love's uglier, greasier, but cheaper sister. 

Cash only.
$19 for Yamo house noodles, tea leaf salad, and black bean tofu (all enough to feed 2 people).

This hole-in-the-wall spot is tiny, with just a few places to sit, making it ideal for a solo traveler wanting to get in/out, but more likely will suit the likes of take-out peeps. 

Get ready to blot your mouth (grease) and add some Sriracha (it's pretty mild) but as far as Burmese goes, this is definitely second-place to Burma Love. I have yet to try Burma Star, but will let you know how that one stacks-up once I know :)
author: Stephanie T.

description:
If you're craving hearty and inexpensive Burmese & Chinese cuisine in a greasy hole-in-the-wall - this place will hit the spot.

As many others have pointed out, it's insanely small - literally just a bar with a couple of seats so come solo or come in a pair.

Favorite was the Curry Chicken Noodle soup - so frothy, thick and flavorful - also very unique to use a Coconut Curry base as the soup - yummmmm! For less than $7, this is a bargain for sure.

The Tea Leaf Salad was pretty small -.a serving was just a few spoonfuls - if you're hungry like me, order two portions.

Bring cash - cash only.
author: Veronica S.

description:
Tea Salad. House Noodles with Chicken. Samusas. $17. Yum.

We got take out since they have something like 8 stools and a line out the door. There are just 3 staff members working mighty hard so there can be a bit of a wait, but dang. Why did we wait so long to finally try what is both delicious and refreshingly affordable especially in comparison to other neighborhood haunts (see: artisanal chocolate/cheese/coffee/mustaches around the corner).
author: Nikki M.

description:
As holes in the wall go, Yamo is at the top. i told the owner that this wa my first time and asked for suggestion. She recommended House Noodles, which I took. Tasty food paired with real characters behind the bar. If you upto a challenge, try to squeeze a smile from the owner. She rivals famous Russians. When I was leaving, in response to my "Thank you!" the owner just raised her hand without turning her face to me. Seeing that raised hand, I felt like a winner. :D 

I'll certainly be back to try other dishes.
author: G S.

description:
I was looking for some Burmese food as I never had it before but what is there to tell about the place? I kind of have mixed feelings about the place. I personally like places like that Yamo, very small place with roughly 8-10 chairs on a bar, quite dark and a perfect view of what is going on in the "kitchen". The ladies seemed a bit disorganized but that was just an impression because they had their orders completely under control despite having people eating in, other ordering out and some ordering ahead via phone.
I had the Potstickers which are basically like fried dumplings, the Tea Leaf Salad which was very tasty but I'm still not sure why it is a TEA LEAF salad. Finally I had the Mango chicken with noodles (an extra 1,50$ or so) and got to say it's nothing special especially considering that the noodles are regular spaghetti and not some kind of Asian noodles. The veggies, chicken and sauce though were quite ok. Overall I'm not sure how closely Burmese food is related to other Asian food like Chinese but if no one had told me it's supposed to be Burmese I would have guessed Chinese. But that doesn't mean it wasn't tasty.
author: Martin H.

description:
This is the best place to go for good food in the city! 

There is definitely a wait to get in but it's not too long. There are about 10 seats in the house...but it's worth it! Food is awesome! We had the spring roll, veggie garlic noodles, and veggie curry. So good! Definitely going back for more! 

They run out of the samusas so get there early!
author: Akshaya V.

description:
So disappointed.
For $6.25, the tea salad's portion was so small... not worth it. 

At least the samusas were good though. For $4.50, that's not bad.

The service was terrible. Communication was so unclear....
author: Tina S.

description:
I can see why Yamo could be appealing. It's cheap, decent tasting Burmese food.

This place really is a hole in the wall located in the Mission. There's only counter seating which only its about 8 people. 

We ordered the House Noodles with beef, Fish Noodle Soup, and Chicken Noodle Soup. The counters aren't very clean and they were sticky. We waited a good 20 mins before our food was ready. We had to grab change for meter while waiting. Our food came out in an odd order as well. My fish noodle soup was ready first then the house noodles then the chicken noodle soup and finally the tea leaf salad. I felt the tea leaf salad should have been done first as it's more of an appetizer and have the entrees come out together or at least one after the other. We had two entrees out then about a 5 min gap until our last entree came out. The best dish was the HOUSE NOODLES and the tea leaf salad wasn't bad, but I wished the portion was bigger. The fish and chicken noodles soups were different, I haven't had noodle soups like it before, but not as flavorful as I had hoped or as amazing as I expected from the reviews.

Service is not only lacking, but slow and rude. I agree with other reviewers that the cookes/cashiers act as if they hate being there. But I didn't expect much from the service. I did however expected the food to come out faster.

But everything is cheap, under $10.

Parking is all street parking and depending on the day and time can be a bit difficult. Also CASH ONLY!

Many people order take out versus dining in. Personally, dining in experience isn't that great so if you live nearby, ordering take out would probably be more pleasurable. If I were to come back, I would order the house noodles to go.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Yamo is my favorite new gem in the Mission District. There is limited bar seating so the wait might be awhile, but the friendly service and incredibly flavorful Burmese food is worth every minute. They are super efficient with seating customers, and they usually take your order ahead of time if there is a wait. Check out the menu beforehand or while you are waiting.

My friend and I shared one appetizer and two entrees, which came out to be less than $20 total!! We first ordered the Mango Salad ($6) which has fresh mangoes, cabbage, onions, celery, and carrots. This is probably my favorite thing on the menu because it's fresh, sweet, and spicy.

My dish was the Yamo Cold Noodles ($6) which contains onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken. The flavor of the chicken itself overpowers the dish but in a good way. Because the noodles are fresh, they're still a little warm (not cold) when served, but I would still highly recommend this. My friend ordered the Curry Chicken ($6) which I found tasty as well, and I'm not usually a huge fan of curry.

Lastly, I love the dynamic of the ladies that run Yamo. Makes me feel like I'm at home. This place is a must-try!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
You can't order anything in San Francisco for $6.25 anymore. Obviously not the best Chinese/Burmese (not sure what it is?) food I've ever had but for the price its pretty damn good. It's also fasttt!

I would say the service is pretty harsh. Just three ladies slangin' noodles and screaming at you... but, when you come to a place like this you aren't paying for service. I would recommend takeout because the inside is somewhat stuffy and there are only maybe 6 seats. 

Ordered the mango chicken, potstickers and house noodles. All for a total of $17.00 (seriously wtf, how is this so cheap?). Anyways, will be back!
author: Amanda M.

description: Love this hole in the wall restaurant! Delish food made in front of you in a tiny restaurant where you'll get to know your neighbors. Can't beat this place for freshness and price. It may not be for everyone, but I think it's a gem.
author: Amy K.

description:
Absolutely over rated!
Ordered 2 house chicken noodles. Very salty, greasy, too much MSG. Rude owner. Will never come back.
author: Shirley W.

description:
Definitely not the most friendly staff/cook/owner, but the house noodle...is so good that will keep me coming back.  

Prices are also more agreeable.
author: Jing C.

description:
Been here twice - the first time, they forgot to put tea leaf in my tea leaf salad. The second time, they talked sh*t about a customer who didn't have cash. The chicken noodle soup was just ramen noodle, stir fried chicken (not shredded), raw shallots and raw green onion. With coconut soup poured on top that's not hot enough to cook the shallots and onion. So...you end up eating raw slices of onion in a soup that's too mild to cut the bite. 

Cheap for SF but half the quality of any decent place in LA.
author: Melissa W.

description:
This little hole in the wall is cheap and SO tasty! I particularly recommend the coconut chicken soup and the beef garlic noodles. Also the samosas. 

There are only 8 or so seats at the bar, and it gets packed around lunch and dinner, so usually I get takeout. Calling in an order ahead of time is the easiest/fastest way to do it. It is a really fun experience to eat at the place though, and people usually don't spend more than 20-30 minutes eating, so if possible, I recommend eating there at least once for the experience! 

The ladies who work here are loud but very sweet. They don't speak great English, but it's not really necessary - just choose tasty food off menu, order tasty food, eat tasty food, and pay the nice ladies. 

Doesn't look great from outside (on a questionable corner off Mission Street), but highly recommend this place!
author: Julia O T.

description: This place is terrible! The food is disgusting and the owner is mean, which made the whole dining experience painful. My friend and I came here knowing full well it was a hole-in-the-wall with a less-than-friendly owner lady. With those in mind, we expected amazing authentic Burmese/Chinese food to make up for the lackluster ambiance and service. What we experienced was salty Chinese food that didn't taste Burmese at all. The potstickers were way too gingery, the curry noodles were so salty (by the way, the lady refused to give us water to wash it down), and the stir fry veggies were a salty, soy saucey mess. There are far better and more authentic Burmese restaurants in SF and the Peninsula. Please save yourself and skip this restaurant. I really hope this place closes down.
author: Leslie F.

description:
The food: Being a vegan it is often hard to find places on the cheap side with delicious entrees but this restaurant exceeds those requests. Everything on the menu is $10 and under, which is honestly really refreshing when you live in the city. I get the stir-fried vegetable with noodles and I am never disappointed. I believe it's $6.50 if, I remember correctly, and extremely worth it. Of course my diet is limited so I can't experience many of the other things on their menu but my friends love everything else on it! We were able to feed four people with $25!! Amazing. 

The restaurant: Now please understand this is a hole in the wall restaurant so don't be expecting the best aesthetic. It is extremely tiny. The restaurant is basically the kitchen with a countertop and 8 stools; however, if you're just going to eat there then who really cares? It's usually very busy so I'd suggest getting it to go if you can. 

The service: Truthfully, I will admit that the service here isn't the best but it isn't horrible. I feel as if some people got spoiled off American restaurants and their high-standards for customer service. This restaurant is not like that. They aren't entirely rude but they will be if they feel disrespected. Just keep in mind that there is NO PHOTOS, it is CASH ONLY, and to be considerate of the people waiting to dine in. Know what you want, order it, eat it and leave. I've noticed people being upset that they rush them but when their restaurant is that tiny they just want to serve as many people as they possibly can. This isn't a restaurant were you sit and chit chat as you eat. You eat your food and leave. If that's too much pressure for you just take it to-go. 

Overall: Highly recommend this place if you are looking for a delicious cheap lunch/dinner.
author: Selena M.

description: Tasty & Affordable! Not much to say that you cannot conclude from the street. Minimal seating and cash only. If you are expecting friendly service and time to enjoy your meal, this is definitely not your place.  But if you want tasty food in a hurry look no further. Be careful as the 4 foot Burmese lady will bite your head without a moments notice, but will always conclude any conversation with a friendly, "Anything Else?"
author: John H.

description:
Worst service in SF! Maybe even in the whole California!!!

Came here during the weekend wanting to try a new spot. We were there around afternoon time. It wasn't too busy. Got seated right away. There were a total of 5 people in this tiny place including us. 8 barstools total. 

Glanced at the menu and got a few dishes to share since we just wanted to try the food. ( it was mid afternoon) And we were on a food hop. You'd think it would be as easy as in and out. But I thought wrong.

We ordered a few noodle dishes and tea leaf salad. The ladies were not in the best of mood. Not even slightly pleasant. It's like we invaded their house and are making them cook at the knife point. Serious attitude and rudeness were served right away- free of charge!! 

We ignored it. Maybe the food is that good. Maybe they just needed a nap. Well we were wrong. We started taking pictures as our food arrived. The coconut noodles dish. Mind you, we were sitting on the counter top. There isn't a way to take the picture without getting the kitchen or the chef. At least not where I was sitting anyways. What came later was a series of nasty curses!!!!!

My friend kindly translated to me what was being said. Something along the line of ***those B****, A**h****, WTF, Wh*** taking my pictures. I F*****ing hate these F****. $%^&#$%^&*%$%&***  in their language no less!! And my friend called them out on it because he speaks the same damn language!!!!! Or replied something.

 All they said was well..No picture!! No apology, nothing. We wanted to throw the food back in their rude kitchen for them. Never having to listen to such abuse for taking a picture, we waited for all our dishes. Tasted one or two out of four! Paid and left. The horror!! The rude, the nasty horror! Can't pay me enough to return!! Ever.
author: Latifa S.

description: Ah gosh, I wanna love this place as it's is a hole in the wall run by two sassy asian women...but once you've had real Burmese food you will see that their dishes really aren't anything special. The classic Burmese fish stew, was all sauce and barely and fish flavor. Most other dishes are more reminence of Chinese stir fry dishes, honestly. If you aren't picky about true authenticity then it's a solid option. Their food is cooked fresh hot to order. Best dish hands down is the tea leaf salad, but a bit overpriced for a small place serving. Only bottle watered and very limited seating.
