It's a nice environment to see it all happen in front of you and always a great chuckle to see the asian woman yelling at customers.
author: Christy C.

description:
I had the pleasure of coming here around 6pm on a Wednesday afternoon/evening (not entirely sure what 6pm is officially classified as being...) and I was initially quite surprised  -- not in a bad way, at least not necessarily. Perhaps I didn't read enough reviews before coming to Yamo, but I had absolutely no idea that it's a very small hole-in-the-wall, with the food you order cooked in front of you and around eight stools for customers to sit on at the counter (that is essentially the entirety of the small food establishment). Yamo is extremely authentic -- the women working behind the counter are experts in crafting the items on the menu, and it was fascinating for me to have the opportunity to watch my meal get made. I ordered the standard Yamo noodle dish with chicken and I was astonished at how flavorful and plentiful the meal was -- and the best part, it cost less than $7! However, Yamo is CASH ONLY, and that's an extremely important thing to note. I got lucky that one Wednesday afternoon/evening (still not sure which it was) because I typically don't carry cash on me (bad habit -- millennials....). 

Anyhow, I had an excellent time by myself at Yamo. I didn't feel lonely because of the tight-knit, more personal experience that I had there. The cost of my meal was extremely reasonable -- especially considering the fact that Yamo is in the Mission -- and its location is extremely convenient for those who would like to get to the BART station (just two blocks away I believe). I'll be back again -- for a casual meal by myself, or perhaps with a friend or two.
author: Persis S.

description:
Amazing hole in the wall Burmese/Chinese food. We got 2 tea leaf salads, 1 samosa order, 1 black bean fish with noodles, 1 house noodle, and 1 chicken curry. All for $39 (not including tip).

I'd say the food is all around a 4 star rating, but the fact that it's run by 3 no-nonsense women, who are busting their butts with this small restaurant, makes it an overall 5 star for me.

They're also extremely nice, as my group of 4 walked in about 30 min until closing, and they encouraged us to stay like how an Asian grandma tells you to drink soup - kind of yell/command/talk tone. But, like the OGs they were, they got our orders, served our food, and we left with our bellies full. 

I'll be back!
author: Evelyn M.

description:
WOOOO! My tour guide Barbie took us out here for lunch today and holy moly... it was hot in here! There is no AC and definitely no ventilation. I was dripping in sweat and had to force myself to wolf down my food cause it was just too hot. I wished I didn't have to so I could've enjoyed my food a little bit more... 

Anyways! I was so surprised when she took us here because she said it was a hole in the wall... and she was on point. It was literally a hole in the wall. They have a counter and a few seats. You can see them make everything and prep. Service is typical of any Asian restaurant but they made sure our water was filled! GOOD for me. I ordered the cold noodles and it was very flavorful. It was spicy but kind of tangy at the same time. Next time I want to try the House Noodles cause that smelled and looked really good. Also, super friggin cheap. WINNING.
author: Kenitha Y.

description:
Oh Yamo, I'm beyond happy you exist. Having spent 3 weeks in Burma and some time along the Thai border I was so excited to try this little hole-in-the-wall.  I have not had tea leaf salad since my blissful backpacking days. 

Tealeaf salad - The flavor is surprisingly and deliciously spot on. My only complaint is the portion size. They go really light on the beans - wouldn't hurt to throw some more crunchiness on there. Nonetheless, there is a restaurant within 2 miles of me that sells tea leaf salad that's not only passable, but freakin' amazing! The punch in flavor is exactly what I miss. It's not too sour, it's the right salty. It's the best!

House noodles - not sure about authenticity here, but it did remind of oiled up Shan noodles and however YAMO seasons and cooks their beef is working for them and for their customers. I totally get why this is a best seller and I can't wait for my next time.

Other things to remember. This place is REALLY small. There's almost always a wait. Don't try to save a seat for a friend, you'll get shooed aside quickly. But people are in and out and don't linger, so be patient!
author: Priti K.

description: Dont plan on sitting in there.  Pretty damn good food.  Cheap and great! You are gonna wait for your food outside though...think of dining in a hallway with seats. They really should look into seats outside or at least milk crates/buckets for people.  Really good for the price...dont be in  a hurry and you will be fine ya know.  You can get a beer at the grocery store across the street while you wait. 420 store on the corner. Go entertain yourselves while you wait.
author: Kirk F.

description:
I stopped by Yamo last night with a friend and got seated almost immediately! 

We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, the Yamo House Noodles with chicken and the Mango Chicken. The tea leaf salad was really good - just the right levels of spicy and tangy. The noodles and the mango chicken were also excellent. Definitely would get them again.

Sitting inside is a little stuffy and you will definitely smell like grease afterwards, so I would recommend getting it to go!
author: Jessica Z.

description:
Came in sat down to order while the bf went to the atm.  I was told to wait outside as soon as I told them we were a party of 2.  Luckily he came back from and we grabbed some seats.  We  ordered the tea leaf salad, Yamo house noodles, and mango chicken.  All tasted really good even though the mango chicken seemed off. 

Then we noticed that we were actually eating the girl next to us cold noodles, which were actually not cold. Since the girl next to us complained she received the wrong dish they slam the mango chicken on the counter next to us. Since we already started eating we ended up with both dishes. Then it got really awkward as the girl glares at us while we eat and they take forever to replace her food. 

Next up a odd couple comes in one singing and the other just kinda being loud with her request.  Some how her pot sticker sauce wasn't right for her.  Think she was expecting some type of sweet and sour sauce.  So she asked for another sauce, but basically told no.  Then she asked for the chili sauce calling it the sweet and spicy sauce and told no that's not sweet!  Then this is when It gets good. Then all the sudden she tells the lady at the counter there was a hair on the pot stickers.  Oh the look on the ladies face behind the counter.  She grabs the dish throws it out and says "No more!"  Tried so hard to keep it together.

We hurry get the check and notice we were charged for the dish we did not order, but we just decided let it go. So end of story really tasty food, angry service, very tight space, and I wouldn't recommend making any complaints.
author: Nick J.

description:
Got here and found a seat at the end of the counter with a friend. We were waiting a while thinking that maybe she is just getting things ready at the beginning of dinner and that she will get to us, but she kept helping other people and not acknowledging us at all. I asked her if we can order and she so rudely replied that she is coming, coming. We kept waiting... and FINALLY she comes. Oh my goodness, I know of bad service in Asian restaurants but this lady took the cake!

So we ordered tea leaf salad - good but nothing significantly special, house noodles with beef which are good, and mango chicken which was not so great and the mangoes were sour and hard. The food was okay but I didn't feel like it was extraordinary and definitely not worth it for the rudeness we encountered. Took forever also to even ask for the check so we just left cash and left. No thanks!
author: Katherine L.

description:
For the price you pay, you get a good amount of food and the quality is great. My go to is the Yamo House Warm Noodles with pork but all the meat is pretty good. If I decide to eat something else, I go with the Catfish stew which is also delicious.

The place is the tiny so be prepared for a long wait or call in and get take out.
author: Dylan T.

description:
I like hole-in-the-wall restaurants, you get mom and pop's cooking and with good value.  I usually don't expect much of the service and ambience from places like this but I never seen bad treatment from the owner like this before (the owner was rude to everyone, not just me).   I happened to be near the area, decided to come in here because of 4 star review and decent pictures.    I sat down the counter and started to order, the owner face was frown and looks angry.  She took my order fine, then when I order the drink, she just told me to go get it myself.  At this point, I was still ok.  My tea salad was good, but very small portion of just cabbage ($6.50), but the house noodle came with very little meat and the portion was also small ($6.50), but the problem is the sauce was so greasy and SALTY!!! I asked if I could have some shredded cabbage to balance out the saltiness, she said "NO!" - then I offered to pay for the cabbage, she just shook her head..  I was just laughing away..    Next to my seat there was couple and after they paid, the owner was pushing their tea cups away to tell to pick it up!  That was just nut!  Looks like she just had a bad day, but please don't take it out on the customers!  I'm all supportive of small businesses but this lady should treat people nicer.  About the price, it seems like cheap, but you need to order a couple dishes - so it's better to go to a Vietnamese, Chinese or Mexican restaurant to get a decent size of food for about the same price.

Check out other 1 star reviews and you will see... This is beyond "don't expect 5 star treatment"...
author: Tom V.

description:
This is how my visit to Yamo went down. 

Friend: Their Tea salad is great. Definitely recommend. 
Me: Out of all their items, you recommend a salad? 
Friend: It's really good. 

So we wait about 30 minutes to get into this place because it's basically a hole in the wall that seats 8 people at any one time at a bar like setting We order a few things to try since their pricing is quite reasonable. $4-6 per item if I remember correctly. 

Ordered their Tea salad (of course), yamo house noodles with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and black bean fish for our group of 3. Tea salad was really delicious. It's comprised of a lot of deep fried onions, which gives the salad a nice crunch to it. You really have to just try it out. The dish is rather small so I'd get one for myself next time. Yamo House noodles with pork was really simple. Just noodles with stir fried pork. There wasn't too much seasoning that I could see, but it was still rather tasty. Fish chowder noodle soup was probably my favorite. I don't know what was the crispy bit of the soup was, but it created a great texture contrast to the soup, which I loved. The black bean fish dish was probably my least favorite of the 4. It was good, but I think I'm used to the black beans not being so strong. I prefer a more subtle taste. 

Our four dishes totaled up to $24 and for $8 per person, that's a pretty sweet deal.
author: Mai K.

description:
One of the ladies screamed at me to not take any pictures with my phone even though they had no sign that said to not take pics.
Ordered samusas that tasted mediocre. This place seems overhyped for me
author: Jiggy B.

description:
This is for sure one of my favorite hidden gems in SF. Brought a friend from out of town to try and I think he was pretty impressed. He said he felt like he was eating in Asia. Can't really get this type of hole-in-the-wall experience elsewhere in city. 

Best time to come is the weird hour. Between lunch and dinner (3-4pm) so you don't have to wait. There's only about 10 counter-bar seats so you can imagine how quick this place could fill up during normal eating times. 

Order #5, the tea leaf salad and #15, the Yamo House noodles with beef. These noodles are the best! My comfort food! And then afterwards, walk over two blocks to Bi-Rite and wash it down with the best ice cream in the city!
author: Amy X.

description: The worse hole in a wall I ever been to!  They only gave me 3 little sliced of chicken and no fried garlic.  The 3 women who work there talked soo loud in their whatever language it is.  The WORSE tasting food, worse service.
author: Elyza S.

description: A tried and tested establishment. Best noodles of your life. Don't be fooled by the poor decor. Take the plunge, order the house noodles, don't make eye contact! #yolo
author: Ali Y.

description:
SO GOOD. Seriously. Eyes rolling back into your head good. 

Was looking for a cheap + quick, late solo-lunch and found my ideal spot here. Only about 8 spots at a counter and a very "gritty" feel. Once you get a menu from one of the women bustling around behind the counter and order, the food is served very quickly. I ordered the coconut chicken noodle soup and it was truly incredible; the red onion with the coconut milk broth was a unique, perfect combination and the soup was cheap (7 dollars), came in a huge portion, and was full of delicious noodles. I am not a soup person at all--in fact I don't even really consider it to be food, nevertheless a meal--but this soup was definitely a meal (and a very memorable one at that).
author: Gianna D.

description: Cheap and fast hole-in-the-wall. Try cold noodles and tea leaf salad. Great place to grab some take-out and walk a block to Dolores park to enjoy eating it :)
author: Natasha K.

description: This place is a whole in the wall that will transport you to another land for the duration of your meal. As soon as you step in you are yelled at to sit by the three bad ass women that run this foundation. They are sassy and I'm loving all of it. They let you know when they are ready for your order and by the looks of the intimate chats and steaming dishes you best order when you get the chance to. I had the chicken noodle soup and with some sprucing up with the spices and soy, this dish is a hands down winner. No doubt about it I would get it if I was sick in bed or out on the streets getting flashy, great price, flavor and authenticity to its region. The place has a great vibe that could only be known to locals in the city. Wait the line to get in its worth it! Btw CASH ONLY
author: Brittany C.

description:
Food is amazing, one of the best Burmese place! There are couple reasons that I'm take off three stars. 
First star, they only have 8-9 seats in there. And it's very smoky and oily inside. There's always a lines due to the minimum seating. If you want to skip the wait, I advice you going early May be around 5.
Second star, the food portion is very very small. I'm tiny, and I don't eat that much, but their portion on the tea-leaf salad is just so small. I wouldn't recommend sharing it. 
Third star, which also one of the major reason I hesitate to go eat here every times. Their customer service is EXTREMELY horrible. They have the worst worst worst customer service compare to any restaurant I have ever been to. They would literally yell at you if you come in close to their closing time or if you dare to ask for salt for your foods. 



I love their food, but I do not think they deserve a penny of tips from me. If I even go back again, I will only ORDER for to go, just to skip all the attitude from them!
author: Jasmine Y.

description:
When it comes to Burmese good... These three gals know what's up. Before writing my review- I wanted to read some of the bad reviews... To get a chuckle.. Face it...these three women have to deal with all the assholes the pretentious the crazies the over entitled . You name it. I hear people making reviews about omg it's only 8 seats.. She's mean to me..(hey whatever sometimes I'm afraid to ask for a refill of water) 

BUT

You all wait.
You all bring new people here.
You all order Tea leaf salad.
And you all are thankful that the prices are low and the food is flavorful. 

They are some extremely hard working women--and Yamo is a SENSATION. 

To you three women I will  always keep coming back. 

You rock.
author: Chris L.

description:
Guys say girls are frustrating. I beg to differ. Guys frustrate the sh*t out of me...

Q: "I'm NEVER eating out with you again...you're high maintenance...you pick all the bougie places and spend more time doing a food porn photo shoot than eating."
Me: "Fine, whatever..."  

ONE WEEK LATER...
 
Q: "Let's go eat."
Me: "Uhh, don't you remember what you said last week?"
Q: "Huh? Let's eat...you pick."
Me: "American ok? I can't have MSG because I'm allergic and I'm trying to stay away from carbs."
Q: "PHO!"
Me: "I can't have MSG because I'm allergic and I'm trying to stay away from carbs."
Q: "Turtle Tower!"
Me: "Dude!!!! I can't have MSG..."
Q: "Aww, why not? Pho at Turtle Tower!"
Me *B-R-E-A-T-H-E*: "Let's go to Yamo. It's a hole-in-the-wall, they don't use MSG, and they have soup for you."
Q: "Ohh, I like hole-in-the-walls."

*Arrives at Yamo*

Q: "It's so small and dingy and there's a line. It's all bok gwais here, not a good sign."
Me: "It's a hole-in-the-wall and we're in The Mission."

*Sits down*

Q: "It's so hot and tight in here."
Me: "Just order."

*Food comes*

Q: "Dayam, the potstickers are hella good...the house noodles...DAYAAAM..." *oil dribbles down mouth*

*3 minutes later*

Me *looks at empty plates*: "What the heezy, you're DONE already?!?!?"
Q *rubs belly*: "It's so hot and tight in here...I smell like grease."

WHO'S BOUGIE NOW?

OTHER NOTES:
*Cheap eats: appetizers - $4 and salad, soups, rice and noodle dishes - $6. NO MSG. 
*Rude and fast service.
*Expect a wait during peak hours. It was a 15 minute wait at 2 PM on a Saturday. 
*8 seats. 10 seats total if they decide to add two extra chairs at the edge of the counter that day.
*Most popular dishes:
-Tea Leaf Salad ($6): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=iLuobb5t4WvdJ89NQsnZ7g#iLuobb5t4WvdJ89NQsnZ7g
-House Noodles ($6): No pic because someone prematurely dove in. Guys. No surprise. 
-Mohinga is the national dish of Burma. Super thick and creamy catfish chowder was the perfect hangover cure along with fresh coconut juice: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=iLuobb5t4WvdJ89NQsnZ7g#U99E-5MGgXTG8ayohEfeew
*CASH ONLY
author: Cherylynn N.

description: Shitty attitude and really salty food. I am traveling from LA to SF. Don't worth a cent! Trust me.
author: Gary Jiarong Z.

description: I went to yamo because the high rated by yelp and super disappointed ! From lunch till minnight I drunk tons of water. I think the salt I ate in the past whole year less than this one meal! My three dishes totally 7pieces of meat(beef noodle , chicken curry rice and a fish dish) and very oily. Is this place famous by oily and super salty?! !
author: Kate N.

description: Food was meh. Service absolutely terrible, which would have been funny if I didn't have to wait a while for both my food, and my drink which they pulled out of the fridge and put within eyesight but didn't hand to me for 5 minutes. Not worth even a ridiculously check meal - I'll pay more for better food, better service and *alcohol!
author: Sarah H.

description: Yamo is a small, dingy, hole-in-the-wall kind of spot. The service isn't great either. But the food! Yum. You can get a full meal here for under $10 (house noodles with chicken, anyone?).
author: Melissah L.

description:
After reading such great reviews, I knew I had to try Yamo. I have to say I was kind of disappointed. The tea salad was great. I loved the texture from the beans. The crunch and spiciness made a great combination. House noodles were good, but nothing rave worthy. Chicken was dry too. 

I didn't enjoy the samosas or the curry. The curry, though filled with spices, just seemed... Off. I'm not quite sure how to describe it. The balance just wasn't quite right. 

Women working there were rude and abrupt. Food comes quickly though, which is great. Don't forget, this place is CASH ONLY. At such a cheap price, I'll probably come back. I just feel like this place has been overhyped.
author: Winnie T.

description:
That is really feel so bad ... And unbelievable.. Ahh....I thought this is Burma restaurant.... I ask my language and she look like she doesn't know ... So feel really really angry and I ask then is it Burma restaurant ? 
she say yes . .. 
I was coming this restaurant all the way down .. Like 25 mins walk ... When I found it .. Honestly I was so happy that I can get my Burma food .. But so bad they don't know what I say ... Well, let's be... So I go to other place .. I am not sure it is good taste or not ! But I am not going to eat here ... But it make me so disappointed!! 
So upset!!  I recommend that if you are Burmese don't go to try there .. Don't know why this restaurant got 4 stars .. If have 0 star I will give it too ..
author: Zaw Win T.

description: First time here and I ordered the tea leaf salad, mango salad, house noodle with chicken, and black bean fish. I liked the salads for their potent flavors, though I thought they were sort of drenched in their sauces. I've had black bean fish/clams/veg at lots of places and I thought this version was a little mild and bland - maybe it needed more garlic and more fermented beans? The noodles were homey and simple. Food was 3.5 stars for me but the awesome (low) prices makes me round up!
author: Jean L.

description:
I don't know how they even get such a high rating and reviews on Yelp. I came here cuz of great reviews and high ratings. Customer Service here doesn't and food wasn't great. This place is shit in the hole. 

I order 2 bowls of house noodles, one with beef and the other with chicken. Both wasn't bad but it wasn't great. To top it off, the lady was rude the entire time when I've been kind and ordered with politeness. I could easily throw the bowl at her face if I wanted to, that's how rude she was.
author: Hung V.

description: I've been here twice, and want to come back enough times to try everything on the menu! I've had the tea leaf salad, fish stew, and some dry noodle dish (don't remember the exact one), and they were all delicious. Egg rolls, I could have done without, as they were pretty generic. The only downside is that the head lady in charge is not the nicest, but so it goes. Worth it, for the deliciousness!
author: Shendi X.

description: One of my favorite place in the city. Crazy cheap and tasty
author: Deon R.

description:
"It feels like an honor to eat here because it's like you're being invited into someone's kitchen" said the guy sitting next to us as his arm rubbed up against my friends in the crevice of a kitchen. 

And it is true, Yamo is a remodeled closet turned kitchen. The intimate space only allows for 8 diners at a time who are sitting elbow to elbow as we greedily wait for our food to arrive. While the menu is small, all on one page, it's a difficult choice to make as all the options sound good and are $6 and under per plate. From tea leaf salad to mohinga (fish) chowder and house noodles, the stomach can't help but to be dazed by the options.

The counter lady/chef who has "invited" you into her kitchen is sassy and snappy, and honestly a little indifferent to your needs. This is no loving mother who feels the need to heal all your emotional wounds with her food. She's just trying to get through the long day herself, so please don't expect a coddling mother, this is the mother who has literally been slaving in the kitchen all day, and doesn't have time for your shenanigans. 

The order of house noodles with pork came out in a sheen of heavy oil that can only mean heavy food coma later. But oh how FRESH those noodles were. We slurped up those slippery suckers in what seemed like mere seconds. We had debated on whether or not the tea leaf salad was a little too interesting for our tastes, but ended up getting it and we regret nothing. The tangy & spicy crunch was the perfect side dish that offered a refreshing lift from the heavy noodles. The samusas really stretched our jeans to their limits with the hearty potato and spice filling. $16 bucks for 2 people and a jean waistband about to pop? So worth it.   

So save your change (they are cash only) ladies and gentleman and you too could have a fine meal at Yamo like the 1299 who have come before you!
author: Joyce K.

description: Very solid little place. It is a joke in the wall and anyone expecting fine dining out of this place is just silly. It is however the exact kind of good old Chinese food that isn't really Chinese but you love it because it satisfies that craving but also is crazy fresh (unlike Panda Express type places where food was frozen and cooked hours ago. Heads up though-The tea leaf salad is great but SUPER spicy! I had to give mine away.
author: Sophia B.

description:
Really, C'mon People.

Foiled by the Hipsters again!

I was so disappointed. I didn't even finish my meal & stomach has been upset ever since (******actually THREW UP later that day).


*I do give a shout out for the ladies for producing the food...'cause they sure stay busy!
-***but need to give the people what they want.  The guy sitting next to me offered to pay more for extra meat in his noodles and they refused..   In that sense the food was mechanically cranked out w/ little care for the end result.


Tea Leaf Salad--  What is all the fuss about?  
Indistinguishable sweet, Indistinguishable tart...the only flavor I tasted was Onions.
Will folks just stop w/ the sensationalist obsession w/ the so-called "Exotic".  SOOO tired. PLEASE!

Fish Noodle Stew--- Where was the fish?  Cause all I got in MY bowl was a watered down, unseasoned broth with shreds reminiscent of catfish.  Really people? Really???

Also--REALLY need to fix the ventilation.  Halfway through the meal my eyes were ON FIRE & BLOOD SHOT from all the smoke (good thing I packed my eyedrops).  Couldn't even finish eating if I wanted to (And this Is coming from a person that has previously lived in air-polluted Beijing!)

Needless to say Cheaply priced. True...but TASTELESS (felt like I was gnawing on air & styrofoam)  & NOT worth the tummy ache
author: Chapstiq G.

description:
I love yamo! I've heard so many great things about it, but I didn't make an effort to stop by. When I finally did, I fell in love immediately. If you like comfort asian food, you'll love this place. The flavors are so homey and so delicious. I love their tea salad and their house noodles (Those are the only two dishes I've tried so far). I'll definitely be back for more! 

Things to note:  It is a tiny hole in the wall. Cash only, and they do take out. If you grab take out, make sure you eat it immediately. It doesn't taste the same once it gets cold. I recommend it eating it there when they're less busy. I stopped by once at around 3pm on a weekday and the little restaurant still had tons of business. There wasn't a wait though!
author: Annie Z.

description: Amazing value! There is literally no cheaper and yummier spot in the city. I love that the cooking is done in front of you. Very unfriendly elderly cooks but so traditional. A literal amazing hole in the wall. Everything is a go but the must haves for me; tea leaf salad, beef noodles and coconut chicken noodle soup!
author: Natalia G.

description:
How the mighty have fallen. This food is a salty, pallid insult to the fine cuisine this establishment used to create. I got three dishes last night, the tea leaf salad (devoid of tea leaves as the previous reviewer noted), the house noodles with beef (too salty, no curry flavor and missing most of the beef), and the cocoanut chicken noodle soup (best of the three but not good like in the past).
I was going to give one star, but they've kept the prices down for the most part - pricing all the $6 dishes up to $6.25, and perhaps they're just misguided so I will give two for old time's sake. 
Please allow me to offer some advice. Raise the prices to whatever you need to raise them to, so that the food can be like it was a year or two ago. I wouldn't go there again for the food I had last night even if it were free.
author: Steven P.

description:
OH HELL YEAH. I'm so happy I finally got to try this place.

The Yamo House Noodle is everything an definitely lives up to the hype. So simple but so freaking good. It's just noodle + meat + dried garlic. And that's really all you need. I believe it's $6.

Small hole in the wall place - I think 8-10 seats. But since the menu is so small and it's not really a place to hang out, turnover is fairly fast. OR, get take-out. If you sit down, you'll probably smell like food anyway because the stove and kitchen is right in front of you.

CASH ONLY.
Defiiiiintely going to come more often when I'm around the Dolores Park area.
author: Emily C.

description: Definitely my favorite hole in the wall restaurant in the mission. Great for takeout but also fun to eat in at the counter and watch them cook your food. The potstickers are some of the best I've ever had and the tea leaf salad is not to be missed!
author: Jordan M.

description: This is the bomb. Wonder how Anthony bourdain missed this spot. Absolute favorite. Get the samosa & chicken noodle soup.
author: Aj P.

description:
house noodles w/ beef, fish chowder, tea leaf salad ~~ 

come for the excellent food, stay for surrogate tiger mom
author: Tiffany S.

description:
Personally, I don't mind being screamed at by old asian ladies. It makes me feel right at home. 

What disappointed me about Yamo was not the service (or lack of) but the food itself. Everything is around $6 bucks but the portions are sooo small that you definitely need two orders per person. Small portions aside, the proportion of meat to carbs is just way off. For example, the famous house noodles with beef comes with 5 tiny pieces of beef. The rest is just bland noodles without any toppings or condiments. The tea salad was also a let down. I didn't even taste any lahpet in the tea salad! It was more of a 3 ingredient chopped lettuce salad. 

2 stars for the price and convenience. I would rather pay a bit more at Burma Superstar/Burma Love.

Tip-- Make sure you don't come right when they're suppose to open. They're always late! I've waited outside for over 30 minutes before anyone came to open up shop.
author: Xinxin W.

description:
A friend brought me here once
an

just my favorite place ever

people working here are very nice to me though; sometimes I think I'm extremely annoying :C

: 3 : 3 10/10 go here as often as possible : 3

don't go though ; because then I won't have a seat :C
author: Robert P.

description: I've eaten here many times and have been mildly amused by the sheer distaste this angry women have for their customers.. but honestly the food is mediocre Costco filler. After being ignored, yelled at and then asked to wait outside in the rain all in the name of a lukewarm bowl of sub-par noodles, I won't be back.
author: Megan D.

description: House noodles with pork! And don't you dare choose anything else, you're mouth will thank me later.
author: Sep N.

description: Hole in the wall, cheap Burmese food. The cooks are a BIT on the grumpy side but they gotta deal with overpaid/trust fund hipsters all day so I'd be cranky too. When I'm sick and willing to splurge (for me, any eating not at home is a splurge), I settle into one of the 10 stools and slurp away. I don't eat much meat so this place is perfect for me to feel satisfied but still healthy. Not possible for big groups; think of this as a solo or MAYBE 2 people meal.
author: Katey W.

description: WORST place I've ever gone. Never go back even you pay me $. Totally don't understand why it has 4 stars. Worst environment and worst service. Oh no. They didn't provide any service.
author: Layla T.

description:
I am huge huge fan of Burma Superstar and Burma Love, and even enjoy the food at Rangoon Ruby in Palo Alto, so I was excited to see what Yamo had in store when I visited for the first time last week.  My BF and I were lucky to snag a seat after only about a 5-minute wait at 6pm Friday evening.  I had heard that Yamo is a hole-in-the wall, so I tempered my expectations on cleanliness, courtesy and comfort accordingly and we squished in on the bar stool.

As we placed our orders - tea leaf salad, mango chicken, and house noodles with beef, we glanced around anxiously to see what everyone else had ordered, and were glad that we had chosen correctly.  However when the food came back, I was a little disappointed in the portions.  Don't get me wrong, $6.25 for a dish in SF is a steal, but the portions are probably half of what you would get at a standard Chinese take-out place, and none of the dishes were particularly savory.  Especially the tea leaf salad which was like cabbage and onions doused in sweet sticky sauce; I couldn't even taste a hint of the tea leaves.  Because it is all pre-mixed before it comes to you (I'm used to this dish being separated when presented tableside), you have no idea what is in it. 

The mango chicken was fine, but is more like sweet and sour chicken.  The best dish was the house noodles with beef, and the beef portions were minuscule (as with all the other meat portions) and the noodles slippery and greasy. Since we were still hungry after the 3 dishes, we also got the curry chicken soup - there were maybe 5 tiny slivers of chicken and the broth was very bland.

I have trouble categorizing this as Burmese food.  It seemed like an oily, not-as-flavorful variation of Chinese food from your typical Chinese takeout restaurant on the corner, and I didn't think it warranted any comparisons to the other more well-known Burmese establishments in SF.  Props to the older ladies behind the counter who cranked out the dishes; one of them was even wearing a wool beanie as she stir fried everything as if she could do it blindfolded.

$30 for dinner for two isn't bad, but I would definitely prefer to spend 2x more on quality REAL Burmese food any other day, and eat at home the rest of the time.  I left smelling like oil and grease and still a bit hungry, but thankfully Bi-Rite Creamery is just up the street!
author: Mengo Z.

description:
Bottom line: All the NOPE. All. Of. Them.
I went here one day off the recommendation of my co-worker. Boy, what a mistake. I ordered the noodles with beef and was thoroughly disappointed. The noodles were soft and slimy, flavorless and the beef was not only sparse but tasted really sour like it was on the verge of spoiling. The "meal" was not very filling since it was a really small portion. My stomach was upset for the rest of the day after eating there and I really feel it was because of that sour-tasting beef. I absolutely will not be back here again.
author: Liz S.

description: This place makes me upset that I live on the east coast. The food here is just outstanding. Authentic Burmese dishes at really reasonable prices in a no non sense kitchen is my kind of language. It is really a hole in the wall with maybe 8 seats total but all with a front row seat to the cooking action. I was truly blown away by the tea leaf salad (I don't even know what tea leaves are but they taste great!). Yea it was a small portion but it was $3.50... I've seen places serve a salad that small and charge $10. The house noodles with beef was life changing, as in what do I need to do to eat here everyday for the rest of my life? As I ate each bite I marveled at the texture of the noodles and the flavor of the sauce. The beef was thinly sliced and nicely charred, muy sexy. A very satisfying meal that I hope to enjoy again soon!
author: Nina S.

description:
Yamo gets five stars for nailing it over-all. The food is cheap, great and fast; the atmosphere is cozy, vibrant and fun. You aren't going to get the most authentic burmese, or the best, but the rest more than makes up for it. Pickup is great, only takes 10m to make - just don't be surprised when they hangup the phone without saying goodbye when you place your order :p

Favorites are the Cold Noodle with Chicken, the Tea Salad, and the Curry Chicken. House Noodles with Beef and Mango Chicken are pretty good too.
author: Tyler M.

description:
I found this no frills, hole in the wall place mediocre in terms of food.

As they only seats about 10 people, my family of 5 opted to takeout. As expected for this type of place, the service wasn't anything great. The ladies working are no nonsense and abrupt, and expected us to wait outside while our food was cooking (which was understandable, given that it was a bit cramped inside). They were also reluctant to give us the amount of forks that we needed. 

Aside from the service and ambience, the food was okay, but nothing amazing. We ordered the tea salad, house noodles with chicken, black bean fish, and fried rice. For me, everything was on the salty and oily side, and left me feeling a little greasy afterwards. There weren't really any flavors that stuck out to me from the food. I did like that many of the dishes were pretty spicy, but this may not always work out for those who do not eat spicy food. However, for the price, this place isn't bad.
author: Karissa Y.

description:
Delicious food, big portions, cheap prices (cash only), 9 stools in a tiny hole in the wall joint. Wasn't disappointed after a lot of build up from friends/review stalking! Got some sass, but still good service.

House noodles with beef: flavorful and oily as expected, crispy beef and garlic added good textural contrast to the noodles. Only complaint is they were stingy with the beef, I had more than half the noodles left when I finished the beef. Will be coming back for this!

Chicken noodle soup: huge portion! Broth was delicious with coconut and onions, but again they skimped on protein- I probably got just 3 small pieces of chicken in my large bowl of noodle soup. 
Noodles also were in a large clump and hard to separate.
author: Erica D.

description:
Tea leaf salad does NOT have any tea leaf!!! If you've ever ordered this at other restaurants, this will not meet your expectations. At all. 

Overpriced for mediocre food. Very salty food. Bitch ass ladies.
author: Katherine D.

description:
3.5 stars 
It's a tiny hole-in-the-wall place with very limited bar seating. 
There is a little bit of a wait. 
The tea leaf salad was good.
The pork yamo house noodle was good but a tad bit salty. 
The spring rolls were fresh tasting.
author: Heejin L.

description:
This place is tiny and unpretentious.  We had the house noodles, tea salad and mango salad.  The noodles were simple and hit the spot and the tea leaf salad - though tiny - was very flavorful.  Tea salad and mango salad were both spicy.  All three were oily but not necessarily in a bad way - it kind of fit the ambiance.  Seating is stools at the counter overlooking the kitchen.  Service is certainly not warm, but it's efficient.  We brought our three year old daughter.  It's not a place that screams "kids" but it went fine and she loved the noodles and practicing with the chopsticks.

I left happy.  It's nice to eat at a place that's about the food instead of the trappings.  Cash only.
author: Teresa W.

description:
Very great food and good service. Will go again.

Me and my girlfriend wanted to get some chinese food to bring home and eat over a bit of wine. We ordered some chow fun and some beef noodles. Both amazing. The spring rolls were not to my liking - but I'm sure they're awesome if you're a vegan.

Very nice little place.
author: Kris S.

description:
I've known of this place for a long time but never wanted to wait in the long line. So today I called in a to go order and was "greeted" by a very rude lady. I gave her my order and before I knew it she was gone, she just hung up. 

Not given the chance to ask how long it would be, I arrived 15 minutes later and was ok if I had to wait. I walked in and was once again "greeted" by this rude lady (apparently the owner) She looked at me with a scrawl on her face and actually said "what do you want?" I told her I called in and then she barked $6.50. 

I had the opportunity to watch her work, bare hands as she prepared everyone's food. I'm fine with bare hands as long as the servers wash in between. She walked up to me with dirty hands, snatched the $7 from me, counted 7 dollar bills and then slapped $.50 down on the counter. She then proceeded to go back and start preparing food. Didn't wash her hands, reached right into a bowl of noodles!! Yuck! 

If they don't care about the basic in sanitation/hygiene, can you just imagine how they process, prepare, and store, their food! 

No restaurant is with the stomach pain and hours on the toilet! I'll pass. Keep my $6.50 and just know I will never eat at or recommend your restaurant!
author: David H.

description:
The epitome of hole-in-the-wall deliciousness. Service is efficient; the asian ladies are not super chatty (so don't take it personally), but you will get a delicious meal :) Yamo has one counter with no more than 10 seats for guests, which faces their open kitchen and prep area. It was fun to see the process of our food being cooked, and all the oil that goes into it haha (but that's why it's delicious, so I'm not complaining). 

*Tea Leaf Salad - quite a small portion, and although it does look different than what you'd get at Burma Superstar, it's still got a lot of textures going on. Watch out for the spicy kick! They were not very accommodating to my brother's peanut allergy, saying they could not make a peanut-free version. (but that's ok, cuz more for me)
*Chicken Noodle Soup - tender noodles and chicken bathing in a coconut-based soup broth was warm, flavorful, and home-y. Eating it kind of felt like getting a hug from a long lost relative. Loved the textures and flavors of this soup, it's a winner in my book. 
*Mango Chicken - another solid dish, but did not stand out as much as the chicken noodle soup.

warning: cash only. every dish is around $6.
author: Tuwie N.

description:
WHY does this place get 4 stars??

1. Food portions are small, especially the amount of meat you get
2. What's special about the noodles that you can't get from any asian restaurant that does garlic noodles
3. Not sanitary
4. Rude service.  Customers shouldn't be rude to the staff, and staff shouldn't be rude to customers.  Sometimes these people are offensive, not just stoic and/or quiet. 

I think it gets a lot of hype because it's cheap, but the quality is really lackluster.
author: Mary X.

description:
I would give this place ZERO Star if my rating was based on customer service. To future customers; if you are coming here with expectations of good customer service, you're in it for big surprise. I don't know if the ladies are rude or that's just how they interact with others without knowing it. Expect to be yelled at. 

I gave it three stars because the food is legit and the prices are reasonable. Like other yelpers said, it's cash only. I've been to this place a few times in the past and never had good customer service. But I keep coming back because of the food. It's the closest thing to Burmese street food in San Francisco that I can think of. 

As for the place itself and the atmosphere, I've always gotten take out from here because I'm not comfortable eating in their presence. Plus, the place is really small. So expect to wait a long time. 

Phone orders. Expect to have them hang up on you. You can order on the phone but don't expect to have it ready when you get there. As far I know, they don't actually start making your food until you get there. So if you've ordered on the phone, just cut the line and tell them about your order. 

I don't know if the owner or the manager of this place going to read this. I just want to say a few things. You guys can make SO MUCH more money if there was decent customer service. I don't mean like you have to kiss ass or smile or whatever. Just treat customers like normal human beings without the yelling. The fact that you have 4 stars DESPITE the worst customer service (not an exaggeration) says a lot about the potential of this place. Just my two cents.
author: TayZar S.

description: Basically my favorite spot in SF. Service is fast, food is cheap and the women behind the counter are AWESOME. Follow their rules folks, it's worth it.
author: Sean M.

description:
People who rated here five stars do not know how good Burmese food really tastes like. 
The place is SMALL, seating around 10 people max and is comprised of the counter and kitchen. When trying to take a photo of the store, the owner glared at me and told me that I wasn't allowed to take photos. She was also glaring at us as we took our order and I quote my friend:

"She looked like she was about to whoop my ass." 

Prices are cheap but portions are also extremely small.
Definitely take your business elsewhere.
author: Christine L.

description:
dude. this spot is on point. 

so, don't go for the customer service, or the ambiance, or the fancy decor. it's literally a hole in the wall. and it's bomb Burmese goodness.

there's three ladies behind the counter who don't greet you, don't talk, just take your order, and serve your food. you're lucky if they give you any eye contact. 

they don't smile and they're probably talking about how annoying you are in Burmese. but I don't care, it adds to the whole amazing experience.
author: Jessica V.

description:
if i can give less than 1 star, i would. i don't even care about how their food taste anymore. i phoned in to order for pick up, she hung up on me. i arrived and ready for pick up and she yelled at me saying its ready but she's not ready at all. so i kindly said well...i'm ready when you are. just saying those cunts rude arse eff. if you don't have a passion for what you do, do everyone else a favor and quit! cunt, please don't kill my vibe 'cause you have a massive stick up your arse. thank you asshole!!! oh...and the food was tasteless, even the amount of hot sauce i mixed it with, can't even save it. what a waste of time and money spent on my first experience with them. never again.

A piece of advice: If you don't see any Asians eating at an 'Asian' restaurant, save yourself - don't do it.
author: Rose L.

description:
I know different people have different personal formula for how they would rate a food joint. Some people believe that the quality/taste of food should mostly dictate the rating - I'm one of those people who rate based on the entire experience of waiting, ordering, dining, and paying. So that is my disclaimer up front.

My friend was visiting me from out of the country and we accidentally stumbled on this place (we actually tried to go to Ken Ken Ramen but they were closed). After waiting for ~15 min on a weekday during lunchtime, we were able to sit down. The entire place seats maybe 10-12 people at the counter, tops. There was a constant line of people either ordering takeout or waiting for a seat the entire time I was there. 

The food was really good actually, and it is very cheap - we all know that it's pretty much impossible to get lunch for $7 these days. My friend ordered the mango chicken and I got the house noodles with beef. I thought the mango chicken was excellent, and the noodles were a bit oily/heavy but in a delicious way. We didn't get any appetizers or salad, but it was a good lunch portion even with just the entree. 

The reason why I would probably never come here again to dine in is because of how rude these ladies are to their customers. As I sat and waited and ate, I saw them yelling at so many customers (someone was taking a long time to decide, and she yelled "WHAT DO YOU WANT??" to him... there was another instance where she yelled "NO PICTURE!" with dagger eyes at a customer and the entire place just fell silent for a moment because we were all so shocked) and making customers feel uncomfortable by very obviously giving them long hard stares after they were done eating and shoving the bill in their face before the plate was half empty. I mean, I get it, you are a business and want to get customers in and out efficiently... but at what cost?!?! 

Maybe I will revisit Yamo if I'm in the area and I have a craving for greasy, cheap Burmese food on the go. But I don't ever plan on dining in again, and I won't feel like recommending this place to anyone (but then again, those ladies don't seem like they give a f*** about something like a negative Yelp review, ha).
author: Sara H.

description:
I ordered the House Noodles with pork and although I enjoyed the meal, I'm not sure it's something I would come back for. House Noodles is really...Noodles and MSG. As the other reviewers have pointed out, they're skimpy on the meat and the meal, unfortunately, does not come with any veggies. 
My friend got the mango chicken and said it was good but she didn't seem overtly happy. 

All in all, the food is nice and cheap (which I'm sure is why everyone loves this place so much) but forgettable. This is San Francisco! I'm sure you can find something tastier and healthier elsewhere.

Also, "Angry Asian Lady" is indeed angry. We weren't even done eating yet and she was trying to get us to leave.
author: Joey Y.

description:
My scale on 3 trips

1/2 - food - they offer traditional Burmese dishes though a small menu they stick to the basics. Not that good but value meals

0/1 - service - bare minimum service. Known to not give a #%^* with this

1/1 value - amazing place for budget food

0/.5 cleanliness - you smell like oil after eating inside

.25/.5 ambiance - cramped, but can be considered quaint because it's a "hole in the wall"

Up to +/-1 bonus stuff - +1 for value! :D

Overall rating 3.25 stars


Not an expert, but I grew up in more a Burmese culture than most (dad is Chinese raised in Burma) so I have some credibility :)

Worst mohinga I've had, the other dishes were ok. Nothing stood out as a go to dish. 

Overall - feed your belly with Burmese food on a budget. You know what you're getting into with this place. I'd go back if there's no wait and I absolutely craved Burmese food nearby.
author: Ian C.

description:
I used to go to this place a lot many years ago. I would even say almost every week. Loved every dish they cooked. 
After maybe 5 years of not going there, I came back for lunch. And let me tell you, it did not change a bit. The same delicious food. You enjoy every bite you make. You literally make love to this food. 
This place is literally a hole in the wall. You come, order, eat, pay, and go. This is not a place where you would take your date to. But this is a place where you take your spouse to, hehe, to impress with delicious and authentic Burmese food. 
The service is funny. They are sweet and rude at the same time. 
Once you're there, you're in Asia. Awesome experience - delicious food.
author: Jenna F.

description:
When I first discovered Yamo, I was super excited to check out the place since I love hole in the wall restaurants. Luckily, there wasn't a line outside so we quickly got seats at the bar. 

Food: Yamo Mama didn't give us enough time to read over the full menu so I only got to taste two of their dishes: the tea leaf salad and their house beef noodles. Overall I enjoyed the tea leaf salad but i thought the house beef noodles lacked flavor. 

Service: I guess you won't get the full YAMO effect without Yamo Mama. She sure did treat us like shit. First, she hurried me into ordering and then she also rushed me out of the restaurant. Oh well, I still enjoyed my visit and will be back for more!

QUICKTIPS: 
- Mix the tea leaf salad and noodles together to add more flavor. It does wonders. 
- CASH only
- Yamo Mama works efficiently: know what you want, eat and leave.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I don't understand why everyone is raving about this place. Maybe its "hole in the wall" atmosphere is attractive to hipsters? In any case, the service is pretty bad: you can tell the wait staff pretty much don't want to be there. You can't blame them though, since the wait staff are also the same folks who do the cooking and cashiering. The food isn't great either--most of the dishes are essentially a bunch of Asian ingredients lumped together in a pile of brown sauce, which is why every dish looks very similar to one another ( a pile of brown)

Again, I don't get the hype. Feels like its a hipster thing. Try to avoid if possible.
author: Henry L.

description:
Ended up in Mission for dinner. The place seemed promising on Yelp, except when my friend and I got there, there were no seats. Because of that, we decided to order our food to go, and find some random place to eat instead.

I did find it funny how when I was placing my order in Cantonese, the younger waitress asked what kind of meat, and I responded "pork", and she said, "what kind of meat is that?" Uh, you just spoke Chinese to me, and you don't know the difference between pork, chicken and beef? (And this was one of the rare times I order pork, because everyone else was eating pork.)

Overall, my experience with the house noodles was pretty good, granted we did wait 45 minutes for our food. The food spoke for itself; there was enough heat from the wok to give it that smoky flavor, as well as a good portion from meat/veggie/noddle to fill me up, even though it was a small portion.

My last thought about this place? Don't mess with Mom. I saw a few people try to come in a little after 9. Yelp claims that the place is still open, except the young waitress flat out said, "we close when Mom says so." So, planning to get a cheap eat here, come earlier than what Yelp says, or find some other place.
author: Tom T.

description:
The food is really good! We had a tea leaf salad and a mango salad then topped it all off with a cold noodle dish with chicken. It was fun watching them make the dishes right in front of us. Our bill came to $18 before tip.

It looked like a grandma, mother and daughter working there. They are busy and don't talk to you much, but the youngest was very friendly. The restaurant is small with just booth spaces for about 8 people. This is not the place for a group or to impress a date. It is a great place to get quality food for a very low price.

Parking was limited in 18th in front of the restaurant. We went to a narrow residential alley behind the restaurant and walked. Bonus that the parking was free!
author: Song H.

description: Horrible customer service rushed us to pay and eat and was so rude to my friend telling him he shouldn't be eating and talking. Never coming back
author: Mai P.

description:
Cheap and yummy Burmese food!

After passing by Yamo after our Mission Chinese Food fail, my friend mentioned he wanted to try this place.  Two friends and I came here last Tuesday around 7pm and waited about 20-25 minutes to be seated.

WHAT TO KNOW:
*CASH ONLY!
*Hole in the wall place that seats only about 10 people 
*Bar seating so come with one or two people at max (if more, it'll be too difficult to seat everyone together)
*Entrees come with an option of noodles or rice
*Cheap! (6 dishes came out to $15/person including tip!)
*Expect your food to be greasy 

FOOD:
*Potstickers - Pass.  They're a bit doughy and tasted like Costco Ling Ling potstickers.
*Yamo House Noodle w/Beef - A must try and my favorite dish of the night!!  You have the option for pork, chicken or beef placed on top of somewhat oily noodles topped off with fried garlic and green onions.
*Mango Chicken - Good.  The flavorful dish consisted of chicken, snow peas, carrots, and onions and had diced mangos that added a slight sweetness to the dish.
*Mushroom Tofu - Delicious!  It's not only for vegetarians.  I love tofu and mushrooms and to have it together with saucy goodness was great.  

SERVICE:
Okay I guess. It's an Asian restaurant, stellar service isn't their focus.

PARKING:
Street parking which at most times is horrible. 

To sum it up, I can't wait to come back!
author: Nicole S.

description:
Finally got a seat here. 

Step inside this no BS hole-in-the-wall and I'm transported back to rural Thailand, where I biked around for two days down every street and alleyway to find what can only be described as the best curry and stir-fry in all of Thailand. Now, Yamo isn't Thai, I understand, but something about it reminds me so much of the friendly lady cooking up the best meal I had in my travels at her namesake restaurant, Mama's. Maybe it's strong female presence here. Maybe it's the authentic northern Southeast Asia smell that washes over you as you hang up your jacket and squeeze in. Maybe it's the freshly chopped ingredients and subsequent deliberate mixing of said ingredients to create a simple, yet intense infusion of flavour in every dish. 

I never thought I'd say this, but I wish they'd raise their prices already. At $6.25 a dish, I'd be here even if the food is half as good it is. But given the high quality and low price? Economists are readily ripping their hairs out over the extreme consumer surplus here.
author: Ben H.

description: Bad food. Food is cheap but NOT cheap at all for the quality. I ordered YAMO beef house noodle. It was just one serving of over cooked low quality noodle with a few pieces of dry beef scraps. This is an Asian food for uncultured non-Asian people.
author: Kaya O.

description: This place is great! The tea leaf salad was amazing , and all their noodles were good. Just remember the restaurant is small, and has about 8 chairs. The wait can be long, but it's worth it. It gets even better, it's dirt cheap for the city! ( cash only )
author: Jad A.

description: If I could give it a negative score, that's what I'd do. First of all, the service was the worst I've seen. They treated us as if we were not only eating for free but asked them to pay us. All of them seemed angry all the time for some reason. When I peeked into the kitchen a little, which is basically looking straight ahead given the size of the place, they'd shout at me as if I were stealing their secret recipes. 2nd the food, which is way over rated. The house noodle was too soft, not even a little bite, way too much oil in it than necessary. The paste is fried rice wasn't even stirred evenly. 3rd is cleanness, which is nonexistent. Kitchen and the bar was filthy. They never washed their hands no matter after what they touched including money and the trash bin. While the price is low, it's not worth being treated like shit.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
Great little hole in the wall place in the Mission! I got the Fish Chowder which was really good, but I wish there had been more crunchy pieces. My two friends that I went with are both vegan, and both their tofu dishes were really good as well.

Downside: It's REALLY small and seating is limited, and it's also really hot.

Also- cash only!! I hate when places are cash only but don't say it on the door or tell you when you sit down (this place).

Regardless, the food was good and I would definitely eat here again.
author: Jenna G.

description:
Charming the first time around if you've never been to a hole-in-the-wall food stall in Asia, but I'll take takeout from here moving forward. If you don't like smelling like grease, take my advice. :)

If you like being  in the midst of all the action, then this place is for you - You'll hear the ladies working in the kitchen at Yamo chatter in Cantonese while they chop, dice, stir-fry and deep-fry your food in front of you. 

Yamo is a mom-and-pop Burmese home cooking joint in the Mission. It's a drastically different experience from the decidedly clean-cut vibe of Burma Super Star. With only bar seating and an exposed kitchen behind the bar, expect to rub elbows with other customers while you're eating and be prepared to come out smelling a little smoky. 

The food is decent if you just want some good old Asian comfort food to go. Nothing to write home about though.

These are the three essentials that I recommend ordering at Yamo: 
1. the tea salad ($4.25)
2. the samusas ($6.00)
3. house noodles with beef ($6.95)

You'll come out with your belly heavier and your wallet barely lighter!
author: Catherine C.

description:
Amazon price for perfectly decent Asian food. Curry was little salty and thin, but the chicken was not overcooked and the two leaf salad was off the hook. The samosas were crispy and hot.

GOOD VALUE!

CASH ONLY
author: Hallie C.

description:
This really is a tiny hole in the wall place between Valencia and Mission.  I like that it's family run (mom and daughter).  I think it adds to the authenticity of Asian food? Given how "hole in the wall" it is, I was a little surprised I was the only Asian person eating here.  It's basically an open kitchen, so it's nice to watch them in action, but you do kind of get a greasy feel from sitting there unless you're by the door.  Lots of people were in line for takeout at lunch.

- Tea leaf salad: sweet and tart, not the fermented tea flavor as I'm used to, and I would have preferred a stronger tea flavor.  It has the right crunchiness but haad too much shredded cabbage and not enough tea leaves. The portion is on the smaller side
- House noodles with chicken: great texture on the noodles, and they have that slightly doughy fresh noodle taste.  The chicken has a lot of flavor and is not dry, and the green onions and cilantro add freshness to it.  The fried garlic adds crunchiness, and the noodles are even better with their chili sauce (better than sriracha). It is a little on the oily side (ok the oil coated my lips..)

Getting a seat for lunch on a weekday wasn't hard, but I wouldn't try to come with more than 1 other person since the only have 8 seats along the counter facing the kitchen.  All the dishes are $6.25 or under, which is really reasonable compared to how much some other Burmese places charge. I was expecting no/minimal service, but they actually refilled my water without me asking. 

Cash only (I think there's an ATM next door).
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Yamo is an excellent restaurant with excellent food. Their service is not the best, the workers are a bit bitter and not super friendly. The place is very tiny, so you really have to just eat and leave, no time for real chit chat. 

I didn't give them the extra star because Yamo only accepts cash and does not deliver.
author: Betty C.

description:
The funny thing about this place is that I passed and waited for the bus right in front of it. Till I finally notice and looked inside so I sat down to eat with my girl and her lover my food came fasst since they cook it right in front of you and I all I have to say it was 
Sooo F'n yummy !!! A small place but they cook up a good meal. I had mango chicken and it was just the way I liked it hot and spicy !! Will come back to try their varieties of salad  and the other dishes!!! After all these years I never new that this was a restaurant cause that's how small they are !!! But looking forward to come back to bring some special people here.
author: Gracelove C.

description:
Hole in the wall, 8-9 stool counter with 3 Chinese ladies manning the fort. One cooking, two taking orders and making the cold dishes and one slaving away on the burners. Might be a better idea to stop by and order takeout. 

This place is a great lunch find! It also helps that 90% of the items on the menu are priced at $6 and the portion size is quite fair. 

Tea salad - I've had better and more authentic, skip out on this and get it at Burma Superstar. 

Yamo House Noodle with Beef - YUM! although, I don't think this is a Burmese dish, but it was still damn good. 

Chicken Noodle Soup (aka ohno kwautskwe) - also delicious, but a little overboard on the coconut cream 

Warning: if you do dine in, you will smell like oil and fried goodness after leaving, not to mention your breath will be as fragrant as a rose garden, not.
author: Anh P.

description: I was excited to try this place as I always see long lines waiting outside patiently for what I thought was superior yummies...not the case. I think people rate this place high because it's hecka cheap compared to everything else in the hood. But it's cheap for reasons: no money was spent on ambience, small portions, horrible customer service, food is not great (too greasy), they don't have a functioning exhaust fan, place was dirty.  Go elsewhere.
author: Jonsey B.

description:
Yamo has little less than 10 seats at the counter. it's a true hole in the wall. menu looks burmese, chinese or 2 different cuisines in one menu.

eats: curry beef w/noodles (6)
-small portion
-fresh, tender beef, veggies
-curry a little spicy, no coconut milk used.

wok notes:
-took 10ish minutes to cook
-a couple of liquid squirts, a few minispoonfuls of spices
-very hot in here. couldn't handle eating in here.
-most pricing around 6.
-cash only
author: Victor G.

description:
Enjoy the instant transcendence of this hole in the wall place. The dimly-lit place serves meals like a bar, with two people preparing for a hungry crowd. 

Very genuine, extremely filling and very cheap.
author: Ryan K.

description:
The menu has expanded. We got the curry prawn dish and you have the option of getting it with rice or noodles. There's a few more curry dishes and rice plate options including a tofu dish. 

This place gets a 5 stars for the Chicken Coconut Noodle Soup! It's probably my favorite dish in all of San Francisco. It's a must try!

Previous review:
The Chicken Coconut Noodle Soup is dream-worthy! It is seriously one of the best soups I've ever had... and I'm still thinking about it! 5 Star Soup!

The menu is very small, the place is small, and all the items are all very inexpensive! There is only about 10 spots to sit at the counter, so you may have to wait to take a seat there. There also isn't very much standing room for take out orders either. You might be waiting out in the cold for your order. The service is quick and fast though. The water glasses are super tiny though, and I felt awkward asking for a refill. 

We also ordered the Beef House Noodles and Fried Spring Rolls. The noodles, which take up the largest section of the menu, were alright. I expected them to be a lot better. The fried spring rolls were fine too. Neither of these items were spectacular, but they were cheap.

Seriously, have the soup! The soup is worth a visit and will keep you coming back! Yum Yum!
author: Rebecca G.

description:
Literal hole in the wall with a great vibe and setup that made me feel like I was in Asia. The menu is simple and the woman who took my order was able to quickly give me a recommendation - the standard noodles with chicken. Oddly, they did not let me eat in the restaurant even though there was an empty seat at the counter

The food was very good. Noodles were moist and tasty, and the chicken was high quality and tasty, none of that stringy business you find in some quick service restaurants.
author: Josh L.

description:
I never imagine that people can stand with the rudeness of the lady behind the counter.
She is so rude, I don't mind if they tell us no pic allowed in the nice way or you can even put the sign so we know.
We also witness she is so rude to other customer and also two customer walk out because she give them an attitude.

Food is mediocre, their tea salad is good though but I can skip that because their attitude, definitely will not come back again.

If that kind of marketing strategy( rudeness or no bs attitude) works for other customer then go ahead and try this place but this place is not my kind of plate.
author: Xinta B.

description: Really was excited to try this place ...potstickers were beautiful but cold inside. Curry was blah ... Not much curry flavor ... Very bland .. Darkish gravy ... Beef chow fun ... Very greasy ...samosa - nothing to brag about .... The best - tea salad & the house ... Price is cheap ..about $6.50 ... Portions / great for the ladies - small for the guys ...everything is sticky .. The counter, the seat , the menus ...but we like the ladies behind the counter. Probably won't b bk unless we're low on cash ....
author: Jay S.

description:
We had Yamo for takeout recently, and it was good, but I wouldn't say it was great. Based on these reviews, we decided on the tea leaf salad, some samusas, mango chicken, and house noodles. The tea leaf salad was the highlight of the meal, and as good as I have had at other Burmese joints in the area. The mango chicken combined an interesting amount of sweetness with some spice, and was also good. The noodles were ok but seemed a little overcooked and oily.

I think that I would try it again and give some of the other items a shot, but as it it I thought it was only ok.
author: Brent W.

description:
Best noodles in town 
This place is definitely unique San Francisco hole in wall
Even if service is kind of ok
author: Maria M.

description:
I'm glad I don't understand Burmese, because I know these biddies are talking smack while they're slanging this delicious food. I hope you like a side of sassitude with your House Noodles, because it comes for free. 

The food is awesome. Comforting, hearty, and dirt cheap. Coconut chicken noodle soup, house noodles, and tea leaf salads are all must haves. Only complaints are that they could work the knife skills a bit more, everything is jumbo chopped and quartered, which takes away from the dish. Part of the home cooked appeal I guess, but I don't always want to have to pause and chew through 1/4th of a bell pepper.  Also, I wish they used a higher quality noodle. It's a little doughy where it could be chewy. 

Getting a seat is a crapshoot, and know what you want before they see you. They don't like slowpokes. The inside is pretty "greasy spoon" but it adds to the weird vibe. 

Come, eat, don't sweat the little things, and enjoy the show.
author: Patrick T.

description: I came here with excitement and walked out with extreme disappointment. The food was cheap. That's all I have to say about the place.
author: Kerstin C.

description: Is this place for real? After placing an order and sat down, I simply asked for a drink and got yelled at by the angry Cantonese (?)old woman. I know you are not supposed to expect good customer services here but please give people the basic respect that they deserve.
author: Roro B.

description:
House noodles $6 egg rolls $4.50

Great price, small hole in the wall place to get some quick grub. I always call in and get takeout. The place can only seat about a dozen at the cafe bar. 

Minus 1 star for noodles sometimes tasting plain, easy fix with hot sauce.
author: China D.

description:
Prices have gone up 25 cents... oh no! Nahhhht, slightly less than $7 can get you a full  and satisfying dish, an anomaly to both restaurants and food trucks in the city.  
With prices like that you need to pump people in and out.
Don't be that person who tries to linger with their date.
Don't be that person who tries to probe them for backstories. 
Don't be that person who spaces out, takes a million seconds to decide and expects to be pampered.
No it's not like that, they'll make your food, you'll eat it then leave and smell like oil (which is better than urine which is sometimes the predominant smell outside.)

I like the house noodles, cold noodles, soups and tea leaf salad. Eating here too frequently would prove to be too umami, but every once in a while the flavor profile of oil, fish sauce, soy sauce, lime etc., is nice.
author: Maggie S.

description:
I forgot it was ca$h only when I dropped in last night. Huge mistake. 

Finally had the tea leaf salad and an order of cold noodles. 

For $6, it was a tiny portion of tea leaf salad! Although it's flavorful and tasty, it just didn't float my boat. I was starving so I killed that and my cold noodles. The cold noodles hit the spot but i kept eating..
author: Susy C.

description:
I think this is the type of place where they have 1-2 AMAZING items (like the noodles) and you only order those when you go. 

I ordered the black bean tofu take-out one afternoon for lunch. It took a long time, the restaurant is cash only and the meal was very, very bland. I don't like spicy food and this was so bland I was searching all over for hot sauce to pour on it. Based on this one meal, I wouldn't order or go to again. However, you might have a different experience if you order what they're known for. It is pretty cheap compared to many restaurants so that's a plus.
author: Hailey H.

description:
Classic hole-in-the-wall Mission restaurant. Really amazing & cheap Burmese food. I had the Yamo steak noodles, so good. 

It only seats 8 people, so usually there's a 20-30 minute wait. If I lived in the Mission, I'd totally order takeout. 

No alcoholic beverages and the women cooking aren't there to schmooze with the customers. They make good & cheap food so with that in mind, don't expect to be catered to like the higher-end restaurants in the Mission. It's an SF experience to have. 

I'll be here again.
author: Juan T. K.

description:
Dude, the lady that took my order, she's scary...

I'm Burmese and this doesn't really taste like Burmese food. We ordered the Mango Chicken, Fish Curry, Tea Leaf Salad, and Fish Noodle Chowder. 

Mango Chicken - Very delicious but I have never heard of this as a Burmese dish. The mangoes taste so good and the flavor is a bit spicy. It taste more like a sweet and sour chicken dish. 

Fish Curry - This dish taste a bit more Burmese but has more of a Chinese style to it. This dish is also spicy but good. It is on the oily side.

Fish Noodle Chowder - This is known as Mohinga. The taste is pretty close but it's missing a few ingredients like banana root as an example. It was also extremely on the thick side. This traditional dish is usually served with lemon, chile powder, and sliced egg which was missing.

Tea Leaf Salad - More like cabbage salad topped off with nuts. We barely tasted the tea leaf; more like a tiny scoop of tea lead mush. 

Overall, I would not come back to this "Burmese" restaurant. The food is good but this to me, is not authentic Burmese cuisine.
author: Michelle A.

description:
The worst mohinga I have ever had.  So tasteless and bland.  And they seemed to have run out of everything even though I was the first customer of the day walking in at 11AM.  No lemon wedges to squeeze into my bland as hell soup.  Then I heard the server say to other customers that came in after me: No rice noodles, no prawns, no black bean sauce...  Uh why are you even open for business...?

The food was cheap.  My gigantic bowel was $6.  But $6 of crappy food is still considered a waste of money to me.
author: Jiajia C.

description:
Just came in today for lunch with my boss. I would only sit inside on a cold winters night. There are only around 8 stools against their counter facing their 100 degree kitchen that is constantly blowing smoke and steam at you. They also yelled at me for trying to take photos! Homph. It was so packed and stuffy inside my boss refused to come in! 

We ordered the tea leaf salad, mango salad, fish curry with rice, and their house special fried rice. Grand total was $24! The only thing I would reorder would be the two salads. They were so good!!! I would never order the fish curry and fried rice again. The shrimp were the super tiny kind and the curry was not much of a curry at all. 

There was a nonstop stream of people ordering at 1pm and they food comes out slow so be prepared to wait! I don't know why but they gave us like 6 pairs of chopsticks even though there was only enough food to feed two. Portions are definitely on the smaller side! All entrees are $6 and you can get a fresh coconut for $3.50! 

Street parking was pretty easy. Bring cash and be prepared for a long wait and to take it to go!
author: Tiffany V.

description:
Walking in your first reaction is "oh Crap!"    This is a hole in the wall place with exposed walls, and plumbing.  You should plan to take your food to go or have a nice place to picnic in mind because seating is limited to a narrow counter with 6 or 7 stools crammed up to it. There is almost always a line, for both seating and take out.  We got there, coincidentally, as they opened.  Apparently if a good portion of the menu isn't available at the moment it's no big deal.  Eavesdropping is inevitable and tolerated because your so close knit with the other patrons.  This turned out to be a positive thing because foodie talk emerges and word of mouth is always the best know all.   The woman behind the counter is also stereo-typically charming (NOT), and location of the "establishment" is also in, I'll say, a more colorful part of The Mission.  
Now,  if you can put all that behind you....  Most SF Foodies can,  SF Foodies appreciate value, authenticity, and taste before all the fore mentioned.  Flavors are bright and spicy, as Burmese food should be.  I had the Chicken Salad (Chicken with a combination of cabbage, carrots, onions, tomatoes, and cilantro) ,  smoky quarter sized medallions of white meat that were grilled and somehow giving a real smoky flavor.  The salad had some kick to it too, with a spicy front-end heat that somewhat dissipated before the next. My partner started with the Tea Salad ( Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds) He said it was different than other Tea Salads he's had before, but we (I mean He) really enjoyed it.  It also had a spicy-vinegar sinus clearing quality to it.  
It some conversation with a regular there, the talk of the place is supposedly the Chicken Noodle Soup (Coconut noodle soup with chicken, onions, and cilantro), so we promptly ordered some to go.  It's supposed to rain this afternoon so I plan on cracking that baby open then.  I can say it was packed nicely though with the broth separated from the fixings in a separate container as to keep there freshness until use.  From what I can smell it's going to be awesome.   Portions aren't huge but either is the pricing, a fixed $6.25 [cash only] for all entrees and and $4 something for appetizers (when available).  I was denied both spring rolls and egg rolls but saw them being made later.  hmmmm.  
I'll go again and if I can get a smile and a spring roll, I'll boost it a star.
author: John W.

description: My friend and I were in the Mission on Monday evening to see a play. He had researched and found this restaurant on Yelp. It was SO good. We were lucky enough to get 2 of maybe 8 seats total at the counter. The place is tiny and primarily for take out. But we loved the food and the authentic atmosphere. Great food, great prices.
author: Judy K.

description: I really loved the vibe in this place. It's super small and all counter space with speedy friendly service. My chow mein was a bit salty but I'll definitely be back to try more items.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Do not go here! You've been warned. 
My Burmese husband and I from Seattle went on our road trip and visited here. Just 1 word: RUDE, VERY RUDE, EFFING RUDE! End of story!
Tip: If you wanna get yelled at by the employee like me, or the dirtiest, uglies look like everyone else on Yelp, just try taking photo of the restaurant. Simple as that!
author: Tam D.
