description: The place reminds me of a small Tokyo restaurant .  I love a-hole-in-a-wall kind of mom and pop restaurants.  Kind of amazing the place is run by three women.  Don't come if you expect some kind of royalty American styled customer service.  Sometimes the place can get noisy.  And the end of the day the ladies are a bit curt but give them a break.  It ain't easy cooking food for people in that kind of heat.  I only order one dish here: Yano house beef noodles.  I can tell you it varies depending what time you order it.  Once it tasting fucking amazing 10/10.  The meat was super tender and done just right.  Other time it is 7-8 out of ten.  Which is still great consider the price.  Come for lunch if you can dinner are too crazy.
author: Anh H.

description:
I went here once before thinking it was the complete bombdiggity. I had received the tea leaf noodles, house noodles, samosas, and the fresh coconut juice. I also came during dinner time and had to wait a bit so maybe that's why I thought my first experience was just SOOO good. 

Came here again after forgetting the name of this hole in the wall and finally found it on yelp. I was SO excited to bring my boy here. 

Don't get me wrong, he actually loved this place. Or what he got at least (yamo house noodles chicken). The service however........

Is it because we came during lunch time rather than dinner when there was absolutely no line and ample seats for diners?

The service was just so mediocre. Everyone seemed sad, out of it, unattentive. Maybe it was just a bad day, but the food was good at least. Potstickers were a new try, wouldn't recommend. Also, didn't seem like they had an option to have the cut coconuts to drink from this time. But I didn't ask, they didn't offer sorta thang. So shrug. 

That's my take on it. I'd go again for a cheap quick delicious meal anytime. Just wasn't impressed this second time around.
author: Kaitlyn E.

description:
I was very excited to try this place but ended up being pretty disappointed... 

Yes, the ladies here are pretty fucking rude/obnoxious. It can be entertaining depending on your attitude... I wouldn't have minded if the food was actually good, i mean some of the most delicious food comes from terrible customer service - BUT from my experience it wasn't good so I didn't appreciate their disrespect... Also English not being their native language doesnt justify yelling at people to hurry up when they sat down for no more than 10 minutes. They're not stupid or "lost in translation", they just don't give a fuck. 

ANYWAYS

The place is pretty small and gets busy so don't count on eating in... I liked that aspect personally (the small divey feel). I liked the assembly line they had going on, was cool watching them prepare and cook everything.

Got the samusas and the flavor reminded me of dirt... not very appetizing.  Boyfriend and I both got  rice dishes (i'm sorry this was HELLA days ago so I don't remember which..) and were not impressed with either. Both were lacking in flavor and far from anything special. After observing the people around us it seemed as though EVERYONE besides us ordered noodles...opps?

I'll admit that maybe we didn't order the "right" things...probably should have went with the tea leaf salad, noodles and/or soup but our experience was so off putting that I had no desires in giving this place another chance... that and there's a Burmese place (Kyain Kyain) closer to where I live(d) that was SO much better both in food and customer service.
author: Melissa C.

description: Authentic Burma cuisine cooked right in front of you, served on an intimate counter top surrounded by 9 other patrons. I ate the tea salad, egg rolls, chicken noodle soup, and the house beef noodles. All impressed me. The tea salad was spicey.
author: Sophia T.

description: Divey eatery in the Mission. We went on a warm Saturday afternoon in May and were able to grab two seats right away, despite very limited seating in the tiny place. It was a bit hot and stuffy inside, and cleanliness was questionable. The service is bare bones, but the house noodles ($6.25 cash only) are absolutely fantastic and super cheap. Overall, great place for cheap, delicious takeout.
author: Patty C.

description:
As authentic as the thick cloud of greasy smoke rising from the stoves and deep fryer (the exhaust hood doesn't work). When dining in, expect to leave smelling like Asian mom's cooking (worse than a Chinese restaurant).

Otherwise the food is analogous to the kind of fare you'd get from a typical side-street mom-and-pop enterprise in the neighborhoods of Bangkok--cheap, tasty, and down-home.

Good: Chicken curry plate, mango salad
Bad to average: Egg roll

CASH ONLY. Very limited seating.

To the First World babies bitching about the staff:

1) Shut your entitled, privileged mouths.

2) Travel, especially to a Third World country.

3) Put yourselves in their shoes and imagine how pissy you'd get from slaving all day in a cramped, smoke-filled kitchen at $6.25 a plate, right up in your customer's faces. 

4) Lyft/Uber your lazy asses one street over to Valencia (or the Marina), pick any restaurant, and get served "properly" at $16+ a plate.
author: Inigo M.

description: YAMO must mean YUMMY. This is definitely a hole in the wall place.  There's seating for about 8 at the bar and that's it, so you may have to wait a while to get in.  I can recommend the chicken curry soup, house special noodles, and tea leaf salad.  It rivals Burma Superstar at a fraction of the price (I think everything on the menu is $6.25). I'm writing this review while waiting for an order of shrimp fried rice.   When I ordered, the funny ladies (who all the other reviewers describe as "mean" -- you have to come here to see what I mean) went to the very old fridge and scooped out a few frozen shrimp which she threw into a bowl and gave it to the other funny lady on stove duty.  I kinda wish I didn't see that part, but I guess with the kitchen right in front of the customers, you see it all
author: Max G.

description:
Well, after my first terrible experience, immediately walking out after walking in, I took a chance when a friend suggested Yamo.  Since then I have now been there 3 times and enjoyed the food each time, so I thought it was appropriate that I update my review.

Now that I have a better read on the place, this is a no frills type of place with people trying to run a business with high turnover in seating.  So, don't go if you are in a not-so-good mood yourself and don't try to take a seat for a party of two if you are the first to arrive or you will be asked to wait outside.

Food is tasty, but should mention that portion for tea leaf salad seemed smaller when I went to eat by myself.  Over all enjoy the food and recommend going on off hours if possible!
author: Christopher W.

description:
Believe me when I say that this place is a legit hole in the wall. There's only approximately 10 seats at the counter, so you might have to wait at times. In spite of the cramped space though, Yamo seriously knows how to produce some delicious food. The women who work here know how to run this place efficiently, cost-effectively, and most importantly, deliciously. 

The food here is nice and incredibly flavorful (and oily). The tea leaf salad is a great starter. Although it's a little on the small side, it has great flavor and it's different from your typical tea leaf salad. My two favorite entrees are the Yamo House Noodles and the Mango Chicken. The noodles are very greasy and filled with tons of flavor and a light sauce. The meat is also always tender and cooked very well. The mango chicken also has tons of flavor, as there is nothing better than mixing the rice with the sauce and chicken. The chunks of fresh mango within the dish are generous and add a nice sweetness to the dish.

Yes, you may not be getting the best service nor the cleanest services, but it all adds to the unique hole-in-the-wall-type vibe. It always amazes me to see how fast they are able to cook despite the lack of space and dim lighting. Even more, all the dishes here are no more than $6! (I think they actually recently bumped it up to $6.25....but still, it's a bargain!) What more could you ask for?! Don't be intimidated by its exterior (or interior for that matter...) appearance - this place serves great food at a great price!
author: Aaron W.

description: Great food. Very small portions. Cash only. My friends and I ordered to go to avoid the line because the restaurant, as you can see from pics, is literally a hole in the wall. We ordered the tea salad, house noodles with beef, mango chicken, and potstickers- all for only $24. To our surprise, when we got our food, each dish was going to end up being like a couple bites each for 3 of us. The tea salad and the house noodles were especially good. I would come back to order those again, in multiple portions next time.
author: Michelle S.

description:
I was grabbing lunch with some friends who decided they wanted to get Burmese food because they'd never had it before. I decided to take them here because it's one of my favorite places and the prices aren't too bad.

The line was really long, but we decided to eat in. The place is really small, dingy, kinda grungy. You can feel the heat from the kitchen because you're sitting pretty much in front of it.

We decided to get samusas, curry prawns, house beef noodles, and tea leaf salad. The house noodles were very delicious although a tad oily. The curry prawns were okay (more mushrooms than prawns). The samusas had the right amount of spice and curry powder. The tea leaf salad was crunchy, tasty, and had great flavor (just kind of a small portion for the price).

We had grass jell drinks too. It comes in a can for $1. Not bad. Pretty refreshing after such a spiced up meal.

Great place!
author: Sofia R.

description:
Was initially excited to learn that a Burmese resto was in central SF vs. out in Richmond. Yes the prices are cheap ($6 entree) but when it's bland who cares? Would rather pay more and get something tasty. Just tea salad was good, the beef noodles and chicken and rice? BLAND!

Will never go back...
author: Eric K.

description:
Cramped seating, interested in seeing the food safety rating, and unfriendly service. 
But the Tea salad was one of the best I ever had at an eatery, the coconut noodle chicken soup better than some ramen places in the mission, and they sell $1 cokes....DOLLAR SODA people. Would not order the mango chicken again but definitely coming back. You'll forget the economic doldrums once you make like a bandit with three courses for $20.
author: Seira M.

description:
"No pictures" screamed the little women behind the counter as my friend tried to capture the essence of this hole in the wall. Literally a hole in the wall that seats about 8 people. The beef yabo house noodles were delicious, a simpler version of Lo mein with an amazing sauce. 

The sweet and sour sauce for the spring rolls had a not so secret ingredient, dried chili. Which added a kick (spice level 4). 

Cash only, No frills, This place is my definition of hole in the wall.
author: Vicky H.

description: Bruhhhhhh! The food was so flipping good. Got the tea leaf salad, the house special noodles with chicken and also tried the samosas, spring rolls. Everything was on point! The lady here is like Gordon Ramsay - she yells but the food is amazing. Guaranteed foodgasm
author: Venkatesh A.

description:
Yamo is simple, cheap, and delicious. Cash only which is always a huge irk for me, but believe - totally worth the inconvenience here. 

House Noodles with Beef - Awesome
Fried Rice - Good, but nothing spectacular
author: Anush V.

description:
Stopped in at 2pm on a weekday and was fortunate to find extra seats at the bar (granted it was a tight squeeze).  My friends and I shared the garlic noodles, Yamo house noodles, and mango chicken.  All of them were delicious, but the Yamo house noodles were by far my favorite (got them with tofu).

The bar only seats about 8-10 people, but there is a takeout option.  I've seen a massive line out here, so my only thought is to go at a very off-peak time.  Great little hole-in-the-wall.
author: Michelle K.

description:
This is the real deal hole the wall place. One of the reasons I love the mission are places like this : low budget and authentic. 

The tea leaf salad was spicy and packed with flavor. Dish is small so plan on sharing as appetizer not main dish. The chicken house dry noodle was no fluff. Balanced and noodles were wok tossed just right. Lunch under $10!  Bring cash and expect a line to eat at the bar stools. 

Also don't expect friendliest of service. But for quality and price can't complain.
author: Sam S.

description:
The line is long, the space tiny, and the food is cheap.  

I would give the samusas 5 stars.  They are incredible. Delicious, flavorful, and unique. 

We also had the garlic noodles and mango chicken.  Mango chicken was pretty good, but didn't blow me away.  The garlic noodles were super bland. I think they've toned down some of the flavors to appeal to a broader audience.  I was expecting something a little more bold, like the samusas. 

Will come again and keep trying other things though.  Totally a great deal, if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Alison H.

description: Yamo is a new favorite! The food is legit and also crazy cheap (a hard find in SF). I personally love the tiny counter and watching the women who work there prepare everything, but if you're not into waiting in a short line and are looking for white table clothes go somewhere else.
author: Tini T.

description:
I was excited to try this 'hidden gem'. What a disappointment!

I came here few days ago around 11am, ha, they weren't open. 

I finally got a chance to try it today. This place is mediocre. The food is a bit greasy and salty. Service are horrible. I told them I parked at the truck zone and hoping my order I placed earlier was ready, ha, they don't care and take their sweet time to pack my to-go order. Never coming here again!
author: anita s.

description: I love hole in the wall restaurants that serve good, honest food. This is one of those places. There are a couple ladies that work this place, and it's a very well oiled machine. All the seats are counter-style facing the small kitchen so you can see all of them at work. The food is delicious and pretty cheap too. It's a no frills kind of place. The service isn't great, but you're not coming here to be pampered. You're here to eat delicious food.
author: Derrick W.

description:
I have strong conflicting feelings about this place.

The very good:
- Super flavorful curries. The mango chicken and chicken curries were phenomenally spiced. The mango and vegetables were delicious and fresh.
- The price point was great, especially in San Francisco. We got 2 tea salads, 2 mango chickens, 2 beef noodles, and a chicken curry for $44. That fed 4 of us (2 ladies 2 gents) with some left over. 

The very bad:
- There was almost no meat in the dishes.
- We waited 45min in the cold for our food even though there was no one ahead of us when we got there.
 - The service was bad. My friend got shooed off of the unused counter when she was trying to get her money out. We weren't allowed to stand inside even when there was space, which is fine actually, but the lady was very rude about telling us to get out. Maybe the rudeness is part of their shtick. I don't mind so much about the tone as long as transactions are carried out as they should be, but my friends were pretty upset, particularly after the 45min of waiting in the cold.

The not-terrible-but-worth-mentioning:
- Portion sizes are small. But again, the prices are low so I don't feel right complaining too much.
author: Carina G.

description:
How dare you call yourself a tea leaf salad. Where are the tea leaves?

Mango Chicken was very disappointing, the chunks of mango tasted disgusting, would have been better without them. What kind of mango are you? Canned? 

Of course we were attracted by the large lines and crazy reviews. Yes, we have to admit the prices are cheap and it's true we get what we pay for...sometimes. 

I know its not the cleanest place, asian places rarely are. But what is disgusting is the ladies picking up the phone, taking down orders, then digging their hands into all the ingredients without washing their hands. This isn't something that happen once, it happened throughout our dinner. They have tons of phone orders, but still, have someone who isn't touching the food do it. 

Also the ladies may see rude, but they just don't speak English very well and the way they talk is normal in their own language. So try toughen up and don't get emotional about it.
author: Michael S.

description:
One word - BOMB!  Ordered the potstickers, house noodles with beef, chicken noodle soup and curry chicken.

Potstickers came out super hot, super fresh!  The skin was soft and tender, tasted like it was homemade.  It was served with this sweet chili sauce, on the spicier side.  Nothing too special, though.

House noodles were my favorite!  The noodles were soft and beef was tender.  just enough sauce and flavor drenched onto the noodles.  Yummmmm. 

Chicken noodle soup tasted like a Thai dish to me, but overall still pretty good, but didn't catch too much of my attention.  Maybe because it was a bit too creamy for me?

Curry chicken was quite delightful.  The potatoes were already seasoned and sauteed before cooking it in the curry, with the crispiness of the chicken.  My second favorite dish of the night!

This place is really small and expect to stand and wait for awhile, or just order take out.  Actually this hole-in-the-wall is a cute casual date place.  Just don't expect it to be super nice, but I would definitely come back!
author: Nancy S.

description: My husband and I visited Yamo on our trip to SF after reading about this hole in the wall on SF Eater. We liked it so much we came back a second night! The cold noodles, tea salad, and chow mein are the way to go! Great cheap eat, definitely don't go for the service.
author: Shelby F.

description: Noodles are good, price can't be beat but the meat quality and lack of flavor is why I'm rating it low.
author: Narma G.

description: My coworkers decided to get take out from here cause they heard it was good and cheap.  I ordered the Mango Salad, and at $6 it's pretty good.  But compared to my coworkers' orders, it's relatively small.  My salad was tasty with a good amount of mango slices.  It was a bit soggy, but that helped with the spice.
author: Karen L.

description:
the hole in the wall magic just adds the the flavors in the food. i got the chicken salad and it's deliciousness was packed with flavor and spices. Small leafs of romain chopped up, topped with grilled chicken, green onion, cilantro, carrots, rice crisps, all covered in a refreshing sweet light vinaigrette dressing. my friend got the classic house noodles. she said it was a little on the salty side. good thing i got the grass jelly to wash everything down with. it was a sweet fruit drink but once i got to the chunks of "grass" ekk me no likey. 

im def about to go back and order the noodles. thats where its at!!!

oh yeah and its cash only. dont worry each dish is only like $6.50! :)







@devour_sf 
#devourthat
author: Lia B.

description: I ordered the house noodle bowl with pork. Didn't get pork, instead I got 5 pieces of chicken instead. Also ordered potstickers  and one piece looked like it fell on the ground and put back into my container. There was dust and hair at the bottom of the potsticker. It was my first and last time ever going to Yamo.
author: Andrea H.

description: Didn't even get to try the food yet. Was rudely interrupted on phone with order. Need attitude check.
author: Shane M.

description: I am deeply pleased with the many vegetarian entrees, including a new take on Green Tea Leaf salad that is a cooked variety - yum! My one quibble is the ambiance, which really can't be helped in a space this small - still, there are few seats which means sitting at a counter space near the several frying pans and the clouds of oil-scent. Nonetheless, the staff are friendly and hard-working and serve promptly, and the prices are inexpensive.
author: Geri W.

description:
Good little Asian place ... Everything is freshly made like an Asian place in Asia .... Little Burmese ladies making your food ... Pretty good ... 

Needs a better beverage selection.... In my opinion.... Like hot green tea, Vietnamese ice coffee, and soda water.
author: Faith C.

description:
My first post!

It meets all my expectations for a cheap, filling, and delicious meal. Although I could've tried all the dishes three times over with all the times I've dined in and ordered to-go, I always go for the tea leaf salad and house noodles with beef (have tried with pork, meh). I've been guilty of ordering two orders of the tea leaf salad and not sharing. For $6 - $7 a dish in this city, why not? 

Caution: the tea leaf salad definitely has a kick to it. 

Most people seem to have negative comments on the service, but for 2 older ladies and sometimes a college-aged female, they do a heck of a job. Sometimes their bickering with each other is part of the entertainment. I think that's just part of being Asian: no indoor voice. You should meet my mom.
author: Kit E.

description:
Hole in the wall Burmese place. Really good food!
We had to wait for about 20 minutes even though we went on a weeknight. It is a very tiny space with about 8-10 stools facing the kitchen. The lady who runs the place took our orders at the door and then had us seated. Food arrive pretty fast and was sooo good! The tea leaf salad was probably not as good as Burma Superstar but it had its own unique flavor. 
Will definitely be going back sometime soon!
author: Shriya P.

description:
Great food. Cheap food. When a place is always crowded, you know its good.
Cant wit til i go back!
author: Fareed F.

description:
CASH ONLY.  Yamo is a tiny restaurant in the Mission where you can get Burmese food pretty quick.  They only have a counter for maybe 8-10 people.  I got the stool by the door, but kept hitting my knee on something on the bottom of the counter.

I got the House Noodle $6.  It's just a big bowl of noodles with choice of meat & some green onions, no soup.  I picked pork & it was ok.  Noodles are nice & chewy - I liked them.  There's a hot oil condiment, sesame oil, jalapeno pickled on the table.  Siracha available too.

You can eat there or take out.

One toilet/sink in the back on the right.

I might go back, not in any hurry.
author: Ann L.

description: Solid, cheapish eats. Beef and chicken noodles were pretty damn good. Try it before you load up on the chili sauce/soy. Will be back - the lady who runs the joint is funny. She was laughing after she turned a customer away, hahaha
author: Jeff M.

description: I was super excited to try this place. But.... the service was awful  (Which wasn't the worst part). The food was disappointing. The egg rolls had no flavor and no sauce and the tea leaf salad was soggy and had too much sauce. I wouldn't recommend it.
author: Rachel S.

description:
I'm lovin' the foods! Had vegetable curry and fish noodle soup there. Idk why people said they tasted bad. But for me and my sis, who grew up in south east asia and had our burmese grandma cooked for us, we loved the food. It's not salty but enough to make you thirsty. well, my tummy is satisfied!

Yes, the ladies were rude. Trust me, they were actually not that rude. We talked to one of them and she smiled often when responding to us.
Tip: don't take pictures there. They gonna be mad. Cash only, better give final amount and don't expect change.
author: Bianca N.

description: Burmese cuisine with character.  This small kitchen probably serves out the best noodles I've had in California and some of the best Ive had in my life.  A must stop in place for anyone traveling through the area.  And if you live in the Bay area and haven't been here, shame on you
author: Nathan M.

description:
Cheap, messy, unfriendly yet some find continence and tasty. I've tried twice, and I didn't enjoy my experiences. 
When you call to order to take out, they take orders yet they didn't make it. Yet, elsewhere can we get a filling meal for $5-6?
author: Chacha M.

description: My favorite Burmese place..fast and yummy. Always hits the spot! I always order the house noodles, chicken noodle soup and black bean fish..
author: Maricar F.

description:
What It's like eating here: The ladies running this joint are at Folsom Street Fair wearing full zentai suits and whipping the Yamo grease out of their customers.  The 'Safety Word' is: "Tea Leaf Salad".  If you are a masochist or like thrown shade, Yamo is the place for you!  One time I saw the staff be unreasonably rude to a sweet pregnant lady, which I'm not cool with.  Another time a friend of mine asked if they were still open and she scowled at him and walked away silently. Tactless.  

The food: pretty cheap yeah, but honestly go to Burma Superstar or Mandalay; the quality and consistency of these places far outdo Yamo. Things don't really stand out here. BASIC MEHnu.

The ambiance or lack thereof: crowded (literally, you will rub elbows), unkempt, oily, and did I say Oily?  Don't wear anything nice because you're clothes will reek for the next week.  More oil than a Noxzema commercial.

Overall this place is a case study in the inexplicable correlation that "divey" has with "cult following".  "Divey" doesn't necessarily mean bad, and in most cases it doesn't, but here there's a lot left to be desired.  

Yamo? More like Ya-No.
author: Ovidio C.

description:
Found on Yelp this tiny restaurant when I looked for lunch around work, and went to Yamo for a to-go based on good reviews and a decent quantity of reviews. 

What I ordered: tea salad ($6) and Yamo house noodle with beef ($6). 

Food taste and quality: 
*The tea salad is nothing really "tea". It is cabbage and onion and a variety of nuts. First of all, the portion of the tea salad is WAY TOO SMALL. I am not sure about dine-in portions because pictures on Yelp look big enough, but the to-go portion is absolutely too small for a $6 salad. Taste is just a okay. Nothing special. 
* Yamo house noodle with beef: nothing really special and just very average quality food. Taste bland and I gotta use chili sauce to make it taste better.

Maybe other foods at Yamo worth a 4 star review, but I don't see how it could happen. 

Restaurant is run by several old ladies and a very tiny restaurant that sits maximum of 8-10 people. You have to sit at kitchen counter. If you just want something quick and fast, then grab and go because sitting there for lunch/dinner will make you smelly cuz of all the smoke inside. A run-down, small, crappy-looking place. 

Foods are Chinese foods, not really Burmese. 

I won't go back again! Keep looking if you want good foods and a comfortable sitting.
author: Lena H.

description:
Worst service ever!!! Those ladies treat you like enemies instead of customers. It's really hard to find parking so my bf went to look for parking while I waited in line. Then they told me I have to wait for the other party to come to sit inside. Fine. Since we didn't know how long it would take to get a parking, we changed our mind to order take out. Right after I ordered take out, my bf found a parking and came. There were only 2 ppl dining in at that time. And no one was waiting in the line. Then we asked whether we can change to eat inside. The lady yelled at us "no, you can't change your mind". 

Food is really good and cheap. But I still give them one star since there's no reason to be so rude. And I will never ever come again! I'd rather eat instant noodle at home!
author: violet s.

description:
I was lucky enough to come when there was NO wait here, but after eating at Yamo I would definitely wait for the food. 

I had the house noodles with pork... one word to describe it? AMAZING.

This place is cheap, greasy, and delicious. It's tiny so don't come here with big groups!
author: Tammy T.

description: I have been going here since they opened and the food quality has diminished in quality.(although it does depend on the cook). The fried rice used to be a great example of the dish. Today at lunch I was served clumps of wet rice with the spices not blended in entirely throughout. The curry fish was over sauced and lacking the intensity of flavor that it should have. The tea salad is still the best in town ( minus the small rock I had). The service is "unique" but Judy, the owner, is a very nice person.
author: Eric P.

description: Amazing! The house noodles are perfectly flavored and reasonably priced. Tea salad was a perfect texture, bites of crunchiness, very refreshing and a little spicy, just enough spice to entice your appetite. Would recommend to go as this place is TINY, would go again for a weeknight dinner take out. Overall delicious!
author: Ingrid C.

description:
Phenomenal. I had the yamo house noodles and tea salad. Both are really good. 

The place is small and nothing fancy. The staff is pretty straight forward but the food is simply good.
author: Sam G.

description: The house noodles, as everyone has mentioned, are delicious and not that oily, but aren't filling. I probably would need at least two bowls of these to be sufficiently satisfied. I would highly recommend taking the food to go as it's extremely crowded inside. I wasn't able to try the tea leaf salad, though I hope I will next time.
author: Ruobin W.

description: Pretty cheap for the price, under $30 for four dishes. Tea leaf salad tasted like crispy nutty salad. My chicken noodle soup was plain coconut soup with noodle and five strips of chicken. Asked for sugar and fish sauce but was confirmed twice that they don't have them here, just soy sauce lol
author: Yanakon D.

description: Divey, cheap, fast.  Recommend taking it to go as there's only counter seating close to the cookin range.  Get very hot up in here.  My go to for cold noodles.
author: Sam T.

description: One of the ladies that works there is extremely rude. She says "WHAT DO YOU WANT?!" every time someone new sits down. Also screamed at someone NO PICTURES! last time I was there.  Very consistent in her rudeness over many weeks. Food is very good though and cheap.
author: Pete S.

description: We came here at 7pm on a Wednesday and didn't have to wait long for 3 ppl. We knew what we wanted to order -- beef noodles, black bean fish, tea leaf salad, curry chicken, spring rolls. There wasn't much meat in the noodles, but what meat there was, was great. The tea leaf salad was definitely the winner, and the thing that'll bring us back. Everything else was good but nothing to write home about. Bang for you buck (it was $12 pp after tip) but you do deal with the wait, the unfriendly service, and the smell that lingers in your clothes and hair.
author: Vivian H.

description:
This may be the cheapest good-quality restaurant I have ever been to. Everything is $6 and under! Granted, this isn't a place you want to take someone on a date.. it gets stuffy and squishy. This place defines "hole-in-the-wall." There about 8 seats at the bar, no table seating, and you watch them cook your food. I ordered the Yamo House Special Noodles with Chicken, and it was great! The chicken was super tasty and the noodles were garlicky. Only downside is that there were 0 vegetables in it, but that's fine if you're a meatatarian. I would say that servings are smaller than average here, but it's still great for $6. And that $6 includes taxes!! Would definitely come here again for a cheap/good meal. 

Side note: My friend got the mango chicken with rice and he said they were spicier than expected. Also he preferred the noodles :) 

Don't expect to go to a fancy party afterward because you will smell like delicious fried noodles when you walk out!!
author: Amanda C.

description: It's literally a small hole in the wall, and if u blink u will probably miss it, although there is a huge sign on top of it's door. It's in the heart of the mission and serves up some darn good burmese cooking! The place is really small, and there's only probably a dozen or so seats available. You can order to go if u don't want to wait, but I prefer to snag a chair and witness the 3 ladies in action, cooking up a storm. The food is really authentic and cooked fresh to order right off the grill. The house noodles is a must, and everything on the menu is $6 or less. Oh, and they also serve fresh coconut juice. They also provide a lot of vegeterian options which seems quite popular with a lot of the customers. Can't beat that!
author: Gina N.

description:
If you go out to eat for the customer service, don't eat here obviously. I think a good sign for authentic Asian restaurants is if people complain about customer service. I ordered, the food appeared. The ladies refilled my water glass. I'm happy. 

The food was delicious. I came on a gloomy Saturday afternoon and the chicken noodle soup hit the spot. The chicken was cooked perfectly, it was little breaded and crispy but still moist and tender. The broth was flavorful and the texture of the noodles was spot on. 

The space is small but we didn't have to wait long. I am looking forward to coming back.
author: Portia M.

description: Rude service and mediocre food. Both of the staff working were extremely rude. Both staff members refused to give me the spivey sambal sauce that I love so much (even though there was a gallon of it behind the counter) and insisted on giving me sweet and sour sauce as if I couldn't tell the difference. After all I needed some decent sauce because the food was bland-- you'd be better off going to Panda Express. I'm not sure why there is so much excitement around this restaurant! The condiment cases are greasy and it generally looks unclean. Very poor service and bad food. Don't waste your time or money.
author: C. W.

description:
Sorry guys it's just not that good. I want to love this place as I am prone to liking hole in the wall type of places such as this.

Bottom line - food lacks flavor and is bland. I'm sorry but it's true. If people really liked this with a 5 star review then I question their taste buds and they are giving the review based on ambiance.
author: Suntosh M.

description:
I don't know what I can add that hasn't already been said but hot diggity, I'm all about $6 menu items. I may not be a math whiz but I can easily multiple by sixes, yessirree. I've always seen a long line snaking out the door and at 7 pm on a Tuesday, it was a small blessing that only the bar seating was full sans line. 

Burmese food in the city tends to cost an arm and a leg and after a particularly hangry (albeit first world) experience waiting three hours for Burma Superstar, this was the complete opposite end of the spectrum. It seems to be operated by a family of brisk, no-nonsense women. The menu hits all of the right notes from salads to curries to soup and noodles along with a selection of appetizers. Portions are modest but filling. 

The Tea Leaf Salad was crunchy, savory and spicy - all of my favorite things. Followed up with piping hot mango chicken with juicy chunks of both fruit and poultry, the dish was tempered by a side of fluffy white rice. The house noodles with pork were also spot on with chewy intensely garlicky noodles and bright fresh herbs. Together, it was a flavor explosion of awesome. I'm usually one to add tons of sriracha and chili garlic sauce on 99% of my meals but this one needed no extra spicy lovin'. I gulped down plenty of H2O but I was a very happy camper.

Cash and minimal 8-person bar counter seating only. Don't expect super friendly service besides taking your order but that's not what you're here for now is it?
author: Faith Y.

description:
DON'T EAT HERE!!! Absolutely WORST customer service I have ever experienced! The place is small and the three older women were extremely rude. My gf and I sat down at what seemed to be open seats. Once we sat down, one of the ladies literally threw the menu at us. Seemed as if she was upset we decided to eat there. 

The same lady rushed us to order and was really impatient while we were looking over the menu. We quickly decided on two dishes to avoid anymore confrontation. I realized the restaurant was a "cash only" place so I ran down the street to an ATM once we ordered. Wasn't gone for more than 10 minutes and the same grumpy woman that was cooking the meals GAVE MY SEAT AWAY despite the fact that my gf told her I was coming back. She gave my one seat to another couple right when I got back. Incredibly rude! 

I'm usually forgiving of bad service especially if the food is good, however, this restaurant is one place I will NOT support. Not worth the horrible experience! If you absolutely must try their food...order 'To-go!'
author: Christopher C.

description:
I'm all for hole in the wall spots and rudeness usually does not bother me.  This place is something else.  

Food is 3.5 stars.  Service, cleanliness, and just common human courtesy are minus 5's.

Get over it old ladies.  Whoever or whatever wronged you...let it go.
author: James S.

description:
I love Burmese food so I had to check this place out while I was in the Mission.Upon walking in, I noticed this place is literally just a counter.

As you sit down, you will likely be within spitting distance to the 'chef.' It's may also get really hot from all the cookin' and the fact that you're in a tiny, tiny space. Although they do get some points for having a place to hang your coat :), hey little things matter - right? I was taking a phone picture and got yelled at for it (I made sure no faces were in the picture), so eep! Watch out with your camera phones!

I ordered the Mango Chicken and a tea salad (both dishes were $6). The menu said the tea salad comes with dried shrimp and tomatoes so I was pretty excited -- I do love some shrimp and the concept of a salad from tea leaves is incredible, right? Well, the salad comes out and it's a few tea leaves with some dried beans.. no shrimp or tomatoes. I mentioned something and got yelled at that people didn't like the shrimp in the salad, so it no longer comes with it. Okay, that's cool, but it would be nice to be told this before I place the order..? I was disappointed.

The mango chicken on the other hand was incredible. Large portion, good amount of chicken, pieces of mango (I didn't even know mango could be cooked like that) and just typing about it makes me want to eat some RIGHT NOW. I tried to ask for a few bucks off the Tea Salad at the end, because come on -- the menu said shrimp and tomatoes and the salad had none of those things. They just yelled at me some more and whatever, I would have been happy to tip them if they simply listened to my concern and did something, but I guess this isn't the type of place for that. So, yeah -- I paid the bill and left all frustrated, but stumbled into a Buddhist temple down the street and did some meditation which brought perspective that my first world problems of a tea salad not having shrimp are not all that bad. :)

Anyway, come here for cheap food -- get take out if at all possible. The mango chicken IS incredibly delicious.
author: Alex L.

description:
I don't get what the fuss is about.  I've been to this part of the world, and eaten street food there.  So the fact that the decor is, well, non-existent and you're sitting at the counter doesn't bother me at all.  What bothers me is isn't not actually that cheap, and the food is not that good.  

Everything kind of tastes the same -- like underseasoned grease.  The noodles are both overcooked and greasy.  The fish is fried so much there's just batter, no fish.  The chicken has no flavor.  They use onions and green bell peppers as filler vegetables, instead of things that taste decent and cost more than zero.  

It'd be one star if it wasn't for the tea leaf salad, which is quite good, although too small.
author: Zachary R.

description: The servers are so rude.  Sometimes I think they pretend to not hear you, sometimes they ignore you.  BUT the food is so good, and their attitudes don't really bother me.
author: Jeff M.

description: I don't understand the high reviews. I love Burmese food and this is nothing like what I've had. I support hole in the walls and really wanted to like this place but the food was not good.. at least it was cheap.
author: Elle C.

description:
Yamo was an easy and quick dinner to grab on a Friday evening! I came here around 6pm and there were only a couple orders ahead of me. I ordered food to go, and it looks like you can also call ahead. I was warned that this restaurant was "divey" and greasy, but I thought it looked clean. You sit up at the counter to order and they cook the food in front of you. It smells like food/oil, but I would feel fine eating at the bar for dinner.

We ordered the tea leaf salad, house noodles with beef, and cold noodles with chicken. I loved the tea leaf salad - it was small, but perfect for two. The noodles were chewy and really delicious, and I really enjoyed the house noodle dish. The beef was tender as well, although there wasn't a lot of beef with the noodles. The cold noodles are spicy! Plenty of red pepper on top, chicken, noodles and some veggies. I expected the food to be greasy, and it was not at all.

For two people, we had some noodles left over and spent less than $20! Except some delicious and budget-friendly food, this is not Burma Superstar. I recommend coming to eat here if you are a party of 1-2, there really isn't much room for more. It's fun to watch the women cook and make the food while you wait. Take-out took about 10 minutes, and was an easy option.

Cash only!!!
author: Lauren G.

description:
Definitely a Hole In the Wall! 

Seating is quite limited so I suggest you order to go and head up to Dolores Park to enjoy your meal unless you really really want the counter experience.

I don't think food is bad but I certainly don't think its that amazing either. The problem I have with Yamo is that there food is too greasy. I find that after I am done eating, my mouth is coated with an oily film. That aside, the flavors are one note at best and leaves me wanting a little more. 

I have tried their fried rice, chow mein, egg rolls, curry shrimp and etc so I have a good sense of what Yamo can deliver. I really wanted to like this place but I have to disagree with all the 4 star raves.

I will admit that the price and portions are enticing but its not enough for me to give Yamo any higher than a two star. 

Overall Thoughts

I love Hole in the Wall places but sadly I do not love Yamo.
author: Eddie W.

description:
A cozy joint, about 10~ seats, bar seating only.

Cheap prices, honest food. I recommend trying the tea leaf salad if it's your first time, and definitely get the house noodles with your choice of meat (pork, chicken, beef).
author: Patrick L.

description:
I can't get enough of Yamo. It will forever remain one of my all-time favorite cheap, hole-in-the-wall gems. 

The thick, perfectly cooked potstickers, the deliciously simple yet amazingly flavorful house noodles, the tea leaf salad and the super sassy staff are my favorites. People complain about the "rudeness" of the staff, but that's also what makes this place so hilariously charming. I find it efficient and an excellent source entertainment while eating at the counter. 

The only downside: You'll smell like Yamo for a week 'cus you're practically sitting in the kitchen - Totally worth it though.
author: Colleen C.

description:
How can you beat $6 entrees that's delicious, fast, and CHEAP. My favorite!

It really is a "hole in the wall" and you walk in to bar seating. Grab a seat and put your order in. There's 3 ladies working one manning the stove that has about 3 pots on top. I can't help but laugh and think of "Cooking Mama" (for those of you who play Nintendo DS games).

I ordered the house noodles with beef which was super good. The noodles tasted so good but every time I slurped some, I would end up feeling like I put on oily lipstick. That aside, the beef was perfect and as a whole the dish was bursting with flavor but not too salty... yum. The portions are a bit on the smaller side and you shouldn't end up with leftovers so if you come here with a buddy or a date, my suggestion is get 3 entrees and eat it family style or try a bit of each other's.. or get 2 entrees and an appetizer. The spring rolls looked pretty good.

No complaints about service. There are only about 11 bar stools and with 2 waitresses/chefs/servers right in front of you, they won't forget if you ask for a refill on tea or an extra order.
author: Lauren K.

description:
All I can say is that I made all the ladies there laugh tonight. I love them! Speak a little mandarin, ask them what dialect they're speaking and where they're from, then tell them their food is delicious. I even made fun of the "angry" lady's Cantonese (it's not Cantonese), and said I had a hard time understanding if that was Cantonese or not. She jokingly yelled at me to not poke fun at her "Cantonese" next time I come in. Gotta work with schmoozing, people! 

The food was delicious if you order the right things. Curry is so so, but the tea leaf salad, though small in portion is delicious. The cold chicken noodle is tasty as well, but don't get it if you don't like spicy foods. 

Take the pissy lady's attitude as entertainment, eat what's brought out for you, and you'll do just fine. If you speak some mandarin, take a risk and flirt a little... it'll make your next visit a bit better.
author: Ray C.

description:
I go to Yamo all the time and I've pretty much ordered everything off their menu. The tea leaf salad is a must. It's sweeter than what you'd get at Burma Superstar or other places, but it works really well here when combined with the spice.

The House Noodles and Cold noodles are fantastic, with a perfect amount of flavor without being overbearing on sodium. The Mango Chicken needs some work though, it was too heavy on the sauce and a bit lacking in flavor. 

Also, I love how blatantly mean the Asian ladies that work here are. I don't think I've ever seen one of them crack a smile. Don't ever change, Yamo.
author: Charles H.

description:
We had tea leaf salad, Yamo house noodles with pork, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.  The flavors were so so, chicken and pork were on the tough side.  Really bad service.  We arrived at 12:00 PM, 6 seats were available.  We sat at the counter for at least 30 minutes watching the two women doing prep work that should have been done when they're opened at 11:00 AM, before our orders were taken.  The worse part was everything's very oily. After we left, we both smelled like old deep fried oil.

Will not return.
author: TopCat W.

description: Showed up at 11 am or opening time, and the gate was closed and the door was shut but someone was inside, and they noticed me. After waiting for at least 10 minutes, I left and went elsewhere. Later on, I came back and sat down to eat at one of the 7 or so barseats. The fish curry was so-so and pretty bland overall, but my neighbor ordered garlic noodles and he offered me a bite, and they were delicious. The main problem is the service is terrible. The ladies working there think they are doing you a favor for serving you. The food was good, but not out of the world, as it should be for putting up with the seating/service/etc.
author: Kelly M.

description:
There's a difference between being curt from being just plain rude. During my most recent and brief visit for lunch, I witnessed the two ladies behind the counter argue with each other, reprimand a customer when he made a simple error of calling the "house made" noodles "homemade", and mock the customers after they have left. It also took me 5 tries to get a glass of water from them - and I was nice and polite about it each time (same lady just kept giving me a blank look).

The food is still consistently bland and sadly not enough to buffer the awful service there. Yamo, you've lost another customer.
author: Camie K.

description:
I really should hate this place..

I seated myself in between two guys and was bumping elbows with them the whole meal.. and by whole meal I mean 15min max.

There was zero customer service (the server/cook lady was busy yelling at another customer. "You pay now or after order??")  

I got my food, a little too salty but pretty decent otherwise.

I paid my $6 cash with some tip and walked out. 

I stink now because the restaurant had no ventilation.. AT ALL. 

But after everything, I walked out feeling pretty satisfied. Yamo reminded me of the dirty hole-in-a-wall type places that I frequented in Asia. The food wasn't bad, the experience was interesting, and I didn't burn a hole in my wallet. 

Way to win me over Yamo..
author: Lynn C.

description:
The food is very cheap and quite good, though somewhat oily for my tastes.  My preferred dishes are the Yamo noodles and the mango chicken.  The tea leaf salad is okay, but does not pack much flavor; the versions I had at higher-end restaurants have been substantially better.  

However, don't expect much in the way of service, and whatever you do, try not to argue with the people working here.  One time I was here, a misunderstanding between the staff and a customer about his order led to the staff berating the customer and bluntly telling him that he was wrong.  Several times, I saw a people being scolded for trying to take pictures inside.

The way to get your food without trouble seems to be to come in, wait your turn, give your order, and not make a fuss.  As other reviewers have noted, it definitely reminds you of a certain Seinfeld episode.

Much as I like good, cheap food, I am not going to be a regular here, and will gladly pay a few dollars more to eat at a place with better service.
author: Alex L.

description:
so overrated!!  how is this so popular?  it's just like any divey hole in the wall.  It's not bad for the price, but it's nothing to wait in line for?  Maybe the mission is just lacking any Asian options that are low-brow?
Fish curry was no good.  Tea leaf was ok.  Noodles were greasy and bland.  
And they have shrimp, but they definitely don't have shrimp.  So don't ask for shrimp, unless you know they have shrimp.  Wait, what?
author: Christian W.

description: Yes, the food is good. But the portion size are so small that might as well be serving French dinning.  See picture of tea salad in Togo container with regular mug next to it.  The container was barely half full. Also try ordering the black bean sauce fish and you'd know.  It doesn't cost that much to add a little.
author: Gus K.

description:
The food was good, but this place has plenty of room for improvement. We waited over 40 minutes for a small to-go order, and the employees/owners simply could not care less if you have any questions about their food or menu. Be prepared to be met with blank stares and mocking if you dare ask a question.

If you want some good, cheap Burmese food and don't mind waiting for it - this place is ok. I would definitely take it to-go, and if the employees are rude to you I would definitely either walk out without your food and go somewhere else, or leave a comment as such on here. 

The owners need to realize that poor customer service has an effect on business regardless of how great the food is or how long you've been in business.
author: Aaron L.

description:
Yeah, she is not here to make you happy. It is what it is and unapologetically so. It's an experience. It's not clean or polite. But it does not pretend to be otherwise. 

If you don't like it, go have your new mission sterile predictable experience where everyone is trying to make you happy someplace else. God knows there are plenty of options. 

I miss this kind of place. The owner is who she is. Take it or leave it. 

Food is good.
author: David C.

description: Thee worst Burmese in San Francisco. Very rude. The ginger and tea leaf salad was drenched in fish oil and soggy red onions. Do not try this spot, go to Burmese Kitchen or another place. Promise
author: Ryan T.

description:
I ate here with a friend a couple of years ago and remember loving it.  It's a true hole in the wall, bordering on a dump. The food prep area is clean but don't look too closely at the walls and ceiling.  This is an OLD space and looks it.  

I ate here again today and it was dreadful. I had the chicken curry with rice.  Grand total $6.25 cash including tax.  The "curry" did not taste at all of curry.  The rice was perfectly cooked (but then again, what Asian restaurant can't cook rice?).  The curry was very salty, not spicy, and the pieces of potato (yes, potato), onion, bell peppers and chicken were floating in grease.  Bright orange grease.

If the starch is rice why am I eating big chunks of mushy boiled potatoes with the rice?  Is that a thing in Burma?  I don't know, but I didn't like it.

I left most of the sauce on the plate.  I felt a bit ill after my meal.  Not food poisoning ill, just heavy greasy meal ill.

I do love dives (though this is more of a dump than a dive) and I love cheap good food.  I'm sorry my experience was so different than the first time.  I won't be back.
author: Alexandra D.

description: The ladies who work here speak loudly and quickly with a thick accent, don't be alarmed if you feel like they're yelling at you. They're not (I'm 47% sure) and you get to watch them cook all of your food! Everything I have eaten here is delicious, and it's absurdly and wonderfully cheap for how fresh and authentic the food is. I was slightly disappointed with the size of the tea leaf salad today, but I adore the food and incredibly small, hole-in-the-wall status of the place, so I give it 5 stars. Not to be missed. I wouldn't go with more than 3 people to eat in, the restaurant seats 8 people tops.
author: Hannah C.

description: The food is good for the price, but I feel like I'm getting yelled at whenever they take my order, either on the phone or in person.  No pleasantries. The chef also handles the cash without washing hands. I guess that's what gives this place its hole in the wall charm.
author: Jeff B.

description:
Really A-OK taste (ate, got full, felt like finishing each dish), price ($6/dish, incl. tax), and efficiency (you get in, order, eat, pay, and you're out asap). 

I like the homey-ness of the service and I dig the hole-in-the-wall atmosphere but unlike a Chinatown restaurant, you can see all the action.

By seeing all the action, I mean the good, bad, and the unsanitary.  We sat at the back of the restaurant by the fridge and the third/last prep station.  This was where all the cold drink, big veggie-cutting, curry or rice scooping, and utensil/iced water pouring was happening.  The Aunty that was at this station was really very nice, telling us to shout our order to the other lady-- "she's not deaf!"--and giving us priority service.  We noticed a smattering of veggies and various other things falling on the ground, and being then picked up to only be put back in place without washing or replacing.  Our salad was made with a bunch of yummy things, but it was tossed with part hand, part glove and we noticed money was handled with the same! OK so I wasn't born yesterday and other places do these things too, but most times, please lie to me and don't show this side.

Anyway, tips--
1 Order at the front
2 Cash only it seems, no tax, but it's nice to tip
3 Close your eyes during food prep
4 Chicken noodle soup, tea leaf salad, house noodle-beef were solid choices
5 Water cups are small, order a canned drink& get a straw (they have soy milk, grass jelly, and guava juice!)
6 Speak Cantonese and you are taken care of
7 Be prepared to smell like oil afterward
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Today I came in so excited to eat at Yamo again, there were random single seats available and I was with my boyfriend...soooo we thought that by ordering out would be the smartest choice!

We had just placed our order and then two groups of two left. We asked the ladies working if we could sit down and they immediately yelled at us and said "NOT YET". uhmmm okay..not yet what? I can't sit down, not yet or...you haven't gotten to my order yet???

The bigger lady with short frizzy grayish hair then continued to cuss at me in Cantonese...which she had no idea that I could speak fluently ( my first language ) and I immediately fired back (in Cantonese of course, duh) " I was just asking, you didn't have to be so rude about it "... She of course said some other choice words...which were so uncalled for. I'm just asking a simple question most dining customers would have asked -_- geez, chill out.

and of COURSE the food this time was not as good. They obviously didn't care about our order...just glad they didn't spit in it :'(

My bad I asked if we could change the order for it to be for here....ew, this experience made me so upset because while I totally enjoy the food and the feel of this place, the service is horrible for no reason! Not that they will read this or a "manager" will have a meeting about customer service..but I guess for future customers that want to change their order from to go to eating there...beware!


:'( another bites the dust.
author: Selina W.

description: Love this place so much. Hole-in-the-wall with the best food and affordable prices. Ladies who run the place are no-nonsense, don't get offended by their curtness they just mean business and want to keep the line moving. Food is delicious, cheap, and really hits the spot every time. Get the Yamo noodles with Pork, Tea Leaf salad and the potstickers.
author: Max S.

description:
Yamo is...what it is.

The service is terrible, but the food is decent and at $6 a meal the value for price is amazing.  I go to Yamo more often than I care to admit, and yes everytime the food tastes a smiddggeee different but i'm generally always happy.  My fave dish is the black bean fish (there are maybe 3 black beans in it but alas..) 

Feed yourself and a few friends for under $20 and have a very unique experience. thats Yamo.

Pro tip: call ahead for take out and skip the line
author: Maryanna Q.

description:
Really, no water??? C'mon! Ya gots ta be kidding me. I have been coming here since 2006 and have been very faithful of the best food for the price in the whole section of SF but then I go there the other day with my gal and we were chowing down on some Mango Chicken and Chicken Curry Soup and I ask for water (you know in the nice crystal water glasses they used to cool the burn in their spicy cheap goodness and what?-no more glass of water?) The glass was the only semblance of classiness in the total HOLE in the WALL. (Which was ok by me really, yes it was fine-the hole-in-the wallness.) But no more! I say bring back the glass water glass and we return-or be doomed to obscurity. It is the only thing to do gals. Get it? I don't think you do. Ever since your big sister left years ago you were just skating on her smarts. This is a bad decision that will not bode well at all (plus maybe your shrinking portions, sometimes too salty and too greasiness). 
Big suggestion here: bring back the water, do a better quality control (IE: watch the salt and grease), raise your prices by .50 (to pay for the water-if you must-and you will be fine! I hope you make it because you ARE (or WERE) one of the very best!
signed, one of your faithful
author: Lantz G.

description: This place has consistently great food, and consistently surly service. Which is fine by me. I went with the fish chowder and curry beef, neither of which I'd had before. The fish chowder was huge and surprisingly delicious. That may become a regular item for me. The curry beef was good, but I still prefer house noodles with beef and the mango chicken.
author: Jamil M.

description: It's like going to grandma's house to eat, except there are three grandmas and they make great food!
author: Ulises R.

description: This place is so good and cheap for San Francisco.  Portions were small but were good for the price. The house noddles with beef is a must try because the beef is slightly crispy and tender.
author: Andrea M.

description:
My initial impression of this restaurant was better than just three stars since it was such a quick process. But the second time is when I discovered how terrible the environment was! This place is DEFINITELY NOT A SPOT TO eat or chill at -- it's cramped and SUPER smokey. And I have only ever ordered to go, and even the wait is terrible because the smoke burned my eyes during the waiting process. Also, the lady making the food was pretty rude too, but considering the environment of the restaurant, I wasn't expecting great customer service. This is really is a "What you pay for is what you get" kind of ordeal.

The food is pretty good. I actually prefer this place over the ever-so popular Burma Superstar. Only because the tea-leaf salad is much more tastier and actually has me craving for more. The house noodles with beef is really meh, a little tasteless, just add soysauce+hotsauce & you'll be good. But the only thing I genuinely like about this place is the tea-leaf salad, it's pretty bomb and cheap! Portions are kinda small, but it'll have to do.

 I'd come back, only for to-go, cause I'm not trying to burn my eyes while I eat.
author: Mel T.

description: This little hole in the wall is the definition of home cooking. The ladies that work here are adorable and it's great to see them cooking as you sit at the bar. We got the Yamo house noodles with chicken and the samusas, both of which were very tasty. It was pretty clear that their takeout business is strong, so since the place itself is so small I would definitely recommend getting takeout.
author: Amy Y.

description: Literally the worst service. Food is terrible here too. I have no idea how this got rated so high but do yourself a favor and never come.
author: Alanna P.

description: Rude obnoxious behavior! Doesn't know what customer service means. Yelled at us just because we asked her if we could eat in the restaurant instead of take food to-go! Good food doesn't mean you can behave however you want with customers
author: Akshay B.

description: This is a true hole in the wall.  Cheap inexpensive eats.  It reminds me of old Chinese places with greasy noodles and core fun.  The noodles they use in the soup is the thick ones for chow mein. Overall it's simple comfort food that I'll come back again for.
author: Harry C.

description:
Walking in here is like being transported into a third world country. Came here on a weekday night, all 8 chairs were taken. Not that I would've sat down anyway, since I don't want my clothes and hair to smell like food. I stepped in briefly to order and pay for Mohinga (fish chowder, no dairy), about $6, and already felt like I smelled like the restaurant.

5 minutes later, it was ready, and I brought it home. It was pretty good, no complaints. But +1 for being the most legit hole-in-the-wall I've seen in SF.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
I agree with people saying about the customer service.  Confirmed!! It sucks!! This place is pretty cheap but you probably have to order 2-3 orders of stuff just to get full so you pay for what u get. The tea leaf salad was good but I think it was like 3 forks full. I was like What???? All you guys that gives this place 4/5 stars?? You guys are freaken high off your ass!!!

Ohhhh yeah.... this place is filthy!!!! I got the eebie jeebies when I walked in this place.
author: RICKY C.

description: Never disappointed with food. This is my 2nd takeout. It is literally hole in the wall place. Food is fresh and cheap. Can't wrong house noddles and samusas.
author: Niaz K.

description:
Yamo is not for your friends with OCD tendencies or if you want white linen service and the food can be hit or miss. When it's a hit, it's just the best.

+small menu- can be a good thing, can be a bad thing
+the cook/servers don't speak English or just don't want to talk to you- I come to a restaurant to eat food, not talk so I am fine with that.
+there may be a wait, it has 8 seats, what do you freaking expect.
+this dish may or may not be authentic and frankly I don't care, they taste good.
+it's cheap but not as cheap as it used to be, there are also a lot more people in there wearing skinny jeans and who can afford 750,000 1 bed condos in the Mission. 

It is not wheelchair accessible. If there is a bathroom I've never seen it. The only seats are at the counter or one table.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
Such a small place you could easily miss it. It's worth eating in, but you will probably have to wait due to the shortage of chairs and space. 

Humorous staff, they'll make jokes with you.

Great food. Big portions and really cheap. Mango curry chicken is the move.
author: Andrew H.

description: Yamo is an overrated hole in the wall joint in an up-and-coming neighborhood. Portion is super tiny, quality / sanitary is questionable but they've got some serious devotees (as you can tell by the line going around the block especially during busy lunch times). Service is non-existent, as expected from this kind of places. I'd only recommend Yamo as a mid afternoon snack (to go, not for dine-in) for those who'd like to get a taste of Burmese. Don't forget to bring some cash as this place is cash only, although you can probably get some cash back from Duc Loi Supermarket across the street.
author: Effie G.

description: Okay look - it's $6.25 for a bowl of delicious noodles. But you don't get that without giving up something in return. That something is your time (wait for a seat, wait for your noodles), and good customer service. The noodle matron is a grumpy old broad who just wants to hear your order, serve it to you, and get you gone. Decide what you want on the menu at the door, or quickly at the counter. Don't ask her how long it will take. Don't make unusual requests. Think of this like place the soup place in that famous Seinfeld episode, only noodle style. I'd have given it five stars, but the potstickers sucked and I love me some potstickers.
author: Arthur G.

description:
Went to this place last night for the first time. It's absolutely amazing. It's 150% worth it to wait in line. The tea leaf salad didn't sound great but it's insanely good. 

I can't wait to go back!!!!
author: Blake Y.

description: Authentic Burmese/Chinese food + cheap + quick = happy stomach/wallet
author: Wayne Z.

description:
I thought this place was only okay but maybe I ordered the wrong things. The tea leaf salad was really good. I'd get it again. It was crispy and flavorful.

I also tried the vegetarian curry and fish curry. Both were bland and oily. If we'd only tasted those things I would've given this place one star.
author: Julie N.

description:
I was so excited to have my first Burmese food experience at this renowned hole in the wall or at least they say. I was so disappointed.

I had the Yamo House noodles with beef. it was completely lackluster. No sauce on the noodles except for some fried garlic and scallions. The beef wasn't even marinated in anything and tasted like it was going bad. I almost threw up even.

The catfish chowder was completely unsatisfying. I couldn't even taste the catfish. There were not even chunks or bits of fish. The flavors didn't grab me.

I definitely got what I paid for, all $12 of it. I should of just saved it for So wings and black bean noodles. They need to open before 4.
author: Wen C.

description:
I thought my food was great. 

It's pretty entertaining  to try to order, then wait and watch everyone try to order.. Don't try to tell them to make any changes to your order, the guy ahead of me was getting  yelled at for asking for more sauce in his noodles....my best advice is to come here with humor cause these ladies are  brusque!!!

I had the cold chicken noodle and the tea salad.

Walked here after class at Yoga For The People...
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Date & Time:  Saturday November 21, 2009 @ 4:30pm
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Neighborhood Peeps & Hipsters
Vibe:  Very Casual
Decor:  Hole-in-The-Wall w/ Counter-Seating
Service:  Nice & Efficient Asian Ladies 
Imbibe:  Fresh Coconut Drink
Devour:  Yamo House Noodles, Chicken Chow Mein & Curry
Total:  $20.75
author: Genevieve Y.

description: There is no place like Yamo. The definition of a hole in the wall. Great food, all of it, and ridiculously cheap. Just don't lounge around after eating if there is a wait, they'll chase you out.  Somehow it endeared them to me even more.
author: Jan S.

description:
I ordered the house noodles with chicken - OMG they do their chicken something amazing. Greasy, sweat, crunchy in all the right places. The noodles were good, sweet, slimy and greasy too. My stomach is not happy with the amount of grease I just consumed...but it was worth it. 

Okay, the ambiance: the service is perfunctory and direct. It's a team of no - nonsense older Asian ladies who don't mess around. No, they won't take special requests. And they won't apologize for it either. And no they don't want people hanging out and loitering when they make their money by rapidly turning over seats. But the lady was nice enough to let me stash my massive backpack next to their fridge in the teeny tiny dining room. Thanks, lady. 

Oh yeah this place is small, divvy, smokey, and dirty. You'll love Yamo if that's what you're into. If you're not...maybe get their take-out instead. 

I'd go back and try their soup (the guy next to me got it and I had instant order envy) and the tea leaf salad because apparently that's a thing. 

Although I'd go back, I would not wait in line. It's good, but not that good. If you want to wait in line for amazing noodles and Burmese, check out Mandalay in the Inner Richmond.
author: Michelle K.

description: Yamo literally embodies "hole-in-the-wall," with a row of counter seats facing the open kitchen and breathing in the hot air and grease from home-cooked Burmese cuisine. Every dish is bursting with flavor and very reasonably priced, while filling up with just the right portion sizes. I had the cold noodles, which were served with vegetables, chicken, and a lot of spicy sauce. Every bite had chewy noodle, crunchy vegetables, and the extremely spicy but delicious sauce that was reminiscent of both Thai and Chinese cuisine. We also tried the spring rolls, which were rolled right in front of us with fresh shrimp and mint. You can't go wrong with anything here, as everything is prepared in a no-nonsense manner, letting the ingredients and the authentic flavors speak for themselves!
author: Ashley T.

description: Stellar. Absolutely changed my perspective on cold noodles. I'be fallen in love with a new cuisine.
author: Mike W.

description:
This place is TINY. Only about 10 seats (bar seating), so make sure you either order take out or deal with the wait.

The food here is okay. I've definitely had more impressive Burmese food (e.g. Burma Superstar, or B-Star). The tea-leaf salad here was really spicy, but small portions. Both Burma and B-Star trumps Yamo's tea leaf salad by far.

The other dishes (mango chicken and house noodles) were also both okay. Nothing blew me away, but it didn't leave me disappointed either.

The great thing about this place is how cheap it is. Three dishes we got for $18. Incredible!
author: Stephanie L.

description: The tea tree salad and chicken noodle soup on a rainy day is the perfect combination! Best hole in the wall in the city!
author: Ian M.

description: Tea salad and chicken noodle soup both ridiculously good, and at about $7 each, what a deal.  I would eat here all the time if I lived nearby
author: Brown S.

description:
When the only thing u can rave about is the price, that's not necessarily a good thing. I'm really sorry if this review offends others who like this place. But this is SF, we have lots of asian restaurants that are much better than this place, so it merits only 2-stars.

This is a true hole in the wall with only a few coveted counter seats available. I love how this tiny space has survived for many decades. Somehow all these years, the 2 older asian women manage to greet and handle customers, take orders, answer the phone, serve drinks (includes opening coconuts), cook, package to go meals, and wash dishes all day long. They are amazing!! so they get no complaints from me if on a rare occasion sometimes they appear to be grouchy.
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/GVeUTiGqWSJ39sQ0HX_RfQ/l
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/ZvKgw0yrzjCzR0-vdwcRJA/l
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/K_-idIy-0-iAlhezSUdqKA/l

And I do remember that I raved about their house noodles and the rice dishes in the past when I was still a college student. Now that I'm older and hopefully wiser, food quality matters more. Yamo is just not that good. If u try many of their dishes, you'll taste the same horrible raspy sauce that's not even authentic. Sorry these night pics are not as sharp.
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/dQRn0_6g_a9C0WoG-80F-w/l
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/9hmJMW8H53nSxLjFz3mozQ/l
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/H7ca6jPgiyjG7FsXI83IHg/l

Sorry Yamo, I won't B there.
author: Luis C.

description:
sometimes you get home from work and want a home cooked meal. You've no energy to cook for yourself. So you decide to go to the low-key, hole-in-the-wall spot your roommates rave about... and you have exactly what you needed--a meal prepared just for you.

Coconut water straight from the coconut
Dumplings
Curry

Yum, Yamo, yum.
author: Mariam T.

description: Exceptionally rude staff. Take the hype out of it and it's average food for the foodie masochist in denial.
author: D T.

description:
This has got to be the worst hole in the wall ever.  The lamp above me was shaking back and forth and would not stop. Believe me, I've been to some really good hole-in-the-wall's but this is not it.

Service: terrible. boyfriend had his phone out and the lady cooking yelled at him, "DONT TAKE PICTURE!" They don't really speak much English and are extremely loud and rude.

Food:
Tea leaf salad-1 star. First of all, it is tiny. Second, it was way too saucy. Third, I'm sure people who liked it, or this place at all, has never tried Burma Superstar..or other Burmese places..
House noodles-3 stars.  The only thing that tasted good, and for only $6. Really greasy and oily, though.
Mango Chicken-1 star. Mango was not ripe.  Entire dish was too saucy.  Everything was greasy.  What is this...

Price: 3 stars. you get what you pay for. it's dirt cheap.

Love this area, but this little place is just not for me, or any foodie..

I also got a little nosebleed from the clustered, tiny, steamy, greasy place. 

I will not be returning.
author: Alyssa Z.

description:
Hole in a wall, so you cannot expect much. Food not so special, super greasy, only tea salad was good. The ladies yell at customers for: taking pictures? for seating down w/o your guest who is at a store around a corner getting cash???!? It's no cool, unless you go to the special "rude" restaurant :) After 15min you smell like an old pot of grease, that place has ZERO ventilation. 
For the variety of foods and places SF has to offer I will pass on this next time in the area.
author: Aleksandra I.

description: The food is pretty delicious, the staff is as rude as it gets. They are so rude I actually find it funny and I don't really mind. Food is really good and really cheap. Must try the Mango Chicken, Spring Rolls. Don't look too carefully at the cleanness of the place and the kitchen or you may change your mind and go somewhere else. Stay strong and try this place out, you won't be disappointed
author: Marco R.

description:
Great Burmese food at a fair price!

It's not usual to find a budget eat with such fresh food.  I ordered the mango chicken with rice.  They have an option to pair your food with noodles in case you're not feeling rice.  I must say that the noodles are so tasty!  I'm going to make sure to order that for my next visit.

Fair warning, this place truly is a hole in a wall.  My friend describes it as "an extension of their personal kitchen".  There are no tables and seating is at one counter bar where people sit side by side to eat.  It's definitely well worth the wait, which there usually is a short wait.  You can also order your food to-go in case you can't find street parking (all metered but their meters take credit cards as well).

One thing I really want to try for the next time I visit is the tea leaf salad.  I've tried it at an overpriced Burmese place in the East Bay (the kinds of places where you pay for the ambiance) and yet Yamo's dishes match up in taste and quality thus far.
author: Krystal Nina L.

description:
My OCD tendencies, Food Safety Manager/nutritionist instincts are rendered useless here. I believe that either the sheer thickness of the caked on layers of grease and grime that adorn the walls are so overwhelming that it literally paralyzes me. It's either that or the food.

Can I just say one thing? This place is one of the dirtiest places I've ever eaten at in my entire life... and I'm from the NYC area. Like, damn.

You can see for yourself - the women that run this place mean well; they treat the restaurant kitchen like home. A very dirty, grimey home. Drinking coffee, ringing people up, taking orders, throwing menus, and tearing up lettuce in a 4 foot radius without any hand washing makes for a very high incidence of projectile vomit from immunodeficient customers. I don't know, maybe I can't blame them.. the line is constantly out the door... what am I saying? There's no excuse for poor hygiene.

Unless of course that excuse is Burmese noodles, specifically from Yamo.

God. I'm going to regret this.

The noodle dish that I ordered, smelled, consumed, made sweet foodie love to... has long since been unmatched. I dined here months ago. While my germ-ophobia prevents me from returning, my imagination runs wild at the recollection of fond memories of savory umami flavors, tingling spice, and complete palate satisfaction.

Case and point. Dine if you dare. I, personally, have dared and been delighted.

Bring some hand sanitizer, bottled water, and an appetite. Good night, and good luck.

PS - there are like 8 stools in there so the line gets pretty long.
author: Rosavida C.

description:
(See pics) Review #1131. More of 4.3 stars. What happened when you have a heavy breakfast and skipped lunch? You are on a carb starving mode and all you can dream (crave) of was greased up Chinese food.

Totally hole in a wall and tiny, delicious tea salad was an appetizer and a palate cleanser. The popular noodles were wrapped with just enough amount of oil and the chicken was good crispy delicious. And I did finish the whole bowl  (not huge) very quickly.

Definitely love the fresh coconut but felt sorry when they had to saw it through with a knife manually.

And it's quite inexpensive.

Also love this kind of atmosphere, hot, cozy, a sense of style and super friendly service by the super sweet Asian women and other patrons.

Ah yes, there's a line but it moves rather quickly (15-20 mins) for dinner.
author: T L.

description: So disappointed with this place. Made a mistake in assuming that because this place was both divey and busy, it had to be good.
