I ordered the fish chowder with noodles, and it tasted neither like fish nor chowder. In fact, it had very little flavor at all, and the noodles were soggy. Along with other reviewers, I , too, observed one of the ladies handling cash and then dishing out noodles into bowls with her hands. As I write this an hour later, my stomach hurts, and I don't want to think of the so-many reasons that may be.
author: Angela K.

description:
horrible service, incredibly rude. I had made an order for take out, I then immediately noticed a seat opened and asked to dine in instead, she refused to give me that seat even though it was clearly open and the rest of the customers told her it was fine to allow me to dine in. Still a no. What happened?!

the tea leaf salad is delicious, however shockingly small in proportion.
author: Sydney L.

description: Don't come here expecting some sort of amazing experience and or to be aesthetically pleased. The food is good, some ingredients are questionable but I still go all the time, price is right. Lol.  The ladies working there might seem rude to some but that's just their culture I don't mind it.
author: Chris T.

description:
Love Yamo! One of the few places I don't mind waiting nor the lingering smell of grease hours after. 

Even though I don't usually go for greasy, oily foods, I always get the Yamo House Noodle with Beef (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=GVwiKtfXiq8KfiwTjeLshw) Screw you, irritable stomach! Something about the way they cook the beef, its so-dang-good. It's lean, yet tender and flavorful. Reminds me of rehydrated beef jerky, if that makes any sense at all.

New discovery: The Yamo Cold Noodles (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=LdOX74kqLs8Yps_6Y-rT-g). Cold noodles, chicken, cabbage, onions and cucumbers with "House Special Flavor". This flavor is a mixture of sweet sauce and chili flakes. First taste might be odd. But couple bites later, you'll be hooked. Great dish anytime!

Cash only. No delivery. And oh, those ladies love Chinese-speaking boys. lol.
author: Marti L.

description: this place has been on my list for ages and ages, and since my client is now in the mission, i tried the tea leaf salad for lunch. prices have gone up by $0.25 on every menu item. sooo the salad looks quite sizeable on yelp photos, but in real life it's tiny. i thought i could eat it like an entree - no go - but it was pretty good even in a takeout box with all dressing mixed in. service is basically non existent and the lady taking your order is quite rude... but. i will be back a few more times to try the rice and noodle dishes. not ready to give up on this spot just yet!
author: Christina L.

description: I've been a regular here for years, loving Burmese food, cheap prices, funky one counter holes in the wall and I live directly across the street. But I will never go back because they shrunk the tea salad to a couple tablespoonfuls and are rude. The last two times I went in, there were 3 other people there because I know the good times to go and never wait in lines. The main lady was on the phone and when she got off she proceeded to do everything else but acknowledge me. I walked out both times. No "I'll be with you in a minute." No "hi". Nothing. Anyway, they don't wash they hands and the counters are filthy. I'll get my Burmese across town at star or at Streat foods, thanks.
author: Josie L.

description: Excellent food for the price.  Not a lot of seating.  Come early and enjoy.  Everything on the menu is great.  Staff are nice.  The broccoli beef is fantastic.
author: Zach T.

description: What a hidden gem! Favorite restaurant in SF, super cheap! The owner is something out of a Jerry Seinfeld skit! I love love this place!!?
author: Thomas S.

description: Love this place. Delicious, fast and cheap. Cash only. Noodle nazi lady - don't try to change your order after you placed it she will say no.
author: Julia M.

description: How come no one gets the fish chowder? It's amazing! Also really like the samosas, I enjoyed them. Everything else might be kind of bland.
author: Gina R.

description:
CHEAP and DELICIOUS. Nothing here is over $6 and there is such a great variety to choose from. 

I really enjoyed their tea salad. Just the right amount of spice and very appetizing. Their house noods are AMAZING. We got 2 orders. One beef and one pork. We also got their curry chicken and mango chicken. Both were delicious with the rice they came with.

Potstickers were big and juicy. My first time trying samusas. Will definitely not be my last. So good.

Place is ideal for to-go/pick-up. I want to try everything on the menu.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
If you like eating in a closet, come here!  I've only eaten IN the resto a couple of times, preferring to call in and pick up my order.  It's definitely a tight squeeze and the wait can be long at times. If you're there for the first time with your sweetie to keep you warm as you stand in line...go for it (but I digress)...the food is really good.

It's amusing to watch the ladies behind the counter do their thang.  Shouts all around, but it's a graceful symphony that results in an absolutely happy tummy.

Prices are very reasonable, and the food is served to you very quickly.  All of the dishes I've tried here have been good, but some faves:
Chicken noodle soup
Tea leaf salad
Yamo House Noodles
Yamo Cold Noodles

If you're having a meal there, ask for fresh coconut.  As you sip on the juice of a baby coconut cracked open just for you, enjoy the tastes, smells and sounds this Burmese eatery.

Oh, don't plan on going anywhere after because those scents stick ;)
author: Moo C.

description:
I stopped by Yamo for dinner on a Friday evening hoping to find good Burmese food and fast service. Although, they seated me as soon as I get there and got my order like in 2 minutes, it took exactly 45 minutes for my noodle to be ready. Well, I don't care about waiting a total of 45 minutes on a Friday evening but, boy, you can't let your customers suffocate under that smoke for 45 minutes. As soon as you get in, you know that you are going to stink for the rest of your life.

Food, was absolutely great. When I was there they did not have prawns so I ordered beef noodle (#15). Everyone seemed to be satisfied with their food. Service was slow and it is annoying to wait under that grease cloud that can rain instantaneously. Employees are rude but well, who cares. 

Super helpful-tip: Do yourself a favor and take it to-go.
author: Gokhan T.

description:
This is an overdue review from back in feb 2013:
Not worth the wait. If there were a Burmese version of panda express this would come close (except panda express is highly commercialized/americanized and clean). I didn't find the food to be particularly Burmese or particularly good (greasy/soggy) especially considering the long wait (almost an hour) and the staff looked completely overworked and on the verge of meltdown. I really don't know what the draw is except that it's cheap for sf and  maybe the whole locality thing might play a factor in supporting neighborhood businesses.
author: Chrissy C.

description: Restaurant is owned and operated by rude and unhappy people. They are keep yelling at customers. Even not allowed to look and take photo of shop. I don't care about taste. I don't understand why it has good rate.
author: Cony L.

description:
Long wait and I mean longggggggggggggggggggg...

Yamo is really cheap and when I mean cheap, you can't really find anything above 10 bucks or even above 7 bucks. I love the food here, especially the cold noodles which remind me of a noodle salad. It has tons of flavor and makes me go wow. The samosas are awesome and so is the house noodles. The curry chicken is standard while the mango chicken is above average. I would stick to any of the noodle dishes at Yamo.

The food is definitely homemade because you can see all of your food being made right in front of you and the 7 other people sitting next to you. The downside, yes, the restaurant only holds 8 people. The wait is killer because you can wait an hour before 2 seats are available. Ordering togo might be a better option but that can take just as long or longer since togo orders outnumber the actual diners. I have gone here several times and the staff is nice and very entertaining. Others know what I am talking about when I mean entertaining...
author: Danster L.

description:
This place is certainly a good value for money, but don't expect the best food you've ever had. Most of the meals appeared to be around $6.25 which is super cheap! We got ours to go and there was a small line around 8pm, so we probably waited 20 minutes for our food. 

We tried the house noodles with beef that I had read about in other reviews. Decently tasty but nothing I'd run back for soon. The chicken curry was also decent, but definitely not the best curry I've ever had. One portion is just enough so you don't leave hungry. My friend tried the mango salad which was good but very spicy. Overall if you're looking for some inexpensive and relatively quick food, this is a place for you.
author: Amy Y.

description:
I had the tea leaf salad and house noodles with beef.   They both were bursting with flavor. The tea leaf salad was so good, I almost wanted to order a second. Their menu was simple, which I liked.

This place is affordable, each dish I ordered was $6.25. Most other dishes where about the same price. It really is a hole in the wall--there are literally only 8 or 9 seats so there's usually a line. I see a lot of people ordering for pick up. There are also hooks for coats and bags on the walls behind the seats, so you can make yourself comfortable. Would definitely recommend.
author: Lisa V.

description:
The perfectooooo greasy spoon and Burmese/Chinese food at that! We got lucky and there were a few empty seats, Tues 11am...you're thinking lines on a Tuesday? Yup, this is the type of place that does! Seats about 10 on the bar stool so try to go on your off-hour or you could be waiting for a while.  The better alternative would to actually get the food TO GO to avoid the long line situation altogether!

Chicken Noodle Soup coconut noodle soup with chicken, onions, and cilantro - $6 -  I've had traditional Burmese chicken noodle soup and this comes pretty freakin close!  It's not the best I've had but when you don't have the time to prep the broth 24 hours in advance, this is a good alternative.  They cook to order and the broth is creamy and full, the noodles are cooked to order and they have nice full flavors of coconut, garlic, onions and cilantro.   

Tea Salad tea leaves, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds - $6 - I'm not sure why there was no tea leaves??  It was GOOD but not GREAT.  Yes all very fresh ingredients but wish there was more tea leaves to bring out that strong bitter tea leaf taste.  ah well...  maybe they should RENAME this item because if i didn't expect tea leaves i would say this is quite an excellent salad!

Yamo House Noodles mixed with fried garlic, and a choice of beef, chicken or pork - $6 - Greasy but so delightful!  Every bite is full of that garlic taste.  We got chicken and i absolutely LOVE the way that they prepare the chicken.  Crispy and crunchy on the outside and still juicy on the inside.  The noodles are the perfect amount of chewy and i really enjoy the sauce that they mix all together in this unique stir fry.  This is MY GO TO ITEM.  

Next time I think I might call ahead to order TO GO but this was a good experience sitting in this little piece of Mission district heaven.
author: Sandy L.

description:
Okay, I'm all for a hole in the wall, "authentic", greasy spoon joints. I don't  mind the sass or broken English - as long as food is worth it! 

Since the place is small we called to place our orders around 3pm. Some lady picked up on the 7th ring and barked, "wah u want?" 
Mango chicken and House noodles? 
"15 minutes" Click!

When we got there, 3 older ladies milled about.  5 minutes of standing attention, one of them finally asked "wah you order?"  She got the bag, "13 dolas"!  So the price is friendly enough.

It'd all be rather charming if food is as tasty as some of these reviews claim.  Oily and salty seem to be the flavor, and if that's the aim, they've succeeded for sure.  Once is enough for us.
author: daphne w.

description: One of my favorite places to eat in the Mission. Great, delicious Burmese food at a very reasonable price. The atmosphere takes the you away from the the techy-elite male dominated playground that the mission has become.
author: Will M.

description: Rudest place in the world. Can't believe that they kicked out customers before finishing dishes. Not even deserve one star.
author: James K.

description: Fish chowder soup!!  The other stuff is good too.  Cash only and it's a tiny diner style place so you might wait around 15 mins
author: John P.

description:
The epitome of a hole-in-the-wall. 

If you Google hole-in-the-wall, I wouldn't be surprised if this establishment pops up. 

This tiny place is grungy, sticky and greasy; yet it all makes sense and adds to its charm. All those years of greasy build up from the walls to the ceiling and electrical cords all adds to the experience. 

There's a kitchen then a counter that seats less than a dozen people at any time run by an all-female crew that takes no nonsense and lacks a little bit of customer service....in a charming way. They either have none or limited English, but you can easily communicate with them with basic English...and maybe some pointing and nodding here and there. (OK...I'm exaggerating, but you get the drift) 

There's no frills here, and you come here just for the food experience. If you have to use the restroom.....ummm.....good luck? 

But the food here is delish. Everything is lovingly and expertly prepared by an old, Asian lady that could probably beat an Iron Chef on any given day. She's fast, efficient, a bit grouchy but knows what she's doing behind the kitchen. And what she turns out is similar to a good, homemade cooking similar to what grandma used to make. They even offer vegetarian dishes and the Tea Leaf salad is on the spot. 

I love hole-in-the-wall places that serve good and inspired food. Yamo is definitely that place.
author: John G.

description: I'm all for hole in the wall places -- in fact, I LOVE hole in the walls but this place, unfortunately embodies all that is bad about one without the good -- dirty, grimy, and bad service.  I had high expectations for Yamo given the glowing reviews and my own love for tea salad -- the tea salad was pretty OK for $6.25 (except there wasn't really any 'tea' in it) but the service was terrible. Ordered a noodle soup specifically asking for no cilantro -- only to find cilantro in it and have the waitress/cook challenge me saying that it wasn't cilantro (I've spent my entire life avoiding/detecting cilantro in many a dish so I definitely knew what it was). Instead of redoing the order (I hadn't even touched yet), she just started picking at it with the same chopsticks she had used for something else with impatience and annoyance written all over her face. Hole in the wall or not, it was an experience that left much to be desired. And especially when you're in the Mission, cheap, GOOD hole in the wall options are aplenty -- will not be coming back to this one unfortunately.
author: wendy q.

description:
Perfect spot for lunching solo, it's like hanging at your mama's kitchen and eating while she cooks.

Plus you might just strike up a convo with random strangers grabbing eggrolls and tealeaf salads next to you and find out you both speak Mandarin with a Beijing accent and appreciate Dolores Park on a sunny afternoon.
author: Jackie G.

description:
Dug it.  

Went during the week so there wasn't a wait.  Intimate seating -- only 8 or so stools at the bar, all facing the kitchen where they cook and serve up your dishes.

Their house noodles were all they were built up to be.  Filling and delicious!  And all for $6!  

Tried a bite of my friend's Cold Noodles -- awesome chili sauce!

Loved the dry garlic bits sprinkled on top.  Definitely added to the awesomeness.
In all, I'll definitely be back.
author: Lily B.

description: Some of the food is undercooked and the kitchen is pretty dirty. I ordered the potstickers and when I cut it open with the fork it was still pink and uncooked. I understand things happen so I asked them if they wouldn't mind cooking them for a bit longer. To this, they both looked at each other, said something I didn't totally understand, and proceeded with what they were doing. They never acknowledge me again and also never recooked the food. The rest of the food I ordered was ok but overall the experience was pretty terrible. Totally don't reccomend this place.
author: Diva H.

description:
Let me say first that the complaints about service shouldn't even be an issue. The whole takeaway from the Yamo experience is knowing what you want to get before you go inside, getting your food order in once they address you, pay for it, and go or if you decide to sit at the counter, dig in. Y'all want some conversation and a smile? Go talk to your neighbor next to you because these ladies are too busy making quality food and don't give a shit, which I kind of admire.

As for me, I usually drop in after the lunch hour and go up to the counter and order my house noodles with chicken or pork to go then pay my 6 bucks and wait outside (unless you like hot smoke blowing in your face), people watch, and get asked if I'm waiting for the bus to which I kindly reply "no" to about 5 different strangers for about 5-10 minutes, depending on how busy it gets. Easy process and you get one of the best noodles in the city. I've developed a habit of getting my Yamo noodle fix every week due to its proximity to my work. Even if I didn't work in the area I'd try to make a trip out here to satisfy my craving. It's that good.
author: Leslie K.

description:
Dear Ladies of Yamo,

Thank you for all you do. Thank you for being yourselves: Alpha Females feeding us healthy, hot, delicious food for a reasonable price. Thank you for reminding us that the customer is NOT always right (the sense of entitlement in this city is disgusting at times...you're reminding people that they don't always get their way and sometimes they have to wait, and you know what, sometimes they don't get noodles at all if they ladies of Yamo are too tired or simply just over it). 

I love you. Keep on rockin' in the free world, and serving up the best noodles OF MY LIFE!

xoxo
Serena
author: Serena Q.

description: The ladies may be a little mean. But, the food is so amazing that if you complain you suck. Mango chicken. Tea salad. be appreciative, and don't let your tech privilege get in the way. Go back to Mountain View.
author: Troy R.

description:
I have no idea why this place has such positive reviews. The place itself is just a countertop and it is very hot inside due to the cooking which is done basically on top of where you are eating. The service is rude although this can create some mild entertainment as you watch people try to order and get waived off or dismissed. Remember the "No soup for you" episode of Seinfeld? Yeah, kind of like that. Also, they only take cash which sucks.

Considering all those negatives the food at this place must be divine, right? Wrong. The food was bland, lacked flavor or complexity, and was below average at best. 

Tea Leaf Salad - This was just sort of meh. If pressed I'd agree it was good (nothing special) and that's a bit of stretch. Based on the reviews I was expecting it to be amazing or at least above average. 

Mango Chicken - Not bad but again, nothing special.

House Noodles with Beef - Completely bland. No flavor. Barely any meat. Even hot sauce didn't add much help. Just not good. 

Overall, there just is nothing appealing about this place at all. The atmosphere is poor, the service is terrible, and the food is below average. I think the reason this place gets positive reviews is because after waiting in line at a small hole in the wall restaurant that is sort of off the grid people don't want to feel dumb so they convince themselves it's better than it really is.
author: Jackson B.

description: Just amazing Burmese food!  Tea Salad was the best and we had great noodles too!
author: Steve F.

description:
CASH ONLY!  

I love this place!  It's small, so I recommend take out if you don't have time to wait.  It was introduced to me by a broster years ago and this place never gets old.  It's a go to spot for out of towners and when you are craving home cooking from someone who reminds you of your mama or aunt.

The noodles are really good here (noodleholic here) and everything is fresh!
author: J. T.

description:
Ok place to eat. Don't think it deserves as high a rating as it has.

Food: ok to good.. Really greasy. I got the house noodles and curry beef.
Service: lol. The lady behind the counter seems to be perpetually angry. 
Atmosphere: small.. Definitely take it to go.

Cash only. Nothing special.
author: Tony P.

description: This place has good (although not the best) food, and it's very affordable. But we waited half an hour to get in, and after that, as of now, we've been sitting for half an hour and no food. That's an hour.  People who got in after us have already been served. Given how many good restaurants there are that don't have this long of a wait, it's unlikely we'll make another special trip to come here.
author: David A.

description:
WOW. I had no words but WOW when I took my first bite into the tea salad. After a few bites of WOW'ing and nodding, I asked... whaaaat is that crunchiness in every bite I take?! (mystery yet to be discovered)

We also got the house noodle with beef. We learned from our neighbors that it also comes with a small bowl of veggies. ASK FOR IT! mix it up with the noodles and ENJOY!

The mango chicken was pretty good, but probably 3rd ranked out of the items we ordered. Don't get me wrong.. it's still good. It has a nice sweetness to it with a slight spiciness.

I left full. Happy. and with $9 in my pocket for dessert. oh, and not to forget... onion breath. ALL WORTH IT.

Sit on the far right side when facing the kitchen. Not only do you get bombdiggity food... you get a butt massage from the vibrating dishwasher! WOOOOOT WOOT! hahaha. Such a great hole in the wall place. Literally. There are probably like 10 stools available.

oh yes, one last thing- PARKING SUCKS.
author: Kathy Y.

description:
Been coming here for a few years- and we usually get "decent" service, but that is because you have to operate by a code.

1: Know what you want and order simple. 
2: Don't ask questions.
3. Don't look the 3 Raw Burma Mamas in the eyes.
4. Enjoy your meal as quick and best as you can while packed like sardines in a can.
5. Don't mind the grease and smoke.
6. This is a place to eat and go. This is not a place to linger or lounge/conversate.
7. Always have cash.

The last time I was here- this poor naive chap broke all the rules.  He started with asking what was in the dish when all the ingredients are listed right there on the menu. Scowl #1 from the cook plus a big fat WHAT DO YOU MEAN.  Next, he proceeds to ask her how to pronounce a word in Vietnamese. Scowl + Death Look #2.  I cringed as I was sitting next to him.  This very naive guy continues to make a point that he googled it and proceeds to pronounce his newfound Vietnamese vocabulary word.  Burma Mama #2 looks at him and yells OK! with Scowl #3.  I about died inside for him. I think he finally realized to shut the hell up and just enjoy his damn noodles.  Poor guy.  You don't go ordering soup from the soup Nazi and try to be his friend.

These ladies may be RAW but the food is cheap and good.  It's a certain kind of hole in the wall experience. (8 seats to be exact)

Our favorites always comes down to the House noodles with beef and Tea Leaf Salad (although there isn't really any fermented tea leaves inside) it's still good.

Follow the Code and you will avoid the Death Looks with laser beams that want to incinerate you.
author: J C.

description: This place is AWESOME! The only set back is, that it is the size of a walk in closet...But it is WELL worth that inconvenience! I had neve rhad Burmese food before and needless to say, I was blown away by how delicious and mind blowing the dishes here are ands they seem so simple when you see them on the menu...Then, they are served, and you are takne away to a lanbd of blissful flavor! I will always visit this placew when I am in the City! It is a MUST!
author: Spike D.

description:
This is the literary definition of a hole in the wall eater that's worth trying.

Once a hidden gem, now is a well known spot. The line certainly dictates that. With diner seating around the kitchen food is shuttled and passed to all the customers. It can be cramped because of the space constraints but don't let that take away from the food. The service is as best as it can get with the staffing and limited space and customers constantly filling the seats. If you've ever played Diner Dash, this would be an expert level, LOL.

The food is absolutely worth it. It may take a bit to get to you, but once it does it erases any complaints with possible wait. Everything is affordable. We were tempted to order one of everything just to try but that's not possible because, 1) space. diner spacing is already an issue. 2) staffing. there's just enough for everyone and we didn't want to piss off the whole place and staff. And 3) we didn't want to be jerks, haha. 

I can recommend some things but it would be too much to list! Everything we had was good. Served properly and don't let the surroundings deter you. It's worth it.
author: Jay V.

description:
All of my friends SWEAR by this place so I had to come and try it out for myself.

The menu was semi-short to go with the small hole-in-the-wall shop. We weren't sure how to order or if the lady was going to take our order. If you just stand there for a little bit, they will come to you eventually. I had just chicken with noodles and they were very tasty! Not sure if I would wait in a really long line for them though...

I won't swear by this place but I definitely wouldn't mind coming again for some cheap good noodles.
author: Ezequiel R.

description:
By chance, I noticed Yamo last week and now passing the place (with fast sinking blood sugar), I stopped and decided to give it a try.

First off, Yamo is a shoebox. But this place last week and tonight was full. Everyone sits at a counter on some funky, red vinyl covered stools. What caught my eye this time was a guy seated close to a door drinking from a straw that fed into a real coconut. I had to exam the menu in the window.

Appetizers: $4.95 - only 3 choices: samusas, egg rolls and potstickers. 
Salads:       $6      - tea leaf or chicken salad

Ahh, the samusa and tea leaf salad on the menu immediately screamed "Burmese" to me. 

Entrees: All $6 - choice of curry beef, chicken, curry prawns, curry tofu or curry fish. Everything goes over egg noodles or rice. Don't like curry? they make a house fried rice or a house pan fried noodle. You kind of get the drift that their repetoire is strictly enforced.

When I popped my head in, the main lady and the cook looked over the full row and then peeked over the counter and nodded me to the 1st stool right inside the door opposite the stoves. Umm, is this the best seat in the house? Or is this the worst seat?

I've got to say I like the fresh air coming into the door. Didn't like the closeness of the flames from the wok shooting up in the air from the stove.

Without being in a party, I chose only one dish: curry prawns with rice. I was fascinated watching the ladies' system. The head lady takes the orders, gathers ingredients and places items in a silver dish which she lines up by the cook and the cook stir-frys each dish up and gives it back to the head lady to deliver to the customer.

Back to the food: now dairy-based curry generally has a good sauce that goes good with rice. But when I was served up my dish, I found I had a reddish, oil based curry with the prawns. Foiled - not much sauce. The food was okay and definitely hot from the oven.

Other male diners (with bigger appetites!) went all out ordering potstickers, curry fish noodles and fried rice and curry tofu just for two people. Some couples took out an order of the tea leaf salad on their way out. Seems like a very popular dish.

It was really interesting to watch the interplay between the ladies busting themselves to get the food out. I watched the youngest of the ladies hack (with a cleaver) at the top of a fresh coconut to pierce the shell so a straw could be inserted. Amazing.

What else can I say? If in the area and hungry but on a budget, come for the food and stay for the show.
author: Joanna T.

description:
The employees here are rude and have bad attitudes!

I called in on a Saturday afternoon to place an order for pickup. I didn't have adequate cell phone reception, so I called back in about one minute since I couldn't hear her (and wasn't sure if she heard my order). 

She proceeded to yell at me over the phone, scolding me for calling twice (?). 

The portions were small and greasy - Totally not worth being yelled at over the phone!
author: Alex H.

description:
I am right at Yamo. Narrow and dirty space. It's like eating inside a bunker. Unfriendly owner. Food is so-so. Service is poor and slow. The dishes are small, and therefore inexpensive. This is my first time and my last time dining here. 

If you like Burmese food, I would recommend the restaurants at Inner Richmond. If you still want to try, go right ahead! You will be welcome by the yelling of the owner.

By the way, I had a quite similar experience as in the review posted by Samee M. Read her review and be prepared!
author: Hazel H.

description:
The wait is usually about 30 mins. I always get the:
Beef House Noodles - tasty
Tea Salad - a bit spicy but good
Pot Stickers - sweet with a kick, good 

Good pricing - less than $8 a plate
author: James L.

description:
AMBIANCE: Classic hole-in-the-wall! It fits about 10 people so either expect to wait or order to go (definitely the better option when it's crowded). The place reminds me of a grimy and tiny diner. Everyone is seated on stools, facing the kitchen where the magic happens.

FOOD: Wow! I haven't been exposed to too much Burmese food but if it's all like this, I will need to set up a vacation to Burma. We had three dishes, each unique and wonderful in its own way. 

Of course, we had the tea leaf salad. This is much better than Burma Superstar. The leaves are crunchy and are a good balance with the rest of the dish. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=UH3Aa9I4CdvqwvYpxekSRg)

Second item was the House Noodle with Beef. Nice, tender meat over chewy noodles. Lots of good flavors. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=4gV5_ohdBe_bMKtFMn2AiA)

I'm having a brain fart and can't remember the name of the last dish. Just click on the picture and guess what it is. I'm going to take a stab at it and assume it's the Mango chicken over rice. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=GKQ1fPAOdH1Fv-Y2WO5pCQ) 

PRICE: Very very reasonable! Less than $10 per dish. 

SERVICE: Run by a couple Asian ladies. They work fast and are very business-like. Just order your food and move on. Of course, business is bustling so can't really expect them to slow down and chat it up with the customers. On the bright side, the food comes promptly and without complaint from us.

THE BOTTOM LINE: 5 stars. Duh. It must be good. Check this place out if you're in the area. Or don't so that others can take your spot. =)
author: Jonathan L.

description:
You know a place sells authentic South-East Asian food when they use those bowls with a rooster painted on the side.

This is a hole-in-the-wall place that serves up decent home-cooked food. I had the Mango Chicken with Rice. The mangos were sweet, and the sauce was pleasant. It's the kind of street food you'd get anywhere in Asia. Yes it's legit, but it's really nothing to shout about. 

What makes this place worth coming back to is:
1. THE PRICE. $6 (after tax) for a meal in the city is a pretty sweet deal.
2. The three SASSY BURMA MAMAS who take your order and whip up the dishes in front of you. They do so while chattering in a high-pitched Chinese dialect and laughing at each others' inside jokes. It was a true joy watching them at work. I've heard complaints about their attitudes, but really, they're not trying to be rude- they just make no effort to be polite. Because they're fearsome beasts of efficiency who just want to get you your food as quick as possible. If you don't co-operate, prepare to get yelled at.

I left the restaurant with a smile, partly because of the savings, but mostly because it made me happy seeing those three ladies holding no airs, doing their thangg serving up good food at a cheap price, and not letting entitled customers ruffle their feathers.
author: Joel K.

description: Bring your own water bottle!  They will not serve water unless you pay for bottled water.  Its unheard of bad hospitality.  Food is so so depending on who's cooking.  I hope they can have the heart to change their mind about serving water.  I know there's a water shortage and we should be considerate about serving water but I asked and was refused water after eating spicy food.  Its about principle, and Burmese people have a great sense of hospitality.  But making customer paying for water is just a way to make more money.  If they want to make more money they can increase prices (which they have done) or create a longer menu. WILL NOT GO BACK UNTIL I SEE WATER.
author: Mar H.

description:
Food is OK, but I've had better Burmese food at Little Yangon in Daly City. Still, the food is pretty cheap. 

I wish the tea lea salad had more tea leaves and less cabbage. 

I would eat here again if there wasn't a wait and if I were too lazy to drive to another Burmese place.
author: Heather R.

description:
super cheap and really yummy. i'd never had burmese food before i came here, and now i LOVE IT. there's usually a wait because there are only a few seats at a bar in the really narrow restaurant, but if you call in or order takeout it's usually pretty fast. 

definitely get the tea leaf salad and the house noodles (my favorite is with beef). love this place!
author: Amanda L.

description:
Yamo is a hole in the wall run by dragon ladies.  What to expect: great food and kind of intimidating service! 
  
1) wait in a long line.  (although if you come 45 mins before prime dining times, the wait will be really short! 11am, 6pm)
2) sit on a rocky stool at a greasy countertop
3) get yelled at if you don't order within 3 minutes
4) eat elbow to elbow with your neighbors and hear everyone's conversations
5) possibly get yelled at again: "are you done??!", at which point you will pay a ridiculously awesome price for all the food you got with cash only.
6) smell really disgusting after, so bad you would stink up the entire cartrain on bart.

What to eat, to share with one other:
1) Samusas
2) Tea salad (so delicious, best thing on the menu! better than burma superstar's)  You may need two orders. nommms
3) Yamo House Noodles (I like it with pork)
4) Fish chowder noodle soup (my burmese friends say its really good here!)
author: Susan L.

description:
So good upon first taste, came back again for dinner on the same day. Cash only, 10 spaces, bar seating, crammed and air full of frying grease = some of the best food I've had here in SF. And after being in Myanmar, the best Burmese food I've had outside of Burma.

- Tea Leaf Salad: Tiny portions, but full of flavor and texture. Fried beans, nuts, tangy perserved veggies with fresh shredded veggies. $6.
- Yamo House Noodles with Beef: Greasy stir-friend egg noodles with strips of tender beef. Basic and filling. Would order over and over.
- Fish Chowder: It's hard to beat street-side mohinga in Myanmar, but Yamo comes pretty close. Be weary of  bones, because this catfish stew has tons. It's delightfully thick and spicy. The owners claim it's a fantastic hangover cure.

I hope the prices remain low despite the surge in business this place will no doubt receive.
author: Linda T.

description:
This place is only good if you want to feel like you are in a third world country. 

Atmosphere:
The lady who runs the place is extremely rude. She came in for her shift and started to scream at her employees in the kitchen (which is basically also the dining area.) When my dish (fish curry) arrived, I took a picture of it and the same lady screamed at me. She said "No pictures!!! What do you not understand?! I told you already!!" First of all, that was the first time she told me. There was no warning for her rude outburst...and there was no reason for her to continue her rudeness by saying..."What do you not understand?!" That kind of ruined the whole experience.

Food:
Ordered the fish curry...was greasy and basically just tasted like salt. Just an ordinary meal. Yamo is kind of like Panda Express. Good when you're hungry...but nothing special.
author: Alicia A.

description:
Authentic Burmese food but very VERY small place (seats about 10 people at a time).  A lot of people like to use the term "hole in the wall" for a lot of SF restaurants but Yamo is literally just that.  But don't let that make you underestimate what they can do in such a tiny space.

Their tea leaf salad is the best I have had in the City yet.  It has great flavor and a good crunch.  It won't beat home style tea leaf salad but still the best you can get at a restaurant.  I also really enjoyed the fish chowder noodle soup (mohinga) because it was very creamy and tasty.  The chicken noodle soup was good too but IMO not as great as the mohinga.

It was a long wait but well worth it, especially considering the cheap prices they offer everything.  Yamo is a very good find!
author: Linh V.

description:
Holy cow. Total hole-in-a-wall place.  I mean there are barely 7 seats at the bar, and barely any walking room, and they manage to squeeze in a restroom in the back!  You're facing the kitchen, btw....

Food = delicious. It's a bit greasy but the flavors are great.  Yamo house noodles are the BOMB.  Fresh noodles, delicious flavors.  I wanted a second bowl but I still had potstickers coming.  Potstickers were moist inside, crunchy outside, and savory all around.  My sister's beef curry, I thought was boring, even if the potatoes are awesomely fried. 

Service = well, it's a tiny joint, so what you see is exactly what you get.  If you want water, ask.  If you want something else, just ASK.  

Prices = cheap.  $6.00 entrees and $4.25 appetizers, and they have a few beverages too. 

Overall, I'll be back...for take out!
author: Fannie S.

description:
I honestly wasn't that impressed with the food at this place.  For what appears to be a super authentic hole in the wall restaurant, I expected the food to be delicious...especially given all of the reviews on yelp.  The food unfortunately was just ok.  I ordered the chow fun and a tea leaf salad ($6 each). A fairly good deal for lunch, but lots of hole in the Southeast Asian-Chinese fusion restaurants offer comparable meals at that price range for lunch.

I like the fact that it's run by three women...gave me a feel like I was going to their house for dinner.  That's a definite plus!  But when I go to this type of place it's all about the taste, and that wasn't there.

Tea leaf salad was also tiny, but it was the same price as the entrees, but it was definitely nowhere near as substantial.  

All in all, 2.5 stars on good, 3.5 stars for the home-like feel.
author: Michael M.

description: TERRIBLE.  Went Twice.  First time, GREAT, Second time, SUCKS.    1.  horrible service..rude, mean would have been tolerable had the food been good.  2.  dirty (nothing really changed there, it was always dirty;  how it does not get an F grade defies me, but they must be paying someone off.  I cleaned off about a 1/2 inch of scum off of the serache chile bottle, just so I did not have to look at it.  3.  finally the food, horrible.  Curry beef was served in a pile of greasy orange sauce, with no curry, there was no more than 1.5 oz of beef, the rest potato.  4.  Finally, its been discovered by the take out crowd in the last 2 years, so you wait and wait and wait for lousy food while take out orders are being filled in front of you.  DO NOT BOTHER
author: Thomas L.

description: My friend Steve turned me on the addictive Yamo!   I am always craving their (hot) House Noodles which are rich and wonderfully garlicky.  Their cold noodles, Mango Chicken, potstickers and pretty much anything on the menu ~ amazing!  I'm quite ok with the "hole-in-the-wall" atmosphere - the place had got so much character - and at just $6 per dish (appetizers are $4.25) to me it's a steal.   Yes, cash only and if ur driving like me, parking can be tricky.  the earlier u get here, you'll avoid more of the long lines - it's just a counter with about 10 fixed stools.
author: Merrick W.

description:
First off you know its going to be amazing when there is a line out the door! It's easily the best Chinese Ive ever had!

We had the Chow Mein and the House Noodles! Both were so different and just so incredible. Clean, fresh flavours, not greasy or over powering. 

The portion sizes are really good and its like $6 per meal! Its so delish, go and enjoy!
author: Sophie K.

description:
Had the curry chicken noodles and the mango chicken. Phenomenal. Will definitely comeback again, and try different items. The chefs sure have some character. Minus one star because I smelled like the food for hours afterwards and there seems to be a lot of oil used. But man, it was tasty and amazingly priced.

Almost always there will be a line outside the door, as it only seats 8-9 inside? Somewhere around that number. It's quick, easy, and an institution of the Mission. Cash only don't forget, and don't forget the ladies behind the counter will yell at each other and at YOU! Don't take it personally, also don't be such a softy!
author: Howard J.

description: It's a small place that can be easily overlooked in the Mission. There's sometimes a line outside of people taking orders to go. The place is run by three Burmese women who are very interesting characters; they remind me of my grandmother . They have really good tea leaf salad, spring roll, fish chowder noodle soup, and fresh coconut drink. They make everything fresh and the wait is short. Be aware that they are cash only!
author: Jacqui C.

description:
First reaction: A hole in the wall with more than 1000 reviews? 
Holy moly, we need to go! 

We got to the hole in the wall and found seats almost immediately and felt incredibly grateful. But after a few bites of the curry, I was not convinced. It tasted like typical Hong Kong restaurant food. Maybe I need to try another dish here? Any suggestions?! 

But I have to say, I enjoyed the cozy atmosphere and the cheap dishes!
author: Jiwon M.

description:
I meant to order the cold noodles, but ? mango chicken? came out of my mouth. Tea salad was not interrupted. Both were very good. Unusually good even, in that, this is well done Burmese food - which doesn't just happen. 
Were they worth the kind of evil attitude? Eh- yes.  Would they be worth standing in line with the hipsters for an hour on a rainy, cold Friday night? Probably not.
author: Judith M.

description:
This forum is supposed to be about how good the food was people! Stick to rating the food! It was terrible! I have lost faith in this forum after this experience. Four stars? Four and five stars should be reserved for some of the best food you've ever had. I love little whole in the wall places with quirky appeal and good food, this IS NOT ONE OF THEM. I don't care if the ladies work hard, they sure do. They work hard making crappy food flavored with salt and hot sauce. 

We had the mango chicken, the mango was so hard I had to spit it out. We had the house fried rice, which while edible, was not even good. We had the cold noodles which I did not even try because I was getting an upset stomach. The food was some of the lowest quality, poorly seasoned, garbage I've had the misfortune to eat. The way they handles money, dirty dishes, shrimp, and then ice cubes...in that exact order, with their bare hands, with no washing was so disgusting, I couldn't even believe my eyes! I literally googled the San Fransisco health department on the spot to see if they gave ratings for restaurants. They do. I looked everywhere in this place, and theirs was not posted. No surprise.

Nasty unclean women making bad food is not cool. Reality check. Y'all people giving this four and five stars cuz you think this kind of thing is "cool" are ruining this forum as a way to actually find good food.
author: Norma G.

description:
Fine. Food is standard.
Nothing crazy. 
Very affordable and they do take out. 
There is no such thing as customer service here. If you want it fast with a frown, go here. 
If you want cheap and decent noodles, go here. 
I found it rude and dirty myself.
author: Melody M.

description:
I com here just for the food.  It very good, not great.  
 
Don't expect a dinning experience because you're gonna be sorely disappointed.  Not the best service.  The space is crammed and kinda unsightly and it's so muggy inside. Take it to go if you like.

I go back regularly.
author: Bob S.

description:
*Note: This place is cash only.*

This is a great hole in the wall spot that is worth going out of your way to try. As many others have said, the Tea Leaf Salad is incredible. Fermented tea leaves, cabbage, fried beans, nuts and other ingredients give an incredible flavor for this $6 dish you could easily pay 2-3 times for in a fine dining establishment and be happy with. The garlic noodles were great and every other dish I saw looked amazing as well. I don't think anything is more than $6. What a deal!

Please note you're coming here for the food, not the ambiance or the service (although both should meet the functional needs for most). Personally I'm all about the food and value so if you share those focuses, this place is for you.
author: Cameron C.

description: I placed an order for pickup and was told it would be ready in 15 minutes. I arrived 30 minutes after order placement and they pretended like they had it ready.15 minutes later and my request was greeted with anger so I walked out. Wish I could give zero stars have never experienced this level of weak. Never going back
author: Richard B.

description: I've never had Burmese food before even though I am an Asian. It's a great, cheap way of enjoying Asian food. The sauce is just right and the way how the scallions and the meat are cooked and mixed is just perfect.
author: Michelle C.

description:
HELLO!!!?? THIS IS YAMMOOO!! ..WHAT DO YOU WANT!!?? 
CHICKEN O BEEF?? TO GO OR FOR HERE???? 
YOU!! HOW MANY!!?? 
HERE!!! 
GIVE ME A COKE! NOT THE CAN.. THE BAHH.DOHH!!
HELLLLOOO!!! YAMO!??

+10-12 bar seats
+15-20 min wait on a Thursday night at 845pm
+4 ladies hustling and bustling, working the phone, working the lines, working the stove, working 5 pans, go girls go!!! They WILL SCREAM INYOFACE..BEWARE..They are NOT AFRAID!!! Watch out!! It's MON-GOH CHICKEN!!! ......no its MAN-GO CHICKEN!! 
+$4.25 appetizers
+$6 salads, soups, entrees
+++3 proven things I've tried: the hot house noodles, the cold house noodles, and the chicken noodle soup- MUST GET CHICKEN NOODLE SOUP!!!
- 0 peace and quiet
- 00 room to move and groove as you eat elbow to elbow with other diners, try to avoid knocking someone over with your purse, rubbing against someone's puff jacket or knocking your head on a bike helmet hanging on the wall. Check, check, and check!! I've done all three! =/
-Tender waft of greasyliciousness drifting onto the street 
= 1 super cozy little hole in the wall

4 S*A*U*C*Y STARS FOR YAMOOOO!!!
author: Angela W.

description:
The term "hole in the wall" was created for this place. 9 seats along a small bar with about 4 feet between the counter and the wall. $6 entrees and $4.75 appies. For the price, the taste and portions were awesome. I'll def be back!

Disclaimer - your entire being will smell like grease after but that's part of the ambience
author: Cynthia H.

description: Delicious, inexpensive, the beef house noodle is #1 and just a small broke down shop in the Mission. The food is amazing, don't expect a Benihanas experience. In case you are wondering, the old ladies are yapping in cantonese and its quite hilarious what they talk about
author: D L.

description:
The food was mediocre, and i was highly disappointed. I loved the tea leaf salad, but if I were to come again, i would order to go for the salad only. the fish noodle chowder wasn't bad. The mango chicken was a disappointment. I'm not sure what their special sauce is but I couldn't taste much. Also the specie house noodles with chicken was whatever. The noodles were very broken. All the food are heavily cooked in oil. 

I loved the ladies though. They can be seen as rude, but I thought they were funny. 

Would not wait in line for it, but would definitely order to go for the tea leaf salad.
author: Ha L.

description:
In what other city than San Francisco could you sit at an old 50's style diner counter while eating Burmese food and being yelled at by old ladies?

Best of San Francisco, hands down.
author: P Z.

description:
Wow - what a place! One of my favorites in Mission. Funny staff and amazing food. The house noodles with beef/chicken is so good, I can't bring myself to try anything else!

It does get smoky so if you're worried about smelling like food, be sure to get it to go!
author: David L.

description:
Quite aptly a four-star restaurant.

Food: great. It's really really oily but in terms of the taste, it's great. I did not like the spring roll-- it tasted bland and the peanut sauce was actually a little gross. But the noodle and rice dishes were quite good.

The wait and the seating was terrible though. The ladies cooking and serving are hilarious, but they are short-staffed. It's funny because a blind lady just stuffs cash (oh yes, it's cash-only!) behind the plates and cups.

But anyway, if you have the time and are craving tasty (but oily) Chinese-Burmese food, go for it.
author: Min Ju L.

description: I went here over the weekend to grab some take out food. I thought the flavors and ingredients used were pretty good, I liked that the chicken dish I ordered had mango in it and a little kick of spiciness.  I ended up ordering the Mango Chicken, House Noodles and spring rolls. The total came out to under $18 for those three items which is pretty cheap for being in SF. I liked it a lot, I would definitely go back there again!
author: Gabriela S.

description:
4 stars and 1000+ reviews--I was expecting better!  What deceiving yelp coverage.  Let me preface this by saying I love 'hole-in-the-wall' places that are really good and inexpensive.  But when it's a hole-in-the-wall place that is just bad and cheap = not so good.  Don't wear nice clothes or clothes that you want to re-wear because they will stink.  The ingredients they use are really poor quality (I saw the bag of frozen shrimp).  It is incredibly dirty behind the counter where they are cooking and preparing your food.  They use a ton of oil and not enough salt or spices.  

Sorry for the negative review, I just have to be honest and help others who were naive like me.  And yes it is cheap, but this time there is good reason.
author: J L.

description:
We came here because we love Burmese food, but apart from the tea leaf salad (which i will give a 4 star for), everything else was just below-par at most 2-star greasy Chinese/Cantonese street food. 

We got the tea leaf salad, house noodle, curry fish and mango chicken for two. Portions were great for the price. However the curry fish and house noodle both tasted like they added at least 1/2 cup vegetable oil to each dish. The mango chicken is less greasy but I did not manage to taste mango apart from the few canned mango pieces (which honestly did not taste like mango neither) floating around.

What really triggered me to give it a 1 star is the hygiene of the restaurant. OMG the lady shredding onions next to me had no gloves, wore a super dirty apron, sneezed all the time, wiped her nose with her bare hand, and continued to cut onions with the same hand... I later realized that there was raw onions in the tea leaf salad and that was not easy to get over it.

The ventilation of the whole place is also extremely poor. My coat smelt like grease after I sat inside for 30 mins.

Bottom line: will not come back again.
author: Christine C.

description:
This place is dirt cheap, and I was excited but then you get what you pay for.  

I'm Burmese myself and at any Burmese restaurant the tea leaf salad and cold noodle is essential to any Burmese establishment.  So why not order it ? You can't mess this up right ? 

well apparently you can!!! 

The house noodles were bland, the cold noodle was the same as the house noodle but with chili sauce onions garlic and cilantro, the tea leaf salad barely had any tea leaves in it, and just didn't taste right at all!

Best Burmese food hands down is Burma superstar or Burma cafe, and after Burma superstar had that case of ecoli, Burma cafe is definitely the place to go!
author: Jorlyn W.

description:
Stumbled upon this little hole in the wall after taking the 10 am Anchor Steam Brewery tour and after the 2-3 free beers we drank food was our number one priority. I don't know how many of you readers will be in the same tourist-y boat as I was that day but if you are finishing up at Anchor Steam and headed towards checking out the murals nearby or Yamo is a great stop to make in between those two destinations.

And that's about all I have to add that's new info. I was sold on this place because who doesn't want to try Burmese food and you put tea and salad together in any kind of cuisine and I'm there. So, to reiterate what others have said, the tea leaf salad did not disappoint! As I'm writing this review I'm reminded I gotta start experimenting with adding tea leaves to salad...

Only reason that fifth star is missing is cause it seemed like we kinda got stiffed part of our salads (photos looked was plumper) and the mango chicken dish was pretty unmemorable. 

Also, I don't know how it happened but despite there only being 8 seats at the counter (and pretty much all were full the entire time) magically no one had to wait. We approached right as two people were leaving. We left and two others happened to show up right then and there. If your experience isn't as lucky, it'd be worth waiting outside the front door (which is welcomingly left open) for someone to leave.
author: Megan F.

description: A hole in the wall for sure. The food was pretty good, although the noodles were a bit disappointing because they were too soft in texture- could have more of a chew. The beef noodle was good and the price of the dishes are cheap, but they don't make you full. I was disappointed because the place didn't offer any water nor was any to be seen and the host lady taking the order and phone calls was extremely rude. A customer was about to take a photo and she screamed, "NO PHOTOS! DON'T SAY SORRY!" while facing in front of us. A moment of silent awkwardness followed. I would probably never dine here again unless it was carry out. Beware!
author: Ting Ting C.

description:
Arrogant b***% with no regard for customer service. Have been to this place multiple time everything giving the owner the benefit of doubt around her mean attitude and alarming lack of courtesy towards her customers. She will yell and treat you like a peasant. She manages to stun me every time. Go if you're 
 looking for a wallop of insults with a serving of discourteous plate stuffed with bad attitude. Never again...
Someone needs to tell this Mata Hari that is not the way to treat customers. Even ignoring her FOB approach, her attitude is inexplicable. Even the goats in my village treat sewage better. And I exaggerate you not. Try this place and ask yourself if you would tolerate this service from Denny's or even the Mexican hole in the wall. Totally flabbergasted that she is still in business.... 
What a f-edup place with a lady who given you a mind fxxx, I need a stiff one after this runin. Mama Mia ....
author: Bobby T.

description:
Holy hole-in-the-wall batman!!! 

It's not often that I immediately fall in in love with a restaurant but this was love at first sight/bite.

LOVE LOVE LOVE!
-  The cute lady with short curly hair manning the saute station is so bad ass and pumps out dishes like nobody's business.  (just ignore the fobbiness/rudeness)
-  The teeny tiny bar area where you sit allows you to watch all the action.
-  $6/dish?!  What a steal!
-  Tea salad:  Simply AMAZING!  So perfectly balanced, vibrant, and flavorful.  I still have dreams about this salad.
-  House noodles with PORK:  So simply, yet satisfying with perfectly cooked tender morsels of pork and oh so garlicky.

I cannot wait to come back and try every damn thing on the menu.  The only advantage Burma Superstar has is more seating but for taste, Yamo really is the star!
author: Allison T.

description:
Ah, Yamo... I was hoping for more. I ordered take out, and waited ~10 minutes for my food (6pm on a Thurs), lucky me! When I placed my order, the waitress seemed angry at me, but no points docked here. I'll attribute that to the authentic Burmese vibe :)

House Noodles with Chicken Curry:  Not as chewy as I expected. Curry was decent, nothing out of the ordinary. I felt it was actually a little too heavy. Tiny portion. Perhaps you are better off with the beef or chicken.

The Mushroom Tofu with Broccoli: I expected silken white tofu, but instead it was deep fried. The sauce was a thick brown sauce that reminded me of Chinese food. I guess all their entrees come with rice, and like the previous dish the portion was small.

The spring rolls were pretty typical, I would probably get them again.

I was really hoping it was better than Burma Superstar, but Yamo is a good Burmese option for the Mission. I may return but definitely not wait in any line.
author: Jess C.

description:
I would be surprised to find a better value anywhere else in the city. $6 a plate is an incredible deal, and everything I've tried so far has been delicious.

The Yamo house noodles are DIVINE, and the catfish chowder is great comfort food on a cold day. The tea leaf salad is another staple and a must-try.

Keep in mind that this is a hole-in-the-wall with bar-seating only, so it does get very crowded and can be hard to get a seat during peak hours. Also, the fact that it's very humid inside and the food is spicy, so you might not want to come on a hot day.
author: David W.

description:
A Burmese Food Haiku:

House noodles, get them.
Coconuts, so refreshing.
The air, filled with smoke.

PS: Is it just me, or is Burmese food just a dumbed-down version of Chinese/Thai/Viet food???
author: Calvin W.

description: Very dark and not to clean don't waste your time for those of you who said this food is good I guess it comes down to what you're use to eating. Place just wasn't clean enough for me should have went with my first mind and left but I didn't but that's ok if you like a clean restaurant this would not be the place to patronize however if greasy and nasty is your thing then try Yamo
author: Rochelle A.

description: MINUSCULE portions. I ordered the tea leaf salad and when it was presented, I thought it was an appetizer. Honestly, I ate it in 4 bites.  I will say it was delicious and spicy.  However for $6.25, you want more than 4 bites.  The service/attitude is not exactly warm and friendly. Sure enough, I got the head nod mentioned in other reviews, rather than a verbal interaction to take order. No thanks when I paid.  Cash only which is a pain.  Very overpriced for tiny portions. Won't be back.
author: Osama B.

description: Charging for tap water makes me feel ill will. Is that even legal? The food is delicious and well priced. Yamo doesn't need my good review to fill seats.
author: Josh B.

description:
The line is sort of haphazard and the staff makes no real attempt to organize it so you're very much on your own at yamo but the food is pretty solid. I would pass on the samosas but definitely get the tea leaf salad which to date is my favorite.

I wasn't that in to the house cold noodle but my friends fish chowder (nothing particularly chowdery about it btw) was pretty great.
author: Misha T.

description:
I'm usually not a "hole in the wall" fan, but this place is not JUST a little, minimal eatery - it has an amazing atmosphere of travels, adventures and Asian chaos, which reminded me of Thailand. Just about 10 seats around the "bar", looking straight at the kitchen, where three loud ladies put up a very good cooking+yelling show. So it's 5 stars for the FUN factor.

The food is good, but I think it tasted even better because of the great price - garlic noodles with crispy, perfect beef for 6$? Sure! The house rice, with tiny shrimp, also delicious, and so is the tea leaf salad a friend passed over to me because it was too spicy. His loss! The only thing I would pass on are the potstickers - I've had better, but don't let this minor detail bother you. Go, stand in line, enjoy!
author: Flora T.

description: I really wanted to like this place more.  Very cheap but also small portions.  Easy to order at the counter but don't expect any degree of service.  Pretty tasty but even greasier.  The amount of oil is probably what is most authentically Burmese about it, unfortunately.
author: Matt H.

description: If you're a local you know that this place is the place to go if you're craving good food. The place is small with around 7 seats, it also however provides take out so if you're not in the mood to wait just order to go. The little old lady's that work there are not the most friendliest ppl in the world but they get work done so I don't mind. The prices also went up but not for much so it's still a cheap meal. I went with my girlfriend and we spent $17 on three dishes so it's not bad at all. Keep in mind that it does get very busy and it might take you some time to get a seat so I recommend to go early in the day.
author: Antonio C.

description: Along with the bahn mi across the street, this is my favorite Asian food in the Mission. I love the fish chowder, and the noodle dishes are delicious too.
author: ramesh g.

description:
I have only had their house noodles so this is relatively limited. They're delicious and fill the craving of garlic-y noodles. 


 I love this place because it is no fuss. I always get mine to go because, as others have said, it is incredibly smokey and cramped on the inside. Yes, the women are less than friendly, verging on hostile; However, I don't see cloth napkins and white table clothes so I won't hold it against them. 

Can't wait to try the rest of their menu!

CASH ONLY
author: Mimi D.

description:
The world is better for having Yamo in it. It is a near perfect place.

I love the old ladies. They are hardcore characters, cooking delicious, affordable, greasy Chinese food to perfection. 

I love how they bark at customers, and watching some people get exasperated in response (see other yelp reviews).

Try the curry beef, the mango chicken, the egg rolls, and the potstickers. You could get an order of each for twenty bucks total. Amazing.

Enjoy this Mission gem.
author: Jimmy H.

description: For the price point the garlic noodles with beef is an AMAZING deal. It's my fiancé go to when we need a quick fix. Expect a line even when you call for pick up because the space doesn't occupy a lot of people and it's always super pack. It's worth the wait though!
author: mimay M.

description:
As authentic as you can get, I imagine. This place makes me feel like I'm in a third world country, super shabby interior, everything feels (and looks) dirty, service is crazy rushed and rude, yet the food was amazing. 

Actually, two things in particular were amazing. The tea leaf salad was life changing. It was delightful, soo fresh, with the perfect crunch in every bite. The catfish moringa was also soooo good, I can't wait to go back and eat it again. 

The samosas were only ok, and the house noodles (or whatever) was just okay. Nothing special, I probably won't be back for them. 

Solid food. rude service, this place gets straight to the point. They kinda have to, with Only like 6 seats, as soon as you're done they hand u the bill and ask u to leave...
author: Lisa N.

description:
4 Stars for very yummy, true blue Asian homecooking for dirt cheap price. This is what we had for $28: 
1. Tea leaf salad!! I have been to a few Burmese restaurants here in the Bay Area & I can safely say this one beats them all! I thought Burmese Kitchen in Larkin St got the crown but Yamo beats it hands-down! 

2. Fish Chowder Noodle: every sip brings me back to SE Asia!! Home sweet home!! I almost forgot to share it to my date :) A perfect blend of saltiness & spiciness. 

3. Spring Rolls : very fresh & I love watching one of the ladies make it from scratch in front of us:) 

4. Yamo house noodles: yummy!!!!!!!! It's like yakisoba but Burmese style! The chicken is so good! 

5.Mango Chicken: we both agreed that while the house noodles is yummy, this one is Yummier!! 

I find it ridiculous that ppl write poor reviews based on "ambiance"... Oh come on bitches! You expect five-star service for $6???? Now that is down-right stupid & self entitlement! 

If you are looking for very good Burmese-Chinese food with real SE Asian experience (ie old mamas yelling the orders, whipping up one meal after another, tiny crowded place), then Yoma is the go-to place.  

This is officially my new fave place here in Mission!
author: ASIANDIVAH A.

description:
Literally a hole in the wall.  I drove pass this place so many times and always saw long lines out the door.  That's when you know its got to be good.

I've been here twice and have tried their tea leaf salad, catfish chowder, and the house noodle with beef.  Everything I had was worth every penny (About $6 per dish).  The only thing I didn't expect was that the catfish chowder came with vermicelli in it.  

However, the seating area is not comfortable at all.  They only have a counter that sits about 10 people where they cook right in front of you.  This means your clothes are going to smell.  If you like the full experience, good for you.  But I personally prefer take out to avoid long lines, the wait, and having to do more laundry.
author: Lynn L.

description:
Yamo seats around 10 people, and some veteran customers told us how they had failed to snag seats the past 5 times they had been there.  Unless you arrive with a full tank of persistence, plan to call ahead and order for takeout.  

We all ordered the house noodles with beef (cilantro-phobes beware!).  The slightly-saucy noodles were snappy, and housed scattered slices of seasoned, well-done beef that were buried under an aromatic mix of fried garlic, green onions, and cilantro - in other words, wonderful!

Although there was some to be desired in terms of the size of the dish, I was surprisingly full upon finishing.

I will be back to try other menu items!
author: Andrew M.

description:
Once you see this place, you'll see that it's a true hole in the wall. There's exactly 8 bar stools for seating. I would not suggest coming with more than 2ppl in your party. Seating is tough as you can imagine. You're basically sitting at the chef's counter in the kitchen. The whole restaurant is one room. 

Expect that Asian service! But with that service comes authentic Asian food, cooked in a wok, in a room where the windows are caked in grease. Yum.

Don't shower before you come here because you'll just end up smelling like food and grease afterwards and have to shower again! 

The tea salad was exceptional, spicy and flavorful. It's definitely too salty to eat by itself but leaves your mouth wanting more. I would probably eat this with rice next time. The portion was teeny tiny! Maybe they were factoring in the takeout box? Think of this as an expensive Asian coleslaw.
author: Theresa D.

description: I love this place! I try to visit whenever I'm in the Bay Area. I love the semi-angry ladies. They make me feel like I'm at home jk :) Prices have slightly gone up since I first came here in 2010. My favorites are the tea leaf salad and cold noodles.
author: Alison L.

description:
I love hole-in-the-wall places, street food, zero or negative ambiance restaurants, etc.  This place is all of those, but frankly the food is just not that great.  I would go back and try it again if it weren't for the ridiculous line.  I believe there were four people standing in front of me in line; it took me 30 minutes to put my order in and another 15-20 to get my food.  That's just too much.  

Give it a shot I guess, but go with a friend so you don't get bored to death.
author: Tom C.

description:
Yamo will always hold a special place in my heart as my First Meal in San Francisco - the potstickers and the black bean tofu entree, which I ordered to go and then ravenously ate in Dolores Park.

Terrible ventilation inside the restaurant (granted, my visit was during a "heat wave" of 82 degrees) and there is just counter space, but the food was tasty and the price was right.
author: Rachel H.

description:
This place is dirty and super small. The only seating is a counter with about 10 stools. And three loud, gruff Chinese women cook all the food and operate the place.

 But...I LOVE IT!

I came here a few weeks ago with 3 other friends and we squeezed into the remaining 4 seats at the counter. Food was good,cheap, and greasy!! Between the 4 of us we got 2 orders of samosas, a tea leaf salad, mango chicken, house noodles w/chicken, chicken curry w/noodles, and curry fish w/noodles. 

And all of this was only about $35! My first thought was "WTF?! Am I still in SF?!" It's almost impossible to find prices like this in this city...and they don't skimp on their portions either!!

As for the food, the samosas and tea leaf salad were on the spicy side, but very tasty. And the chicken curry and house noodles were rolling in grease, but so delicious nonetheless. I didn't try the mango chicken or the curry fish, but my friends seemed to enjoy them! 

Sure this place is ghetto and hole-in-wall, but that's why there's take out. Plus, I really didn't mind the ghetto surroundings when food was so good and at such devilishly low prices! When we left, with our tummies full of good food, there was a line forming outside...and it was raining too. That can only be an indicator of good things. 

Yah, I want some Mo'!  4 Stars!
author: Natasha H.

description: This place used to be great. Now it just feels like a drag to go, get yelled at by the mean ladies, and get rushed out the door, all for ok-food. The tea leaf salad is good but pretty salty, but I'd still get it. The fish chowder was way too fishy and didn't have enough seasoning to balance the fishy smell. The cold noodles were way to sour because they put too much sauce. The inconvenience and poor service were all charming when the food was on point -- now that the food isn't great, I got no reason to tolerate them.
author: Michelle K.

description:
God bless these Burmese ladies putting up with us and each other, just doing what they know best. 

Home style cooking (basic noodle and rice dishes) in an 'intimate' setting that feels like a neighborhood joint in Asia. And don't forget the tasty salads!
author: Kai H.

description:
Yamo by far was one of my favorite dining experiences that I have ever had.

I came here on a recommendation from a friend. My partner and I were lucky as we came after the lunch rush. This place is small and I loved it. It's more of a hallway and there is only bar seating where 3-4 women work harder than I've ever worked in my life. When I read reviews from people saying the service was rude, I just sort of chalked it up tot he fact that they've probably never worked a service/serving job. My order was put in correctly, she was fast, and was just pleasant enough. I think in this particular setting I would have been put off if she was sugary sweet. 

This isn't a restaurant; it's a dining experience. 

My partner and I shared a few dishes. Most of what we ate were recommendations from Yelp and we weren't set astray. It was all pretty excellent (and quite different than anything I've had before).

We tried the curry fish which was really a gut bomb (in the best way possible). It was pretty oily but in a good way an exactly what I was craving at that moment. Everything was seasoned nicely and it tasted great. The tea leaf salad was also excellent and very different than anything I've tasted before. I'm sort of trying to reach for adjectives other than "good" but am coming up blank, so I'm sorry. Just get it :)

My prescription for after you eat Yamo? a solid 45 min to an hour nap.

Oh and the prices were great. We got four large dishes and our check was something like $22. Yes.
author: Jordan B.

description: This place is delicious. I really appreciate what these ladies do. I enjoy going eating here
author: Carlos T.

description:
Had the house noodles with beef and they were amazing! Will be back.

Went at 1pm on a weekday and found easy seating. Plenty of people dropping in for to-go/call ahead orders. Didn't mind the service, got everything quickly with no problem. Besides, it's 2 ladies staffing a hole in the wall with orders flying out the door. For you shy/indirect people out there, think of it as a way of rounding out your communication skills.
author: Lisa G.

description:
I love tiny hole in the wall places and this place definitely fits that description. It fits about 10 people at most and you sit at the bar facing the cooks. The cooks are busting their booties like madmen and its pretty entertaining to watch them push out the orders of food. 

Their noodles are amazing, the rice dishes not so much. My friend ordered the cold noodles and it was delicious. I had the mango chicken and I thought it lacked flavor. It was just salty and oily. 

I don't expect much in terms of service from these places, but the asian ladies working there were pretty nice (and very efficient might I add). I definitely would come back here again, but will stick to the noodle dishes, and maybe the salads since everyone else seems to be raving about those.
author: Caroline C.

description:
Super tasty, super cheap, super sinful OR super healthy, you choose.

Totally worth the wait (in my opinion). Ain't fancy so don't go wearing your fancy clothes-n-shoes. Rough it. Wait it out. Enjoy the counter and the sweet ladies as they do their thang and cook you a lovely authentic meal. Yes, you'll have to ask for water 20 times, but who cares? Just wait and wash it down with coconut juice:  a *must-do* to end this fantastic experience.

Yay, Yamo!
author: Meredith R.

description:
Yamo, a little hole in the wall that is definitely worth a try. It has good food and the prices are really cheap. 
Sometimes there's a wait, but that's just a good indicator of good food.

I've had Curry Beef, Yamo House Noodles, and Mango Chicken and they're all absolutely delicious. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. Something you should definitely get is the tealeaf salad. It's a definite must try. The first time I had it, it tasted a lot better than the ones I got in the later visits for some reason :\

I can't wait to go back and try the rest of the menu.
author: Harriet W.

description:
A friend asked that I pick up the phone order made to Yamo. Warning me a bit of what to expect, my interest was piqued, in an uncomfortable way. 

I learned that no one can help you understand what an 'alternate reality' is like, it must be experienced to understand.

Yamo - The Place

For many it would not be a comfortable place to be. A place that does not consider the delicate "feelings" and "sensibility" a middle class upbringing cultivated. A place that is so uninviting to dine in, I was amazed that all the 10 seats were filled and there were maybe 8 people in outside on the sidewalk.  A place that doesn't care if you are dining there, and doesn't care if you ever return. A place that didn't give 1 second of thought to the comfort of anyone eating there. 

Yamo - getting the food

Seeing the line, and not wanting to cut in, I asked one of the diligent and hungry diners if they were waiting to pick up food or sit down. All sitters. Went to the front of the line and squeezed into Yamo. Got the attention of the woman who seemed in charge.

Saying I was picking up a phoned in order, she thought I was placing an order and she grabbed a small tablet of paper. I said it again and motioned like I was talking on a phone. She got it. The Yamo phone rings, she grabs it and starts speaking, loudly, and scribbling on the small pad.  She looks back at me and says something resembling "what did you order", I knew this was the key to getting the goods, since my friend said that they didn't ask or give time for a name when the order was called in. I read from my own scribbled list of 7 dishes. Half way through she determined it was the recipient of the stack of 'to go' containers in front of her. And starts adding it up. I had a brief thought of what if it isn't what was ordered. Quickly concluded, that what ever was in those sturdy looking containers was going with me. 

Yamo - The Food

Fish curry, House noodles w/ beef, mango fish, samosa (like) appetizer etc. was all good. 

Yamo - The Diners

Standing in front of the cash register which is just behind a women who is in front of 3 large woks sizzling on high heat, and 3 other pans also on high heat. The heat was almost unbearable. Like being in Las Vegas in mid August with a down jacket on. The alternate reality took over. The 10 or so folks at the counter were seemingly enjoying themselves. One person scooping out the innards of  a coconut that had a hole hacked in the top, clearly enjoying the fruits of their labor. Another couple trying to figure out their new smart phone, which they acknowledged was smarter than them. The noise, the heat, the cramped quarters, the shouting woman, no sensible person would be comfortable and unaffected by the environs. Yet, they went on eating and cavorting as if everything was as it should be, as they expected and as they have accepted. Thats it. The 'alternate reality' thing that I kinda think Burning Man brought to the 60,000 folks that "experienced" it this year.
author: Matsuo U.

description: There are maybe only 12 seats in the whole place. The GF and I beat the dinner rush and made it in and found out seats immediately. We decided to go with the house noodles and the mango chicken with an order of samusas. The food is flavorful, very affordable, and came out reasonably fast (I mean they make it a few feet away and right in front of you). The samusas came out after our main dishes and they were piping hot but just delicious when they had a second to cool down.
