When we left, there was a fat line waiting outside to get in and eat/order to go.
author: Jerry Y.

description:
Don't be frightened, but this is a hole-in-the-wall establishment. I had a hard time finding it since there was black tarp over where the signage should be which, of course made me think they weren't open fo some bizness! I highly recommend not eating inside because it has like a handful of seats and plus the kitchen is right in front, thus your cheap makeup would slide right on off! Ordered the tea leaf salad (no brainer), mango chicken, and the beef house noodles. They were all yummy. I don't remember the tea leaf salad being so tangy (compared with Burma Superstar), but it was still tangrrific if you're into some tang ;)

Asian lady cook is on biatch patrol, so if you want her to be nice... stroke her hardworking ego! Other than that, make a run to the ATM and get some singles for now and perhaps later.
author: Diana W.

description:
The best SE Asian food in SF, period. The taste is perfect, and the price is cheap. The restaurant itself is beyond ghetto, but the old Asian ladies run a tight ship and I've never gotten sick here.

The only negative is the usual Mission dickhead hipster clientele. Don't let them cut in line or steal your seats, because they will.

Eating in can be quite crowded and hectic, but the portions are larger than those made to go.
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
How the F does this place have four stars??????????? 

This was barely passable as human food. I had the chicken curry over egg noodles, which was horribly greasy, salty, and didn't taste like curry. My girlfriend had the fish chowder which was just strange -- it had the consistency of snot and lacked flavor.

I can't believe people line up for this shit. I can't believe people put up with bullshit service. F this place and the hipsters that swoon over it. I wouldn't eat here again if someone paid me to.
author: Rich L.

description:
Ate here tonight. My thoughts: 

Are people really lining up for this food? Really? Ah, El Mission.

Okay, I get it. $6 is cheap these days. "Broke" people who can't cook need to eat somewhere!

The food: very ordinary. Battered fish tossed with black bean sauce and awkwardly shaped veggies. "House Noodles" tossed with soy sauce, scallions and grease (plus crispy fried garlic, which was tasty). Also got the pot stickers. Not horrible, but nothing memorable by a long shot. The kind of food you could most likely throw together at 1:30 a.m. after a bong rip and a 12 pack of Miller High Life.

Perhaps sitting at a stool in a grease-stained hole-in-the-wall while the brusque waitress burns a hole through your epidermis with her glare is a touch charming but let's be honest: there's a boat load of dive-y spots around the city with far more inspired dishes for the same price. Location, location, location...
author: Anthony R.

description:
Food: 4
Decor: 2
Service: 3

Came here with some friends to grab take-out for a weekday dinner.

1. Tea leaf salad, 6
~Pretty good. 

2. Mango chicken with rice, 6
~Pretty good. Somewhat generic, but decent overall. Sauce had a bit of a kick to it.

We were quoted a 10 min wait, but it ended up being closer to 15 min. The place was packed when we arrived due to the limited seating, and 4-5 more people arrived for take-out shortly after we did.
author: David L.

description: If you're not looking for this place, you will never find it. It's a charming little hole in the wall, complete with swinging overhead lights as if a subway car was right above you, although it's quiet. Seating is a small bar that faces an open kitchen, where they cook everything fresh. The people that work there are courteous and sweet. I got the garlic house noodles. They were fabulous. Husband got the black bean tofu, which was very good but I like what I got more. We also got the fresh spring rolls with peanut sauce. Yum. Nothing was too filling. Perfect for lunch. And the prices were LOW. Would definitely go back.
author: Kat R.

description: Cheap and delicious. It is a small family owned business and can get hot in there, but at least you get to see the food being cooked on the spot!
author: Daniel L.

description: Long ass wait and the people who works here are rude! The food was greasy and didn't taste good! Not coming back to this place!
author: Mido E.

description:
Just moved here and this is my favorite place in sf. 

I usually get the cold noodles and spring rolls tho the fish chowder, tea leaf salad and beef yamo noodles are great too.  I haven't tried anything bad. 

The cold noodles are spicy! I love the contrast of hot chicken and cold veggies/ noodles. It's also nice to have different textures.

Be prepared for abrasive Burmese ladies who want to keep things  moving... They don't really like to make eye contact but they are listening and will get u your food when it's ready.. :) 

Awesome little hole in the wall that draws interesting people who are equally obsessed as I am!
author: hannah l.

description:
I have never written any review, but felt compelled this one time.
Never tried their food. Never got there because THE SERVICE AND ATTITUDE SUCKS.
I called in an order. The lady got it wrong. When I went to pick up the order, she refuse to change the order to the right items, and said too bad. No apologies. No compromise. When I protested, she yelled back at me. I've had bad experiences before, but this was one of the worst.
If you want to be treated with some semblance of respect, do not go here. You won't find any.
author: Tony D.

description: Cheap, oily, and fast - just how I like it. This hole-in-the-wall joint is heavenly. It's quite hidden along the lines of dirty, rundown storefronts so make an effort to look for this place...you won't be disappointed. Seating is very limited as it's just a bar-like area where you face the three ladies who cook up your meal to-order. You have to try the house garlic noodles. The noodles are very flavorful and the meat is well-seasoned and tender. I've heard very good things about the tea leaf salad, but haven't tried it. You try it and let me know!
author: Kevin H.

description: This restaurant made me feel like I've walked into a noodle stand at a night market in Asia. There are only about 8-10 booth seats in a very tiny, hole-in-a-wall space. We waited for about 15 minutes to get in. There are 3 chefs (2 of them in the late 50s-60s age) cooking on woks with grease on the walls and very minimum ventilation. I have never tried Burmese cuisine before but I'm hooked! I loved the tea leaf salad and the house noodles with beef. The flavoring and texture was both dishes were just spot on. We also ordered the fish noodle soup, cold noodles, and samosas, but none was as impressive as the first two dishes. We ended ordering another house noodles because it was just so good. Prices were very reasonable, but the whole dining ambiance environment was a bit rough- sticky table top and sriracha bottles , no place to put your purse, tiny water cups, and questionable cleanliness of dishware. I personally like eating at funky places like this because it reminds me of home (Taiwan) but I could see how others may not enjoy it as much. Stepping out of the restaurant after dining was like stepping out into the real world again...oh right, I am in SF...in the the United States.
author: Nina H.

description: Some of the most delicious noodles I've ever had. Don't go there for the customer service, I would highly advice that you get your order to go. Not only does that keep your wait time shorter, but you can also eat outdoors at the nearby park. I had the house noodles this weekend and they served as the best lunch with my friend. Did I mention that their prices are by far unheard of in the city. $6.25 for a complete bowl...SOLD. cash only....
author: Karen A.

description:
It did not taste like Burmese, more like Chinese. Chinese with a lot of   "ground fresh chili paste". We had tea salad, cold noodles and mango chicken. Tea salad was ok but no match to tea leaf salad from Burma superstar, sorry YAMO.  Waitress handled money and food without washing hands in between, I am not a big fun of it. 

tip: all dishes were really HOT, so if you are not big fun of HOT food, ask to make it mild.

Personally, I would rather go to good Chinese or to good Burmese instead of Burmese / Chinese YAMO. 

Dining setting reminded me street food of Bangkok, not a bad thing but not for all.
author: Dasha T.

description: Delicious food. Inexpensive and great for take out. The place is small and is cash only so be prepared, and take it to go.
author: Chiara M.

description:
Smokey, cramped, rude customer service - but awesome. 

You don't come here for the community atmosphere, you come because the food is cheap, authentic and it's a hole-in-the-wall that makes the Mission awesome.
author: Catherine M.

description:
The food is great, but the service is awful, BUT awful in the most entertaining way.

Let's start with the food. House noodles with beef - delicious and cheap. Tea leaf salad - delicious and cheap. There isn't anything on the menu that costs double digits so it's a great place for a cheap date. (Note: if you're date brings you here, he/she is a cheapo but you won't notice because the food is good).

The service...hilariously bad. This place is run by a bunch of small cranky asian women who have very thick accents and often-times sassy attitudes. My favorite past time when eating here is watching newbies try to order food from them and seeing the reactions of the customers. They will ignore you initially and can be fairly rude if you catch them at a bad time. 

Just remember that they're all business - they just care about your order and that you pay. One time I remember I had to yell my order because she asked what I wanted when she was on the other side of the restaurant. Tip: if you want to pay, just put your money down on the counter and wait for your change. Sometimes they like to ignore you if they're busy, but they won't ignore money on the counter so they usually get to it right away.

Watch out: Cash Only. There's one of those sketchy ATMs on the corner if needed.

Watch out #2: There's maybe around 10 seats in the whole place, so be ready to get it to go if you show up during high demand times.

5 stars!!!!!!!
author: Brian M.

description: Nice tasting food but the lady at counter today was rude. The first time we were there, about a week ago, she wasn't in and other staffs were nice but tonight she messed up my order. I ordered chicken noodle soup without cilantro, she realised she forgot and started picking out stuffs from the bowl and ended up removing onion instead of cilantro. I didn't want to bother her so I picked out the cilantro myself and asked for some onion, that's when she got mad and started cursing in Chinese or Burmese, I could tell because of her facial expressions and hand gestures, and if it had not been anything rude she would have just said it in English. Anyway, I'm not saying I would never go back because the food was nice and cheap, but I would always check if she was in before walking in next time (chubby with short curly hair, very small curls). Oh, and one more thing, the area isn't safe, tonight there was a homeless person walking in asking for food and ended up having a fight with some guy in the shop, that same counter lady had to call the police. My boyfriend, who was with me tonight, said he had been troubled by a homeless person once in the same place another time. So, keep that in mind and be extra careful when you're in the area.
author: Veronica P.

description: Awesome small Burmese restaurant. Super authentic food. Good pricing, super fast service. The food is prepared in front of your eyes and you can see how fresh everything is. Tea salad tastes awesome. Rest of the food we ordered was very good too. The restaurant was run by 3 chinese/Burmese ladies. Very authentic.
author: Andi B.

description:
I've come to Yamo twice. Both times, I did not wait in line because I came at slightly odd hours. There's only ~10 seats and no waiting area, so if you are not in immediately, you'd be standing outside.

Would it be worth waiting 30min-1hr to eat here? For me, NO, because I can make most of the dishes they make within a shorter amount of time.

But is it worth coming if there is at most 15 min wait? YES because it's cheap (~$7 meal), fast, and delicious. A little greasy, yes. Pretty much no service, yes, but because the ladies working here are really really busy.

Recommended: tea leaf salad (it's not as gourmet as Burma Superstar's, but cheaper); mushroom stir fry; yamo house noodles (does not have veggies tho).
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Hole in the wall with old asian ladies screaming in the background. It literally has maybe 10 seats on along a counter and the kitchen is tiny. Can get packed super fast but it doesn't take too long to order take out.

Ordered the curry fish over noodles and house noodle with chicken, which is BOMB. Not great service but they remind you of Asian moms so it's homey and provides great entertainment. Dishes are about 6 bucks per plate so it's definitely wallet friendly.

Awesome food, good portions and great price!
author: Jeffrey S.

description: This place is my favorite asiatic spot in the city. I tend to gravitate towards the chow mein dishes, but their soups are awesome too. Be mindful of the fact theres like 8 seats, so be prepared to wait
author: Nathan T.

description:
This is gonna be my favorite Chinese restaurant now. Loved the food. 
This is more like family run business and I can imagine what it means to stand there for  8 hours and keep cooking delicious dishes, so kinda natural for those human beings to be cold, but no complaints really.
author: viren s.

description:
Best meal in San Francisco under $10.

As long as you don't mind smelling like fried noodles when you are done...
author: Erica D.

description:
Small restaurant, almost unnoticeable. Thankfully you can spot it with the crowd outside.

Decided to try this place for lunch and avoid the long dinner wait.

Ordered the house noodles w/ pork to go. 
(Uncomfortably hot inside)

Took about 15 mins to be ready - food was generic. But hey, for 6$ a plate what can you expect?
author: Thomas R.

description: The wait was long and quite honestly the food was not good. I ordered the beef curry oily, slimy, and way too spicy. I tasted my friends dishes and they were... Blah... I mean it is cheap and the food was still edible. You can watch them cook the food too... Bad idea for me since they weren't very sanitary or clean with they way they handled the food.
author: Kelley L.

description:
A tiny hole in the wall with minimal bar seating.  I was really eager to try the food based off the stellar yelp reviews and planned to do take-out and bring it back to the house.  

However, upon stepping into this stuffy, greasy restaurant, you are approached by a  women who seems the least bit excited to take your order. But whatever right? I'm really here for the food.  So I got the tea leaf salad and the beef house noodles.  

First impressions; not pleased.  There was barely any food and the small container for the salad wasn't even half filled.  I could probably fit the amount of salad in the palm of my hand.  Now I will add that I enjoyed the taste of the two dishes because the flavors were there.  But most importantly, did it tickle my toes? No it did not.
author: Marissa K.

description:
4 1/2 stars for the food, 1 1/2 stars for the aural punishment. The chef/head lady carries on non-stop conversation at steamwhistle intensity with the women at the inside end of the place. If you don't mind having a ballpeen hammer slammed against your eardrum while munching tea leaf salad, sit anywhere. Otherwise, wait for seats to open up on the far right side of the counter. Your hearing and sanity depend on it.

You're welcome.
author: Douglas G.

description:
We were very impressed with this little hole in the wall (literally).  We use to live in Cole Valley so found ourselves going to Mandalay, which is good, but I think this place is better.  

We had the spring rolls which were made there right in front of us, then the mango yummy salad, and curry chicken which was extremely flavor and not greasy at all.  The women there are hard at work and all business, so don't expect to be treated like royalty, however you can tell they take pride in their cooking so I will support that any day.  

Can't wait to go back.
author: Jackie L.

description:
How to be cooler than the line of hip hipsters...

1. Call your order in 15 min ahead.
2. Stop by Duc Loc supermarket and pick up beer.
3. Stroll across 18th and politely excuse yourself past the line waiting for food/seats.
4. Pick up and pay.
5. Casually saunter out of the door with your goodies.

It's pretty simple.

Cheap, no nonsense service, bare decor.
From the items I've tried...

Not to miss:
-samosas
-mango salad
-house chow fun w/beef
-house fried rice

Get next time:
-tea leaf salad
-house noodles w/chicken

Save your $6:
-black bean tofu
author: J L.

description: Kindna a tight spot, serves is slow but understandable. I love the food. I don't mind to coming back here again. oxox
author: Leeto B.

description:
This is the type of place you come to after sex, with someone you've dated for a while.  If you are trying to impress someone by coming here first, you will not have sex.  If you just had sex, and trying to keep impressing them, that won't happen.  You need a companion that loves you for you to appreciate coming to this place with you.

But if you just want a dive quick and dirty Burmese meal, this is pretty good. Not the best, and something seems to be missing, and the staff doesn't care about you, but it's so interesting it's worth it.  You will wait for the 8 or so bar seats, and it's cheap as balls.

My fave is Burmese kitchen in the loin for the tamarind fish and noodle soup.  Burma superstar is a great go to for out of town visitors and it is my most visited.  The Burmese place in Burlingame is good too.  This place takes the edge off, and is my dirty little secret.
author: A A.

description:
There is a closet fire in the mission district is what I thought when passing by this place, yet no is moving away from it. Confused much? Yes!

This is the smallest restaurant that I have ever been in and what it lacks in size it makes up in quality. There are zero tables and you eat at the counter approximately two feet away from the hot action. It was full when we got there and my friends and I scoured the mission district for something that would hit the so called spot.

I stood at the door and shouted over two eating patrons, it was somewhat rude but i could neither move any closer nor could she without running to a hot wok! so we made it wok (cheezy i know) I ordered the samosas along with the house special fried rice with skirmps  and my friends ordered the yamo noodles, one chicken and one beef.

It took a good 10-15 mins for everything to finish as everything is made to order, we kicked it outside and you see random after random people walk by as they think a building fire is taking place, i would say half of them ended up going in a grabbing something to eat. 

The samosas were light crispy and spicy but not overpowering, the fried rice gave me a watermelon smile! that damn good! every grain of rice was individually covered in spices, after every bite i wanted more.

The women in the kitchen were nice, I have no complaints nor do i expect good service in any any asian restaurant because emphasis is not on service but food so people who complain about these women should go to... rhymes with smell.  

One thing i have to mention is we found a place on the street to eat our meal and a couple literally stopped in their tracks and asked us where the food came from because of how good the smell was.

The food was so perfect and makes me a sad panda that I can't eat here whenever i so please.
author: David N.

description:
So if you eat at Yamo you know that the service is lacking. You go for the delicious cheap food. I have been eating here for years now dispite the terrible service but my experience last night was probably the worst I've had there. I order what I usually get, the cold noodle salad with chicken and a tea leaf salad as an appitizer . I saw my order come up and sit on the bar while the lady who takes orders and is generally the most unpleasant, took a walk-in togo order. By the time my food was delivered the chicken was cold. Two bites in and I had to spit out a piece of chicken because it was so rubbery I thought it was raw. I brought this to her attention, only to be told that it was the knuckle part of the chicken and that I should eat it. Not only that I got my appitizer halfway through my main course and water halfway through my meal....It's safe to say that I am more than willing to put up with bad service for good food, But if I am getting sub-par food and terrible service I think it's time to find somewhere else for a cheap fix. Sorry Yamo I won't be back after being treated like SH#$%

I forgot to mention that part of their over stove hood had water pouring down it....I'm pretty sure that must be against some health standard somewhere...just saying.
author: Lauren Y.

description:
This place caught my eye whenever I waited for the bus. It's a dinky place, but usually with a line out the door. My cousin and I finally went to it when were starving after dance class. FYI, it's a cash-only place, but there's several banks on Mission. 

I had the curry chicken while my cousin had the house noodles. The curry wasn't as what I expected. It was more oily and had a nice kick. The noodles were good, but the overall dish could be less greasy. My cousin's house noodles were greasy too and bit on the salty side. 

It's not a bad place, flavor is really good, just less salty/greasy taste please.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Good and cheap hole in the wall asian food
Sometimes the wait can be a bit long, also sitting inside can feel a bit crowded, they only seat about 6 people at a time and your practically in the kitchen.
Get the mango chicken and/or chicken noodle soup!
author: Kevin K.

description:
Tea Leaf Salad + House Noodles with Beef + Chicken Curry Noodle Soup + Samosas = HEAVEN 

I make it a priority to come here at minimum once a month--It is well worth the 35 minute drive!  

The women are my favorite - - they cook their hearts out everyday BUT Sunday...Make note.  Also Cash only.  

Yamo, I love you and your 11 bar stools.
author: Jay T.

description:
Oh Yamo... You haven't ceased to amaze me. Few places ACTUALLY qualify as hole-in-a-wall, and I'll admit I throw that term around lightly on occasion, and you're one of them. You're the kind of hole-in-a-hole place that people brag about, so keep up the good work! 

Now to the people reading this. You're a fool to wait in line and eat inside of the hole called Yamo. I mean, you're basically waiting for the opportunity to stand up in a kitchen! Expert move: call ahead, pick up 15-20 minutes later (bring CASH or risk embarrassment of being yelled at and an ATM fee), and take it to a quiet street or Dolores Park. Just don't wait in line to eat in. 

Now, about the food. It's hot, wet, and greasy. Garlic plays in heavily to many of the dishes (note: I like garlic a lot). There's a good mix of crunch and soft chewy with the House Noodles (I recommend. Get it with pork if possible). The potstickers are good. The tea leaf salad is straight funky... But then again I don't particular like that dish at other Burmese places so don't take my opinion too seriously there. The curries will disappoint, I think. The mango chicken is good though. 

Be careful with the women serving. It's a hot kitchen and they have little patience for anything other than cooking and taking your money. and whatever you do (and who would ever do this?!) don't suggest that they can increase their prices by, like, 30% and still have a line out of the door every night. Because it's only of the few cheap, good spots left in this city! 

Enjoy.
author: DJ D.

description: This is a must go place in SF. I was skeptical initially but when I tasted the food. It was awesome. The way the three people make food and serve, it's quite an entertainment. Chicken noodle soup and house special fried rice that they make with shrimps were awesome!!!
author: Dinesh C.

description:
Was super excited to try this place since it had such good reviews.  

Pros: 
beef in the house noodles were good
cold noodles were decent
Prices are pretty low

Cons: 
Servers have a boo-boo 'tude and yells at customers
the place is small and smokey 
The actual noodles in the house noodles are HELLA bland.

The pros of this place arent any more special than the run of the mill decent asian place. Skip the smoke, the wait,  and the boo boo attitude of the mean mugging cashier.
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Ya know....I have been here only once.  It's an OK place but there is no way I will give this place a 4 star.

customer service....none.
space....none.
food...OK
price...Excellent

I mean, there is absolutely no customer service.  It's basically just like eating the street food in Asia.  Sit down, eat, pay and get the F out.  I was very nice, smiley and asked them how their day was....Yes OK, they don't speak English very well, but really, not even a fake smile.  I'd almost give this place 2 stars.
author: Jorge T.

description:
Cash only
small bar that seats about 10 
long lines
3 ladies: one takes orders, one cooks and serves, one hacks the tops off of coconuts WITH A MACHETE, sticks a straw in them, and gives them to you to drink.
author: Lily K.

description:
Don't expect service with a smile--or really much of any service beyond the lady yelling at you to order from behind the counter (it's loud and chaotic). It is what is...and when you come to Yamo's it's pretty much what you should expect. 

The lines are long, but they move rather quickly. The menus are taped to the windows, so you can decide what you want while you wait. In lieu of tables there are bar stools at the counter, so you can cozy up to the random people who pile in. The rule is, once a stool becomes available, you plop yourself down and order. You're essentially eating in the kitchen (yes, it's that small). On the plus side, you get to see the wonderful food cooked right up in front of you. On the downside, it can get smoky inside and your clothes will have that funky Asian food smell afterward. 

The food? Delicious! Everything is cooked to order--very flavorful. My friend and I split an order of samusas (appetizer) and a mango chicken entree and garlic noodles with beef. It was GOOD! I'll be back to try some of the curry dishes. The prices are super reasonable too--okay, actually more than reasonable for San Francisco. Entrees are priced at $6, and appetizers are under $5. Hit the ATM first--it's CASH ONLY (but no tax).
author: Lisa N.

description:
ATTN: Yamo Restaurant
The Mission
San Francisco, CA

To whom it may concern:

Thank you for the excellent and entertaining lunch I had at Yamo recently. I haven't had service that helpful and entertaining in quite some time!

Getting quick, cheap, and tasty food in San Francisco isn't easy these days. With the salad and two entrees I ordered, I easily had three meals' worth of food for under $20. I found the tea leaf salad particularly delectable, but both of my entrees were flavorful and intriguing choices. Sometimes I feel like I've tried everything there is to eat, but you helped my senses jolt with excitement!

In addition to the delicious food, I loved the free sauna treatment I received by choosing to dine at your cute little bar. Normally you have to pay a lot of money for that! After finishing my meal, my wet jeans ensured me I'd kept my diet intact through sweating out my Burmese delicacies through every pore in my body.

Yamo Restaurant, I look forward to returning and eating again! But next time, I'll be getting take-out.
author: Denise B.

description:
I get that oil is the vehicle for taste at these kinds of places, but Yamo douses everything. I caught myself tapping each forkful of noodles so that I could pretend the drippage would make it any less fatty. I got the cold noodles thinking that'd be refreshing on a warm day. Nope, warm noodles mixed with a ton of garlic flakes and chicken. While tasty, it was on the smaller side for what $6 will get ya in that part o' the Mission.

Tea salad was disappointing here. Where were the flecks of tea and why was it super tiny to the extent that it looked like cheapo leftovers from Burma Superstar?
author: Kevin L.

description: I would recommend ordering take out and eat it elsewhere since there's about less than 10 booth seats. Their curry chicken is kind of bland but the potato was a starchy smooth potato...Yum! I really recommend black bean sauce fish and house noodles with chicken! it technically hit the spot for a person who was raised on eating rice! I would give 3.5 stars.
author: Paulina D.

description:
Not sure what the hype is about here either, apparently, I was told that I had it all wrong, and the 4 stars comes with the experience of sitting inside this little hole-in-the-wall and dining at the enclosed space watching the mom & pop cook. Unfortunately, I took the food to-go, and I am writing this review solely on the taste of the food. 

Ordered: Tea Salad and the House Beef Noodle.

Tea Salad: WOW! DID SOMEONE SPILL SALT? Because this "salad" was WAY SALTY. I know I tend to eat on the blander side, but man, this dish needs to be toned down dramatically. The ingredient was nicely paired though, as there are lettuce with nuts, giving it a mixture of soft and crunchy, creating an interesting combination. Only if it was 50% less salty, this would have been a great item.

House Beef Noodle: This tasted like a better version of beef chow mien, but still pretty similar. A bit on the oily side, but I am sure that's how Burmese food is supposed to be. The flavor was great though, and you definitely get a generous amount of beef. Was it amazing though? I say no. 

If I happen to pass by the area again and was desperate for a quick bite, I would give Yamo another shot, and actually sit there to dine for the "whole experience", but this isn't something I would fly from LA to SF for.
author: Luby H.

description:
I could have dealt with the mean noodle lady, but, when you try to make fried rice with fresh hot steamed rice you should call it Porridge. 
Awful.
author: Dan C.

description:
I love this place! And not just because every time I'm sitting at that counter chowing down I feel kinda smug and special, since it means there's someone else waiting, who can't eat yet.
Yes to the house noodles, chicken or beef depending on my craving. And the potstickers are excellent. Some of the most flavorful I've ever had. I blame the ginger.
Totally worth the inevitable greasy kitchen smell that lingers on your attire.
author: Genevieve S.

description:
Cheap, greasy, and delicious. Need I say more? These three older women sure know how to run this hole-in-the-wall efficiently and successfully. Just off of Mission on 18th Street, you'll notice a line of hipstered out peeps standing outside of a random store. That, is, in fact, Yamo. The place is literally like eight bar table seats where you pretty much are eating your meal and watching the three women cooking and shouting to each other (in what I think is Cantonese!) as the orders come in. The food comes out real fast and your meal is so tasty, you'll probably down in less than 20 minutes.

House noodles (noodles with fried garlic) and beef, tea salad, and samosas were all so good! The beef on top of the noodles was so tender and flavorful - I think if you add just a bit of the chili sauce on top of your house noodles and mix it all around, it'll make this dish even more fantastic. If you aren't down for greasy foods though, either don't bother to come here or just avoid these noodles. But you should seriously try them... The portion size of the tea salad is actually pretty small, but it's definitely worth trying! The samosas were also pretty good, the potatoes that they put in them is somehow mixed with some sort of spice or other vegetable that makes them surprisingly sweet and tasty. The pot stickers were also pretty good - they did a good job of preventing the pot stickers to be full of juices (like what happens at some other places).

Overall, great food and a great experience. If you love trying something different and I guess actually typical of SF hole-in-the-wall businesses, give this place a try. It's good stuff!
author: Cheston W.

description: Best tea leaf salad with the best sassyness around. You cant go wrong with anything on the menu.
author: Julia H.

description:
Best $6 meal I've had in a while - fish in black bean sauce - at the tiniest restaurant I've ever had the pleasure to sit in. 

You will smell like cooking oil. 

The service is fast and mesmerizing (I can't believe there were four! cooks in the kitchen and no one got hurt and nothing got knocked over). There are a lot of dishes to choose from although you might feel rushed by the crowd of people waiting at the door to sit down. A dozen people came in for take-out while we sat there and the entire 15? seat counter was packed the whole time.
author: Phoebe R.

description:
Oh Yamo - I dream about your tea leaf salad and black bean fish. 

In our fair city of overpriced Asian food (OSHA?!?) you are a true gem. 

Out the door, sated and sooo happy for 12.00. 

I must admit, I get a bit scared when those ladies wield the meat clever, but one firm swing and you have an open fresh young coconut in your hand. Bliss.
author: C J.

description:
This place was fun! Went for lunch with a friend. Total hole in the wall off of 18th but a nice big sign out front.

Only about 8-10 seats at the bar so do not come with a group. Fun to sit and watch your good be made.

(+)
- The tea leaf salad was amazing. So much flavor!
- Cold noodle salad was apparently good but packed with crushed chili flakes
- I had the wide rice noodles with chicken. Very lite and had good amount of veg with it. Needed a little chili oomph to help it out but was generally good

(-)
- Was not particularly enraptured with the very curt ladies behind the counter who gave no time to think before ordering and were all together incredibly no-nonsense to he point of being terrifying. Luckily you can't really lose with anything you order there.
author: Jenn M.

description:
Ugh. TERRIBLE.

My friends and I showed up and placed our orders at 7:20. Waited outside. 30 minutes in, still no sign of our order,so my friend went to the counter to say we're still waiting. No explanation, they keep working it. 50 MINUTES LATER, we finally received our food. No apologies, no explanations. People who had ordered a half hour after us had been served first. We were so hungry, we opened up the order at a bus stop... only to find 3 of our 5 dishes had no sauce of any kind. My curry chicken had no curry. Tasted like steamed chicken and noodles with a couple spices thrown in. 

Ridiculous wait, awful service, food that tastes like butthole. yamo more like yeah, no.
author: Argonaut A.

description:
2.5.

After 4 years away from SF, it seems the trend of overrating new hole-in-the-walls has not yet subsided. Yamo is maybe 2 steps above a good Chinese takeout place. It is not stellar dining but a quick order and go type of place. 

The tea leaf salad was very interesting, slightly bitter, and unlike anything I tried before. But the black bean fish was nothing to write home about at all. It was tasty but greasy and unoriginal. I've had much better and fresher fare at Szechuan places. The other entrees don't appear to be any more original or novel. 

The prices are pretty cheap with nearly everything being $6. And they don't include tax. Cash only.

Highly, highly recommend ordering takeout. Honestly, I have no idea why Yamo even has seating. It is too small and it would be hard to enjoy your meal with the heat and smoke from the stove tops blowing into your face (and your hair, and your pores, and your clothes, etc. etc). 

Take a look at the menus posted outside and know what you want to order right away and then order. For the love of God, don't block the entryway staring at the menu for too long if you don't know what you want and don't try to ask the ladies questions about the orders. It is not that kind of restaurant. Once you've ordered and paid, stand by the doorway out on the street so that the ladies behind the counter can see you. They'll motion to you once your food is ready. Carry and go.
author: Nene K.

description:
Wow. What a piece of crap restaurant.

Full disclosure: I wouldn't throw myself on the hip-Burmese-food bandwagon, but my opinion on Burmese food is irrelevant, because this wasn't it. This is bad, cheap, oily, and totally flavorless, run-of-the-mill chain Chinese food (cooked by two Chinese people). Then they throw a mediocre tea salad on the menu and call it Burmese.

I got "curry" fish -- fish fried in way too much oil (and I love me some oil) with a slight pinch of curry powder, a heap of undercooked green bell peppers and onion wedges and a huge mound of overcooked rice -- and the "tea" salad, which was slightly better but over-sweet in what tasted pretty much like Italian dressing and, frankly, not all that cheap for a small plate of dry-friend vegetables.

I get it. The service sucks, so it's got to be authentic. (I asked for a suggestion and was glared at in silence before I was handed a peeling menu sticky with other people's food). The wait is long, so it's got to be worth it. (I snuck in before 12, so I only had to wait 10 minutes for my waste of a meal. Yippee.)

Most of all it's cheap (thus, star #2) -- if you calculate on the basis of poundage alone; not sure how it could be considered even OK value when compared to food with flavor. 

But come on, guys. Really? Four stars? Semi-cult following? Stupidly long lines?

This place is honestly terrible.
author: Sasha K.

description:
This place used to be great. But now food is cooked in too much oil. Beef curry had maybe 5 pieces of beef mixed in with darkened potatoes that looked like beef. Disappointing. 

Mango chicken isn't what it used to be. They're inconsistent with he amount of spice. 

I won't go back until I hear it's gotten better.
author: Raymond R.

description:
Heard good things and took a bite of my friends dish a couple weeks ago. It was awesome, although very greasy. I went in today. I called ahead and ordered the mango salad and the yamo house noodles with chicken. They are definitely down to business in there. I would challenge anyone to get a smile out of these ladies! It's also hot and humid in there, I feel like I just walked into a restaurant in Burma. Instantly I saw how they operated and thought, all dirty, poorly run places have great food so I'll give it a chance. 

I asked for no onion on the noodles but what I got was just noodles and chicken... No biggie, it was still flavorful and I mixed my mango salad in with it. There should have been cilantro or something on my noodles but maybe they were just playing it safe and left my dish plain. I enjoyed the dishes but there was barely any mango in my salad and my noodles were pretty plain. I was slightly disappointed. 

What really left a bad taste in my mouth was how horrible my stomach felt a few hours after. I saw the way they stacked the bowls of noodles, they shuffled the to-go bowls around and then stacked them on top of each other, so the bottom of one bowl that was God-knows-where was now directly touching the noodles below it... And don't get me started with the FILTHY menus! They are so sticky you could press them against the wall and they would stick. Also, she took my money and started cooking without washing her hands. Lastly, I saw her pour the oil that she used to cook her chicken in a container on the ground. Is she re-using it? Is that for disposal? Who knows what made me sick but I feel terrible and I really wanted to give this place a chance... I really don't care about cleanliness because I enjoy authenticity but when it makes me sick it's a whole different story. I will give them one more chance and update my review accordingly.
author: Audra H.

description:
Mango salad. Get it or feel your life isn't complete. 

Go with the flow at this place. You should sit down, but if its full when you get there, you only have to wait like 10-15 for a seat to open up.
author: Allison H.

description:
"Fuh heer o to go?"
"Wut u waan?"
"Sicteen dalluh."

The lady taking orders is so sassy! I love it. I went here with two friends for a snack after wandering around Mission. I ordered the Yamo house noodles with beef, Friend 1 ordered pot stickers and Friend 2 ordered black bean fish with rice. The service and food came quick cos they want y'all outta there! 

This place is pretty neat, hole in a wall kind but nothing too amazing. If you want quick, decent, cheap n' small meal, then give it a shot.

I do have two complaints though. Home girl chef uses hella oil. Now there's left over oil and then there's the you tilt your container and you see about 1/4 cup of oil kinda oil. Yikes. Also, the container of spicy sauce or something totally melted my friend's box of pot stickers. Double Yikes.
author: KD M.

description: Cold noodle, cold noodle, cold noodle and repeat. Hands down my favorite dish and must have if you're a first timer here. I have tried other dishes here but I always come back to my first dish, the cold noodle. It contains cold noodles, chicken and spices. Simple as it sounds the flavors on this dish are meant for each other while complimenting one another. Must have!
author: Javier P.

description:
I don't typically do fantastic hole-in-the-walls like Yamo because, even though the food is slimygreasyspicygood and dirt cheap, I can't take massive crowds plus bad service without having an anxiety attack. 

However, I can do phone orders with takeout windows! The service is still crappy because they don't take your name over the phone, meaning you have to recite your order precisely as you did on the phone if you want your food... and they will still ignore you when you get there, and your food will still take a bit of time. But, whatever. At least you get to eat house noodles, curry, coconut soup, and whatever other dishes you didn't order but they accidentally put in your bag and didn't charge you for.

Again, I emotionally can't deal with this kind of chaos, which is why my boyfriend picks up the takeout. He has... actually, SIGNIFICANTLY less patience than me, and yet, he's a much better provider.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Three Old Asian ladies,
Three Old Asian ladies,
See how they cook,
See how they cook,

They all ran & shout after
each other
She is rude bossy taking order
for every one
Have you ever seen
Such a manner in your life
As three Asian ladies

Three Old Asian ladies,
Three Old Asian ladies,
See how they cook,
See how they cook,

They all ran & shout after
each other
She cook most food so fast
With 3 hot burning pans
Did you ever see
Such a fast cooking in your life
As three Asian ladies

Three Old Asian ladies,
Three Old Asian ladies,
See how they cook,
See how they cook,

They all ran & shout after
each other
She whack off a fresh coconut
With a carving knife
Did you ever see
Such a great whack in your life
As three Asian ladies

---------------------

In case, if you don't know anything about the place, Yamo is small, only counter seats about ...... 11? yeah, I think 11 or 12 seats. And 3 old Asian women were working their ass-off like Non-Stop, because people are keep coming one after another.
The food is very flavorful Burmese dish, and really inexpensive.
I have to say,
GREAT REAL ASIAN FUSION.
YAMO HOUSE NOODLES w/ Beef, 6 bucks
Curry over egg noodle, 6 bucks
Pot sticker 8 for $4.50

This is the real super star of Burmese, THE BEST "HOLE IN A WALL" IN THE CITY!!!
author: Nobu K.

description:
interesting hole in the wall, fun experience, but i wouldn't go back. the food just isn't that good and its far to greasy. 

also, don't go there expecting to be catered to. they basically let a mob form at the front door, without explaining anything to anyone, and as the other reviews say, they just don't treat you well.
author: K R.

description: Inexpensive, amazing, hole-in-wall Burmese place in the Mission. Mango chicken, tea leaf salad, house noodles with pork/beef/chicken, it's all yumz. This place maybe fits up to 8 people and all counter seats. Cash only, bring more than you think you need!
author: Yumi H.

description:
I've never been here physically, but I have had this place for takeout multiple times. My friends are addicted to the curry potato samosas.  Every time they go, they bring back at least 20+ back.  If you love ginger, order the pot stickers.  You can taste the shredded ginger/meat in every bite. 

My favorite has to be the house noodles and also the fresh hand made shrimp spring rolls. They also serve fresh coconut juice, right out of the coconut!! I can only find those at Vietnamese restaurants in San Jose! 

I haven't been inside, but I can def imagine a person who sits in and eat will most def smell like grease afterwards.  You are eating inside a greasy kitchen! Take out FTW! 

My next try will be the tealeaf salad!
author: Chanel L.

description:
Small, smoky, stools-only... It was love at first sight. I wish I lived in the Mission--I could have bacon donuts for breakfast, super burritos for lunch, and this incredible Burmese stuff for dinner. I would eventually grow out of everything I presently own, but what's a few inches and several pounds? TOTALLY. WORTH. THEM.

My friend and I shared the spring rolls ($3.60), the tea leaf salad ($5.25), the black bean fish with wide rice noodles ($5.25), and the Yamo cold noodles with chicken ($5.25).  We had a satisfying meal of four dishes for a just over $21! Insane for SF!

The rolls were made fresh and super refreshing--good because you're in a bathroom-sized restaurant with a hot kitchen before you. The tea leaf salad was small but scrumptious--I just love the textural contrast of the many ingredients. The fish was lightly fried and really tasty, but the rice noodles were a bit bland. The cold noodles were chewy and flavorful, but the chicken was rather dry. Next time I'll have to try the curry fish with rice and the Yamo house noodles with beef. And get a tea leaf salad just for my gluttonous myself. This is going to be a fat summer, but at least it will be a cheap and spicy one. Everything was mildly spicy except the rolls.

I wasn't crazy about Burmese food after Burma Superstar, after Mandalay, after Burmese Kitchen, but I am definitely a fan after Yamo. The food is so homey and delicious, the Asian ladies are so hard-working and sweet--I can't help but just adore this hole-in-the-wall. 

Although I ate here last night, in anticipation of eating here a lot, I will begin accepting dinner dates here for the rest of the summer starting right now. Don't all flood my inbox at once.
author: Liz T.

description: Food was mediocre and service was horrible. My friend and I felt like we were in a seinfeld episode of the soup nazi. Haha. There's better places to eat at, so pass this one up. It's cheap if you're on a budget.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
4 stars for food. Great House noodle and Tea Salad!
2 stars for service. HORRIBLE and RUDE. Seriously you yelled at customers?
author: Winson W.

description: The house noodles with chicken was soooo good! I went there for lunch with a friend and the place is tiny, with the only space being the seats along the bench where they make the food. It's cheap food for a great size bowl for lunch, and the garlic flavor is just too good! I will definitely go back for those house noodles - but don't take a big group! There's only about 5 seats and you can do take-out but it might take a while for them to make the food.
author: Vhia D.

description:
What do you do when you want affordable Asian food in the Mission District and Mission Chinese is CLOSED ON A WEDNESDAY? As I found out go for Yamo (it must mean in "yummy" in Burmese)!

Samusas + shrimp spring rolls + tea salad + beef curry over noodles = can't lose!

My only worry is that they'll get too popular for their own good and jack up the very reasonable prices for current menu items. Oh well, I'll enjoy the heck out of this literal hole in the wall as long as I can!

Useful info:

- CASH ONLY
- line out the door so call in your order
- limited seating in a tiny space means you will walk out of there smelling like the food
- this part of the Mission looks a bit shady at night so go with a friend
author: Lorraine Y.

description:
The ladies are grouchy to a point where it tickles me -- apparently the hipsters all like it too as they line up for this place. If you don't want to deal with the attitude, lines, hipstery crowd, and smoke, order  takeout. Food is mouthwatering, but loaded with MSG. Prices are cheap like any good asian food should be.

House Noodles are simply amazing.
Mango Salad is refreshing and bright, as are the spring rolls.
Everything else I've had is good too, but nothing in particular is registering at the moment.
author: Soysizzle t.

description:
if i walk by and one of the seven barstools is open, i go in.
papya salad is nice and spicy.
love the vegetarian noodles.
greasy and flavorful.

to the other reviewers: its not ghetto, its not hipster, its a hole in the wall chinese place, and it. is awesome.
author: Jenny C.

description:
I gotta downgrade Yamo to 3 stars. The portion is becoming smaller and I think some of the dishes are kinda bland. Me, being a chili queen, almost finish 1/3rd of the chili oil they had.

At some point I asked where the drinks are and this girl (with very bad English) just said "oh yes" mumble mumble mumble and went back chopping stuff up. We were not very happy at that point. Although, they seem to always mess the drink order, it's very strange.

Yummy, oily good stuff, but need more seasoning + better service.
author: Novalina N.

description: If your looking for an authentic ethnic experience, definitely check this place out. Well worth the wait and be sure to try the tea salad.
author: Shannon G.

description:
lunch

food: fish chowder noodle. this doesnt taste fishy at all. as in i wouldnt have known it was a fish chowder if you didnt tell me, which can be a good thing for some. it was thick and creamy. the noodles and the toppings add some texture to it or else it feels like eating mush. they have some crunchy stuff on top that i couldnt figure out what it was, but i liked it. either fried lentils or corn or something. ***4/5

service: its a pair of asian ladies working the joint. one primarily cooks and the other handles the customers and prep. they do a splendid job with the number of customers they have. she took my order fast, but it took awhile for orders to come out. like i said, only one person cooking the food. ***4/5

atmosphere: this is a hole in the wall. i walked past it and didnt realize it. the front isnt fancy and reminds me of street food stands in asia. the place is extremely small and narrow. fits maybe 8 people? i got lucky and got in before the crowd hits. they do to go orders too and a line of people were waiting outside. TIP: dont go in big groups. 4 is big in my opinion. ***3/5

value: 6 bucks for a bowl of noodles and it fills you up. if there is no line, totally go for it. but if there is a long line out front, ill pass. ***4/5
author: Andy Z.

description:
sorry Yamo.  I had a mediocre tea leaf salad a few years ago and gave up on you. I hoped things had improved and tried the house noodles today.  Terrible. 

Oily noodles with ok pork and almost non-existent flavor. It gets worse. 
The predominant flavor is either grease or fuel or greasy fuel.  Even with some fish sauce and chili sauce, the fuel flavor was heavy. If it's not fuel, than it's some god awful cooking oil. I hate to give anyone a one star review, but all of these 5 stars are from kids who wouldn't know good food if it kicked them in the face.  I can make ramen and pork in 5 minutes (for $1 dolla!) that would be exquisite compared to what I just experienced.
author: Jim J.

description:
4.5 stars, I'm very close to giving this a 5.  

Another great place for good eats for the young, fabulous, and broke.  It really is like walking into your Asian momma's kitchen.  There are about 12 stools at the bar, and the entire time you're eating, you're facing three Asian women cooking up a storm.  How they manage to cook that much good food, so quickly, in such a small space impresses me to no end.  They do it WELL.

Every entree on the menu is $5.25, and all appetizers are $3.50.  Affordable, and good portion sizes!  On a weekday around 6:00pm, we came and ordered the samosas, the tea leaf salad, the mango chicken, and the coconut chicken noodle soup.  All for only $19.25 total.  Great value!

Of all the dishes, I liked the tea leaf salad the best.  Great textures, especially with the crisps and crunches, a bit of a spice kick, and very fresh.  Excellently made = highly enjoyable.  The coconut noodle soup was creamy, slightly spicy too, and highly recommended.  I had a small bite of my friend's mango chicken with rice dish, and I thought that was fine, but it didn't stand out to me.  Also, they give you a good amount of samosas for the price - 6 hot, hearty pieces for $3.50!  

A coupla final notes and conclusions:
+ Not so crowded when we arrived at 6pm on a Wednesday night, but I noticed that a small line started forming around 6:30pm, so get there early if you want to avoid a line.
+ Cash only
+ If you're going to get ONE dish, gotta make that the tea leaf salad.
author: Vivian C.

description:
This place was legit, straight up ghetto interior. A tiny hole surrounded by good bars, hustlers, bike thieves, some OGs and hoodlums, and yet I felt at home, safe and cozy. It's big enough for 6-7 people tops, unless you're a midget don't bring your whole squad there and make a scene. Its fucking inconsiderate to wait on that many all at once, go there 1-3  at a time, you and the other human beings will be rewarded by the universe.

The food was good, if you don't like it for being too oily, just tell them to add less oil! If they yell at you, enjoy it! Welcome to the real world you bunch of spoiled, sugar coated brats! 

I loved it. Had the house noodle with beef, was delicious. I covered mine up with real home made chilly sauce, none of that sriracha tomato paste. Don't get me wrong, there isn't anything wrong with sriracha, but it DOES NOT go with EVERYTHING, and it aint hot, so don't call it a hot sauce. When you have the choice of a superior chill sauce in front of your ignorant face, dip that shit in, if u don't add the chill, you'are missing the point! 

Ordered the tea salad. Theres no tea in it. But was delicious though. Full of onion and vinegar, seems would go well with rice porridge too, it's got that Chinese pickle vibe to it, Chinese pickle is better than Kimchi Da Truth!
author: Alvin D.

description:
Been here a number of times. 

If you eat-in:
- come during off-hours - there are only 8 seats at a bench.
- wear clothing you don't mind getting smelly. It's HOT and the smoke sticks to you. 

If you order: 
- call in 10 minutes ahead
- bring cash
- cut the line and get your food

Everything is $6 or less. 

Highlights:
- chicken noodle soup
- beef curry
- tea leaf salad
- cold noodles
- fresh rolls

everything else is good but you can afford to skip it.
author: Arjun N.

description:
I'll take this over Burma Superstar anytime.

This is a fantastic hole-in-the-wall Burmese spot in the Mission. Literally, it's a hole in the wall. Cramped because the eating space is pretty much just the counter area, while they cook on the other side. Always a long line to get in around dinnertime.

But it's worth it. Even if you're separated from your friend once you get seating. Screw them. The food is good; you pretty much can't go wrong with any dish.
author: Thuan N.

description:
Definitely order to-go here. Their house noodles are on point and prices are cheap!

If you do have the unfortunate displeasure of dining here, be prepared to be rushed out the door. Seriously, nothing would make them happier than for you to eat it and quit it. Sit as far away from the stove as possible to avoid getting splattered with cooking oil. If you get chewed the eff out by the ladies behind the counter, your Yamo experience is complete.
author: Zeal B.

description:
Burmese seems to be the "it" thing for now, and I'm on the bandwagon.

This quality/taste of the food definitely isn't equivalent to burma superstar or mingalaba (in Burlingame) but for the price you pay.. it gives it a HUGE boost up there! YAY! :)

For $19 we were able to do takeout and walk away with: tealeaf salad, chicken curry with rice, beef chow mein, and an order of potstickers - wowzas.. we are... IN SF RIGHT???

Love love love that you can get Burmese for the price of ...... meh, I don't know .. something that no longer exists in the city where your standard price for a soy latte is $4?

I am happy to have finally gotten around to trying this place - definitely on the list of takeout places when we're looking for cheap and ... greasy.
author: Melody T.

description:
Ok, it's definitely worth the awesome ratings... 

(Upon reading other Yelper's reviews- thanks!) We had:
-Tea leaf salad.
-House noodles with chicken.
-Curry potato samosas.
-Fresh veggie spring rolls.

Super yummy. I definitely prefer take-out to eat in, though...the line-to-seating ratio doesn't work when you're the type to get hangry when it's meal-time.
author: Jodie B.

description: This place is still probably one of my favorite places to eat in the bay. Super authentic with incredible food that's not too pricey.....since its a hole-in-the-wall type place you'll usually have to wait a few minutes for a seat, like 10 or 15, sometimes 20, but totally worth it. Also the employees are hilarious and super awesome people
author: James D.

description:
Feeling overly confident about yourself today?  Come to this place and the stinkface lady behind the counter will gladly remind you that YOU AIN'T SHIT.  I think half the appeal of coming to Yamo is witnessing the lady's scowl in real life.  She makes the Soup Nazi look like the Gerber Baby.  For some extra entertainment, I dare the fuck out of you to ask her for gluten free or no peanuts in your tea leaf salad.  

The fact that this place can maintain its popularity and high rating despite stinkface says something about the restaurant. 1. Hipsters love hole-in-the-wall restaurants with lines outside. 2. They have plenty of sweet-savory dishes to cater to American tastes. 3. It's cool to rave about this place bc it means you survived the mean lady and are open-minded and cultured. 

The food itself is pretty good, but nothing life-changing.  There are better places in the city.
author: Per C.

description: Do not let the long line or small, cramped, hot restaurant discourage you! This food is awesome. My recommendation is the house noodles with beef but the mango chicken is bomb too. You will wait in line and have to sit on small stools that are jammed close together but I'd say it's worth it. If you want to try to food but skip the restaurant experience they do take out as well.
author: Amanda C.

description: I used to get takeout from here all the time.  Prices are cheap (~7 a meal), food is greasy (in a delicious way) albeit with slightly smaller portions, and service is no-nonsense.  I highly recommend calling in your order, and arriving 15 minutes later than the time estimate they give.  Note: be succinct.  The ladies over there won't hesitate to slam the receiver on you once they've decided that they have enough information to go off of.
author: Larmon L.

description:
Yamo is one of my absolute favorites in the city. I don't know how I haven't reviewed it already.  This is superstar Burmese food.

Other reviewers have mentioned how small the counter is. So fucking what? The food is so good.
Other reviewers have mentioned the wait. So fucking what? The food is so good. 
Other reviewers have mentioned surly service from women old and young. So fucking what? The food is so good. 
Other reviewers have mentioned the yelling, the hot oppressive steam, and the dirty counters. So fucking what? The food is so good.

Quit your whining. Order up pan fried dumplings as an appetizer and black bean fish with rice as a main. I bet the dumplings don't come till you finish the fish. So fucking what? The food is so good. Quit your whining.
author: Ivan L.

description: It's a pretty small place. You eat at the counter and watch your meals being made. Since you're right up next to the cooks there's lots of smoke and heat blowing in your face, but I think it kind of adds to the atmosphere of the place. The service was quick and to the point. Don't expect any overly chatty servers. The food was delicious, but not unlike other Chinese/Burmese spots. Ordered the Tea leaf salad, Chicken soup, House noodles and spring rolls. I would suggest ordering take out because the place is so tiny.
author: Rose D.

description:
I walked in with a friend and instantly knew that the food was going to be the bomb dot com. How, you ask? First these ladies are rocking that grey hair that lets you know cooking, and making good food is nothing new and don't you dare ask if the food is good, because it is totes amaze!

One thing you got to have before you sit down is time, or call in ahead of for a to-go. These ladies are in their cooking zone and I couldn't even be mad, you wouldn't rush your mom's delicious food would you? 

This place is literally a hole in the wall, okay a hallway with an island that separates you from their greatness (aka: cooking, skills, & speed)

I started with the Spring rolls, end result BOMB. Then I ordered the Garlic chicken, they call it something else but shit was off the hizzy my nizzy! Again, BOMB! My friend ordered the Chicken Chow mein, I died. Soooooo good! To end the meal I ordered the Pot stickers... You know when you eat too much you lose interest in food right after, well I took a bite of the pot stickers, instant smile and all of the pot stickers were gone.

We killed it and with all that food I was expecting a nice bill, but these ladies are literally like family because they hook you up! I gave her an Andrew Jackson along with some George Washington's to give her a generous tip.

3 Things that make it to the top of my list:
1. College student cheap
2. The bomb dot com, & 
3. Generous size servings.
author: Edith G.

description:
Greasy, foreign, TINY, hole in the wall- the type of place you would only be able to find in the city. It was definitely a neat experience for trying Burmese food for the first time. I was fairly authentic, but, this is a place I would come to more for the experience than the food. Although, they do use very fresh ingredients and despite the greasiness, the food was pretty tasty.  

If you are looking for a change of pace and scenery, something novel and fun, I would definitely recommend.
author: Stephie M.

description:
Price & Quality-  This is my favorite place to eat in San Francisco hands down. The prices here are ridiculously (and beautifully) low. For about $6 you will get a yummy and just downright delicious meal. My mouth waters just thinking of their delicious food.  That being said, I recommend you get some sides and a coke... yummy.

Service- This place is run by a couple of hardworking women who are no bullshit. It's like a mom's kitchen of sorts. The women here are always busy so they don't have the time to be smiling and caring for your every need although they will bring what is needed to you in a timely manner.

Vibe- This place is super small, and I mean super small. It's like a bar set up and only about....10 seats inside so expect to potentially wait in line depending on the time of day. It should be noted that this place is frequently , not always but frequently, busy. 

Will I come back? Yes yes & yes. Anytime i'm in the neighborhood, I gotta go get a quick bite here although I don't go as much as I'd like since their food is super oily and that's really a turn off. However their food is just THAT delicious that it's like a treat to me every time I do go. If you haven't gone, go go go!
author: Moises L.

description: Since I've had the real authentic Burmese food before. Some Burmese signature dishes here like "catfish chowder" and "tea leave salad" are pretty Americanized in a good way.
author: Jeannie Y.

description:
Yamo is sadly not yummo. It's YUCKO :(

- question the sanitation of this restaurant
- greasy residue on their plates =\ ew
- there's a black garbage can within viewing distance INSIDE O_O BIG nono
- small food portions for $5, especially the tea salad!
- old women yelling at each other makes my blood pressure go up
- still hungry after eating 3 dishes :(

Avoid eating inside this tiny hole-in-the-wall. If you do plan to order food from here I recommend calling them to place your order, picking it up, and then eating it at home. They run out of a lot of things towards the evening. So go early!!!!

I really wanted to like this place, but I just didn't like the quality of food here. My Mom can make better food than this. I felt the food portions were a bit small for being around $5 a dish. Maybe they thought my friend and I were small and had smaller stomachs? We noticed that the other people around us got larger portions... -.-

Sitting at the small counter and watching these old ladies yell at each other in their native languages made my blood pressure go up! Watch out for Albert Einstein-haired lady, she likes to yell a lot! O_O I guess many of the other customers found it quite entertaining and just laughed in amusement. Untidy kitchen, small sink, etc. I quickly lost my appetite as soon as I saw the black garbage can within 6 feet. O_O

They buy their coconuts from the market, Duc Loi, across the street for 1/2 of their selling price. I wonder if I can be ghetto next time and buy a coconut at Duc Loi, but have Yamo cut it open for me! bwahaha j/k

** Note: Enter at your own risk! **
author: CeCe C.

description: It's hard to beat for the price. 6.50 per person, the food is not bad. It's tiny and there's a lot of smoke but has it's own little vibe going on. Overall I would come back from time to time.
author: Nicolas D.

description:
first time it was nice. great character and ambience of this place.  well I always love soup nazi-type of chefs.  Yet second time, I would have to say everything was disappointing.   tea salad, stir fry and rice, all too salty and greasy.   my fish chowder is so salty and doesn't taste fresh. 

if you come, order mango chicken. it is good.
author: Shuting Z.

description:
So when I told my friend to choose a place, I had NO clue what I got myself into. When I (didn't) realize that we were, in fact, standing in front of this restaurant, I was thinking...this reminds me of the night markets of Taiwan where hygiene, personal space, and formality don't exist.

Lucky for us we got seats at the bar. I don't know how they manage to make enough money off of only 8 bar seats, but (apparently) they do. So this place was fine...for the price it was probably good. BUT with that said, the tea leaf salad is INCREDIBLE and probably the only reason for why I would venture into the Mission and wait to go eat here. GET IT, try to avoid questioning whether the woman mixing your salad with her bare hands washed her hands, and enjoy!
author: Chrissy H.

description: Tea leaf salad was delish. Cold noodles were better than beef house noodles but both were tasty.
author: Eli W.

description:
3 stars for the flavors in the green tea leaf salad. Salty, crunchy, nutty.
1 star for the cleanliness. I get hole in the walls are cramped and maybe dusty, but no need for an employee with long nails to keep forgetting to put on gloves before handling food after taking orders and handling money. I know this happens more than we probably realize or like to think, but when the customers are two feet away from the employees, it's impossible to not look. Here's your warning.
author: Theresa S.

description: Old lady was super unfriendly,  She threw my order in  to me and said that I have to go out :) From what I have learned thats their trade mark . Food was tasty but not a lot protein inside :(  It was cheap though.
author: Radoslaw D.

description:
Why do people out put up with such poor services with ok food?  Cheap prices? Tradition? The new proprietors have took on the bad attitude of the previous owner. 

A jovial customer comes in and ask: Do you miss me? Reply: no. And the customer shuts up.
author: David L.

description:
This place is amazing. I drove/walked by Yamo a million times and there was always an insanely long line out the door and was too intimidated to check it out.

Today at 3:30 I was walking by and there was no line! I actually got to sit down at the counter with my boyfriend. 

-it was a sweaty beast in there...but totally worth it for the atmosphere...but trust me next time i'm doing TO GO for sure!


We ordered everything because I was afraid I would never get to go back bc of the lines!

We got: 
-Samusas (WAY better than Indian Food samusas)
-Tea Leaf Salad (so delicious...i would rather pay $6 than get ripped off at burma superstar)
-Cold noodles with chicken (AMAZE)
-their chicken noodle soup (yummy coconut broth mmm)

Pretty much we spent $25 (with out tip) and have leftovers for dinner!

I would recommend this place to everyone!! Cheap eats and way better than any other thai/asian/burmese place i've been in this city!

ps. i love the amount of cilantro they use. 

Super happy i got to try this little whole in the wall. YUM!
author: Ellary C.

description:
I've been wanting to eat here for a while since whenever I pass the place, it either has a long line or is closed. Once, I after asked someone in line what was good, he replied, "Everything." I left with high expectations.

This place only has 8 or so booths so we realized that we probably wouldn't be able to get seats anytime soon since there was five of us. We placed to go orders and ended up waiting 1.5-2 hours. 

We ordered a bunch of dishes...and all I can say is "Ehhhhhhhhhhhhh." It's just cheap greasy Chinese food. Not even good greasy Chinese food. I think the only thing that made me think of Burmese food was the tea leaf salad, which was aiite. If I was drunk or hungover, I would think this place was awesome. However, I wouldn't come here again with such a long wait time.
author: Margaret R.

description: Hole-in-the-wall authentic Burmese restaurant. I had coconut chicken noodles and the tea leaf salad. Food was good, but not breathtaking. Tea leaf salad had just a little teal leaves and was only a light recollection of what I remember from Burma. Coconut chicken was good, but not great, very mellow with no decisive taste. The ambiance is very authentic, I felt like in the rural Asia (which may be discouraging to some, but I personally find it entertaining). All in all I left satisfied and definitely not hungry, but honestly I was expecting a bit more, especially from the tea leaf salad. Maybe it's just me, because the place was very busy, with queues both for eat in and take out.
author: Grzegorz J.

description: Someone needs to correct the opening time for this store.  It closes at 9pm, NOT 10 pm.  The place is kinda neat.  It reminds me of real ghetto places in China that serves delicious suspicious meat.  It's tasty food, but it's ghetto.  Everything has a slight burnt/charred taste to it.  It may be on purpose or it may be the pans need to be cleanse better.  The tea leaf salad is super small, but it's tasty. The Yamo fried rice and House special cold noodle are nice.  Service ain't great, but I hear customers thanking Ma for dinner.  I'll be back if I want good decent food before 9 pm.
author: Byron L.

description:
I always wanted to try this place but there's always a line. Forget about trying to go to dinner here if you're hungry. During the day it's not so bad. I've been here a few times for Saturday lunch and it is super quiet. 

The salads and the main dishes are $6 and it's decent. There's nothing really special. The tea salad is good and has a nice crunch to it. Mango chicken with rice is a little dry. Curry fish was good. I like the noodles because on a hot day, all you want is some cold noodles. 

Don't expect good service (which I appreciate the loud sassiness of the ladies) or sanitary. Burmese food seem similiar to most SE Asian food so nothing spectacular that there need to be a huge line for. When you're broke, hungry and don't feel like eating Mexican, this is a good alternative place...if u can get in.
author: Nam T.

description:
Came here on a Saturday evening after exploring the mission district. Literally a hole-in-the-wall, don't let its looks deceive you.  Run by 3 women (grandmas), there is only one long bar table, with the kitchen directly on the other side.  You can see exactly what they are cooking etc.  Although smokey and poorly ventilated, if you desire to eat legit burmese food check this place out!

We tried the tea leaf salad (very flavorful and delicious!), garlic noodles (I think this was my favorite), and Mango Chicken (decent, but I found the mangos a little odd with the spicy sauce).  The dishes can be quite small, so I would suggest splitting them with your friend (We ordered 3 dishes among the 2 of us, and it was perfect).  

Overall, this is a great place to eat at to fully experience San Francisco and it's cultural diversity at its finest!
author: Austin R.

description:
Hmmm...I stopped by for a quick dinner yesterday evening, and luckily there were seats available - I was in luck!  I sat down and ordered potstickers, tea leaf salad and mango chicken - ok, my eyes were much bigger than my stomach, but at least I got a chance to taste a few things.  

I thought the potstickers were ok, the tea leaf salad...hmmm... I've had better elsewhere in the City...and the mango chicken was a-ok.  I wasn't wow'd like I was expecting to be.  

It is definitely a cute and charming place with just 9 seats at the counter, hooks are behind you on the wall to hang your stuff (very thoughtful!), and the ladies are busy cooking, talking, answering the phone, taking to-go orders, preparing and serving food.  

Maybe I'd go back to try other things on the menu, but I wasn't impressed with the things I picked that other Yelpers recommended...hmmm....maybe I'll give it another shot sometime, but I'm not really running back for more.  

Potstickers+tea leaf salad+mango chicken+tip+tax - $17
author: Maile N.

description: I love the food here.   The salad, the curries, and noodle dishes are all so good, and great prices.  I leave out 1 star because the place is small, rarely ever get to sit down, and service isn't the best.
author: Gloria G.

description: OK, I so badly want to love this place. The food is alright (if rather bland), it's reasonably cheap, and it reminds me of my favorite SF restaurants in the 90's. But every time I've gone there I've had to ask multiple times for a glass of water (most recently, three times). They serve water in a 4oz glass. To get more water, you have to catch the eye of someone behind the counter and ask (again, sometimes repeatedly) for each refill. To me that's justification enough for one star, but unfortunately there's more not to love. The staff is always surly as hell; they seems to be constitutionally unable to smile. Appetizers usually come out last. They often forget to serve dipping sauce with the potstickers. It's always 1000 degrees inside. Meh, I think I'm done trying with Yamo.
author: Christian W.

description:
Cheap, quick, tasty. For vegetarians, #14 with noodles is the best. 

Cash only. If you order over the phone just go up to the counter and tell them what you ordered (no need to wait in the often massive line outside).
author: Ryan S.

description: The owner's attitude was very rude, no customer service at all.  The place is tiny, just a few bar stool seating (maybe 10 or less?).  I ordered the tea leaf salad, and it was the worse salad I have ever had: it was overly salty, portion was ridiculously small (it's smaller than a side salad at almost any restaurant), and its sauce was not good at all!  My friend had a cold noodle dish, the noodle was nothing special, and there were maybe 4 or 5 thinly slices of meat in curry sauce.  The dishes are about $6.50 per entree, but the portion and the amount of food you get, is less than half of any restaurant I've been to!  And they are especially skimpy on the meant, don't expect more than maybe 4 or 5, thinly sliced, small pieces.  I don't understand all the high rating.  I would definitely never go back again.
author: Laura T.

description:
Yelp!! Why?? So I just ate here for lunch. I ordered the vegetable curry over rice, and it took quite a while for the food to get to me. In the meantime, I'm getting smoke blown directly at my face. Don't sit in the seat closest to the door because that's where they stirfry their food and get smoke and spices all over you T_T. I did my best to ignore it, but there were times I had to lean back away from the counter cause the smoke was that bad. I wonder how many complaints they've gotten from that. Probably none cause the cook was pretty scary/kind of rude. How could she not notice??

Anyway, I get my vegetable curry over rice. Except it's more like hella salty/spicy vegetables with hella grease over rice. The portion wasn't very big, but I felt like I had to eat most of it just not to be rude and leave the whole plate there. Uggh it was so oily and salty T___T. Not worth $6!! Left pretty annoyed. Why does this place have 4 stars?? WHY?

P.S. I didn't know that this place is literally just a counter. Also, their water tastes strangely minty.
author: Betty W.

description:
The food here is quite good. The ingredients they use are pretty standard, but everything is fresh and cooked right in front of you. It's also tiny! Basically a row of seats and then a parallel row where all the cooking is done. The ladies who work there can be snappy and a bit hard to understand, but they get orders out fairly efficiently. I usually dine in since the to-go orders are a bit smaller than the sit-down. If eaten hours after cooking, the food tastes more pedestrian. 

I've had the cold noodle dish, exactly $6, which is noodles plus a mix of finely chopped veggies, your choice of protein, some sort of goopy, delicious sauce, and tons of garlic. I've also had the house noodles, which is similar to the cold noodle dish, but wasn't nearly as good since it basically had no vegetables (except cilantro). 


If you go during peak dining hours, there will probably be a small line out the door. I usually go half an hour after they "open" in case they haven't actually opened yet.
author: Jasper P.

description: Exquisite and awesome. Appetizer $4.50 and others $6.25. It's like chinese street food style with a little mission culture.
author: Zaoshi Y.

description:
