Yamo is cheap, tasty and busy. There is literally only about 8 seats inside and its facing the cook area. I don't know why anyone would want to 'dine in'... you are literally bathing in heat and oil. Unless you want to come out smelling like frying oil, be my guest. 

The menu is relatively simple, nothing fancy. Considering it looks like a 3 person operation; everything will have some form of curry, tofu, mango or protein. 

Now there are only about 3 ladies working there and they are masters at multi-tasking, taking orders, prepping food, handling money....not sure if this translates to the cleanest food but you literally cannot complain when the food is so cheap. 

Things to try: Samosas (fried and filled with curry and potatoes). Personally the dipping sauce is not that impressive, just a simple sweet and sour red sauce. Wished it was more light and yogurt-y (like its Indian counterpart) 
Curry beef: delicious, oily and salty! 
Mango Chicken: more delicious-ness and oily-ness
Noodles: taste like chow Mein 

Wait: is dreadful when its busy. You literally have to wave down one of the lady to grab their attention. They are not the type to ask you 'if you're ready to order'. If you don't speak up, then you might be waiting a very long time. Knowing a bit of Cantonese also helps, if you can order in Cantonese; you're golden.
author: Amy L.

description:
Braved the curry facial in this little hole in the wall spot with a friend to grab some food. Horrendous service. Felt like they threw the food at us and watched angrily as we quickly shoveled our food into our face so we could be out of their way. 

But God the food was good. and for $20 bucks I can't really complain.
author: Mariam H.

description:
House noodle w/ beef + Curry beef w/ rice

BEST DISHES EVER FROM YAMO. Thank you nice Burmese ladies for making them and thanks for Burma!
author: Nery Z.

description:
Yamo? YUM-O!

With so many restaurants in SF, it's hard for me to justify going to one repeatedly when there are so many I've yet to try. But with Yamo, I make an exception. I almost can't pass by 18th and Mission without coming here - it's gotten so bad that I once ordered takeout and brought it to ChaChaCha's where I was meeting friends for dinner!

When you walk in it's almost like walking into a different country. It's one of the diviest restaurants I've ever been to but that's part of its charm. Seating's very limited (about 8 along the counter) and ladies behind the counter can often be heard bickering with each other in Chinese. Personally, I think it's a pretty cool place to take a date. 

There are 4 things I always order when I come: tea leaf salad, catfish chowder, chicken noodle soup, and fresh young coconut. I've tried some of their stir-frys but didn't think they were as good as the soups

I love the flavour of the TEA LEAF SALAD (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?userid=5bmpGbzPd-gfcUl6o5j7FQ) and the nuts/beans/lentils in it really add a nice crunch. The CATFISH CHOWDER (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=fMdV017JTpolF_W1tHH-eQ) is my favourite dish. The soup is cooked so long that all the fish is broken down. The fried lentils adds to the texture too. The CHICKEN NOODLE SOUP (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=QJ72eeYAXqqdpE1c2Tr2Vg) is also amazing - great coconut curry broth that I can't resist drinking every last drop of.

I start every Yamo meal off with a FRESH YOUNG COCONUT (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=QPJzK4OXzdu5JK1WoRai-w). It's served with the top cut off, a straw, and a spoon to scrape out the meat. Only problem is I like to eat the meat before I finish drinking it, so I tend to splash myself and whoever's sitting next to me multiple times with coconut water...
author: Steph L.

description: At one point I thought this place was hella good. Slash last time I was the the lady was so rude. She must of not been having a good day bu.... The food tasted bland and way greasy. Had to walk it off. The coconuts are bomb. So try those.
author: Malik C.

description:
(1) First off the food here is cheap. Very cheap.

(2) It's also very dirty. You get what you pay for.

(3) Service is also rude and curt. Again, you get what you pay for.

(4) The food here is meh. Being a lover of all things divey, I really wanted to like this place, but I can't get over how mediocre it is. Yet again, you get what you pay for.

(5) There's always a line during dinner. Which leads me to conclude that either:
Yamo customers are cheap and/or broke, and/or Yamo customers have very low standards, foodwise.

So if I tally up the above, I'd have to give it negative 3 stars (+1-4). But since I cannot, I'll give it +2, 'cuz I've most definitely experienced better.

If the line at Yamo weren't so ridiculous, I might consider it on occasion. The food isn't *that* bad, in fact it's somewhat decent, in an Asian street food kind of way. But I cannot justify wasting my precious time for this food, especially when there are much better options in the Mission and nearby 'loin.  Even if it were cheaper (if that's even possible) and/or cleaner and/or more welcoming.
author: J K.

description:
Love this place. 

I usually get the beef house noodles. The women who work their are really funny and get sassy with the patrons. Sometimes they can be intimidating. If they ask you what you want....you better be ready to order!

Sometimes there's a line outside. There's a counter that seats only about a dozen people, but I've seen a lot of people ordering to go.
author: Czar Y.

description:
Absurdly awful. So bad it would have been funny except that we had to pay for the crap food and the sad attempt at service, and trust me... we weren't expecting much. One look in the place and you kinda give up all hope anyway.

Food was either greasy, bland and tasteless or greasy, over-salted, and over-vinegared. I don't know exactly what they're trying to prepare here (frankly, I don't think they know or care, either) but it sure isn't Burmese food. Bad Chinese at best, and these poor ladies know how to AIM LOW. In between arguing with each other and confusing the customers with their angry, shouted instructions, they managed to screw up our order of three dishes twice.

The hood over the burners stopped working decades ago so the place has a seriously impressive coating of grease, the kind that makes everything sticky including you and your clothes. If you do choose to sit at the counter, don't wear anything that you're too fond of, it'll reek of rancid oil by the time you're done. Don't look around too much, definitely not up past the black, greasy lights toward the black, greasy ceiling. You'll start to wonder exactly what's ending up in the food.

I have no idea what people see in this place; I guess they think they're getting some kind of authentic experience, but it's a total waste of time and money and a complete joke.
author: Josh H.

description:
I like spending money on expensive food, but I have a soft heart for inexpensive meals with a whopping price tag of $6!!! Read on Yelpers.
My friend Dan and I wanted to roam around SF for fun before we had to trek it back to SJ. He mentioned we should grab a quick bite at Yamo before continuing the rest of our day. Finally took the opportunity to check this place out after so many attempts and never actually dining here until now. I can't complain about this place, regardless if they only seat 8 people at maximum capacity. Yep! I said it. 8 people. Consider this a sit down, eat your food quick, and smell like grease after having food coma status.
Anyway, food costs between $4-$6. Yeah, right?! Cheap!! We ordered their popular dishes: samusas, cold beef and chicken noodles, and tea leaf salad. From my standpoint, I loved it all! Reminds me of the type of dishes my boyfriend's mom cooks at home. She's Chinese/Burmese. Gotta say, this is by far, one of my go-to cheap spots to eat at now. Worst of all, that same day, I went back here after 3 hours because my drunk-a** had a fat craving for their cold noodles. How's that for being a foodie?!
FYI...the women who run this business, don't be shocked or turned away by their speaking tones. They're not trying to be rude. I think that's how they speak to each other.
For those who admire Burma Superstar, maybe your palates got spoiled by fine dining, but you can't go wrong with hole-in-the-wall spots like this....especially when it's greasy food. Duh people! Get over yourself.

Am I a fan?! F*** yeah I am!!
author: Fraulein C.

description:
Burmese. $6 dishes. Maybe 8 stools. Clothes will smell.

Had the tea leaf salad, which had hardly any tea leaves to speak of. It's basically a salad of all the other garnishes of a traditional tea leaf salad. 

The mohinga (fish chowder) was decent, hard to detect if there was any sort of protein, but the broth was rich and thick, with some scallions and fried things as garnish. Noodles were plentiful.
 
I'd rather go to other Burmese spots than return.
author: Derrick V.

description: People complain about the wait or how "rude ".the staff is but HELLO great food for an amazing price, and look how small the restaurant is! If you want to sit down for awhile order ahead of time and take to go, they aren't rude people, they just want to keep an flow and make money!
author: Lauryn L.

description:
I had the tea leaf salad. First of all, I was surprised by how small the thing was, I guess the close up pics on yelp made it look much bigger. Secondly, where are the tea leaves? I didn't see nor taste any tea flavor. I do, however, like the assortment of nuts they put in the salad. I also tried some of my friend's chicken curry. It was bland. I also ordered the spring rolls. Once again, it was average and the peanut sauce was, you guessed it, bland. Considering the price, I would give the food 3.5 stars. 

Now, here's the kicker -- the server was extremely rude. I get take out from Chinatown often and am well acquainted with bad service, but even I was shocked. I asked for prawns on my salad and the lady said OK. When my salad came, there were no prawns in sight and I asked her about it. She told me that it has dried shrimp. I told my server that I would pay for some prawns added to the salad. The lady literally yelled "NO!" at me. I was stunned. Maybe it was the language barrier thing, but there was absolutely no excuse to treat a customer like that, especially since I didn't argue with her and was courteous.
author: Alice W.

description: This is what you call a straight hole in the wall restaurant. Now remember when you go to a hole in the wall restaurant, there is one thing you cannot expect. That is good service. The woman that takes your order is extremely rude, but you can't expect much. Trust me just order the Yamo Noodles, and you will completely forget how rude this woman is. So I ordered the Yamo Noodles, with beef. Oh man the meat was soooooo tender. Holy crap. It was like heaven, in my mouth. If you guys like heaven, and you like it in your mouth. Go to Yamo. Yesss I'll be back.
author: Quyenna T.

description:
I remember when I visited my relatives in Penghu Island as a child, my late grandmother would bust her ass to make dinner in the stuffy tiled kitchen, and the heat from the cooking pots and pans would waft into the living room where ten people would wait hungrily and chat incessantly. Yamo reminds me of that moment. Three old Burmese ladies dash here and there in the open kitchen, shouting and chatting excitedly while patrons wait at the bar, amidst the sound of sizzling oil and blasts of stir-fry heat.

There's almost always a line of varying length here all day. Maybe it's because this place can only seat seven or eight, or maybe the food is so good. Well, scratch that "or", it's more like "and". I went here once and it has become one of my favorites. My date and I had fish curry and tea salad, both highlights of the night. The curry had plenty of fish and rice, and the mild spiciness topped off the appeal of this dish. The tea salad was interesting. Little tea leaves with peanuts, cabbage, and something crispy which I couldn't distinguish, all in light fish sauce. Mmmm, a good complement to the hearty curry. All together, the bill ran to something like eleven dollars, which is pretty cheap.

They also have grass jelly, but ran out when I went. Oh well, next time.
author: Hannah H.

description:
Yamo, oh Yamo, Yamo, Yamo, yummmmm-o. Ha. 

That being said, there are a lot of downsides to this place. It's cheap... but oh-so-dirty. It's authentic... meaning the place is run by your typical, er, terse Asian ladies. The space is small, and even if you are lucky enough to find a seat in there, you'll emerge smelling like chili oil, smoke, and stir fry. But believe me, you will NEVER find a seat in there. The crowds in this place get RIDICULOUS. There's always a long wait, even at odd hours of the day. I even flirted with giving this place three stars because of it.

However, it's not often that you can find an Asian takeout place that's cheap, authentic, healthy, and delicious. Yamo is all of those things -- like everybody else, I especially recommend the mango chicken. It tastes like my mom's stir-fry... and let me tell you, that's probably one of the biggest compliments I've given to a restaurant on Yelp.
author: Michelle L.

description:
The samosas are very enjoyable. The Chow fun was a bit greasy for my taste, and didn't express much flavor from the noodles or the beef.

Something else I noticed was that the girl taking the orders was touching both money and food, without washing her hands in between. For me that is a HUGE nono.
author: Alex G.

description: Food is amazing, one of the best Burmese place!
author: Geezy L.

description:
Divey yet charming hole-in-the-wall spot in the Mission that offers quick, decent food and a great price.  They go heavy on the oil though despite the array of fresh, delicious vegetables on the counter.

The place is tiny with a small wait for the handful of bar seats available.  There's not a lot of personal space, so we quickly befriended our neighbor.  We bellied up to the bar and almost immediately was asked what we wanted, like regulars.  Food came out quickly.

The house noodles with chicken and pork potstickers were tasty.  The curry noodles with shrimp were not very flavorful and while I enjoyed them, I would not order them again.  The meals were greasy, so I want to come back for their lighter options.

The girl next to me order the chicken coconut soup and it looked delicious so it's next on my list.  The salads also seemed very popular.
author: Caitlin T.

description:
YES. i heart the chicken noodle soup here. it's basically their house noodles, with chicken in a coconut curry broth. totes comfort food! i also ordered the tea leaf salad, which was a great side meal to the soup. 

skip the mango chicken. 

also ordered the house noodles with beef. greasy, but still tasty. 

this place is chaotic and most of the time i call ahead my order to pick it up. but even then, it can take awhile. but it 's tasty and not expensive! one of my new "go to's".
author: Clara H.

description:
Waited 45 minutes for take out that we'd called ahead for. Was very excited, but ended up very sad and disappointed when our food (house noodle, curry, fish chowder) was greasy and flavorless. Yes the environment feels authentic, but the food was not good and definitely not worth the wait. Too much hype from other reviewers*.

*hipsters
author: Ryan K.

description: Delicious, small portions, fight to get attention and a seat.  Do take out if possible. Don't look at the ceiling or watch them make the food if you are sensitive to cleanliness (or lack there-of).  Wish there were more meat in the dishes, but hard to argue when everything is under $8. Bring that cash money, check it off your bucket list.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
I would give Yamo four stars, but the service wasn't that great when we dined in. Which is why I HIGHLY recommend take out! Regardless of the service, I can see why Yamo had high reviews because it really is good for being a hole in the wall. 

Their Tea Salad was pretty good! Being someone that doesn't like salads, I enjoyed it. We also tried a fried curry appetizer but I forgot what it was called. For my main dish I got the Yamo house noodles with beef as my choice of meat. They also had chicken and pork, which my other two friends got. There was nothing really special about them, they were just like chow mien noodles. 

For four people dining in we were pushing it since they only had 10 seats, but together our bill came out to being only 34 dollars. You get exactly what you pay for so I don't have much to complain about.
author: Cat P.

description:
Some places just speak to you the moment you lay eyes on them and demand you try them out. I knew I had to eat at Yamo as soon as I saw it.

Yamo consists of a kitchen, a counter, bar stools and almost nothing else. Maverick this is not. In a given trip you can expect a line out the door, the cook yelling to her coworkers about incoming orders, possibly one glass of water (sometimes none if you dont ask) and some of the finest, dirt-cheap food around. 

I'd wholeheartedly recommend you try a dish involving noodles and, if possible, curry. That said, the soups, black bean dishes, mango chicken and tea leaf salad are all excellent in their own right. I love to order in, but takeout is an option for those with somewhere else to get to. 

Yamo isn't for everyone. It's as much an experience as it is a place to get dinner. But if you're in the area and have a little patience, I will gladly come wait in line with you.
author: Scott T.

description:
Yamo = Yum-o!

Got the tea leaf salad, house noodles with beef, and mango chicken. 

The tea leaf salad made me laugh because it comes on this cute tiny plate and is just enough to whet your palate for what's to come. Very small, but good balance of tea leaves, crunchy thingies, and crisp veggies.

House noodles were delightfully flavored. The noodles itself were a little soggy for my liking, but I didn't mind because it tasted scrumptious! The beef came in ample portions and was very tender.

Mango chicken was AWESOME! That's all I have to say. Yes, the combo with the chili powder and fish sauce is a little weird at first, but after the first few bites I was hooked!

The cute Asian ladies don't play no games when it comes to cooking real, home-y, satisfying food. LOVE. Wanted to have a young coconut but they did not have any. WHYYYY.

Beware, if you're sitting in the back, getting out will be like getting out of a jungle. Especially when the patrons in the front have HUGE HIKING BACKPACKS that are hanging on the walls and you're literally TRAPPED behind them. Had to duck and weave just to get out in one piece!
author: Moraia W.

description: Delicious house noodles and tea salad. Skip the curry fish. Expect to sit down and order quickly as there are only 8 seats or so. The cooks are on a mission so don't expect smiles or courtesies like that. Cash only - really well priced. I'd definitely come back!
author: Charlene N.

description:
So I went back to Yamo the other day and ordered the House Noodles with Chicken. This dish was much better than the curry I had before. The noodles were a little too soft, but the flavor was delish and the chicken wasn't dry. If I go back to Yamo, I will stick with their House Noodles.

Warning! This place is hot as Hades during the lunch hour. I don't recommend eating in, not that you'd find a seat
author: Barbara W.

description:
I bet these ladies work really really hard to cook some tasty tasty food at a low low price in a cozy little place.
My go to place for indo Chinese... In fact the chicken chow mein is closest thing to authentic outside India. I also love the cold noodles and the spring rolls.
author: Sumit S.

description: 3.5 This tiny mouse hole in the wall has fresh food cooked in front of you that is super cheap.  Noodles are little greasy but still dank.  Tea salad and house noodles are top things to get here.
author: Lynn J.

description:
Cheap burmese food. Minus the rice in the rice platter, small salad and entree portions. Black bean mushroom tofu sauce was tasty, house noodles weren't horrible. 

The restaurant is a hole in the wall, serves ~10 people max on the diner bar-like counter. i think people just come here because they are not asian, it's cheap, and food isn't bad. Service is ok, but the place is filthy.
author: Judy C.

description: After being overwhelmed by the club-scene that is Mission Chinese my friend and I opted for Yamo for take out instead. The place is quite literally a hole in the wall, I was certain we had the wrong address until we peeked inside. The ladies behind the counter are serious and curt, but they're busy boiling, frying and tossing dishes with about three inches of counter space in an chili oil sauna, so you really can't blame them. We waited outside for our Yamo House Noodles with Chicken, Egg Rolls (with amazing, homemade sweet and sour sauce), and Pot Stickers. Even after BART-ing home the food was still warm and satisfying. Not the best Chinese food I've ever had, but far from the worst.
author: Nan H.

description: Food needs salt for flavor.  Food was cheap but I wasn't underwhelmed.  I was expecting more msg or something
author: Fatty A.

description: There's a complete dearth of Burmese food in NY - it's something you have to hunt for with great grit and tenacity, like how you might approach a needle in a haystack - so imagine my surprise when I came upon Yamo right in Mission in San Francisco, leading a completely nonchalant existence with a single counter and a handful of bar stools. I took my SF friends there for the first time and we dug everything, particularly the tea leaf salad. The only downside was eating right in front of the stove, so we took in all the grease, cooking odors as well as the spices (I had to remove my glasses to avoid residue!)
author: Crystal W.

description:
It seems like the wave of yelp influenced hipsters that made this place nearly impossible to get into for months has moved on to Ike's and I couldn't be happier. Now I can eat here after only a reasonable wait.

I finally tried their tealeaf salad and loved it; of course their fish noodle chowder is as good as ever.

If they gave the place a good scrubbing and a fresh paint job I'd gladly bump them up to four stars.
author: Manny F.

description: Place looks very grungy but can't ask for much for the prices. The service wasn't the greatest either. I ordered the House Noodles with pork to go. Was fairly disappointed as I basically got all noodles with like enough pieces of pork to count on my hand. If you want to eat a bowl full of noodles I'd check out this place.
author: Vijith N.

description: just feels like a kitchen in burma. eat fast or else they'll rush you out. cash only, super cheap, smallish portions, awesome flavor.
author: Sonya Z.

description:
Hole in the wall
expect a line
order to go
Cash Only
and you'll be fine
every item is $6.00
no tax charged
call over the phone 
and you're food will be ready when you arrive
Tea leaf salad
mango chicken
chow mein
Black bean fish
All were delish.  

once you're finished 
Yamo will be missed.
author: Blue S.

description:
Yamo is Yum-o!!!!

This is the perfect stop after a random night of drinking in the mission.  The space is TINY but everyone is so nice and moved down to accommodate my group and the ladies behind the counter serve food like it's no joke.  Considering I was starving I was so happy when food appeared 5 minutes after we ordered.

Tea Salad - small portion but super tasty
House noodles with pork - delicious
Curry Shrimp over rice - I'd get it with the rice noodles next time, good sauce
Fish Chowder Soup - not my cup of tea but had good flavor, consistency is a bit thick for my taste
Samosas - looked fresh and hot but I'm just not a samosas fan
Potstickers - pretty basic but hits the spot.

Seems like a bunch of regulars and lots and lots of takeout orders.  Oh single ladies I noticed a lot of single guys chowing down by themselves at the counter!
author: Jen C.

description:
Yamo's is one of my favorite spots in the Mission. It's tiny, which I dig. It's got some chef's who take your orders while shouting to each other in a foreign language, which is awesome... And the food is delicious, which is ultimately what counts. 

Vegan friendly. Pretty cheap. And after living in San Francisco for four years, this is one of the places I'll return to. 

Check it out, don't be shy, and as always, think before you eat.
author: Travis J.

description: So I have been out of the country for 2 years. And this is the 1st new restaurant I got try after returning to America. Me and a friend shared the yamo cold house noodles, the yamo hot house needles with beef, and the samusas. Bursts of flavors all over the place. My friend said that those three dishes were the ones to get. I certainly agree. Top it off with fresh coconut to drink. Fantastic. I could not ask for a better homecoming.
author: April D.

description: Hole in the wall (seats around 10) popular place between Mission and Valencia usually gets crowded later in the evening with people waiting to pick up take out orders. Tealeaf salad, was amazing. Average vegetarian options. Spice level bit above average.
author: Sandeep M.

description:
Ok this place is small as hell. Like hole in the wall in an open kitchen. I suggest ordering ahead for pick up because getting a seat here will be impossible. 

I wanted to like this place because it was owned by 3 Burmese ladies working their butt off with the hot wok. But I just felt like the portions were super small and nothing wowed me. It is cheap (according to sf standards) but my native friends said Chinatown is cheaper. 

My favorite was the tea leaf salad. I never had anything like it so I went to my local Burmese market to hopefully get a replacement haha. 

They give pretty durable Tupperware for their takeout orders! Totally reusable.
author: Lisa T.

description: Loooove this place. If you want to have real exotic and authentic experience - go there. One lady is frying the food and the fire is above her head, another one is chopping coconuts with huge ass knife. My favorite dish is house noodles - so simple but so good. CASH ONLY.
author: Nadia A.

description:
It pains me to do this. I love Yamo more than suburban moms love their gifted children. When I could barely afford to go out, Yamo was there for me, a cramped, steamy little treasure of a restaurant where I could get an amazing hot meal and still have quarters left over for my laundry. 

But yesterday I had one of the worst restaurant experiences of my life, and it was at Yamo. I placed an order to go for myself and one other person (a friend laid up with a messed up leg, since you asked). For my two orders of noodles and one order of potstickers I waited an entire hour, while people who ordered after me got their food and left. Then, when I got the food home, I found that they hadn't even seasoned our food! So I waited an hour for plain white rice with a bland assortment of chicken and vegetables on top. I would have been better off going to the supermarket and buying a frozen dinner, and that makes me sad. 

I still love this place, but I won't be coming back during dinner rush again, because I don't think they know how to handle their ever-increasing volume of admirers. Mango chicken, tea leaf salad, samosas, you will be missed.
author: Aaron Y.

description:
I'd wanted to try Yamo's stuff for a while so when my brother got noodles to go for us, I was really excited. 

...Unfortunately, I was a little disappointed in the food. I mean, it's tasty, but it's not really worth the wait. 

I definitely would consider going back and trying more things, but I really don't think that their noodles or food is worth all of the hype. 

I love hole-in-walls and hidden gems, and definitely think that Yamo should be given a chance...but their food is not one that I crave or a place on my list that I HAVE to visit the few times I visit home a year.
author: Alison N.

description: Greasy, oily house noodles. Was nauseous for the rest of the day. Tea leaf salad was good but there is a lack of sanitary procedures here. Didn't see any washing of hands after handling money or touching the register (which is wrapped in plastic...) and then picking up a handful of noodles to prep to-go order boxes.
author: L C.

description:
My son brought me to Yamo's this afternoon. It was like stepping into a third world dive - it's small, a counter top with 8 stool chairs. It' hot, smoky and greasy with three not very friendly woman behind the counter - one taking orders and serving the food, another doing the cooking just a few feet away, and the third woman prepping veggies nearly in your face. I have to admit it was fun to watch and a lot cheaper than going to Burma. 

We ordered tea salad cause so many yelp reviewers mention it, also mango chicken, the house noodles, and potstickers. The tea salad was very tasty with a nice peanut crunch, the mango chicken was very flavorful with the contrast between sweet and salty, the noodles with pork were very good and filling, lastly the potstickers arrived last and were flavorful with a fried edge on the bottom side. The hot sauce that came with the potstickers was perfect.

The dishes are small so don't come here if you want a huge portion serving; on the other hand, the price for each of our plates was $6.25 and the potstickers were $4.50. Not bad especially since we left very satisfied. For the very hungry, I would simply suggest that you order more food if after your initial order you are still hungry.

Yamo's is not for everyone. As I said it is like stepping into the third world, but for my palate the food was good, the price was right, and I loved the experience. I would definitely go back to Yamo's. Try it out.
author: Amado P.

description:
First of all, I thought this was a Korean place (for no reason in particular, just an assumption.) Secondly, every time I see this place I think of the quote from 40-Year-Virgin: "If I have to hear 'Ya-mo Be There' one more time, I'm going to 'Ya-mo' burn this place to the ground. Classic Paul Rudd.

I had no intention of eating here on this particular night, but after passing by the place with my girlfriend and seeing no line (there's always a line), we decided that it was a sign we should eat here. So we went across the street to buy some groceries from the market, only to return less than 10 minutes later...to a line!

Should've taken that as a sign that it wasn't the day for us to 'Yamo eat there,' but we already had our hearts set on it, so we waited it out.. for about a minute. Then we decided to order take out so we didn't have to wait in the cold City night.

We ordered the samusas, beef curry over noodles, and the tea leaf salad. The samusas were great. Not too big and oily, and very flavorful. The tea leaf salad was good, but doesn't compare to the version at Burma Superstar. Lastly, the beef curry over noodles was disappointing. It might've been the fact that we didn't eat it until we got home 20-30 minutes, but it the noodles were dry, and the sauce was lacking. Like I said, it most likely dried up on the drive home, but for now, I'm calling it like I see it, and for now, I'm not a fan.

I would like to try it again (and eat-in this time), as I feel this place has potential, and the prices are quite cheap, but only if I happen to pass by on an empty stomach and there's no line. But if I'm in need of my Burmese food fix, it's Superstar/B-Star FTW.
author: Stan A.

description:
The counter holds 8 or 9 (if one adult sits on your lap).

One of the nice lady over the stove is clipping her nails.  Damn, I know the whole time I will be cautiously chewing my food watching out for nails.  :-)

Ordered the fish chowder noodle soup(mohinga - national dish of Burma or Myanmar).  The soup is really creamy with quite a strong kick of ginger.  Not bad, not great...I would say it's good. I don't want to gross you out but I felt it tasted a tad too mucous like for me.  I also ordered the #15 House noodle with beef.  That #15 is some delicious noodles as in the Asian equivalent of a Carbonara.  I mean how bad could garlic noodles dipped in some fat and topped with stir fried beef with some fresh veggies thrown in? 

The most delicious thing at Yamo? The young coconut juice.  I forgot about it until one of their regulars came in and ordered #15 and a coconut juice(there's a guy who knows what's good).  The owner Judy took out a big machete looking thing and hacked the top off a good sized coconut.  Inside was the most delicious ambrosia imaginable.  I get coconut juice all the time overseas and this was as good as or better than any coconut I had in Thailand.  Cool soft sweet coconut juice slid down my throat.  Afterward you could also spoon out some of the soft white coconut meat.  Yum!

A tip if you are walking from the 16th Mission BART station, cross the street before making the right to head toward 18th st.  I think that side of the Mission street is a little nicer for this stretch. JMHO.
author: Jim J.

description: The food was delicious and simple. A perfect representation of the Asian kitchen. The whole atmosphere of the place was great and I enjoyed every bit of it.
author: Davey S.

description:
Visited for the 1st time last night and was pleasantly shocked how much I enjoyed it.  

Its tiny, only about a dozen seats at the counter and so I can imagine on a busy night there is fair wait, but we waited only about 10 min.  We ordered the samusas  (this is how they were spelled on the menu), pot stickers, tea salad, and the curry fish. Everything was super tasty and the bill came to whopping $20 and change, not bad at all!

Take-out seemed to be a popular option, which makes sense giving the limited seating. Honestly the only reasons I'm not giving it a 5 star is 1. No alcohol... a beer would have been great with that meal and 2. We came at the end of service and do to the limited space the staff was chopping up large volumes of onions next us in prep for the next day which was making my eyes water.  But let me just say, a little eye watering wouldn't deter me from going back!
author: V R.

description:
I love hole-in-the-walls, so this place was pretty perfect for me.  There are about 6 stools and you sit at the counter.  Front row to all the action:  the ladies are hard at work chopping, steaming, and barking instructions at each other and at customers.  Yamo has a slight, and somewhat satisfying, Soup Nazi-esque feel to it.

The food is great.  I split the mango salad and the house noodles with beef and both were delicious.  The noodles are oily, but that is why they are good.  I have a feeling everything is good, so I imagine you can't really go wrong no matter what you order.

Great little spot, and I can't wait to go back.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
This is seriously a hole-in-the-wall type of place. If you're looking for this place while driving, you may blink and miss it so make sure to look at the photo of the place before coming here. There are about 12 stools lined up along an open kitchen so you can see how they prepare and cook their dishes.

Highlight: Tea Leaf Salad ($5.25): smaller portion than Burma Superstar but so good. Similar in flavor with added onions and heat, if desired. I loved it spicy!

We also had the House Noodles with Chicken ($5.25). Soy-flavored noodles with juicy slices of chicken breast. It was very good but I couldn't help but think it tasted like any other decent Chinese restaurant. Same goes for the Mango Chicken with rice ($5.25). The sauce was very good with the rice but it wasn't anything too special. They also have fresh coconut juice and Cokes in glass bottles.

The ladies who work here are quick. I saw them use gloves to prepare spring rolls and salads so that's a big plus. It's not the most quiet place because those ladies are yelling out orders left and right. I heard them speak Cantonese and what I suspect to be Burmese since I couldn't understand it. 

Overall, great place for some good, cheap food. However, it is pretty much Chinese food so I would only come back for the tea leaf salad.
author: Tina T.

description:
Whenever visiting this place, please, please, PLEASE keep in mind that it is VERY very tiny. My girlfriend and I had to get our food to-go. I had no idea that this place was just a hallway. You've got a cooking area, and a row of chairs to sit in, and barely enough room behind those chairs to walk through. It was my first time trying this place out, and it definitely packs a punch. The prices aren't too bad, no tax, exactly the amount you see on the menu which is posted on the windows of the place.

Two of the items that we both ate were the House Chow Mein with Chicken and the Samusas. Everything they have is freshly cooked in front of you, all veggies and noodles prepped, and ready to get cooked up. They won't make it until you order it. The House Chow Mein with Chicken that we ordered had so much Chicken in it (not that it's a bad thing, a good thing really), and the portion sizing was pretty good, and we had a good amount of Samusas. So if you're ever feeling adventurous, and in the mood for Chinese food when you're in the Mission, check out Yamo's.
author: Jay A.

description:
Went there again and had the following:

Mango fish
Shrimp noodles 
house special rice

Another priceless experience
author: Hasham Y.

description: Not sure what all of the fuss is about. Horrible food, cramped environment, cooks/waitresses are the Chinese version of the soup nazi from Seinfeld. It doesn't matter if it's $6 if you can't eat the food what good is the low price. I had a couple of bites of the seafood chowder and had to leave - it was that bad. Think gooey msg consistency, no seafood in the soup.  Unbelievable how/why so many people love this place. It was packed with hipster 20-somethings when I was there on a Friday night. If you want real Burmese food that you can actually eat, in a better environment with servers that actually care about you and your well being check out Rangoon Ruby in Palo Alto.
author: Josh N.

description: Fun spot with good food. But recently there has been a line. Get here early if you'd like to avoid that. Very small space.  You will come out smelling like the cookin's and it gets very toasty in there.
author: Ali B.

description: If you're looking for a good customer service for not so bad hole in the wall type of place, this is definitely NOT the place! The people (at least the two that were working when we ate) don't seem to notice you the minute you walk in and by the time you walk out except of course when you give them your order and when it comes to paying. Food wise it's A-ok. Nothing to brag about, yeah the price is affordable but look at what you're getting. I'm sure there are better one around for the same price. Those ladies need to learn how to smile.....SMILE LADIES it doesn't hurt.
author: Lorna O.

description:
You want hole-in-the-wall? This place has you covered. It is 10 seats max, and if it's at capacity (which it nearly always is), it is crowded. Be prepared to bump elbows with your neighbor, and don't bring in too many bags/jackets, as that takes up the aisle space well.

Space aside, the food is good and extremely affordable. Their salads are a must - tea leaf and mango are awesome and the best things I ate there. Chow fun noodles are good with veggies, but I like my food spicy so I added a lot of chili sauce on them. I wasn't a fan of the curry fish - very salty, even when mixed with rice and/or noodles, and not appetizing.

Overall, you get a bang for your buck (my four dishes cost me $24 and I was suitably full). This is a no-frills place, so don't expect much in terms of service or space, and come early (before 8pm), to avoid a long wait.
author: Shikha K.

description:
The line I often see got me to go. 
The place is kind of fun. It's a tiny hole in the wall, much like places you'd find in Taiwan or Japan. But the food is not good. It's greasy, and poor quality.
The price is a bit cheaper, but the portions are smaller (which I'm into), but it's just not good.
author: Laurie W.

description: Visiting this place reminded me that when you go to a restaurant or a food street place... "It's not all about the food,  it's about the soul." Negative energy is spewing in this place. So much attitude and rudeness.  I think the older lady thinks that people worship her food.
author: Mark M.

description:
Want some grease with that?

So Yamo is cheap.  You've heard it before.  And yes, some things are delicious there.  And it's a whole in the wall but let's be honest - it's a shit hole too.  Thus a 3.  
How the health department hasn't shut this joint down simply proves the City is grossly understaffed and Asian restaurants are grossly overlooked.

House noodles I had the other day were ridiculously greasy.  They're very popular but just be warned if you don't have a strong stomach.   I didn't finish them. The last 25% were so drenched I wanted to gag.  But the garlicky beef was fantastic.  There's the balance I suppose.

Yamo IS as ghetto as it gets.  It's probably much like a dive in Burma except from what I understand from fellow travelers, not all Burmese joints or people are colorful.

Still standing by their $6 mango chicken or tea leaf salad - sometimes you've gotta lower your standards and grub on the good and the cheap and disregard service, cleanliness and get your grease on.   Then do a spin class the next day.
author: Athena S.

description: Not much seating but it's worth the wait. Solid coconut chicken noodle soup. You can watch your food be prepared on natural gas stove.
author: Tiger T.

description:
After reading all the great reviews by fellow yelpers, I was looking forward to an evening of mouthwatering and flavorful deliciousness that would transport me back to my recent trip to Burma.  But what I got was attitude and condescendence.  Even if I looked past that, the place is dingy, I mean unhealthyly dirty.

Against my better judgement, the friend convinced me to try the food as take-out so we ordered the mohinga and green tea salad.  Let me tell you, Chinese it isn't and Burmese it ain't!  Please, do not let what you are having here be the future informant of what Burmese food is supposed to taste like.  It is just disgusting goop that they are disguising as food.  Don't fall for it.  Go elsewhere, anywhere.
author: Quoc V.

description: These foodies are lying. Just because five Chinese grandmas are cooking, I'm suppose bow down to sub par food. Have fun waiting in line to fight for one of three counter seats.
author: Harry V.

description: Don't let the awesome smells wafting out the open door fool you. This place is awful! I ordered chicken curry. My noodles were super mushy, potatoes were over cooked, everything soaking in a pool of oil. Oh and zero curry flavor. Maybe I would have been better off with rice instead of noodles, but then I'd still just have an oily zero flavor dish. How this place has 4 stars is beyond me. So disappointed.
author: Paul R.

description:
OKOK time for a Yamo update. It's still ridiculously cheap but after a couple years, I'm ready to lighten on the criticism. Lunch here was uneventful, perhaps because the female cook didn't have her screaming partner yet. The food is still a fusion of Burmese and Chinese food. 

The TEA LEAF SALAD has nearly the same taste as other places, but from the sight of it I can hardly make out the tea leaf. 

The CHICKEN NOODLE SOUP is delicious with pieces of sauteed chicken thrown into a coconut curry bowl of noodles. 

I can't help it but find myself always going back to ordering the **YAMO HOUSE NOODLES though. It's oily, has clean distinct flavors and just makes me happy every time I get it. I find myself craving these noodles whenever I'm in the vicinity of the restaurant so I couldn't give anything less than 5 stars.

Parking: metered close by and non-meter a small walk away
Wait: none if you go during lunch but be prepared for 30-45 min wait if there is a line
Crowd: hipster
author: Dennis L.

description:
I love this place for a great takeout meal. This little "hole in the wall" serves the most delicious Burmese food. I crave their exotic spices and wish I had the skills to get down in the kitchen like that. It's a family owned restaurant with spunky attitude, be prepared to wait as the matriarch does her thing right in front of your eyes. I've never eaten inside because the place has about 5 counter seats but I do like the atmosphere of the hustle and bustle of the open kitchen. Prices are great. Food is even better. I love me some Mango Chicken. Garlic noodles, fish curry, and potstickers are the bomb too. 

Go to YAMO but call ahead and give me 20 mins, eve. If they say 15. IT IS WORTH IT
author: Destiny P.

description:
The night was headed in a downward spiral after prospective restaurant, after prospective restaurant was either closed or oozing with hr long lines. Mission Chinese was out of the question and on a whim, I looked around the corner. There stood, Yamo.

A hole in the wall of hole in the walls. Only a bar to sit at, which is so close to the make shift kitchen that the sizzling veggies sauteing can block your sight momentarily (slight exaggeration). But that, is completely apart of the ambiance. You FEEL like you are in Burma with these cute, but very stern mix of ladies who are busting their ass to serve some very authentic, delicious food.

The entire menu is delicious and not at all intimidating to the palette. It's quick and easy to choose what to get. Not to mention, basically every entree is only 6$. I recommend sharing a few apps and entrees with a friend or date since the portions aren't overwhelming. What can you expect for only 6$? Their dumplings are splendid and you cannot go wrong with the Mango Chicken.For the flavor and the price, it is extremely hard to complain about this place.

Don't expect to find seating easily for more than 2-3 people and make sure you are in the right line. One line is for diners waiting for seats, and another is for take out if you don't plan on staying. Be vocal and yell out your order. You wont offend.
author: Spencer C.

description: Yamo is HOT and you will leave smelling of grease, but the food is delicious and incredibly well priced. The house noodles with beef are so tasty and my friend really enjoyed his black bean fish. The service leaves something to be desired, but it's worth it.
author: C.K. O.

description:
I love eating here, both because the food hits the spot and I often meet nice people.
Last time I was here, I sat at the counter next to a group of ladies from Burma/Myanmar. Had a very nice conversation with one to my right and she told me that she and her friends come here at least once a month--and they all always get the fish stew. I had never tried it before, so she got a second empty bowl so I could try hers.
It had a very authentic flavor, and though the cold noodle with chicken is my hands-down favorite, I will probably get the fish stew next time I am there.
author: Bitty B.

description:
One of my favorite places to eat... EVER. I would recommend this place to anyone unless you're not down for a lil divey grime. 

This place feels like a legit S/E Asian street food spot and the the food is so tasty you'll find yourself coming 3-4x to satisfy your Yamo's fix. Yeah, you might have to wait awhile, but if you go in the off-hours, you'll find that there's always a spot to sit down. Yeah, the mamas will yell at you if yer actin' a fool, so... Don't do that. 

My staples are the Chicken Noodle Soup, Cold Noodle Chicken, and Tea Salad with a Grass Jelly drink. You'll never have better Burmese food in the states...
author: Fuu C.

description: I love love LOVE this place! Yes it's a little mouse hole, nobody speaks english & you can never get a spot at the counter but the food is AMAZING! Just stand outside, grab your cell and place an order to go. It's just as good on the run. Try the Yamo house noodles with tofu & veggies, spring rolls, and mango salad! Everything is less that $8 bucks, can't go wrong with cheap yummy food....
author: Caye Q.

description:
Tea leaf salad-AMAZING
Yamo House Noodles with Beef- Very soft and yummy noodles but bland.
Mango Chicken- This was okay, kind of bland IMO.


It's definitely the 'soup nazi' type of customer service here, so consider yourself warned.The main lady there (there's only 3) was super rude. I wasn't expecting to be catered to, but I also wasn't expecting to get yelled at! Not worth us coming back at all.
author: Jenn H.

description: Bomb diggity! I spent a lot of time in s.e. asia, and have tried countless noodle shops. This is best spot in s.f. and cheap.
author: Blake S.

description:
One word, and one word only - DELICIOUS!

This was my first but definitely not last experience at Yamo. So it's a hole in the wall restaurant, ya-da-ya-da-ya-da... however their dishes are just bursting with spices and unique flavor. I ordered the cold noodles with a tea salad and it was whipped up in just a matter of minutes! I gave this place only four stars because the service is eh, kinda iffy. Okay, yes I'm aware of different cultural norms - but if this is your first time ordering and the lady is yelling at you for not brining cash, sheesh I would be a bit thrown off.

Regardless, I will be back and just as a suggestion - I wouldn't recommend this as a place to get a quick bite! Every time I've stopped by the line is out the door. On a side note ordering in advance and picking up your order seems like the best way to a) cut interaction with "angry" cooks and b) enjoy your meal in the comfort of your own home.
author: Amy Y.

description:
Hands down best worst kept secret in SF. This place has GREAT food AND entertainment if you're willing to wait...

Almost everything on the menu is $6, and the portions are healthy for that price. I always order the same thing...house noodles with chicken, no cilantro. After being a regular about 5 times--they FINALLY stopped putting cilantro on my noodles! Not a big deal, worth picking it out for a yummy piping hot made to order bowl of noodles, chicken and crunchy garlic. Other favorites include tea leaf salad (you can't get anything like it anywhere else), samosas and egg rolls. 

The women who work the place are all friends and own the place together...they are hard working women who make their living a $6 dish at a time--so if you think they are rude, it's just that they want you to eat and get out so they can turn the seat for another customer! That being said, if you take the time to get to know them during slow times, they are really great and funny! 

Bottom line--this place is worth the wait. If you haven't tried it yet, what are you waiting for? Just be sure you know what you're going to order, or you might get the stink eye.

I think I'd be a little cranky too if I had to put up with the hipster invasion in the mission...just saying. KIDDING...put the apple device down you crazies...no comments necessary.
author: Mariko S.

description:
You can't go wrong with anything on the menu!  The three BADASS Chinese Burmese ladies do not mess around in the kitchen.  I am never disappointed in how much flavor the dishes have and the prices are unbeatable at $6 for an entree dish.

Here are some of my favorites:

- Tea Leaf Salad
- Mango Salad
- Cold Noodles with Chicken
- House Noodles with Beef
- Chicken curry coconut noodle soup

I usually order the any combination of the above dishes every time I go, but I am sure everything on the menu will be delish!

Just an FYI, it is cash only and no alcohol!
author: Sandy L.

description: The prices are amazing, the (vegan) food is ok. Health code 94 seems high for what's going on back there. Probably cleaner than a food cart in Burma and as close as you'll get to the experience in America. Definitely for the adventurous! ;)
author: Elise H.

description:
YAMO = YUMMY!
I absolutely love this place. So simple, cheap, fast and delicious. Their noodles are my Go To's. I love the cold noodles or the house noodles. Their samosas and spring rolls are also munchworthy. I always try to avoid peak times, like lunch or dinner to avoid the line. The ladies in there are hilarious, they are so serious about their craft. Our goal every time is to try to make the lady smile. Its tough, I got her to crack a half smile once!
author: D S.

description: The tea leaf salad is packed with flavor but it doesn't quite overwhelm you. The texture of everything combines quite nicely. The house noodles had a very nice wok flavor to it. Everything was cheap. They make it fresh so there can be a wait.
author: Eve C.

description:
This place is an excellent hole in the wall. In as few words as I can put it: it is bargain exhibition Burmese and it feels so authentic. 

1. You're in for an experience: the kitchen is literally in front of a bar with 8 seats. This is the exhibition: and no this isn't Benihana's. These lady's give a performance that is a bit more eclectically appreciated. You'll have to submit to a fiery attitude to pick up a menu, and don't even think about showing up twenty minutes before they close. They've been slaving in front of a hot grill for hours, and they'll let you know about it.  Just watch one of them yield an enormous machete and hack up a coconut and you won't press the issue.  


2. You won't feel cheated: everything is about $6 and it's good. Of course if you're looking for Burmese cuisine, as in the best ever:  Don't pay $6.
author: Brandon C.

description:
Granny and family's home-cooked meals ? You had me at Granny !

I had been here on two separate occasions and the teeny little joint with barely enough room for 7 bar-stools didn't disappoint. 

Both times I started with the tender coconut water to quench my thirst and cleanse my palate. 

The potstickers initially looked store bought as it was frozen solid when they plonked it down on the pan to steam them but boy, was I wrong once I took a bite and felt the texture of the dough as well as the meat inside. It was definitely way better than any frozen brand and convinced me that it has to be house-made. The only caveat ? The ginger was pretty strong so that took away a bit from the delightful experience. 

The shrimp spring rolls were pretty good but were neither noteworthy nor disappointing. The one dish that disappointed were the obviously 3P (processed packaged products) samosas and I will leave it at that.

The main dishes (or entrees) are, in my opinion, what makes Yamo.

The first visit, I had the shrimp curry with steamed rice. The sauce was creamy and the vegetables served to enhance the whole dish very well. The shrimps were well done and 'bouncy' (as in not overcooked).

On the second visit, I had the Chicken curry with steamed rice. I enjoyed it thoroughly but alas I possess neither the elquence nor the artistry to describe it in a mellifluous poetic form. So just take my word for it ! Alright ??? (so that settles it)

I was told that their house-noodles are fabulous and no prizes (no, not even a discount coupon) for guessing what I'm going to order next time.

Go eat at Yamo ! You will not be disappointed !
author: Umesh T.

description:
I'm not a salad guy at all. I never ate a single salad in my life up until I was 27. Just never was my thing. That said, the tea leaf salad at Yamo was absolutely effing amazing. Definitely the best I've ever had (although I'm admittedly not an expert).

Noodles were awesome too, but damn that salad is crackin and super cheap too. Definitely gonna become one of my regular spots.
author: Tommy P.

description:
i'm surprised by all of the poor/mediocre reviews of this place. maybe it's gone down.  but i use to eat here all the time a few years ago when i lived in the area and loved it. 

my favorite: tea leaf salad. i don't know why this hasn't become as trendy as banh mi...or even cupcakes.

i had a bunch of their noodle dishes and all were super delicious.  my mom agrees that burmese food is very good - and when my tiger mama says something is good, you know it's good.
author: Pauline N.

description:
Yamo is excellent! My friend and I shared one dish, which was a little greasy but that's how I like it. The women who work there are precious beyond belief. They were closing up, and we were the last customers. When we left to wait for the bus they hauled us back inside and made us sit down, gave us water, and doted on us. 

Cheap, awesome, and the food is goddamn delicious. Thanks for taking care of us Yamo 
 I'm coming back the next time I don't feel like another Mission burrito/super nachos.
author: Shanna G.

description:
So, sure, this may not be the place you'd go on a  first date, or where you'd take a fancy client. But this place does belong in the club of restaurants that as seen as stepping off the street and in to, you forget for a moment that you're in San Francisco. 

The tiny place seats about 8 at most, and once you're in, things move quick. The old women that run the place don't mess around making your order and getting right to it. You feel like you're in a family's kitchen, rather than a restaurant's. 

For only 6 bucks (a rarity in this city) you can get just about any heaping bowl of noodles. I went with the chicken curry, and it was delicious. For a few bucks more I recommend ordering the dumplings and loading them up with the various accouterments of spices and relishes offered at every seat. 

Bring cash, sit down, get in, get out, and enjoy the little slice of culture and flavor this place has to offer.
author: Andy H.

description:
Dang it for all the yummy and inexpensive food that they have here.  I really enjoy everything they have on the menu.  Even the strange mis-communication that I have with the staff...it's all good.

Some of the clientele however, are just a little too privileged, precious, and self-entitled for my taste.  

And then, when they talk about Burmese food, as though they are connoisseurs...they talk like they've been to Burma,  have Burmese family, have Burmese friends, as if they could speak the language too (but mispronounce everything),  but really, they're just a little too "precious" and pretentious.

Oh, and another thing, no hipster actually OWNS a seat there, even if they think they do.

Yes, some people are actually starting to acknowledge that "dirty little places" are actually great for food.  lol.
author: angel a.

description: Tried this place since it's right by our house and had great reviews. It has that cool hole in the wall feel, you might experience a little soup naziness and it's a little unorganized, but overall the food was good and cheap, but not amazing. We had the house noodles with chicken, one with pork. I'd definitely recommend giving those a shot.
author: Anna V.

description:
YA (gimme) MO, is nothing short of amazing, and the food is simply fabulous! I ordered just one entree, but could just tell that if I closed my eyes and put my finger on any item on the menu, it would be just as much of a party for the palette. I literally felt like asking other patrons for a taste of their dishes cos it all looked so good.

Many of my reviews tend to be about the service, the interiors, the overall experience and somewhere in there I comment about the food. At YAMO the grub is so fantastic that I find it impossible to stray away.

At 6ft 3in and 210lbs, when Im hungry I can wipe out little convenient stores; but my portion was good enough to leave me satiated. Any other night and I could see myself having had leftovers...and best of all my tab was $5.25!

There is no question that these guys provide THE BEST value of any place in the city. If yelp bestowed upon me the power to hand out medals, YAMO would have received the triple platinum (which in my world would have been the highest achievable honor)

Oh one last thing...if you like spice like me, you can always have the Siracha sauce, or better yet, have the red chilli flakes in oil. It has flavors like none other and is calling me back for more, I think I'm going to have to give in!
author: Vivek N.

description:
Ate: house noodles with beef; curry chicken. 

Both were substandard greasy Chinese food standards. The beef was better than the chicken, which was tough and bland. 

What works for this restaurant: it's CHEAP. And it's an interesting dining experience in the narrow bowling alley. But I wouldn't come here except for the novelty, unless someone can recommend better dishes than the two I had.
author: Mandy H.

description:
Love this place! 

*It's small
*It's smoky 
*It's loud (Mama behind the counter constantly yells)
*It's unfriendly
*You will smell like the food after eating there

But this place a great! I love the food! I keep coming back! 

House Noodles w/ Beef - House Fried Rice - Shrimp Curry are my favorites.

Oh wait I forgot to mention its inexpensive too :)
author: Christina D.

description:
If you have an American palate then you might think  the food is good.

This place appears to be cool because of the long line of 
mostly young new money emo, hipsters that dont know any better.....sorry.

And no disrespect to the owners.

The dishes are small in portion and the food is........lets just say...Asians dont come here if they want good Asian Food, they go to the TL or Richmond neighborhood where its cheaper and a better portion served. If a hole-in-the-wall place is what youre looking for, you can find it in the TL, Richmond, 6th Street and Chinatown.

The price is cheap, and you get what you pay for......a small plate of nothing.

THUMBS DOWN!
author: MacKenzie S.

description:
Yamo is not about frills and customer service. Yamo is about seriously delicious food, as cheap and as fast as possible. Call in a pickup order, or sit at the bar, and your customer service is going to be curt and quick. But the food is effin' delicious.

I would pay any amount of money they asked for some of that tea leaf salad. Their rendition of it is light years above anybody else's in this city.
author: Celeste R.

description: Great hole in the wall place. Food is cheap and awesome. Can be a line sometimes. Get the noodles.
author: Matthew P.

description:
I love hidden gems! Yamo is defintely a hole in the wall and hard to miss - the entire place is smaller than my closet.  Be prepared to wait in line as there are only 5-7 counter seats and it's elbow to elbow.  

The food was fresh, served incredibly fast and so cheap!

I recommend getting take out otherwise expect a wait.
author: Sterling P.

description:
food is good
service is bad, but expected after reading all the reviews 
we ordered take out, they forgot to pack our salad, which is a bummer

If you don't care about service, wanna grab a quick bite of yummy food.  I suggest order and take to go, but count the dishes before you leave :)
author: Vicky Y.

description: The food is pretty good. Nothing amazing. Loaded with MSG. Small portions. Price is good, service sucks. I would suggest going at off times because I don't think this place is worth the wait. I think it's just popular because there's a line. Hipsters and techies love lines. I think there's better Asian food in the neighborhood.
author: Becca S.

description: A pretty decent little Burmese place that serves a hodge podge of Burmese and other food that is a generic swipe through Southeast Asia.  Pretty decent friendly service and showing any interesting in really exploring Burmese food, gets you some smiles and at time dishes which are modified to make them more "authentic".  Personal favorites is the khaosay essentially chicken sauteed in ginger-garlic-shallots and turmeric finished off with coconut milk and topped with noodles.  Chopped peanuts on top and fresh green chilies and life is good...especially on a cold day.  Other dishes are serviceable but among the best dishes is also the tea salad  (when they have it) which is a wonderful mixture of tea leaves and other ingredients that will remind you of the Thai papaya salad.  This sounds strange but really works and worth a shot...at least twice!
author: Sunay P.

description: Truly a hole in the wall. Too smoky though, so I prefer getting dinner to go (try the teal leaf salad) and walk over to Dolores Park just down the street!
author: Omar M.

description:
"House Special Noodle" was great (garlic, pork)
"Curry Beef Noodle" wasn't that good
Pot stickers were really great.
Prices were great.

This place gets mad busy so best to go before you're hungry or during off-peak hours.  Or do a phone order.
author: Eric H.

description:
*5 stars when drunk.

I'm rating the food--you came here to eat, not to park.  So I don't recommend coming in here in a car or in a hurry, but if you want a legit asian streetfood experience in SF, eat here!  Perfect noodles, great crispy home-made tasting eggrolls.  Few things in life are this good for this cheap, so eat here and appreciate it.
author: Sarah M.

description:
I recently went here on an early Saturday evening and we were lucky because we only had to wait maybe 15 minutes. As noted in other reviews this restaurant is about the size of my closet. 

The busy grandmas do a good job turning over the customers but if you don't like sitting in a hot kitchen while you eat this is not the place for you. 

We had two bowls of noodles and water is mandatory to wash down all the greasy goodness. This place is an absolute hole in the wall and you must try it. It was good and worth what we paid. I'll be back.
author: Justin S.

description:
You eat there, you shall eat like a conformist Asian.  Step in, sit down, order, then wolf down all the way - no talking! Just slurp their goopy noodles and chug down the residual broth. That's the whole Yamo experience which made it an exceptional dining canteen!

Ridiculously cheap fares....and would reasonably fill you up without causing a fatal fluctuation on your health.
author: Jesada P.

description:
This place is a tiny hole-in-the-wall that you'll be happy to crawl into.  There's only about 8 seats total so depending on your arrival time, you'll be waiting, but not too long.  These ladies are quick and no muss no fuss about taking your order and getting you in and out.  That said, they're not rush-y, just efficient.  You'll probably have to ask for water and it'll come after your meal does, but suck it up because it's worth it.  The tea leaf salad is a must -- tea leaves, dried shrimp, peanuts, cabbage, beans, tomatoes -- and I also had the mango chicken.  The mango chicken isn't overly sweet, which is good.  The mangos are firm, so maybe their secret is to use under-ripe mangos...kudos to you Burmese ladies, kudos to you.  Also had the fish and bean dish, which has the fish lightly fried in a flavorful batter.  It's a tad greasy, but oh so tasty.  

Dear Burma, I'm sorry your health care and economy sucks, but your food is fantastic!
author: Myra S.

description:
TIP: The seating is basically one bar with 8-10 seats. If it's full, wait right outside. As people finish up, one of the 4 ladies behind the counter will ask you what your order is. Once people leave, you can scoot in and take your spot. Your food will be ready in minutes!

TIP #2: If you need water, just ask for it. The ladies hear you and will give you a cup of water shortly. Don't expect any other service, really! The ladies are probably too busy cooking to notice that you've finished eating, so wave your money at them, they'll check it with your order slip, take your money, and you can free up some space for the next customers. 

Delicious and just the right amount of food. My sister and I, starving at around 8:30pm, waited for 15-20 minutes for spots to open up. The wait can be worse, she said. We ordered the tea salad, mango salad, and house noodles with chicken. They were $6 each. Portions were just right. 

The tea salad was the star of the meal, at least for me! Such interesting flavors, satisfying crunch from fried peas and fried peanuts, spice from chilis and fried garlic. Near the end of the salad, the pieces were too small for me to grab with my chopsticks, so I (shamelessly) picked the plate up and shoveled every last bit into my mouth. 

The mango salad was tangy and refreshing. Again, the melding of flavors and textures--slightly sweet and spicy, smooth mango and crunchy toppings--worked together beautifully. 

The house noodles were a bit bland. The chicken was nicely cooked, but the noodles themselves lacked flavor (and had a pretty good layer of grease). I had to use some chili hot sauce to put some life into it, but it came out steaming and fresh. 

We watched the ladies work their magic, efficiently and elegantly managing 3-4 pots and pans at once. Mesmerizing. It is what it is--bare bones service, delicious satisfying food that comes out fast, an unforgettable and unique experience.
author: A.L. H.

description: The ladies behind the counter are always yelling at each other- it's entertaining in my opinion. The food is good and the price is right. Warning- you will walk out smelling like fried food.
author: E R.

description:
Great tiny, hole-in-the-wall joint that literally can feed only about 8 ppl on the counter. Expect nothing fancy and everything greasy. Eat in if you can, the portions are bigger and can you bring home the scent du oil for free! 

It's pretty hilarious watching 2 ladies cooking fervently to keep up with the madness--they get lots of phone in orders. It's perfect, hits-the-spot food, esp after grabbing early drinks in the Mission. It's a shame it's not open until much later, they'd prolly make a killing!

Can't really say its authentic Burmese food, maybe more so Chinese food with a southeast flair. I always get the cold noodles, which I feel are better than the house noodle that everyone raves about. It's tangy, spicy and very filling. Potstickers were standard, but also good. 

Go ahead and get some today, worry about your arteries another night! Did I mention it's hole in the wall prices?! AWESOME!!

Please stay open later and open another/bigger location!!
author: Ly T.

description:
Love this place so so so much. As others have said, tea leaf salad is great, and I'm a particular fan of House Noodles -- they strike the not overly flavorful but darn good balance I'm always looking for. The tofu is really good and the way they cook it is pretty great.

The ladies who work here are super stank -- when you order from them, they don't really acknowledge that they heard your order or look at you while you're speaking. I've seen people come in for pickup and they don't really understand the system for picking stuff up (because there isn't one), and the ladies have openly mocked them, which is pretty awesome. You just have to trust that they heard you and they'll get your stuff done quickly. And it will definitely be delicious.
author: Justin S.

description:
Dingy hole in the wall spot. No my ideal of cleanliness with grease on the wall since the invention of time. but....

Food is awesome mostly cuz its cheap. Plates are typically under 7 bucks.
 I would advise getting there early and never more than a party of two.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Came back for the fish chowder. Always great.

Ordered my fave samosas as well. Just the way I remember them.

My friend ordered the fried rice (nothing special) and the mango salad (delicious!).

Always wonderful here. Be prepared for yelling in very accented Cantonese. I showed up at 7 pm exactly and there were 5 seats available. At 7:15, there was a line out the door. This was a Tuesday. 

Had the hot tea. Served in a water glass. Green tea available. 

BTW, this is a dry establishment. No booze whatsoever. I know. I was shocked as well. But it's still so tasty and cheap! 2 appetizers and 2 entrees and a tea and it was only $19.75. 

I'd order the entire menu to go. I love it so much.
author: Betty C.

description:
If you don't care about service with a smile and, quite frankly, not a ton of flavor, then come to Yamo. We got there early enough to sit at the counter without having to wait and ordered 3 items:

Tea Leaf Salad - Tons of texture and flavor, but not a large portion. I'd almost order 2 of these. The fried bean and nut variety? Ingenious. 

Chicken Noodle Soup - This isn't Campbell's noodle soup. We almost thought they forgot about our order until I noticed one of ladies placing chicken, red onion, and cilantro into a bowl. Then she opened up a rice cooker and dipped a ladle inside, bringing out the coconut chicken broth with her. Ahh, that was unexpected.

Yamo House Noodle - Alright, the noodles are the star here. I was disappointed by the flavor of the beef (or lack thereof), but the egg noodles tasted fresh and I almost wished there were more doled out for us.

I respect the assembly line happening here - 1 chef who clearly runs the show, with 3 sous chefs diligently taking orders, cutting vegetables, and making sure mama chef has everything she needs. It wouldn't hurt them to smile every 10 minutes or so, but hey, you don't come to Yamo for the service. You come to Yamo for cheap Burmese eats. If they added more flavor, that'd be great, but I guess that's why we have chili sauce.
author: Johanna L.

description:
Drop what you are doing and go eat here.*

Pro-tip: Order the food. I highly recommend all of it.

Pro-tip: push aside all the hipsters blocking the door. They are weak and their frail frames can be snapped without effort. There is limited seating inside and most of the patron's don't deserve it.

Pro-tip: feast of the view of the delicious food being cooked before your eyes by the trio of Rubenesque hotties.

Pro-tip: Cash only.

*If you are holding a baby or vial of infectious viri, please set them down first and drop something else.
author: Nik D.

description:
The food was amazing. Tiny little spot, this is what you call a "hole in the wall" 

You have never experience a hole in the wall until you eat here and see this. Food was excellent, the the three Asian ladies get the job done, the service was as expected, pretty decent, but they were not rude at all. I enjoyed the experience for sure.  

The Salad and the house  noodles with chicken were amazing!
author: Tuan V.

description:
Totally random stop in here and was a nice surprise.

Tiny, narrow restaurant that you can either pick up from or eat at the counter. While tiny, it seems like the seat turnover is fairly quick.

Recommendation - get the house noodles with pork! Super tasty and flavorful. However, we also got the black bean tofu and I was not very impressed with that dish.

Each main dish is $6 and that apparently includes tax - hurray!

P.S. I have the feeling this place is cash only. Lucky for you, you probably need no more than a $10 or a $20 if you feel like a banquet :)
author: Rachel R.

description: Ok food and long line. For a whole in a wall place, food is not particularly impressive. I think people is more going there for the experience of going to a seemingly authentic place. But as asian myself, I honestly don't get why it is so popular...
author: Mengmeng C.

description: The tea leaf salad is super spicy for me - so I gave it to my boyfriend. But it was still really good. I would get the tea leaf salad and the spring rolls.
author: Gina H.

description: After a friend raved about eating really good Burmese food in SF, I looked up the best Burmese joint and ventured out late one night to try it. They were near closing and still had a full house, or rather bar because the place only had about 8 or so seats in total. So we still had to wait what seemed quite a long time. As we took our seat, more people kept coming but the owner wouldn't let them in (this was about 30 min to closing time). Even though I wasn't particularly hungry, I still could finish the tea leaf salad and house noodles because they were pretty tasty, especially the noodles. The curry fish however, was a disappointment, because it tasted nothing like curry. Overall I think it'd be a good place to grab a quick bite or especially take out.
author: Lucy X.

description: I had come back from a South East Asia trip and was already missing asian style cooking. I tried the fish curry over rice. It was like a home cooked meal. No complaints !
author: Cup C.

description:
Got taken here by a bunch of friends after a nice time in Dolores park.
The place is tiny... like 12 seats tiny and we had 5 people with us.... 
So after waiting for probably 15 minutes a bunch of seats opened up and we were seated. 
We were great-ed by a very friendly lady and handed some menus.
I really like the style of this place... so small and busy, it really reminds you of being in Asia at a little family run place. My favorite part of this place has to be the sounds though... food cooking and hissing, people chatting and the cook staff talking to each other all combines into a very special cacophony.

On to the food. The Samosas and tea leaf salad were amazing, best versions of the dishes I've ever had. If I lived anywhere near here I would be a vegetarian because I wouldn't need anything else. The mango chicken was pretty tasty, nothing special really, and the Yamo noodles with beef was really good as well. Also, this place is cheap.. really cheap... I left feeling stuffed like a turkey on thanksgiving for 25 bucks. I love this place and will return whenever I am in the area. 

tip: you know a place is good when it looks like a hole in the wall and there is a line out the door.
author: John S.

description: Yamo cold noodles + tea leaf salad = heaven. Amazing hole in the wall. Fun to come at an off-time and actually get a stool (limited).
author: Kimberly D.

description: Among the overpriced hipster foodie trappings which pervade the mission, Yamo is leading the good fight for quality, authenticity and value. The house noodle beef is one of the best meals I have ever had. I can barely go a single day without it. I take everyone I know here - in short - pure culinary bliss. And it's only $6!
author: brandon f.

description:
OMG get the Coconut Noodle Soup! End of Review!

The other 2 dishes we tried were so so, good but nothing special, but I will for sure be back for the Soup! FYI our other dishes were Beef House Noodles & Spring Rolls

This place is really small, only 8-12 seats counter style, so expect to hang around or get take out. The prices are perfect, cheap as chips, most things on the menu are $6.

Did I mention the soup?!
author: Chris M.

description: I'm a huge fan of Burmese food, and I don't know why this place is rated so well. It was not good. The beef curry had no flavor at all. The samosas didn't seem fresh. The tea leaf salad and house noodles were decent. If you want really good Burmese food, go to Mandalay or Burma Superstar. Not impressed with this place.
author: Cori M.

description:
I'm ecstatic to have found a Burmese hole-in-the-wall restaurant in my neighborhood. It's like a dream come true...AND the awesome ladies who run the place speak Cantonese which is perfect for me so I can chit-chat with them!

I've heard nothing but great things about Yamo so figured it was time to give it a try for dinner one night.
