It's diner-style with an tiny open kitchen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=CWKicY2EvYWZccR0tNePjA) and a narrow counter space as the eating area that seats maybe a max of 10 people so expect to get cozy with your neighbor! Luckily, my friend Audrey L. got there a little earlier and was able to nab 2 seats towards the back. I was starving (and the portions are decent) so here's what we ordered:

spring rolls ($3.50) - 2 gigantic rolls loaded with basil, shrimp, vermicelli, and lettuce with a side of peanut dipping sauce. This wasn't the greatest and kinda bland...I would stick to getting spring rolls at Vietnamese places.

tea leaf salad ($5.25) - This was by far my favorite dish...don't be fooled by its mild appearance because it's spiiiicy! It contains a mixture of tea leaves, cabbage, onion, cilantro, and various fried beans and seeds to provide crunchiness. The combined tangy and spicy flavors ignite on your palate and are oh-so-delicious! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=fbZj28B92VTTWV1jwGrSNA) 

Yamo house noodles with chicken ($5.25) - If you like garlic, you will love this dish. It's pretty much just egg noodles (similar to thick ramen noodles in texture) covered with fried garlic pieces, chicken, and topped with green onions. It's a greasy and simple bowl of food but has that bite from the abundance of garlic. Yum! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=oIhBcY34GoprtwED1BuaNQ)

curry prawns with noodles ($5.25) - We saw the girls next to us order this and it looked so good, we couldn't resist getting it! They ran out of the flat rice noodles (choice of also rice or the egg noodles) so we chose the latter. It is stir-fried with mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers, spices/curry...a well-rounded dish with layers of flavor/heat and textures. The jumbo prawns were cooked and seasoned perfectly too. I give it a big thumbs up! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=aAuG0KHwIMTJFTegFcSjXg)

I want to come back very soon!!
author: Karen Y.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall, that's sorta good! 

Oh and have your money ready!  

Garlic noodles are good

Curry Prawns are decent! 

Good place if you're walking by and need a quick lunch...this is no way a destination or worth making a trip to eat there!!!
author: Yva D.

description:
My kind of place: delicious, cheap and hole in the wall. You are stepping into Burma and forget where you really are. The classic house noodles with beef is divine, truly comfort food and the fact they cook right in front of you, you know it is fresh and good. 

Quick tip: bring cash
author: Johanna P.

description: Amazing food.  Very simple dishes, but perfected executed.  Can't beat the price either (~$6 / dish)
author: Josh F.

description:
Yamo is one of the first places I was recommended to try, since it was nearby and on the cheap side, as unemployment made that a priority. Since then, I try and go whenever I'm in the area on an empty stomach. Talk about consistency!

Tiny spot, basically a long hallway with ~10 counter-seats. I've only been fortunate enough to eat here once, I normally call and order ahead to pick up. I recommend doing the same!

Tasty food. My favorites include the House Noodles with Beef, Mango Chicken, and House Fried Chow Mein with Chicken. Made with fresh ingredients, the simple combinations create light but pleasing flavors. 

The entrees ("Chef Selections") recently went up from $5.25 to $6, but it's still as cheap as it gets for some freshly made, consistently tasty asian dishes in the Mission.
author: Chris G.

description: I had the mango chicken, samosas, and house noodles with beef. I felt like they gave a sparse amount of meat for the two entree dishes, and the beef was slightly burnt. Service was horrible. Although you sit right in front of them, their back is constantly turned away or the workers are just talking to each other. It takes arm waving and constant "excuse me"s to get a response. Disappointed with my experience because I expected more with the reviews this place got.
author: Michelle H.

description:
What a great find in the Mission. 

We're always complaining about not having a "go-to" Chinese restaurant near the house . . . . . and alas, we've found it.

Just happened to be walking by and noticed a line coming out of their doorway. A quick poll of those waiting ALL said that we shouldn't miss this place. 

Spent $20.00 for a full-on feast and got it all to go since the 12 or so counter stools were taken. 

Close enough to Dolores Park to make this THE picnic food stop, and can't wait to actually sit inside Yamo for the full Yamo experience.

For food recommendations the other Yelper reviews are spot on about the deliciousness.
author: Mickey A.

description: The food is nice, somehow relates to Sabah and Sarawak style. I ordered the chicken noodle with coconut milk curry, and I like it a lot. The place only have capacity of max 6 people, so if busy day, just order to take away.
author: Gooi Z.

description: This is the noodles I've been looking for. So tasty and eating in a crowded dingy hole in the wall satisfies my need for an authentic feeling experience. And so cheap too!
author: Melville M.

description: Came to this place for lunch with my girlfriend after looking for a unique place to eat in the city. What a HORRIBLE mistake. Walked in ordered the tea salad( or cabbage slaw because thats all it really was) the house noodles and the curry fish. My girlfriend decided to take a picture of the food in front of us and the owner yelled at us " wat du yu not undestand no piktures!"...... First of all there are no signs posted saying no pictures, secondly, you never warned us a first time. This made the whole experience the worst experience I've ever had in a food establishment.Dont remember if the food was bland because I was angry or because it did not have flavor, a bit of both perhaps. And for that I will never come back to this little Rat hole in the wall ( i wouldn'd be surprised if a colony of rats live their)...
author: chris B.

description:
A place so smokey, that simply sitting at the counter waiting to order makes your eyes water.  Food so greasy and rich that I actually felt my heart stop not once, but twice during my meal.  Little Burmese/Chinese women anywhere between the age of 25 - 60 (seriously, I can never tell with Asian women) that scare the bejesus out of me.  In a word:  heaven.

This place is TINY - I think I counted 10 seats at the counter.  It seemed that most people called their orders in and picked it up, but this place was still uber packed the entire time we were there.  We ordered a plethora of plates, but the standouts were the tea leaf salad (dare I say better than Burma Superstar?), house fried rice, and the house noodles with beef.  And the best part:  all of the dishes were only $6!

If you're looking for good & cheap eats and aren't too concerned about eating healthy, this is your spot.  I'm actually glad that I don't live too close to here as the temptation to eat most of my meals and shorten my life by a few years in the process would be too great.
author: Norm U.

description:
Best cheap eat in the city? Probably!

I would probably pay over $10 for these delicious Burmese noodle. However, YAMO dishes are all $6.

Good to know: This is a hole in the wall. Its loud, small, looks dirty, almost no space to eat inside, but the food is amazing. Simple yet delicious.

If you haven't tried YAMO noodles before, go there today!
author: Boris H.

description:
Tea - Leaf Salad. Small portion  for $6, but i love the crunchies in it. 
Must get.

1st visit, had the house noodles, they were ok. i mean, they use the same type of noodle for everyhitng. 
2nd visit, i remembered seeing these 2girls get the chicken soup and told myself, 'next time, i'm getting that!" ... it was good. mi gusta
author: Miss J.

description:
One of my favorite hole in the walls in the city. The only Asian food that seems to be really cheap these days is Chinese food, but this little joint serves Burmese food at cheap Chinese food prices, averaging at about $3.5-$5.25 a dish. The quality doesn't compare to Burma Superstar's, but you definitely get more than your money's worth here.

Must orders: Yamo House Noodles, Tea Leaf Salad, Mango Chicken, Samosa, anything curry.

JONASAPPROVED!
author: Jonas T.

description:
You won't notice this super small restaurant when you pass by the area. There are no signs, posters, nothing. However, you will be curious why there are always groups of people standing outside by the door. When the curiosity brings you into Yamo, you figure out it really is a tiny restaurant. 

The atmosphere - Open-kitchen divided by a counter which can seat 8 or 9 people, the food is cooked right in front of you. Once all seats are taken, you barely have enough to walk through and place your order. Get your food to go if you don't want to smell like grease or you are too hungry to wait, because Yamo is always packed. 

The prices - Very affordable. Every single dish is under/around 6 bucks. Cash only.

The food - Delicious. The tea leaf salad is a must-have dish, very tasty and yummy. House Noodles with Chicken and Chicken Curry Noodle are other good dishes. I would give 4 stars for the food, but have to take off 1 star due to oily noodles.
author: Chloe B.

description:
yummy...  tea leaf salad delicious, but small portions.   

For 2 people, we had

2 tea leaf salads
Catfish chowder
Mango Chicken Rice
Beef Chow Mein

delicious...  and just $30, tips not incl.
author: Regi K.

description:
House Noodles with Beef all day, everyday.

I've also tried the Curry Fish, which is great (yet not as amazing as the aforementioned dish).

Cheap, cheap, cheap everything!

If you aren't put off by a cramped and hot eating area (one counter that seats about 10), *ahem* a less than spotless cooking area, billowing smoke from a wok, and a healthy amount of grease (hey, I don't eat here everyday), Yamo is for you!  If divey, hole in the wall Burmese is not your deal, go to Mandalay Restaurant on Clement for Burmese.
author: Emille L.

description:
Cheap and cheerful is how i would describe this place.  90% of the time I have to wait for a seat along this miniscule establishment and its slim counter space.  The menu is small but everything I've had is tasty delicious.  I've had the potstickers, tea salad, black bean fish and all the tofu dishses (curry, black bean and mushroom) so far and they've all been good!

Cash only and be prepared to smell like cooking when you leave.
author: Favoloso M.

description:
I vote we change this restaurant's name to "Yummo" because the food here is extremely yummy.  I first tried Yamo a few years ago on a whim and it has become one of my favorite spots in the city. Don't be put off by Yamo's aesthetics, it looks very dingy and is  pretty much the size of a walk-in closet with very limited seating, and yes it is loud. There is usually a wait, but their coconut chicken noodle soup is SO worth waiting for, it tastes like a wonderful oniony yellow curry soup with hints of chilli and of course, creamy coconut. For the price, you really can't beat it. If you aren't in a soupy mood, try the spring rolls or mango chicken. To wash it down, enjoy a glass bottle of Coca-Cola or (my personal favorite) order coconut milk and one of the cooks will chop off the top of a fresh coconut and serve it to you with a straw and spoon. 
One last tip, Yamo is cash only so don't forget to hit the ATM before you go. I usually spend under $20 bucks on a full meal for two here.
author: Heather M.

description:
If I could give a zero star I would.

OMG!!! THis place obviously hasn't been reviewed by the Food and Health department.  It's a nasty hole in the wall made popular by the Mission wanna-be-hippie crowd.  It took 45 mins to get a seat so I was expecting phonomenal food only to be dissapointed by rude service and below par food.  The thing that really did it for me was the woman chopping the carrots behind the counter-  chopping then popping a few in her mouth, scratching her head, handling trash and then going back to chopping all without wearing gloves and/or washing her hands in between each action. Tried it once for the experience but never again!!!!
author: Swati K.

description:
Avoid like the plague!

Ordered $60 worth of food with 2 friends and asked for take-out but then literally 30 seconds later when i noticed there were 3 free seats and NO ONE in line i asked if i could eat there. The women proceeded to yell, scream and wave at me and told us we already said take-out and couldn't change our minds and refused to let us stay and eat there - she hadn't even started making the food yet let alone packaging things we had only just ordered. Then, she proceeded to take other orders of ppl who came after us and sat them down and served them food before even starting to make our food. We waited 30 minutes until finally i asked if we were going to get our food and she yelled at me some more before finally starting to make our food which we got like 45mins maybe even an hr after first entering. Also when she made our food with her bare hands in between handling money (for example making the tea salad with her hands after just handling money) she was also coughing, sneezing and yelling/spitting over our food. The actual food was good, but given the entire experience it's just not worth it. I used to order takeout from here at least once a week for our office i've given these guys so much business and she just pissed away a loyal customer. Will never go here again and recommend anyone looking for a great eat-in experience to steer clear, it's just not worth it!!!
author: aneel r.

description:
Yamo!

Did they misspell yummy or something?

Came here with a couple friends on a food adventure.  Never had Burmese food before so this was a first.  It's on 18th and easy to miss if you don't know what you are looking for.  I took my order to go but I have a feeling I should have stayed (I feel they give you more if you do dine in).  It's really small in there so good luck trying to find a seat.  The women working behind the counter work very fast pace, so make sure you know what you want, they're not too keen on customer service.  The eco-friendly to go boxes are kinda neat and seem very reusable and microwavable, definitely a plus.

My friends and I ordered:

Tea Leaf Salad
House Noodles with Beef
Curry Chicken
Prawn Chicken

Each one ran at 6 dollars a pop so 24 dollars out the door.  My friend made a comment that they probably add tax and tip into their prices for their portion sizes and service...

Orders came in about 10 minutes and we were off.  Decided to go eat at Dolores park and the first thing I noticed was, man these portions seemed a little small.  Oh well time to chow down.  The tea leaf salad was spicy, sweet, crunchy, and tasty.  There was a ton of peanuts in there but a little oily for my taste.

House Noodles with beef was good but again portion seemed kinda small.  It had a nice presentation in my to go box, but still seemed smaller than what I'm used to.  Maybe I'm spoiled by the normal Chinese take out places I go to.  But seriously, this reminded me of an even oilier version of Chinese noodles with beef.  Still good.

The Curries were good, but again really oily.  I was expecting more curry but got more of an oily taste to it.  The meats were okay but  scant, they pack a lot of veggies into it.  Portions seem kinda small but hey, they have to make a living too.

Overall an "Okay".  I might come back if I'm in the area just to try the other things on the menu I didn't try, but won't go out of my way to go here.
author: Jay W.

description:
I don't get it. Don't trust the masses. 

After reading "great" reviews on yelp I figured that Yamo would be be a super safe choice. It was completely the opposite! Like most of the reviewers, Yamo is literally a hole in the wall. We almost drove right past it and either way we had to park far because sf never has parking anywhere anytime. As we waited in line, there were tons of kind people raving about how good Yamo is and how the wait is SOO WORTH IT, they recommended tons of different dishes (which we ordered.) After about 30 min we came in and ordered a variety of noodles, and some type of meat (I don't remember exactly what we ordered.) The women at the counter were quick, unhygienic, and rude. They obviously knew that we were at their disposal so they don't give a sh*t about their customers. The food came out and looked already SUPER GREASY. This is definitely NOT A HEALTH FOOD so dieters, beware. As I first tasted the food it tasted OK, but then the propane flavor started to kick in and I was ready to leave! All the dishes reeked of propane and oil!! 

I agree that Yamo is a budget friendly place at $8-15 a dish, but at least give some REAL FOOD! Overall our bill was $40 for CRAP FOOD. Has Yamo's prices brainwashed the people?! If they were located in San Jose or some other non-overpriced city, they would be out of bushiness. I would personally rather take a trip to costco for a $1.50 hot dog and heck why don't I add an Ice Cream Bar for $1.50! Seriously people there are much better things you can spend your money on! Do not go to Yamo unless your already used to cheap sf "hole in the wall" food.
author: Amanda W.

description:
FOOD
It was AMAZING. I ordered the tea leaf salad and the house noodles with beef. The tea leaf salad had a kick of spiciness (but not too much) and was very unique in a very very good way. The house noodles were typical of Asian pan-fried noodles - greasy, flavorful. I'm definitely a fan of both dishes.

VENUE
It's small. I recommend ordering it over the phone and getting it to go. I came here at 9pm and I still had to wait 15 min for a seat. If you're going for a sit-in dinner, you will probably have to wait since they only have about 11 seats? The location is a bit hidden away and I would've never spotted it if it wasn't for my friend who's been here before.

Would I go again? Definitely.
author: Stacy X.

description:
Flagged forever.  .  .  finally took the dive (pun) -

Y? **** for a DINKY dive-y noodle house? -  Here's Y -

No line out the door at 11:40!  I got the end counter seat facing the fridge. 5 civil service workers were just licking clean their bowls & plates.  [-don't know how Adam counted 12 seats.  I sat at the 7th stool and the last 2 are edge-2-edge around the no-top counter.]  "DINKY" is accurate, Charlton, wherever U R.

Having decided my test Items from the window menu, I ordered in  Cantonese, hearing that dialect of choice among the four women who work the very efficient line. Started with Chicken soup noodles, very like ramen;  then the curried chicken (w/o rice).  Still thinking Chinese, I watched the soup lady  ladle 1.5 c. ofopaque golden soup into the large bowl headed my way.  Still curiously clueless, noticing it was coconut milk, and detecting a hint of lemongrass. . . cilantro, green onions, making for savory and aromatic broth to finish 2-the-drop.  Test item 2 was the curried chicken, on a serving platter, sufficient for 2 - 2.5 persons, the curry  something reminiscent of Singapore, I added hot chili oil paste for heat.  Again that haunting feeling that the cooking style was not Cantonese in the style of our upbringing. . .

Needless -2- say, given a small box, I crammed in the rest of the curried chicken and chunx of potato, drizzling with the remaining coconut broth, my BURMESE treat for high tea!

. . .  $15 worth of food for $12.  [A]
Service FAST EFFICIENT FLAWLESS  A+
Food  UBER FLAVOR PACT FRESH HOT FROM THE WOK   A+
Décor   DINKY but clean eating surfaces  A

Need I say more?
author: Clifford L.

description: Total hole in the wall which is awesome in terms of its uniqueness/ ambiance. The food overall unfortunately is just average though, so unless you like salad may not be worth the long line. The plus is you actually see the chefs making the food as the only seating available is in the kitchen. The tea salad is phenomenal and may be worth the wait!
author: Romita J.

description: Cheap (1 star), delicious (2 stars), and staffed by cackling Burmese ladies (3 stars).  Been going for two years solid, will continue to as long as the magic square of popularity-capacity-quality-price remains (more or less) in the commendably uncorrupted balance it has enjoyed as long as I've been a patron.  If there are lines, they work quickly enough to take care of their people.  When the overall popularity increases (as it continues to), the prices aren't jacked, nor the portions diminished, nor the general feel scrapped for something hipper.  If Godzilla wielded a giant Occam's Razor and set upon the food establishments of San Francisco with wide, scything strokes, shaving away the many overhyped, complicated, effete-elite eat- and drinkeries that absolutely litter this overpriced city, Yamo would emerge unscathed.
author: Danny N.

description:
My coworker told me that this place was a "hole in the wall" but HOLY SHIT, I didn't know she meant literally!

This restaurant only holds 8-10 people (on stools) at a time, and the wait can be pretty long if you come for dinner. Even the wait for take out is long... but wow is it fantastic.

Came here on a Tuesday night at 9pm and still waited 30 minutes. The house noodles are to die for and these women really know how to cook!! LOVE IT LOVE IT LOVE IT. It's also only $6!
author: Stephen N.

description:
First of all this place is not better than Burma Superstar and whoever tells you that is full of shit.  It's basically great street cart food.  Simple, fresh, and great value.

Pros

1.  Food quality - Walking into this place you'd think it'd be crap but to be honest its exceptionally good quality food.  By quality I mean the veggies are fresh and the meat isn't the discarded portions of the animal high class restaurants don't want

2.  Quick - A product of a small amount of seating but you'll be guaranteed to be in an out of that place as soon as you want to be.  You probably won't wait longer than 5 minutes for your food.

Cons

1.  Tight space: Only seating for 10 at best

2.  Hipsters: I hate hipsters.  Too many in SF and they definitely congregate at Yamo as well.  if you want to listen to an annoying conversation from some hipster whose bemoaning the fact that no one will pay him money for doing nothing but picking his nose you'll find it here.
author: Peter C.

description:
I would give 5 stars for the "hole in the wall" atmosphere and the endearing two ladies sweating away in the kitchen area orchestrating five hot skillets and a boiling deep-fryer. 

In terms of food, I absolutely loved the Tea Salad (tea leaves, cabbage, tomato, onion, dried shrimp, and crunchy beans and sesame seeds). The beans were definitely the secret ingredient, adding a nice crunch and nutty flavor to the dish.  However, I think the Yamo House Noodles with Beef is what is making me "EH" about this place.  The beef was nice and tender.  However, the egg noodles were sauteed with not enough garlic and SERIOUSLY a quart of oil. It was SOOOOOOOOOOOOOO FREAKEN greasy. I've made noodles with more yummy garlic and less oil then what was in that bowl.  I felt pretty gross after that.  

It's a great place to go late at night after a few beers and you are HUNGRY...but if you already have a muffin top like me...go with caution. :)
author: Rose J.

description:
How does this place receive such high ratings? It's not bad, but it's not supremely praiseworthy.

The food is just fine. It's nothing special at all, though. I could prepare this stuff at home.

It's only slightly cheap (as in $1 lower). Given portion size, the prices are in line with other similar places, not really cheaper.

Limited seating = long wait to be seated. For Asian street food? Ummm... Ok, if it's such a novelty, wait your heart out.

The staff have character. The place has some character too.
author: David S.

description:
One of the best hole in the walls in the Mission!

When you're a college student want awesome cheap-eats, this is the place go! 
I've been here about 5+ times and love coming back. I take my friends visiting from the East Bay here to eat at. 

What I got:
Great Tea Leaf Salad. Rating: 4.5/5 (Better than Burma Superstar)
Mango Chicken. Rating 3/5
House Noodles. Rating: 4/5
Coconut Drink: Rating 4/5

This place is tiny, there are only about ten seats for the store and you're eating at the bar. Its a great find, and enjoy! =)
author: Erin M.

description: This place is ridiculous.  I called ahead to place my order and was yelled at over the phone but it cracked me up.  The lady was nice but she was yelling to her cooks for another order.  This place always have 10-15 hipsters waiting outside while their meals are being prepared.  So much flavor is put into their dishes that you can't go wrong with whatever you decide to order.  Just be ready to wait and I would take the meal to go.  The bar is all they have as far as space goes and that goes quick.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Hidden around a slightly sketchy part of Mission is a small place with two older Chinese ladies working diligently in a tiny kitchen with very very limited seating. This can only be known as, "Yamo". 

My first time there we waited about 20 minutes until the three of us could get a seat, and the place was tiny! No servers, just two ladies cooking / taking orders / yelling back and forth to each other. If I could say one restaurant is truly legit, it would be this place. I ordered the potstickes (which they told me they didn't have enough for a whole order so I got a potsticker and samosa combo.. AWESOME), and the beef house noodles. Both were amazing.. not too salty and the meat and noodles were cooked perfectly.

The other excellent thing is the price: Menu items range from about $6-8. And remember, this is Mission. Cash only!
author: Jesse Y.

description: Tea leaf salad was delicious. My friends really enjoyed the curry chicken and house noodles with chicken. I'm looking forward to going back and trying other dishes!
author: Himani A.

description: We walked down to check out this little hole in the wall.  Don't expect good service and do expect good food that's inexpensive.  We ordered the tea leaf salad and fish chowder and loved both.   Plan to order to go and eat elsewhere...perhaps Dolores Park, if you don't want to smell like a wok!
author: Cookie D.

description:
Yamo? More like Ya-meh for me. I see why people rate it high. Their dishes at no more than $6 a plate are super cheap so there is the allusion of getting a bigger bang for your buck. However, as soon as you get your food you realize the portion is adjusted to the price. Still a cheap eats joint and I'd still drop in once in a blue moon. But by no means should you go out of your way to check it out, especially considering the line it always has. But if you're on a budget, add this to your list.

The place is super small and may seat as many as ten along a bar in a narrow 3.5' hallway (that's seating and circulation space my friend). The kitchen is just on the other side of the bar, completely open to the diners and filled with three or four ladies shuffling tightly around each other. You see everything you don't want to see... scratching of scalp, nibbling of food, etc.  It reminds me of restaurants you'd find while traveling in some small Asian cities, but you're actually in an the international city of San Francisco. It's like going for an adventure. You will definitely smell like the food you eat if you opt to dine in. yucko!

I kindaaaa like Yamo's food. To be exact, I like one of their foods. The tea leaf salad is more flavorful than when I had it at Burma Superstar and I love it. The crunchy fried beans over chopped up cabbage tossed with tea leaves in that slightly sweet & tangy dressing, and a touch of chili paste is divine. It comes in a much smaller portion than the other dishes. Unfortunately I wasn't crazy about the house noodle with chicken as it was simply a greased up yellow noodle with dry lackluster chicken pieces. There was nothing else on it to give it more interest, texture, err flavor? My friend's vegetarian house noodle looked better with all the colors. Another time I tried the curry prawn and got more greasy noodles. Yah, I've cooked better noodle dishes even when I screwed up.

Give it a try if you must. Worse comes to worse, it's only a few bucks of disappointment.
author: Rina W.

description:
Love this place, House Noodle is mouthwatering especially for the price.
You will not find a more delicious cheap eat place in the city.
author: Victoria S.

description: Yamo gets an extra star for entertainment value. The food here is pretty good. Amazing? No, but it's cheap, fast and pretty tasty - especially the Tea Salad. The experience sets it apart. First, the place is tiny - REALLY tiny. There are about 8 stools and the kitchen. That's it. Second, there doesn't seem to be any ventilation. I felt like I was walking into a wall of grease. (As an aside, don't plan to do anything other than take a shower after you leave here.) Last, but certainly not least, the service is bad in the best way. They're prompt and you better be, too. I felt like I broke a rule when I wasn't ready to order right away. I received a look of death before she walked away, only to come back in about a minute. All of this would send me packing elsewhere, but it's somehow endearing.
author: Brett B.

description: The best hole in the wall place to go! Definitely recommend. The dishes are simple and tastes amazing. The prices are extremely cheap.  If you're looking for a fancy restaurant type of atmosphere, go somewhere else!!! This place is small with some stools at the counter. You'll get to see the action behind the kitchen which is cool. This restaurant has it's own charm.  You'll appreciate the food considering it tastes like a home cooked meal.  The workers are not the friendliest people, but what do you expect? It's a hole in the wall.
author: Koko B.

description:
Holy frikkin cow man. This is like Sam Wo meets Mandalay, and better than the other two. I have never lived so close to a restaurant I love so much. I am going to get take out from this place every frikkin day. Dude - its $5.25 a meal. It's authentic, tasty, basically life-altering.

The space is TINY and there's always a wait. I hastened to enter before, but never will again.

Spring roll: So fresh and made right in front of me w/ a delicious sweet peanut sauce
We had tea leaf salad. MMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM
Chicken noodle soup: comfort food, chock full of noodles, broth is viscous
Mango Chicken: fresh veggies and ripe mango - good quality white meat chicken

I usually say "go", but this time, I'm going to encourage you not to go. I want it all for myself.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Part of it's that I work close by, but I'm at Yamo on a weekly basis and I've become loyal. 

As many have said, I like that it's just a few Asian ladies cooking you meals (like you are in someone's mother's or grandmother's kitchen). I usually go with the fish or vegetable curries, but I see a lot of things served that look tasty. It is comically frustrating that I cannot understand them sometimes, but whatevs. 6 buckaroos for a decently healthy meal wins any day.
author: Kiran U.

description: Best hole-in-the-wall restaurant. If you're lucky you'll get there when it's not too crowded, but the wait is never too long. I had something dank with rice and curry. Delicious.
author: Eliza D.

description:
I love what Yamo is about.. 3 little lady entrepreneur cooking up some grub, they don't care about your experience.. you wait, you eat, you pay, you go.  In a sea of Mexican fare, and "hipster" restaurants Yamo has pretty good home cooked Asian fare.

Best times to go is from 2-6 (after lunch/before dinner). Or order togo.
author: Maggie L.

description:
I'll probably get reamed for this, but...

Yamo isn't exactly yummo, if you know what I mean.

Loved that it was cheap, appreciated the dutiful chefs busting ass in the kitchen, was happy that my friend and I got seats without wait on Friday night,  

BUT

it is definitely not worth the hour plus wait for the meal to come, which tasted no more flavorful than Panda Express.  Burma SuperStar is the only other Burmese restaurant I've been to, but coincidentally I had just gone to the Alameda location last Wednesday, so with less than 48 hours between Burma Superstar and Yamo, I feel justified in making a comparison, and there's no comparison to be made, at all.  The dishes I had at Yamo just did not compare.

And to be useful, don't go to Yamo if you have plans later that night.  My friend and I had RSVP to see some Crazy Cat films, and sitting down at Yamo (a block away from the cinema) more than an hour beforehand, the food wasn't served until the moment the films began.  I shovelled, she took hers to go, but the cinema wouldn't let us in.  It would be miserly to blame Yamo for ruining our evening, so I won't.  Just a note to leave plenty of time (or get takeout).

Bless their hearts, but I'll be getting my tea leaf salad and other Burmese delights only at Burma SS from now on.
author: Joanna M.

description:
Samusas... FREAKING HOT!!!!

This is a spicy place.  The only thing not spice is their house chow mein and mushroom plate.

This place is meant for people who love spicy food and are single.  Not for families.
author: Jinny K.

description: This place is god awful. Truly blown away that it's rated so well. Normally 4 star yelp rated spots are slam dunks for consistency and quality. I've been here twice now and the food straight up didn't taste good. Not even remotely close. I'm not an overly anal reviewer like a lot of people on here. I once rated a restaurant 4 stars after a homeless man smoked crack next to me inside. Yamo sucks. It's cheap and that's about all it's got going for it. Go to Burmese Kitchen if you want bomb, relatively cheap Burmese food.
author: Rik R.

description:
The place was dingy, cramped and smelled like grease but in a good way. It sounds strange, I know.  But it feels like some dark artsy cinematic alleyway hole on the wall. Only if it was raining outside and I entered with a mysterious hat and trench coat. Paired by the bare naked hanging light bulbs, it would have been picture perfect.  

Food was dirt cheap and hits home hard. Went back the very next day just to have another serving of the house noodles because it was THAT good. I even love the bowls they serve the noodles with. Feels just like street food in Asia. 

The ladies who work the kitchen/counter combo are not only amazing cooks but will give you some serious entertainment with their friendly bickering with each other. They are a riot!
author: M C.

description:
The food was decent. The Mango Chicken was really good with snow peas, green bell pepper, mango, chicken, rice. The Mango Chicken was slightly spicy in a good way. The Tea Leaf Salad was perfectly crunchy and savory. Also got the Mango Salad (good, but nothing extraordinary) and the Yamo House noodles (bland, nothing special). Total was $24, $6 each item.

The ladies were very nice and the food came fast. Only downside is that the food was super oily and the place was small and crowded.
author: Lillian W.

description:
ok, YAMO, DON"T change a thing.  

 I now eat tofu black beans chow fun.   I gave up on hoping they will brown rice.

YAMO DOn't change your decor, don't buy fancy furniture.   Stay low prices, low overhead then you maintain your low prices.

The students and other low income folks enjoy your food.   

I don't like seeing all these multi million dollar restaurants popping up.   All I want is good clean food.   That's the best atmosphere around...

When some of these fancy restaurants closes, they have to tear down all their fancy decors for the next restaurant.   Not eco at all.
author: Sunny O.

description:
small place VERY Small, you may have to wait. they can probably seat 10 people at any given time. appears to be run by a group of sisters, cantonese speaking. service was fast, so if you see a line and are deciding whether or not to wait, know that they bring the food quick. 

tea leaf salad was good, everything else was decent as well, but the tea leaf was the highlight.
author: Long C.

description:
While walking towards my comfort food mainstay (Luna Park) in the Mission from where my friend parked her car, we saw a growing line of people standing outside of this truly hole-in-the-wall eatery on 18th Street, just west of Mission. Peered inside and saw no more than about 10 people perched on barstools, savoring the asian fare along the counter.

My friend suggested we try it, and I'm glad I left that decision up to her. She loves trying out new and random places, as there is so much to experience within the city. (I walked back to Luna Park and cancelled my reservation, but told them I'll be back.) After another 15 minutes of waiting in line, it was our turn to take a seat. Given the open kitchen in proximity to the countertop, I sat about four feet from the stove and could feel the radiating heat. I caught a glimpse of quite a bit of what was being dished out to the other patrons from my vantage point. Looking at the menu, practically every entree was under ten bucks. There are so few places that I've been that are under that price point.

Onto the food... quite delicious indeed. We ordered the mango chicken and the house noodles (with beef) along with a samusa appetizer. Besides trying to get a handle of the semi-round shape of the samusa via disposable bamboo chopsticks (by which my friend and I experienced a degree of difficulty of doing such) the curry and potatoes were balanced out by the neither sweet or spicy dipping sauce provided. The mango chicken had kind of a kick to it, balanced out by the other vegetables from within. The house noodles were good, albeit ordinary as it was stir fried with thin, tender slices of beef. All of the food was quite delicious nonetheless... and served with no MSG added, which is awesome for me.

Andrew Jackson would have approved... as the two entrees plus appetizer cost less than one of those bills.

While savoring the delicious life, some dude walked in and asked if he could drink his bottled beer along with his meal. I guess he didn't look up to see that there are several signs above the food preparation area... stating that no alcohol is allowed.

Please take note:
1. This really is a hole in the wall. I'm quite surprised this restaurant can operate in such a small space.
2. You'll smell like asian food afterwards, given less than adequate ventilation, but a lot of love and joy that goes into the food.
3. Sitting next to the door would ordinarily give you some more breathing room, but the stove is right there too, so it really doesn't make much of a difference.
4. CASH ONLY. So don't be that person who after finishing their meal, asks people if they've got some money.
author: Cuong T.

description: My co-worker ordered take out for lunch here so I have no comment on the service or décor. I had the mango salad and samosas. Sumosas were great. The salad was a bit soggy by the time I got it and had very little mango, but the samosas and dipping sauce were spicy and good. Very inexpensive and quick.
author: Amanda L.

description: Amazing prices and even better food. Kinda cramped, and noisy but this is SF, deal with it.
author: Matt H.

description: My kind of place. Small. Family owned. Cheap and delicious. Tea leaf salad and house noodles.
author: Jon E.

description:
Thank goodness I had a friend who showed me the way! 

The first time I came here, I liked it so much, that I had to return twice more that same week -- for take out! 

Nothing fancy, just a counter top, stools, some older Burmese women at the helm and some seriously delicious and cheap eats! 

Some of my favorites are the tea leaf salad, the samosas & the garlic noodles with beef. 

Portions aren't too large (perfect size!), though the pack in a lot of flavor. Pick a few dishes and share them. 

But...get ready to have people giving you the evil eye as they stand outside the door waiting for you to finish eating so they can get their turn! 

Def. recommend!
author: Jennifer H.

description:
It's a cozy set up--a counter then four little ladies behind it, cooking their hearts out.  

Me and my friend walked in to a packed place of about 6 people (it really is a hole in the wall).  We didn't have much time, so I asked how long the wait would be.  She scowled and barked out, "How many!"  After hearing the lady's response, I was left wondering whether I said something wrong, or maybe the lady was just having a bad day. I figured she was stressed, and something was lost in translation, so I just placed our order and watched them cook our food.  The service leaves a lot to be desired, but there's something to be said about seeing the ladies cook your food in front of you.  I bet the other customers would agree.  As a couple left, one of them said, "Thank you!  That was excellent as usual!"  That prompted a grunt from one of the cooking ladies.  

Me and my friend got the Mango chicken, which we thoroughly enjoyed.  Would I go back?  I sure would!!!
author: Kai C.

description:
In this part of Mission, you get sun and cheap eats.  Upon my return to SF after 17 months of being away, I craved for this.  Prices have gone up a little from $5.25 to $6.00, but it is so worth it.  The three ladies that run the place don't smile much but if you are polite and use an icebreaker, you will be one of the lucky few that will get a smile with your meal.  My favorite dish is the pork/beef Yamo noodles.  The chicken is good, but not as flavorful.

Heads up: This place is tiny so call to place your order and take it to go.
author: Mui Anne C.

description:
Came here late at night for dinner, and there was a small line out the door.  It's not too surprising considering that the place can only sit 6-8 ppl, it is literally a hole in the wall!

I ordered the Yamo House noodle and some simosas.  The house noodle tasted just like stir fry to me, no creative or exotic flavors in them.  I also noticed they were a tad on the greasy side.  Simosas were good, nice texture.

Service was slow due to the busy-ness, prices were great, very inexpensive.  Portions tend to be on the small side, though that can depend on how much u can eat.  I'd say try it out once just to say you did.
author: Ben S.

description: Food is good. I recommend the house noodles and mango chicken. Overall the place has cheap tasty food, but don't expect any customer service. The server is fiesty and chewed me out and talked shit about me for not ordering my takeout fast enough.
author: Bryant N.

description:
YAMO = YUMO!!!! (I have an inkling that this has been used already but I can never resist a play on food related words)

As others have mentioned this place offers delicious flavors for a very reasonable price. We ordered: a coconut, samosas, fish chowder, house noodles = $16. AMAZING! I would highly recommend the fish chowder which has delicious flavor but is not too heavy at all. The house noodles with beef has a very subtle garlic flavor that won't have you breathing fire the rest of the day.

Although the place seems pretty small the turnover is relatively reasonable and our party of 2 waited around 15 minutes for a spot. All in all a great experience - I wish I lived closer so I could order take-out but the next time I'm in the area I will definitely be at Yamo, shoulder to shoulder with all the other happy patrons =)
author: Christina L.

description: Wow that's some amazingly good Chicken Noodle Soup.  Especially for only 6 bucks. I bet the other stuff on the menu is good too, but I may never find out, because I'll have a tough time resisting the soup.  Can't quite give it 5 stars because it's pretty divey and the first stool I tried to sit on was broken, but if you're just there for the food: YES.
author: Andrew E.

description: Love those knocking off a star for service.  Yamo is all about getting you a hot mess of deliciousness.  Not time for talk, and who has time anyways when you can't stop eating.  You always get what you ask for and it's always awesome.  No need for flair and fake smiles here, the food is too damn good.
author: Tobin J.

description:
I experienced Yamo for the first time last night and was truly delighted. The atmosphere is great- bar seating only with a max of about 12 people, orders taken and food prepared by 3 cheerful ladies. Perfect authentic/inexpensive dinner with entrees priced at $5.25 and appetizers at $3.25.

I had the chicken curry, tea salad, and dumplings. All were fantastic.

Get you some!
author: adam m.

description:
Everything on the menu is $6.00.  Cash only. Please~ don't come here with a posse of more than 2 and then sit like you have an hour to catch up and look through pictures of their dog/kid/ trip to Europe. The set up when it's busy goes like this.

1. Stand in line
2. Order at the counter while waiting and standing in line.
3. Sit down and promptly served
4. Eat (served water) . Eat (ask for water). Eat. Eat ( ask for some more water).
5. Pay Bill/ Ask for to go boxes
6. Leave. 

Follow this and you'll enjoy a great cheap meal. I would get the mango salad or the tea salad to balance the oil in the food. I don't think I've had Burmese food that's been this heavy. It is a bit greasy, especially the noodles- but the house noodles are really tasty. The beef is so soft and tender ~ it's similar though to beef in Chinese beef chow fun, but more tender and tasty. The curries are more salty, less creamy, but with slight hints of tumeric and curry powder~ don't expect heavy Thai or Indian curry flavors. 

II would definitely go back again and wait in line to try their other dishes and order their house noodles again.
author: Wendy L.

description:
One does not dine at Yamo for the customer service or ambience. But that's okay, I'm not that uptight/high maintenance. 

My friend and I came here on a weekday around 3 PM, parked in the secret cheap parking garage and walked down the charming Cornwall St. We only waited for a couple minutes, squeezed our way over to the counter and hung our items on hooks behind of us. We quickly ordered the tea salad, mango chicken, samusas, along with 2 fresh young coconut drinks. Using two hands, we clunked our coconuts together in light of the delicious meal we were about to devour.

The price is affordable in comparison to the other name Burmese restaurants in SF. I didn't think our food was greasy nor did I think the 3 women "threw" anything at us. I did notice one of the women serving two people next to us who kept asking for things and she kept saying "Yah, yah, yah," and looking annoyed. I thought she knew them, but I don't think she did haha! 

Yamo seems a good fit for singles or duos who are low maintenance, on a budget, are in the neighborhood and there is no wait.
author: Solitaire M.

description:
Yamo- I love the hole in the wall feeling, the authentic culinary experience, the older Asian ladies bickering at each other as they cook, the rice cooker in the corner.  

But, I had the mango chicken & the tea leaf salad.  The salad was good but the chicken was very greasy.  :(
author: Sayaka K.

description:
It's the epitome of "Hole-in-the-Wall" without being literal. Don't expect to find seating at Yamo, and I'd advise waiting outside for your food, because the whole place is basically the kitchen. It's also super duper hot for obvious reasons.
I liked what I got, the pad se ew I think, but I'd want to try something less slimy next time. As some of the other reviewers have pointed out, the women behind the counter are difficult to communicate with.
author: Nik K.

description:
Yamo is the type of place that San Franciscans *would* love. It's a cheap, no frills, hole-in-the-wall joint in the Mission that serves ethnic food. Everything that makes Yelpers go fanboy/girl over an establishment. 

Do I dare admit that I actually (might) believe the hype??

I'll at least admit to believing in Yamo's noodles... They are a perfect texture ("QQ", if you're Asian and know what I'm referring to). I had the chicken noodle soup this weekend, which is the perfect remedy for someone recovering from a cold. Hot, coconut infused broth, with perfectly chewy noodles.... Amazing. 

The tea leaf salad, on the other hand, is disappointing. Compared to Burma Superstar, the salad is bland and contains way too much cabbage. It's a matter of taste, I suppose, as a number of reviews for Yamo rave about the salad. 

Word of advice: If you're a big dude, or a small girl with a huge appetite like myself, I recommend ordering two entrees or at least an appetizer on top of your entree.
author: Elaine C.

description:
Wow, talk about a hole-in-the-wall establishment!  If Yamo doesn't epitomize hole-in-the-wall, I don't know what does.

There are normally 8 counter seats in this very narrow and tiny restaurant.  But sometimes there are 10, because 2 of them are pseudo counter seats right by the doorway.  It's really not a counter for eating, but a counter for ordering takeout.  But when you're hungry for cheap and good Burmese food, sitting anywhere is fine.  Even if it means sitting right in front of the open kitchen, making it much easier for your hair to smell like grease.  But it's all good because that means you have the best seat in the house to watch the chef lady bust out her multi-tasking culinary skills.

There were two older women and one young girl working the night we came here.  The SO and I were delighted to hear them talking to each other in Cantonese, so we bust out our Canto and made friendly conversation with everybody in our native tongue.  While we waited for our food, I just sat and watched in awe at how the three of them dealt with taking orders, cleaning up the counter, wrapping spring rolls, collecting customers' tabs, yelling out dishes to the chef lady, preparing ingredients for the chef lady to cook, packing up to-go orders, and answering the phone.  Even more amazing was that they did it with finesse.

Appetizers are $3.50 each, and all salads, soups, noodle soups, and entrees are $5.25.  The SO and I ordered fish curry with rice, Yamo house noodles with beef, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.  We finished it all, as the portions weren't that big.  Or maybe we're just pigs.  The noodle dishes were great and we especially loved the tasty and tender beef slices that came with the House Noodles.  The food is on the greasy side, but it's real homecookin' you'd find in your Burmese friend's mom's kitchen.
author: Diane L.

description:
Yaaammmmmooooohhhhhhhhh.... my God am I in looooovve. Blame it on my very light piggy bank these days but the fine dining is on hold for now and cheap eats rule the day. So we went and discovered Yamo. Fabulous Burmese food at teeny weeny prices. 

Bare bones, about 10 seats in the place but the 2 women running the show here are rock stars. You watch them making the food right before your eyes, everything fresh as can be. There are about 8 pots simmering on the stove and non-stop action as dishes come together with a beautiful simplicity, though the combination of flavors are anything but simple.

The tea leaf and mango salads are wonderful combinations of crisp and crunchy (if a wee bit salty) and fresh spring rolls and chicken mango are both superb (white meat chicken only - yea!) My new favorite here though is the cold Yamo noodles. It's not cold exactly, more like room-temp noodles topped with crunchy blanched bean sprouts, shredded cabbage and hot cooked chicken. It's topped with those delicious crispy fried shallots and is an incredible dish. As with all Yamo dishes, it's a steal at just over $5 bucks.

Fabulous find.
author: margot b.

description:
In the SF Burmese Bunch, Burma Superstar's the Marcia Brady...all the guys going crazy about BurmaSuperstar! BurmaSuperstar! BurmaSuperstar! Yeah she's pretty and has nice hair, but who wants to compete w/ all the other admirers for obscene waits? Mandalay's the Cindy, with more charm than its more popular sister...but just like that darn lisp, there's something kinda off about it.  Then there's Yamo, like Jan - the overlooked, slightly homely sister. Except Yamo's not as annoying and desperate for attention - apparent from the 150+ reviews on Yelp! 

The quintessential hole-in-the-wall, much of Yamo's charm is in sitting at the counter of no more than 6 people, watching the two women prepare your food right in front of you. The food is cheap and generally pretty good. Their fermented tea leaf salad is nearly indistinguishable from the ones you'll find at BS or Mandalay and appears to be more authentic (compared to some home tea leaf salad mixes I've tried). The taste is entirely another animal - very strong flavors, garlic, spicy, and a more briny fermented taste. It's good, though I have to say I like BS's version the best. In the catfish chowder category, Yamo's version has more oomph than Mandaly's version. Their curry chicken w/ noodles was greasy and pretty unmemorable flavor-wise, save for the chicken being tender. 

Check it out during lunch hour and make sure they're open that day (I think they're closed Mondays). When it comes down to it, Yamo's a good, cheap alternative to its two more illustrious siblings. No, I'm not saying Jan Brady was easy.
author: Steph P.

description: A few chunks of chicken over a bowl of minimally seasoned & greasy raven - not impressed.
author: Sheng W.

description:
Decent; nothing to write home about (I write home about tons of restaurants). 

Went here because the place was cheap (~$6), had good reviews, and was fairly close to my place. The service was about as friendly as a starving honey badger, and the food was average at best. Not sure how they got so many 5-star-ers.

I had the house chow fun with chicken, and my friend had mango chicken (a fairly common Burmese dish). My dish was basically rice noodles with wok oil and some chicken bits. Her dish was white rice with some chicken and oil on the side (having been to Burma, this dish was pretty far off). Not that I'm a total health nut, but if I'm going to eat super fatty foods, they better at least taste good... this is simple stuff here people.
author: Will J.

description:
Excellent Food & SUPER cheap (my boyfriend and I usually eat for about $12-15). It's nothing special and the service is not impressive but those ladies are nice and can cook some awesome Burmese food. 

There is always a line and take out is great if you don't like lines.... also their take-out containers are super reusable (makes great tupperware).
author: Caitlin F.

description: Tiny place hidden in the shadow of Mission Street.  The place holds around 12 guests and the wait can be long.  Order via phone and pick up in you're in a rush.  Most dishes are $6.  The tea leaf salad is my favorite. You must try it.  One of my favorites for cheap eats!
author: Rex C.

description:
This place gets points for being cheap and tasty.  They have an awesome chicken noodle soup with a coconut milk broth and great fried rice.  

If I came here again I would definitely get take out though.  I love watching the four ladies that work here scurry around while talking to my fellow foodies, but sitting in a hot, small restaurant with air thick with grease (and with the world's smallest glasses of water) is not my cup of tea. 

Also, go early to avoid a line and bring cash.
author: Lara O.

description: I love noodles especially Yamo Cold Noodles.  Love great mission eats.
author: Deborah V.

description: "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" is absolutely right! Wait your turn, these Burmese mamas are cooking up a storm in this cozy space! I wonder if their children know how many people in SF admire their moms ... tastes like home cooking for little in the pocket.
author: Andrea M.

description:
This place is definitely over-rated.  Helps that they are small and cheap and located in hipster central.

I got there at 850pm on  Tuesday and waited for about 20 minutes to get seated with my bf.  I got the house noodles with chicken and veggie.  It reminded me of the mongolian station at my dining hall in college.  I wasn't sure if I would be able to digest all of the grease, but so far my stomach has been okay.  We shared the tea leaf salad which was a TINY portion but good.  My bf got the chicken noodle soup that is in a curry like broth, it tasted good.

We both left reeking of stir fly and oil on our skin, in our clothes, and all through our hair. EEEEEK.

This place isn't really burmese food, it's more like chinese with a twist.  There are too many other well priced food places in the city to get caught up on this one.
author: Skye W.

description:
House special noodle with tofu - no broth, garlicky, saucy noodles.  Delicious!
Fish chowder soup with noodle - Good, but not as good as Mandalay.
Tea leaf salad - tossed with cabbage - better then Burma or Mandalay.
Samusas - I like these better then Indian samosas - smaller and in wanton wrappers.

All for $22.
author: Wakako U.

description:
The best way to describe Yamo is to call it Asian comfort food.

No one decides to eat at Yamo for anything fancy or especially fabulous.  That said, for $6 or less for anything on the menu - this place is great.  I usually call in our order on nights where I want something yummy and fast.  

What you should order:
Mango Chicken - with noodles instead of rice.
House Noodles - my husband likes to order them with chicken and pork. They even throw in more noodles for him. :)

I like the women who work here too. They are loud and on a mission to get the food served and they kinda have a strange thing about the water, probably so you just buy a $1 Arizona tea. I don't need excellent customer service or warm fuzzies for $6,  I really just wish I understood what they were saying.
author: Autumn B.

description: l oved the fact lots of people go there and eat a great warm meal. likes moma's meal. its simple and fast. the service itke go ,go,go, i would say its more like a take out then eat in place.
author: B H.

description:
Man I loved YAMO!  till today...

I have been going there for the last 2 years , and I am not sure if place is just going down hill or the cooks have forgotten health rules, but I was blown away by some very disgusting behavior today.

I watched as I stood waiting for my cold noodle with chicken that I phone ordered, as one of the cooks handled money while handling food.  Ten times over this happened as she would take money for to-go orders, then directly put her same un-washed hands directly into the noodle bowl.  It really grossed me out, and I just turned away my food and left. I couldn't believe it.  It really bums me out to take this place off  my list of fav cheap eats in San Francisco.  But i will not be returning after that.  Not too mention I got a handful of greasy change back from her greased noodle hand.  Yuck!

Sorry Yamo,  you have always been 5 stars to me, now your a 1.  I am really bummed!
author: Graham L.

description: Darn it! I wanted to like this place so much! But I didn't. I have my bus back home just outside their place so I thought I could get a Take Out while waiting to the bus and eat at home. I asked the lady in charge how long it would take and she said 10 minutes so with a but 13 min away I went for it. I asked for mango chicken and tea leaf salad. 13$ for both, charged in advance. So I waited and waited and asked if it's ready from time to time. It wasn't, they didn't even started. They might have started 10 minutes later, and 3 minutes before the bus came she said it's 2 minutes ready. It wasn't. I saw the bus passing by and my food was not even in the box. A minute later I got the bag and had to wait 20 more minutes for the next bus. It HAD to be good enough to compensate for this long wait to get home. It wasn't. The tea salad was okay, a bit spicy and very crunchy. Smaller then I expected, and just okay not more. The mango chicken dish was hideous at best. Badly made. And I'm usually forgiving when I'm super hungry so I guess it was extra awful. My cat liked it though. I thought the white rice was the best out of the take out. Not coming back here.
author: Mashav S.

description:
the tea leaf salad is superb, a flavor explosion in your mouth. 
pretty much everything is good here. 
they are fairly heavy handed with oil. 
the samusa is pefectly crispy and the potsticker crust is expertly done.
author: Michael C.

description:
YAMO. means YA i want some MO!  The food is on point! Stir fry never tasted so good. sorry mom. 

I'v never had Burmese food before and boy do they like there food spicy! I love that Burmese food and I have that in common!  

My SF friend took me to this literally hole in the wall. where there's a bar for seating and no where else. Can you say downside :( and expand already! Therefore the minus star. 

I can't remember exactly what we got.  But I know I we got a cold noodle which was bomb and tea leaf salad which was very nutty! mmm! I think we got a yamo noodle? not sure. whatever I ate it and it was delicious! The flavors are not spicy at first, but definitely pack some heat! wooo! Lots of garlic, onions, more yummyiness and peppers and you got Yamo saying you want mo! hahaha ok I'll stop now. 

Love this place!
author: Sunanda P.

description: The selection and price of dishes here cannot be beat. We had the mango chicken, tea leaf salad, house noodle, and another chicken dish all of which were delicious. We definitely left feeling extremely satisfied, and at a good price too!
author: Austin P.

description: A literal hole-in-the-wall with cheap, fresh, fantastic Burmese food served by three energetic little ladies behind the counter. All prices with taxes included too. Love it!
author: Lennart L.

description: Food was excellent, price was cheap but don't let that deter you, I'd send anyone here. Inside was super smokey and hard to breathe in, felt like I was in a damp and dank opium den. Awesome.
author: J L.

description:
This place is excellent... one of the most authentic you can get and you could never tell that by the outside.  I heard about them through an article in the SF Chronicle and decided to give them a try.  Like a lot of Burmese people, the two ladies behind the counter are actually Chinese people who grew up in Burma.  

This tiny hole in the wall can fit up to 10 people and it's all counter seating so you can see them cook your food right in front of you.

To start off, I had samosas and young coconut juice.  The samosas were nice... not too overpowering in the curry flavor or too spicy.  Young coconut juice.... well you can't really control how this will turn out because it depends on the coconut.  

We then continued with some sauteed garlic noodles which were amazing.  Just like how my Burmese mama made them when I was young!  The noodles were soft and full of garlic flavor.

I can't remember the exact name (as you can tell in many of my posts) of the dish but we had a curry beef dish that was also amazing.  It was a burst of sweet and spicy flavor in your mouth.

Tea Leaf salad was just ok.
author: Shannon L.

description:
After hearing a great things about Missions very own burmese treat, I was joyed that I could have some of this delicious fare on the cheap.  

I had Yamo on my second attempt, the first time I opted not to enter cause of the overwhelming crowd formed outside its small gate.  

On the second occasion the place was pretty empty and we are talking a very very small restaurant, to the point of cute, with only about 6 seats on a very small counter.  

But this is where Yamo's charm comes from and the fact that there are a few ladies behind the counter whipping up all the food.  

I ordered to go as there wasn't enough space at the time.  Ordered tea leaf salad, samosas and a few noodle dishes.  They all smelled amazing.  When I got home I was a bit let down, the portions were pretty small and the flavor I was used to from places like Mandalay and Burma Superstar just weren't there.  

While it was WAY cheaper than the Burmese restaurants I am used to, it just wasn't worth cutting the cost in the end but a fun attempt.
author: Andrew Christian C.

description: This place is worth a visit for the experience and inexpensive food, however, prepare to have some pretty greasy food. :-) The place only seats about 8 people and kitchen closes sharply at 9pm so best to get there early to beat the crowd. If you want take out, you don't have to wait in line. The food is prepared right in front of you and served steaming hot.
author: Robin L.

description: Best cheap food in the mission, as long as you can deal with the non-existent personal space and almost horrible service. My mom is Korean so I can deal with the curt-ness.
author: Pamela G.

description: yamo is great, not only the food but the whole experience, its like you travel to another country when your in there. you get to sit at a bar with 8 seats and they cook right in front of you. MANGO CHICKEN is great!! defiantly love this place, enjoy the whole experience
author: Lauryn L.

description:
What an interesting establishment!  

It was like going to a diner, but instead serving Chinese/Burmese food.  The food was pretty tasty, although on a little on the greasy side...but hey, that's restaurant food.  My friends and I shared samusas, the tea salad, and we each got our own entree dish (I got the curry fish with noodles)  Samusas were great, well seasoned with enough kick to give your tongue a tickle.  Tea salad was great too--a lot like the "tea leaf salads" you get at other Burmese restaurants, but this place is a bit more authentic.  Tea leaf salads traditionally are made with cabbage (which this one was)... but at most establishments like Burma Superstar or Pagan, they use romaine lettuce since we Americans eat more romaine than cabbage.  Curry fish was OK, but my friends who got the curry chicken and mango chicken loved theirs.  The curry fish, which had batter around it, wasn't deep-fried, but instead was panfriend, a lot like how my mom cooks it.  I would have preferred it to be deep-fried, that way the fish is a lot crispier. . .so instead, everytime I ate each bite of fish, it was like chewing into something kinda soggy...so that didn't sit too well on my palate, despite the good flavor.

Pricing of this food is really cheap--the appetizers are like $3.25 and entrees are like $5.25.  So you definitely get full way fast at such a low price.

The place is opened by 3 Chinese ladies.  Me being Chinese I couldn't help but listen in on their conversations.  I found their conversations to be quite entertaining!

Since this place only seats about 8-10 people, there is usually a line out ther door.  Last night, when my friends and I went...it was raining, but fortunately when we had gotten in, there were 4 seats for all of us.  There really isn't a "prime time" for eating dinner, since it's pretty crowded during all hours of dinner time.
author: Matthew L.

description:
I used to live right down the street from this place - which meant I could conveniently stop by when the lines for this tiny place were not so long (rarely). Even if you're not so lucky to avoid the lines - it's totally worth the wait. 

The tea salad is by far my favorite and I highly recommend it. The black bean fish is a close second. 

The women who run the place are also really great. Watching their process behind the counter is pretty impressive.
author: Little C.

description:
-Stand in Freezing Cold at 8pm..wait..wait..
-8:30pm sitting at the tip of the booth where I can see everything and I had the most space to stretch out in this tiny place.
-Beef Yamo Special noodles and Samosas ordered, friend ordered cold chicken noodles
-Then the entertainment begins! This is when I was so happy to understand Cantonese, these ladies were HILLARIOUS!! It was like watching a funny youtube show. They were cussing each other out, yelling at each other about how messy each writing is, "I wrote Chicken Chowmein!!, Mushroom?? can you read? I did not write that! You are RETARDED! RETARDED! I can write English better than you, you can't read!" Then she says to the customer, chicken chowmein right?? He said yes, I don't care feed me anything! haha. Then she continued asking me to read the ticket, she insisted it was clear (uh..I just saw scribble and laughed and nodded). Some customer left and shorted them, then she started screaming RETARDED White person! I said $21 not $12 Retarded! Retarded! 
Note to everyone: BRING A Translator and you would have the best time here ever! 
-Ok back to the food, the beef tasted like the beef in beef and broccolli, nothing exciting, but it was tender. The noodles were very tasty but oily, but still good. $6 later I was still hungry, Samosas came out cold in the middle so they had to fry it longer. Happy I got the Samosas they were really good and filled me up just right! 
-Entertainment, and descent cheap food I came out happy but that line was stupid long for ok food. I gave them a extra star for making me crack up.
author: Karen T.

description: Really wanted to like this place but as others have said, it's just cheap and greasy Chinese food delivered in large portions.
author: l c.

description: So amazing! Haters, stay away and go back to your fancy organic gluten free oil free whatever nonsense so you can save the 8 seats for the rest of us!
author: Ashley S.

description: Ahh I loved this place. It reminds me of Taiwan, even though there's no Taiwanese food.. just the hole-in-the-wall ambiance (or lack thereof) and even the fish chowder had that fresh Taiwanese-y smell, if that makes sense. I had the house noodles with pork and garlic and it was delicious. I wasn't too hungry so it was a filling amount, though I can imagine that if I came here starving, I'd want more. Pretty straightforward Asian service. The Asian ladies bitched at these two people who walked in claiming two empty seats and ignored the line. It was glorious.
author: Jacqueline K.

description:
I was excited to try a hole in the wall Burmese restaurant and went with two other friends.  We waited maybe 10 minutes before being seated which wasn't bad at all.  As everyone else mentioned, it's super small, and you can watch all the food being prepared for you which is pretty cool.  But, the food was only ok to me.  I'm vegetarian so we ended up getting:

Tea-leaf salad - this was pretty tasty, but I prefer this dish at other Burmese restaurants
Samusas - actually really good and hot and fresh
Mushroom Tofu - ok, kind of lacking in flavor
Vegetable Curry over noodles - luke warm, but interesting - I appreciated that okra was among the vegetables in the dish.
Coconut Water - awesome, got to eat the coconut meat at the end as well, but not really special to Yamo
Green jelly drink - a canned drink that was ok

But, this place IS dirt cheap.  We got all of that for 25 bucks.  I wouldn't resist if someone wanted to come here for dinner, but I think I'd prefer most of the other Burmese restaurants around town (even if they're further out).
author: Rachana S.

description:
It doesn't get diver than this. Mostly everything on the menu is $6 except for the beverages. It is a tax inclusive, cash only, and no frills place with 3 ladies slaving over and keeping the kitchen in order. They have their system of running the establishment and serving your orders so you will get your food, but you should don't expect the conventional restaurant etiquette. If you keep that in mind, your "dining experience" will go great.

The food is yummmmyy!! I am impressed by the lightness of the dishes, and yet, I felt comforted and satisfied after I ate. The food was flavorful and hearty but without the guilt. We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, Pot Stickers, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, and Fish Chowder Noodle Soup which were perfect for 2. Every dish had its unique flavors and none of dishes tasted what I expected. Even the pot stickers surprised me. Their use of fried broad beans to give the crunchy element is smart and inexpensive which is probably how they keep their cost down. The use of ginger is ingenious to give that spiciness you need, but not the norm of spicy you expect. If you crave for spicier, sriracha and other hot sauce condiments are available, but I would not suggest putting them on until you try a few bites and let the original flavors kick in. Their portion are not for a growing boy so you might want to order doubles if you are super hungry. I want to go back this weekend to try the other dishes.
author: Judy F.

description:
I went here with a group of 6 at the suggestion of one of our friends. We got here at a good time because parking was easy to find and the wait wasn't bad. The 6 of us actually all got to sit next to each other at the very end of the restaurant, very cramped though. Everyone else eating was very cordial about moving around so couples or groups can sit next to each other. I believe my boyfriend and I shared one curry dish and one other chicken dish-- but whatever it was, the food was very oily and I had a stomachache the next day. That's the kind of result you can expect from anywhere with cheap food though. I can see what the allure of this place is for a lot of people, but I'm not eager to return since it's a bit out of the way for food I consider slightly above mediocre. At the end of the day, dining here is a good conversation topic both while dining inside the restaurant (people watching while you wait and people watching while others wait for you to hurry up and finish) and after. The staff is friendly, a bit hard to understand, entertaining and very busy with to-go orders.

I'll definitely need to venture out for better and possibly fresher/healthier Burmese options.
author: Ghia G.

description: Cheap price and delicious food. What more can u ask for! Try the fish chowder it's a feast that will put you to sleep
author: Dafne M.

description:
Yamos is the definition of a hole in the wall. Counter seats only for 8. Five Asian woman barking orders at each other and at you. Small kitchen in the corner, cranking out dishes, food being flipped in a wok. It is quite an operation to see, haha. 

Things move pretty quickly so be prepared to place your order the moment you're seated. We got the tea leaf salad, house noodles with chicken, and curry beef. 

- Tea leaf salad - I would say comparable to other Burmese restaurants in the city. The salad is served in the traditional way without lettuce and full of fried crispy garlic, spice, and peanuts. Very good, I just love the crunch I got from eating it.
- House noodles - decent, not much "sauce" just simply tossed with garlic and sesame oil I think topped with your meat of choice and cilantro.
- Curry beef - served with a side of rice or noodles, you pick. This dish is saucy and had some kick. The meat is surprisingly tender and theres a decent amount of it. 

Overall, good. I'd come back for some late night eating. And with everything only $6/plate it's super affordable! You can get stuffed on less than $10 for sure, spend your remaining change on ice cream down the street at BiRites for dessert!

Note: CASH ONLY.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Love the hole in the wall joints!

You have probably passed by this restaurant many times and never even known its there.  The great thing about this place is that its intimate, delicious and cheap- one of my favorite combos.  You get a bar seat to the kitchen!

We got the Chicken curry noodle and the black bean fish over rice.  I was definitely eyeing other peoples dishes (Curry noodle soup and various friend noodle and tofu dishes) and they all looked delish!  I will totally be back!
author: Nadiyah S.

description:
when you say "hole in the wall", this place is literally, "a hole in the wall". the place is itty bitty w/just a counter space for diners, the kitchen is right behind the counter so you can see and hear everything. with that said, i must say, this hole in the wall is a-mazing!!! the food is delicious! my favorite is the tea leaf salad, it's a must. I dont think anyone has ever tried it before and did NOT like it. I swear, you wont be sorry. 

Everything else is tasty, and for the price you really cant complain. Such a good find.
author: Vi N.

description:
The tea leaf salad should not be missed. Cabbage, bean sprouts, fried garlic, pickled red onions, chili paste, peanuts, cilantro...there's a lot going on, and it all works. It's not a main dish, so be sure to order something else (Simple as they are, I like the samosas. The dipping sauce they come with is fiery and delicious.)

Excepting the superstar tea leaf salad, Yamo's dishes typify standard Chinese comfort food, and that's just fine with me. My problem with Yamo is that its best selections are so small, and not that cheap for what you're getting. I can only come here when I'm just sort of hungry. 

No alcohol, cash only, abundant parking during the lunch hour.
author: Karin H.

description:
------Y---ou gotta be kidding me, this place has like...... 8, maybe 10 seats? 
------A---mused by this joint's hole-in-the wall personality and originality
------M---unching on some delicious tea leaf salad and spicy cold noodles
------O---ut the door with pockets $13 lighter (tip included) AND leftovers
author: Brian L.

description: The food is delicious but the people who work there hate you soooo much. Just called for a pick-up order and when I was done reciting my order, she just hung up on me; despite all of this, I'll be back, again and again.
author: Aaron A.

description:
Eating here is an experience in an of itself. I recommend trying to grab a seat if there's room (I believe there is only 10 seats in the whole place and most people order to-go). 

I had the Vegetable Curry with rice, and it was certainly tasty! It's not a curry dish in the traditional sense but rather a stir-fried veggie plate with a curry sauce. Everything on the menu seems to be prepared in the style of Asian "street food." 

I'm not sure how authentic this is, but I'm glad I gave it a try and I think everyone ought to drop by at least once to experience the unique atmosphere.

That said, I can't say that I will be back soon because unfortunately (and the reason I'm docking one star) the food is VERY salty. Be warned, you might be thirsty for the remainder of the night :P
author: Anthony A.

description:
I'll confirm what everyone else has already said:

- Hole-in-the-wall factor:  High - it seats ~10 people at a counter.
- Dirt factor: Manageable - it's about what you'd expect...  
- Price factor: Low - it's cheap.  Really cheap.
- Flavor factor: Low - not even close.  More Chinese than Burmese.
- Grease factor: High - disappointingly high.
- Cool factor: High - it somehow really *is* hip to eat noodles at a counter!

In summary, it seems like a place to get excited about just because it exists in the first place, everyone else is excited about it, and it's sufficiently different from the other dining options out there.  Beyond that, however, the quality and flavor just isn't there... sorry, hipsters!
author: Laurence W.

description:
I knew this day would come. Yamo finally raised their prices to a whopping $6 for all main dishes. INSANE. Mind blowing.
