After all these years, I still love the surly waitresses, the fact that they always forget to bring you water after you've asked for it 9 million times, the cramped space and of course the grub. When it's cold out I always get the coconut chicken noodle soup, but my new favorite is the house cold noodles with chicken. Oh my god, people. Best under-$10 dish in the city. And their pork potstickers, all gingery and meaty and oily, soak up all your bad thoughts.  Love Yamo forever.
author: Laura M.

description:
I've been wanting to try out this new place for quite a while now and I went there for the first time today with a friend of mine.

It's Wednesday night around 7ish and we had to wait about 15 minutes to get seated for 2 people. Not bad... 

We ordered samusas (kinda like triangle fried mashed potatoes) and man.. it was delicious!! especially with the spicy sweet and sour red sauce... YUMMY!!

We also ordered 3 dishes to share: Yamo's pork house garlic noodle, mango chicken, and curry beef. All of the 3 dishes are amazing even though they are on the greasy side! My favorite one is their house garlic noodle with pork. The pork is so tasty and delicious!

The mango chicken is good but ehhh... it's alrite. It's more on the plain taste side.

THE PRICE IS SO FREAKING AFFORDABLE!

All of the appetizers are $3.25 & all of the main dishes is only $5.75 including ride and/or noodle!

Total paid for our meal is only $21.25 (excluding tips but including one Fanta and one Diet Coke for a buck each!)

I love this place!! I'll be back but this time I think I will just take it to go... I don't want the greasy food smell stuck in my clothes & my hair! LoL!!
author: Reyner T.

description:
Although in general I like Burmese food, the food here was really oily. The place is also really really tiny, and your clothes really come out stinking like the food you just ate. 

For 3 we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, house noodles, chicken curry soup, and curry prawns. Everything was just okay - the portions are what you'd expect (they're definitely not huge), and the food came out one at a time since the three ladies behind the counter were swamped with take-out orders.  I was the most disappointed with the tea leaf salad since I expected it to taste amazing, but what gave it that satisfying crunch was mainly the store-bought fried garlic/shallots.
author: Leily P.

description: I wish I had read the section of "not recommended" reviews, rather than just seeing the 4 star rating here. We went in at 5:30 tonight and ordered the food as take out. I ordered tofu curry with noodles, husband ordered chicken curry with noodles, and we shared samosas. The samosas were over fried, but still had good flavor. My noodles were over cooked and soggy, no texture. The tofu was fine as were the fresh mushroom, onions and green peppers. The sauce was unacceptable. No flavor, just oil, literally no flavor- I'm thinking that some ingredients for the sauce were forgotten- there honestly was no flavor- just a lot of oil. Since I was at home, I drained out the oil, added ponzu sauce and chili paste to attempt to add flavor. I was disappointed because we've walked past a few times and there was always a wait and the cooking aromas lofted in the air. I should add that my husband felt the same about his Chicken curry noodles, but rather than try to add flavor, he just put it in the compost and made a veggie burger instead. I'm just really disappointed.
author: B B.

description: Who knew I could get so excited about mushrooms and tofu? Yes, it's true! I feel like I'm stealing from them because the prices are so low. Please, just expect to be confused about when/how to pick up your order. Then you won't be upset. :)
author: Heidi H.

description:
Luckily for my friend and I we came early before the crowd that creates the super long line. The food here is very good, and the best part CHEAP!

The service is good, but the decor is that of a hole in the wall.

Recommends the tea leaf salad and okra dish
author: Chatree T.

description:
This is quickly becoming one of my favorite lunch spots.

Let's say you're hungry and you're just kind of tired of burritos (hell, it's the Mission) but you want some awesome tasty hearty food.  You kinda have time to sit down but you don't want to plunk down $20 for lunch after it's all said and done.

This is what you've been looking for.

It's literally a hole in the wall but one that serves really good food.  You walk in, sit down and are given a menu and half of a greeting.  Whatever sounds good to you, you order.  That sounds wrong but I've been trying to find something here that I don't wolf down in minutes and have failed miserably.  The mango chicken is awesome as are any of the curries.  The black bean fish is totally not in my usual area but I was almost licking the plate after the last succulent morsel went down my throat.  On cold days, the chicken noodle soup here does the job.

If the great food wasn't enough, probably the prices are the best draw.  With no entree over $6, yet nearly each enough for one, this place is an incredible bargain for quality food.  Even if you're a hungry kid like me and must have two entrees (or just want to try more things on the menu), $12 for a guaranteed stomach fill is still a deal.

The only concern here is the line since this place holds 9-10 diners max but worst case scenario they do takeout which I can't see disappointing anybody.

In fact I'm already planning on having lunch here on Monday, maybe even Tuesday too.  Come say hi.
author: Steven R.

description: All I Can say is "YUMMYLICIOUSNESS". Come with no expectations and simply ENJOY the entire eating experience. My favorite is the YAMO house noodle with beef. It is so addicting!!! I can go for another bowl.  Everything on the menu looks delicious and I'll gonna try them next time.  When it gets crowded there, I just order it to go.
author: Joel Q.

description: Wow. Talk about a hole in the wall. Feel like this is straight out of a movie and there should be someone smoking at the diner with a look of "leave me alone". Good food that is really cheap and fast.
author: Heather R.

description: Great little restaurant, sometimes a bit of a wait but damn good noodles. The chicken and meat is meh but those noodles are the best. You get all your food super cheap and super quick.
author: Rohan D.

description: Poor poor hygiene to the point that I was a little shocked with myself for eating here but I had heard raves about the food being delicious. The women there do not wash hands, I witnessed one put her hand inside a jar of seasoning after scratching herself with that same hand. (after this i still ate here...wow me) However the food was good a bit greasy but I will give them that. Until the next day...today when I was woken up at 6am with food poisoning literally. I have been sick from this all day until late into the afternoon. I do not suggest you go here regardless of the tast unless you are used to eating in 3rd world country type restaurants where the ingredients and hygiene status are questionable.
author: Michelle D.

description:
There are about a total of 8 stools in this place.  You sit at the counter and watch the two ladies cook your food.  There is a very good chance that you will smell like grease afterwards.

The food is amazing cheap.  Everything is 5.25 and 3.50 for the appetizers.  However, portions aren't that huge and the bulk of it are noodles or rice.  I had the curry fish and it was SO GOOD, but very greasy.  The curry is actually spicy!  Make sure you pick the noodles, not the rice!  The mango salad was also amazing, the flavors were just right.  My boyfriend had the mango chicken and that was also really good.  The SAMUSAS are great!!  Very flavorful!  It puts other samusas to shame.  

And.. no tax?!!!
author: Vivian H.

description:
Yamo is great place to go if you want a delicious meal and you are solo. 
The food is consistently great, and it's so affordable. 
I love the chicken soup. 
It's a tiny little whole in the wall but that's what makes it charming.
author: Annie S.

description:
Here's the deal. The food here is pretty good. It's flavorful and fresh. The price is right. But MAN, is this place disorganized! I had to wait for over 45 minutes for a simple noodle dish. There was no rhyme or reason to the way they prepared or served the dishes. People who came in after me were served before me. I kept reminding the woman of my order but she kept forgetting to ask the chef to make it. Some people called in orders and when they showed up to pick them up, the woman at the counter had no idea what they were talking about. If you can tolerate the madness then you might enjoy this place. For me, it was a little too much.

Bottom line:

Food: 3.5 stars 
Service: 0 stars
author: Blond E.

description: All about it! House noodles with pork were fantastic. Tiny hole-in-the-wall with only seating at the bar. Definitely worth a look if you're in the Mission.
author: Clara H.

description:
Not really sure where all the 4 stars are coming from . . . Maybe I hit Yamo on an off night?
The tea leaf salad was bland and came in a ridiculously small portion. The mango salad had crunch but no flavor. The house noodles with garlic and chicken were, for lack of a better word, bland. The beef curry was very good but was served with such a huge portion of white rice that it made the beef practically disappear. The two veggie dishes were essentially the exact same dish and in all fairness had a decent flavor. Now, dinner was fast and super cheap but I would rather pay more and wait longer and be ensured a meal with flavor.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Hole in the wall in a somewhat questionable neighborhood. But the food makes it all worthwhile. Try it!
author: Thomas C K.

description:
Before a night out in the Mission last weekend my friend suggested we try her favorite Burmese place in the city, knowing how much I love tea leaf salad, I agreed.  First off, this place is TINY - we ordered to go, since there were 4 of us and only about 6 stools in the whole place.  I died, it was So good.


Yamo noodles/Beef: We ordered 2 of these.  It was very very good.  I loved the beef, nice little spice to it.

Cold noodle: Neither cold in temperature, nor in spice... But it was DAMN good.  I loved how spicy it was.  I could only take a few bites at a time, but mm I think this was my 2nd favorite dish we had.

Chicken Curry: I liked it.  It reminded me of Chinese or Thai curry, but with a little something different.  I really enjoyed it with the steamed white rice.

Tea Leaf Salad:  Mmmmm.... I LOVE me some tea leaf salad.  This one was just perfectly crunchy and so refreshing to the oilyness that were the noodle dishes.

Overall: YUMM YUMM YUMM - $25 for everything, beat that!  This restaurant definitely got me saying... Burma Superstar, what?
author: Isabella O.

description:
I love Burmese food!

This place is tiny and you sit bar style watching them cook your food right in front of you. Everything on the menu is $6 bucks and under and you get a good amount of food for the price. A friend and I were able to share the Chicken Noodle Soup and the House Fried Chicken with a little left over. I've been meaning to try this place for a while, but every time I would drive by there would be a line out the door. People eat quickly and normally order their food while they wait to get their food right when they sit down. I felt the food was a bit spicier than the other burmese restaurants I've tried, but the food was still really good and flavorful!

knocked down a star when I saw the lady making tea leaf salad with her hands after she was handling money, but no one seemed to mind. THE FOOD IS THAT GOOD!
author: J B.

description:
Yamo's food quality deserves 3 stars, but the experience in itself deserves 4 stars.  

There is always a line at Yamo!  It might be because the hole in the wall that Yamo calls home is comparable in size to a muni car.  And let's be honest, riding muni during rush hour sucks.  You can never get a seat at the bar and you're constantly rubbing shoulders with people to order.  Once you do get your opportunity to order, you better do it correctly or else the intimidating Burmese women might let you have it.  

For starters, I'd recommend hitting up Yamo during non-peak hours.  If you do manage to get a seat at the bar, I'd recommend sitting as far away from the door as possible.  I'd also recommend getting a fresh coconut to sip on while you wait.  

As far as food goes, I'm a huge fan of the Tea Salad, House Fried Chow Mein, and Yamo House Noodles.  Don't expect much from these dishes in terms of size as everything on the menu is only $6.  

I highly recommend Yamo because it is a unique experience.  You probably won't be able to absorb another experience like this one anywhere else in San Francisco. 

*If you're looking to eat and beat the line, call your order in and pick it up 15 minutes later.  It definitely beats the crowd on a cold San Francisco night.
author: Trevor U.

description:
Talk about a hole in the wall. I love it!

Simple Burmese food with clean flavors. Burma superstar overrated. You got to check this place out.

Tea leaf salad was excellent. Sambusas were delicious and on the spicy side. House noodles were very simple but also very delicious. 

The space is very small so get there early if you want to eat in. Otherwise pick a time where it is not so busy.
author: David W.

description:
The tea salad is beauty on your tongue.

The samosas are crispy and delicious.

The house noodles are never greasy, always tasty.

You'll walk out smelling like the kitchen with a big smile on your face.

I want these women to be my Chinese grandmothers.
author: Shawn C.

description: Was rudely told to go away at 9:35 and that the kitchen was closed even tho their hours say they're open til 10. I liked this place, but I won't be coming back.
author: Evan P.

description: The place is small, but the food is like home cooked food. Definitely worth it for its price. This food tasted as good as or even better than more expensive Chinese food restaurants in SF. The only thing is that eating in the place is not that great because of the ventilation and there are not that many options.
author: Charles Z.

description:
The first time I tried Yamo, I had the curry chicken to go. I didn't get what all the hype was about because my co-worker, who loves this place, journeyed all the the way here by Muni to pick up lunch. I thought the curry was disappointing. Maybe because I had not developed a taste for Burmese food yet.

So, I decided to give Yamo a second try. This time, I ordered the Fish chowder soup and the Mango chicken to go.

Again, after the first few bites... not impressed. The flavor and spices seemed odd. But then it started to click. I found myself cramming down all the food. I really enjoyed the spiciness of the mango chicken. Though, the dish was kinda greasy, I liked the flavors and the perfect amount of heat, which gave this dish a nice kick.

The Fish chowder soup was just as good. Unfortunately, I ran out of noodles to go with the soup... But, the soup did go well with a package of ramen the next morning. That was a tasty breakfast.

So, I'd be back for take-out the next time I'm around the Mission. Space is really small... kinda dirty... prices are good.

As Paul Rudd would probably say... If ya mo be in the Mission... ya mo be there.
author: Sam T.

description:
I went there with two of my girlfriends and we were not impressed. May be we didn't order their signsture dishes? We had fish chowder noodle soup and tea salad. 

The flavor of the soup is bland and the soup is not hot. It's warm. I think it's due to the fact that they use rice cooker to make the soup. It's definitely easier for customers to eat and makes the turnover faster. Unfortunately there's nothing memorable about the  noodle soup to us. 

The portion of the tea salad is extremely small. It's definitely tapas size appetizers and it costs $6 or $7. As for the flavor... I have had better. It's not bad but nothing memorable. 

It's a pity cuz this place appears to be one of those hole in the wall type amazing local restaurants for quick and awesome food. However, it is truly not it and the line is long and not worth it.
author: Ricki H.

description: Awesome for a solo diner. The tea salad is whats up! Its delicious and spicy (though yes, small but c'mon it's 6 bucks). Would definitely go again!
author: Ivy M.

description: How did I not know about this place before?!?! It's worth the wait for the small single counter space. The cold noodles were delish! Spicy but once you start to get all the flavors on your pallet...OMG
author: Jessica C.

description:
Count me in as a follower! I totally agree with most reviewers of this place that although the long wait and the lack of seats is off putting for some, the affordable and most importantly, the delicious, Burmese/Chinese food is worth the sacrifice.

I went here after my sister had recommended it. I called ahead and placed an order for the mango chicken and noodles to avoid the lines as I was advised. Located in mecca of hipsters, the Mission District, I drove to Yamo and picked it up and only paid less then $6!!! Went home and indulged myself in dinner and was truly satisfied. The taste of the chicken was tender, not too spicy and the noodles had enough flavor and not greasy at all. In addition to the chicken, I also got vegetable samosas, which were also appetizing but I felt the sauce that accompanied it was a bit too spicy for my taste! Overall, I will be a returning a customer!
author: C M.

description: YAMO provides a classic eating experience and they package for take away also.  The dishes are quite good, though a little bit on the salty and greasy side.  Speed of service varies greatly with the size of the crowd.  For the amount and quality of food the prices are extremely low.  Service is always friendly even though the action can get very hot and hectic.  Alcohol is neither served nor welcome which keeps the focus on the food.
author: Christian M.

description:
I love Yamo!  Literally go there 2-3 times a week.  I might have a problem.

Food is delicious.  The ladies have an amazing taste.  Cheap.  Dinner plate for less tha $6!  Favorite dishes:
-Chicken Curry (followed by beef & fish curries).  The sauce is really good/creamy.  not too spicy just great.
-Chicken Noodle Soup:  Perfect for cold days.  Plenty of food!
-Tea leaf salad & Samosas
-and many more...

Negatives:  only reason it has a 4 stars v. 5 stars is that it's too small.  always packed (esp nights/evenings).  wait is too long to get a table.  service is not so great.  they are nice but too busy to take care of customers.  

Advice:  Just call it in and enjoy...
author: Ivan M.

description: Definitely not a place to bring a date, but DEFINITELY a place to get nomtastic, cheap food. Boyfriend and I came here yesterday and we were in and out the door in 30 minutes; the food comes out quick. We ordered the samusas (these were just OK), black bean fish, and the tea leaf salad (both were pretty delicious). What didn't make sense was why the black bean fish and the tea leaf salad were both $6, but the portion of the salad was WAY smaller.  I'll be back to try some of there other dishes.
author: Cindy A.

description:
Oh meh gawd, 835 reviews?!?  At least mine is near the top. 

So Yamo is one of the diviest placest you can eat, incidentally in The Mission--their sign used to be spray-painted "YAMo" in silver lettering on black.  It's gotten an upgrade since.

The most expensive thing on the menu is about $6.25, I believe.  
Always the same 3 elderly women who look like they'd be my aunties, as I witness them cooking in action--kind of nostalgic in a way.

The place exists of a bar approx. seating 9-10.  Old-school red brick walls and no art whatsoever.  Just a few coathooks hanging by the door. 


Burmese food at its best for cheap.   Take your parents here for a good scare haha.
author: C Q.

description: They never served us our tea leaf salad, although you can bet it was on our bill! I came here specifically for that so it's hard to rate.  The staff behind the counter is no nonsense and borderline rude.  The place is tiny, and they flip people FAST!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Best dive restaurant in the neighborhood.  Just 12 stools at the counter so you focus on ordering / eating / leaving.  House noodles are the best, curry rocks, and you have to try the tea salad at least once.
author: Naomi M.

description: Very good food for the price, but portions have either been cut substantially or they really skimp on takeout. My tea leaf salad barely covered the bottom of the small takeout container.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
It's just about time Yamo will come up in "Hot on Yelp" box.

"Special house noodle with beef and tofu, please."

Alrighty, the aunties will go directly cook the dishes in front of you. Next thing you know, you feel full, satisfied and feel the desire to tip bigger since the food itself cost no more than $6. 

Be prepared not to wear fancy clothes or your expensive shirt will ended up smelly.....in a good way. you can smell that yummy food all day long ! LOL
author: Jazzleen H.

description:
The food was delicious, the prices were so low I almost felt guilty about it, and the service was fast...but my far-and-away favorite part of Yamo was the atmosphere. You walk into the maybe eight-seated narrow bar and feel as if you've stepped into a Burmese train station (not that I've ever been to a Burmese train station). The overhead lights swing inexplicably as if rattled by passing trains; the place is tight-packed with an air of controlled chaos; even the curt Chinese ladies serving us added to the general feel of being pleasantly transported. 

Everything we had was delicious, including the coconut that one of the ladies hacked open for me and my date to sip. We ate ourselves silly and the bill came out to $18 (before tip). 

The one downside to this place is there's almost always a line out the door, but I hope that never changes. I would love for this place to remain one of those timeless San Francisco landmarks into the next century.
author: Risa P.

description:
The only reason this isn't a 5-star rating is that getting in is really inconvenient. Calling ahead for take out is probably a good idea.

The food is awesome. Burma is physically between India and China, and the food has influences from both sides.

While I ate my food, I sat there and watched one of the cooks chop cabbage. Every few cuts, she would stop, inspect the remaining chunk of cabbage, then resume cutting. I have 100% faith that every piece of food going in the pan is high quality -- not going to be any brown pieces of veg or nasty meat bits.

Crazy cheap, too.
author: Tim R.

description:
How awesome is this place. Your typical divey joint, with two screaming women, shouting your order. By the end of your meal you are definitely slightly deaf and also smell like you bathed in some burmese food :)

The only seating option is the bar and you have to wait maybe ~20minutes. But its definitely worth it.

We were four, and sat initially as twosomes separately and then as people got up to leave, we scooted to sit altogether. 

We got the,

tea leaf salad - really good and definitely different from Burma Superstar
Potstickers - didnt try (pork) but I dont think it was that good because they were not wiped out
Curry Shrimp with Noodles
Curry Fish with Noodles
Chicken Yamo - to go
Stir Fry Vegetable with Rice


super cheap and really good food! perfect for a low key evening. Also, vry popular as a "to-go" option. As expected, this is a cash-only joint!
author: Sapna E.

description:
I really enjoyed Yamo.  First Yamo is extremely small and seats only about 10 people.  It is also not a place you should expect fancy-smancy decor.  While it is basic, the food is terrific and tasty at a great value.  

Our group had the Tea Leaf Salad, Cold Chicken Yamo Noodles and the Curry Fish dish.  All were excellent.  The Yamo Noodles were extremely simple in a sauce with a nice kick to it.  The Curry Fish has a textured sweetness that reminded me of French Toast.  While I did not try the Tea Leaf, our friend enjoy the flavor.  

We lucked out and got their early on a holiday weekend Friday.  There is not much room and their can be a long wait.  If you are looking for something different from your Thai or Chinese, you should absolutely try Burmese at Yamo!
author: Matt L.

description:
Mmm, I do love me some Yamo. Literally a hole in the wall, one definitely goes there for the food and the low low prices. I personally also like the divey atmosphere because of the smoky "diner" interior and the super productive ladies getting food orders out like lightening. 

Love all the menu items that I have tried, but the garlic noodles with beef always get me. Greasy, garlic-y, and delish!
author: Lindsay W.

description:
Yamo baby!

Not an ideal place to sit-down and grub. Great for take-out doe!

It's cheap as nails, but you may have to wait in line. Both the house special fried rice and chicken "coconut" noodle soup are bomb.
author: Charles N.

description:
I'm completely infatuated with the tea salad at Burma Superstar, but thought I needed to give Yamo's version a try after seeing all the rave reviews. 

Yes, it's less expensive, but it's also decidedly a smaller portion than Burma Superstar. The cabbage, tomato, onion, dried shrimp, fried beans and nuts were all present, but I couldn't help thinking that the pungent fermented tea flavor that makes this salad so special was missing. 

Love the army of ladies shuffling around the small kitchen and the cramped quarters, but the next time I have a craving for tea salad, I'm heading to Burma Superstar.
author: Lee H.

description:
This place was recommended highly, so I kept trying to go - the lines out the door every time convinced me it was worth the effort. So when I finally found it with virtually no line, I was excited.

The woman who greets you also hands out menus, takes your money, plays with her hair - and prepares the food. Yes, she is touching all the raw ingredients, prepping them for the cook, and touching everything else she can get her hands on. OK, so you know what? Not the end of the world - I'm sure this happens everywhere (health codes notwithstanding). We usually just don't see it, so we think it doesn't happen.

But when I got my noodles home, I almost broke a tooth. Yes, there was something undecipherable in my dish - either a bone fragment, or a stone, or heaven only knows what. But it made the loudest, scariest sound I've ever heard in my mouth. I couldn't figure out what it was, but was thankful my teeth were not damaged.

So if you really like cheap street food, go for it - but just know what you're getting yourself into.
author: judah m.

description: this place is great for some greasy, oily comfort food. prices are pretty reasonable, and the food is tasty -- we got the house noodles with pork and the cold noodles, but all the oil left me feeling sluggish and weighed down afterward. i also have to question the cleanliness of the place/food because i saw the women using their bare hands to handle both food and money with their bare hands and no visible hand washing in between. alas, it is the mission! next time i want to try the soups!
author: Sabrina L.

description:
OMGOMGOMG.OH MY GOSH! LOL. i've been CURIOUS to know what's Yamo is all about. Let met tell you: THE MOST HOLEY IN THE WALL-y I'VE EVER BEEN TO. NO JOKE! I say this in a MOST positive way, because what i got from Yamo is some kind of a humbling experience--one short table that can fit less than 10 people, PLUS you definitely get in line for the goodness (well, it's awesome if you go on a better way--NO LONG LINE!). With tons of gentrified places in the mish, nothing can beat Yamo's goodness. Yamo suffices their hole-y reputation with their food.. i mean, where can you get the UBER CHEAPEST AND YUMMIEST BURMESE/CHINESE food around SF?! My first visit consisted of having Yamo's House Noodles (hot)--garlick-y and noodle-y. :D 

This is definitely the "non $5 burrito" joint..like the burrito joints that have the same price as Yamo's. OH, and please don't FORGET to immerse yourself in Yamo's "fragrance"..if only they sell it! HAHAHA. (shhhhhhh)
author: Marc K.

description:
This is the most awful place I've ever set foot in. I still cannot understand how the health department hasn't shut it down yet. I gave it a chance even though the place is a complete dump and that was a HUGE mistake. Besides the rusty kitchenware, sticky menus, and lack of ventilation, the service was the WORST I've ever seen. The lady taking orders was the RUDEST person I've ever met. Not only did she rush me to order, she kept pushing the check in my face when I didn't even get my food yet and I was eating there. Another guy ordering to go asked if he can eat his food there and she flat out said "NO, it's too late." The poor guy ended up standing outside the restaurant eating his food. Anyways, I sat there with my boyfriend for half an hour watching people that ordered after us get their food first. Few minutes later, I saw that they had just started cooking our food and I was completely fed up. I got up and left. I walked into the place in a very good mood and walked out extremely irritated. I've never felt the need to write a bad review about any restaurant before (even though I have had bad experiences), UNTIL NOW.

DO NOT EAT HERE! IT IS COMPLETELY DISGUSTING, THE SERVICE IS TERRIBLE AND THE FOOD DOES NOT LOOK GOOD AT ALL.
author: Karen C.

description: Seriously... this place... nothing special. Never understand the good reviews. Probably because it's cheap that's why people loves it. The place is dirty, stuffy and so small that you have to wait outside for your orders. The food was typical chinese food you can get in any restaurant. The ladies working in there are rude, never smile and indifferent.
author: Wesley W.

description: Great food here. Heads up, if you plan on eating here there may be a wait. The place can only seat a total of 9 people, so beware of a line. I suggest calling ahead and order to go. Aside from that, the food is cheap and super delicious! Go here!
author: Tom T.

description:
We sat so close to the cook that this was more like a food class in Burmese cooking. She was totally cool, explaining what she was putting into the dishes, what the different exotic ingredients were, how it was her mom's recipe and the waitress was her aunt, etc etc.

All you need to know is the food is great, the prices are cheap and the people are cool. Highly recommended for the adventurous.
author: Bart C.

description:
Fast food ,great ,tasty yummy $6 small portion tea leaf salad. I just use it as a condiment and hype up the flavors of my dish. I love Yamo and I think I crave it maybe at least 1 every 2 weeks for sure. 
Wait can be long or short just depending on luck. Support the hard working girls there. Love you Yamo..
author: Lia N.

description:
Definitely get take out, definitely do not hazard to eat in because you will be waiting for an hour for one of the eight seats inside.  It's a bit befuddling going there for the first time . . . people walking in, people going out . . did those bitches just cut in front of us and take our seats . . . no, no, I think they're just getting take out. . . no, they're sitting down! . . what the hell is going on here.  You get the idea.

Anyway . . . after enduring starvation and confusion during the hour long wait, the cheapness of the food, in and of itself, is enough to excite and revive.  $14 for two dishes and an appetizer?  It really can't possibly get any better than that.  Although the mango chicken might not have been the way to go.  The noodles are pretty necessary though.

The other positive about Yamo?  The neighborhood!  As we were walking down the street from the restaurant, we got screamed at by a homeless derelict, "You fuckin phony hos!"  A truly unforgettable experience.
author: Jenny R.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall with delicious house noodles. The house fried rice and chicken curry are also good, but House Noodles with Chicken is a winner. I'd eat this every day of the week if I didn't live so far away. Service is reasonably paced, not exactly fast food, but not like a full sit-down meal either. Very reasonably priced. 

If you're going to eat there: Don't bring in a huge bag or anything, and don't bring a large group. The counter seats 9 (maybe 10?), first come, first serve. 

If you're going to carry out: Be prepared to order it in person (not once did I hear a phone ring) and wait for it on the street because there's really no space behind the people on stools at the counter.
author: Gina E.

description: I've been going to this place for about 3 years. Overall, the food is tasty. My favorite is the Chicken Noodle Soup. The prices are great!
author: Janet R.

description:
OMG, love this place. Ever since I came here on a date over a year ago, I can't get enough. FYI - it doesn't really have an intimate date feel, as you're sharing bar seating with 10 other customers over the counter that the awesome ladies are cooking at. However, it's one of my favorite hole-in-the-wall finds.

You gotta try the Chicken Noodle Soup. It's so freakin' delicious. It has a coconut curry broth with noodles, chicken, and some veg toppings. I usually only order this because it fills me up and I can't seem to get myself to order anything else. However, I have also tried the Mango Chicken, Curry Beef, and House Noodles once....still delicious, but I gotta have that soup! Also did I mention all of the entrees are just $6? Can't beat that price.

Great tip - order on the phone and pick it up to avoid the line out the door, and have a picnic in Dolores Park!
author: Vanessa P.

description:
This is a great little hole in the wall. The space itself is tiny, and your food is literally cooked in front of you. The food is great and the service is no-nonsense, but that doesn't mean they are unfriendly, they are just busy. Your best bet is to call in ahead of time and order take out if you don't want to wait for a seat. Also - since the place is so teeny tiny, the ventilation is quite poor, so take out may be your best option in that respect as well.  

Reasonable prices and I have no complaints about the food. Their portions are a little on the small side, but you can't expect more than what they give you for the price you are paying. Their menu is not huge, but what they offer, they do well. I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu and they were all great. All of their noodle dishes are excellent. 

This is a Mission gem - it encompasses everything I love about San Francisco: Tiny little hole-in-the-wall places with yummy but dirt-cheap food.
author: Joy L.

description:
What is the big deal about this place??? We waited in line for 15-20 minutes just for run-of-the-mill Chinese food?! AND EVERYONE ELSE DOES TOO?!

With exception to the tea leaf salad, which was super small, there is nothing to rave about at Yamo unless you enjoy fair-priced greasy Chinese food. Meh!

I'm not sure what designates this place to be "BURMESE" but I'm guessing it has something to do with all the curry stir-fry dishes they offer. Nothing struck me as being awesome, but I can't really complain THAT much because each dish is around $5-6 - priced like any reasonable Chinese establishment. 

I guess alot of people dine here because it's the only decent Chinese food in the area, if even that (because it's greasier than most) + CHEAP PRICES.

If you have to go, I'd say get the House Noodles. It was the only memorable thing - noodles with lots of garlic, some sweet soy. Everything else tasted the same as any other Chinese joint and wasn't  anything to rave about.
author: Charles L.

description:
While in San Francisco (visiting from Orlando) I decided to try this place out after discovering about it on Yelp.

This is defiantly one of those places you probably wouldn't stop in and eat at if you are just walking or driving by... but the line leading out of the door and down the street during the lunch time rush would convince you otherwise.

On this particular day it seems like they had one person working on carry out orders and 1 or 2 of them working on sit down orders, so they seemed to be moving people through as fast as they could.

There is roughly about 8 seats at a bar to sit and eat at, so expect to wait or carry out if you're in a hurry.  My friend and I managed to get some seats.  The staff are really nice; they move pretty fast without necessarily leaving you with the feeling that you're being rushed.

I got the house noodles with beef.  I absolutely despise cilantro... which apparently the houe noodles contains, but that aside, the food was amazing and at ~$6 in San Francisco, out right a miracle.  My friend ordered the Tea Salad and I tried a little bit, it was a nice blend of crunchy and spicy nom noms!

I would say the only negative thing about this place is the lack of proper ventilation.  As noted in some other reviews, if you sit to eat, you will come out smelling like the food.
author: Brian H.

description:
529 reviews, talk about redundant. 

Yamo is the quintessential SF/foodie dining experience. Small musty restaurant that serves tasty and unique flavors for $5. The obvious go to dish is the tea leaf salad, duh.

I fell in love with tea leaf salad a few months ago. I come back to see him as often as I can.  But, before I commit to the best salad ever, I tried the Mango salad. Equally delicious, but doesn't slap you with the smokey, garlicyy, and nutty flavors tea leaf has going on. Mango salad is refreshing with a zing of spice. Mango salad is my go to back up. ha. 

I was reluctant to order the warm noodle dish with beef. I thought it would taste like any other asian noodle dish. I was wrong. It had an interesting kick. Supposedly they don't add MSG, but whatever seasoning is in that noodle dish is worth it! Everything on the menu is worth $5 and more!

If you don't like making new friends, too bad, you're basically holding hands with the person next to you. 

YUMO!
author: Mariele A.

description:
What a weak excuse for Burmese food. 

As a Chinese/Burmese American foodie, I  find it incredibly hard to satiate my hunger for authentic and delicious Burmese food. I've tried numerous Burmese Restaurants throughout the Bay Area (including Burma Superstar and Mandalay), but none have been as bad as this place. The food is okay, but the rude service is totally unacceptable. Do yourself a favor and head to Burmese Kitchen on Larkin Street instead. 

Mediocre food + HORRIBLE/RUDE Service  = Recipe for Disaster.
author: Ryan L.

description: Tea salad and Chow Fun with Chicken were AmAzing!
author: Manu M.

description:
my girlfriend took me to what she was claimed was the best hole-in-the-wall place in san francisco. she was right. the old lady working there is so cute and friendly. sits about 12 people, but it's worth it. the food is absolutely delicious and you absolutely get what you pay for. 

if you get clastrophobic or have a hard time understanding burmese accents, you should probably just order to go.
author: Ted S.

description:
I see how my friend has this as her first and last meal to eat while visiting SF. 

We had a delicious lunch around 11ish on a weekday with a less then 10-minute wait. Its connotation to a modern-day Burmese diner was the feeling upon entry. I can't recall the last time I ate Asian food on a bar stool at a restaurant. Well then again, this is not your typically restaurant. The paw jais here work at a nice and moderate pace. Never too stressed and nicer when you speak to them in Cantonese (I had to throw it down)!

The noodles with beef were very simplistic in flavor and the portion size just right. The tea leaf salad was good as well (there may be some MSG) with the fried, crispy shards of garlic sprinkled throughout.

Chug all items on menu with a refreshing Coke. Repeat.

BEST ADVICE: We brought a backpack with a plastic bag inside to bag our coats. Otherwise you will reek of Yamo all day long!
author: clb k.

description:
It didn't take long for me to fall in love with this place. Sure, if you want a traditional dining experience stay far, far away, but this place has tasty food, good prices, and character like no other.

Yamo's a tiny place with only about 7 bar stools in the entire place. It was cold and rainy when I went and they left the door open the entire time. They don't really believe in frivolities like serving the appetizer before the main course, either. 

Nevertheless, the noodle dishes here are really good and I do think Yamo is so stubbornly what it is that it exudes charm. It's the sort of place you'll love to take people that haven't been before, and not just because it's hip. It's because it's a fun experience.
author: Ty B.

description: This place is one of my favorites! Try the tea leaf salad, house noodles, and mango chicken. Probably the best tea leaf salad in all of San Francisco, IMHO. The ladies who run it are pretty awesome as well, they're all business. I once ordered something like 5 tea leaf salads to pick up for friends, and when I showed up at the restaurant, the ladies made fun of me for ordering so many. It's fantastic. I do think it's better to order food for pickup, since the location is kind of small and smokey. But eating there can be fun too if you have 2 or 3 people. Definitely check it out.
author: Justin P.

description:
A HOLE IN THE WALL. Really...A little bit about this place: serves no more than 10-11 people at a time(really small), a bit darkly lit, chef cooks in front of you, and waitresses bustling left and right in front of you. It felt like watching a show in front of you but with really employees at a restaurant. 

About the food.... it's a mix of Chinese and Burmese. I really think so just because the some of the noodle and curry dishes they have there reminds me of some Chinese dishes I've had before elsewhere. 

MY RECOMMENDATION: tea leaf salad- for $5, not bad....i could probably just come here for the tea leaf salad itself either for lunch or for dinner and I'd be good off of it.
author: Eudora Z.

description:
Blink and you will miss it. 

Not sure about the meat options but the veg noodles are to die for. Something like $5 gets you a massive plate. I had some kind of veg/shrimp rice dish and it was OK. Not as good as the noodles.

Overall a really fun hole in the wall dining experience.
author: Hilarie S.

description:
What I learned from reading reviews about Yamo:

Some Yelpers don't know Burmese food from Chinese food.
Some Yelpers think gritty, urban eateries can only rate an "eww!"
Some Yelpers are adverse to eating in restaurants that have garbage cans. Garbage cans! Oh, the frickin' humanity!

What I learned from eating at Yamo:

The Chicken Noodle Soup broth is sublime, like some sort of magical elixir that bathes you in warm sunshine and happiness and love. It's creamy, unlike pho broth, spicy and just a tad sweet--coconut milk, no doubt. The noodles and chicken are plentiful. Eat them, yes. But dare not forget the soup spoon so you can slurp up that broth. Over and over and over again.

Next up: Beef Curry. I've had plenty of asian curries over the years, one of my comfort foods. This one was very good and on par with any others I've sampled. I liked the spicy kick it had, tempered by warm scoops of white rice.

We also ordered the Mango Salad, House Vegetables and House Noodles w/Chicken. All tasty(the dressing on the salad is lovely,) all fresh and all absolutely filling. 

With drinks, our bill was just over $31. When they say more bang for your buck, they're speaking of Yamo.

What YOU'LL learn when arriving at Yamo:

It's tiny--a restaurant built into a hallway. And you'll most likely stand in line with others outside the door, waiting for one of the eight barstools to be vacated. You could order to go but why not stay and enjoy the dingy sidewalks, loud cars and fresh-faced city-dwellers passing by. Participate in real urban living. Stand in line. Meet your fellow San Franciscans. Make new friends. 

Just watch out for the garbage can!
author: Jefferson L.

description:
On the last night of my first visit to San Francisco (first of many I hope) a friend I was visiting suggested several dinner options. Because I'm indecisive, I had someone else do the picking. I'd never had Burmese so I had no idea what to expect, but it was AWESOME. 

We did wait outside (maybe 10-15 minutes) but it was worth the wait. The counter seating was a little cramped but okay. We split tofu in black bean sauce and rice noodles with tofu, both plates, which were huge portions were $5.25. Food was ready super quick and service was friendly, though I did have to ask for water refill. I will definitely be back on future SF trips. 

My only regret is not trying the mango salad.
author: S R.

description:
Hole-in-the-wall Burmese, maybe 10 seats along a counter overlooking the kitchen, can get pretty toasty in here.  House Noodles, chicken with fried garlic, yum! Two dishes, total $10.50. Can't beat the price, food is made right in front of you and it hits the spot. 

Minus 1 star for the people who linger at the counter after they eat to chat... there are people waiting outside, get a move on! The counter staff should just yell at them to leave, it would add to the ambience.  If I lived in the area, I would be ordering out all the time and save myself the wait.
author: Ai S.

description:
As far as cheap hole-in-the-walls go, you can't do much better than Yamo.  For $5.25, you can get a wide range of dishes that taste better than you'd expect and are much fresher than you'd generally get at oily hole in the walls.  The menu is not as interesting as other Burmese restaurants, but the traditional options are very good for the price.  The tea leaf salad is very tasty, though not comparable to Burma Superstar's or Green Elephant Gourmet's.  The  black bean tofu has a very tasty sauce and great tofu, though not much black bean taste.  My taste of the chicken mango was also better than expected, especially since this dish is usually too simple with low-quality chicken.  Nothing tastes terribly unique, but it all tastes better than similar dishes.

There are about ten counter seats, so its not great for large groups.
author: Tom W.

description: I used to love this place and was introduced by a close friend of mine, but was not that impressed with this visit: some of the dishes I ordered and I'm wondering if it is because I ordered to go or I just ordered different dishes in the past. I ordered the Tea leaf Salad, Yamo House noodles, the Yamo Cold Noodles, and the fish chowder noodle soup.  The Tea leaf salad was nice and spicy, make sure you have water to help with the spiciness.  My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.  I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.  I called ahead for my order and they said done in 15 minutes, by the time I got there the food was ready for me to pick up.  The have maybe 6-10 bar stools to sit and watch them cook,  and there is only 2 or 3 ladies working behind the small cooking area.  it is hard to get in so you usually will see people waiting outside the door to pick up their order or waiting for an open seat.  Cant beat the prices of their dishes though.
author: Lily L.

description: House noodles were awesome.
author: Michael E.

description: Really average food, with super bitchy service.  The worst part is that my girlfriends hair still smells like this nasty place.
author: California B.

description:
this place is is the quintessential hole in the wall with outstanding food. It's tiny... as in it seats about 10 people. You literally will stand outside during someone's entire meal, waiting for their seat. This is the only reason I'm not giving the place 5 stars. Granted, their entire restaurant is tiny, so they make do with what they have. They do have food to go, and will take your order ahead of people waiting for tables if you're on the move.

As for food, I'll start with appetizers. Tried the pot stickers, lots of flavor, perfectly cooked. not too crispy, not soggy. The spring rolls are large. you get two large ones with a nice peanut sauce. They're quite refreshing! The Samusas were awesome. Tons of flavor, they're taking taters to the max here. Try popping them with your chopstick to vent. mine were hot, and you won't want to burn your tongue and miss the flavor bonanza coming later. 

Chef selections: I tried the mango chicken and the beef curry with noodles. Quite different dishes, both were fantastic. The beef in my dish almost tasted as though it were marinated in marsala, I'm not sure if they did or not, but it was subtle and a really great flavor to compliment the rest of the dish. The curry was fairly light in quantity compared to other curries I've had, but this was a good thing. No one flavor dominated, it just tasted like a recipe that has been perfected over a long time. One of the other guys eating there said it best: you're about to have the sort of meal your grandmother would cook for you. The mango chicken was very refreshing. The mango pieces actually made me laugh out loud - they were that good. I'm not sure if they marinate those too, but wow. Something about the combo of mango and the lightly seasoned chicken, it was a great dish. 

Now for the best parts: PRICE. four of us ate appetizers and main dishes for $26. whaaaaat? yeah 26 bucks. granted two girls shared one dish, but seriously. It's almost not even fair. They got a big tip. And now for you more adventurous types - there is a powerful dishwasher under the far end of the bar seating. It was running during my meal and it shakes your seat like a washer/dryer. You haven't lived until you have Yamo curry on a washing machine.
author: Adam F.

description:
Brought my parents here on their trip to San Francisco. It was the highlight of the trip! From the stepdad:

"Yamo is Whamo! If you don't mind being pestered by the vagrants, bums, drunks and lunatics of the Mission District, Yamo is one of San Francisco's great epicurean and entertainment bargains. Watching three smiling women work virtually non-stop behind their closet-like lunch counter as they feed the multitudes waiting outside to get in is an experience you'll never forget. If you're in a hurry and don't have time for the show inside, you can be like those in line who simply called in their order by cell phones as they too stood beside our party. "
author: Tim W.

description:
What I liked:
It looks like a crack den from the outside which makes the cosy interior more enticing. It feels like you're sitting in your foster family's kitchen watching them prepare lunch - nice.  I love the prices. 

What I didn't like:
In short, the food.  Reading previous reviews I can only imagine that we either chose badly or walked into a different crack-den-like-hole-in-the-wall Yamo on 18th street.  We had the fresh spring rolls, the prawn curry and the fish curry.  Calling those dishes 'curry' is a gross misrepresentation - no discernible shred of ginger, chili or spices (but enough oil to rival the Gulf of Mexico).  Yes, yes, I know... next time we'll try the darn House Noodles.   

What I'd want:
From Yamo - some fresh ingredients (scallions, chili, ginger, anything green, red or yellow) to balance the oil. From me - the foresight to read other reviews to know the menu highlights.
author: Marzena K.

description: This is the most "hole-in-the-wall" place ever.  There's like 10 counter seats available.  It's run by cool ladies, who speaks Cantonese and English.  These are tough ladies who can handle the drunk!  I had the fish chowder soup with fried yellow bean-interesting.  I don't see the fish.  It's so dirt cheap:  what do you do with $5.25 with no tax and no health supplement! The samosas looked really good.  I don't think they use MSG, because I would have felt it.  I just want to go back to try other stuff.  Don't wear your Sunday best, because you will smell like their kitchen!  There's a big sign that said "No alcohol".
author: Helen L.

description: Meh.  Tea leaf salad was good, not amazing.  Fish curry w/noodles and tofu curry w/rice were okay.  Flavorful enough but very oily.  Certainly not worth 4 stars.
author: Rebecca H.

description: i'm totally into hole-in-the-wall type places as often you can find the best food there. but i agree with some other reviewers that the food is just ok and some of the dishes seems more like chinese food. which makes sense since chinese cuisine influences all other asian cuisines. but i would think there's still some burmese differences. love the mango salad - very refreshing. but seems like a thai salad. the fish noodle soup was more like a thick sauce like curry consistency and overly salty. the dumplings were just like regular chinese dumplings. at least everything is cheap. i dont know how they can afford the expensive sf rent charging only 6 bux a plate!
author: p f.

description:
Dear Yamo,

You ain't that YAMO.

Maybe if I was non-Asian, I'd like you.

Maybe if I was a pretentious SF Foodie, I'd dig you.

Maybe if I had sandpaper for tastebuds, I'd love you.

But truth be told, I am none of the above, so therefore I hate you.

XOXO,

Lisa
author: Lisa W.

description:
Yeah, it's a hole in the wall kind of place. In fact, I think there are only like 5 stools along a bar table in the whole restaurant. I normally order to go ... there's really no seats or space available whenever I visit. The cooks are all women that are experts in dishing up fast food Burmese food. I've tried to ask for less spicy, milder tea leaf salads and mohinga (cat fish chowder), but have been responded with disapproving looks and remarks of how it tastes better with the burning sensation in the mouth. 

Burmese food is hard to find and the places that do sell some of this amazing food overprices like I can't believe. Yamo is decently priced - a huge plus for a hungry college kid like myself. 2 thumbs up for some yum Burmese cuisine. 

Tip: The cooks speak Chinese AND Burmese... that might be helpful.
author: Elaine S.

description:
Yamo is definitely one of those "hole in the wall" treasures. The place is barely a hallway & probably seats less than a dozen customers. The stools and everything else were all pretty close together; its literally: you, counter, kitchen. But aside from the tiny area the food definitely had a huge flavor. I had the house noodles and inhaled it when it was cool enough for me to eat. Not only was the place tiny, the prices reflected it as well. My delicious noodles were ONLY $5.

The food was great but this is one of those "in&out" places. No loitering, not that that was said, but for the lack of space and seating, it'd be rude to stay and chat while others line up outside. I was definitely in & out within 15-20 minutes.
author: Kris B.

description:
Caution I tried all the food quite inebriated....so everything tastes a little better. But the long wait (especially when anxiously drunk) is not exactly worth it for some random greasy chinese food. Tho that greasy tasty goodness does satisfy that drunken tastiness!

The noodles and meat seem fairly standard, BUT I see NOTHING that is Burmese about this place. Curry does not automatically make it Burmese...HMPF I've still not had convincing Burmese food...outside of Burma/Myanmar (STILL craving Shan Noodle Soup).

What really gets this place a good ol' OK is the price, at $5.25 for nearly every dish, with large satisfying amounts, its definitely a place to consider if you're short on change and want to greasify your stomach (maybe after damaging ur body with alcohol...or other stuff...)! But hey it makes you have that warm fuzzy feeling inside, or maybe that was just the booze speaking. I'll consider trying this place sober, but I doubt it'll really be better. PLEASE find me a good Burmese place, cuz this is nowhere close
author: Nehal N.

description:
Spring Roll (not the deep fried ones but the soft rolls): Good but I've had better elsewhere. Like more mint in mines.

Tea Leaf Salad: Crunchy!  All ingredients FRESH. Excellent!! Better than Burma Star.

House Noodle (Pork): Meat seared perfectly. Noodle consistency is chewy but not hard.

Cold Noodle: Same noodle as the House Noodle but mixed in with lettuce, carrots, cucumber, cilantro, onion. You mix it all together and it's almost like having noodle salad. Tip: to give it a kick, add jalapeno and vinegar (part of the condiment on the counter where you sit)  into this dish.  

Fresh Coconut Juice: Drink it straight from the coconut shell. Freakin' awesome.

Portions on the small side just like in all parts of Asia (except the Cold Noodle. That was a tad bigger).  

Total cost:  approx $28.00 (plus tax, $5) = $32.

Will be back to try their Crispy Egg Rolls and Curry Fish!
author: Sassy G.

description: Black bean fish and mango chicken are pretty good, and for 6 bucks I can't complain.   Still, the amount of oil and salt is overwhelming.
author: C M.

description:
After coming back to this place a few times, I've decided to downgrade it to 3 STARS.  Reason behind it is because beside the House Noodles, Chicken Noodle Soup, and Tea Salad, there's not much to eat.  All the other dishes were A-OK.  The spring rolls were actually kinda disappointing...the rice skin was too thick...not enough ingredients on the insides..and the sauce was mediocre at best.
The CURRY dishes were alright...cause there just isn't enough sauce, although the potatoes in them were really good; they were fried and then stir fried.  Then again, I don't know too much about Burmese food.  Maybe that's the way it was meant to be.

Having said that, if you haven't tried the place yet, you should.  Cause the House Noodles are just THAT GOOD.
author: Jonathan C.

description:
A true hole in the wall and great find. The food is yummy, cheap and the wait was worth it.  Like other reviewers said, this place only seats 10.

I recommend the House Noodles and the Tea Leave Salad.
author: Charlayne A.

description: Best tea leaf salad around. Nothing on the menu over around 7 bucks. And listening to the cook yell at customers just adds to the ambience. Very tiny space with just a few counter seats so you are not going for an elegant evening out. Just super food.
author: Carl C.

description:
Yamo reminds me of home, the dirtier the better.
The service is fast and efficient too, which i like.
For the price, you actually get very good food~
and Burmese food is really hot right now.
Yamo is a place where you just wanna grab some good food with a buddy.
Not a place to hang out with buddies.
There are only like....10 seats? 
And there is always a line.....................................
Love the house noodle, tea leaf salad ,and coconut chicken noodle soup. Oh, and Mo Hin Nga too!
author: Marlis T.

description:
Cheap, fast, home-cooking right in front of your eyes - always packed (which is a great thing) great location, and friendly, family-vibe service.

Yellow curry fish, baby Thai coconuts and TEA SALAD! Brilliant. Try it out!!
author: Lauren S.

description:
The food at Yamo is delicious, and the portions are plentiful. My friend and I each ordered a bowl of the house noodles, with sides of pot stickers and samusas and it was way way too much food. One appetizer would be enough for 3 people to share. This is definitely on the greasy comfort side of the food spectrum. 

The interior is tiny, one long, narrow counter, so unless you really want to smell like noodles all night (and wait for a spot) I'd suggest calling ahead and getting your order to go. The prize for eating inside is overhearing hipster girls reveal their plans to zomg go to every bar in the Mission. The prices were reasonable, our bill after all that food and 2 sodas came out to $18. Looking forward to getting regular take out.
author: Beth D.

description: Absolutely a little gem. Not that I have been in Burma, but you instantly feel that this place is authentic. Yamo Cold Noodles is my favorite, very well balanced spices and a bit spicy. Also like spring rolls and samosas. The curry chicken could be a bit more spiced. I will be a repeat customer here.
author: Mpunkt H.

description:
Little dirty hole in the wall with delicious burmese food...the way i like it!

Seriously this place is a diner counter with 10 seats, you have to wait your turn to get a seat or just order take out. 

Their menu is cheap! dirt cheap for delicious burmese food. Get the samusas, tea leaf salad, and the chicken noodle soup...i'm drooling already... its super good and its worth the wait...even if the wait is an hour long in the mission... I can wait..I love Yamos!!

Not an ideal date spot on account of the cramped space, but its part of its charm, its not the cleanest spot as well as you can see the two burmese ladies prepare your food right in front of you and you can see the dirty dishes piling up right in front of you.

I overlook these things as there food is too good for me to care :)
author: Christine W.

description:
I'm sorry in advance for sounding like a 16-year-old myspacer, but OMFG! YAMO YAMO YAMO YAMO YAMO YAMO! You will continue to rock my world forever more.  

Reasons to love:

1. Less that a minute bike-ride from my house.
2. Open at 10 a.m.!!!!
3. Tea Leaf Salad.
4. Quick and fresh.
5. Sincerely pleased to do business.
6. Dirt cheap (I mean inexpensive).
7. No frills.
8. Little Hype, except if you come past 7 p.m.

I shouldn't even write this because I don't want anyone else to know about this place but it may just have to be my after yoga spot!
author: Mennlay A.

description:
*Note: This review is coming from somebody who grew up in a Burmese family and has mucho experience in the world of Burmese cuisine.

I'll give it 4 stars for a few reasons:

1) This place truly defines the whole "hole in the wall" home-style comfort food image. 

2) Price to portion ratio is great. It's uncommon in SF to find good tasting food at a friendly price, but this little hole in the wall definitely delivers. 

3) The food actually tastes good! When I went the restaurant was packed with people ordering the house noodles and cold noodles, so we went with the crowd favorite. They do not dissapoint, the flavoring on the noodles is just right (a little greasy, but that's how it's supposed to be) and you can have them with your choice of beef, chicken, fish or vegetarian (tofu/mushroom I believe).

Now, a couple of things to look out for, the main thing being that this restaurant is extremely small and compact. It seats about 10 people (bar style) at most so most likely if you drop by you're going to have to wait. The cook and waitresses also do not speak English very well, but they are VERY friendly, so I'm sure you'll get by just fine! They seem rude (at least I thought so when I was waiting and observing) but once I sat down I was pretty much family to them.

In terms of authenticity it's not too far off from actual Burmese cuisine. Sure it's tweaked a little bit for the American taste (I mean, come on... Burma (Myanmar) is a third world country, so they don't have the luxury of putting so many ingredients into their dishes). However, the seasonings for the noodles are pretty spot on.

If you just want to come here for delicious noodles, over-rice dishes, pot stickers, samosas (pronounced samUsa in the restaurant because that's how you say it in Burmese) or egg rolls then this is a place that will not let you down!

However, if you want to try authentic Burmese food, definitely grab an order of Tea leaf salad, or either of the two soups. I'm not a fan of fish chowder (not Yamo's fish chowder, just fish chowder in general) but the Chicken Noodle Soup (uses coconut based broth) is definitely a favorite of mine! And the house & cold noodles are also authentic to Burmese cooking, so give any of those a try to experience Burmese food (especially the Tea leaf salad). I only actually tried the house noodles because my parents can make everything else at home (and they do! very often...), but I'm just telling you what to try if you want authentic Burmese food.
author: Ron T.

description:
Summary: it's cheap hipster chow for folks who aspire to travel to exotic 3rd world locales (or who think that the Mission is). While very affordable--with an atmosphere reminiscent of a hawker centre in SEA--the food was nothing remarkable.

The food: tea leaf salad, curry fish over rice, tofu and vegetables over rice.

The tea leaf salad was tasty; the one thing that stood out. The other two dishes, while well-prepared, didn't really distinguish themselves flavor-wise from Chinese. It reminded me of upgraded college food-cart fare, if my alma mater was the Universidad de Hipsterdam.

Would I go again? Sure, it's cheap, tasty and quick.
author: Tak N.

description:
if you love watching ladies bicker with each other behind the counter while they cook your super cheap, super delicious, super homemade food, then you'll love this place.

Somehow the lack of service, long wait and small menu only make this place more charming, and I'm not even a hipster.

Are you tired of your go-to taqueria every time you feel poor and need to eat for under $6?  Then mix it up and get your Yamo on.  You won't be disappointed.  And even if you are, you won't really be.
author: nick w.

description:
A coworker suggested we go to Yamo one day, and since yet another coworker owed me a lunch, i was all game for it.

Yamo is super tiny, like the Bow Bow Cocktail Lounge, but there's no karaoke and no booze slinging going on at Yamo. There are something like 8 stools here at the counter, so don't be surprised to arrive and have nowhere to plant yourself.

The food is all very good and very reasonably priced. The ladies behind the counter are working like mad and in tandem, it's a little funny if you ask me. Be prepared for something greasy, and the air may just have the palpable acrid taste of burning oil in it. But don't let that dissuade you, Yamo is a good little spot.
author: Wes T.

description:
Sitting crammed together at the bar with strangers and the sink and stove and fridge all right there and rubbing up against you and the single window all fogged up makes you feel you've discovered something secret and special. 

Everything is made to order--the fresh spring rolls go together right there on the counter while noodles sizzle in woks--which means they can vegetarianify pretty much the whole menu full of fantastic Burmese flavors.  

We stuffed ourselves silly for less than $10 a person.
author: Dana S.

description:
WOW! this pace is legit...and super super super cheap. About the 'not clean' comments thats BS - the only reason you may think that is that its greasy because your IN the kitchen - every restaurant kitchen looks like this. 
This is a beautiful, authentic world away feeling place thats simply awesome, be back soon. 

My wife and I got super full on delicious food for $8.75 SERIOUSLY??? no its not burma superstar, but Superstar is also about 5X THE PRICE! get over it.
author: Ben B.

description: This is the divey-est of the hole in the wall dive restaurants that you'll find in the Mission. The three ladies that run the shop are sassy if not rude, the place is not the cleanest, in fact it's not for the faint of heart.  But the food delicious.  Go for the tea leaf salad, stay for the house noodles.
author: Mateo E.

description: Yamo is my go to place when I'm craving noodles.  The beef or chicken over house special noodles is always good. But now my favorite is the fish curry over rice or noodles.  This place is super small and they only except cash but the good thing everything is like 6 bucks. Tip: you can call in order and place it ahead of time for pick up and is usually ready in 10-15 minutes. Parking is hard so its always a team effort to picking up dinner....drop off as your driver circles the block and by the time you pick up order your driver is just coming around the corner.
author: Christine M.

description: We went with the Yelp highlights getting the tea leaf salad, mango chicken, and house noodles with beef. And we cannot wait to go again! And when we go Again we will order the same exact thing because it was so good! Thank you Yamo! *Note* I heard from a real local to mix the tea leaf salad in with the house noodles with beef! FLAVOR EXPLOSION!
author: Willie M.

description:
Yamo, Yamo where have you been all my life? So there are so many overpriced places in this town, and for the most part, they are not even close to being as good as this no-frills hole in the wall. So you put it on a fancy plate and serve it to me with a hot waiter in a crisp white shirt doesn't make the wallet assault any less insulting. 

At Yamo there is a short counter space at which you can plop down, the ambiance is hot Burmese kitchen and not hot SF hotspot, but the lovely ladies there cook up some gorgeous fresh plates of yumminess, AND they chop off the top of the fresh coconut entirely: so you can get at all the fresh coconutty goodness. Some places don't do this...why I ask you? It is like $2.50 for the coconut. $5.25 for each entre. I love the vegetable curry noodles. The veggies are cooked perfect (they are still somewhat crisp) and includes okra. Yumo. Flavors pop, appetizers rock. The tea salad, and fresh spring rolls. Go to Yamo and drink a coconut already. You will be glad you did.
author: Maria D.

description:
if this Indiana balcony I'm on was just a Spring retreat and not full-time living...it'd make me feel a whole lot better being 1,945 miles away from Yamo. From a place that makes me feel like I can walk in alone and feel like I did when I'd wander into my Grandma's kitchen as a kid. 

But my Granny ain't know nothin' 'bout this Tea Salad! 

If I ate too much of this fine, not-too-wet, not-too-dry, just enough peanut salad, I'd start yammering Burmese on the streets. 

Wait...maybe that's my destiny...eat enough of this tea salad to be inspired to overthrow the Myanmar government and restore Burma? 

Wait, then we wouldn't have Burmese refugees that open many a Yamo. A crux!

Most of the time...there was a line...but there are only what? 11 seats? Your match.com date will be queasy if you show any signs of indecision. But again...be prepared for a bit of wait...play Bear, Ninja Cowboy.

Keep your party 2 or less or you'll just be plain troubled and will end up ordering take out, which is well & good but you'll miss out maybe sitting next to someone who says "Fahhhnta," instead of "Fanta."

Chicken came off slightly dry but I expected such with the flash quick fry they gave it. 

Embrace the dive-feel the same way you embrace the dive feel of The Attic. 

Don't be afraid to chat up the cooks either...they're not as austere as you think...warm, really, just terse. And terse is good, because on with the Yamo food! On with the tea salad and Hot House Noodles! 

Wiley cheap too, as in $6 for dinner.
author: Jon A.

description: Amazing small place. Food was delicious, service was curt, and prices were cheap. Amazing find.
author: David A.

description: The women who run Yamo are slightly intimidating, but the food is delicious and cheap! The chicken noodle soup, drenched in a coconut milk soup base, was comforting and tasty. My curry prawns/noodle combo was awesome the next day (Yamo's food makes for good leftovers!). I'd recommend taking this stuff to-go though, the smoke lingered on my clothes for a while.
author: Rachel S.

description: Yamo was adorable, affordable, delicious, and fun.  The food is $6/ plate.  No, really.  There isn't necessarily a surplus of seating, but that just adds to the intimate experience.
author: Nicole J.

description: Great food, a little greasy for me. Also, since I have food restrictions I am not always sure they are understood (no one's fault, just pointing it out). But can't beat the price and the experience if you happen to snag a spot without too much of a wait!
author: Sarah X.

description:
Food here is the bomb!  The pots n pans are seasoned and aged and worked in.  This is like eating and your mom is cooking for you.  Place holds like maybe 11 people.

I once saw a guy in there at the counter looking at a porno magazine eating a salad.  it was HARD porno too.  Like close up scenes of plunging genitals and nasty cream pies.  No one said a word to him.
author: Shawn L.

description: This place is the epitome of hipster hype for hole-in-the walls. Mediocre food, long lines. I really wanted to like this place, but there's too much good food in SF to give a place more than 2 chances
author: Gary T.

description:
Dear Ridiculously Hard-working Ladies Who Work At Yamo, 

Please be my new moms.  Don't get me wrong, I love mine a lot, but she simply lacks the kitchen prowess to turn out bomb-ass mango chicken or mushroom tofu.  I'm willing to make the switch.  Please come to my studio, which will remind you of your cooking space at Yamo because it's approximately the same size, and stir-fry up some of your house noodles with fried garlic and beef.  I could eat it all day, every day.  

Thank you very much.

- Christy
author: Christy J.

description:
Popular likely due to an overrated hipster obsession with the authentically terse woman who takes orders.

I've tried the curry, mango, and noodle dishes. All were edible, but extremely bland and greasy.

Pot stickers are tasty. Tea leaf salad is good, but unfulfilling.

If you're looking for a cheap fill-up, it's not a bad choice at $6 per dish. If you're looking for taste, you'd be better off licking the sidewalk.
author: Railroad T.

description:
I LOVE THIS PLACE! 
The food is delicious Burmese/Chinese fusion without all that unnecessary glamour. You order fried rice, you get fried rice. Samusas are great as well as my all time fav - the fish chowder. 
Four stars in lieu of five because of the limited seating.
author: Jen E.

description:
I've been dying to go here, and finally last night CHECK off the list! 

I'm giving this place 3 stars, one for each of those short, loud, lovely little ladies working there butts off in that tiny little kitchen. 

You get what you expect. You see 8 worn, crowded bar stools in a Diner-like setting where if you fell off your stool you'd hit the wall behind you, hardly any decorations, and a fridge. If this is what you expected then you'll love it! If you wanted to kick up your feet, and lounge into plush booths with fancy stuff on the walls, then mosey on along.

What those fabulous ladies create in that kitchen is by no means masterpiece. But I left with a full belly and still full wallet. Sampled two apps, two noodle dishes, and a soup. I have a feeling that you could get anything and it would all taste the same without tasting at all the same. Each dish delicious, $5.50, pretty darn spicy, and with just enough oil to leave that slick in your mouth. Order anything and get a fresh coconut. Way to go Yamo. 

P.s. and If you don't want that dirty, awesome diner experience? Take it to go, and kick your feet up in your living room with your plush couch and fancy stuff on the walls.
author: Brandi B.

description:
Have only been here once and loved it. Cheap and tasty food. Entertaining Chinese service - don't expect it to be the American way. And don't expect to change an order, they will tell you what you want. It's very authentic.

A main dish is $6. We were two people and ordered the mango salad, cold Yamo noodles and the Yamo house noodles with chicken. They were all great.
author: Sara-Lee R.

description:
tea leaf salad is outstanding, but everything else was ok (fish chowder, vegetable curry, samusas)

I saw the chef drop a broccoli on the ground, then toss it back into the pan.. YUCK!
author: Cece L.

description:
If you want a great cheap authentic meal, this is a fantastic place.  Definitely try to tea leaf salad.  

The only downside about this place is that it's tiny and can only seat about 6 people at a time.  Of course, that's the charm of it as well, it's never crowded and you always get served fast. 

Love this hole in the wall.  Wish there were more like in SF.
author: Sutha K.

description:
I am very angry that Yamo is not open on Sundays.  ok, not quite angry, but disappointed.  I always want to eat it when I'm hungover (like today, right now), I'm really feeling like it would be the most magical thing ever to eat for a Sunday hangover, but alas I will never have the opportunity.  I suppose I could get trashed on a Friday instead.

PS, everything here is pretty good.
author: Greg J.

description:
Have you seen the "Soup Nazi" episode of Seinfeld? 

Well, that's what some of the cooks are like here. Pay up front, and expect immediate action by those magicians behind the counter. I once asked the lady how fast it would take to make a tea leaf salad. She said, "Gimme money, I make." I said, "But how long will it take?" She responded, "Gimme money, I say, I make." Within 1 minute there was a beautiful tea leaf salad in my hands, to go.

The food is AMAZING. The space is a hole in the whole. The cooks are impatient, and even rude, but it's all worth it. I promise.

I recommend you get the tea leaf salad and the fried fish. Everything is good. 

You'll be lucky to eat in as there's no space, so TO GO is likely better.
author: K P.

description:
Okay so...it's small, it's dirty, and it's nearly impossible to get a seat but OMG the food is DELICIOUS. I would recommend getting togo, but not a Sunday, when they are closed. I've wanted to take the BF here but it was always closed whenever we wanted to visit (usually a Sunday).

Yummies!
- moh hinga (very fishy though)
- house noodles with chicken or pork....SO BOMB! prob my fav dish here
- garlic noodles with beef ...super yumy
- tea tree salad - yum!

I would give it 5 stars but the dishes are kinda tiny..but hey for $5-7 per dish, not complaining!
author: Kay P.

description:
Don't get the superficials of this place scare you away - gritty outside, dingy inside - this is the classical definition of a hole in the wall. A classmate of mine took me here after a trek of the Mission and we were hungry. So we came here. 

The food's tasty here, I had the curry chicken with noodles and I have to say, Burmese curry is a little more saltier than Vietnamese or Cambodian curries and it has the consistency of Thai curries. It was still enjoyable, the lady at the counter asked me if I wanted the regular chow mein noodles or the chow fun noodles. I had the thinner chow mein noodles which worked nicely with the curry. 

All in all, I would have given this place 4 stars - but 2 things first. Portions and service. I would have liked to see a little more sizewise, and my glass of water could have been topped off a little more frequently but I understand the 2 ladies who are the cooks and waiter/servers here are busy. I'd come back again.
author: Navi T.

description:
HOUSE NOODLES! 
COLD HOUSE NOODLES! 
ALL NOODLES!
