I'm a regular at this place but I can never find the check in button, I can only remember it so often. lolol. it's cheap its easy but lines are long, food takes a while to make while waiting in the cold. if you dont speak up they'll forget you! everything is under 6. it's cool dude. I love it. it's fast, it's easy its good. but be careful theres no place to sit. it's just a kitchen and some stools. for Burmese food this ROCKS MY SOCKS!
I started ordering their one appetizer, I can't remember the name it's a little triangle, fills with good instead. it's really good you have to try it. plus it won't even break the bank its only 3.25! :]
author: Carolyn Y.

description:
What can I say about Yamo that others haven't said?  Perhaps I'll just reply to the review of Lisa W, who so kindly provided me with a convenient format.  

You're just that YAMO.

Maybe if I were more Asian, I'd like you even more. Also, if I were an attractive Asian girl I'd have tons of "funnies" and "cools".

Maybe if I was a "yelp elite" member, I'd be too stuck up to dig you.

Maybe if I had super mutant tastebuds that were as hard as sandpaper, yet as discerning as that of a piggy, I'd love you all the more.

But let's face it, I'm none of those things, but Yamo, I do love you.

xoxo,
Leon
author: Leon K.

description:
Tea salad:  Pretty good if you can handle all the dried beans and garlic.  That garlic was potent and looooooooonglasting.

Chicken noodle soup:  ramen, chicken, onions in a yellow curry coconut soup.  Fantastic.

Get the fresh coconut drink for $2.50 only.  Same price in Mexico!
author: Yvonne Y.

description:
Straight forward Burmese, not as enchanting as Burmese Superstar
But more of a whole in the wall and a nice place to take a friend to talk.
author: Mario C.

description:
This place has character. You won't like it if you're one of those needy customers I used to have when I was a waitress- if you need your water to constantly be topped off, and for someone to ask you how your food is several times during the course of the meal, you probably won't like it here. 

If you like grumpy ladies who give you water if you're polite and they feel like it and who can cook up a mean plate of noodles, you will love this place. For some reason I REALLY loved it here but I couldn't tell you why. The food was excellent, and the service (or lack thereof) only added to my experience. I will be back as often as I can manage! 

Oh, and try the dumplings. DELICIOUS.
author: Rika Y.

description:
I was taken here for a first date. Lucky for Mr. Fancy Pants, I love hole in the walls so I instantly became a fan. Everything is about $5 and very tasty (and a little heavy, might I add). The tea leaf salad is a must try. On the first date, I had the Mango Chicken which was pretty delicious. On the second and third time, I had the Curry Prawns with noodles, which are really good too. This is definitely no Burma Superstar, but for the price, it's worth it.

I've read some of the other reviews here and noticed that some have complained about the cramped space and lack of cleanliness of the locale. Dude, it's a hole in a wall, you have to expect something to give for the low prices.

BTW, if you're Chinese, don't get too confused by the Cantonese-Mandarin-Taiwanese speaking owners. I noticed there is a bit of a Chinese influence in the food, i.e. just about everything is stir-fried. I don't really care for technicalities though, as long as it's cheap and delicious!
author: Anita W.

description:
Conveniently located next to the 33-bus line stop at 18th and Mission, this literal hole in the wall serves some of the most flavorful food in the city at unbelievably affordable prices. 

The place is run by, three angry looking Asian grandmamma chefs.  Hard to tell if they are really mad or if they are just concentrating really hard on cooking the food.  Eyebrows are permanently fixed in the upset position.             

The small menu pairs together time tested traditional ingredients with simple dish concepts to create food that is surprisingly complex in flavor.  In a few words... this place may not look like much, but everything taste delicious.  
   
The Tea Leaf salad is as good as or better than any other in the city (including Burma SuperStar and Mandalay) and at half the price.  Ultimately, in a battle of tea leaf salads, I'd put my money on this horse to win, because at the end of the day good restaurants are defined by their VALUE.  (Quality to price ratio) 

The catfish chowder has a savory aroma that will make you want to lift the bowl up directly to your mouth like you were drinking the remaining milk from a cereal bowl and with its great flavor it is absolutely worth a try.  Good for casual soup cravings and fantastic if you have a cold (or the h1n1 virus.)  

The house noodles with beef was off the charts tasty delicious and is definitely a must.  The beef is very tender and explodes with flavor... I'm talking fireworks in the mouth good.  The noodles are cooked to a perfect texture and absorb the components of the sauce very well.   
 
Parking situation is horrendous, that is if you plan on driving to this place.  You are definitely better off taking the bus, biking, or walking if you do not live in the surrounding area.  

Simple counter-style dining that can only accommodate 10-12 people at any given time.  Meaning long lines and long waits.  Go before or after peak dining hours and you will not have any problems snagging one of the few counter stools.  Take-out is also easy and convenient with temporary illegal parking available in the back alley.    

A meal for two will set you back no more than $15-$20.  In the value department it is always a great option and does not leave you with that heavy/greasy feeling often associated with this type of cuisine. 
  
YAMO eat at this restaurant whenever I'm in town. 

Recommended
author: Raphael C.

description: This place rocks. It's tiny, hot, and loud, but the food is incomparable and the prices are incredibly low.
author: Dominic B.

description:
I love hole-in-the-wall restaurants and Yamo is everything of that. 

Luckily, we had perfect timing and was able to snatch up the last two seats at the counter (out of about 10 spots). 

We were enchanted by sporadic flames from the wok, the swinging lights above, and the 3 women behind the counter and their methodical ways of taking orders, cooking, and serving; these women have it down to a T. 

We ordered two appetizers, two dishes, and a soda all coming out to ~$16. What a deal! No wonder the line was out the door and the take out orders kept the phones ringing. Not only was the food cheap, but it was flavorful and it was hot off the stove.
author: Christine A.

description: Solid authentic Burmese. Love the salads and cold noodles, lots of flavor.
author: Xing C.

description:
I just moved to the Bay Area so I'm going to claim that this is probably the best Burmese food I ever had here. 

Definitely, a hole in the wall. And you know what that means? Delicious and cheap food!  The place is really small, they only seat around 9 people if you want to dine in. You will also smell of grease and smoke after dining in because the tight space and because they cook right in front of you. We opted to just order take out and eat at Dolores Park, a walking distance that is just a couple of blocks away. The wait was long but it was worth it. 

I ordered the tea leaf salad and samusas! Both of the dishes are the bomb. I love the nutinness and crunchiness of the tea leaf salad. I was expecting greens; I was somewhat hesitant to order the salad because I was super hungry and because I didn't feel like eating leaves at that time. Although the salad is small in portion, it is very rich and savory. It was also a bit spicy but the spiciness added more kick. The samusas were tasty but I cant say they are the best tasting ones. My friends and I also shared our meals. The cold noodle was pretty standard yet it was still delicious. The mango chicken was tasty as well but it wasn't one of our favorites. 

Would I go back again? Heck yeah. It's pretty cheap and I feel that the portions are about right. You will feel satisfied but you won't feel bloated.
author: Anette N.

description: I feel like i'm on a busy street in an asian country! Yamo's noodles really hit the spot and not because the space is tiny and unusual (i prefer clean bright space...). The noodles have the perfect texture and delightfully soak up the light yet savory sauce. Ahhh.. Pure bliss.
author: Sarah L.

description: 5 seater with angry looking chinese/burmese women cooking your food right in front of you.  $6 for a glorious plate of noodles.  The hot sauce really makes a difference.  Perfect hangover food.
author: vivian p.

description:
Fast, cheap, tasty food served on a counter brimming with attitude. What more do you need?

I have fun bringing out-of-towners here.
author: Bihn K.

description:
Arrived in SF from Vancouver by way of LA. Famished. Having stashed and stowed my luggage and what-not I headed out to find a meal. It was near 8pm and I had to cross town to the Mission in this vast new city in order to get dinner at Yamo which closes at 9:30. Authentic Burmese food. Colour me intrigued. I walk through the Tenderloin District toward the Civic Centre BART station. This area of town is akin to Vancouver's Downtown East Side and the poverty is apparent everywhere. I come to an elevator and stupidly get in to take it down to the station.

I am standing in a urinal. It's like I am actually immersed in a giant toilet. I press the button to go down and the slowest elevator in the universe begins it's descent. I touch nothing and can't decide whether to breathe through my nose and smell it, or mouth and OH FUCK... I can taste it. Urine and human filth. Puddles of piss and other unidentifiable stains keep me locked in one spot and I swear I will never ever take the lazy way out again.

I arrive on the platform, efficient and easy the BART - essentially a subway - takes my 30 blocks or so in about 5 minutes. Nice. I get out and play the fun traveller game of re-orienting myself, of course this involves walking a block the wrong way as I don't like to ask people for directions. I circle around and go a block past where I need to be. I chuckle at my stupidity.

I track down Yamo and the line is out the door. I'm about the fifth person back from the door. Inside 3 Asian woman work the line bellowing at each other in what I assume is Burmese but given that there are over 100 languages spoken in Burma I'm not sure. It's Cantonese-y sounding... The place is narrow and small. The hood vents don't seem to work and there is a layer of grey grease and dust on the walls and some surfaces. The open line is chaotic but seems clean enough. I guess. The place only seats 10 people and right now they are all young hip white people in their twenties and thirties. I fit right in. Usually at a place like this it's nice if everyone is of the ethnicity of the food but while I trust that I also trust faux-poor hipsters in their ability to find good cheap eats. 15 minutes and I'm in and seated at the end. It's cramped and I have to move my leg when one of the cooks needs to access the dishwasher. I really do love eating like this. The service is harsh and abrupt. Usually a good sign. Her English is limited but I just point to what I want. A traditional catfish noodle chowder and some dumplings. She get's to work. Everyone eating is friendly and chatting and I engage the couple to my left in conversation while on my right I avoid being hit by the door of the dishwasher which is causing my stool to vibrate in a delightful manner. My and my dinner companions chuckle about this. My food arrives. The dumplings aren't made in house which is a let-down. I saw her pull them from a bag in the freezer. Expectations low I take a bite. They are pretty good, boiled and then pan fried making one side delightfully crisp. A nice cabbage to pork ratio and heavy on the ginget which I like. They are served with a dipping sauce much like Vietnamese Nuoc Cham, sweet vinegary fishy. Yum..

My chowder arrives. It's thick and hot. The fish is in small chunks interspersed amongst thick egg noodles. It is pleasantly fishy and deliciously thick. A wafer like fried to crunchy type thing with bits of fried corn in it are broken up over the surface. It tastes a bit like a wheat cracker and I ask one of the women what this is.
"I don't know!" She spits out, "I'm just the cook!" She grins a massive grin laughing wildly and returns to hacking the tops off young coconut with a massive cleaver. Her speed and precision are astonishing. I return to me meal. I'm getting quite full so I offer my dumplings to the couple beside me. The thank me and finish the plate. I feel the onset of a food coma and I know I have to get to my feet and move soon. I had noticed a little bar called the Elbo Room around the corner and a pint was exactly waht I needed. My food and a bottle of water was $12 with tax n' tip. Nothing on the menu was over $6 and it was totally worth the wait.
author: Christopher N. W.

description:
This place is a total dive and a total treasure.  The food is EXCELLENT, spicy and CHEAP!  If you go during peak lunch time hours there will likely be a wait, as it's a tiny, narrow space that seats only a little.  Be patient and it will be worth it!  The ladies speak Cantonese (even though it's a Burmese restaurant), so I'm not sure about authenticity but regardless, it's great =)
Get the cold noodles with chicken!
author: West P.

description:
Yummy Burmese food for two cooked by cute, funny Burmese women: $20.

I suggest the Mango Chicken and the Chicken noodle soup-- you won't regret it (that is unless you're all veggie;).

Need I say more?
author: Chantal P.

description: Yamo delves into depths of the psyche as it overwhelms the sensory lobes of the mind with it's richness. Textures rule the day, freeing the mouth to explore realms as diverse as fallen snow and gritty earth. Tea Salad is a must, a dish that can be inhaled or savored with equal enjoyment. Fish with black bean sauce delights the diner crafty enough to chop and stick their way to a quick meal. Where is flavor country you ask? It is Burma, full of Buddhist monks. But for San Franciscan Monks, may I suggest trying out Yamo, for health.
author: Amy S.

description: Ever had a big fight with your significant other then 10 minutes later had some amazing make up sex? That's how I feel about this place. After waiting in the sun outside for 20 mins and having the chef yell, " what you want to order!". I was thinking why was I coming here again? And its cramped (hole in the wall)? Duh! THE COMIDA. House noodles with chicken..... So many textures at once.. fried garlic, al dente noodles, grilled chicken. It was crunchy, soft, chewy all at once. And the sauce... Boo Yah! Hit the spot. Pot stickers had a lot of ginger which I like, and thick wrapper. Awesome! Went with my friend, and the bill is usually what i tip. So let's see, full, satisfied, and have money left? Now this makes me think, If only my girlfriends could do the same.
author: Q L.

description: I come here from time to time, but I would refuse to stand in any line more than 4 people. It's not worth my time when there is good food aplenty in the neighborhood. The crowded times are very centralized, so you can easily get a coveted seat inside right before or after noon. Never plan to sit inside though and it certainly would not happen if your group is more than 3 people. Even though you'd think there'd be a commotion in the kitchen, those ladies actually cook at a pace not close to a flurry. And the service isn't even friendly. As for the food, the house noodles is the favorite here. I love that it had a buttload of garlic and a little bit of spicy, but nothing spectacular otherwise. I like the tea leaf salad a lot, which has a ton of crispy parts like deep fried fava beans. But that is one tiny dish. The fish curry noodle soup was good. The fish was nicely fried and the broth was milky. Though the prices are cheap, they are only cheap relative to everything else around. But honestly speaking, I think a $6 burrito will definitely fill you up more than a $6 bowl of noodles.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Everyone already knows Yamo is about the most badass eatery in the city, so why would I waste numb my fingers writing a review?  

Because I had the curry fish last night and it was so good that i think the only way i can get it off of my mind is to process the pleasure here.  SO GOOD.  I usually get the Yamo House Noodles with Pork (its greasy garlic noodles with bacon, really), but decided to go for the fried curry fish instead because somehow i thought fried fish would be a healthy alternative to grilled pork.  Whatever.  

So good.  The fish was stellar, fried but still softish, served with some veggies over noodles.  The curry was pretty hot and really tasty.  Blew my mind.

Oh!  And the ladies behind the counter were definitely the nicest they've ever been.
author: Tom T.

description:
Ok, this place is a dive. An absolute hole in the wall. It consists of about 10 stools sitting at a counter. The walls are painted black and the ladies seem to yell at each other in Chinese while you sit there. The bathroom is a closet and there are hangers behind you that you can hang your coat on.
I LOVED it. I took my sister there and we both loved it. The food is SO cheap and SO good. I would give it 5 stars if it wasn't such a hole in the wall.
author: Clive L.

description:
I'm glad to be the 600th reviewer of this hole in the wall. 
I was in the bay area for a family trip and decided to trek down here after the reviews from my fellow yelpers. My father was so pissed off that he decided to storm off before even trying the food. Well, he missed out. The House Noodle with Beef was the best damn noodles i had in SF. I wolfed down the bowl of cilantro beefy goodness in no time. The tea salad was also a must have. Make sure you have something to drink along with this salad. My sister had the Mango Chicken. The mango chicken was okay at the very best. 

There are about 9 stools, one chef, and 2 waiters in the place. Make sure you don't come in groups and prepare to wait for a long time. The price was reasonable. Our bill came out to be about 24 for 3 people including tips. Just order take out.
The dishes looked like they were mish mash together. Don't expect any heartfelt stories from this place.  The chef was this tired 50 yr old woman. She told us a chef made all the sauces and prep everything. All she had to do was put it together. She recommended the House Noodle and the Fish Chowder Noodle.

My father ended up chowing down on my sis' mango chicken because he was waiting by the street corner while we ate. I love how karma works.
author: Kenneth L.

description: 5+ stars for incredible food, impossible to give 5 stars for the overall review since the decor and setup is anything but nice and comfortable. But definitely worth a visit if you don't mind waiting in line and dining without any style for some authentic, cheap ($6/most plates) Burmese food.
author: Natasha F.

description:
Cheap. Fast. Good. Pick 2.

That is a common engineering idiom. With Yamo, you get full on cheap and halvesies on fast and good.

"The Chinese view chaos as opportunity" -- a fictional TV show character said this; it seems highly likely to be a 100% false statement.

However if you are an ABC character's idea of a Chinese person, Yamo is knocking loudly at your door. Speaking of doors, the restaurant is only slightly wider than a door. It seats 10 people, 12 people tops? 

I got takeout and watched my order get lost in the swirl of the kitchen chaos, eventually surfacing 20-30 minutes later in exchange for 5.25.

So remember! Full on cheap, pretty good, not that fast. So call ahead! This is what the causality of a butterfly flapping its wings in South America tastes like.
author: Alan F.

description:
Pretty good food for the price.

Unfortunately, the kitchen was too small and crowded for the head cook to wash her hands after pulling out her bundle of dollar bills to make change. Sorta grossed me out.

They are fun to watch, though!
author: Morgan B.

description: Dag yo, I come in here once a week and I still get hella verbal abuse! I put up with it week after week, out of fear that if I retaliate the lady who runs the grill will 86 me for life. The chicken noodle soup has saved me when I've had bronchitis and death gripped me so hard I could only make it that one block to find nourishment. The tea leaf salad is one of the most amazing things that I've ever eaten. I love taking dates here, as it only seats like seven people, so it makes it all intimate and cute. Watching the ladies yell at each other and at bewildered customers is a fun show to watch.  Cash only. When I call my order in I never know if it's really going to be ready in twenty minutes or they might not even begin my order until I show up twenty minutes later to pick it up. Either way, I'd never complain, because let's face it, those ladies do not give a fuck. Also, for the love of Christ don't  ask for anything to be altered (like added vegetables) you will definitely get yelled at.
author: Vanessa B.

description: A real hole in the wall! Unpretentious , cheap and tasty authentic Burmese fare!! Tea leaf salad is a Must. They cater to vegetarians. If you need an ambience this is not your place.
author: Ashish K.

description:
Quick, extremely tasty food. 
Super cheap. 
Environment to match.

Always in my order: tea salad & house noodles. Hard to beat.
author: A S.

description:
For the price, this is awesome. 
Total hole in the wall, and thats what I love about it. Its all about the food. 
Order anything, and you'll leave very, very satisfied. 

Addictive. House noodles are a must.
author: Tasha A.

description:
Yamo is really cheap and yummy.  I really love eating their food.  esp yamo cold noodles, they are really fkin yummy.

getting sick from all orifices is not yummy.

I always get the shits after yamo.  I figured it was because it was spicy.
But this morning around 4am was my second getting vomity sick after yamo. 

I am not a vomiter I don't normally vomit even on half a fifth of whiskey.
I'm fkin done.  can't do it.  

wtf yamo why  have you scorned me!
author: Matt N.

description:
I so badly wanted to like this place more.  So badly.

The prices, of course, are spot-on, however, when I received my order, it was exceedingly greasy.  (Even for Burmese/Vietnamese food)  I ordered the Yamo House Noodles.  Again, yes I expect an inherent amount of oiliness with this dish, but it was SOPPING.

The flavors were not well-blended and the grease just really did me in.  I NEVER throw out food, but it did cross my mind.  

What saved it from a 2-star rating is the women were very friendly and fun.  It has a great "hole-in-the-wall" vibe.

Next time, I think I'd try a soup or something as it looked/smelled really yummy.
author: Chris Y.

description:
exceptional food that you can't get just anywhere. price is there, too.

and the atmosphere? let me tell you: the ladies behind the counter are SO SURLY! getting them to even crack a smirk is a wonderful gift in itself.

setting is epically tiny - no groups! - and it seems like getting your to-go order requires muscling through the line/crowd at the entrance and demanding your food over the hustle of the place.

not normally my thing, but something about this place just WORKS. it's a go-to Mission/SF experience if you ask me. and an awesome date place. get the fresh coconut, the tea leaf salad, and anything with black bean sauce.

highly, highly recommended.
author: Sean C.

description: Delicious cheap Burmese food in archetypal hole-in-the-wall eatery.  Oft grumpy-looking Asian ladies run the place very much like street food carts in Asia, where everything seems at once makeshift yet operated with ruthless efficiency.  Food is not as sophisticated as Burmese Superstar, but perfectly comforting and pack in that explosive savory Burmese flavor as you would expect.  House specialty noodles are superb, tea salad very good, and curry okay (it was just spicy and not much else to me).  Delightful to have a fresh coconut as beverage.  Probably need to come at strategic time to avoid long wait.  I am a fan!
author: Kozmo C.

description:
I was waiting for the 33 bus when I noticed this line extending out from the door of this place. Checked out the menu and had to rub my eyes when I saw that all the mains were $5.25 a piece.

Tasty grub and as cheap as it gets. The ladies in there are crankin it out and the vibe is great in this hole-in-the-wall of a place.
author: Rob G.

description:
If you don't mind the low key (by low key I mean dirty) atmosphere, this place has the best value for take out food. For $20, my husband and I stuff our faces with:

samosa
tea leaf salad (best thing we ordered)
mango chicken
house noodles (could have more flavor)

Call in and they'll have your order ready in about 10!
author: Elaine L.

description:
Went there last night with a friend that said 'is really good', I beg the differ! The food was mediocre and boy was I circling for almost 30 mins to find parking - EPIC PAIN!

The extra star given cuz to my delight the 3 'MOMS' aka chefs were busting out Cantonese (when one would think 'Burmese' after all, this is a Burmese restaurant) talking smacks and mocking two customers on what they ordered - COMICAL!

What we ordered:
Tea salad - nothing special
Samosas - alright, dry and one of the samosa had a strong 'SOUR' smelling in the stuffing aka expired...yucky!
Cold chicken noodle - decent and chicken quite tender.
Curry fish rice - rice was stale hard. Could barely taste the curry and the fish was quite edible.

Not worth the parking hassle for me to ever return....just sayin'
author: Katy N.

description: I've known and loved the dishes at Yamo for awhile now, but tonight for the first time I experienced the greatness that is the Black Bean Fish dish. Delicious!!
author: Trish A.

description: This place is the BOMB! Tiny hole in the wall, I think there's like 10 or so seats. The cooks, which seem to be 3 generations of Asian ladies, take no bull and deliver fast, hearty grub. The middle age lady butchers the shiiit out of fresh coconuts you order. Three hard whacks and wallah, you got a fresh coconut to drink from. On side note, I would never want to get into an argument with these ladies...
author: Jim C.

description: Affordable and great food!!! The ladies working this place are on another level, but thats okay because its their little hole in the wall and the customers will keep coming. I always get the yamo house noodle, it can be a little bit greasy for some peoples taste, but it is indeed some greasy deliciousness! The mango salad, and springrolls are two of my other favorite orders.
author: Ganesha B.

description:
This has to be the best new discovery for me in a long time.

I have never had Burmese food until today. I met a friend and we were seated pretty quickly. This place is one long counter and the food is cooked right in front of you. 

On the massive recommendations, I tried the Mango Chicken with a Mexican coke while my friend had the tea salad. She mentioned that the salad "had a kick", and I would say the same for the Mango Chicken. My chicken came on a plate with white rice and crispy fresh stir fried veggies. Nothing was too oily, salty, or spicy. This dish was exactly what I hoped it would be. The big chunks of mango made this dish even better, as I love the taste of mango with chilies. 

The staff was so polite to us given the pace that they have to keep to make sure the line outside does not get too long. This place obviously is popular and for good reason.

Next time I plan to try some noodles because I sat and watched them make dish after dish of a noodle dish which just looked amazing. I am also interested in their fresh coconut milk. Oh they have not seen the last of Eric G.
author: Eric G.

description:
Cheap food for the Mission? Yes.
Greasy? Yes.
Tasty? Sometimes.
Order process? Horrible.
Fresh mouse droppings in the tea leaf salad? Yes.

This food churned my stomach faster than the story about the Ryan's Steakhouse Incident. Google it.
author: Evan W.

description:
I love this place! The wait can be horrendous as there are only about 8-10 seats available in this literally hole-in-the-wall. Your surroundings while sitting in this restaurant might scare you, but hey, the food is hella cheap and delicious! You can see the ladies working their butts off cooking your food right in front of you. If you're lucky enough, you'll sit where their dish dryer is at and get some vibration for your arms. 

The Yamo House Noodles is a dish you should definitely try. It's yellow noodles mixed with fried garlic and their sauce and choice of meat. Delicious!

The Yamo Cold noodles reminds me a lot of the infamous Burma SuperStar's Rainbow Salad, except less ingredients and much cheaper. The cold noodles are really mouthwatering. I probably prefer this dish over the House Noodles.

Did I mention the food here costs on average $5? Talk about Deal Steal!
author: Peter N.

description:
These women are BOSS!!

They work quick, efficientlly, AND have great costumer service.

The main lady that takes phone orders, to-go orders, and most eat-in orders will strike up a conversation, that is if only the line is not out the door and around the corner onto Mission Street. 

Yamo is the epitome of a hole-in-the-wall diner in SF. I have missed this place a numerous of time while searching for parking because in a blink of an eye, you can miss it. But their are the massive letters out front, "YAMO."

Every time I've eaten here, I have gotten the house noodles with beef only OR in addition to another plate (mango chicken over rice). BOTH are great and cheap. Mamosas are delicious, just not right after they were taken out from the deep fryer. Potstickers are good too.

A 9pm closing time may be discouraging at first, but once you see how efficient these ladies work ALL DAY, you will understand and even want to help them get through the day. 

seating is SUPER MINIMAL, I believe a max of 9-10 seats. Personally, I have refrained from inviting a lot of my usual eat-out friends just because I know we all won't get a seat at the same time. (sorry everyone). Maybe keep your party at most 4 people.

The usuals that eat here are also super nice. They'll recommend something that you haven't had yet. They'll know if you haven't eaten here if it takes you more than 2 minutes to decide what to eat. :D
author: Cipriano G.

description:
This place was not worth the hype at all.  We went at around 3pm since we didn't want to hit the lunch hour rush.  Based on Yelp recommendations, we got the tea salad which was a lot smaller than I expected (1/2 the size they give you at Burma Superstar), the house noodle with beef, and the curry prawns.  

The Tea Salad was pretty good.  While it was small, it was indeed very flavorful.  I'm not sure what they put in this, but it's pretty addicting. 

The Curry Prawns are pretty spicy.  The shrimp is just your normal frozen shrimp with a light curry sauce with some onions, mushrooms, and bell peppers.  I wasn't a huge fan but it also wasn't horrible. 

I had high hopes for the House Noodles but while the texture of the noodles were good, the taste is just like any other place that stir fry's in egg noodles in a ton of oil.  The noodles are extremely oil with pretty mild flavor.  I think the chow mein noodles at a decent chinese restaurant are equivalent to what they serve here. 

When people say "hole in the wall" they're not kidding.  The place looks very run down and the counter seating is very squishy.  Apparently there are lines out the door during lunch time, well that's because there is absolutely no space inside the door if you don't want to be rubbing shoulders with someone.  I also noticed that this place had no ventilation so I felt like I was suffocating just waiting for my food.  

Would probably not come back unless I was drunk but I guess it wasn't a bad experience, but not something crave-worthy.
author: Kristie G.

description:
Ghetto. Grimy. Grueling. 

If Cordon Bleu on Polk and California is a hole in the wall, Yamo is a mere crack in the sidewalk.

Too cheap to get a facial?!  Go to Yamo on a hot day for a full sauna...fo free!   Refresh and rejoove with Yamo's hot cold noodles!  Hot in spice, cold to the tongue (actually more lukewarm, but flavorful and packs a punch nonetheless!)  Tossed with chicken (lots) and veggies (little).

Elderly asian ladies toss, saute, and scoop from their endless vats of rice.  they don't speak. they rarely smile. but they durn well try their best to get your order out to you right quick!  (not very quick)

But at the end of the day, $5.25 for a tasty, filling, cultural dinner ($3.50 for any appetizer, $1 for drink) is a great way to keep it real in the Mission.

Know Before You Go:
1. Bathroom hidden in back, but personal hand sanitizer recommended
2. Cash onnnlaayyyy
3. Gern phob? Take it to go a la Dolores park!

Cost
$5.25 ALL entrees
$3.50 ALL apps
author: Jane L.

description:
I heart Yamo.  Good Burmese food, but also a fun/bizarre TINY hole in the wall that is an experience in and of itself.  I have actually had a frustrating experience of waiting 45 minutes for a delivery order that I had placed on the phone BEFORE driving to Yamo, so that was infuriating, but given that the whole place consists of three women and a space the size of a walk-in closet, I decided to let it go.  

After only experiencing Yamo via take-out, I ate inside Yamo this evening.  I loved it!  First of all, it feels like an accomplishment just to get a seat because there are so few.  Once I was hunkered down along the counter, I set my sights on the young coconut, the tea salad, and the chicken noodle soup -- based on a fellow Yelper's recommendations.  YUM!  The tea salad is a party in your mouth.  So many flavors, and so much crunch.  I loved it.  The chicken noodle soup is not to be confused at ALL with good ol' Campbells in a can.  This soup is more like a spicy curry - and it's very, very good.  I ordered a spring roll as a starter, and it was fine, but not thrilling.  Pretty standard spring roll.  The young coconut was delicious - and it's fun to drink directly from a straw in a coconut!

All of this for $16.50!

This place gives a new meaning to "hole in the wall."  If you haven't gone, you must!

Also - don't forget to have cash on hand.  They don't take credit cards.
author: Molly P.

description:
Edgar and I came here as a thank you for me for picking him up from SFO. He suggested this place because there aren't many Burmese food places in the city, its cheap, and its good (high flavor/cost ratio).

This place is insanely small.. and there was a line out the door. Lucky for us, somehow everyone in the restaurant finished at the same time and we got in before the next rush.

House Special Fried Rice - this was very good. The rie had great texture and the satay flavors were good. There wasn't much heat, so sauce it up accordingly. There also was a good amount of small shirmps in the dish, which added some fill to it, but if anything the satay makes the dish.

House Noodles with Beef - garlicky and tender beef is all I could think of. This is the Asian equivalence of Peruvian Beef and Noodles, but without the tomatoes... at least to me it was. The noodles were a nice al dente, so obvious plus points for that. The steak was ultra tender, and the deglazings from the pan were used for the sauce of the dish, which was amazingly flavorful. I don't know if cilantro is growing on me, but it again worked on this dish, as the freshness cut through the oiliness and saltiness of the sauce (this saltiness and oiliness is far from a bad thing when it comes to sauce/delgazing/gravy, at least to me). And the garlic. A good amount of fried garlic and the garlic oil added to the dish. That put me over the top. This garlic was crisp and had a good amount of spice to probably also counteract the additional freshness of the cilantro that overwhelms me. Additionally, its not so overpowering to mute the rest of the dish. This dish was very home style and so good. I honestly should have split this into 2 meals.

I probably would order something over the house special fried rice the next time around. Don't get me wrong, it was good, but there were other things on the menu that looked great, but Edgar and I were looking to carb up. Definitely am coming back here for the samosas, salad, and mango dishes! Everything was like 6 buck
author: Marc T.

description:
Yamo is fast, cheap and out of control delicious. It's an unsuspecting hole-in-the-wall, that you might have walked by before without giving it a thought. I've done that several times.

I had the chicken soup, delicious spring rolls and coconut water. It came up to something around $11. A lot of food for that price. All of it was quickly prepared, well seasoned. Coconut water came in an actual cococut - an awesome perk.

Be warned, if you sit near the door (where the kitchen is), you'll smell of the kitchen after you leave.
author: ryan s.

description: House noodles with chicken were delicious! Very small little countertop diner style; Get here early to avoid the crowds.
author: Dina G.

description:
Fresh, excellent, cheap:  Asian food kicks your ass again!

Also: good selection of condiments.

The place is a grubby little hole in the wall, but really sweet ladies behind the counter (what is up with me and the "really sweet ladies" phrase in my reviews?!), attentive, and it just has this nice and homey feel to it.

And it's definitely scruffy in there.

But it's soooo fresh.  They cut up whole vegetables and then cook them and give them to you on a plate.  That sounds simplistic, but it's something special to see a whole zucchini disassembled and turned into food right before your eyes.

No idea how authentically Burmese the food is, but it's Asian-ish, light on the oil, and tasty-cakes, baby... TASTY-CAKES.

And cheap.  I swear they don't charge much more than the raw cost of the ingredients.
author: Martin W.

description: Not a great experience. The food is good, but I wonder how sanitary it is. And it takes SOOO LONG! The women who run it are a bit gruff. They always charge me more than the posted prices. (Either update your menu or charge that price!) And I've caught one cook skimming from people's orders: She cooks it up but doesn't put it all in. She puts a big spoonful in a separate little bowl and eats it herself. Another way they're cheating us i guess.
author: Lake Y.

description: Yamo you are my girl!  A great meal for under $10 including a trip is my kind of place.  I really like that you can get your dish with rice or noodles.  I always get something new and I always stuff myself silly.  Super small place and cash only.  Just eat here!
author: Ryan P.

description:
By far my favorite Chinese/Burmese restaurant in the neighborhood. (despite one very bad run in with a pidgin while reading the menu). This is one of those places that at first glace, I would never consider eating at, but some nights when hunger has taken over any coherent thoughts you may have once possessed, it will happen. Which is how I ended up standing directly in front of the exhaust vent scarfing down veggie chow mien. It was the most amazing thing at the time, subtle yet spicy. 

Since then I have been back on a few occasions, both for take out and eat-in. I would recommend both, but only the latter for small parties as the place can only seat 8-9 people max and always has a line.
author: Allyson S.

description:
This place is ten kinds of awesome.  Dirt cheap hole-in-the-wall lunch counter that serves Asian comfort food (noodles noodles noodles, baby!).  The two women who run the place are friendly and funny.  You have no choice but to watch them cook, and it's lively dance of busy-ass people who know what they're doing and are doing five things at once.

I was afraid to tell anyone else about it lest there be no seats at the counter any more, but with over 500 Yelp reviews, it's too late anyhow.  I'm glad a small restaurant like this is getting so much support.
author: Jen D.

description: Great noodles. Small hole in the wall with about 6-7 seats at a small bar. Slight wait. Definitely worth a try.
author: Will M.

description:
5 stars for the OH SO CHEAP price and the quality of the food. The two of us ordered Beef Curry and Mango Chicken with a spring roll appetizer (which is actually a summer roll - cold salad wrapped in rice paper). 

The beef curry was very basic with potatoes and VERY succulent beef pieces. The flavor was perfect, tasty and spicy. My friend's Mango Chicken was white meat chicken stir-fried with fresh mango chunks, bell pepper, sugar snap peas, carrots and onions. He's Venezuelan, so he loved his mango dish, but I really preferred my curry. The spring rolls were actually summer rolls, so we were kinda thrown off when they were served. If you want the real spring rolls, then you should order the egg rolls from the menu. The guy next to us ordered the potsticker appetizer and there were 6 savory, meat filled dumpings on his plate. Next time, I will def try those bad boys!!!

Since there are only 10 or so counter seats, there is always a line to get in. We went late, close to 10pm so there were only 2 people ahead of us in the line to get seated. My friend had gone before, so he knew to order our food while we were standing in line to get seated. So, when we did sit down, our appetizer came right out and our entrees were about 4 minutes behind. 

Now, if you go to restaurants because they are clean and sanitary with exceptional service, then Yamo is not the place for you. This place is one of the grimiest dive restaurants that I've seen outside of Southeast Asia. The 3 older ladies that were working (one cooking, one taking orders / chopping the veggies, one doing the dishes) were working so hard with their tasks that it's hard to get any extra service besides ordering your food and getting your check. If you want water or a soda, you might have to ask each of the ladies twice before you get your drink. In fact, it might be smart to bring your own water or soda so you don't have to worry about asking (bothering) the super hard workin ladies. There is an no alcohol policy so don't try taking in any booze. 

Also, if you're done eating, get your ass up and get out the door because some other hongry fools are waiting to get their grub on!!! Only 10 seats and a long line out the door every day!!!
author: Rex D.

description: I loved Yamo, it is a Hole in the wall for sure and just has a couple seats. We were lucky, we came right before a line started. Don't expect anything fancy but the food is delicious. Not the biggest portions, but it is cheap enough that you can easily order 2 portions per person.
author: Anna K.

description:
I LOVE this place. I feel like I'm in Southeast Asia when eat here. The ladies who work here are so gruff and tough, but I love it. It's definitely not about friendly service. You get in, eat, get out. The food isn't best quality but taste oh so great. I usually order the Chicken Noodle Soup in a curry broth. Practically everything on the menu is $5.25 or less so...

The Fish curry dish is good too. I also like the spring rolls and samusas.
I once ate here four times in a week and am still not sick of it.
author: Julie N.

description:
Yamo is a terrible, horrible, awful, hyperbole, hyperbole place.  It only seats 8 people.  

Maybe if I can write a shitty enough review, then no one will come to this place and I can get a seat.
author: Josh L.

description: Good noodles, try the house noodles with pork. The fried rice was a bit spicy and we finished it all. The spring rolls were fresh with a great peanut dipping sauce. Overall, worth the wait to seat inside and inexpensive. Have a fresh coconut drink to cool the spices.
author: Tommy K.

description:
This place is by far the best food in the world.  If you do not give this place a try after reading this, then you are a retard.  I think Yamo should charge more, because of the quality of the food and the atmosphere. So go and eat.  Trust me.

Scrat
author: Fady A.

description: The ladies manning this hole-in-the wall have got it down. This is the real deal. The line out the door is not a result of hype, it's because there are only eight seats at the counter and all the entrees are super delicious at $6. We ordered the Yamo noodles with beef, the black bean fish, and the spring rolls. I highly recommend the Yamo noodles, which are amazingly good. Everything is made to order. It's a great experience sitting at the counter watching one of the ladies make all the dishes and the other lady shouting out orders and managing the cash (no plastic here). The huge flames arising from the gas stove is the reason why you eat out for food like this. I noticed a number of people ordering take-out, which is a good idea. I would do the same if I lived in the Mission. A new favorite of mine in SF.
author: Annie Y.

description:
Oh, yelp, you did not steer me wrong. Yummy hole in the wall. 

4 of us came here at noon on Saturday = no line to wait. When we left though, there was a line out the door. It's just one counter; they cook behind it and you sit in front of it. Maybe 8 stools and luckily some coat hooks to hang your bags from. I got the cold noodles; it was spicy but not ice-cold like I was hoping for (hot day!). My friends got the mushroom tofu and the black bean fish. All yummy for $5.25 an entree. Don't get too excited by the size of the rice wrappers for the spring rolls; they're small but it's only $3.50. 

I commented that it was pretty clean for a hole in the wall. A exclaimed "What?!" Remember, it's hole in the wall standards. It is possible I was blinded by the cheap prices and yum-o (someone has to say it) food. What impressed me is there's a bathroom in the place. Apparently, it's hidden behind the wall.
author: Yan E.

description: I am from the midwest. We don't really have little hole-in-the-wall restaurants like this place. I was a little thrown off at first, but I had so many people recommend Yamo that I couldn't pass it up. I ordered the house noodles and the pot stickers!  This place is only 4 blocks from my work. I will be back often!
author: Chase L.

description:
Wow $3.50 for all appetizers.
The main entrees are $5.25 each.
The ladies hell of ignore you.
The place is crazy small with just a counter space for people to sit in a row.
And one of their refrigerators is just a standard household one.
This place is cuuuuute.
I'm so in love with the Yamo house noodles with beef.
I think I'm going to be here a lot more.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Total whole in the wall with this place with only about 10 counter seats. We waited for about 10 minutes, and someone was kind enough to scoot over one seat, but this meant we were sitting on the end of the L shape of the counter- even less counter space. It's really hard to order too many items because the counter just doesn't hold everything. Our plates were nearly stacking each other.

We had a fish dish over rice and a noodle dish. They were good, but nothing special. My favorite was the tea leaf salad. Better than all the other popular burmese restos in SF. t I just wished it was bigger.
author: Heidi L.

description: I think I expected too much from Yamo is my problem. It's for sure a good noodle lunch place, but it's not something I'd seek out on a trip to the Mission (I act like it's such a hike, really it's a 20 min walk. Once again - lazy). I got the vegetable curry and it was way spicy. It's a tiny hole-in-the-wall type place, so there's not many places to sit, either. I just expect more from a solid 4-star place in SF.
author: Amy S.

description:
Yamo is amazing!! I stumbled into this great hole-in-the-wall and now I am a regular! After a trip to Burma 5 years ago, it feels great to get some down home Burmese food (theirs is especially influenced by the China border). It's cheap, great atmosphere (I love dives) and the food is great. Mango chicken was delicious and the samusas were also great. The food was spicy :)  I love watching the women chop veggies and cook with huge cast iron skillets. 
This restaurant feels like a great secret...except that maybe it's not such a secret anymore.
author: Owl B.

description:
Yamo is surely YUM-O! 

Yamo is one of the most grungy food joints I know, and guess what? I LOVE IT. 

If you want cheap quality food served by cute fobby asians, then Yamo is more than a treat for you. 

If you want cheap nasty food, walk your butt to Burger King. 

WARNING- If your obese, you might probably get stuck in between the bar chairs and the wall.
author: emily g.

description:
After getting over the extremely long lines at the SF St. Food Festival, my boyfriend and I, ventured down the Mission to Yamo. He'd been before and could not stop talking about their noodles. When we arrived, the place is literally a HOLE in the wall. It's the size of a medium sized kitchen! Literally only sits 8 at the counter and that's it! We waited for a bit but he insisted it was worth it! 

The prices are great with everything at about $5.25 or so. I opted for the house chow fun with beef which was soooo good. I finished the very generous plate. It was oily but what else can you ask for with a place like this. Along with my yummy chow fun, I had fresh fresh coconut juice. Mmm..I'm making myself hungry. If I only lived in the area, this would be by go to "to-go" spot. The two women who cook, order, clean and own(?) the place are non-stop and friendly. I'd love to come back here and try more things on the menu!
author: Empee P.

description: This place is pretty much all hype. The food isn't bad (very greasy and not terribly interesting, though) but it really isn't Burmese--it's pretty much the same sort of thing you can get at any Chinese fast-food place.They have very little seating (maybe ten stools) and you're about five feet from the wok, so be prepared to smell like grease afterwards. There can be a long wait, so I'd recommend ordering to-go since you're not missing out on the ambiance anyway.
author: Alexei P.

description:
Me and 4 friends came here for lunch. Food, good idea. Group, bad idea. There was a wait, but I didn't have an agenda so hanging on the street was fine by me. We got in, and we sat at different stools and ordered. Me and my friend Calvin had the fish chowder with noodles and the house cold noodles. 

The house cold noodles with chicken were really good. Spicy with hints of sweetness, herbs, and a zesty vinegar sauce/ dressing. I would definitely get this again. The other dish me and Calvin ordered was the Fish Chowder or mo hing ga. It was passable, and not by any means bad, but I have had better at the other place on Larkin. 

All stated, I had a fine experience. A hole in the wall with fantastic prices, good food, and makes you feel like you stepped into a seedy Hong Kong alley. Yum!
author: David L.

description: Hands down the tea leaf salad is tasty, while looking past how otherwise run down this place is.  I could not imagine having a sit down meal here, but I am definitely alright with take-out from here.  So, I suspect that when I called in my order that they never actually placed the order.  It seems like the women that run this operation are a bit disjunct from normal protocol.  However, it was interesting to watch them hustle while having such fluid communication that was a mixture of shouting, quickly teetering back and forth and an occasional hand gestures here and there.  There were some other items that sounded delectable, but just seeing the cascade of dishes ordered by the people that managed to get ahold of seats there seemed like it would spike my cholesterol levels ten fold.  I think these ladies should conceptualize a new branding strategy, where they prepare, mince, chop, and serve your meal directly into your mouth from across the kitchen with a flick of the wrist.  I would pay to see that unfold.
author: Ty T.

description:
Wow, talk about the definition of hole in the wall.  The extent of this eatery is a single counter and some stools.  That being said, I was lucky to have my butt occupy one of those stools as a line out the door formed shortly afterward.  

The ambiance...wait what ambiance?  Ceiling lights were swinging, the outside of the restaurant was covered in graffiti, and the two ladies on the other side of the counter were scrambling to take orders, cook, package food, and take phone orders.  

Due to suggestion from the gentleman next to me, I ordered the black bean fish.  It was good but not incredible.  Then again, for less than $6 I really have no right to criticize.    

This is a cash only joint so be sure that you are armed with more than plastic if you plan on stopping by.

I don't recommend dining in at Yamo but for a cheap and quick meal to go, it doesn't get any better.
author: Renee M.

description: This place is a gem.  It reminds me of some of my favorite establishments in NYC and has so much hole-in-the-wall character.  The food is great and the atmosphere is really fun, with intense cooking and conversation behind the counter, as your food gets whipped up in a no frills kind of way by the three ladies working there.  Walking in is like being transported to a different time and place, and the food is delicious.  Definitely recommended!
author: David B.

description: This place is so overrated like many of the Burmese restaurants in SF.  This place is definitely hole-in-the-wall.  I expected HELLA good food, but it failed me.  Tea leaves salad looked stale (pre-made?) and tasted so salty, drenched in fish sauce.   It tasted like Vietnamese salad instead of tea leaves salad.  $6 for like 1/2 cup of the salad.  Cheap, but portion is tiny.  I got what I paid for.  Fish chowder noodle was my other thing I ordered. This tasted the opposite of tea leaves salad, bland.  I might come back to try other noodle dishes since it's only $6.  It wouldn't be on my #1 list to eat place.  It just happened to be walking-distant from my office.
author: MT D.

description: Tasty and very cheap! I had the beefy curry with noodles for $6! This place doesn't combine their Burmese recipes in the same delicate fashion you'd find at Burma Star in the Richmond, but their food was flavorful, albeit a little greasy and a wee bit salty. They did have some healthier options on the menu that looked interesting though, like the tea salad and the mango salad. The place is often crowded with a line out the door, but that's partly because it's literally a hallway with a cramped row of bar stools-no tables here.  Once I got in though, the service was speedy. I'd eat here again, as an alternative to fast food, greasy Chinese or a taco, but not a place for a romantic date, unless your date is impressed by your ability to spot descent hole in the walls. When you eat here think of it as kinda like a Burmese version of Tulan in the Tenderloin.
author: Juan F.

description:
The chicken noodle soup is phenomenal, especially with a nice cold young coconut.
The rest of the food is a bit too greasy for me. 
Nice atmosphere because counters are fun for eating and the people behind the counter are nice.
author: Mort B.

description:
Our first time here and we were taking it out...but BOY! it was confusing! There was just a lot of people(both waiting to be seated or just waiting for their takeout) and the place was small. They should at least have numbers to call out for costumers.
The food was oily, but delicious. Pet peeve is that I dislike eating at restuarants that look...well not so sanitary, but I can put up with this one. For some old school asians, they say the dirtier the place, and the  greasier the food...thats when it tastes the best. 
Overall, good food for the price.
author: Hubert H.

description: This place looks rundown and almost not even open from the outside but it fits in perfectly with the mission vibe. It's a hidden gem and the food is delicious! I had the tea salad which was a pretty small portion (so order something else too) but it is so so tasty. The prices are good and the ladies behind the counter are hilarious, shouting all the time and laughing while they cook. It's a small place and the kitchen is open. I would recommend it to anyone, fellow vegetarians and meat lovers alike!
author: Amy C.

description:
So as my friend and I were walking through SF looking for a place to eat, we stumbled upon Yamo.  It is a small Burmese establishment with bar seating, instantly I was intrigued. I had never tried Burmese food, and quickly became excited. There are about 10 seats, so finding a stool next to my buddy took about 5 minutes.  The three women running the show? They mean business.  When seating becomes available, you are quickly handed a menu and "encouraged" to order.  The kitchen is on the other side of the bar, so you can watch as everything is being prepared from scratch.  Between the sizzles of the skillets, pots and pans clanging, and the cooks yelling back and forth, it really becomes quite a show.  I ordered a fish curry for about 6 bucks, and it was very tasty. The fish was cooked excellently, had a good kick to it, and the curry sauce rounded out the dish nicely.  The food comes directly from the stove, and temperature wise,  nice and hot.  The assortment of chili peppers available enable you to add a little more heat to your dish, which I personally am a fan of. 

Overall, I enjoyed my experience, and definitely will make it back soon.
author: Billy O.

description:
Yamo is the best hole in the wall Burmese restaurant for me. Maybe the best Burmese food in the bay area. Inexpensive and very delish! It's always a long line though during early dinner time, but it's worth the wait. You get your stool/chair, order your food, eat, pay and go, no time to chitchat with your friends, do it outside, people are waiting to be served too. Enjoy!

(Warning though, if you don't like to smell "food" after eating in a restaurant then don't come here. Maybe you have a date after, so I don't advise it.)
author: Jake D.

description: Burmese is just so full of flavor. I would date a Burmese guy who can make tea lead salad everyday for me. Yamo is special because it is quaint and cute. It's a place to really eat. The price is no issue. If you're into hole in the wall, this is a go to.
author: Kara Y.

description:
This little hole in the wall will knock your tube socks right off your stinky feet!  


"I cant wait to see Cats and Dogs 2, yippppeeeee!!"
-Kim Jong Il
author: John B R.

description: This hole in the wall restaurant is an alright place to get your typical greasy Chinese food fix.  I tried the Yamo cold noodles and it just wasn't too satisfying.  It had a real similar taste to Great Khan's Mongolian BBQ that you can find in some shopping malls.
author: Dustin W.

description: Limited seating. Went there on a Monday night at 9pm. There was a line out the door. I was sick and looking for some soup. I read that this place had a great chicken noodle. It was awesome! 8 bucks cash. It had a curry spice to it that was magnificent. Not too hot for those who don't like heat, but enough to satisfy my love of heat. I took the order to go because it was cramped and there was a line. Probably wouldn't sit there and eat, because I don't like that cramped environment, but will definitely be back for the soup.
author: Brian A.

description: The beautiful country of Burma would be disappointed. Why is there trash cans underneath the counter where food is being prepared? Why are they swearing and cursing at one another in front of customers? Why don't they have ice cubes when asked by customers, instead scooping it up from an iced pitch water? I guess you get what you pay for. Will not go there again. The food is mediocre, and you leave there with a disgusting after smell!
author: Megan S.

description:
I only thought this place was ok...

Seats only like 8-10 people. Might have to wait long. Better to order takeout. 

I thought the 3 old Chinese ladies working there were really cute. They kind of reminded me of my mom and her friends. Btw i find it interesting how Cantonese speaking ladies were cooking Burmese food. 

Tried the tea leaf salad. That's the only dish I liked so far. 

Tried house noodles and stir fried noodles. They were ok.. Quite oily. Also reminds me of regular Chinese food.

The portions they give you here is quite small. 3 plates barely fills up 2 people. 

The price is ok.. $$ might add up since you will be ordering more food because of the small portions.
author: Jannifer H.

description:
My friend recommended this to me and I have to say it's alright. It definitely has its (really) tiny restaurant charm and the prices are very reasonable. However, I felt that the food was just middle of the road. Not bad, not great. 

The Curry Chicken and Mango Chicken were decent. However, this is the first Burmese place I've ever tried so maybe I just don't like the dishes in general.

I would recommend ordering in person. We ordered over the phone and had our ordered screwed up when we arrived. Either that or talk very, very slowly when you call.
author: Corbin C.

description:
Yamo was an experience.  The restaurant is as wide as a hallway and as short as an elephant.  You sit at the front of the kitchen so you feel the heat, smell the food, and see the fire.  When you receive your entree and take your first bite you know that you are getting quantity and quality for a good price.  Each entree is $6- max.  

I would recommend the tea salad, curry prawn (spicy), and Yamo house noodles, WITH GRASS JELLY TEA. 

MM-MMM.
author: Philina L.

description:
Yamo is a great place to go for a casual date or by yourself.  Just don't bring an entourage because the place is essentially a hole in the wall that can fit approximately nine people at any given time.  

Food:  4 stars.  I definitely will come back to try more dishes, but thought that the chicken noodle soup was excellent, especially for the price ($5.25, are you out of your mind?).  The soup is a hearty blend of coconut noodle soup with chicken, onions, and cilantro.  it was very flavorful, but don't expect it to be spicy.  The fresh coconut is interesting, but wasn't for me because of the aftertaste.

Service:  4 stars.  Kudos to the charmingly busy yet funny Chinese ladies that work behind the counter.  It may be hard to get their attention at times, but they are fun to watch at work and are friendly with anyone who strikes up a conversation with them.

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  The hole in the wall aspect is a bit charming, but the place is definitely a bit dirty looking.  The crowd can be eccentric at times.  For example, someone waiting in line for a seat started practicing qigong, an internal Chinese meditative practice which uses slow graceful movements similar to tai chi.  

Hits:   Chicken noodle soup.

Misses:  The crowd can be creepy and they're kooky, mysterious and spooky.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Burma Superstar, Rangoon, Nan Yang, Mandalay.
author: Keith C.

description:
From some of the reviews from Yelp, as well as my roommate, i've been meaning to check this place out in my hood for quite a while.  Well, like an overly hyped movie, it just didn't match my hopes and was totally blah. 

We got take out here on a rainy Friday night, but it wasn't as busy as most nights.  I had the House Noodles +chicken, and the g/f has the curry vegetables.  Both were surprisingly bland, and my noodles just tasted like grease.  I also got an order of the "samusas" which were just a little too deep fried, were only okay but came with a good sweet/spicy red sauce.  

Not sure if I came here on an "off" night, but i really don't get what all the rage is about.  Others tend to cite the "hole in the wall" vibe, which it has...but in the end you still want to eat something with flavor and not sopping with grease. I'll try it again since its about 100 feet from me, but simply put I make better food in my own kitchen.
author: Andrew K.

description:
This is the best place I've been to in a while. The place looks decrepit at the door, but in a way this is a blessing, because with about six seats in the place you need something to steer the fussy away if you want to cop a squat here.

And the seat is worth it: you get a ringside view of what have to be two of the hardest-working women in SF culinaria, knocking out delicious-looking dishes with brutal mastery of time, space, and ingredients.

I got an order of Samusa, which is served with that Thai hot-sweet sauce, and the Yamu Cold Noodles topped with sauteed chicken. Both were spicy and delicous.

I can't wait to go back and try something else: the place is so cramped that you're pretty much looking over everyone else's food, and it all looked good.
author: Karsten P.

description: Best Asian greasy spoon in the neighborhood.
author: C. H.

description:
wtf?

Why did i never see this place? Vegan friendly and just friendly in general. I had so much fun watching the grandmas cook. My friends tea bag (haha teabag) broke and one of the grandmas happily (like a jolly lil dumpling) got him another one. The food was great. Why? 1. no MSG. 2. fresh 3. cheap
author: Sunny Joy B.

description:
First off, it's best if you order the food to-go unless you want to wait in line outside!
I always order the house noodles with beef. Omgosh it's so yummy! I've tried some of the other stuff, but it's not all the great. If you're a new comer, definitely order the house noodles with beef! You will drool every time that comes to mind!
author: Sandy T.

description: Tasty (not amazing, but good) food for cheap. Served to bar seats right in front of the small, busy kitchen. Downside is that the place is small, but the upside is that it feels like a little room of authentic Asia right inside middle of the Mission.
author: Chris L.

description:
Think Soup Natzi from Seinfeld.

Check your ego at the front door. Enjoy a bowl of house noodles. Wash down the grease with some fresh coconut juice. And be thankful there are still a few establishments in the Mission that cater to the 'barely getting by' class.
author: Regina A.

description:
They know you and address you by your name. They remember my favorite dishes. They always welcome all my friends. All dishes are $5.25, large, colorful and great tasting. The tea leave salad, spring rolls are excellent apetizers. They have vegetarian dishes, house noodles, the large bowls of soups are a great and filling treat especially when the fog sets in. It is always busy and intimate...
Their Burmese kitchen is infused with Indian and Thai flavors. For $2.50 they open up a fresh coconut, which you can drink the refreshing water and then scoop out the luscious fresh coconut meat. 





Please read the street parking signs and don't get a ticket or worse get your car towed due to street cleaning while you're enjoying your affordable dinner.  Public Transportation is available  the #33, 49, 14 stop is right there and 16th St BART is two blocks away.
author: Tigre T.

description: Awesome little place that's easy to miss if you're walking by it on the street. The food has this home cooked flavor to it that is wonderful. I liked the atmosphere, the food, and the prices. A great spot.
author: Miller W.

description:
All I gotta say is that if you want authentic Burmese food, THIS IS THE PLACE, BABY! 

My whole family is from Burma and I grew up with homecooked Burmese food. Tried it, Love it. 

Get it TO GO because the place is small and seating is competitive.
author: Geneva X.

description:
This is my kind of place.... a total hole in the wall with just a counter to sit at and two ladies cooking hot fresh food. Amazing! This is the reason why I live in a city like San Francisco.

Yamo is a great take out option, and I  love it since it's a great Asian option that's close to my house. 

I've only been here once, and it was on a Monday afternoon so the place was empty. I can see how it can fill up quickly, though.

I had the tea leaf salad, house noodles with chicken and mango chicken. The tea leaf salad and mango chicken were great, but the house noodles weren't anything special. I will definitely be going back to check out the rest of the menu.
author: Keau K.

description:
If I were a cheerleader captain for this diner, I would use my pom-poms to holla: 

Go Yamo Go *clap*

Give me a Y for Yummy
Give me an A for Affordable
Give me a M for Meaty
Give me an O for Original

What does it spell?
YAMO - YAMO

**
This dinky hole-in-the-wall restaurant holds a special place in my heart.  

Yamo doesn't need any more business because through Yelp reviews, it already has a steady stream of diners who return for their unpretentious, cheap and tasty Burmese food.

With 8 to 10 bar stools, eating by the counter is like sitting in a dining room with three Burmese aunties you never had!

Your order is prepared and cooked in front of you as the friendly staff, scramble like busy bees pollinating from one flower to the next.

If you have never tried their food before, I would recommend some of my favorites:  tea leaf salad, mango salad, chicken curry w/ cold noodle, pot stickers, samosa, and a coconut drink.  Their entrees are only $5.25 and appetizers are about $3.

I would order to-go if you do not want to wait outside by the bus stop.  You may even experience some claustrophobia when your elbows rub against the next diner.  But hey that is part of the fun.

Just don't rub too close to me or else I am gonna think you are getting fresh with my pom-poms.
author: CT L.

description:
i really wanted to absolutely fall head over spring-rolls- IN- FUCKING-LOVE with this place. but alas, Yay! I'm JUST a fan. 

here's the deal. I LOVE hole in the wall restaurants and this fit the criteria: approx 5 seats, neighborhood where you could be stabbed, $0.50 in the decoration budget, lots of loud yelling in Burmese. 

we ordered the tea leaf salad, vegetarian spring rolls with tofu, and house noodles. the spring rolls were very bland and the peanut sauce tasted a little weird. ate none the less. obviously. the tea leaf salad was pretty good. the noodles were also pretty good. 

idk. i think i liked the idea of this place more than the food itself. mostly because of the women making the food in front of you and the location, and. stuff. 

bottom line is that i am going to be back and order other stuff off the menu.
author: Samantha G.

description:
3.5 stars. My friend and I were semi-wandering around the Mission looking for dinner since I already had a motive to try Yamo... When we were close, I excitedly said "ooo let's have some Burmese!" I'm slick like that. ;) As we approached the place, we realized it was probably cash only and I only had $3 in my wallet! Good thing there was an ATM close by. We were also lucky that someone seated by the only empty seat was leaving! We secured our spots and looked over the (VERY grimy) menu. The waitress if you'd like to call her that was very friendly and was patient with our indecisiveness. We ended up with:

Samosas - $3.50, This was actually the spiciest thing I had that night! It's fried right in front of you so it comes out fresh and hot. It's made with some kind of yam and spices but I honestly couldn't taste much because my tongue was in pain! 

Tea Salad - $5.25, It's cheaper but smaller than the ones you'd find in the Richmond District. It's also spicier. The ingredients weren't as colorful and fresh looking as I'm used to. I prefer more of the nutty taste so I was hoping for more sunflower seeds and peanuts. I'd probably skip this one next time.

Fresh Coconut Juice - $2.50, Pretty sure everyone has had one of these but that doesn't make it any less tasty! It's a real, young coconut with the top cut off served with a straw and a spoon so you can dig into the coconut meat after you finish the juice. I say it's way worth it since you could pay that much just for a coconut at the market. I'm also too afraid of trying this at home again. Coconut shells are like rocks!

Mango Chicken - $5.25, with your choice of house noodles or white rice. I got the noodles and they were quite tasty! They were eggy and chewy in the good way. My friend was surprised they had real mango chunks and they were big too! This dish also came with green peppers, bits of chili peppers (so more spice!) and big flavorful chicken chunks. It was good but this dish was also a bit greasy. 

I'm not a fan of spicy food, though I'm getting more tolerable. It helps when all your friends like spice and INSIST that THIS THE TIME I'm going to start liking it. Nope never happened. I still thought Yamo was above average but I wouldn't go out of my way to come back.
author: Julia T.

description: Get off your high horse. This place is rad. The food is made fast and couldn't be cheaper. $6 for every menu item (which includes tax!) is supremely cheap. I mean, don't get me wrong, there is NO ambiance and the noodle bar only seats about 8-10 people tops. During busier eating times call ahead to place a to-go order. I think I fell in love with this place when I went in and saw the gruffest of the three women working there wearing a classic Wolverine t-shirt. I died. This is totally the dive bar of Asian restaurants.
author: Phillip F.

description: My favorite noodle spot in San Francisco. Hands down. Atmosphere is unreal! I feel like I'm in the belly of a boat crossing the Pacific in the year 1900. Why? Maybe because the place is a shoebox & their storage is overhead and only accessible via a ladder attached to the wall. Kick ass. I will visit this place every time I am in the bay.
author: Marcus M.

description:
Oh Yamo, I did want to like you. And I did at first, when I got my house noodles with chicken. Flavorful and a good size. 

Then at 5 am, I awoke to the most violent, devastating case of food poisoning I've experienced in my life. Perhaps my punishment for taking the comments about greasy food too lightly. Or just terrible luck. In any case, I enjoyed the one and only thing I will ever have from Yamo, before my stomache decided it was toxic.
author: Christie C.

description:
I came here upon a friend's recommendation. He raved about this place saying it had the best chicken noodle soup and warned me that it was a hole in the wall place. 

When I got here, I realized that I can now say that I literally have been to a hole in the wall restaurant. The seating area is a bar right in front of their kitchen and prep area, so you feel all the heat and oil on you as you wait and eat. You have to wait in line and then grab a seat whenever someone leaves. When we sat down, I waited 5 minutes before asking one of the 3 ladies for a menu. She rudely threw it at us. We decided to order the cold noodles, chicken noodle soup, tea leaf salad, and spring rolls. The spring rolls were given to us with plates and utensils rudely thrown at us after. They were okay and the sauce was interesting. The tea leaf salad was really interesting and quite tasty & spicy. The cold noodles were spicy and was not good at all. My boyfriend just ended up eating all the chicken and left everything else which is surprising because he is a huge fan of noodles. My chicken noodle soup was mediocre also. The coconut soup was really light and it was actually pretty boring to eat after a couple bites. We left unsatisfied and with terribly rude customer service.
author: Syd T.

description:
i was kind of upset that i didn't plan ahead and i wore a nice jacket.  this place is GREASY!  wear stuff that's easily washable.  but great for the price, flavorful, and i didn't have to wait (i went at 6:30ish on a weekday)

tea leaf salad - burma superstar's is better.
house noodle with beef - really flavorful, but so greasy.
chicken curry - spicy, so i only had 1/2 a bite.
author: Maggie L.

description: This place kicks ass. There's like 8 stools on a bar top or you can get take out. Waited 10-15 mins for seats and totally worth it. A unique experience with 3 little Burmese ladies staffing the "kitchen" behind the bar top and cook up simple burmese/chinese grub. The house noodles with chicken stole the show and only $6. The potstickers were plump and crispy on the outside. Samusas were filled with potato and curry and were just ok. The prawn & veggie curry had a deep sweet and sour colored sauce, with a light curry hint...delicious. We each took an order of house noodles to go after our meal and it was still only $32. Will be back for sure.
author: Adrian S.

description:
So-so Burmese food, but über greasy

Combined review from two visits.

DISHES:
Tea leaf salad
$6
It looked like a small wad of spicy salad toppings. Was there suppose to be lettuce or greens in it? If so, the ladies forgot that part. Everything was heavily fried, and I couldn't discern the tea leaves. All I tasted was fried garlic and crunchiness that oozed oil.

House noodles with chicken
$6
Noodles are thick chow mein noodles like those in the Shanghai fried noodle dish. Chicken was fine, not dry for slices of white meat. Also had onion, but not much else. So oily... 

Mango chicken
$6
Nicely cooked chicken slices, some chucks of mango paired with rice. Pretty spicy, but not detracting from the dish. This seemed less greasy than the other dishes


AMBIANCE: Hole in the wall with Chinese-speaking ladies, quickly taking orders and cooking in parallel. Limited stool seating facing them. Most people call in to order, then walk over in 10-15 mins to pick it up. It's just not comfortable to eat there. I bet it gets miserably hot during warm weather too.

SERVICE: So-so. It's slightly confusing to order, because you have to flag down a lady. Feels like placing an order at a bar, getting the bartender's attention over people seated at the bar.

VISIT DETAILS: Take-out dinner with a friend most recent time, seat-down the previous time (probably took 20-30 mins wait to get two seats during dinner time)
author: C L.

description: Nothing special, just cheap regular Chinese Burmese food.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Love this place and the wonderful women that own and work so hard to make great food. 

They have limited counter seating and you will most often find people waiting in line outside, but it is worth the wait. This is a whole in the wall place; they don't have room for tables. 

Each dish is custom made and you'll be able to see them work their magic since they prepare each dish right in front of you. Everyone I share this place with loves their food and go back often. 

Did I forget to tell you the food is yummy? Try the Tea Leaf Salad.
author: Buddy M.

description:
It's not the classiest joint, or the quietest, but the food is sooo yummy you'll want to keep coming back despite any other deterrents.  I love their noodles and curries, and my mom (who grew up in Burma) says their Catfish Chowder is some of the best she's tasted since she moved to the States...

In summary: really delicious Burmese food.  I'm sold.
author: Lucinda W.

description:
hole in the wall with an open kitchen and now a $6 menu for 2011.
