order the tea leaf salad which barely had any tea leaf, but what can u expect for the price (it was a smidgeon)  however the take on this version was more tangy and slightly spicy.  the samusas were ok, deep fried, potatoey, and slightly spicy.  ordered a chicken curry--the curry had a lot of those soft fried potatoes.  the nice thing about it was that it wasn't sweet, more salty savory.  still a deal, but not something I'd be seeking out compared to other burmese options
author: Rob C.

description:
Literally a hole in the wall "Burmese" eatery. The door opens up into a narrow "hall" that is only wide enough to let one person (I'm talking about a size10 max person... well below the US weight/size average of 163lbs/size14) to squeeze past, bounded by a wall on the right, and a narrow counter top/seats lining the left. Three Burmese ladies man the kitchen space, which is immediately behind the counter: One is in charge of all wok related cooking, one takes orders and prepares ingredients for the wok lady, and the last one takes orders and cleans up after patrons.

Yamo is very simple and straight forward. You wait for a spot to open up, order your food from a limited (but extremely cheap) menu, watch your food being cooked, chow down, pay the bill, and leave. I highly doubt that it is authentic Burmese food... it tastes very Chinese to me. However, it IS very much homestyle cooking, which is nice, especially since nothing costs over $6. Pictured below is the "Yamo noodles"... regarded quite highly on yelp, but turned out to be a bit of a bland disappointment. If I lived in the Mission, I would probably return to Yamo for it's cheap and easy eats.
author: Susanna W.

description:
Don't worry about the divey appearance or the fact that a soccer team would have trouble getting seating.  Don't be too intimidated by the gruff, unsmiling trio of ladies that whip up the food in no time. Yamo is a no frills, good eats at a good price, type of place. You could tell that by the number of broke looking, trust fund Mission hipsters that pick up their to-go orders.  Time it right and you can find one of ten seats in the place.  We happened to go on a weekday around 12:15. I guess everyone waited to avoid the lunch crowd. Sucks for them b/c they all showed up at 1pm! 

As for the food, it's all about the house noodles. I tried the pork (good, but the beef looked like it had that glazed, salty, saucy appearance I always crave) and my friend asked for the noodles and tofu (not on menu). The noodles are perfectly cooked and textured from wherever they bought them (I assume - they were uniformly piled in stacked bowls). The resulting broth/gravy/sauce that hits the bottom is heaven's nectar.  Watch the cook seamlessly mix the dozen or so ingredients (topped by some fried garlic flakes! Yow!). Just don't look too closely if you're paranoid about Health Department scores (I don't recall seeing one...). Let's put it this way: it was good food, at a great-for-SF price, I didn't get sick, and I enjoyed the experience.
author: Erick K.

description: I love this place! it doesn't try to be anything that it's not. Quick, tasty and wildly entertaining with tiny long cramped bar seating and bustling women with flaming frypans who'll serve you up a fresh coconut with an unimpressed attitude.
author: Hemmie L.

description: Great bang for the buck and very fast service, assuming you can get in the door. Although all the main dishes I've had have been too oily, they're always tasty. The ladies who work there are the grumpiest humans ever! But you don't come here to make friends with them. Minus one star for not taking credit and for not having beer.
author: Ben R.

description: Soooo delicious.  i love the cold house noodles and the black bean tofu.  dont go there with a big group or you will wait forever.
author: Scott L.

description:
Yamo is the bomb.

This place is tiny, maybe 10 seats at a counter. 

Samosas, tea leaf salad and the house pan fried noodles FTW.

Taking food togo is sometimes a good idea when there's a line for those 10 seats.
author: Mark R.

description:
The yumminess and price ratio is just unbeatable! The place looks cheap and needs a long wait but it's worth it! The food is really yummy and authentic (one precious note: it's spicy for those who can't take hot foods). The service is okay (they cook in front of you and bring foods to you, nothing fancy).

I highly recommend it except for those who care ambiance/interior of the restaurant.
author: Lo Y.

description: 6$ for anything you eat. Excellent value for money. The food tastes good  and the whole experience of waiting outside to eat at this small run down place makes it all the more exciting. Forget the service, enjoy the taste and the experience.
author: Chetan K.

description:
"Yamo be there...up and over" (random Michael McDonald reference...always wanted to quote him on Yelp!)

I may have found a time that Yamo isn't AS crowded as usual...Tuesday night at 5:45...when its raining...and BART is having service issues...and the stars are perfectly aligned...

Yes, Yelpers love this place.  Its cheap.  The food is amazing.  Tealeaf salad. House noodles.  Done and done.  

Don't come if you're claustrophopic, get sketched out by a poorly lit closet masquerading as a kitchen, expecting stellar service, unwilling to wait, want a place to have long drawn-out conversations with friends.  

Grab your food, scarf it down, and go...make room for the rest of us...

(minus 1 star for the 36-hour heartburn afterwards...so worth it...)
author: Susan L.

description: The food was awful! I asked for the fish curry and they ran out. Instead I ordered the tofu curry. It was brown & flavorless. I feel like I'm going to be sick:( also is the price $6. Well I got charged $7. Don't waste your time on this hole in the wall. Yuck!
author: Jennifer M.

description:
3.5 stars

I stumbled upon this restaurant when I was blog surfing. This past weekend, my boyfriend and I ventured down mission to find this hole in the wall. The food is absolutely delicious but you WILL have to wait awhile (depending on the number of cooks working and the line of customers) for it. When we arrived, there were 3 female cooks working their butts off for a small line. The place itself can hold maybe 10 sitting customers and the rest order to go. There's no order when serving their customers and it seemed like it's easy for them to forget your order, especially when there's a long line of customers. 

Anyway, my boyfriend and I hadn't eaten all day and we ordered the tea salad, mango chicken, and yamo house noodles with chicken. (You can also order fresh coconut drink, which they will cut up open for you on the spot!) The mango chicken with rice was very good. It didn't feel heavy in your stomach and the vegetables were pretty fresh. My favorite was the tea salad. I didn't see them make it but I think they have this mixture of nuts or something that goes really well with the salad. The house noodles were super garlicky and it was good! 

This is a good place to eat if you have a lot of patience waiting for food but I suggest not to go during lunch rush.
author: Faye F.

description:
Yamo house noodles w/beef. For $5.25. Seriously. That's all you need to know.

Also...curry chicken, potstickers and samusas....YUMYUMYUM.

It's tiny, the wait is forever and there is no parking. Save yourself a headache and call ahead with your order for pick-up. Come in 30 minutes versus the 15 minutes they tell you, pick up the yummy, sesame oil-drenched noodle goodness and eat from the comforts of your home. You will be much happier if you do.
author: Adrienne C.

description:
What is wrong with you people?! Four stars?! C'mon, my grandma can cook up better food than this joint and she's not even that great! 

Came here with my boy toy and lucky us we didn't have to wait for 2 out of the 8 seats there total. This is truly a hole in the wall eatery. I love it! Great place to rub elbows with strangers, profess your love of cock sauce to the whole table, watch the women behind the counter cook up a fire and hear them yell in Cantonese (not Burmese as someone else stated) about how the bills are all mixed up. 

The lady recommended we get the mango chicken. A MISTAKE! Everyone knows that one of the basic rules in cooking is to season the food. What I got was a plate of uber blandness. At least the chicken was tender. I was tempted to pour soy sauce all over my dish and mind you, I rarely do such a foolish thing. 
Where was the spice in our spicy curry tofu?! Where was that rich, the extra kick in flavor that usually accompanies curry? It wasn't there. It was all forgettable. Took me almost an hour to even remember what we ordered...
The only good thing that I got out of it was how I paid under $15 for the entire bill. If you're solely looking for a cheap-eat place, this is it. If you're looking for real 'Asian' cuisine, try some place else. 

I'm a believer in second chances, I might give this place another shot and try their fish soup as someone else mentioned...
author: Emily Y.

description:
My new favorite hole in the wall...right here in the Mission! Where else can you get  2 big fresh summer rolls with shrimp for $3.50, dinner entrees for $5.25 (fish/shrimp/tofu...doesn't matter...they won't charge you a couple of extra $ for seafood!), and top it off with fresh coconut juice? Plus, the food is cooked right in front of you, so you know you aren't eating thawed stuff! 

We tried the curry fish (fried fish pieces sauteed with veggies in curry sauce) and curry vegetables with noodles. Both tasted great - noodles were a tad oily though, and don't be surprised if the "curry" dishes have no curry in them (like Thai curries). I was concerned about the fish quality, but hey, I lived to write this review with no stomach upsets! Also, loved that the veg curry had okra. 

The place is small - it's like a little food bar - you seat yourself based on available space, and sit facing the chefs. The ladies who run the place look like they enjoy what they are doing, and IMO, that makes the food better! They are friendly though - make eye contact & smile, and you'll be surprised. However, don't expect much conversation with them...it may look like a bar, but they sure are not chatty. The food rocks, is served fast, and they will not rush you to finish, even though the line outside is a half block long.
author: Shweta V.

description:
Yamo is yummy!! (& cash only)

For under 6 bucks you can get really really good noodles or fried rice with the experience of having it cooked in front of your eyes. Two ladies behind the counter are good at what they do. She gives you enough time to go over the menu but very prompt at taking the order. 

I tried samusas and house_noodles with chicken, and ordered a shrimp_fried_rice to go. I've seen long line in front of it earlier but I got there early today and had great food without having to wait!!
author: A K.

description:
I'm such a fan of this place.
It's like a  on-again-off-again lover you keep 
them on the DL for a bit. Sometimes you swear off
carbs, or cut back on extra fats,
But  you always come back for more.
They know exactly what you like and you're never disappointed.
It's a little messy sometimes, maybe even greasy but you always 
leave satiated. The saucy ladies that run the place, take their 
time to come to you  they yell at each other and maybe even 
at the customers. No harm intended, just the way it is, as if they 
are yelling at children in their living room. And that's exactly how it 
feels, like you are sitting in the living room at the house of your 
Burmese auntie waiting for a home cooked meal. 
My faves:
tea leaf salad(spicy sour/salty goodness)
catfish chowder(spicy, brothy yum)
curry fish w/rice(yummy, yum,yum)

I suggest calling ahead for pick up. This tiny place gets packed
and the wait can be upwards of 20 minutes. Any of the above items
are great for takeout. But while all of the curry noodle dishes
are great eaten in the restaurant, but sometimes they lack enough
sauce and can be on the dry side when ordered to go. . .
author: Kia B.

description: Great noodles and food. There might be a wait but the food at the end of this experience is completely worth it. Food is delicious and fresh, the price is unbeatable and the location is on my way home. I could not ask for more.
author: Analise T.

description:
Roughly the size of a postage stamp, this place is so busy no one goes there anymore.  You are only paying for one thing here: food.  The decor is akin to eating in the basement of your messy friend's house, with red painted walls, a long counter with bar stools for seats and a fridge in the corner.  

All the magic happens right before you as the three women behind the counter cook your order.  The food was very good and flavorful.  

For $5.25 an entree, it is probably one of the best deals in town.  

Only downside is that our food came in the strangest order.  First one entree, then the appetizer, then the second entree.  Weird.
author: Eric M.

description:
Four stars for being cheap, and close to my house, and not a burrito joint. 

Because really, this is the ONLY cheap eats option in that area of the Mission that's not a burrito joint, except pizza or cheesesteaks, and I don't  eat cheese, so there's that!

So the fact that I can get a tea leaf salad three blocks away for less than ten bucks is FOUR STARS, all by itself. Doesn't matter that I really have no opinion about anything else here...

I very rarely eat IN Yamo. I'm not going to wait 45 minutes to sit at a counter. Fxxx that. I can walk home in less than ten and sit at my kitchen table.

I very rarely order much else, except the Yamo noodles, special-ordered with tofu, because I also don't eat chicken. Or beef. Or pork. And that's pretty much what this place is about. The menu is small, like the counter. Small and meaty. The Yamo noodles = okay. The Mandalay special noodles are like a zillion times better.

But THANK YOU, Yamo, for bringing some MUCH NEEDED variety into my life in the meat- and dairy-laden Mission, and at an affordable price. For that, you get four stars.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Tea Leaf Salad, and Samosas!
 
Like a pregnant lady with pickles, or a junkie with rocks, I am a Burmese food fiend. 

Who would guess fermented tea leaves would taste so good? . 

Yamo provides Gary Danko meals at Taco Bell prices. 


 I highly flipping suggest getting your booty over there if you have not already.


I always take an order to go too!
author: Gina K.

description:
What a find!

Had a free hour between wedding this and wedding that while on a trip to SF, and wanted to go to one of my old faves Minako.  Unfortunately it was not open, and I already paid the meter.  

So I walk around and find this Bourdain-esque hole-in-the-wall lunch counter.  I swear there are only 10 seats here.  The two Burmese ladies were working furiously.  Looked good to me.  So I wait a few minutes for a seat and sit down.

"Can I get the mushrooms and tofu?"  She nods.  "Is that spicy?"
"No."
"Can I get it spicy?"
"No."
Guess I'll just use the sriracha.  She seems like she knows what she's doing so I don't get too worried.  Thought when i see those zigzag-cut carrots and broccoli in this allegedly Burmese dish, my heart sinks.  I think I'm in for some intestinal distress, but go ahead anyways.  With sriracha of course.

The sauce is actually really good!  and the enoki was cut in a new way to me, they didn't separate it out that much, so it didn't disintegrate, and actually turned out really spot on.  

I wish I could try all the other dishes.  Too bad I moved away.  But a really good place.  Plus you can't beat the prices.
author: Nessie V.

description:
I was a little confused by the cooks behind the counter speaking Taiwanese-Mandarin and Cantonese, which kind of took away from the seeming authenticity of the place.

Waited a while to get seated given the small space and the relatively substantial patrons. Ordered the cold noodles and friend ordered the house noodles -- interesting ingredients and open kitchen, but honestly a little too heavy and greasy and didn't taste all that different from how I would expect general Chinese food to taste. Might give it a second shot, might not.
author: Chieh T.

description:
I can't believe I waited until my last night in SF to try this place... and it was literally right below my apartment. Everyone I had met in the Mission raved about this place, but truth be told, I'm not a big Burmese food fan (which is essentially Chinese food with a big kick). I decided to finally give this joint a shot and boy, HOW I REGRET NOT EATING THIS MORE OFTEN! It's greasy and flavorful and most importantly, SPICY! One of the major perks besides the quick service is that everything on the menu is less than six dollars. Yes, you read correctly. 

ATTN (strict) VEGETARIANS! 
I am quite sure they use the same pots and utensils to cook their non-vegetarian items.
author: Kristy H.

description: The food is bomb and so fresh! The place is super tiny and can only seat like seven people on barstools. The menu is pretty short but good noodle dishes. You won't want to eat there - TRUST ME - it's hot and the smoke from the grill is all in your face. Get it to go.
author: C C.

description:
Love love love the Mo Hing Nga (fish chowder) and the house noodles. Prepare to wait if going for lunch. There's probably less than 10 bar seats in there. The ladies that work there are quick. Guess to get you in and out of there. Kind of a greasy spoon, but those are generally the best places! 

Yummy Burmese food in the Mission. Whoodathunk?
author: Carolyn J.

description: Yamo is still great. But they did raise their prices. Used to be able to get a entree for $5.25. Now its $6. Still cheap but since they only take cash, I was almost a little short on my last visit...
author: Michelle L.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place.  The food is fresh and delicious, cooked right in front of you-- literally 5 feet from the only seating in this tiny joint.  Everything is made to order, and they'll allow you to swap ingredients.

The 3 women who run Yamo are as wonderful as the food.  It feels as though they've invited you into their home for some of their favorite dishes.
 
I'm very glad one of my coworkers told me about this place.  And like everyone else, I'm selfishly leaving out the last star :)
author: Zuzzi E.

description: No way!!! This place is adorable! Three cute old asian ladies cooking right across as you sit at the bar. It's like you're hovering in the kitchen or sitting at the kitchen island as your mom makes food and then eat it hot and fresh right as it comes off the stove.
author: Kaushal P.

description: Went here a few days ago for my second time with a friend from LA. We had the vegetable curry and were both satisfied. She was slightly alarmed by the grease on the wall but, otherwise, this is a fantastic, cheap local spot. The man next to us told us he was from Burma, an affirmation that Yamo attracts not only collegiate foodies on a budget but also customers who really know Burmese cuisine.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
Had the fish chowder and tried the house noodle - absolutely delicious.  Went by myself, but had a great time chatting with the other very friendly diners; even shared food.  

Pros:
- authentic and flavourful
- cheap - $5.25
- family owned and run

Cons:
- may be a wait, since there are only ~dozen seats - goes quickly though

Yeah, the service is like a typical small hole in the wall (i.e. they may not notice you), but with food that delicious and cheap, I've got no problem with it!
author: Marco C.

description: Not sure what all the hype is about. Yes, the prices are amazing ($6 for a square meal in the city, whaaat.) Yes, it has that tiny, grungy vibe of a cool, under-the-radar spot in New York. Yes, it has the requisite grouchy proprietors (all the cool places do.) But the bottom line is, the food wasn't great. I had the house noodles with beef, and my bf had the mango chicken and tea leaf salad. The only above average part of our meals was the beef in the noodle dish. It was perfectly seasoned and shockingly tender. But the noodles themselves were too soft and not very flavorful--like overcooked instant ramen before you add in the flavor packet. I actually had to add soy sauce to punch up the flavor, and I'm not one of these salt monsters that have to add salt to everything, often even before they take a first bite. It just wasn't that impressive.  A+ ambience though. You may call it smoky, cramped, and a little bit dirty, but that, friends, was my favorite part.
author: Elise T.

description:
A strange friend of mine took me on a foodie date and Yamo was our first stop. We ordered fresh coconut, samusas and the mango salad. I have gone back since and ordered the same. I don't know much about Burmese but I do know that this is a chiller spot! It reminds me of Art's Cafe on Irving. Cheap, tasy hole in the wall... and who run it? Little Burmese women. Girl Power!!!!!!!!!!!!

Oh by the way, there is a wait and it can be brutal at times... Try venturing out during the week at an odd hour.
author: Janice K.

description:
I was lucky enough to have a burmese friend who's mom always had some delicious burmese food cooking in the kitchen every time I came over. 

And now since i can't free load anymore... I was lucky enough to find this little place. Cheap, yummy, and quick. And after a large meal... head over to bi rite creamery for some ice cream and a walk in doloras park to end your night. Life does not get any better than that....
author: Charlie L.

description: The house noodles with beef are terrific. Service is minimal, seating is limited with maybe nine seats but this is a terrific place to grab a quick lunch at a very reasonable price.
author: Jeff Z.

description:
My daughter and I checked out there first, ordered the fish chowder and fish with black bean sauce, they were flavorful.

The second time I felt brave enough to take my husband alone.  He is the final critic of the house, AKA Anton Ego.  My daughter had the house noodles, we all liked it.  I like my fish curry, I thought it was tasty.  My husband did not like his order, the mango chicken, and  commented the sauce tasted like dish wash water.  

I analyzed and realized the cause, the kitchen is setup on the other side of the bar, cook uses 3 or 4 woks to prepare dishes.  She did not and could not wash the woks after cooking each dish.  As there is no faucet or sink she can use as far as I can tell.

I don't mind, this seems to make the dishes more flavorful, Anton is willing to give it another chance, house noodles for him next time, so I can have my meal in peace.
author: jen j.

description:
What a great little hole in the wall! I passed by it about 4 times expecting a restaurant to show up before I realized that the 10 stools at the counter was the extent of it. 

The food is pretty good and fresh, but not amazing. What is amazing is the fact that lunch for two including 2 appetizers came out to $21 after a good tip!
author: Nick H.

description:
Discovered this place while listening to NPR with Broke-Ass Stuart S. talking about the best places to eat.  Cheap?  Good eats?  I'm there.

Trying to find Yamo is like trying to find a door into the fourth dimension.  You walk to the correct cross section.  Peer out for any signs.  Circle around in place.  Finally you head back to the starting place assuming that you just missed it.  Then you ask yourself, "Does this place even exist?"

As I stood scratching my head in confusion I peered at a little craggily black storefront that looks to be condemned.  The windows of the door are posted up with newspaper clippings and awards.  Oh wait, I found it!

After observing the business hours, I entered Yamo with curious eyes.  Just how "hole in the wall" is this place?  Well on a meter of 10 it's probably an 8.  I've been to worse but this isn't Gary Danko's.

The restaurant is essentially one part long counter with bar stools, one part open kitchen -- that's it.  In the back is a little crevice with a wooden ladder leading up to who knows where.  One regular refrigerator sits in the corner and another window refrigerator sits across from the counter.  It's a very basic eating experience that is perfect for a quick eat; however, not for the wheelchair bound, children, dog owners, or people who can't sit up on bar stools.

I was the only customer here yet it was a quite loud.  The refrigerator or something made a long thumping sound and stopped after awhile.  The two ladies talk to each other in yelling pitch cantonese.  It's kinda funny how loud this place is after you get used to it.

I asked for a recommendation and the lady advise me to have the "Cold Noodles".  The dish is like a spicy noodle salad served with temperature hot chicken.  It also has spring onion, cilantro, cucumber, carrots, and bean sprouts.  The dish isn't as fire hot as I expected yet it was just spicy enough that I could still taste my food while getting a kick.  Even so, if you don't like spicy food don't get this dish as my nose started to run profusely and I needed to resort to my can of 7-Up constantly.  Portions are just right.  I wasn't too stuffed but rather on the verge of being so.

Talking to the staff was fun.  They're really friendly and open for chit chat.  They said that a sign was supposed to be put up during winter break but the "guy" didn't come around.  Regular customers don't want the sign to go up so they can have the place all to themselves.  Selfish pigs! lol

My dish was really good but not out of the ballpark great.  It tastes like good ol' home cooking, nothing wrong with that.  I think I've only had Burmese food a couple other times so it was good finding another place.  The staff recommends the soup and curries as some of their most popular dishes.  I asked myself, "Then why am I eating 'cold noodles'?"

___

I'd definitely come back to try out more of the fairly priced menu.
author: Michael H.

description: Ok this place is a hole in the wall in a semi shady neighborhood, but don't let that scare you away. Isn't the old saying the best restaurants are hole in the walls? Well Yamo is one of those places that has good tasting Burmese food. The prices are out of this world! SUPER CHEAP. The only thing I dislike is the long wait to get in because of the small location. Overall if your in the city this is one of those hot spots to checkout.
author: Matthew L.

description:
hole in the wall, neighborhood gem, ... call it what you want, this place is amazing and a must try.  I recommend trying everything on the menu but if you need someone to start you off, try: tea leaf salad, samosa, spring rolls, or pot stickers as an appetizer, and house noodles or black bean fish as an entree.  All appetizers are $3.25 and entrees are $5.25.  

There is a bit of a language barrier thus service does suffer a little bit but who cares when food is this good!
author: LIVE to E.

description: Amazing amazing amazing. Best Asian food in the city and for the best price!
author: Tyler J.

description: Good thing about this restaurant is it is cheap. It is a overrated restaurant with resemblance of food I used to find in the night market in Taiwan. Can't taste anything after I ate. Had to eat lots of bread to wash off everything. Excess spices garlic and grease.
author: Eric L.

description:
Seriously? What's up with the lemming hipsters??? Though claiming to be Burmese, this is basically greasy Chinese food at its worst. 

Yeah, it's cheap, yeah it's got character (it's really popular with the hipsters).  But for those of us who like to enjoy tasting good food, I cannot recommend this restaurant. Pay a few bucks more at another Burmese restaurant and get 100% better food. 

We tried a few dishes that people recommended to get a broad sampling. All were awful. As a friend of mine joked: "they use seven spices and they're all salt and pepper."
author: Aaron N.

description:
Came here last Saturday because my girlfriend wanted to try it. It's just a few blocks from the BART station but we had to walk through a pretty dirty and smelly portion of the Mission. I'm not sure I would have found it if I hadn't seen a picture of it before we came. Anyway, we arrived around 3pm and didn't have trouble finding a couple stools at the bar (there's only 10). 

Ordered the tea salad, mango chicken and Yamo house noodles with chicken. The tea salad was the standout of the three dishes. Nutty and crunchy. My house noodles were sort of bland but perked up when I added some hot sauce. The cooks were generally inattentive and the service was fairly slow. But you can't beat the $5.25 price for entrees!

Summary: 3.5/5 stars rounded down
+Tea salad
+Price
-Slow service
-Limited seating
author: Daniel M.

description:
Yamo is the hole in the hole in the wall. Yes, it's so small you'll probably miss it if you blink. Nicole and I probably walked a good 2 blocks past it when we were trying to go there.

It's greasy, spicy, probably high in fat and cholesterol Burmese fast food, but it's yummy! The ladies that work there speak little English, and the cheap menu is no nonsense. If you can score one of the 8 seats at the counter, enjoy watching them prepare your food in minutes. Call ahead for take-out in case the place is packed. 

I had the Yamo house noodles with chicken and had some of the tea leaf salad. Each bite packs a punch, so don't be surprised if you start tearing up.
author: Connie C.

description:
Yamo, a tiny, hipster-infested hole-in-the-wall that wouldn't look out of place in Mos Eisley. According to my Burmese girlfriend, the food has been a bit Americanized and she had little critiques here and there about Yamo. How they skimp you on tea leaves in the tea leaf salad. How Chinese tasting everything was. But hell, I didn't care because I was busy scarfing down whatever richly-flavored thing the staff put in front of me. My taste buds were applauding the flavor explosion.

My favorite was the chicken curry over pan-fried noodles. It's goddamn delicious and that's the potatoes' fault. They were the best. I do have to say that Pagan in the Richmond does a better tea leaf salad but this one isn't bad.

Yeah, you have to stand in line for quite a while only to be seated on a very cramp bar seat. But that's part of the whole experience of Yamo, and it's just the way I like it.
author: Derek L.

description:
I eat here once a week so basically this is like my other kitchen!  I almost always get the same thing: coconut soup with tofu or black bean tofu with noodles. 
Man I wish that they would deliver...or have some sort of take out system that was efficient...but I guess both of those would take away from the overall charm and unique experience that is Yamo.
author: Jessie H.

description:
Yum yum yum. Tried to come here two other times (once closed, once there was a line) and glad I finally made it. I thought there'd be a line Saturday at 1pm but there were at least three available stools. There are a total of ten bar stools, in case anyone was wondering. The menu items seem to range from $3.50 to $6ish. 

We ordered the samusas (potato and spice fried goodness) - you get 6 small triangles for $3.50. Then we had the mango chicken and house noodles with beef. It wasn't the most flavorful burmese food I've ever had, but it was still damn good for the price. I wish the house noodles had some sauce. Even after thoroughly mixing, it mostly just tasted like stir fried noodles with really good beef. They should use whatever they marinate the beef with for the sauce. They also have fresh coconut!! We ordered one ($2.50) and they cut it open and gave us a straw for the coconut water and a spoon to scoop out the coconut flesh. Dee-lish! All in all a very yummy satisfying meal, and the pre-tip total came to $16.50! Would def go back to try the other dishes on the menu.
author: Humaira M.

description:
Free food is good food.

Cheap food comes in a close second to free food.

I have not yet completely shed habits from my poor student days and at times still crave the meals that can fill my belly for under ten dollars...regardless of how good the food actually tastes. And despite how the food really tastes, I still enjoy it. Why? Well like I said free (cheap) food is good food.

Yamo fares on the side of better tasting food on my list of cheap food! Their tea leaf salad is amazing (though small in portion, which makes me sad) and I also enjoy their chicken noodle soup (not at all your standard chicken noodle soup...think chicken, noodles, curry soup) and their fish chowder. Their curries are pretty tasty and come with choice of noodles or rice. And the best part...two people filled with Burmese-y-Chinese food for 20 bucks. Burmese-y-Chinese, you ask? The three ladies that are behind the counter of this ten seater hole in the wall are Chinese ladies that lived in Burma. Mmm, just like Mom used to make...if Mom was a Chinese lady that lived in Burma.
author: Christine L.

description:
my boyfriend popped my burmesefoodcherry @ yamo.. and i must say it was GOOOODD..

we like to use yelp to find new spots for us to eat at.. and he found this yummy hole in the wall.. like seriously.. i woulda never stopped by here to eat even with the LONG line of folks waiting..... so thanks Yelpers!!

i was always taught to never judge a book by it's cover... standing just in front, it's not the looker.. but the food is mosdef worth the wait!! we got there around 730 on a wednesday night.. and we waited about 15 minutes.. and even when we finally got seated.. there were 6 other people waiting behind us in the cold.. :(

we ordered the much raved about Tea Leaf Salad which was AWESOME.. i love spicy.. so this made dish definitely made me happy.. i just wish they gave us more!!  we also ordered the house garlic noodles with beef?! i thought it was just ok.. and we also ordered the samosas.. which were YUMMMMM.. 

everything was about $6 a plate so our total meal came to about $25.. A DEF "PLUS" in my book esp with how low funds are for us.. 

the only reason i gave it 4 stars instead of 5 is because of the lack of seating like others have stated.. it's just a counter.. with about 7-8ish stools which face the lovely ladies cooking everything FRESH!!! i like when i can see my food being prepared.. imma huge germaphobe.. and these ladies were very clean and very very cute and kind!!!

service yay! food YAAY! cost yay! YAY YAMO!!! :) 


i will MOSDEF order for take out next time!!
author: Lisa Marie N.

description: 900 Reviews? What more can be said other than the food and atmosphere are sublime.  However, I have walked past on a few occassion when the line was too long.  As wonderful as this place may be, I cannot justify waiting too long for a seat.  Your best bet is to dine solo or with just one other.  It's a small space with limited seating, so not advised for groups beyond three people.
author: Charlie B.

description:
Me amo Yamo.

A friend took me here yesterday and I fell in love.  
We walked in around 4pm on a Monday and magically there were 2 seats waiting for us.
It's a cute little hole in the wall with awesome red walls run by some crazy, crazy hard-working women yelling at each other about something.  (I'm convinced they were talking shit about me, but ya know....)

They only have about 6 stools at the counter to sit and you get to watch them cook up some delicious-ness.
We had the spring rolls, samusas, mango chicken, some delicious crunchy salad thing, and 2 bottles of bottled coke. (HELLS YES for bottled Mexican coke which always tastes like heaven!)
We only spent $20 on everything.  Great portions, great prices, great atmosphere.  AWESOME.

I would definitely come back here and hope that those 2 vinyl stools are waiting for me next time.
author: Andrea F.

description: I am truly in LOVE with their tea leaf salad. Everything else is pretty good too. Great prices. Service is very basic, those ladies mean business! A fair trade for good food at great prices.
author: Claire b.

description: this is a must try whole in the wall.  I've got to say, with $6 you can get some pretty bomb garlic noodles.  This place is super tiny and cash only ... seats about 10 people.  So I'm guessing usually there's a wait.  We came here on like a 3 pm on a tuesday and there's still about a 10 minute wait, but some people seem to just callin their order or order at the counter so they dn't have to wait to sit.  We tried their garlic yamo house chicken noodle.  Perfect balance of garlic, chicken and whatever else they put in :D
author: Stephanie C.

description: It may be a hole in the wall...but the flavors are OUTSTANDING! The Tea Leaves Salad and the House Noodles are DELICIOUS!
author: Terrence Q.

description:
i LOVE the chicken noodle soup - thicker egg noodles, with deliciously sauteed chicken, red onion and parsley in a not-too-spicy coconut milk broth. ONLY $5.25. they also have some awesome samosas for only $3.5. cant beat the price. 

its tiny and there is usually a wait.
author: Yevi A.

description:
I have a few reviews for Yamo, all of them positive, but nothing I could easily weave into an easily digestible narrative.

I think that eating at Yamo is technically less expensive than buying food, preparing it yourself, and eating at home.

Eating at Yamo is like having dinner made for you by your crazy aunts, provided you're Burmese and your aunts cook really well.

Every time I eat at Yamo I feel like I'm eating at one of the million hole-in-the-wall joints in Brooklyn. You know the ones: they're cramped and hot and surly but the food is sublime.

If you eat at Yamo, the combination of the in the capsacium in the condiments, the carbs in the noodles (I know they have rice, too, but when given the option, who gets rice?), and the warmth of the kitchen will all make you want to pass out into food coma and you will sleep like a peaceful Burmese Baby.

If Yamo was in my neighborhood, I'd be grossly obese. I'm seconds from taking a nap.
author: jason l.

description:
Holy flurking snit, Yamo - where have you three lovely ladies been all my life!!

"Samusas" were tasty though nothing like a samosa, and the yamo house special noodle with beef was absolutely delicious. I can hardly wait to eat my way through the rest of the menu. Cheap and hot and fresh as hell, plus you get a free cooking class while you wait.

Crazy that the best intersection in the city for foodies right now is 18th and Mission!

The atmosphere at Yamo makes me feel like I'm Harrison Ford as Decker slurping noodles in "Blade Runner."

Avoid the shrimp dishes because as Dwight Schrute says, "You know that line on top of the shrimp? That's feces."
author: Adam Z.

description:
This place has the same yelp rating at Mandalay? Bitch, puuuullllleeeease!!!! Are you people so cheap that you cannot see past the price to the quality of the food? 

Sure, its cheap eats. Yippee. I am all for cheap too, now that I have proverbially shoved it up the mans ass and gone for a more rewarding non-profit gig.  That is why I am giving this place 3 stars. Price x Quality/Competition = Rating. Damn, I am, like, some sort of Einstein or something. But lets not get crazy here kids. The food, though a great value for the money, is by no means 5 star cuisine.

Lets examine this a bit, shall we? The place is referred to as a Chinese/Burmese diner, yet the OWNERS have printed on their menu "Thai Kitchen"? If that ain't a sign of some good home cooked ethnic confusion I don't know what is!! 

The narrow space with the 8 seat counter does not even allow you to walk behind someone without knocking into them, and forget about just stepping in to place a to go order. You could walk out violated, but, hey, if you are into that well hee haw!! 

I don't know what the hell I am saying here. I am preaching to an audience who gave the Bacon Dog Cart one of the top marks of this site for weeks on end. Let me rewrite this review.......

Go here, you will love it!!
author: Drue C.

description: it's greasy, spicy, no frills, oh-so cheap, down-to-the-nitty Burmese.
author: James G.

description:
Most awesome hole-in-the-wall rediscovery eva! Why do I say rediscovery? Because the Thai nazi used to reign over this 8 seater restaurant in terror back in the old days. I'd creep in, find my seat at the counter and meekly order, hoping not to get yelled at. One time I even saw her chase someone out of the restaurant with a frying pan.

The ladies who have taken over are so nice... being in this hole in the wall makes me feel like I'm in someone's kitchen, and I love watching them make the food. Watch out though, the food is super spicy! I ordered the tea leaf salad and yowza.
author: Nicole G.

description: This place is INCREDIBLE. It is as funky as it gets, and has very limited seating, AND usually has a crazy line around mealtimes, BUT it is D.E.L.I.C.I.O.U.S (and very inexpensive)!!! The tea salad is spectacular, as are the house noodles and cold noodles. YUM YUM YUM in my tum tum tum and it never fails to satisfy me (big portions) despite how cranky I am from standing in a line outdoors. The ladies who cook are so involved in what they are doing, and are (inadvertently) really funny at times as they argue (sometimes screaming) with oneanother. But hey, if I was working in a small, fast-paced, busy crowded space with several other women, it would be bound to happen to me too!
author: Jessica M.

description:
With counter seating to fit no more than 10 folks and an all enclosed kitchen/dining area, Yamo is the epitome of a "hole-in-the-wall".  It's as if you're eating in a garage--a garage that just happens to have a large stove, a couple of rice cookers, fridges, and that familiar black garbage can parked to the side.  Thankfully, the restroom actually is off in a separate room.  Because other than that, what goes on in this joint occurs right in front of you.  Even the sink is located just under the counter you dine off of.

The menu, filled with Burmese inspired cuisine, is amazingly simple...and generous:  At $3.50, appetizers are hearty portions.  And with the exception of beverages, everything else is $5.25 (tax included).  Curry, noodles, and salads are the favorites here.  It's not mind blowing food in the least, but for the price and homestyle cooking, I can't complain. 

It's a two (wo)man operation.  A full house (in this tiny place, six people is a lot), can mean waiting a lil longer than normal for service.  Don't fret; they haven't forgotten you.
author: Marsha Z.

description:
Yamo is the kind of place that I don't want to review, because I don't want anyone else coming here!

I LOVE Yamo. It's a funky little no nonsense place with nothing but a counter that seats about 10 people. Walk up to order to go or wait in line until a spot opens up at the counter. 

Food is amazing, and I'd pick Yamo over Burma Superstar any day. My boyfriend and I always order the house noodles with beef (always beef, it's garlicky and AMAZING), tea leaf salad (crunchy, spicy delicousness), and samusas. Nothing on the menu is over $5.25, so our bill is never more than $20 for two people.

Minus one star just because there's not much customer service. The little ladies that work here are cute, but they're always barking at each other behind the counter, don't ever really make eye contact with customers, and almost always forget to bring me my beverage. Interior is funky, not terribly clean and cluttered behind the counter. I like that though, it gives it more character.

In sum, Yamo rules, but don't come here because I don't want to wait in line behind you.
author: Stacey J.

description:
Every morning, I board the 33 and sit on the left side of the back of the bus. I'm pretty woozy while the bus is leaving the Richmond, but I somehow wake up by the time I hit the Mission. I've seen Yamo and their red awning with fancy disco type (I think a designerd fan donated some graphic design skillz to this joint) through the window a bunch of times, but I never figured out what the hell it was until a month ago, when I squinted really hard and saw people sitting at the counter eatin' one afternoon.

I went home, looked Yamo up to see what kinda food it served and went there one day after work armed with tips I got from fellow Yelpers.

My bf and I showed up on a Wednesday at around 5pm, the place was empty and the Yamo ladies were still prepping for the dinner crowd. We sat down at the counter, and quickly decided what we wanted: samosas, tea salad, house noodles with chicken.

After a few minutes of sitting around and feeling awkward, food just started showing up in front of us. 

Samosas: Careful! Might burn your mouth!! Light and crispy is right, but the flavor is good, but not really special or anything. OH! They give you like 8pcs, so even 3-4 people can share.

Tea Salad: Yum! Definitely on par, if not better than anything that Burma Stupidstar serves. They can easily slap this on a fancy plate and charge $15 for it.

House Noodles: I was anticipating more of a garlicky flavor, but it was very tasty anyway. The chicken is well marinated and the cold onions/cucumbers you get is great to balance out the grease.

Going to Yamo totally feels like barging into a neighbor's house and just sitting down and getting fed, sans the southern hospitality. The Yamo women are tough and can't be bothered. One of them reminds me of my grandma. If you are ready for the bill, don't sit there and ask for it. Pack yo bags and head to the register, they'll know what's up.

Our bill with a drink was maybe just like $15.

I don't think you need to be THAAT adventurous of a eater to go there. It's not like they serve rabbits or anything, ya know what I mean?? Even if they do, I'd definitely go back. =D

(Originally) 4.5 stars!

5/23/07 I'm bumping this up to 5 stars because I've had 4 more dishes from here and it's really the fricken bomb!
author: Faffy L.

description:
Do you know why this place is called "Yamo"? 

Because after you realize that their delicious entrees will only set you back $5.50, you'll turn to your date and say, "Hey, should we order some more?"

And she'll say, "YEAH, Mo'!"

JAZZ HANDS! I'll be here all week folks.
author: Vic W.

description:
My wife says I am not allowed to go to Yamo.  She tells me it is too greasy, and I don't even like it for the food.  Apparently, I like the divey dinery atmosphere, the fact that there is only a counter, and the fact that they served me an entire coconut as a drink.  

I don't think she's right.  I actually think I like the food here.  But since I'm not allowed to go, I don't know that it matters
author: Steve S.

description:
Teensy tiny and you can walk right by it on 18th without even noticing that you have passed it. However, when seeing people peering inside the screened window and waiting, you know you are there.  There are like 9 seats at the bar which faces the open kitchen. FYI, I was inside for 5 minutes and I could smell the food on me.  I got it to go and avoided more food smells in the clothing seepage. The prices are incredibly reasonable, $5.25 for most dishes! 

The tea leaf salad was very flavorful. The stir fry and curry dishes come with rice on the side. The other dishes was not as flavorful as the salad though and ended up tasting a little bland because I started with the salad. Maybe I need to ask for extra spicy Rangoon style next time.

They pack the food in a nice little container to go and it was prepared really quickly so at this price, I highly recommend it if you're in the mood for getting quick Asian food to go in the mission. I've always been a fan of Burmese food after trying Burma Superstar (which continues to be my favorite Burmese restaurant). But now that I've tried 2 good Burmese restaurants, I can say conclusively that I like Burmese people. Go Burma!
author: Natalie S.

description:
Yamo's Cold Noodles rock my world.  Perfect combo of hot, cold, spicy, and tangy.  I was drunk the first time I had them, so I had to go back for a sober confirmation - and they were indeed awesome.  One of my favorite hole-in-the-walls in the city.

Wish there wasn't such a wait most of the time, but it is worth it.  $3.50 appetizers and $5.25 entrees.  Can't beat that.  Have only tried 1 of their rice dishes (the curry prawns), and that was disappointing - no flavor!  But the noodles and appetizers are great.

Also love the ladies who run the place.  When one guy asked her what was good, she shrugged and said, "Nothing."  Ha, that is why there is a 10 person line at the door!
author: Leslie L.

description:
Positive: good cheap Chinese Burmese food. My favorites are the imperial rolls, Garlic Noodles with Chicken, the Samosas and the fresh coconuts. A bowl of noodles with chicken and a coconut will only set you back about $10 with a tip. 

Negative: The place is small, actually a dive/hole in the wall - Literally. they can only seat 10 maybe 12 at their counter. Waits are long, usually up to 1.5 hours. If your not a fan of Valencia St. Hipsters being ironic by eating $6 noodles while wearing $50 t shirts - don't eat here or get your food to go and take it to the park. This place is over run with Hipsters.
author: Raf A.

description:
I tried this place today with my brother at around 5.  The food was good, the place cozy and the prices hard to believe.

I don't think that I had had Burmese food before and thought it was a bit like Indian in that the food has quite a bit of curry in it.

They make the food right in front of you so it feel cozy and intimate.

A little too spicy for my taste but you might love it.  Considering every dish is around 5 bucks you can't really go wrong.
author: Lauren S.

description:
HOLE IN THE WALL GOODNESS!!!

Favorites:
- Yamo House Noodles
- House Special Fried Rice
- Tea Leaf Salad

Call ahead and pick up your order because chances are, you won't be able to get one of the 8 seats at the counter. Service is slow, but you can't get mad at the 3 little ladies working in their limited amount of space while chopping and cooking up fresh ingredients two feet in front of you! Your patience will be rewarded with yummy food for $5.25! Oh, and if you do get a seat at the counter, be prepared to smell afterwards, but not as bad as Korean BBQ!
author: Linda C.

description: Cheap and DELICIOUS. Anytime I have friends visiting from out of town, I bring them here ! The house noodles and the Ted salad Are so delicious!
author: Christina D.

description: Aside from the tea leaf salad and the cold noodle dish, nothing felt particularly Burmese here.  Cheap, yes, and I dig -- but the serving for the salad could've been a touch bigger.  Not a bad spot for what they're doing (let's be honest, basically cheap stir frys) but I think the allure of this place is people thinking they're getting Burmese food.. which I guess it technically is, but a watered-down and neutered representation of the cuisine at best.
author: M K.

description:
Yamo is a good place for a lot of food that is quite easy on the wallet.
This tiny counter sitting is compelling in the restaurant experience that you may be seeking.   It is super small--either expect to wait or come early or late or as I do pick up and take home (prefer eating my order at home to enjoy with beer or wine).  No beer or wine license and strict warning about bringing your own.  It could be a perfectly sunny day and yet inside it is dark and reddish.

I am fascinated by the three cooks working what seems to be nearly effortless work but upon closer inspection is a careful and learned way of cooking.  This must be brutal work--cooking and waiting all at the same time.  It looks like it must be super hot with the gas burner cooking all day.  

I enjoy the curry chicken--Burmese style--hence no coconut milk or tomatoe or cream.  Very spice and the potatoes pick up the flavor of the spicing quite well and together don't become a filler but a great accompaniment.

So when you think this might be a Burma Superstar Jr. it isn't but presents a much simpler fare.  I do like coming here for  inexpensive takeout but for several reasons it is not my destination restaurant to bring family and friends.  A great place to watch an amazingly orchestrated cooking experience.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
I can't get enough of this place.  The house noodles with beef are AMAZING.  For all the suckas that say that there's too much garlic, I say fuck you.  There can never be a thing as too much garlic.
The end.
author: Meh M.

description:
hole-in-the-wall
(plural: hole-in-the-walls or holes-in-the-wall)
noun

1. a small or obscure place, especially such a restaurant
2. (colloquial, chiefly UK) an automated teller machine (ATM)
3. Yamo


loved every second of it.
author: Paran Y.

description: Eating at Yamo is quite the experience. It is everything you dream of for a hole in the wall place. A tiny restaurant on 18th street with about 6 boor stools and one counter top, if you are lucky enough to get a seat, grab it! Inside, you are greeted with the slipping of some paper place mats and chopsticks on your little section of the counter and handed oddly sticky and greasy menus from which to make your selection of food items. You might order the popular tea leaf salad, samusas, some curry, or whatever else you fancy. What you get is appropriately greasy, appropriately delicious, and the perfect quantity for cheap. You eat your food while watching three little old ladies whipping up dishes for fellows patrons and the smoke rise and fill the poorly ventilated space. You might consider making today laundry day because you will definitely leave smelling a little too tasty for your own good.
author: Vrushali P.

description: Ordered to go, no wait at all! Tea leaf salad good but spicy. Black bean dish was fried, served with green bell peppers and onions. Fish dish was standard. But for the price of $6 each would come back. Definitely not worth it to stay in a long line though.
author: Jenny B.

description:
OMGOMGOMG. This is the best place to eat! Seriously! You can eat here for lunch, dinner, an after-dinner snack, etc etc. But it all depends on you. (I mean, whether or not it's daytime or nighttime, it's the freakin' Mission district...so it won't be appealing to the eye anytime.)

Yamo is like hidden treasure. Without their banner, you can mistaken this place for a real hole in the wall next to some other small shops and a wall full of helpful unemployed "workers", but trust me...you have to look HARD for this place.

The food is awesome. The price is to die for. The service is good (for dirty Asian restaurants). You can have a whole meal here and have it cooked RIGHT IN FRONT OF YOU.

Caution: You may stink of oil once you leave, but who cares, you just had Yamo.
author: Jeff H.

description: Very cool hole-in-the-wall! The cold noodles are the best! I also like the curry dishes. The lines are always insane, because its a tiny place, so order "to go" if you don't want to wait. Very simple menu, affordable prices.
author: CatsPjs Z.

description: Great to have an inexpensive, vegetable-filled alternative to Mexican fare close to home. What the place lacks in style it makes up for in character and authenticity.
author: Joshua S.

description:
Absolutely delicious food! My favorites are the mango chicken and samosas. The prices are great. You can feed two people for less than 20.
I recommend ordering your food to go cause its literally a hole in the wall and there is only seating for about 10-12 people. So you're going to be waiting for awhile cause the line wraps to the corner.
Check your order when you leave cause I ordered a salad before and I only got half of it.

None the less! It's amazing and worth every minute and every cent!
author: Reebeka L.

description:
Went to dinner around 7:30PM on a Friday night 

- Very Hipster-y, the holey-ist of all walls 
- Seems to always have wait, so allocate an extra 20 minutes to your meals
- Prices are cheap. 6.00 for entrees and 4-something for appetizers 
- The place is crammed in there and slightly grimey, so prepare yourself to be knocking elbows when eating
- Food comes fast, but you should also eat fast and not linger for conversation because people are waiting
- Portions are the usual.  Noodle dishes are slightly smaller than filling, but the rice plates are better portions and will fill you up. 
- Service is ehhh... The ladies will yell at you for your orders.  If you're willing to compromise less service for cheap dishes.  Here's your place.  Don't expect so much as a smile. 

Recommendations: Chicken Noodle Soup (Warms the soul.  Not the boring soup out of a can. Real tasty).
author: S c.

description: Good, cheap, and fast.  The place, however, is almost quite literally a hole in the wall: just a single counter of about a dozen seats. The 3 women who work there are also seemingly emotionless. So go for the food.
author: Paul L.

description:
Yamo is tucked away on a side street in the Mission district. This 8-seater, open kitchen boasts as a legit establishment for Burmese fast food. Inexpensive, filling, fresh. 

Black bean tofu could use more black bean sauce. 
Tea leaf salad has a nice flavor but it has too much oil for me. 

Interesting must have experience in The Mission. Suitable for quick meals, cheap eats and strange encounters. I met a patron who brings in his own eggs because according to him fried rice must have eggs in it.
author: Jack C.

description:
This tiny gem of a place deserves a review. I've been torn, because I don't want them to get all trendy and popular (resulting in me waiting in a long ass line like at Swan's), but I guess this is the right thing to do. Plus I doubt you will find it - it is quite hidden.

The experience: You sit down at the counter. Order something that seems good (Tea Salad, Noodle bowls, Curry). And you watch the ladies cook it for you. They serve it to you and you eat. Delicious. I feel like I came home!
author: Ali K.

description:
Took a few misses till I found something I liked, but once I did it was incredible!

Tea leaf salad and cold noodles are great. If you go on an off hour you can get counter space to enjoy the atmosphere. Plus it's cheap!
author: Dan F.

description:
YAMO!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
(that's what it's like inside my brain every time I decide to eat here.)

What can I say this place is cheap and good. Sometimes it's so good, one thing is never enough to satisfy my hunger... I look down at my empty plate and then suspiciously at the people sitting next to me on the counter until I realize that I was the one who ate the rest of my noodles when I wasn't looking. oops, so I order something else and maybe I'll splurge and share a bunch of stuff with a friend.... I still barely spend $20 (including tip) on a huge meal there.

And yeah sure sometimes you have to wait but they are fast, sometimes they'll take your order while your next in line for a seat so that as soon as you sit down, you chow down.
author: Allegra W.

description: We are already planning on what we are going to get our next visit.  So far, we love the cod with black beans and noodles with chicken. Just as other reviews stated, the place is small but the women there are polite and always laughing. A HAPPY place =D
author: Dave And Teenz Q.

description:
Oh, this place is great! I loved it.  I sat at the counter eavesdropping, watching the cooks, and reading a novel till my food came-and that was de-lish.  Very content experience.
 I think in general, though, I am gonna move toward eating vegetarian at establishments such as these; the meat IS cheap for a reason!
author: Melissa B.

description:
Really? I mean, really?

Classic mistake of confusing grunginess for authenticity. Please.

To quote Yelp, "meh". Only item I'd reorder was the shrimp spring roll. And even that was mediocre. Tea leaf salad was overly salty. Fish chowder was run-of-the-mill comfort-food without any pronounced flavors/textures. Cold noodles were one step better than your average per-kilo Chinese buffet. Seem like lovely people, but we experienced begrudgingly indifferent service. Cheap, yes. But not worth even the low price.
author: N K.

description:
literally a hole in the wall place that i walked right pass the restaurant w/o realizing it. looks quite ghetto from the outside and it's next to a badass tattoo shop. 
anyway, food is decent. i expected better but i guess the hype is just over how they were able to strategically fit a kitchen, counters w/ 10 seats, and restroom in space that was smaller than my living room in my apt.
- get the house noodle with beef, but overall it's just cheap chinese takeout food w/ a burmese twist to it
author: Joyce B.

description: Now I know why there's a line out the door here. Every time we've tried to go here it was always on a Sunday and they're closed then. I'm glad we finally stopped in here. The ladies that work here work really hard to give you your food fast, tasty and hot. It's a tiny little hole in the wall, but it's definitely work seeking out. We ordered Samosas, Chow Mein (not too adventurous today), and Black Bean Tofu all for about $15. All of them were really yummy. Yamo made me say Yum-O. (I know I'm quoting Rachel Ray but it seems necessary here, no?). If you don't mind sitting at the counter while they prepare your meal or if you want your food to go, check it out.
author: Amy J.

description:
This restaurant may be Burmese, but the food tastes like good old fashioned comfort food to a Chinese-Am girl like me.  I love having a baby coconut drink and having some Yamo House noodles (garlic noodles), tea leaf salad, and spring rolls in this tiny dive with maybe 8 stools.  Don't come here expecting an atmosphere that's romantic, private, or conducive to conversation -- it's loud, cramped, and hot.  You do get the advantage of all your food being made from scratch in front of you though.  Yamo is definitely a hidden (or not so hidden now due to Yelp) jewel right off Mission Street.

Best part?  All entrees on the menu are $5.25, apps are even less!
author: Sid D.

description:
wakako u. and i were out on a mission stroll when we decided to tuck into this semi-hidden hole-in-the wall and tuck into some no-frills burmese street eats. we were lucky; there was no line and so we grabbed the 2 nearest bar stools, surveyed the animated old ladies feverishly preparing spanking fresh dishes before our very eyes, and got down to business. 

the house special noodles were oodles of garlic-drenched goodness, but avoid them if you're doing anything social for the next 2 days. next came the tea leaf salad. of all the iterations of this classic dish i've tried in SF (mandalay, burma superstar, burmese kitchen and here), this was my least favorite. it was very cabbagey, which is probably why wakako u. couldn't stop extolling its virtues. i liked their fish chowder, but it may be better at mandalay. the main difference is that yamo cooks theirs with noodles. for finger snacks we had an order of samosas. they were very much like the ones you get in indian restaurants, but i prefer the indian ones. 

perhaps the best part of our whole mini-burmese street feast was the price-- $22 out the door, and you can't beat that.
author: Brett W.

description: Everything you'd expect from an inexpensive hole in the wall - in the best way possible! Great food, cheap prices. A wait is inevitable due to the 10-person bar stool seating, but it's worth it for a quick no-frills Burmese bite.
author: Jen W.

description:
Just countertop dining. True family joint that is operated by a couple of really tough ladies who are very friendly.

Not a place to bring a significant other who is high maintenance.

Tea salad is awesome
author: Tony N.

description:
I was craving some sort of chinese food and found this Burmese kitchen and loved it!!!  I went in by myself and thankfully did so cause there is only like 10 seats on a bar and that is it.  This is actually the first Burmese  Kitchen I have ever been to so I can't compare it to anything but I thoroughly enjoyed myself.  
I took it for what it was, a hole in the way kitchen with 3 women dishing out some awesome food.  Although they did not speak much english they were still very nice and accommodating.  I got the egg rolls which I know is typical but they were surprisingly tasty and came with a lovely spicy garlic sauce.  The I ordered the house special fried rice and was so pleased with the absolute perfect amount of spice I could not of asked for anything better.  I literally  licked my plate, my only complaint would be that I wish they had better chop sticks but that is probably my fault for not knowing how to use rounded chop sticks as opposed to squared.  But all in all I had a  coconut water, egg rolls and yamo special fried rice and I payed 11.75... Come on seriously a cheap meal does not get better than that.
author: K Q.

description:
talk about best bang for your buck! this is one of the best cheap eats ever and well worth the wait.  I'd almost be inclined to move to the mission for this place! now i did notice their health screening food card was a bit hidden, so it's just not worth thinking about. It's a total hole in the wall and really not good for groups. but the food was great, maybe a bit greasy for some people, but good portion size and the menu is awesome.

I enjoyed the YAMO house noodles with the chicken and the samasus (their spelling not mine) SOOOOOO GOOOD.

eaters beware, this is not the place if you are looking for a sit down meal, this is eat and go!!!!

I hope to come back real soon!!!!
author: Olivia W.

description:
Literally a hole in the wall.  
My New Fav. hole in the wall.. Everything is fresh, make in front of you... The line if pretty long, but its worth the wait.. No need to get all dolled up for this place..=)

All you need to know is Yamo house noodles w/beef. For $5.25. Seriously and fresh coconut juice... 
I can eat here morning , noon and night..
author: tramy n.

description:
One of my favorite local diners.
Small "mom and pop" venue...actually 2 sisters.
They work very hard , 7 days per week.
Great diversity of dishes and flavors, and even have fresh coconut, opened old school style with a machete.
This place is always packed out the door...
No other place like it!
author: Daood P.

description:
Great place if you need to grab a quick meal and go!  Tea leaf salad was good but not mind blowing however, the Yamo cold noodle was excellent!  

Greasy and delicious!   Oh, if you're looking for good customer service, DON'T EXPECT IT HERE!  The workers hate their job but do a great job cooking!
author: Jo S.

description:
After reading many of the 4-5 star reviews of Yamo, the boyfriend and I were truly looking forward to having our taste buds treated to a great surprise tonight as we drove out to the Mission.  As we arrived, I was already dreaming of the "tea salad", samusas and curry.  

There were some positive things that I took note of right away:

94% inspection rating (hanging on the back wall)
Family owned and run
The ingredients looked fresh (as the ladies were peeling & chopping items right in front of us).
The young lady serving us was quite friendly and customer service oriented.

Yet, I must say that I was EXTREMELY disappointed with the food.  While I read a few reviews raving about the tea salad and how it is so much better than Burma Superstar's version, I must WHOLEHEARTEDLY disagree.  There really is very little tea leaf in the Yamo tea salad.  While tasty, it is almost comparable to campbell's "chicken" noodle soup, where the chicken flavor is there, but the chicken is MIA from the whole equation.  

The samusas were average, but nothing to go out of the way for.  The beef curry that I ordered was dripping with oil, lacked any flavor (no spice at all) and I just couldn't make myself finish it.

Yes, it is cheap (2 curry meals, 1 tea leaf salad, 1 order of samusas = $19.20 w/o tip) and it may be convenient for some, but I just can't imagine eating there again.  The food was pretty flavorless and just too greasy for me to handle a second time around.  :(
author: Hiromi N.

description:
So I see here that we have quite a disparity between reviewers.  Since I live like half a block away, I thought so what the hell - I do like me some cheap, so let's do it.

I can't say I'm an expert on the menu, because my party of three all ordered the same meal of coconut milk, tea leaf salad and spring rolls.  Yeah, I think you are all right in saying that Burma Superstar is better, it is fresher and less greasy.  But this is a fast food place - and you don't have to wait in fucking line forever and ever!  I am totally pleased with my experience here and will go back all the time.  Also I'm in love with the ladies.  I have a crush on them and want them to adopt me.
author: Dana M.

description:
This tiny, divey restaurant is a trip -- I'm so glad I finally checked it out. Came for lunch one day on a sunny Mission afternoon. Didn't have to wait for one of the few bar stools, had my order taken right away by the woman working in front of me. It did take me a while to figure out you don't order at the register, though.

I had the house (egg) noodles with chicken. Really nice flavor, spicy without being deadly. A bit oily, but not swimming in it. Next time, I'd like to try something with more different ingredients. The pot stickers and rice paper rolls looked good. Intrigued the by coconuts.
author: Tara M.

description: Dining at Yamo is like sitting at your kitchen counter at home watching your mama cook--except at Yamo you have 4 mamas. Between bursts of flames cooking the food and candid bickering amongst the 4 ladies....the end result is savory Burmese dishes full of heat and spice. For $15, we ordered the cold noodle with chicken, the fish soup, and the tea leaf salad--all hearty, tasty, and wonderfully spiced. I think any noodle dish will be delicious. I thought that So had awesome noodles...Yamo gives So a run for its money. Be warned though, all the dishes we ordered had a really crunchy nut which, if you are not careful, you could hurt the roof of your mouth. Definitely a bargain and a gem!
author: Sue L.

description:
Although the food is probably really only 4 stars ---  the 3 ladies who work until 10pm almost every night AND the awesome prices gives it the extra "happy i'm not broke if I eat here" star!  It really is good food and you can't beat $5.25! holla!

I don't know why everyone keeps comparing this place to Burma.  It's not really meant to be a sit down, let's chat and have wine kind of dinner restaurant.  It's more like a bar that serves Burmese food rather than alcohol. But when I actually sit down and eat here I like to treat myself to a fresh coconut drink too.  It's deeelishious!  I love all the curry dishes and they are so wonderful for take out.  This is an excellent go-to-place, quick fix and anyone in the Mission will tell you, just a simple neighborhood good eats for everyday.
author: Christina C.

description:
Yamo is just down the street from my home, and I eat a meal there
at least once or twice a week.  Yes, it's tiny and it can be crowded. However,
the food is *phenomenal*. It's almost cheaper to eat there than to cook
at home! The restaurant is open for both lunch and for dinner, and it's honestly not especially crowded in the afternoon or  in the early evening.
If there are too many people in the restaurant, I generally order food to go.
The women that work there put in long hours, and I find them to be very nice.
I honestly LOVE this little restaurant!
author: Natalie P.

description:
The safety training officer said, "Always trust your instincts- they are right 99.9% of the time." Damn right he was. When I walked in here the first thought in my mind was, "Hello Susie's on 7th and Townsend!" Susie's is a greasy spoon cafe run by two Chinese women. You SMELL like grease even if you just poke your head inside for 2 seconds. 

Undaunted and confident that my Yelpers wouldn't lead me wrong I orderd two standards- tea leaf salad and the cold noodles with chicken. 15 minutes the little lady behind the counter said. 

I stood just inside the door secretly wishing I could prop it open, and watched as the two ladies ran a bumbling and inefficient orchestra of food preparation. One would do something- i'm not quite sure what, but it wasn't very purposeful- causing the other to fall behind on whatever she was doing. One was fishing out some fried egg rolls from the fryer and the other mumbled to her that she should get my order finished and out the door since I had been there for more than 15 minutes and my food had been sitting in it's containers for at least 5, waiting for lids. 

I managed to escape the grease pit and drove back to work with my windows all the way down the entire way, trying to shake off the lingering tell-tale scent of a greasy spoon joint; much like a hooker's cheap perfume marking a travelling business man's shirt.

So how was it? The tea salad was a heap of disappointment. Highly salty and spicy hot, it contained a TON of little fried crunchy things. Fried onions, fried garlic, fried pumpkin seeds, fried lentils, fried batter bits; you get the picture? Oh, it had a small amount of shredded cabbage too, thinly sliced red onion, peanuts, sesame seeds and trace amounts of green onion, but by far the prevailing theme here was oil and drenching things in them. The crowning glory was that it was toped with cilantro. Shoot me now.

Deciding I had enough disappointment/torture, I moved on to the cold noodles with chicken, and this was an odd dish because given the name, one might be led to believe that the dish is actually cold. Oh, no my friend. This it is not. The chicken was cooked in a mildly spicy chili/onion oil/sauce. Have I mentioned the oily mess yet? If I didn't twirl the noodles perfectly, it would flick oil. Onto my face, my clothes, my desk. It was like noodle oil bukkake. Not only was I smothered in it from the inside out, but now I'm being bathed in it too. 

After a few more bites of coating my arterial walls, I claimed surrender and put a lid on the offending meal. I felt as if I had cooking oil poured over me, and have had an uncontrollable desire to take a long, hot showers with industrial strength Dawn since then. Just because a place is inexpensive, doesn't mean it needs to be greasy.

Up-side: at least I won't have to moisturize or use conditioner for the next week. I have enough oil on me for the EPA to send out auditors. Exxon-Valdez ain't got nothin' on me.

Instinct says: Don't trust good Burmese cuisine to come from a place that smells NOT like cooking and food, but of grease, run by two Chinese women.
author: Mortiche W.

description:
i won't repeat what everyone has already said, but i love this little place, the food is crazy good and CHEAP, omg CHEEEEAP!!! everything is pretty much five dollars or less! so for $10 I could get two delicious freshly homemade dishes and be set for the next two meals. you really can't beat that!!

and i hope the lady (one that doesn't speak english) there remembers me because the last time i went, i ordered something to go, $5.25 right? so I gave her a $20 bill, and she goes to find change.. comes back and gives me a $20, 4 ones and some change. i look at her like she's crazy, thinking WHY ARE YOU GIVING ME BACK THE $20 I JUST GAVE YOU?!! so i point that out and she laughs, kinda flustered and finds me the right change, smiles and thanks me. its okay, i'd be kinda out of it if i were standing in a shoebox size kitchen for 10 hours cooking food for hipsters and co. all day. but i digress.. anyways, point being, now if this happened at a mcdonalds, i would've just took my food and $20 and left, but not at yamo's because i love this place.. i better get extra potstickers or something next time for being so kind... ahah jk. or not?

and people, please try to not bring in a party of 6 and just take over the whole damn place!! get it to go at least and go eat it at the park or something! :)
author: Jennie L.

description:
I've never eaten IN the restaurant, but I've got take our a couple of times and I absolutely recommend their chicken or tofu curry with noodles...it the best!  Has potatoes, chicken, onions and green bell peppers in curry with fired noodles on the side! YUM!  The ladies who work there are a gas and little cooking robots-I swear!  They are fast and to the point, but not mean.  Grab a couple of orders for the office here...you can't beat the prices either!

Edit: OKAY! after reading some if the comments I have to add...YAMO is not a clean place!  It is not a nice place to sit and chat with friends.  They have NO seating.  IF YOU DO WAIT FOR SEATING IT WILL BE A LONG, LONG, LONG TIME SO CALL FOR TAKE OUT.  THEIR FOOD IT ABSOLUTELY GREASY and OILY and WONDERFUL...if you want a salad, don't come here.  This is pure Burmese comfort food...I'm plugging the chicken curry with noodles again.  Eat it.
author: Kat D.

description:
Oh, Yamo... I fear you will continue to be an amazing deal on super awesome food until you are slowly overtaken by the masses as they crowd me out of your precious ten square feet of seating!

If you've ever been to Art's Cafe in the Inner Sunset, the setup is similar: twenty-odd feet of bar stool seating where you are served piping hot meals while you watch them being made, all for less than the price of a cocktail at one of the many hip new joints down the street.

The ladies who run Yamo are entertaining to watch as they hustle hungry diners in and out of the joint, coconuts and cold noodles flying all the while.  Speaking of coconuts, nothing soothes a throat full of Burmese spiced noodles like a fresh coconut, hacked open right in front of you by a sexagenarian who could definitely kick your ass.

The cold noodles are worth trying, but my vote would have to be for the mango chicken.  The spring rolls we ordered last night were on the bad side of average, but the entrees are delicious, generously portioned, and crazy cheap.  A meal for two will run you under $20 for both entrees, an appetizer, and two coconuts, with leftovers to spare, or you can grab a single entree for only $5.25.

The wait is never too long (for now...) but ordering to go is always a good idea, unless you're staying in the area for other reasons.  They're also open for lunch -- smaller crowd, no wait, and fresh coconuts on a hot summer afternoon -- What's not to love?
author: Melissa T.

description:
Yamo ladies swift
with wok of garlic noodles -- 
scent of grease lingers
author: Mel H.

description: Like a crack addict, I keep coming back.  I had to eat before I met up with my friend and I'm glad I did.  I was suppose to eat at Sycamore but my body told me that it could not wait for 1 1/2 hours.  Worth it.  The wait was non existent this time around.  It was about 5:30 but it soon gained a line by 6pm when I left.  It was nice to eat and read alone with the cook/waitress yelling/placing an order over the phone.
author: Ashley I.

description: Love this place, got the taste just like my grand ma cooking, the food here  with that kind of price are unbeatable. This place knock my shoes off... just dont look at the kitchen in front of you if you think you would have problem with street food.
author: Tony C.

description: Sometimes, it just feels right. And Yamo was that way on my first visit.
