The crowd of people at the door seemed to suggest a long wait, but when we found out they were all waiting for takeout orders, we slipped into counter seats after only a few minutes. The women that run this place are just the perfect combination of sweet and sassy, like you'd expect from a cool grandmother. The food is simple but doesn't disappoint. Loved my noodles and veggies, and I will definitely be back for more.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Yamo-goers beware, the operation of this place can be a bit confusing at first.  A line forms on the right of the entrance for seating.  A line forms on the left of the entrance for take out.  I was a little skeptical, at first, waiting without my name on a list, but it turned out alright.

I got there at exactly 7:34, on a Tuesday.  There were 6 people ahead of us, but considering the place seats maybe 10 total, that turned into an hour long wait.  I thought the wait at Burma Superstar was kind of absurd, so when 8:29 stuck and we weren't seated yet, I proclaimed: "Fuck." (We said we wouldn't do this.)

We decided to keep waiting and didn't have to wait much longer than that, thankfully.   Based on friends' reviews, we started with the tea leaf salad.  I thought it was very good:  a stab of spice mixed with the crunch of nuts and refreshing crisp of lettuce leaf.

Next came the Curry Beef with Noodles and I found them to be light on the oil, but full of flavor.  At this point I was starting to wonder why we hadn't gotten our other appetizer, the samusas, yet.  

They showed up to the party a little late and when I bit into one, I nearly spit it out, exclaiming, "Holy shit that's good!"  Luckily, for those around me, I managed to keep that sucker in my mouth, although I was surprised by how good it was.

We also tried those grass jelly drinks out of curiosity and they were okay.  They have bits of grass-flavored jelly(?) in the bottom to add texture to the drink, ie. you need a straw.

The shape and size of the place really reminded me of a small diner where I would get breakfast in my hometown.  Even though it was my first time there, it felt very familiar, and everything had the appearance of a home cooked dish.

At the end we were full, and it was 8 dollars each with a 20% tip.
author: Adam C.

description:
SF Food Inspection Score: 90

So. Here's the thing. I love that there is Burmese food in the Mish. I do have to say that the food was served quickly but with love and was very tasty.

But I have had better. 

Plus, sitting at the counter made for a distracting meal with my my friend Emmanuel A. 

Maybe next time, I'll come alone or get food to go.
author: Kristina C.

description: Went here yesterday. Like other reviews have noted, very few counter seats so go during odd times if you don't want to wait. For two at 5pm on Saturday, we scored seats right away but shortly after there's a line.  Had the tea leaf salad (good - crunchy with lots of nuts), samosa (perfectly fried), mango chicken (sauce is a bit sweet but also spicy), and garlic noodles with pork (my favorite dish of the night). FYI - it can get really smokey inside so thankfully the food is served quickly.
author: Jenny G.

description:
BEST cheap eats since the tamale lady.  

I am a self-proclaimed noodle-and-dumpling-whore.  I first discovered Yamo thanks to a girlbuddy who lives around the block, and we met for lunch one afternoon: The menu is definitely in line with my carbo-lust.

We sat at the counter and slurped noodles and coconut.... but the BEST part for me, without question, were the potstickers.  They are steamed and FULL of fresh ginger, which is one of nature's perfct foods (after bacon).

Now that I am aware of it's existence, I always see a line out the door here-- no matter, pack it up to go and walk to the park!  

Nothing on the menu is more than ~$6, so it's a guilt-free indulgence that everyone should treat themselves to.  Seriously!
author: Laura F.

description: Tiny place where you can feel the heat, listen to the kitchen banter,  and watch them cook.  Love the cold noodles with warm chicken-nice spice to it.  T orders Mango Chicken, but its not as good as Mandalay.  Fish chowder we both enjoy.  Price is right and you walk away content.
author: Tony And Candace T.

description:
Prices seriously can't be beat. I think we stuffed ourselves with food the other night for like twenty bucks or something like that? It was insanely crazy.

Now, I will say that it's a small place, so those that are claustrophobic should not come in here. About 10 stools in total. You sit at the counter and you watch the ladies work their magic. Kinda cool actually. :)

The food was a bit too spicy for my tastes...and the curry beef dish was pretty plain. Nothing special about it really.

I wil make two recommendations. #1 is the tea salad. DELICIOUS! Had just enough spice and kick to make you wanting a sip of water, but it was all out awesome! #2 is the chicken noodle soup. It had this velvet-buttery taste that was sensational! OMG! That'd hit the spot on a cold night.

All in all, it's cut and it definitely has it's personality.

Would I force someone to come all the way across town for it? Probably not. But would I ask someone to eat there if there were in the hood? Definitely at least once.
author: Nicolas H.

description: Yummy, cheap, greasy...my type of place!! However, don't come here expecting to be treated like royalty. This is a hole-in-the wall. I love these kinds of places...unpretentious and simple!
author: sigourney w.

description:
I read all the review before I hit Yamo.
     Actually I looked for it about 6 months ago and did not find the place (I know, shame on me).
     I can see both sides of the story on Yamo.  So I let go of my high and low expectation and decided to simply experience Yamo as it is yesterday evening, when I was craving greasy noodles with lots of vegetables.

And I did enjoy it, the "Mommy" and Auntie made me Yamo noodles with vegetables and tofu, no even on the menu.  I had Tea Salad without dry shrimps, on my request, veggie spring roll, like the peanut sauce and a fresh coconut.  I cannot say for my ex for his Mango chicken with rice, but I did enjoy my share very much.

Love the little cave, smoke alarm going off from time to time, because it reminded me when I was cooking Chinese food in my own studio in Madison, WI.  

I guess it is more of a personal projection thing, I wanted mom made stir fried noodles, watching mom cooking and the feelings going with it.  And I got it all.  Seeing daughter and mom and aunts are busing preparing meal for you is comforting some times for some one.

So if this is what you are looking for, you may be very satisfied, like I was ;)
author: Yi Z.

description: Smallest restaurant I have ever had lunch in before but I am a fan of any of their noodle dishes!  Can't go wrong with this place.
author: Tony T.

description: This dive is a must go to while in the Misson District. I fell in love with the tea leaf salad after being introduced to Burmese food. However, their tea leaf salad had its own unique flavor. Their noodles with beef is delicious! But be prepared to wait for a bit. They only have a bar with several chairs to eat and the place is small. Very affordable and cheap for a good portion of good food.
author: Aileen F.

description:
For the price, superb.  But I got in on this place too late.  Although I understand it's been here forever, I only started coming here for weekday lunch a few weeks ago.  I guess if I hear about a place, EVERYONE has heard about it.  I went to Yamo today just a bit before three o'clock.  It was full.  There were six people waiting outside.  That's way beyond my threshold of inconvenience, even for food with such a spectacular quality/price ratio.  Won't be trying it again.

If all you need is take-out, five stars.
author: Richard R.

description: A good hole in the wall that delivers good food at a very decent fixed price. The house noodles, the chicken soup and fish chowder are my top picks.
author: Dean I.

description:
I've been to Yamo a couple of time now and, though I can't say the food blows, or even knocks, my socks off, I can see myself returning here for many more meals.  First of all, the food is good, like I said, not lick my plate or bowl clean great, but solid.  I've had the Yamo house noodles with beef, and though i was looking for a bit more flavour, the beef was nice and tender and I like the texture of the noodles.  I also had their curry with shrimp and noodles.  Likewise it was pretty good, needed to add some pepper oil for spiciness, but I had no problem finishing this dish.  I have also eaten the potstickers and samosas, both OK.

What I love about this place is it's third world charm and simplicity.  I love restaurants that you walk into and feel like you've left the the country.  OK so you could say you feel like you've left the country just walking down Mission to 18th St.  This place feels like a grundgy, slapped together noodle shop you could find down some back alley in SE asia with enough grease built up on the front window to make a meal of if you were brave enough to lick it off (and I mean this in a good way).  I love the simplicity of the menu, all noodle dishes, the same price.  So what if you want chicken, beef, shrimp or veggies, same same same same.   And finally, that price is cheap!  

Summary: CHEAP, GOOD, and I'm sure there's one other thing I could annoyingly capitalize.
author: Adrian L.

description:
A friend recently turned me on to Yamo and I was very glad they did.

I was once fond of Burma Superstar, but Clement Street was starting to feel a long way to go to stand in line for an hour for good Burmese food.

Not only is Yamo just blocks away from my Mission home, but it is even more homespun: a few burmese women behind a counter making your food for you as you watch.  And it is cheap!

I wish the good women of Yamo much success.
author: Tara M.

description:
I don't understand, but I guess I should make note that I'm a vegetarian.

Not many options on the menu if you are....curry vegetables seems to be the cake. There was a tofu dish, but...meh. Kinda over tofu.

Fair enough. I like curry and vegetables. 

It was $5.95 for the meal and the rice. That is this place's ONLY redeeming quality.


Yeah, yeah, yeah. I see what you're doing here. Hole-in-the-wall "ethnic" place with no sign outside or anything to note what it's called - such style - but the line out-the-door for GUSTO. Inside: one long bar smashed up against the counter and absolutely NO STANDING ROOM. Super-hip clientele. (It IS in-between Mission and Valencia.)


And the food wasn't that good. Crazy spicy, "eh" rice, and some vegetables. Sure, it's cheap....but that's the case with the flavor, too.
author: Danyell K.

description:
This is now the third incarnation of Yamo's I've seen, and it took me too long to make it to part III of the trilogy. Last time, it was eclectic and visually amusing. Before it was Anna the Thai Soup Nazi who was good for endless entertainment as she showed you pictures of her nieces she wanted you to marry.

But now as a Burmese restaurant, Yamo satisfies as well as ever. Insanely cheap entrees ($5.25 each!), nice spices and ingredients, and well-crafted rolls rarely go together.

I had the black bean fish noodles. Make sure you get them or live to regret it. Our server-cook recommended against the curry prawns but they were pretty awesome, and they'll give you the spicy if you like. Samusas and fresh spring rolls as appetizers? Yes please. They even make the spring rolls in front of your very eyes.

Service is with a smile, and an occasional forgotten item. But then the smile comes again and you just go back to eating your plate of deliciousness.
author: Blake E.

description: Cheap food that tastes good.  Seating is a bit cramped; I'd recommend ordering the food to go because (although the person next to me was attractive) you will have very little personal space dining inside.
author: B M.

description:
$5.25 gets you plenty of *decent* food.  It's tasty, quick, and cheap.

Don't be fooled by the 4-star rating - this is not Burma Superstar wedged into a hallway, but it is definitely better than most anything else for the price.

The Yamo House noodles are pretty awesome.
author: Bobby C.

description:
I love nothing better than little ethnic hole-in-the-floor joints with great food for practically nothing.  Thus is Yamo.
Sure you leave smelling something of recycled grease, but the flavorful food and very friendly people behind the counter more than make up for it.
Make sure to try the tea salad (so many crunchy goodies mixed in).  The cold noodles are delish, the black bean fish was good and the curries are nice and spicy.
And for such a no-frills place, it's nice that they have an array of condiments.
author: Xtina C.

description:
Yamo used to be Tai Wei's kingdom... tasty unpredictable veggie thai. I experienced vegetables that I'd never even heard of... wore some borrowed "bling" from off the wall, and a watched 70's rennfairesploitation film. Alas, the place has been turned into another run of the mill restaurant...

**UPDATE** Tai Wei is back in action in the kitchen of Bender's Bar! He is serving meat now, and the menu is whatever he feels like serving, but it's divine! You may not get what you ordered, but it will surely be delicious!!
author: Bethanne S.

description:
What we ordered:

Tea Leaf Salad - Good tea leaf salad, splits well as a starter for two people, would recommend
Fish Chowder- came filled with over cooked rice noodles, ate less than 1/4 of the bowl
Curry Prawn over noodles - egg noodles with diced mushrooms, bell peppers and onions, was ok but not really a curry. 

I'm not a professional chef so my standard for good food is simply if it is better than what I could make myself at home.  The Tea Leaf salad was certainly better than ones which I've made.  The Fish Chowder and Curry Prawn noodle weren't though.  The Fish Chowder was almost inedible due to the overcooked, sludgy rice noodle and the Curry Prawn wasn't a curry in any of the Indian/Thai-sense of the word so I'm not sure why they call it curry.  I was disappointed after waiting for 15 minutes outside for a spot at the bar to eat very mediocre food.  On the upside their menu is very simple and most items are $6 which is reasonable.  Unfortunately that $6 could be put to better use at many other Mexican restaurants in the area.  I can't recommend other Asian restaurants in the Mission but if you can make it to the Chinatown, the Richmond, or Sunset you'll be sure to find better Asian food for $6.  

Whether you like this restaurants depends mostly on yours tastes.  I'm not Burmese but all the places I've had Burmese food in San Francisco have been better.  For some background, I grew up eating Asian food, I shop at Asian markets in San Francisco, own about a dozen Asian cookbooks (Chinese, Vietnamese, Thai) and cook Asian foods most days of the week.  This place doesn't suit my tastes but it appears to suit the taste of many others. I think that if you cook a lot of Asian foods you may find this place wanting.
author: Mike N.

description: I've been here twice and so far, I'm happy for what I had. I ordered warm house noodle and prawn curry noodle and both were yummy. Although my friend ordered fish with blackbean sauce and it wasn't all that good. I think it depends on what you pick. I'll try more of their food, the staff here speak English, so that part is good for this kind of cheap eats.
author: Yoko S.

description:
Very cheap, yet tasty.  I had the tea salad, chicken curry over rice, and house noodles with chicken.  The tea salad had great flavor to it and was more memorable to me than Burma Superstar's.  The house noodles were also very tasty with the fried garlic on top.  The chicken curry over rice was good, but I think next time I'll order over noodles.  I don't know if it's just an illusion, but it looked like if you order noodles they give you more.  I saw other people with the veggie curry and it looked great. 

The food here is greasy.  It's not for people looking to lose weight or count calories.  It's for a good quick meal that's extremely easy on the wallet.  The other reviewer is right.  All the noodles are coated in oil as is all the vegetables in the curry.  Just FYI - the potatoes in the curry look like they're pre-fried earlier in the day then boiled when you order curry to heat them up.  

(Also, ideally you'd go to the bathroom before coming here.  It's not unusable, but it's not a pleasant experience.)
author: Joann C.

description:
Yummy comfort food.  Like eating in your Aunt's kitchen.  

Favorites: Tea Salad, House Noodles with Beef and Broccoli and Chicken Soup (with coconut milk) and don't forget to get the whole fresh coconut as well.  Just try not to splash the person next to you with coconut juice while attacking the flesh like I did.  

 All of this would cost you less than $20.  How the heck do they make money?  I like Burma.
author: Anna C.

description: Cheap as hell. Great place for a party of 2 or less. Also, don't walk in here with a tight ass, as the lovely ladies here only dish out the customer service that you paid for, none.  The food is bomb, and yamo is a perfect setting for those of who only care about yummy ass cheap food.
author: Alex V.

description:
This place truly is a hole.  

I wasn't that impressed with the two meals we got.  The food was actually cold and we waited in line for a long time.  

We did however enjoy the two 40s we got from the market across the street with the tea leaf salad we ordered.  We ate this meal sitting on a hill in Dolores Park, where we took in the wafting scent of weed during our nap.
author: Bhumika K.

description:
For god's sake, don't eat here, order to go and eat it at home, or someone else's home. I'd give it five stars as a take-out place, and three as an eat-in, so I'm averaging my stars. 

The samosas are unbelieveable... very delicate and crisp with a wonderful spiciness that has no burn, all flavor. Definitely my favorite thing there (so far). Everything else I've gotten has been stellar, as well.
author: dana l.

description: This is one of my favorite stops for a quick bite on a weeknight.  The food is really tasty (if not exactly health food) and I love siting at the counter and watching the tiny open kitchen.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Yes, the place's location is not so great. 
Yes, this place doesn't look so great and, maybe, even not so welcoming. Small, tiny place. have to wait a line to be seated, since, a lot of people are coming to have a lunch and dinner. 
However, the service is great and VERY fast!!! The food is amazing. The Curry prawns, the Chicken noodle Soup are amazing. Actually, they make the best chicken and prawns. The beef is alright; I had better before. 
Everytime when i am hungry during the lunch, that's the place I go with my boyfriend. 
This place is very cheap. The main dish is $5.25 the whole day. The side dish is only $3.50.
author: Jenna F.

description:
Yamo is not the best Burmese food around, but it's a great place for a no frills meal that is fresh, tasty, made to order, and *cheap*! It's a wonderful little oasis of tortilla-less cheap food in the mission.

The place is very unique, and some people may be turned off by the fact that it is literally a hole-in-the-wall.  For those people, I suggest taking it to go and eating it at home or in one of the nearby parks.

Despite the Tu-Lan-esque vibe, the food is always super fresh and not as greasy as you  might imagine (although I can't speak for meat dishes ) They make everything, even the fresh springrolls,  for you right in front of your eyes. And they've always agreed to make anything I've requested vegetarian for me, which means they fill it with a wonderful mix of familiar and unusual fresh veggies, herbs and/or tofu. yum.

Try: tea salad, black bean tofu, veggie curry, fresh spring rolls (peanut sauce is awesome), mango tofu, and fresh coconut juice!

All apps are $3.25 (and the spring rolls by themselves can be a great light lunch), entrees are $5.25. 

don't be turned off by the fact that it looks like it's closed or abandoned. it's definitely worth a try, especially if you live in the area.
author: Suzanne S.

description:
Original Review:

I went here with melissa v. she is like three people down from me. 

1. If I was Vietnamese, the lady who served us would be my aunt.
2. The place is tiny and warm, but be careful. If you fall back hark enough you could probably impale yourself on the coat rack.
3. The place smells of yum
4. for like 8 bucks you can get a big ass bowl of noodles and some spring rols. 
5. The only reason they got three stars and not four is because Melisa V. wouldn't talk to them in vietnamese. You could have changed this MVC, but you didn't!
6. I will be back soon to have more fun tummy times.

Updated:
I gave you 5 stars because of your great service, the high school girl in here, super talkative, but totally sweet. I tried the chicken soup... BLOW  AWAY! I want to be a regular so that you all know my name! Be my friend!

:::::::::::::update 4/8/08:::::::::::::::::
To the group of 7 who I have seen twice now... you know very well that the place only has 10 seats, and you know very well that it is a popular place to eat. Please be considerate and just call things in and take it out. This has been the second time I have seen your group, the first time you had "saved seats" for your friends, and we were ok with it at first, then as we realized it had be a 45 min wait when we were already there 15 min before your friends, we became a little upset, food made us forget. Lets try to keep it to a group of 3 or less so that everyone can enjoy the seats. bringing 7 friends to hang out is just rude.
author: danny e.

description:
San Franciscans are so lame sometimes!
Just because this place is a cheap hole in the wall and appears to be authentic, people swear its the greatest.  They feel like its their little secret and they love bringing people there and showing off the cute old Burmese ladies and the totally affordable prices.  It makes them feel cool.
But they aren't cool.
They are fools.
Because the food is wack.  Its cheap, yeah, but wack.
So if you enjoy eating kinda wack food cramped shoulder to shoulder with other tasteless cheap geeks, bon apetite!
author: Skeptical Spee ..

description:
Finding this restaurant only by walking by was a true statement of a "great find".

A small joint that has maybe a total of ten counter seats, its pumping with a mom & pop (its actually two sisters and a brother) vibe and just cranking out the food!

I can honestly say I've been here numerous times already and I have never been disappointed. Super-consistentcy is what Yamo has to offer. 

My personal favorite is the Black Bean Fish- white cod fish lightly battered and sauteed with bell peppers and onions in black bean sauce.You have your choice of egg noddles or steamed rice. 

Another great dish is the Curry Chicken- chunks of chicken, potatoes, onions and a mild spicy curry sauce that seeps into your rice so you can just lap your plate clean.

Other favorites I've tried, Chicken Salad- crispy cabbage with chicken, crispy garlic and some other secret spices and nuts. Samosas are very tasty but I did find they were frozen prior, but none the less its a small operation. Pot stickers are another good one if your just craving apps or adding it to your meal. Fresh coconut juice (cut open right in front of you) and hot tea are nice accompaniments.

My last suggestion is that Yamo should be part of a list of restaurants you have in mind trying, because the line could be out the door or they maybe not enough seats for your crew or date. Just keep this in mind, otherwise To-Go is your other option! 

Bon appetit!
author: Dave S.

description:
I'm sorry! I just don't understand the hype about this place! The food's not bad, but I wasn't wowed by it. Granted this is my first rendezvous with Burmese food, but if all Burmese food is like this, I might not be impressed.

I won't go into the details about the physical location of the restaurant since it's been covered in depth by others already.

We started off with the tea leaf salad which was delicious until about the fifth bite. After that your taste buds get kind of overloaded and the dish stops being tasty. Then came the samusas which my friend claimed tasted like pizza rolls! I think he meant the dough, which I do have to agree with. The curry filling was slightly spicy and well-seasoned.

The entree was the curry chicken over egg noodles. Is it me, or does it taste like a watered down version of Thai yellow curry? I guess I'm used to curries being more in-your-face, so Yamo's was a little boring for me.

 I would go back to try out the other menu items that people have recommended, just because I still have faith that I can like Burmese cuisine. Got to try some other places out now for comparison!
author: Amy C.

description: Found the fish chowder noodles kind of bland. But the curry, salad, and cold noodles were very solid. Definitely kind of a frenetic eating experience. But pleasant.
author: Guillermo K.

description: Love how everything is spicy, tasty, and super inexpensive. Got the mango salad and cold house noodle dish, both of which were extremely tasty and cleared my sinuses. Yamo has limited but coveted seating at the food bar, and the provides the greatest value for your $5-8 lunch ever.
author: Angie C.

description: I went again last night. I called in my order this time - I got there and they handed it to me within 2 minutes of walking in the door. Amazing. I heart this place. I want to move to the Mission just to be closer to it. I had Samusas and Chicken Chow Mein. The best part about the noodles is that you can taste the flames.
author: Krystha B.

description:
I would give this place six stars if I could.

Unbelievable service and excellent quality of food.

I walked into Yamo three days ago to place a rather large order for a meeting we were having at my office.  Since I work at a non-profit and our food budget is limited, I'm not too flexible with how much we can spend, but I still have to find a way to feed everyone.  I wanted to order a couple entrees on the party platter menu but the total was something that I knew my organization did not have room to cover.  So then what?  Well first of all the staff rocks and went above and beyond to try to accomodate our hiccup.  Judy was awesome and did everything she could to get her boss Joseph (the owner) on the phone since he wasn't in at the time.  When we were able to get a hold of him, he was incredibly kind and really tried to work with me on the price.  In the end I was able to stay within budget and placed the food order.

Fast forward to two days later and all I can say is if you haven't been to Yamo, don't walk, run!  The food was such a hit at the meeting that a couple of us, including myself, couldn't restrain ourselves and got second and third servings.  If there weren't others around I probably would've kept going!  Since I'm vegetarian, I only tried the samusas and curry tofu, both rocked!  Others who had the pork chow mein, mango chicken, and beef curry only had raves to share.

This place is a little hole in the wall that is easy to overlook, but if you do happen to stop and go in, I guarantee, you will NOT be disappointed!
author: Swetha G.

description:
To be completely honest, it's been so long since I've been here that I don't even remember what I ordered.  (I live in SoCal),  I'm mostly writing this review just to give a heads up to all the friends that left me and went up north.

Although I don't remember what I ate, I do remember it was delicious and I was really impressed with the place.  I think it's changed a little since I dined there.  For one, there were no ladies working the counter as everyone has mentioned.  It was some "rock n roll" asian dude.  He simply did not give a fuck.  If we wanted something to drink, we were instructed to come behind the counter and grab it ourselves.  We gave him an order and he fixed us "something like that", with his own delicious personal touches.  The sign displaying the hours were "If the door is open, we're open.  If the door is closed, we're closed"

The one thing I remember is they served black rice, and I wasn't expecting that.  It was great though.  Next time I'm in the area I'd definitely like to try it again and see if it's as good as I remember.
author: Bryan R.

description:
I would have never found this place in a gazillion years if not for Yelp!  Thanks, Yelpers!!!

(Now I am in big trouble after finding this place!! I go to meetings around the corner from Yamo few times a week.  It will be hard to skip the place.  I just have to remember to bring cash everytime.)



Date:  November 25, 2008 at 11:58 AM

Occasion: Lunchbreak. Food to go.

Venue: The place is cute:  like a grandma's kitchen in Asia kind of cute.
              The whole place is a kitchen with counter seatings for 9.
              Think Asian, rustic version of the Mario Batali Kitchen.
 
Decor: None. Rustic. Simple. Basic
             Stove, pots and pans
              One long counter seating.

Social Scene:  I was the only person at the place aside from the two old ladies cooking.  I had the best seat in the house and was very much entertained watching them cook.  One customer came in and picked up her phoned-in order.

Taste:  I ordered "Curry fish with steam rice"  Spicy. Fish was fresh and melt in your mouth. YAMOLICIOUS!!! Get it? ;)

Future Taste:  Tea Salad
                           Mango chicken
                           Everything on the menu which is a short-list.

Tab:  $5.25 ( no tax/no tip jar in sight)

Skip:  Dining at Yamo if you are claustrophobic like me.  This place is good for meals to go.  Otherwise, you will be eating elbow to elbow with the person right next to you.  

Downside:  Cash only.
                      You'll end up smelling of food while waiting for your order.
                      Forget about privacy. Save your racy stories for dessert somewhere else.
author: Leah E.

description:
Delicious.

Recommendations... Tea Leaf Salad. & Curry Fish w/ Noodles.

Ladies at the counter are great.
author: Sara K.

description:
As we know, my current obsession is Burmese tea salad, and Yamo delivers in this department. 

Not overly oily, (my only criticism of Burma Superstar's rendition), this tea salad smacks of tea, with about a hundred other flavors going on at once. Sweet, salty, savory, spicy. I love the chickpeas, dried fava (?) beans, fried garlic, and fried peanuts.  And it's made authentically with shredded cabbage, instead of romaine lettuce.

Also, for a whopping $5.25, you can have a heaping place of about a thousand other curries and stirfries. I'd suggest mango chicken salad. Less so the beef curry.
author: Kathleen G.

description:
Warning: This is a review of the "OLD" yamo for historical purposes:

When I first stumbled upon Yamo, I felt like I was back in time, or lost in New York. Seriously, it was like another dimension. It was really special and really different.

Yamo used to be a really weird all vegan thai restaurant run by a guy named Ta Wei. Ta Wei had a masters in german expressionism and wanted the place to look like an oversized Joseph Cornell sculpture. He wasn't really a chef. He also wasn't vegan (if you asked he would say he did it for the chicks). Anyone who ate there in the old days would remember how just crazy and weird it was.

He used to play Bobby Brown on vinyl and would let you come behind the counter and help cook if he liked you. You could BYOB or just settle for the cheap (sometimes free) mexican beer he would lug in everynight. I once traded him guitar lessons for cooking lessons. He made "sangria" with some fruit, carlo rossi, a 2 liter of coke and a chunk of tamarind in it. Ta Wei was also a crazy Republican, but you wouldn't know it by his panama hat, hawaiian shirt and giant zero gauge bone ear plugs.

One day I went to go eat there and it was just closed. Apparently he had had enough of the restaurant biz and sold it so he could travel. Crazy. It was bought by a pair of chinese women and was just a divey noodle joint before they went 'burmese'

The name by the way was short for "Yamo Be There" (Ta Wei always wished he was more gangster).

Does anyone else remember these days? Have Photos? Anyone know where Ta Wei is these days?
author: Zac H.

description:
If you can find this mysterious Burmerse haven, then By ALL MEAN EAT UP! 

The Tea Tree Salad is worth a 2 mile hike.
author: J J.

description: uhhh...ya-no. this place is a disaster. i was actually looking forward to the authentic flavors that I expected to come out of this hole-in-the wall, but i was very disappointed. first, no samusa soup...lame. next,  the veggie curry and veggie chow fun, both lack any flavor, and the veggies themselves were not fresh. the tea-leaf salad was ok. also, the lady who took our order on the phone and took our payment, seemed angry and just decided not to give us back any change. finally, the kicker was finding a hair in our noodles...done and done.
author: Mayur A.

description:
Don't get me wrong, I'm totally into the gritty cheap eats experience and am way down with the hard-workin' ladies serving it up homestyle, but at a certain point in life (after 30?) you realize that some things are worth paying the extra couple bucks for - furniture, electronics, clothes, and pork.

I've been to this greasy spot more times than I can count and have always kept it veggie because quite frankly, I'm scared of their meat as I've yet to figure out where they might keep the fleshy items refrigerated. 

Last weekend my Special Lady Friend and I stopped in for a late lunch and to my dismay she ordered the House Noodles with pork. I know she has a much heartier eastern Euro constitution than I so I say nothing. By the time I'd cleared through my mushrooms and veggies she'd managed to suss out the noodles leaving behind an entire bowl of greasy pig bits. Huh? She claimed it was suspect and her tummy notso hotso, so we paid the $11 check and slipped out just as the smoke alarm set off screeching - a sound cue so aptly timed and suggestive it could not have been written into a script. 

Our flat is not far from Yamo, relatively speaking, but we could not get home quick enough. Comprende?

Advice: If you're way mega broke and not expected to leave your toilet for the next 24 hrs then by all means, throw the dice. Otherwise spend the extra five bucks and get yourself to a place with refrigeration and a visible health code rating.
author: Prattle P.

description:
Yummy. Utilitarian. Cheap.

I am addicted to the tofu spring rolls. $3.50 for two enormous delicious food logs. Ask for extra peanut sauce because you need it. OM NOM NOM NOM.

They also have delicious whole coconuts full of fresh coconut milk for $2. When you close your eyes, they have the magical effect of transforming this narrow dingy place into Polynesian paradise.

Also, if you're vegetarian like me, don't feel too intimidated by their limited vegetarian options. They make most things to order, so you can request almost anything on the menu with tofu instead of meat.
author: T.Z. R.

description:
This place is such a trip.  When I poked my head in here after finding this place on Yelp I was really blown away.  I definitely felt like I stepped into a different world. I hope they never renovate because SF definitely needs places unique places like Yamo to contrast the glitsy pretentious restaurants out there.  I definitely like this place and will go back again, I mean hey can't beat the prices but I can't really give it more than 3 stars.  Potstickers were pretty bad and I love potstickers...springrolls were also eh but better than the potstickers. Mango chicken was not nearly as good as I expected it to be since previous yelpers had reviewed it so glowingly. It was super spicy and I really had hoped they would have wanted more chicken with my plate of mango.  The black bean fish was pretty tasty though. 

So definitely check it out and keep going...decent enough food and I love the simple set-up. I really felt like I was back in the Philippines at times.
author: Lance D.

description: Really small street vendor counter style service; only 8-10 customers fit in at a time.  Expect a short wait. Cheap, quick, friendly and funny service from older Burmese grandmother types who bicker and joke between themselves (probably about you).  The mushroom tofu dish is amazing, the tea leaf salad also quite good!
author: Michael B.

description:
Whenever I'm in the mission and not in the mood for a burrito (weird, I know but it happens!) and only have $6, I always give Yamo a call! I've never went in and sat down for a meal, but I like to call ahead, order, and pick it up 10 minutes later. So cheap and easy! 

One star off for the tea leaf salad I ordered once which was super tiny and didn't fill be up. Other than that, it's been a regular stop for me!
author: Anna Y.

description: Despite the high reviews, I found this place to be just A-OK. For the price, it's definitely worth it, but can't say it was too standout-ish. I tried the fish chowder and the beef curry. I'd come back again, for it's a quaint literally hole in the wall place.
author: Rogerio F.

description:
Not sure what all the hype is about, frankly. Unless it's from folks who really like to get their hole-in-the-wall fix on, bc yes, Yamo is that. So go if you miss cramped, intimate little spots - it's on par with all the holes we miss overseas (and NY). And yes, the 3 old ladies are adorable.

But I have a hard time advising anyone to go for the food itself. I don't even have to be a foodie to say that. It's mediocre at best, and bad / gas-producing at worst. And it's not like anything I ever ate up and down the Burmese border. I'm just sayin.
author: kt s.

description:
Oh, Yamo. How come you don't exist down in LA? 

My friend took us here for a final bite to eat before we left SF and though we had to wait since the whole counter was taken up, I was truly satisfied with my bowl of Burmese noodles and chicken and garlic and *drooool*. I also tried the chicken curry and some other fish noodle thing (sorry, I don't really memorize the menu), and everything was just perfect. So yummy in my tummy that the only conceivable thing you can do next is curl up and take a nap in your mommy's bed. Unfortunately, my parent's house was nowhere near, so I just cried instead.

Asian comfort food 4 life!
author: Moye I.

description: I've flown by this corner dozens of times on my bike without noticing this place, It might be because the storefront is maybe10 feet wide.  There's something amazing about eating Asian food just seconds off the range, cooked a couple feet from your eyes.  The open kitchen ensures relative cleanliness and a memorable ambiance.  The fish curry soup is totally legit, and rivals the likes of Burmese Superstar for almost half the price.  Yamo tops my list of hole-in-the-walls west of Mission St!
author: Phil L.

description:
A fellow Burmese food enthusiast invited to lunch at Yamo. "You have to get there by 11:30", he warned. He wasn't kidding-within moments after we sat down at the bar, there were a number of people lining up behind us. 
To be perfectly honest, I was skeptical about "atmosphere". The decor reminded me to crack den chic-dark sloppy painted walls, archaic ripped vinyl bar stools, a grime encrusted grease hood... Toto, we are not in the St. Regis anymore. 

We started with the tea leaf salad-I would have preferred some more acid in the salad or some rice to cut the overwhelming richness. Next we tried the mango salad which was much more to my liking. I liked the interplay of the sweet mango with the pungent vinegary dressing. 

I would never in a million years ordered the Chicken Noodle soup but I'm so glad my friend did. The "broth" was thick and creamy with coconut milk and curry. The chicken breast slices were stir-fried to perfection and the egg noodles were fresh and springy. A perfect dish. 

The cold egg noodles were a bit of a disappointment after the perfection of the chicken noodle soup but were tasty nonetheless. 

At $5.25 for an entree this place is a considerable value and I would definitely order to go in a heart beat.
author: Monica L.

description:
Small unassuming place to get some really inexpensive good food.  Pretty fast, too but not as fast as like King of Thai or something but hey, I appreciate it when the chicken in my curry is cooked thoroughly.  They can seat at most like 8 or something inside, so try not to come with a bunch of peeps.  Prices INCLUDE tax (chicken curry = $5.25)

They don't even have a sign on the front anymore, nor do they even have #s on the building haha!  Good look finding it!  The pictures from the outside might help.
author: Dong T.

description:
Super yummy crunchy garlic goodness-on meat!  MMmmmmm....got introduced to this pit of deliciousness (and i say pit because it's not much to look at) when i was working at SF General.  We would speed off on our lunch break only to beg people to move down the counter to fit all 5 starving ladies who wanted to gorge themselves on homemade noodle dishes.  I can't get enough of the beef sauteed with garlic and, as i write this, i can almost feel my insides curling in on themselves wanting more, more, more!
plus, the ladies who work there are so sweet and bust their ass trying to cook everything in a timely manner.  sometimes i get the urge to start washing dishes just to express my gratitude for such incredibly cheap and amazing food.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Five stars for the simple fact that I went in with VERY low expectations and ended up practically licking my plate clean.

What the hell? 

My friend and I had just gone to the Found Magazine event at The Dark Room and he wanted to grab a bite to eat. He lives in the Mission, I didn't, and he suggested we wander over to Yamo.

I was skeptical, of course. A small greasy spoon serving curry? But oh... how I love curry. So I couldn't resist. So I ordered the chicken curry dish with rice. And I was not disappointed. At. all.

Obviously, with 118 reviews already, this place isn't exactly a secret. But I had to put my two cents in.

The downsides? One of the ladies behind the counter was really skilled at avoiding eye contact until she was ready to take our order, which took a few minutes. And they accidentally gave my friend rice instead of the noodles he had ordered. Which they quickly corrected by bringing him a plate of noodles. So, no real problems, so much as quirks.
author: Tara B.

description: Great food at a cheap price.  Only problem is that there is always a line and rarely a free counter spot. (the place is small).  They are also hilariously a bit "soup nazi-ish".  I just got my coke in a glass bottle, and when i asked for a glass with ice I just got a "NO ICE!" response.  Authentic.
author: rahul c.

description:
I have never posted, but after what Tracy Y said about Yamo I had to post the truth:

If you google SF Health Dept and goto 'How to find a resturant score" you'll see it doesn't mention vermin anywhere when searching Yamo, but does mention refrigeration issues and it seems they volunteered closed it themselves.
I didn't goto the location, so sorry if there's a sign on the building I am unaware of, but I just wanted to post more info.
Can't wait for Yamo to come back!
author: keith h.

description:
Yamo is very much like a walk-in closet, except there's no room for your clothes because there's a kitchen in it. Suck in your belly, find a seat at the counter, and wait for the Three Ladies to whip up some seriously tasty (and, according to a friend who has visited Burma many times, authentic) dishes.

I am a pot sticker connoisseur and can't remember having had better ones recently. We also got a chicken curry -- which was aggressively spicy, but in a good way -- and pork chow fun. No bland portions here: everything was really rich and really good.

Gotta mention the cons: the air in there is THICK with smoke/oil from the fryer. A little more ventilation would keep people there a little longer...although with only like ten seats, maybe they want high turnover. In any case, you've been warned. As other yelpers have noted, getting the attention of the ladies, even in a place this small, was challenging; but you sort of feel like you're flagging down someone in their own kitchen, which is pretty much what's happening, and that's rude. Still -- gotta ding them one star for barely breathable air.

That said, do not fail to visit Yamo. Holes-in-the-wall are by definition not quirk-free, but the food at this one more than makes up for it.
author: andy d.

description: A delicious mix of Burmese and Chinese food - honestly prepared! This is just the right place to eat at after work (lunch is advisable too if you don't mind the lingering smell of sauteed onions in sesame oil on you).  Tried their mushroom tofu dish with noodles and their black bean dish..YUM! It's slightly oily but one will forget about that once the flavor kicks in the mouth. The menu is simple...prices are extremely fair. The place is small-bar stool seating. But it doesn't matter,  the food comes out fast and not a place for chatting it up. Well...you're not gonna want to talk but eat and eat and eat.
author: Claude C.

description: 2 words for Yamo 's food : cheap and good!
author: Natiya N.

description: Great hidden little spot in the heart of the mission. Tasty clean food, cheap prices, homey service. Done. Perfect spot for mid-week, late-afternoon lunch. Mango chicken delicious...
author: David B.

description:
Yamo is a great place to start the night if you're looking for an adventure.  It is a random hole in the wall near the corner of 18th and Mission.  You walk in and you are immediately amazed how tiny the space is.  You sit at the counter and watch the bustle of the kitchen.

Highlights:
* Yamo House Noodles with Pork- delicious. Pork was thinly sliced and savory.  The noodles were a bit greasy but overall it was good.  Warning: Portions were small
* Black bean fish - good but not mind blowing.  It could have used a bit more flavor.  However, for $5.50, I'm not sure you could expect a lot more.

My overall takeaway with the place was it had good service and decent food, but I wouldn't wait to eat here.  If I had time I would rather go to Richmond or the East Bay for amazing Burmese food and pay $3-4 more dollars. Or I would go to another Chinese joint in the mission and pay the same price for food that has bigger portions and is more flavorful.
author: Melanie O.

description:
fresh.  quick.  cheap. 

super tasty!

i highly recommend this place for a quick chinese/burmese meal.  seating is extremely limited.  take out is better for 3-4 people. 

the samusa is awesome.  the noodles are really good.
author: Peter K.

description:
probably my favorite restaurant on earth. actually it ties in-n-out.

try the mango chicken and the house noodles. house noodles alllll the way.

i always bring my friends from out of town here.

looks like a ghetto hole in the wall, but don't be fooled. it's FANTASTIC.
author: Jared M.

description:
I love Yamo both for the no-frills selections and bargain price!

Except for very few  items, all dishes are for only $5.25 or less..and that includes the tax!

I have tried several including the chicken curry and noodles...and each one comes in a healthy portion and taste excellent for the price you are paying.

This place is very small located in a somewhat shady neighborhood so it really is best if you go during daytime just a bit before or after lunch to avoid lines.  You won't even know where it is unless you look for the torn up awning above the front  door.  The walls outside have graffiti leading you to belive that it may not be safe to even eat inside at all!  However, you can also look for this place just by looking for people waiting outside.

As you go in, you will only see a long counter with about 10 stools on one side.  The other side is the kitchen where you will see the 3 sisters preparing, cooking and serving you.  

The only negative I would say about this place is that the sisters are not that attentive especially when it gets busy.  They get so busy chopping, preparing, taking orders by phone, etc., they would forget to refill your glass of water.  At times, you have to shout a bit louder so they can hear you asking for more water or your check.

I go back to this place whenever I can, but I do not always expect great service each time.
author: Andy P.

description:
When the pocket book is hurting, and I am too lazy to cook, I ride over to Yamo's for food to go. The place has a simple entree formula. 

Entree = curry + choice of fried or sauteed veggies/meat/seafood/poultry + rice/egg noodles

Fried fish curry with egg noodles is a staple. I wash down the yummy inexpensive goodness with the well stocked grass jelly drink. Am I the only person who orders this?

If you see a line 4-people deep, just get your food to go. It is not worth the hell hole wait. Nope you do not go here for ambiance. Not for a date. Definitely not to take in the open kitchen unless you like to reek of curry for the rest of the night. Plus the bickering about how things should be done amongst the 4 ladies gets old. Given the place, you let a lot of the pet peeves pass: getting your appetizer after your entree or someone else getting their food before you even though they ordered after you. So pick up and get it to go. 

Unfortunately Yamo is not opened on Sunday nights, when I need it the most after an intense weekend.
author: Cathy H.

description: Part of the experience here is to watch the three ladies get utterly confused about the orders...  I've never got anything I've ordered right here, but the food is always good..... OH WELL!
author: Demanding T.

description: This tiny place is worth the wait. I had trouble convincing myself to eat anywhere else during my week in San Francisco. The tea-leaf salad is a must.
author: Jen W.

description: The service is crappy and the line is sometimes long,but this place is totally worth it! I've lived here for a few years and was a little intimidated to step foot into what seems like 5 chairs and 20 people in line waiting to sit in those 5 chairs. Huge dishes start around 5 bucks and all of their sides are about 3! Their curry chicken is to DIE for!...and the little fried curry potatoes that come in the dish *drool*  Last friday was my first time eating Yamo and yesterday was my third out of the week.Check it out!
author: mary c.

description:
Somewhere on 18th street, in a small dark closet that has a doorway, a couple of Burmese ladies are busting their butts serving up fresh and tasty food.

I was fluctuating between three and four, but the more I thought about it, the more I liked about this place than not.

As everyone has said, yes.  It is small.  I ventured in at 130 on a Saturday (actually, 138 because i was late...) and there were plenty of seats available for us.  

The first thing I did notice when I walked in was the heavy smell of oil.  I knew I was going to stink after I left which bummed me out because I was heading back to a party after...  Grr.

Anyhow, the menu had several options.  All of the dishes were under $6?!?  That's my kind of place!!!!

My friend who I came with was the professional...  She promptly ordered up the Tea Tree Salad and the Chicken Noodle soup.

I ended up ordering the Tofu Curry, they ask if you want it over noodles or rice.  I chose the noodles, and I'm glad I did!!!

I tried some of my friends Tea Tree salad and it was DELICIOUS.  I wish I just ordered three of them and had that as my meal.....

Her soup looked delicious, and my curry tofu was just okay....  It didn't have a whole lot of taste to it, but the noodles underneath it were DELICIOUS....

This place was definitely a good find.  The women working their are nice, and efficient!!!  She realized they had put my tofu over rice instead of the noodles before she even handed it to me and within only 2 minutes, problem remedied!!!

I look forward to trying a few more things they have to offer, and hopefully they can throw some tofu in their chicken noodle soup instead of chicken.  I would like that.  I also enjoyed watching them work.  Her wrapping a spring roll was the BEST!
author: Jess R.

description: Thumbs up to Yelp because without their iphone app we never would have discovered this hidden gem.  Quick, tasty and cheap.  And all of my Burmese friends tell me its very authentic.  House noodles and tea leave salad are souper.
author: Michael N.

description:
What a find.  Don't be intimidated by the complete lack of decor. The food and entire vibe speak for themselves. The two ladies behind the counter must be two of the hardest working cooks in the city. You place the order with one lady, they both get to work putting their delicious home-cooked Burmese creations together right before your eyes. The food is clearly authentic, inexpensive, and embodies all of those fabulous, interesting flavors that make Burmese so f-ing great. 

What we ate: house noodles with beef, cold noodles with prawn, tea leaf salad, chicken salad. All the meat tasted so flavorful and fresh, the house noodles were rich and hearty, the cold noodles an explosion of delightful flavor, and the salads were crisp and wonderful. Tea leaf salad is one of my favorites and the Yamo version rocks. 

I am counting the days till I eat here again.
author: Jenny K.

description: Much of my philosophy in life involving food stems from being full and it being cheap. This place has questioned some of my beliefs. i remember walking in to this literally "hole in the wall restaurant" and thinking to myself it looks like cheap Chinese food in a barely able to fit 8 people capacity room and it'll be alright. Oh man was I incredibly wrong. It can actually fit about 14 people .  is cash only so make sure just like in all of the Mission to bring cash. This place wins 5 stars because not only is it cheap but the quality of food and the experience you get outweigh the other negatives such as waiting in a small line, barely fitting yourself into a seat, and the women yelling at each other in Cantonese (which I believe is not a negative). Things you cannot go wrong with at Yamo are the Cold noodle and Chicken noodle. If you want to impress someone with your local familiarity. This local joint is it.
author: Patrick W.

description: They are not going to greet you, they won't hardly notice you but they keep it real food and personality wise, and the curry is the best I've had to date!!! Ask for a coconut..if your lucky you will get it ha.
author: Shabnam A.

description:
That woman is a machine!!   Okay. Let me lay it out.   Spring rolls, veggie samusas, tea leaf salad, mango salad, beef chow fun, chicken cold noodle, and then what ever your friends are having.

Everything is like three to five bucks and there is no tax. The place is a lil' scrappy but you can always take it to the park. Seriously, Yamo is the answer to everything...except fine dining.
author: Inbal R.

description:
Well, it ain't no first date place - between the cafeteria ambience, buzzing fluorescents, white noise from the fan, no alcohol policy, and gritty neighborhood, you're not going to win friends and influence people by bringing them here.

UNLESS.  Unless they only care about the food.  Because the food is very good, and ALMOST FREE.

I'm sorry, Burma SuperStar.  I came to the party early, I loved you, you rocked my very soul, and then came the day a few short weeks ago when I went by at 5:30 on a Sunday expecting to waltz in the door and sit down at my favorite table and THE ENTIRE KNOWN UNIVERSE was waiting outside.  People were lined up four deep and you hadn't even opened yet.  A victim of your own success, I sped by . . . never to return.  

Plus, what up with doubling your prices?  I mean, you got the goods, no doubt about that, but sheeeeeeeet.

Back to Yamo's . . . the tea leaf salad is a crunchy, spicy delight; the spring rolls and peanut sauce are simple and tasty; and the house curry with beef, chicken or prawns over rice or noodles was sublime, although a little greasy.  When the bill came I did a doubletake - where am I?  Is there an exchange rate?  How could dinner for two be THIRTEEN DOLLARS?!?

Believe it.  Go!
author: Jefferson C.

description: Love Yamo! Awesome chicken soup and house noodles. I usually take it to go because seating is limited and I end up smelling like fried food if I am there longer then 10 minutes, but the place is great and you can't beat the price.
author: Rositsa K.

description:
This was so good! and CHEAP!  The chicken curry was yummy~! Its this little place right in the middle of the street. And anyone could totally miss it, if they're not looking hard enough! It's one of those places that looks really janky but has great food !

Seating is limited! Luckily, when I went everyone just left,so we had seating right away! But the wait is definitely worth it!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I used to love this place until... they put chicken in my food which I took home and when I called back to get a replacement and drive the 5 mile round trip, they hassled me really bad and were so jerky that I was afraid to pick up the "replacement". I was on the phone for 5 minutes while they argued, loudly about weather or not to make me a replacement. Whaaa?

Seriously, not worth it at any price. I am so bummed, my memories are tarnished and I will not go back.The sad thing is that I have eaten there 50+ times over the years, and maybe 40 of those times were really great. But this last one was so bad...

Two stars because of the previous decent experiences.
author: Freud R.

description: Small, loud, casual. Delicious food. Coconut drink is very refreshing.
author: David G.

description:
The price and location are key reasons that keep me coming back again and again.  Big portions of Burmese food for $5.25?  Three blocks from my apt?  Awesome to-go containers I can reuse?  Counter seating ONLY?  Burmese women working hard to feed me some good ol homecookin?  It beats heading out to Burma Superstar (love me some burma superstar!) to wait in a loooong first come, first serve line (depending on how many are in your party, they have been known to bump smaller parties to seat larger ones! booooo to them for that!).

I love the Yamo house noodles, mango chicken, and black bean fish.  I tried the chow mein and veggie curry - both were ok, but I prefer the above choices over these.  Also, I suggest getting an order of samosas to munch on while you wait for your food.  It's satisfying for my tummy and wallet!
author: Lynda N.

description:
Yamo definitely has its funky charm. The place is run by a handful of kitchen-aunties who seem to work with amazing precision in the tightest most cramped kitchen I have seen in this country.

One visit I had the pleasure to sit at the end of the bar next to a 300+ pound black transvestite wearing zebra skin patterns, and a fake namedropping artist / producer who uncomfortably avoided direct questions. On a more recent visit, I sat next to a quiet baby momma type woman who after finishing most of her chicken noodles, pulled what seemed like a premeditated  dine and dash.

As for the food, Its delicious but greasy. I figured this out after eating at Yamo for five days in a row. 
The food is Chinese - Burmese. Note that many Asian restaurants including Thai, Vietnamese, Indonesian, just to name a few., are commonly run by ethnic Chinese. These countries have historically had ethnic Chinese populations. These cuisines were hybridized a long time ago, and are authentic traditions in their own right.

Sometimes the best bet is calling ahead for take out so you don't have to play Russian roulette in terms of getting one of the 10 seats. The only downside to this is their use of wasteful plastic food containers.

I have tried and can honestly recommend every dish on their menu. The samosas are little deep fried curry-filled turnovers. They are delicious but a little redundant if you order another curry based dish. The pot-stickers are fried just right and have a delightfully aromatic ginger finish. For the grease-shy, I  would recommend using restraint in ordering  either of the above fried appetizers along side an already greasy entree such as any of the noodle dishes. The Spring rolls are very light and refreshing and then there is the tea leaf salad which I would suggest ordering  as an appetizer to be split between more than one person (as opposed to a main dish) as it is quite high in sodium.
author: Joshua D.

description: Wait, did I seriously just get that huge bowl of delicious noodles for 6 bucks?!  Yes.
author: Alice H.

description: How have I never been here before??  I *LOVE* hole in the wall places like this with counter only seating and brusque service.  Efficiency at its best!  We were still standing outside when they started our order and had our food served up by the time we got to our seats.  Tea salad. YUM! House Noodles--pretty tasty, as well!  Spring rolls, too? Our bill was ridiculously small considering how much food we had.  Perfect meal after a monster workout, too! :)
author: Aim B.

description: Your food is good, but not good enough to be hella rude.. The head "lady" is a problem.  I was a fan, but im def not coming back anymore.
author: Sophia M.

description:
DELICIOUS FOOD FOR CHEAP!!

I tried the mango chicken and it was to die for.

I love hole in the wall kind of places. Definitely popular and highly reviewed, so it may be a bit crowded sometimes, but the cooks are so friendly, nice, and efficient about making food quick. And you can watch them make your food in front of you. The true Asian experience.
author: Shelley A.

description:
It's great to watch my dinner prepared before me - at least I know they're not really lying to me about what is in the dish.

What's not to love about this tiny diner that instead of grilled cheese serves Burmese food.  Hello!?  It's awesome.

I like counter service, I like the quick to the point ladies that work there and I love the honesty of this place.
author: Krissy M.

description:
Burmese food that make family can be proud of!  

It's as good as it gets without paying for more or higher quality ingredients and fillings.  

Fantastic and cheap!  I recommend the Catfish Chowder, the Chicken Coconut noodle soup, the tea leaf salad and the curry beef.  Also for those of you who enjoy samosas but don't like the indian ones because the wrapper is too thick, you'll love the burmese samosas as the use the think crispy won ton/ spring roll skins.  

Unfortunately it seats only about 10 and it's counter seating only.  Not great for big parties or parties of any time unless you are lucky to show up with ample seating.  I had a party of 5 and we were able to score the last 5 (in a row) seats around 6:45pm on a Wednesday, just 5 minutes before a rush of people showed up.  

They seem to be popular with the takeout crowd so if you can find somewhere else to eat, get it to go and avoid the wait!
author: David C.

description:
very flavorful sauces!  vegetables and tofu stir fried perfect!  with fresh firm noodles!
great value for quality and flavor!!
author: Paul N.

description:
This small place has enormous charm, delicious food, and inexpensive prices. The Yamo noodles are out of this world. I've enjoyed everything that I've tried here. Not the cleanest restaurant, but the kitchen is in full view and I am satisfied with the sanitary conditions. 

Authentic ethnic is one of the culinary delights of this City.
author: Joe B.

description: loved the tea leaf salad it was delicious but different from what I am use to at burma super star. but delicious none the less. i also had yamo's house noodles with pork. that was a major disappointment, the noodles were greasy and covered with a extremely salty sauce. the pork was cooked to perfection. i felt like i was having a sodium overload. maybe it was an off night for the noodles? but the noodles were horrible. =(
author: Stella J.

description:
Seeing only one person in line at Yamo this afternoon, I quickly seized the rare opportunity to grab a seat.  Three women are in constant motion behind the bar, cooking up a storm, cleaning, chopping, prepping, taking orders, handing out deliveries, sassin' to each other....I felt bad staring at them, but it's such a small place that there's really nowhere else to look and, well, it is kind of entertaining. The crowd was a mix of hipsters and homeless. The waitress let me know that she was ready to take my order by yelling something and throwing a placemat down in front of me. I took this as a good sign.
I ordered the prawn curry and...it was horrible. Why? No flavor, just grease. The noodles were mostly steaming hot with ramdom cold, uncooked clumps. The veggies were fresh, but they were covered in this gross bland grease. I was really hungry but only ate half of it because I was too scared of the grease puddle at the bottom. I really wanted to like Yamo, but the food is just bad. 

Why is this place busy? Whyyyy? Because it's cheap? Because it's fast and convenient? You're in the mission! Go get an amazing burrito or sandwich or something, dummy.

I feel bad being so negative about this place because it's got a really raw vibe that I'm into and the ladies who work there seem really dedicated. But no. Just no.

Here's something Yamo related to cheer you up: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7HbbM-FG8lQ
author: M M.

description: Do you know that feeling of content when you get exactly what you want?  It was cold today and all I wanted was a big bowl of Yamo chicken noodle soup and a tea salad.  When I left my soul was humming.  I think right now, that is my favorite meal in San Francisco.
author: Dan L.

description:
This is one of those hole in the wall gems that one can only find through friends or nowadays, through yelp.  Nice homestyle food in a unique small (dare I say cramped) restaurant, that is more like a hallway than a room.  Seating is only at the counter, but no matter, the food is great.  The samusas are great and piping hot.  The Yamo house dishes are great.

If only parking wasn't such a pain this would be five stars.
author: Stephen H.

description:
I am really glad I walked into this tiny, stuffy little hole in the wall. I love Burma Superstar but it is all the way on the other side of the City, you have to wait a lifetime to get in and well I just can never seem to get there. But here three blocks from the office is a great tea leaf salad and good Burmese style curries. 

They don't seem to sell any booze, but this is now in my lunch rotation, so that is not an issue. It is tough to beat a big plate of very good food for $5.25.
author: Seamus M.

description:
Cheap hole in the wall place with barely any seating and minimal service.  That said, the food is great.  I had the chicken chow mein and some dumplings.  It was def greasy, but really good. The fried rice with shrimp was a bit dry and less flavorful, but still good.  

great place to try and sit down, but most people take their food to go.  def check it out.
author: Isamarie P.

description:
Yes, it's cheap. Yes, it's alright food, but really? All this excitement is over nothing. It's simple: it's just not that good.

I can't believe there is a line out the door for this tiny establishment. The samosas were poor and my dish was meh. Don't bother unless there's no line and you can't afford the extra $1-2 to get something better.
author: Dave B.

description:
3.5 stars.

Some of their dishes are really bland, but others are good.  I like the tea leaf salad and the fish chowder.

The food has a homemade taste...  Like, it doesn't taste like restaurant food, but it tastes like food your friend's mom would have made for you, if said friend's mom was Burmese.

Anyway, I keep coming back cuz it's cheap, and it's so close to me.

To go orders are a must during prime time.
author: Jung L.

description:
Is this Burmese?  I have no idea.  Is it tasty?  Yes.

Sit at the counter while the elderly Asian women cook up your meal.  You'll bump elbows with the person next to you, but that's the charm of this place.  You'll see all the ingredients being chopped, the oil cooking away, and customers wait outside for their to-go orders.

I can't remember what I ordered, but it was all pretty good.  It's the kind of hole-in-the-wall you want to call home.
author: Sanjeev B.

description: amazing.  order their house noodles.  be patient and don't be picky, enjoy the experience!
author: Jorge D.

description:
Really 3.75 stars.  I had the Yamo House Noodles here with pork and must say that this is definitely condiment intensive cuisine.  Not a lot of flavor going on but pretty good if you pile on the jalapenos, fish sauce, siracha, and whatnot.  
For only $5.25 tax included per plate, it's not like you can complain.  The stir fried stuff looked like the kind of Chinese food you find at the mall, big slices of bell pepper etc.
author: matthew w.

description:
Oh Yamo, how I worship thee. You are my favorite bargain eatery.

If you're into discovering a hole-in-the-wall place with a bit of grit then Yamo is the place to be. The real action is behind the counter, where three middle aged Burmese women scurry about--taking phone orders, chopping up salads, spooning heaps of spices onto colorful plates, working the 6-burner stove, and every once in a while, pausing from their frenetic activity to fulfill a customer's request. 

After taking our appetizer order on a small deli style-notepad, our "waitress" abruptly crooned "number 1"; and, waddling away from us, grabbed some cabbage out of the fridge, delivered said cabbage to the stove chef, and then calmly returned to finish taking our entrée order. 

After the spring rolls (which I felt could've used a bit more edginess) came my friend Eirene's House Noodles, which were fantastic. The pork was tenderized and well spiced, while the soupy noodles were flavorful and perfectly cooked. When my shrimp curry entrée arrived, a few minutes later, Eirene took the opportunity to remind the ladies that we were still waiting on our other appetizer, the tea leaf salad. "Oh right!" was the response followed by a falsetto three-part harmony chorus of "Tea Leaf Salad"! Seconds later, it seemed, the salad was in front of us. Served cold, it bombards you with an array of flavors, textures and spices. It is truly a hearty salad, with nuts, beans, shrimp, cabbage, tomato, and sesame seeds. Simply put, it is deliciousness--not to be missed. 

Oh, but did I neglect to describe the shrimp curry? Its got a mountain of red and green pepper jewels, whole shrimps and mushrooms, all smothered in a savory curried sauce. Served with your choice of noodles or rice, this dish is excellent. If all this hasn't sold you, the prices will. Actually, please never go there, because I'll never be able to get a seat.
author: Catherine O.

description:
This place may look grungy from the outside, but don't let that fool you.  The food is so good that I often stand and watch the lady cook, hoping to pick up some of her secrets through some kind of underhanded osmosis technique.

Yamo noodles with beef all the way!  Their samosas are pretty spicy too, and delicious.  

Getting a seat can be a pain however, so I usually just order takeout and take it back to my place a few blocks away.  

Oh, and they have real sugar Coca-Cola. :)
author: Chris C.

description:
The small, hallway like place fills your nostrils with the delicious wonderfulness of spices, stired fried noodles and boiling goodness as your eyes blinded by the brutal Mission sun adjust to the somewhat dimly lit place. Nothing fancy or spectacular, just really really good food made for you at the other side of the counter by three attentive Asian women, charming and delightful.
Do yourself a favor and order a cold coconut, cracked by one of your hostesses, with your food.
author: Elvin R.

description:
what's this place about? cheap decent food.
Honestly I was so hungry by the time I finally ate that I can't tell you how good it was.  Tea leaf salad was spicy (spicier than Burma Superstar for sure).  Chicken noodle soup and mango chicken seemed to be popular dishes...we got 'em both and they were good stuff.
thing was:  I went on a monday night and they were slammed with counter and to go orders...waited over 45 minutes for a to go order...and that was after sitting at the counter with no attention for 10 minutes.  I'm not complaining...just informing.  The ladies were obviously working their butt off to fill the orders.
I have no idea if this was an anomaly or a usual bit for a monday night when lots of other places in the area were closed.
So, word to the wise:  call in your order before you're starving, get it to go unless you're ok with doing it ghetto counter style.
author: miranda caroligne ..

description:
My old co-workers brought me to this charming hole-in-the wall a few years ago for a birthday lunch. There's an open kitchen and everything is cooked to order. My favorites are the yamo cold noodles with chicken (has a kick), chicken noodle soup (curry based) and the samosas. Everything is $5.25 or less, and the portions are sized well. Lots of people grab food to go here frequently, too. 

The women that run this place are so sweet, too. One time I accidentally forgot my leftovers and a cook ran out the door to catch me.
author: CQ N.

description: I've read good reviews about this place so we dropped in for lunch when we found out Mission Chinese around the corner was closed for lunch on Tuesdays and Wednesdays. I had the fish curry over noodles, my friend the chicken curry and my brother the black bean something over rice. My dish didn't even hint of curry and it was watery and bland as was the chicken curry. The black bean rice dish was just ok. Not going back especially since the old lady serving us was not unlike the old Pan Am stews on the mainland-Hawaii flights (surly). The place is tiny (I love hole-in-the-wall joints) with counter seating only and an open kitchen.  But I have a pet peeve about cooks and servers having long hair not tied nor having a cap. I sat at the end over the dishwasher and it had black mold all over the door seal and the rest of the place was not that clean-looking either. Not going back ever. Don't know why this place is popular.  Guess the young people I saw in there think it's good food.
author: g k.

description: My cold day comfort food is their chicken noodle soup made with coconut milk curry broth.   Heaven ...on...my ..tongue and in my tummy.   And a tip for those unfamiliar with the ordering system.  When she asks you, really loudly and fast, a question that you don't understand after you order, and then screams it again when you don't answer, she's asking "RICE OR NOODLE!!"    I love those ladies.
author: B B.

description: Yamo is amazing, I love the noodle bowls and they give you a ton of food for tiny prices. Seriously, its too much food!  Its also a great little hole in a wall setting, I love bringing visitors here.  Usually has a line out the door, so try to go early or on weeknights to avoid the wait, but if you can't; it's worth it anway.
author: K J.

description:
You can't get better food for $5.25.
Perfect for take-out, but sitting down at the bar looks like it could be fun, too. If you do want to sit, be ready to wait in line. For take-out, however, there is no waiting and the food was done fast.
author: Rich R.

description:
Today was my very first experience eating Burmese food, and from what I'm told, everything here is very authentic, or at least authentic from the perspective that identically prepared delectable delights can be had over there.

Meeting a very old friend from back in NY who happened to be in town, we went to Yamo based on her SO's recommendation.

What a treat!  I love experiencing new kinds of food!

The restaurant itself is ridiculously small, with only some limited counter seating, maybe seating 10 or so.  The restaurant looks like it has been around for a while too, and was incredibly popular.  The line was constant and always out the door, tho luckily, it seems that most who get their food here have are well aware that getting takeout is a much wiser choice.  

And the prices!  Excellent prices for the cheap bastard in me.  My friend and I had three dishes, a coconut drink, and a soda for under $20.  For light eaters on a budget, one dish and a drink would be about $7 combined.  Big eaters won't go broke either.  

On to the food.

Tea Salad:  $5.25
 - 4.5 stars
 - Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, oion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds.
 - Wow, by far my favorite dish of the day.  This taste and texture explosion is so good I wish they served it in meal portions, but alas, they only served it as a relatively small and light plate.  More like an appetizer.  It's got a variety of crunchy textures, including what feels like tiny croutons though with a saltier taste (I'm assuming it's the fried bean but might of been the dried shrimp), and the nuts (which I'm guessing may be peanuts), and the more raw veggie crunch of the cabbage.  There are also several software textures as well as the watery tomato texture.   And the taste?  Wow, there's a raw veggie tanginess to it, subtly to it, saltiness to it....Really, explosion is the only way to describe.  And it does this so cleanly and lightly that none of the tastes are overbearing.  This is a MUST ORDER at this small little hole in the wall.

Fish Chowder Noodle Soup $5.25
 - 2 stars
 - Soup chowder with rice noodles, shredded fish, and onions, garnished with Fried Yellowbeans and Cilantro
 - This wasn't bad, but it didn't strike me as very inspired.  The sauce was a thick reddish sauce reminiscent in texture of thick Chinese sauces poured over meats and rice.  Sorry, there should be a better explanation but I can't imagine what it is.  The noodles were very very well cooked and watery, almost like pho noodles, only it didn't seem to be the way these noodles were supposed to be.  The taste was subtle...almost too subtle.  Perhaps, tho, I'm being a little harsh because of the great tastes of the other dishes, but really, I wouldn't order this again.

Yamo Cold Noodles $5.25
 - 3.5 stars
 - Cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken
 - Pretty good dish.  The noodles are similar to chow mein noodles but without the glossy oiliness.  This was their spicy dish, but it's more tangy than spicy.  The chicken was covered in a thick, almost dry red sauce with lots of full sized peppers (like the dry peppers found in jars at the table at pizza restaurants).  This dish was also full of different flavors giving a nice complexity to the dish.  I would order this again.

Fresh Coconut $2.50
 - 4 stars
 - All my life, I thought coconuts had a stronger taste because coconut flakes used in cakes had such a strong flavor.  What a surprise to find the taste was so subtle, if you had told me it was a different fruit, I would have believed you.  So light, refreshing.  Loved it.
