I also liked that it came in a full coconut rather than a glass.  It was fun to see, and we could scrape the inside for the thicker fruity part of the coconut.    Yeah, I'd order this again, just for the novelty of it.  

Grass Jelly drink $1.00
 - 2.5 stars
 - This is a can drink.  Not carbonated, with bits of jelly in it.  It's similar in taste to Chinese turtle shell gelatin desserts.  I'd drink it again if it was served, but probably wouldn't ever be my first choice.  Still, it tasted like it was probably a healthy drink.

Though we didn't order it, the customer sitting next to us order what I think (just guessing mind you) is the Yamo House Noodles.  That looked really good.  Basically several bite sized pieces of chicken (looking like it was cooked in a thick dark sauce) over a bed of the chow mein like noodles.  It sure as heck looked good.

All in all, this place was pretty good.  If I would have rated it a straight 3.5, I'd got to 4, but given that all the food combined average below a 3.5, I'll have to go with a 3 today.

Except...the price!  The price is so good, that adds a half star right there, pushing the average up and making this place an easy 4 stars.

So with that said, Yay!  I'm a fan!
author: Tetsu N.

description:
Total Hole in the Well, Delicious Food, Intimate,Grimy = 5 Stars.

This place is brilliant -- literally just a long counter w/stools in a tiny, tiny space. 4 Burmese women packed into a tiny kitchen making delicious and super cheap food.

The Tea Salad is FAR superior to Burma Superstar's.  The flavors are beautifully balanced, and the residual heat ads a great touch to the dish.

All other food was very good!  A little low on salt/heat -- but that's the point of the copious chili, sriracha, pickled peppers, and soy sauce in front of you.  Add a little chili oil and some pickled peppers and voila -- delicious.  Beef Curry was phenomenal -- and the Chicken Noodle dish w/ Coconut broth was perfect.  Very gentle flavors -- ready to be attacked with chili oil! YUM!
author: Wojtek K.

description:
hole in the wall 
great value
freshly made
tasty
made by chinese/burmese aunties!

i like the beef house noodles, with srichia (sp?) sauce!
author: Dora F.

description: I was in town for a week or so and this place was awesome! Great Price, the noodles w/beef were my favorite and the salad was great too! A very small seating area but well worth the wait if there is a line. Some greasy noodles and a fresh coconut water = perfect hangover meal.
author: Jason J.

description:
Food:
I'm not sure what the fuss is all about. The frozen potstickers were just okay.  My friend ordered the vegetarian spring rolls and said that were bland.  She also ordered the tofu and mushroom stir fry, which was also bland.  Thankfully she didn't eat half of it and gave it to me - because at least 10 people were served their food before I got my chicken curry.  

Service:
A couple sat down next to us after we ordered, were given their apps and main course, ate, paid, and left, and my food still hadn't come.  By the time I got my curry I wasn't hungry anymore.  I had tried to tell the waitress to just give us the check, but she kept assuring me that the food was coming.  

Even if it's good (it's in a to-go container for now), I don't think it's worth going back.
author: Kat M.

description: I pretty much *die* for the tea salad.  Yum.  Really can't beat the prices here.
author: Cathy L.

description: The potstickers are just decent and the curry beef is on par with the most average of Burmese and Thai restaurants. The place is small and seating is limited. Ventilation is insufficient.
author: Sargeant T.

description: After wandering through the Mission looking for something "reasonably priced" and decent to eat, my friend who lives in the area mentioned she just wanted to cruise by and check out the menu.  Once I saw a list of items at $5.25 (the most expensive) we knew we were in. Total hallway-style sit down, which is cozy but sometimes I'm not in the neighbor-elbow-bumping mood.  Friendly service, fun to watch them prepare, and they serve COCONUTS!!! Just a straight up coconut with a straw.  What a treat!!  I'm usually not into the greasiness that some of these dishes would usually have, but for once I didn't feel too full and gross once I left.  Thanks Yamo, perfect afternoon find. :)
author: Elyse S.

description:
Although I ended up getting something pretty greasy (which I can't stomach most of the time) the food isn't all that great like people are making it out to be.  Not bad, just overrated.  Maybe it's good to white people or Americanized Asians.

I'm close to giving 2 stars like Emily Y. did but I'd like to give it one more chance since there were others that sounded refreshing and good.
author: Winton W.

description:
Being that my family is half Burmese, I'm always on the search for authentic Burmese food. Yamo is your definition of an authentic "hole in the wall". $5 for every plate, delicious, and dirty. There are only 10 or so seats so it could definitely get crowded on a busy night. We prefer to get take out on a weeknight. You can call ahead and pick up 15 minutes later. You have to check your order though, since this place gets busy and sometimes they don't remember everything you ordered. This place is pretty authentic for the city, but doesn't necessarily have all of the offerings of true Burmese cuisine.

Our favorite menu items are: tea leaf salad, samosas, beef curry with rice, and Yamo house noodles with pork, and a coconut drink. 

Great place to dine on a budget and provides authentic food at an affordable price.
author: Julie C.

description: Eating here four days a week would not be hard. Everything on the menu is awesome and the atmosphere is great. Plus the veggies are always super fresh due to the extremely high turnover of customers.
author: Dorian S.

description:
The FUCKING bomb.

The I had the potstickers and Yamo House noodles. With a Kern's Mango Nectar it was $ 9.75.

This place is like a Burmese Disneyland for your mouth.

Tiny, tiny place. Definitely part of its charm. So is the authentic Burmese kitchen. Not for you anal, clean freak types, but like Disneyland, if you don't let your eyes wander too much, its fantastic.

If you're looking to put on a show or see one, go somewhere else. If you're ready to pack it in shoulder to shoulder really and get your grub on then this is a good spot.

The staff is "in the bubble," and won't pay you much mind. They are so busy cooking, they don't have time for ass kissing. Perhaps this is why the food is so cheap. They concentrate on efficiency rather than show.

The commis chef / waitress, "Mae," was quite nice once I got her attention. At the end of the meal she just told me and the guy next to me how much we owed and went back to wrapping shrimp and lettuce in rice paper.

Then some nice girls came in, pushed me out of my seat and I was done. This is going to be a regular spot for me now.

I went back again and had the Yamo Tofu noodles and spring rolls.
spring rolls were okay. The peanut sauce that came with them was 
good. The Yamo Tofu was really tasty!
author: Philip N.

description:
Amazing hole in the wall with killer Burmese food.

My friend and I ate here before seeing a movie at the Roxie and we were pleasantly impressed.   Even though we came at 6:30pm, the place was empty and we got counter seats.  Good timing too, because all the seats were taken 10 minutes after we sat down.

We split the tea leaf salad and the mango chicken.  The tea leaf salad was really good- I'm especially glad that the dried shrimp wasn't too obvious, as the sight of them creeps me out.  Tea flavor was balanced and not overpowering.  Unlike Burma Superstar, this wasn't mixed tableside, but I wasn't paying for that level of service.  Also, the mango chicken was really good.  I had been skeptical by the preponderance of green pepper (which usually kills the dish for me) but this blended in surprisingly nicely with the mango.  It would have been awesome if they had brown rice, but white rice did the trick.

Service was really quick.  We were in a rush but we got our food within 10 minutes of ordering

Plus the meal was dirt-cheap.  I think it cost $15 for dinner for two.

If you hang out in the mission but haven't gone here, I would head over here immediately
author: Jeff A.

description:
I LOVE Yamo.  (Not sure why it's "Thai Kitchen" -- I thought it was Burmese?)

Anyhoo, you walk in to this 300sf, long, skinny place and you've got all you need: 8 stools at a bar that's 2 feet away from the kitchen where they're prepping the goodness.  

It's a family run place, and when I went in there tonight, I enjoyed talking w/some of the kids.  They were hanging out, playing cards, and helping prep.

Prices are cheap ($5.25 for amazing tea or mango salad), $3.25 for spring rolls, and $5.25 for main dishes like Yamo noodles (yum), chicken coconut soup, and all kinds of other goodness.  No beer, so have a drink beforehand or better yet get a fresh coconut milk.

I give them 3 months before they break their lease and move to bigger digs.  It's that good.  A cheaper, closer (if you live near the Mission), and just about as good version of Burmese Superstar.
author: Scott M.

description:
You know when you're told about something that's suppose to be SUPER AWESOME and AMAZING and WONDERFUL, yadda, yadda, yadda, then you experience it yourself and it's not so great because you've had your expectations built up? Well, I wish that was the explanation behind my experience at Yamo yesterday.

Although the prices were decent (you don't get very much food for your 5.25) and the service was fairly quick, I wasn't so impressed with the food.
I was so excited to have a coconut juice straight from the coconut, but it wasn't very fresh - it was on the verge of turning and the flesh inside was lavender colored. Eegh!
I ordered the house noodles with beef because of all the Yelp recommendations. The noodles were delicious, but the beef... it was crispy and EXTREMELY salty! I wish the beef tasted like somethings other than salt. And, of course, it was all pretty greasy. At least I was pleasantly surprised by the little bits of fresh green onion and cilantro.
author: Sharon W.

description:
Cheap good fast food.  

The tea leaf salad is unique but not my favorite dish.  
I like the fish curry and house noodles best. 
Samosas are so so....fried to a crisp like an egg roll but with a pyramid shape.   
You have 8 stools to choose from and you might smell like fried food (air circulation is nil) when you come out.
author: PM o.

description:
Love kichy spots like this.  I've had this bookmarked for over a year after living in the Mish.  So, clearly I was so disappointed cuz it was such an AVERAGE meal.  

Great prices.  Women who've worked the wok for seemingly their whole lives right in front of you.  8-10 stools, coat racks, etc.  AVERAGE FOOD.  Officially UNbookmarked.
author: Robby T.

description:
I really wanted to like this more.  It's cheap, you can watch the food being made in front of you, and the ladies who work here are pretty damn focused.

But...the small size really made me feel claustrophobic.  People coming in for to-go orders and waiting for the counter made it impossible to move, and I just wanted to eat my food and get out of there.  The food, I thought, was good but not amazing (and not nearly as spicy as I had hoped!).  I would recommend only take out from this place.
author: Anne D.

description:
I was so tickled to be brought to this place after an afternoon at the MOMA. It was the perfect antidote to high art. 
Yamo is a small, cramped hole in the wall-- counter seating only. The service is sub-par (I think it gets better if you go often) but it's cheap and fast and clearly a local favorite. They were out of chow fun so I got pork chow mein; I was craving noodles. My friend got the mango chicken. My meal was fine but I could see on the plates and in the bowls around me that I had clearly ordered the wrong item. 
The woman on my side had the fish curry soup which looked creamier and was a lighter yellow than other Burmese fish noodle curry soups I've seen/tasted. The guy on our other side had the most beautifully constructed pot stickers. I will definitely be ordering those next time. Still, the whole meal was $12 and made me not feel so guilty for letting my sweet, starving artist of a companion pick up the bill.
author: Summer T.

description:
For a hole-in-the-wall place, the food was AWESOME! My two foodie best friends had mentioned this place twice before I actually ventured out to Yamo's with one of them. I must had been the end of lunch hour since it was packed when we got in there. You pretty much have to sit down and grab a seat right away. I ordered the Yamo House Noodles with chicken and it was exactly what I have been craving for a while. I love the type of noodles they used. Barely seen them in other places.  My friend got the chicken coconut noodle soup. Both dishes were very delicious and all for $5.25 each. We also got six samosas for $3.50. 

Another big thing is the tea salad. Didn't try it but might next time. Even though I hate bean sprouts.

Oh, and fresh coconut. Like an actual coconut. 

At these prices, I might be swayed to drive down there more often.
author: Judy P.

description: Perfect for week night take-out after a long day at work. Can't beat the price. $4 for fresh stir fried noodles!
author: Jenny J.

description:
I was excited when my GF found out about this place since I am burmese and really love burmese food. Rating and review look good. So time to go try their food. We went there, the place looks ok. GF seems to like it. The food is not authentic taste of burmese food. Please don't be like Burma Super Star, all fusion food which was a little disappointing. The taste was adjusted for American pallet. 

I ordered Mango Chicken. GF ordered Curry Prawns. We also got Tea Leaf Salad and fresh coconut. My plate was not bad but really taste like chinese rather than burmese. Curry prawn is ok. GF likes the salad but for me, it's not enough tea leaf at all. Taste is good though. 

Overall, we enjoyed the food. For the price, it's pretty worth it and worth a visit.
author: Win S.

description:
Yamo, Yamo, hole in the wall, who's the greatest of them all?

The ladies there are definitely a kick to watch. The place is tiny, lots of regulars, awesome prices, tasty food... 

They finally have a new sign up outside, so you can figure out where it is, instead of getting lost to find this amazing joint without a name.
author: j. k.

description:
Yamo is great. It's so small that there's no space to wait inside, which you'll be doing should you come at any reasonable hour. But thankfully, the wait's worth it most of the time.
The fare here is cheap, good, and once you're seated, quick.

Definitely a good stop for a quick bite on your way to BART or drinking.
author: Jonathan L.

description:
Does YAMO really need another 5* review?  I doubt it...but I'm gonna give it to 'em anyway!  

I don't even know where to begin, but if you haven't tried this place yet...DO, the food is very fresh and simply grrrr8. 

I am looking forward to my next visit, and my next visit and even my next visit after that.
author: Mariel C.

description:
Great local hole in the wall 
Cheap filling eats, nothing fancy but a warm atmosphere!  
Pretty quick considering the small space and all the people lined up.
I like the fish dishes.  
Great place to take a friend, by yourself, or if you want to have a fun cheap date you can talk to the cooks and the servers easy.
Yum! :)
author: Andre G.

description:
I am hooked -- I always always always get the tea leaf salad and yamo noodles with beef :)

ok not always... but most of the times :)

it's my go to lunch place when I am working from home and have a time to spare for lunch, and I never go there with more than one person (it's tiny)
author: Shipra K.

description:
The ladies behind the counter are working like mad to serve the eight people waiting for their food in the tiny "restaurant."  (It's more like a large street vendor station with a roof.)  They move constantly, and still the food takes forever to get to you.

My visit here made me marvel at how crazy restaurant work is, and I appreciated the meal all that much more.

This place has good food for cheap (nothing over $5 and some change I think); it's a bit greasy and not exactly the healthiest to chow down, but it tastes great (lots of flavor, I don't know what some of the other posters are talking about).  Always get the dry curries with noodles, not rice (if you're not sure, ask which they would recommend); the noodles are chewy and delicious with the light-on-the-sauce, heavy-on-the-fillers Burmese curries.  

I would recommend you do take-out unless you've got a lot of time, have a seat there waiting for you, and don't mind walking out extremely fragrant.  I clean my plate when I go and leave a 50% tip (easy to do here).

The ladies deserve it.
author: Coleen B.

description: A blink-and-you'll-miss-it place that I'd only ever seen from the bus, Yamo is sort of an oddity. It's pretty grungy inside, but I never felt like it was particularly dirty. The seating is very limited, but they move so fast there isn't much of a wait. The staff can be short, but they aren't rude. It's Burmese food, but it tastes almost nothing like Burma Superstar or Mandalay. With all those things considered, it's a very fun experience. Just watching the well oiled machine that is their kitchen cranking out your food before your very eyes is dinner entertainment at it's finest. You can call in your order, but I'm not sure how much of the experience would be lost. I absolutely plan on making a return trip.
author: Jeremy J.

description:
i enjoyed my meal, but i dont think yamo quite lived up to the hype.

the house noodles with pork was just fine, but there wasnt much else in the bowl besides noodles and pork. the samusas were fine, but i was expecting a bit more spice and not simply potato.

overall, i added more hot sauce to this meal than i wanted. also, it was a bit strange to serve me the appetizer second, but at a food counter with 8 stools, i think this is perfectly forgivable.

ill definitely be back because this is enjoyable and right in my 'hood and because there are other menu items to try [tea leaf salad, mango chicken, cold noodles], but next time ill have to remember to bring my lowered expectations as well.

on the plus plus side, yamo has to be the cheapest non-mexican meal in the mission.
author: Jon W.

description:
Like a foghorn over the ocean at night.

The foghorn being tasty filling CHEAP food, and the ocean being built of beer and Saturday night. I randomly wandered into this place instead of waiting out in the cold for the bus, what an excellent excellent idea. Yamo seems like it's been magically transported across great distances of time and space just to fill me full of Southeast Asian delight when I need it most.
I don't know if I would recommend going to this place specifically as a dinner spot, but if you're wandering the Mission drunk at night... this is a gift from the gods of cookery.
author: Taylor M.

description: Yamo fucking rules and its a great place to rob hipsters
author: Blackened ..

description: Bummed- I've been wanting to try this place for a while.  Picked up some take-out.  tea leaf salad ( super small and I think they forgot the tea leaves!), house noodles with beef and curry chicken( both nothing special). I am always disappointed whan seemingly authentic asian places use all white meat chicken.  overall, a disappointment but the pics of teh noodle soups look good so i may atill give it another try for those items since  its rare to find a good mohingna in the city.
author: Amina B.

description:
Yamo is my favourite place to eat in the city.

With
Out
Doubt!

The food is amazing. The service is homely. The price is excellent. I leave this place feeling a bit more burmese (I started at 0%) each time. The ladies working there are wonderful, it's like watching that long lost burmese grandmother/aunty of yours whipping up a meal after you've gotten back from school. 

Yup, I need to eat here again within the next week or I might turn into a frog.
author: mike o.

description: One of my favorite places. dont let the small size and location fool you! Great food (especially the black bean sauce fish...the fish has awesome flavor). i wish this location were closer to the sunset so i could go all the time..only downside is bad parking so walk or take muni!
author: Naima B.

description:
Three stars for the three grandma's that work here!  It was definitely interesting watching these three cantonese speaking ladies work their butts off in the kitchen.  But to be honest, if you're working this close to your customers, at least throw a smile around once in a while.  They did not look happy to be there.

Also, I would have given an extra star, but the food wasn't all that amazing.  I ordered the mango chicken as well as an order of the samosas per yelp recommendations.  The mango chicken consisted of green beans, onions, green peppers, and chunks of mangos and chicken.  While the mangos were pretty sweet, the overall flavor of the dish simply tasted like fast food chinese.  

The samosas were obviously frozen and didn't have much flavor.  It just tasted like potato wrapped in wonton skin and fried.  

So, if you want real and tasty Burmese, check out Mandalay and Burmese Superstar.  For the extra few dollars it's worth it!  

Next time I will try their tea leaf salad and chicken noodle soup.  What's nice about this place is that for 5.25 you can try everything on their menu! I hope they can change my mind.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
If you like tasty hole-in-the-wall type restaurants where you can watch your food being prepared right in front of you, check out Yamo!

The most striking thing about this place is its size.  Teeny tiny restaurant with just enough space for a narrow kitchen, a counter, and barstools.  They take your order and cook right in front of you.  Full exposure, baby!

The food is inexpensive and reminiscent of the lunches my mother used to pack for me before she rushed off for work in the mornings.  I left this place with a full belly and a warmed heart.  You can bet your bottom dollars I will come back again.
author: Teresa K.

description:
It's a hole in the wall, yes, but the food is consistent and such a steal at $6 for dinner. I'm hooked on the Mango Chicken. 

The trick is to get it to go, you don't have to wait on the lines so the order is ready really quickly.
author: Julia W.

description:
I would give Yamo 3.5 stars if I could.  

The tea salad was delicious, as tea salad always is, but didn't include very many tea leaves which made me sad.  The curry chicken noodles were pretty good.  It's true that they don't give you much curry sauce if you order this to go, but if you put what sauce they do give you into a bowl/container with the noodles and give them a thorough tossing, I found that it was just enough curry sauce to give the noodles a light coating.  The mushroom tofu had lots of veggies in it, but was only decent.  All in all, Yamo is not bad and I'd definately come back.  

I love tea salad!
author: Olivia C.

description:
I ate at Yamo last night with my sister and it was so great! Cheap, quick, and delicious! I love noodles and they had a good variety of dishes. 

We had spring rolls, the chicken noodle soup, and the Yamo house noodle with pork. The spring rolls were nice and fresh, I saw the lady make them in front of me! And the chicken noodle soup was good, curry-ish. The Yamo house noodles were bomb. The noodles themselves are just so yummy. They are chewy and fresh and not heavy. The dish was a dry noodle with garlic, green onions, and pork- simple but definitely tasty. 

The place is TINY. We went on a Wednesday night so there was virtually no wait, even though every seat was filled when we got there. The women there are just so quick and great at what they do, you're in and out within 45 minutes. I will definitely come back here.
author: Pet O.

description: I came here for dinner with a friend and had the house noodles with chicken. They should definitely put some vegetables in there but the food here in general is good. My friend had the mixed vegetable noodles and it was great. I want to go back and try the curries. =)
author: Genaro R.

description:
This place is awesome. I would eat lunch here everyday if it didn't take me an hour every time I went (to be fair, there are like 10 seats the lunch rush hits them hard).  It's worth the wait I tell you.

The Chicken is amazing: Curry Chicken, Mango Chicken -- Yes!  Warning the spring rolls may induce visions and speaking in tongues - they're that good.

The place is tiny, 2 women run the joint, the food is great - you simply can't go wrong. Most importantly the menus claim to be for the curious one (see the back) and even the owners don't know what it means -- message from God anyone?
author: Tyler W.

description:
Good and cheap.

I haven't experienced many Burmese places, but I think Yamo is pretty good for the price.  Yamo is literally a hole-in-the-wall--I love it!  It's small place that can fit about 12 people at their countertop and bar stools. The wait is long when crowded..and when it's not so crowded.  It takes forever to get a dish! There's 1 cook and 1 to 2 women preparing and taking orders.  I suggest ordering take out...they'll say it takes 10-20 minutes, but it's more like 30 or 40 minutes...depending on how much stuff you order and how many people are waiting for their food.

I usually order the house special noodles with pork, chicken curry, and the tea salad (with lots of garlic)..those are my favs.  I've ordered the fish dishes before and didn't like the cheap tilapia.  The extra garlic and chili available is great!
author: Dee S.

description:
Did you know the restaurant name comes from a Michael McDonald song?  
Anyway, get the curry, and make sure you're a well-practiced chopsticks user. The food is served in to-go boxes, which is tricky to eat out of, but really quite sensible, when you think about it. 
Yum! Also, the atmosphere is so... San Francisco. You won't find anything like it elsewhere - good place to take out-of-towners who love Thai food.
author: Anika K.

description:
This is a 3.5 star review.  I rounded down since there are so many high ratings.  
Long story short, I really enjoyed my meal and will go back.  The pros?  Very cheap, cool vibe.  I liked the tea leaf salad quite a bit, but it wasn't the best I'd ever had.  (Good spice and crunch to it.)  The chicken noodle "soup" was also very good, but I'd hesitate to call it soup.  It was more like chicken and noodles in a thick sauce.

Everyone here is raving about the garlic noodles, but I honestly had to take away stars for it. Greasy and bland sums it up.  There are better things on the menu.  (like the coconut drink which I loved).

The restaurant just feels dirty - result of being so small and so much grease floating around.  We asked for water and never got it, so service could be better, but at these prices its hard to complain too much.  

On the plus side you see your food being prepared and you get to talk to the chefs!
author: She-Ra ..

description: Don't believe the hype. I've had two of the dishes recommended by Yelpers and it literally tasted like a microwave TV dinner meal. It's easy to have a line out your restaurant if you can only sit 5 people at once.. pass on this one.
author: Alex A.

description: Despite the 45 minute dinner rush line it was awesome!  Great food and you can't beat the price.  When that special someone asks you 'Yamo?'    Just say 'Ya-I-mo-be there!'
author: zane s.

description: Good place for fresh noodles. The ingredients are fresh and flavorful. The place is pretty run down but the people working there are friendly.
author: Rose O.

description:
I've walked back by this hole-in-the-wall several times.  Don't know why my wife and I never came here before.  It might be because of the nice young gentleman hanging out at the corner telling me how to identify my ethnic background in Spanish, but who knows.  He was a such a charming fellow-- so charming that I didn't want to correct him.  "Chino!" he yelled.  I wanted to tell him, "yo soy coreano" but he'd probably give me gift of sputum.  Too generous.

I digress once more.

I went with my wife and a coworker from work.  We ordered the samosas which were pretty good, but needed more texture.  The pot stickers were really good, and we'd definitely give it a go the next time around.  The skin was thick an chewy and the ingrediants inside tasted fresh.  The tea salad was a bit too salty for my palate, but maybe it's because I am a whiny hypocondriac trying to avoid symptoms of a class 1 NYHA heart failure patient.  Nevertheless, it's pretty well prepared.

As the wonderful ladies prepared our meals, my mind started to drift into a euphoria as I saw the care they gave the food.  Or, maybe it was the trace amounts of recycled oil marinating my brain.  Regardless, it was pretty cool.

The house noodles were great!  Chewy, full of flavor, but again, too salty for my taste.  My wife and friend both ordered the fish chowder. My wife let me have some of her's and it was pretty tasty.  I am not too familiar with the cuisine of Burma, (recuerda?  yo soy coreano! --but more like a banana)  I'd describe it as vermicelli/pho noodles in a  corn starch thickened soup with hints of curry and bits of fish.  Not one of my favorites at the time, but it'd be much better if I was super cold and hungry.  
Anyhoo--we'll definitely order out the next time.  The oil still lingers in my limbic system.  We're gonna order the cold noodles, chicken noodle soup, and the pot stickers this weekend.
author: John L.

description:
Yamo rocks. It's definitely on the greasy/spicy side, but when I get in the mood for that, I AM THERE! I'm all about the fish curry over noodles. And I'm also all about the prices at Yamo! You can order a bunch of stuff--drinks, appetizers--and still never run up a high bill! Dining at Yamo has pretty much always been a gratifying experience for me. Except for the one time this guy was smoking pot outside and the smoke drifted in, and another time, there was just this other unidentified god-awful smell coming in, in waves, from the street. But that stuff technically has nothing to do with Yamo, per say, so it's all good. The control freak in me also loves getting to watch them make the food before my very eyes...it's very nice to know just what's going into your dinner!

Oh yeah...and a recent hour-and-a-half long wait over at Burma SuperStar most fondly re-kindled my adoration of Yamo, to say the least!
author: Shannon R.

description:
Yamo is like flying home to Vancouver, visiting my mom, and having her whip up a quick bite to eat.

The menu is simple: four appetizers (samosas, spring rolls, egg rolls, and potstickers), three salads (shrimp & tea leaves, mango, chicken), and 15 entrees (five vegetarian options).    Everything is $5.25 except for the appetizers, which are $3.50.

I had the Yamo House Noodles with beef (also available with chicken or pork).  One of the women fried the beef with garlic and noodles, while the other thinly sliced red and green onions, cucumber, and cilantro into a small bowl.  Because the counter overlooks the prep and cooking area, they make it all right in front of you.

I'm telling you, it was heaven in a bowl.  The noodles were perfect and it was all nice and garlicky.  The raw veggies, which you mix in when they serve you, were still nice and crunchy.
 
If counter seating, cash-only, and dirty windows scare you, go some place else (since all of these yelps mean this place is probably hella busy at dinner, especially with a total of 9 seats).  But if you want a inexpensive, tasty meal, go to Yamo.
author: Marcus W.

description:
Its cheap, good and healthier than most options.

Great place for take out, since eating in can find yourself stuck waiting for the 10 barstools available first come first serve.  If so, there's tons of good resturants in the area.

Stick to the spring rolls, any curry or noodle dishes.

cash only too.
author: J S.

description:
What can I say? This place is completely awesome. I only wish I lived about 3,000 miles closer to it.

My friend took me to Yamo when I was visiting S.F. last month. I had the mango salad and he had the fermented tea salad. Both were excellent. The mango salad was made with slightly under-ripe mangoes, which were complemented really well by the spicy dressing. The fermented tea salad is totally bizarre, but delicious, and also had toasted soy nuts (or something) that were salty and yummy. Best of all - everything on the menu is $5.25 (or cheaper, for the appetizers). I can't wait to go back. (But I guess I'll have to.)
author: Clare B.

description:
I'm kind of amazed that a tiny hole in the wall with 9 counter seats has over a hundred reviews on Yelp -- but it just goes to show you how far good, cheap, interesting food with friendly service can take you in this city.

Don't come here if you're claustrophobic, or like to believe that food magically appears on your plate from behind some mysterious door. You're up close and personal with EVERYONE in this narrow little dive, but the food (and prices!) make up for it. The mango chicken was a little disappointing, but the tea leaf salad was awesome, as was our "server" who was super friendly (but in a nice, small restaurant kind of way, rather than a "Hi, I'm Marcia, and I'll be your server today!!!" kind of way), and patiently explained things on the menu to us. Props for being family owned too!
author: J C.

description:
Reason #2 not to be a vegetarian in 2008:

My mouth is watering just thinking about #19 with noodle, Curry Beef, #15  Yamo House Noodles with Beef, and #8 Coconut Noodle [Sublime] Soup with Chicken. I have this place programmed into my phone which is quite the honor. (I moved out of the Mission, but I will drive around for parking or walk 20 blocks to pick-up take-out. I never eat-in at Yamo (I'm delicate like that).)

Savoury noodles with that damned delicious umami and egg noodle texture perfection paired with succulent meats and various sauces. Curry Beef has just enough kick and can be spicy, greasy and peppers and onions complement the meat. House noodles have that, "Huh, what is that, uh, flavor?" that if you're an Asian child you are all too grateful about. And, my latest discovery #8 soup is a thick, pale-green broth teeming with sweetness of coconut and the savoury curry, spiked with cilantro and onions, noodle perfection and toppings coming separately so you can become the Asian soup scientist!
author: E L.

description:
Yes!! A new favorite place to eat!

It's charming, cozy, yummy, and cheap. We ordered the spring rolls, mixed vegetables with noodles, and tofu curry noodles. The spring rolls were delicious and the noodles were perfectly QQ (how Taiwanese people say al dente).

I will definitely come here again and again and again.
author: Judy C.

description: Wow this place is a total definition of a hole in the wall. it is so cheap and tasty (as long as you don't order the rice dishes). THe noodle dishes and the soups are good. You can't go into this place with more than 1 other person or you will not be seated. THere is only like 15 places to seat in this "restaurant".
author: Nir B.

description:
So, since reading about Yamo, and visiting 3 times since my last review, I really think it deserves the 5 stars. The food is always good, always made to order, and the cost just really sets it over the top.  If i lived in the neighborhood, I'd be here once a week. But for now, I'm just heading to Yamo's once every two weeks. 

Be patient, it takes along to time to eat here. If you;re in a hurry, go somewhere else. If you can, call ahead for pick up. It helps alot. You may wait for 30 minutes before they even take your order. But that's a small price to pay for cheap, good eats.
author: Jimmy L.

description:
i had passed by this place a couple of times when going over to Weird Fish. It looked pretty promising with a small but interesting menu, plus they had lots of curry dishes and I love curry.

So I decided to try it the other day. 

Disclaimer: prior to trying it, I had no idea what the name of this place was so I could not check Yelp prior to my visit. 

The first thing I said to myself when I sat down and scanned the room and the patrons, was " this is a place which people on Yelp will go ape-shit for"  the elements were all there
a. it is in the Mission
b. it is a hole in the wall dive
c. it has sweet little Asian ladies working there
d. the diners were all round-eyed, not an Asian diner in sight.
e. the place just looked 'edgy', like the old days when you went to underground clubs in skanky wherehouse spaces, this was the food equivelent. 

OK,  so I decide on the chowder, since the Curry has deep fried  stuff in it and I don't like deep fried.

It was OK, (the best way to describe is to attempt to use words to verballize my feelings....OK, ...say strech the words "OK......BUT ....."over a 10 second period, that sums up Yamo.

the food was just warm, not hot, soup , chowder should be hot....the taste were too subtle. it was just OK, just a bit too bland for me....even the heftiness of the chowder was just fair, ...i have a love hate relationship with Coconut milk since it is so damn fattening, but I was begging for more in the Chowder.

there were a few take out orders going on when I was there....I was planning on doing some Curry take out for dinner just cause, just cause I like Curry, but noticed the portion sizes were pretty small . 

I get home and of course read Yelp since I now know what this placed is called and lo-and behold, this place is loved. See words like a 'bargain' super cheap, only $5.25, a steal! ....I can only explain that away as being Asian I grew up on Chinese food and $3.95 rice plates the size of Texas. ....I would suspect since most of the diners during my time there were White, Yamo would seem like highway robbery in terms of $5.25 since they did not grow up with Asian dive food.

Would I go back? I doubt it, I am positive I won't. Was the food bad, no way, it just I have had much better. ....

PS----I big minus and I will not go 2 stars although I should, was that on 12/17, the lady who prepares the food, not the cook, was sneezing up a storm and handling the food with her hands....if I get sick just in time for the weekend, I will have to wish you a large lump of coal in your stocking.
author: Garfield J.

description: we only order one and that was the last time... order like about $60 food for our co worker and we don't even know what we were eating tasteless and no favor... so bland, even the soy sauce didn't help... we would never order here again... one time is enough.... total rip off for american people, haha....
author: JessePanda C.

description: hole in the wall joint, humid, cramped, poor service, and oh so damn good. if you're not down get it to go and eat on the curb outside. cheap, fast, spicy, authentic, and vegetarian friendly.
author: Monika S.

description:
o! m! g! this is the SMALLEST restaurant i've ever seen! pretty much a bar facing the kitchen. totally divey with poor ventilation. three employees were there this afternoon (early early dinner, around 4:30), one person cooking, one person serving, one person prepping (and all three doing order-taking and what not). 

i had the tea salad and the yamo noodles with beef. mmm. the tea salad was a bit spicy but better than burma superstar's. i loved the noodles. tender, flavorful beef on top of al dente thick noodles. mmm. 

the older ladies are efficient if not a bit surly. at first i was kind of offended, but i think that's just how they are. they sense things. without asking, you will get a box for your leftovers when you're ready, and you'll get your check when you're ready, too. 

definitely will go back, although i'm afraid of crowds, so it's gonna have to be an off-hour visit.

thanks to eileen s. for taking me here!
author: Jonathan K.

description: Absolutely love this place and the ladies behind the counter that rock it.  If I could only remember how to say delicious in Burmese...
author: Scott E.

description:
Why do I love you so much? Oh, the reasons are endless, but let me toss out a few: 1) the food is great, 2) the prices are so low that we almost feel guilty paying so little, 3) you only fit about ten folks total, so there's less chance of being annoyed by fellow patrons, 4) the staff are classic and 5) if there isn't a big crowd, you'll talk to us about burma, the business and other interesting stuff.

You may be out favorite spot in the city. Let's hang out some more.
author: K F.

description:
Best tea leaf salad in the bay area! 
You don't really know what  hole in the wall place is until you come here...which is literally hole in the wall. This place is a station run by 4 moms yelling loudly over the woks, air vents on full blast, customers..etc so be assured they are cooking up & serving you what they feed their kids, which means the real deal - authentic burmese chinese grubs. 

These moms are nice but don't expect five star service from them. 0 ambiance. It's not a date place. Peeps come here for cheap, good food and get out. Everything in the menu is super cheap. Dishes are wok up pretty fast. When you sit down, one mom will slid you the menu and instantly said what you want? all efficiency.

After I had some of the awesome goodness that's their tea leaf salad, I'm ready to give Burma Superstar the boot.
author: Nancy L.

description: Yamo is yummy, for sure. It's SUPER CHEAP as well.  Go for the chicken noodle or the fish chowder but it's all good!
author: Jennavive P.

description:
searched for $ and 4 stars and up came this burmese option. hopped on over and grabbed 3 of the 11 seats.
ordered the tea leaf salad, black bean fish, vegetables, garlic house noodles with chicken and pot stickers. could have left the veggie dish and the pot stickers but everything else was supreme. 
the atmosphere was entertaining with swaying, circling light fixtures, short asian women working full force tossing noddles around in a tiny galley kitchen.
the three of us stuffed our faces for under $25. we will be back.
author: Rosalee R.

description:
I love yamo, it's so cute. Cheap (although they did raise their prices), yummy food, good portions, small and cramped and dirty. I like it.

I've had the prawn curry, cold noodles and mushroom tofu. The noodles are so good!
author: Diem V.

description:
What the hell, 5 stars for Yamo! Arguably the best food value in the Mission wih $5.25 entrees, House Noodles and Cold Noodles (nos. 15 & 16) are delish. Kinda greasy, but that's cool.

My tip: Don't be shy about getting their attention if they're slow to take your order.
author: Josh K.

description:
You ladies are alright in there. Real nice and informal.
Real cheap eats here,  I just tried the Curry Fish w/ Noodles.. they were pretty good half way through, then my taste buds gave out on me.  The taste got old pretty quick.
They were fast, the place has "hole in the wall" charm, maybe the other food is more tasty!?!? The samosas and spring rolls looked great though, Fry it up, cant go wrong.
About a block away theres a El Salvadorean restaurant that specializes in Papusas... i had a Pork and Queso .. YUMMEHHHH!!! $1.75each.
author: JASON L.

description:
This is a gem in the Mission!! If you are looking for good food at super dirt cheap prices,  this is your heaven.

Every entree on the menu is $5.25 and the appetizer are about $3.50. So, I usually get 2 apps, and 2 entrees for less than $20- can't beat that. For appetizers, I usually get potstickers, somosas or the spring rolls.  The potstickers are ridiculosly delicious, when you bite into them: the juice comes bursting out with a concotion of great flacors. For entrees, I really enjoy their yamo cold noddles w/chicken, the fish in black bean sauce and all of their curry dishes.  Also the chicken coconut soup is really good and hearty, perfect for a cold night.

 This is the tiniest and I mean tiniest hole-in-the-wall I've every seen.  They have about 9 stools where you sit overlooking where they cook and prep the food.   This is not a nose up in the air kind of place. The smallness of it is part of the charm to it.

Yamo is such an awsome place!!
author: Michi R.

description:
Food = Tea salad was delightful.  Sambusas were decent.  Noodles were standard Chinese restaurant fare.

Ambiance = The little old ladies behind the counter were great.  I would come back just to hang out and pretend they're my own personal grannies.  

Price = Cheeeep.  This and the tea salad are driving the rating.
author: Riya K.

description:
After reading ten or so Yelp reviews of Yamo, I decided it was worth a try if only because it's downhill from my apt (not uphill like the Richmond). 

The lady running the place was kind of nice, and it was definitely the cheapest stuff I've put in my stomach for at least a few weeks. However, the food taste and quality was so low that I actually regretted spending my $5.25. Here's why:

* VERRRY greasy - not in a satisfying sort way, but in a too-much-burned-vegetable-oil-coating-everything sort of way. 
* Bland flavor - by this I mean that the four dishes we tried seemed to be exclusively seasoned with oil, salt, and (maybe, if lucky) sriracha.
* Tea leaf salad had little tea mash, even less umami wonderfulness. 

I don't like to be down on family-owned places like this, but their stuff was so much worse than what I've had at other Burmese places in SF (Mandalay & Burma Super Star), that I couldn't NOT yelp about it.

In any case, they seem to be doing just fine with the business Yelp has driven their way, so more power to 'em...
author: Susan S.

description: Super yummy and the price is right!  I ordered black bean tofu, it was good but I think I will try something spicier next time.  I will definitely be back.
author: Maddy F.

description: Awesome Burmese food for great prices.  If you like Asian food with no frills, this is a great place to go.  Tea leaf salad all day.
author: Paul K.

description: delicious, cheap, awesome!! the tea leaf salad was somewhat different from the ones i've tried elsewhere, but still yummy. echo other yelpers' comments about small 8-person counter and 3 cantonese ladies yelling/dishing up people's orders, pretty cool to see. def not a fancy place, and small and smoky. $6 tea leaf salad + $6 house noodles with pork - mm! i didn't think it was THAT greasy. delicious with chilli..
author: Clarissa L.

description:
their food is delicious, cheap and fresh.  the ladies make it right in front of you while they talk to each other in contonese.  it's sounds like they're fighting with each other or something but it's adorable.

the place is clean but it's tiny.  the seating is a counter w/ 5 stools.  know that you will smell like yamo when you leave.  it's not by any means a deal breaker, just something to be aware of. 

also be aware that the secret is out about this place so it will be packed w/ a line out the door during peak hours.
author: lori s.

description: The food at Yamo is yum-o, but the setting is not-o.  Eating here is like eating in the small, cramped, dirty kitchen of my old Asian grandmother...  a place where you know you'll always get a lot of good food (when they get around to it), but it's best not to ask too many questions or look too closely at things.  Stuff is everywhere!  There's barely any room for you to eat!  But really, who cares?  Everyone knows that the ONLY reason you and them are there is because of the FOOD.  -And that, my friends, is actually kinda good.
author: Tom F.

description:
Finally committed to the line while waiting for seats at the nearby Mission Street Food.  We ordered just two dishes to avoid spoiling our appetite.  

The sumosas were excellent, very crispy, with a great sweet/spicy chili sauce for dipping.  One of the chefs counted carefully to make sure there were 6 perfect isosceles triangles on our plate before delivering.  There was some discussion about going easy, maybe saving a few for lunch tomorrow.  The idea of a "to go" box was tossed around.  They'd probably re-heat well, we surmised.  It became apparent, however, that 0 of the 6 sumosas were going to make it past round two.  Yeah, they probably wouldn't have reheated well.  

Dish two, the Yamo house noodles with pork, was EXACTLY as tasty as it looked (it looked very tasty).  Greasy egg noodles, tender well-seasoned pork, and a bit of cilantro.

Yamo is one of those places that I can already feel myself starting to crave as I walk out the door.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
I love this place so much, words cannot even express. I don't even know what to say to the Yamo Haters, except, haters gotta hate. But I LOVE. 

Order: House Noodles with Chicken, Curry Tofu, Curry Fish, Curry Vegetables, Yamo Cold Noodles (with chicken or tofu), Mushroom Tofu, Chicken Noodle Soup.

Bonus for vegetarians and other tofu-lovers: They will sub tofu for meat in pretty much any dish, even if it's not listed as an option on the menu. The fact that the ladies who work here are all-business and brusque-verging-on-rude can be off-putting, but don't be fooled. These ladies really just want to serve you some delicious food cheaply and efficiently. 

FEEL THE LOVE.
author: Crash O.

description: This place was pretty awesome. The food is inexpensive and was served up quick. I had some sort of vegetable dish over rice and spring roll sans shrimp. I got my food to go, so I cannot speak to the seating arrangement, however, it did appear to be somewhat cramped in there. Bottom line, for the price, service, and all that, Yamo (love the name) is a winner for your Burmese/Chinese food needs.
author: Brian S.

description:
What's not to love ?

Food - Awesome - Just the right level of spice. Esp good after a few beers. We had the black-bean fish, veggie stir-fry, samusas & Chicken with cold noodles. 
Total bill - $24

Warning: Samusas are not quite like Indian samosas which I prefer (good ones are hard to find), but they are ok here.

Space - 8 bar-stools - figure out seating for urself

Atmosphere - Choy (Burmese owner) yelling away orders a feet away from you. Great place to chat up a conversation with ur neighbors. You WILL be rubbing shoulders & elbows with em anyway. Choy is 
awesome !
author: Rooibos T.

description:
Awesome hole in the wall.  No frills, no BS SE Asian food.  Wonderful greasy and cheap cuisine.

You must order the Tea salad - as Im sure you've gathered from others' reviews.. and if youre with two, well order a couple then.

You might wind up waiting for a half hour (at most) outside while you wait - there is only enough space for those already seated, but its totally worth it.
author: Zachary K.

description:
Unbelievable hole in the wall  burmese food.  Just grab a seat at the counter and enjoy watching some genuine deliciousness being made in front of you.  Also, get the jelly soda, its amazing.


These ladies rock.
author: Mathias G.

description:
I think I would come here more often if lunch were not on "the company" account. 

Overview:
Questionably unsanitary...if you are on mission and the area seems to get increasingly sketchy, then you are heading in the right direction for Yamo!  Tea salad was okay and house garlic noodles are quick and tasty.  Some of the cheapest edible food in the mission.  Drink from a coconut on your lunch break!!  Do you think they make the apps more expensive than the entrees to deter you from staying too long??!
author: Jay P.

description: Living across the street from Yamo is just pretty awesome. Cheap good eats.  Fav is the Chicken Soup.
author: Shannon A.

description:
Yamo, yamo, yamo.  This place is legit.  I usually go at least once a week (either take out or sit at the tiny counter).  It's getting more and more popular so the off hours are better for a relaxed dining experience.  

I tend to get the Chicken Noodle Soup.  It sounds boring but it's anything but.  Quite possibly one of the best soups in the city.  Hearty, noodle filled and brimming with flavor (curryesque).  I love to put the hot sauces in this soup to hike up the heat factor. 

Go here and thank me later.
author: Anthony V.

description: Good time.  Had a cold can of sweet grass jelly drink, and enjoyed this cave oasis on a hot saturday at noon, after hustling around the neighborhood in the sun doing my saturday morning biz.  My House Noodles with tofu instead of chicken came lightning-fast.  It was a simple meal and simply perfect.  My brother had the fresh coconut, which I have to get next time when I come back for more tea salad.  Even fullness doesn't stop the craving for Yamo's goodness.
author: Pat L.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, but the food was too greasy for my liking.  I had the House Noodles with Beef and that's just what it was..Noodles and Beef with a lot of grease.  After managing to blot as much grease off as I could with a paper towel, the beef was actually seasoned well and tasted OK.  My partner had the Curry Chicken over Rice.  No flavor..very bland.  The Tea Salad was wilted by the time we got home because it was packed in with the hot dishes.  I would imagine it would have been tasty had I eaten it there.  We also had the Spring Rolls which were tasty, the peanut sauce was blahhh.

I would recommend take-out as the restaurant is small (5-6 counter seats).  Since the cooking is done on the other side of the counter, I left the restaurant with my take-out in hand smelling like grease.

I give it 3 stars because the women worked hard and the prices were cheap.  I'm willing to give it another try.
author: Lisa E.

description:
the food was decent and cheap. the best part was the atmosphere though. it's a tight squeeze. it's hot and smells of grease. the air is a little thick from the open kitchen behind the counter that takes up a majority of the place. and the women behind the counter spend the whole time yelling at each other in chinese (best guess). quite an experience. 

i'll be honest though, i didn't feel too sure about how sanitary it may be. 
*  shrug  *
author: Ashley A.

description:
Ahh...Yamo. The George Webb of San Francisco.

Make sure to try the tea salad for an unlikely combination of nutty and delicious. All this with prices so cheap it's silly.
author: Raoul D.

description:
The ultimate hole-in-the-wall.  It's a 10-seat restaurant where you are practically eating in the kitchen (the fridge is behind the corner seat).

Finally, a place with garlic noodle that rival the one at Crustacean and Thanh Long.

Order the coconut juice - they cut it and serve the entire coconut fresh.

Was fortunate enough to have a group of four.  We ordered four dishes and two appetizers.  The total was $9 per person including tax and tip.

I'll be back.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
I saw Yamo across the street from my house but, for the longest time  was too scared to go into it. I did my research here on Yelp was was so glad I did! 

Three words: Yamo cold noodles. YUM! 

Large portions, fast service (always to go - too small to sit in) always tasty, always delicious.
author: Dani M.

description:
Everything on the menu is $5.25! I always get the Mushroom Tofu with noodles. Everything is cooked fresh and you always end up with happy plate action.  My girl ordered coconut water and they chopped the top off a real life coconut!. That the shit. 



-non greasy feel after eating
-$5.25 menu
-frosty water
-bomb noodles
-small cutty place that makes you feel like your underground and better than anyone else
-ladies work so damn hard for your food
author: Richard J.

description:
My friends are foodies. We love to eat. We love to talk about eating. We love to talk about eating while we're eating. So when my foodie friend Di, whose parents are from Burma told me this was her favorite Burmese spot in the city, I listened. 

I was out with another foodie friend Tony, trying to get into Minako, when we decided we'd rather not wait an hour for dinner. We popped around the corner to Yamo, sat down at the bar, and watched the chefs whip up some tasty Burmese dishes right before our hungry eyes. 

We got tofu garlic noodles because that's what the people next to us were having, and it looked pretty compelling (it was). Tea leaf salad, because that's just what you do in a Burmese restaurant. And shrimp curry too. Because a salad hardly even counts as a dish, yo. Everything was tasty and considerably lighter than a lot of the Burmese I've had in the past. As we finished up, both Tony and I agreed we'd be back for more.
author: Katherine T.

description:
3.5 stars

What do I like about Yamo?  Well, it is called Yamo.  That's a pretty cool name.  Also, the food is good.  The tea salad is excellent.  Sounds like it won't be, but it is.  Definitely get it.   The curry beef is pretty solid too, and the black bean fish is ok.

The bad? Almost nowhere to sit.  Just ten or so seats at the counter.  Also, if they are cooking something that smells bad when cooking, you have to smell it too because, well, you are right there.  They also don't serve alcohol, which isn't really too big of a deal for me.

If you haven't been here, try it.  I wouldn't say go across town for it, but if you are near here, go here.
author: Brett J.

description:
I used to live down the street from Yamo.  It was the only restaurant in the 'hood that I was willing to risk my life crusing down Mission Street to eat at.  

Order the Chicken Noodle Soup to go.  They'll package up the noodles and the chicken seperate from the broth and then you basically have TWO delicious meals for under $5.  I also like the cute little asian plastic spoons they give you, and can reuse them at home!

PERFECT first date spot if you get there early 'cause you can watch your meal prepared from scratch!  

Always order everything over noodles instead of rice.  They use these yellow Burmese noodles that have so much flavor, they make the rice or noodles? option a total no-brainer
author: Elisa B.

description:
What an awesome place. The old ladies prepare every thing in front of you.

It's a really small place, with probably 10 seats on the counter, and that's it. Party of 2, showed up at 8:30 pm on Tuesday, wait was 15-20 minutes.

The big hit was the Yamo cold noodles with chicken. So much flavor.

We also ordered the Samosaz (appetizer) and the Black bean fish.  The fish was nice, but not as flavorful as the cold noodles.  The person beside us said the noodle soups were also good. That's the plan for next time.

Totally worth it.
author: Abid M.

description: Awesome food at an extraordinary low price! I highly recommend this "hole-in-the-wall" for fans of authentic (and spicy) SE Asian cuisine.  This place is full of character and mouth-watering flavor.   You won't be disappointed!
author: Hen T.

description:
after months of day dreaming about this spot, I have to say.. I'm disappointed & feelin' a lil illin' to boot...
It was greasy, less than mediocre, & there wasn't anything pleasurable about the experience. After waiting for an awkwardly long time for a menu, one of the 3 older ladies stopped yelling at each other and I could ask for a menu. I ordered the mixed vegetables & tofu over noodles. At the end of my *trying to make the best of it* one of the ladies hands me half a cup of tap water with a greasy black hair. No need for dessert, or to EVER go back there.
author: Miss W.

description:
Cheap, pretty good Burmese fast food.  

Get there early before the lines form out the door. 

If you like counter only seating right in the middle of the action of slicing, dicing and slinging stir fried curry noodles, and employees laughing & yelling in Burmese, then this tiny hole in the wall place is for you!  Questionable prep hygiene, but nothing sits around long enough to go bad.

There is better Burmese food elsewhere & nicer atmosphere at a higher price, but you can't complain for the cheap price!

Extra points for fresh young coconut juice still in the coconut for only a buck more than the canned stuff!  Ask for a spoon to scrape out the delicious soft coconut jelly.
author: Terry B.

description: Cheap prices + no frills atmosphere + tiny counter-only seating area = fun times.  Ok, so I've only been here once on a visit to SF, but I would so totally go back.  The tea leaf salad was recommended, and we enjoyed that a lot.  I liked the noodle soup that I got...unfortunately I don't remember exactly which one it was.
author: Nina K.

description: I don't see how anybody could possibly give this place less than 5 stars. Yes, it's a greasy-spoon kind of place. Yes, there are only six uncomfortable stools to sit on. But the food is cheap -- all entrees are $6 -- and you get a cooking show in a language you (probably) don't understand.
author: Pierre B.

description:
this was one of my first visits in san fran. and i still love it! it's like going into someones home and watching them cook for you. super small and cozy and the ladies just say it like it is. no need for trying to please, just is what it is kind of place.  tea tree salad:crunchy awesomeness. eggrolls: deep friend goodness. need I say more? 

this is one of the places where you go for the experience and the price. the food..well its good, but more in a greasy salty flavorful kind of way.

oh and for the price, its a steal. leave your expectations at the door.
author: Stefan M.

description:
My favorite hole-in-the-wall place.

4 stars because the food is great and very cheap. Don't expect "the best Burmese I've ever had" here. If the food price is above $12, I may have given Yamo a 3-star. OK maybe 3.5... their noodle dishes are addictive :)

My favorite: house noodles, cold noodles, and tea leaf salad
Dislike: Rice with mango chicken

The place is really small, so don't go in groups. Two people max, or get your food to go. Oh try the coconut drink too..
author: dub m.

description:
I haven't been this satisfied with a meal since Thanksgiving. 

...Actually this was better than Thanksgiving. Unique (to me) food and super cheap prices make this my new kitchen away from kitchen.  I'm already plotting to go next week. 

I recommend the tea salad, coconut chicken soup, and anything with curry and noodles. 

They also do take-out :)
author: Rachel B.

description:
If I could grab food on the run here I would do it everyday. Ok more like once a week. Their food reminds me of homecooked asian food, the type you dont get at restaurants. The ladies remind me of my aunts. The flavors are yummy and simple. Prices cannot be beaten. 

My problem with them is that I like getting lunch closeby sunday mornings, and they are closed sundays.
author: Willie K.

description:
If there weren't already 75 reviews, I wouldn't yelp it.  About a dozen seats, 2-3 middle aged (presumably)Burmese women and sometimes a teenage relative, amazing noodles and fresh ingredients combine to create one of the tastiest, most reasonably priced places to eat in the Mission.  

Yamo was recommended to me by some vegan friends so I assume there are some good vegan options, but I wouldn't know anything about that.  I like to get the house noodles with pork(I have no idea what they do to the pork but it is incredibly tender) which I drench in Sriracha.  It doesn't need it, the dish is garlicky and also comes with fresh veggies - I am just a freak for Sriracha.

The spring rolls are also amazing.  I've gotten the black bean fish, but I can't not get the pork noodles.  In general everything can be made with noodles so don't even bother with the rice.
author: Kasey K.

description:
Yamo is yummy.

I dream of tea leaf.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I first saw the reviews on Bargain Bites so I thought that I should give it a try.  I didn't know what to expect.

This little family owned Burmese restaurant offers only bar seating for maybe a maximum of approximately ten guests.  Their creamy Fish Chowder Noodle Soup with fried yellow beans and Tea Salad are definite reasons to return.
author: Eva L.

description:
Four Stars or Five Stars... "Yah I am a fan" or "this is as good as it gets"?

Frankly, for what it is (great food at or below a reasonable price) this really is as good as it gets.

The 4 dishes we had (we shared) were all wonderful, wasn't a big fan of the potato dumpling things, but that was my issue, not theirs.

PERSONALITY PLUS

ALWAYS BUSY

EXCELLENT FOOD

GREAT PRICES

The excursion our family took to eat here (then went to Thrift Town around the coroner... excellent thrift store btw) is one of the most talked about memories of this SF trip.

But it is as another reviewer described, a true "hole in the wall"
author: Paul L.

description:
I will probably up the star later.  I am so excited about this place b/c it's close by and is fantastically quirky.  I read all the reviews on Yelp before trying it, and I gotta say I was not disappointed.

I had the Chicken Noodle Soup because I've been sick this week and have been trying to find some comfort foods.  The chicken and noodles were fantastic, but the soup was ok.  I mean, it tasted good, but I didn't really like it.  For that reason, I will go back sometime (most likely soon!) and try other not-soup dishes.  The soup was some sort of coconut milk and curry concoction.  The noodles were kind of like chow mein noodles (the good kind) and the chicken was perfect, not too-dry, not raw.

I ordered take-out, the soup and the chicken/noodles came separate.  I ended up eating the rest of the chicken/noodles for lunch the next day and they were superb on their own.

This place is pretty hard to find, the pictures show a red sign, but there is no sign!!  Thank you Yelpers for the pictures that show the nail store next door, I wouldn't have been able to find it at all!  If you're eating in, it's literally just a counter right against the kitchen.
author: Christie C.

description: Mango chicken was good, but think I should try the pork next time
author: Jas S.

description: Not bad but definitely don't believe the hype.  Consider this a 2.5-star rating rounded down in an effort to balance out the enthusiasts who exaggerate the stars due to their feelings of euphoria induced by eating food from a real live "authentic" hole-in-the-wall restaurant.  Once we peel back some of the exhausted cachet (for example, 18th & Mission is not a dangerous corner, and Yamo's is no one's little secret place - it has nearly 400 reviews on yelp!), basically what you've got left is a place where for a good price ($5.25) you can get a generous portion of bland southeast Asian food.  That's not so bad.  But it's not so great either.
author: Josh C.

description: OK, granted, I've been to Myanmar many times so I'm biased.  But, when they put lettuce in the Tea Leaf Salad to add bulk, it pisses me off.  The chicken and prawn curries were bland compared to Mandalay and Burma Super Star.  Even the samosas seemed to lack taste.  Oh, how I miss Yellow Pataut!
author: Rick H.

description:
Went there for the first time today. Food was greasy and not too fresh, either. You get what you pay for, I suppose. 

One cool thing - there was this bearded dude who came from upstairs to fill two bowls from his kitchen with their fried stuff. When I asked him about the place, he seemed grateful that it was so close. And it is, to my knowledge, the only Burmese restaurant in the neighborhood.
author: Mike T.

description:
Tasty, Fun, Cheap, Tiny,  fun!
Good for random wanderers like me,  perhaps for groups of 2,  not much more.
It is what it is! 
I Dunno how it could be better, so it gets 5 stars!
author: Chris M.

description: Brothers took me to this place while I was in town. Yamo gets a five from me for insanely good house noodles--with the tea leaf salad the texture combo and the spice level was pitch perfect. But then again you really have to dig the greasy spoon vibe in order to give this place five stars. Personally, the ladies working this joint remind me of my /nanay/. I have no idea how they can break their backs cooking over these flaming stoves and still make dishes that are individually delicious til closing time.
author: Ingrid P.

description: A fantastic hole in the wall place with counter service. It really only fits about 10 people. The food is amazing. We got the curry, samosas, and noodles and they were all delicious. The black bean tofu dish smelled so good too. Really a fun place and cheap! Not the best for a group of people.
author: Sara D.

description:
It's located smack in between the Mission and the gentrified Valencia. You can see the difference a block makes with the rich on one side and the poor to the other.

Anyways....

I really enjoyed the food here. It's nothing fancy so don't expect to be treated like a superstar. But the ladies here are very nice and try to get to everyone when it's busy. 

The food here is super cheap. Not the best out there but hey, you get what you paid for. Their house noodles are rather greasy but I enjoyed it nonetheless. The tea salad wasn't that bad either. And sodas are just a buck! 

It's a hole in the wall joint that I will be coming back to. I just know it.
author: Van D.

description:
This is a great find.  It's super tiny.  I think it seats no more than 10 people and that's if two people share the end of the counter.  It's a cozy place with homey burmese food.  You definitely get the sense that it's a family business.  There's usually a daughter/cousin/sister/aunt helping out behind the counter.  The prices are incredibly cheap, espcially when you compare them Burma Super Star.   Nothing is higher than 6 bucks and the portions are pretty generous.  The fish filets in black bean sauce is deeee-lish!  

I've only been there for lunch because the neighborhood can be a little shady at night.  During the day, there's usually street parking.  Because of it's size, it's pretty challenging to go there with a group of people and if the counter is full, there can be a bit of a wait.  There's one cook who tends to make dishes one at a time instead of all at once, which is kind of drag if you're with friends or family since you'll have to watch them eat their food while your dish is being prepared.  Other than that, it's all good.  This place is one of my favorites.
author: Idala T.

description:
Go Yamo!   The mango salad is too good, and the curry beef is so tasty.  Food quality in general is closer to 3 stars, but the price definitely gives them a 4-star rating

However, I did spend some time in Burma, and the style of food there had much more of both Indian and Chinese influence, depending on where you went.  Food at Yamo is clearly more of the Thai/SE Asian influence.

SUPER FAST take out.  But no delivery... These ladies don't drive anywhere!
author: Dave K.

description:
YAMO be at some other place for lunch.  ( I bet all the Michael McDonald fans are smiling hehe). 

 The first time I ordered food from there I got the black bean fish.  It was good stuff and the portion was just right.  Today, however, is another day.  I wanted to try other yummy goodness from this place, but I was sadly disappointed.  

I ordered the house fried chow fun with chicken.  It was extremely oily, as in oil rig oily.  On top of that it was really bland.  I tried to put hot sauce on it, but the hot sauce wouldn't stick because of all the oil.  There was also a lot of bitter cabbage in it.  I am definitely never going to order that again.    My friend got the house noodles and that wasn't all that great either.  

On the plus sides: really fast take out and cute guys eating there.
author: Miss T.

description:
Yamo is amazing, cheap, burmese soul food.  It might seem weird to classify it as such - soul food normally comes from the south, a long way from Burma - but that's how it seems to me.  I go there when I'm feeling a little bluesy, a little empty & in need of something to fill me up.  

I get the tea salad almost religiously.  I've been there maybe 25 times and can only remember one occasion where I didn't order the tea salad.  It is that good - spicy, crunchy, vinegary, amazing.

After that, I've tried everything.  And it's all good.  The noodles and curries tend to the greasy side, but oh-so-delicious.  One exception is the cold noodles, which make a light and delicious alternative to the curries or the other stir-fried dishes.  

Also, try the fish chowder.  Not really all that fishy, but rich and deep in flavor, and topped with crunchy fried beancake chips.  Orgasmic.
author: Mike G.

description:
Yamo = YUMo

Don't be intimidated by the surroundings, this place has great food, at an awesome price! Take out seemed to be the choice of most patrons but i enjoyed sitting there watching the women work their magic behind the counter.

I went with a friend we had spring rolls which were excellent, samosas which were pretty good, the tea salad (great) and yamo cold noodles.  The noodles were super, spicy, crispy vegtables,  i could not get enough. I will be back to work my way through the menu. 

the 4 dishes + 2 drinks (non-alcoholic) = $21.... wow.

plus we had leftovers, it was easily enough food for 3, all in all, it was super.
author: Ashley T.

description:
how i hadn't been to Yamo before now will be to my eternal wonder. everything on the menu is literally $5.25 and served in generous portions by the the "3 sisters" as my friend Ben calls them.  If you mind hovering like a vulture for a free seat then get take out, but the tiny ambiance is worth the wait.

the prawn noodle curry was more sauted than creamy, but it had a nice kick to it.   the "sisters" were surprisingly attentive to my nut/fish allergies for a place that size. bravo yamo!  i'll be back.
author: Spatial K.

description:
When your in the mood for cheap and tasty with character....Yamo is the place to go. 

It is the ultimate hole in the wall and the food is great. Try the tea leaf salad and curry fish w/ noodles. Although some comments claim it is dirty, that is very misleading. I love the ambiance or the lack there of. 

You gotta try it!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
I kinda dig this place! Nothing fancy or hip about it, it's simply a dive restaurant with good food, not amazing, but good.  For me, the experience of watching the group of women go about their business of cooking was great and the tab made it even better. They don't really interact with you, they just get the job done and work their asses off.  Yamo is very tiny, around 7-8 seats and has complementary hooks to hang your coat on the wall, behind your barstool -I like unique touches like that! 

This place has lots of character.  If you want super cheap and OK-good Burmese, but not the best, this is the place.  

Wait time for a seat was aprox 20-30min.  I will probably do take out next time.
 
What we ordered:

1-The tea salad was tangy, sweet, and crunchy with a kick of amazing mix of flavors. It was yummy!

2-The mango chicken was just OK, nothing amazing but not horrible. It was a bit bland for me and lacked flavor.

3-The house noodles were the best of what was ordered. Perfectly cooked, nice balanced flavor and the chicken added was also yummy!  Note: when you order house noodles with meat and want veggies make sure you specifically request with veggies because they don't add unless requested- I need to remember that for next time.

4- Total tab= $19.85  

*CASH ONLY*
author: Angelica F.

description:
Overall, their dishes range from good to excellent. Stir fry noodles were decent, nothing spectacular. 

Fish chowder is one of my favorites. Though not much noodle with the order, it's still pretty filling and comforting. I especially like the crispy fried garlic topping which adds great flavor and texture to the soup. 

Tea leave salad is a must. It's an explosion of flavors and finishes with a subtle kick that just makes you want to keep eating it.

The place is small so often times there's a 15-20 minute wait. Needless to say, parking is challenging in this area.
author: Bundy C.

description: Oh, Yamo is so magnificent that even though I have to balance on a little stool to slurp down the #15 garlicy noodly beefy goodness, I do so happily. My friends and I take pictures of ourselves eating the #15 and flip off the camera, and then we send it to our unfortunate acquaintances who are not with us. The losers.
author: Jessica B.

description:
good. cheap. fast. 
I recommend the tea salad & coconut soup.
author: RYU r.

description:
Yamo is about the size of a postage stamp. It's hot, noisy, packed and fantastic! My friends and I have learned that you have to get down there right at 5-530 if you want to get a seat at the counter. That's all this place has is a counter and the three ladies working the kitchen (the other side of the counter) provide a fun "show" as they chop and pile and grill and fry and mix and yell back and forth to one another. 
We usually get the Yamo House Noodle "beefy noodly goodness" which is always succulent saucy and Delicious. We have also enjoyed the spring rolls, samosa, and the tofu mushroom rice dish (forgot the name) and all are flavorful and well seasoned. 
Yamo is well worth the trip down to the mission. If you can't get in and don't want to wait take out is quite speedy. 
Oh yeah, best of all, a full belly for under $7! 
If you are like me and enjoy an authentic adventure to go with your dining then this place is great. 

I say: yea.
author: Aya M.

description:
$5.25 house noodle with pork ftw. Yummy.

Please stay away from this restaurant during lunch hours so I can get a seat. Thanks.
author: Nick C.

description: This place is literally a hole in a wall, but for the amount of food you get at the price they are charging, I'd say it's a good deal. The food is tasty too.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Cheap and good.

3 Asian women and no DJ, they will be getting down with lots of delay. Don't expect the best service as you'll have to ask for what you  need.

This place is extremely small Only 8 seats and has a simple menu
$3.50 for appetizers
$5.25 for entrees and salads
Good portions and flavor for the price

There isn't a sign for this place so you'll have to be on the look out for a grimy place.  They do have one faded menu.  If you want a seat you'll probably have to wait making take out a great options.

I recommend the spring roll with peanut sauce, mango chicken and curry beef with noodles because this is all I've had there.
author: Po L.

description:
it's actually pronounced like yam (the potato)-o

anyway, this is cheap, delicious food made with love.

the tea salad is on par with the other burmese places in the city (a good measure for burmese food), although it's portioned more like an appetizer.

the mango chicken was just all right, but the potstickers and coconut were just amazing.

more importantly, this place is tiny, which means lower rent, which means passing the price on to consumers
author: Mark A.

description:
Now, i once lived in a country called Singapore where the local food culture was dominated by eateries known as "hawker centers". To a strangers tthey look like grimy rows of stalls surrounded by grimy chairs and tables, but hidden within is the best damn food you'll ever eat in your life.
