My meal at Yamo took me back to those days in Singapore, espcially when one lady hacked open a coconut with a cleaver before my eyes and served it with a straw and spoon (If you have not tried this you are missing out).  I wouldn't say it's the bestfood I've ever eaten - frankly I found it a bit bland for SE Asian eats, but it was still delicious nonetheless. Mango chicken with rice, Curry shrimp with Noodles, and Tea Leaf salad. Will definitely be back.
author: Polly F.

description:
You have to walk past this place a couple of times before it appears.
Spring Rolls are so so so good and they make them right in front of you plus you get Peanut sauce which I love.   The food is a little greasey but very tasty.  Got tho like the curry. You can order a fresh young coconut for desert.

The three old lady's make the food right infront of you which is also awesome.
author: adams l.

description: This place is amazing. My friends and I stumbled in hungover one afternoon, and have been addicted ever since. It's super cheap and totally delicious!
author: Melissa K.

description: Every amazing thing that every other reviewer said.  In short - This place kicks ass!
author: Dr. Katharine H.

description: This place looks like a hole in the wall. And it is. But that hole is filled with 4 awesome ladys cookin great food up a storm and at a price you can't beat. Thanks girls!
author: Bill N.

description: We ordered a tea leaf salad which everyone rave about, beef  house stir fry noodles and chicken house stir fry noodles, curry puffs. I think it's ok because I have had much flavorful Burmese food. I got to give credit to the tea leaf salad which is quite good, but everything else it's just alright. It's not exactly "cheap" either, cost vs. portion is small. It is a very small place so it's easily packed.
author: E C.

description:
Since I've known about Yamo, it's changed hands 3 times.  The first time I experienced this place, it was Yamo Thai and it was my favorite place for good cheap Thai food.  Fast and good.  And it was near my dance studio.  And the owners were a hoot!  Had some good convos with them

The second owners (Yamo Be There) were, I think, inexperienced because they spent too much effort on the look of the place and not on the food.  It was pretty bad.  Cold and bland.

This current Yamo is good, but I've had better.  I'm a little suspicious of the clear seasoning liquid they use, as I'm really sensitive to MSG (headaches) and beef broth (can't digest).  I've had some of their saucy dishes that left me with stomach cramps and headaches.  I've asked if they used either in my dishes, but they said no.  So, I don't know what it could be.  So now I stick to the fresh spring rolls w/tofu as a pre-dance-class snack - altho they're big enough to be a light lunch.  The ladies are nice and the food does taste good.  But still, I've had better.

I guess I'm still pining for ye olde Yamo Thai days.  ;}
author: Sandi B.

description: One of my favorite afternoon lunch spots! I have gone here numerous times and have never been disappointed. Their tea leaf salad is to die for, I constantly find myself craving it. The Yamo house cold noodles with tofu with fresh coconut juice is my usual order, I've tried other dishes but this one is by far my favorite. I love that nothing is over $5.25, sometimes there is a small wait but its so worth it. The women behind the counter aren't very friendly but what do you expect that place is always BUSY! So definitely come with patience and an appetite!
author: Jen R.

description: This is one of the most UNpretentious restaurants I have ever been to.  Their menu is simple yet delicious.  The owner is extremely nice and helpful.  I don't think I can complain an experience here.
author: Moko R.

description: Some friends told me that they were going to be bringing over Burmese food.  Normally I would have got excited and wonder, "maybe it'll be Burma Superstar!"  This time I didn't because my friends live within 5 blocks of Yamo.  "Uh oh" I thought.  So, previously I said that Yamo's food was gross and I'll stand by the comment when referencing that previous experience.  It was not an exaggeration.  This time however, it wasn't gross, it was instead passable.  I'm not going to go into great detail about it.  I'll just say, cheap or not, it's not worth the time.  I did appreciate the dinner though, having someone bring you food is an awesome gesture.
author: Christopher W.

description: I love dives and I love small hole-in-the-walls, so I was STOKED to find this place near by new house. I ordered the tofu noodles and the samosas. The samosas were AH-MA-ZING; crispy, fragrant, spicy and just delicious. The noodles however, kind of just tasted like oil, and the curry on the tofu and veggies wasn't as flavorful as I was hoping for. I"m settling for a 4 for this one because you can't beat the price and location, and those samosas are making me drool right now.
author: Amber K.

description: A tiny but lovely little place in the Mission with super delicious dishes. Try before the 6pm rush.
author: Tamas K.

description:
CHEAP EATS! 
This place is perfect in every way possible. The service is fast the prices are low and the food is excellent.

If you go on a weekday not during lunch peak hour its easy to get a seat. I have never waited more than 10 minutes to be seated. IF you come in the weekend or dinner be ready to wait. Just saying.
The  chicken noodle soup and tea salad is my favorite.
author: eric m.

description:
Keep coming back to Yamo time and time again. It's just that darn good. The asian ladies working have a certain character to them - each one unique. Once in a great while, i'll catch an occasional smile on them. But most of the time they operate with a poker face, intensely preparing orders with no time for emotion. Usually two of us go, and we are hearty eaters - always leaving the place having spent $20-$25 max. 

The patrons at this place also seem quite friendly. Maybe it's because of the tight dining quarters (the place only seats 10-12 people) and you are forced to kinda be nice, but I like to think we all share a belief that Yamo is a cool lil hole-in-the-wall and were all pretty cool to have each found this place and share in the experience together.

Did I mention anything about the food? =) great as well.
author: mike g.

description: Great noodles nice and fresh and mix of chinese and burmese the price is right and your tummy is fine. No booze minus the one star.
author: Chris D.

description: Tea leaf salad and sautee veggie, 1 coconut drink. Okay food, maybe more like 2nd rate of burma superstar which is okay tho - considering the location and cheap price
author: Cliff T.

description:
cheap, greasy, and great. 

Love that they have fresh coconuts, although I always make a mess spooning out the fruit. 

Dishes may be a bit greasy, but all the veggies taste fresh and the food is fabulous overall. I love the black bean fish and the curry fish. 

Skip the appetizers.
author: Kelly Kate W.

description: This place is amazing.  The cold noodles, tea leaf salad, fish curry, mango chicken, and coconut juice were all delicious.  The door is always left open, so it gets chilly in there in the winter.  Also, they don't serve beer and don't let you bring any inside.  Why, Yamo, why?
author: Jen H.

description: what qualified as a tea leaf salad here is only a very small fist full of shredded cabbage and onions mixed in sauces.  fish stew noodle was bland, and starchy, no visible trace of fish.  chicken curry was watery, bland and stingy on ingredients.  So it failed on all 3 dishes we ordered.  I wish i could give this a passing 3 star, but can't... It does have mean Asian women cashier/cook.  shouts at everyone with thick accent, and take-it-or-leave it attitude, but the spirit is probably what deserves the 2 star.
author: Adele W.

description: Amazing delicious greasy noodles. We always get the Yamo House noodles with Pork and maybe get some Spring Rolls. For the price it's super delicious and cheap. Call ahead to get take-out faster, as there isn't much room to stand inside. Cash only, which isn't awesome because as a bartender I always have cash and my boyfriend doesn't, thus I end up buying the Yamo. Alas, it is worth it. Check this place out if you live in the area.
author: Ericka J.

description: Get house noodles with beef and a fresh coconut. It can't be beat. Never substitute, always say as little as possible. Cash only.
author: Laci W.

description: Ok, so this place is cheap.  So are countless places in Mission.  Greasy and low quality ingredients.  2 stars because it's Burmese which is unique.   Try it once for yourself I guess...
author: L V.

description: I love this place, it's comfort food at it's finest. The vegetable noodle stir fry is pretty addicting. It's amazing to watch these ladies work, 2 of them in a tiny (dirty) space, cranking out order after order. You usually have to wait because it only seats about 10 people at the counter. But it's worth it.
author: jen w.

description: I love cheap food especially if it's good.  Yamo has good cheap food.  The counter sits about a dozen so it's very cozy in there.  I can't imagine eating in although I ran into two of my friends eating here this past week.  These are the same friends who think it's ok to stand front row at a large concert surrounded by teenagers.  I don't like my fellow man that much.  It took about 20 mins for the food to be prepared and that seemed a little long, but not too bad.
author: Corey V.

description: Good food, cheap price. I'd definitely recommend the beef with noodles. This place is really small and probably seats only about 10 people. There were 4 of us and luckily I was last of the group to arrive so I didn't have to wait long but I'm not sure it's totally worth waiting for. I'd still go back but have a backup plan in case the wait was too long.
author: Christopher U.

description:
love yamo! as decent as it gets! hard worker family!
tip nicely they deserve it!
i love the black bean fish!
its crowded and its tiny but who lives around can enjoy the luxury of having nice homemade burmanese cuisine in the hood for as cheap as 5.25 ;)
author: Babs J.

description: This place is so cheap and great.  I want to eat lunch and dinner there every day!
author: A. M.

description: holy shit, it's cheap cheap cheap and so fucking good.  it's just hot, fast, vegetable-y noodle-y amazingness for $6.  so far i've had the vegetable curry over noodles which is a giant plate loaded with veggies piled on top of noodles and the house noodles (which i ordered with veggies instead of meat), same same but different - huge serving of veggies piled over noodles.  just differently seasoned.  the line seems to range from turbo short to super long because there are only about 10 seats for eat-in but it's well worth whatever wait.
author: Emily T.

description:
The tea salad is quite tasty, but this place is a little too chaotic for me to handle on a regular basis.

Takeout is a challenge here: ordering by phone connects you directly into the noisy kitchen, so there is a lot of "huh?" and "what?" before the order is done. The staff doesn't take down a name or a phone number, so when you arrive to pick up, you need to dictate your order again, this time yelling over the counter.

Everyone once and a while this is worth it for two things: the tea salad and the chicken noodle soup. The salad is nicely balanced with lots of crunchy bits like peanuts and fried garlic to keep things interesting. The chicken soup has a rich and hearty broth with coconut milk. The rest of the menu is not very memorable.
author: Matt B.

description: I heart Yamo. It's a place you expect to find in the Mission: dingy and run-down but worth it because of the food. Eats are cheap on top of the deliciousness, as most of the main dishes are under $6. The curry chicken is just the right amount of hot (none of this half-assed yellow-curry-is-only-mildly-spicy crap) and the house noodles with pork is ridiculously tasty. The samusas are pretty good too, although if you opt to dine in they should be allowed to cool before you dive into them (after a healthy slathering of sweet spicy sauce, of course). Also if you eat in be prepared to leave smelling like the food because the stoves are barely five feet away from where you'll be seated. Just a warning for those considering making this joint Date Place #3.
author: Raffy E.

description: Wasn't what i expected from this place. I tried it and probably wouldn't go back again. It's super tiny and can only seat 10 people at the most at any given time. Bad for groups. But i do like the 'hole in a wall' feeling.
author: Do L.

description: This place is tiny, but good. In tiny, I mean there is only room to sit at the counter and you have to walk in and out of this place in single file in one direction only. If you sit closest to the entry, then you can watch the ladies cook.
author: Jenn K.

description:
Great little hole in the wall with tasty dishes for 5 bucks or less.  It's just a little kitchen run by these sweet old Asian ladies, with a counter and a few stools for customers.  You normally have to wait outside for seats to open up before you can go in, but that's because there are others who appreciate the quality, cheap eats that this place has to offer.

Their menu isn't anything fancy, but it doesn't try to be.  That's what's great about this place.  They have rice and noodle dishes, and some appetizers like egg rolls or vietnamese hand rolls.  I'll be back, for sure.
author: Alan C.

description:
yes, they messed up my order and gave me curry fish instead of what i wanted.  and yes, its also incredibly greasy, which was compounded by my choice of noodles instead of rice (soaks up the grease better).  and there is also close to no space in there and can get really warm.  and i almost felt sick when i finished my meal even though this was probably because i'd been doing the my-boyfriend-is-vegetarian-so-i-guess-i-am-too diet and had just eaten a ton of fried fish

whatever. its so damn cheap. and the service is so quick.
author: Amanda C.

description: Yamo is SF's best hole-in-the-wall, dive Chinese restaurant, with only a handful of seats available at the bar...but trust me, it's worth the very short wait! The food has spectacular flavor and is dirt cheap...just $6 for an entree.  The menu is on the small side, but it doesn't matter when I all ever order are my favorites...either the mango chicken or the stir fry veggies over rice!  (If you want a greasier option, you can go for the yummy noodles rather than rice.)  The service is fast and friendly, although you will have to speak up to get a refill in your uber-tiny water glass!  Just thinking about Yamo makes me want to leave work early to head over there...mmm...
author: Heather R.

description:
Grimy. Small. Hot. Tasty.

OK. I want to give this place five stars, because the food is incredible, affordable and the atmosphere is cool.

I've had almost everything on the menu and there's nothing I wouldn't rate as being anything less that 4/5. The Fish Chowder and the Tea Leaf Salad are unreal--so good.

The service is fairly prompt and the ladies are pretty nice. You might have a hard time getting a water refill but everything else is cool--plus you're better off ordering a fresh coconut to sip on anyway--with these prices you can afford it.

It's also the ultimate place for a cheap date. You'll probably drop less than $20 on two entrees, appetizers and drinks combined.

The only thing that drops my review down to four stars is the level of cleanliness here. It's totally filthy. The menus have a layer of grime on them that defies belief. Order your food and go was your hands, trust me. Also don't look at the knobs on the stove, concentrate on how rad your food is and the inevitable conversation you'll have with the person squished in next to you and you'll have a good time.
author: Justin G.

description:
yelp fans, good call on this one!

the chicken noodle soup is RIDICULOUSLY amazing.  shared the samusas as an appetizer, they were ...meh.

$5.25 though for most dishes.  the dishes arent huge but good portions so you arent forced to over eat.  most definitely a good value!!

the wait sucks, and getting a spot for more than 2 is being a little hopeful, we did manage to squeeze in 3 though.

forget eating at the counter and call-in! you can temporarily enjoy the chaos inside when you pick up.  i'm calling in and taking to-go next time...

overall good food and unique experience.
author: eric f.

description:
This place makes my belly, wallet, and face smile simultaneously. I had heard talk of Yamo in the past, but never could quite figure out where it was located (probably because the lack of signage). Once I finally located this tiny place, it took several attempts to arrive before the permanent line crowding right around the 33 stop.
If you get the timing right, you are in for a real SF treat. The food is delicious and made right in front of your face (like you can literally feel the heat from the stove). These women work their asses off, and even if the kitchen was in the back and you couldn't see the preparation of your food, you would know as soon as you took your first bite that Yamo is some pretty authentic shit.
If you go with a group (like 3 or 4, seating is so limited!) you can generally get out of there for under $10 each. Not exactly a Mission best, but pretty damn good.
**Get the coconut milk!! There's just something magical about drinking from your very own coconut, trust.
author: Kate G.

description:
yamo has moved to the top of my cheap eats list. i recommend going before or after lunch or before 5:30 or so and the wait won't be bad. no wait in my experience.

my favorite is yamo cold noddles, they are delicious. mango chicken was good. all of the chicken dishes i have had were made with all white meat chicken. that might be americanized but i like my chicken that way with no fatty pieces. 

tea leaf salad was the first time i have ever had it or even heard of it. try it and be surprised with great flavors. the spring rolls are made in front of you fresh. in fact all the meals are made to order and may take a few minutes if busy.

the two ladies do bust ass and do a great job. $5.25 for main dishes and spring rolls and other apps for $3 something. best deal going in the mission.
author: roger b.

description: Very unique business for our Mission area.  They remind me of being in Taiwan, where it's about the food and not about the service.
author: evan t.

description: Went with friends so I thought it would be difficult to get seated but we managed to get 2 stools after a 10 minute wait and then another stool a few minutes later.  Ordered the house noodles with chicken which was ok and the tea salad which was also ok and the tofu veggie curry noodles which didn't really taste of curry at all.  However the price was really great and the hole in the wall ambiance was really feeling the vibe.  Plans for next time, curry beef (I was wearing a white shirt and pastelly jacket so sensibly avoided it this time), mango salad and the spring rolls.
author: Gwyneth T.

description: the food tasted fine, but was a little oily, both of us had some major upset stomach action after we ate here, i don't think we'll be back. I'll save my Burmese food encounters with the much cleaner and fresher looking Burma superstar.
author: Jared Z.

description: A great value, if you don't mind watching three ladies stir-frying on the verge of a nervous breakdown.
author: Molasses C.

description: Oh how the mighty have fallen. I used to love this place when Anna the Thai Nazi ran the kitchen. Then there was that weird phase when it went vegan and was never open. And now, like a little butterfly, it has become a Burmese restaurant, which is supposed to be something along the lines of Chinese-Indian (or Chindian, if you will) food. Unfortunately, whatever they're serving here isn't that good. It's bland; you're much better off going to Bombay's and getting a couple of samosas and grabbing some home-style tofu from a Chinese place. The meal would have been wholly unforgettable if not for the fact that myself and my mother ate a full dinner all in under $10 (sweet!).
author: anhoni p.

description:
i been to yamo about 4 times whenever im in the mission and feeling hungry.  maybe i was just lucky bc each time i never had to wait. but this place is pretty small, with stools that can barely fit 10 people.  

anyways, it was interesting to me seeing chinese lady cooking burmese food.  like chinese food, its very oily.  the plates are small, that's why its $5 per plate.  

this is what i had:
tea leave salad: it was crunchy, small and pretty salty. i've had better ones..
The yamo cold noodle: this is actually pretty good. the beef was good and the not-so-appetizing-looking- noodles are tasty. probably the only thing i really enjoyed.
i dont even remember the rest of the items i've ordered here, partly because most of them reminded me of Chinese food.  

i dont dislike nor excited about yamo, only that they are pretty cheap.
author: Anna W.

description: great hole in the wall, delicious food and lightning fast service. i wouldn't go here with a party of more than 3-4 (provided you get there early), this place is tiny... but they sure turn tables fast. good stuff.
author: Laxme G.

description: Love Yamo.  Not super comfortable (narrow restaurant with bar stools) but it doesn't really matter.  The mango salad is excellent, as are the noodle dishes.  Everything is fresh and hot and made right in front of you.  AND you can try several dishes for well under $20.
author: Kristin P.

description: If you ride the 33 you cannot help having a glimpse at this hole in the wall and its cute door decor. Curiosity grew and finally I opened the door to have: freshly prepared delicious spring rolls, a great tea salad and a fresh and balanced mango chicken. The entire meal was 14 dollars, 7 bucks each! "Bargain bite" is not fair, this is lovely food at its price. On top of this, which is largely enough, the place is family owned and run entirely by women....big up!
author: Dario B.

description: Just like everyone else, I love this place. It happened to be next to my bus stop home by my new job and it took me 4 days before i had to go there for lunch. The Curry Chicken and noodles...bomb! Tastes like India with a little Asia thrown in.
author: Greg G.

description:
I still absolutely love Yamo. The deduction in star is a reflection of a more general view of Yamo's menu; having been a devotee of their tea leaf salad, noodle soups and Yamo House Noodles, I've discovered I'm not entirely enamored with anything else. I came by with my parents to introduce them to a more pure Mission dining experience and experimented with the beef curry, the mango chicken and... it was okay.
What? Only okay? I know, I have to be fair though and yes, I felt that past my exclaimed favorites mentioned in my first review, the rest of the menu is a bit lacking. I would generously approve of their fish chowder noodle soup and possibly their pot stickers but... beyond this, I'm not entirely sure.
Still, it hardly warrants a large deduction; but, with Yamo's increasing popularity seating at their infamous tiny food bar has become near impossible and as such, weighs further on the negative scale with a full star deduction.
I still really enjoy Yamo, and I still laud it's accomplishments to any who will listen, but have to be fair and numb a bit of the excitement and state the simple fact: if you have a Burmese-Chinese craving, order out. You will most certainly have a more satisfactory experience.
author: Jessica L.

description: This is a magical place :).  I (assume) and love that it is Woman-Owned and worked!!  Yamo is definitely a place worth providing business- the food is outrageously cheap and other than the oil used in cooking, everything is freshly chopped and prepared.  Really good first date material ;).  There isn't much room so you are provided with an excuse to snuggle up close and the hole-in-the-wall effect makes it an Alternate Universe-type feel.  Not to mention footing the bill would be an easy feat where meals are 5.25 a piece!  YAAYY YAMO!!!
author: Eri J.

description: 6$ curries and more.  delicious food. everyone sits at the counter :-)
author: michael d.

description:
One of my go-to spots, quick, cheep, and absolutely delicious!   Tiny place with only a dozen seats at a counter, there may be a wait but it's well worth it, and the turn over is quick.  Or just call in and take it to go.

My favs include the cold house noodles, tea salad, fish chowder, curry,  OK its all good!
author: Libby R.

description: The price is perfect for a mid week lunch. $ 5.25. Better for small groups. No tables, only bar stools....... so if your girl is high maintanence better head to Limon.  Food is made to order and the waitress is hella nice. Nice touch with the choice between rice/ noodles.
author: Joe G.

description: Oh, you spicy delicious tea salad. You tempt my mouth even now. Not even Burma Superstar's can compare to you. I swear it (even as I cower from the audacity of my own words)! Please tell your owners not to be closed on Sundays. Having watched them work their asses off to cook my last meal, I know they deserve the day off, but still. I am lost without you. Thank you for also being cheap.
author: Tracy D.

description:
we went to this place 15 minutes before they close on a friday night . I expected them to tell us its too late considering we were a group of 5 , however they kindly asked us to wait a  couple of minutes and we were seated in less than 10 mins. 
I love the fact that you can see whats indeed cooking and what type of material they are using!. They are also very kind and welcoming , for a second I felt like I am in my grandma's kitchen asking for food :))

overall good food for its price , the food portions are also not too big and not too small . the right size.
author: Farshid G.

description: $6 for every item on their menu. Portion is enough for 1 person. If you weigh more than 180 pounds, you may need to buy 2. Everything is very tasty. I like that they use THICK plastic containers for takeouts, not the think flimsy ones used in most Chinese restaurants. I pretty much tried everything on their menu and none disappoints.
author: Robert S.

description: I've gotten the Yamo hot (#15) and cold noodle (#16). Both are tasty and I love they have sriracha hot sauce at the counter. Service is slow, but fair and in the order received. Forgive the ladies working there -- if you had to work in a hot cramped kitchen all day long, you'd be grumpy too! When Yamo was a Thai place with thai lady & Peter, they were grumpy too. Its not them, its the location. Too bad they haven't figured out a way to serve faster -- they could make more money if they did. I'm sure the kids they are sending to college would appreciate it!
author: Sun K.

description: Definitely order #15 with your choice of beef, chicken or shrimp.  I had the beef, but don't think you can go wrong any which way.  The noodles were delicious.  One bowl was definitely enough food for 1 person and in my opinion is shareable.  The food was cheap and just plain tasty.  I didn't try the tea salad, but heard good things from other patrons.  I plan on revisiting this nifty little spot on 18th street.  Stop in and saddle up to a bar stool and have a bowl of noodles - you won't be disappointed.
author: Anjali K.

description: yikes. this place was terrible. so ridiculously greasy. both my boyfriend & i went home ill. i have no idea what the hype is all about. i think the cheap prices are over inflating the perceived quality.
author: Kristina P.

description:
it was soooo thrilling finding Yamo-  it was one of those times when you almost walk past the place because its so obscure you would never think to peek inside - barely any sign that its the place you were looking for - staking your hopes on a satisfying meal to this little door with a light on a dark street - then you poke your head in and see that there's a person on every stool along the narrow 12 foot counter.  so this might have some promise after all.  you walk in and pick up the menu and decide to wait it out and see if it is worthwhile - and so it was.

we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, yamo house noodles with beef, and black bean fish.  I would recommend the tea leaf salad if you're interested in a surprisingly crunchy and spicy salad. the samusas are cute crispy mini-versions of samosas with a plum-chili(?) dipping sauce.  Yamo house noodles with beef were the prize-winning dish with great flavor moist beef and crisp veggies.  

to top it all off the price was better than most places in the mission as noted in articles on their door.  worth the adventure to find it & now i will definitely go back.

*********
makes me want to sing a little song to a reggae tune: 
"yamo get some yamo~
yamo be alright~" :)
author: Marina K.

description: Wow, this place is great.  Food is awesome and dirt cheap.  The place is really cool looking so small and simple but I like that.  The employees are very nice.  I strongly suggest the Tea Leaf Salad I believe is what it is called and the mango Chicken.  Also the YAMO Garlic noodles with Beef were delicous.  Great food and a hidden gem in the mission.  I love this place.  I am slaivating just thinking about the food.
author: Harry E.

description:
this is a hidden gem in the mission!!  we wandered in here around 830 pm, and the dining area is just the kitchen w/ some bar stools.  you feel like you're eating at someone's home as the chef, her daughter (i think) and another relative take your order, cook, and serve you a great meal.  there are only about 10 stools in the whole place, but it moves quickly.  

b/t the two of us, we shared the samusas, tea leaf salad, and the house noodles w/ tofu.  they can make everything vegetarian.  we were able to order before sitting down, so once we sat down, our food came right away.  everything was delicious, and you can tell it was really made w/ love.  i would definitely come back for authentic home cooked burmese food.
author: Helen T.

description:
we had been wanting to try this place for months when we finally braved the line out the door last week. the wait was pretty much worth it; the ladies are super fast and work harmoniously in typical Asian restaurant fashion (take your order before you sit down and shuffle the poor person out of your soon to be seat while multi-tasking like mad and yelling things at each other).

food is a little on the greasy side but sometimes that is just perfect, with fresh veggies, yummy tofu and delish sauces. I have to agree though that a cold Burmese beer would really complete the experience.
author: Eva L.

description:
this cute hole-in-the-wall joint sells fresh, cheap food.  

i wasn't, like, utterly blown away by my black bean tofu dish, but i'll definitely go back again.  i'm curious about the house noodles.
author: Elle B.

description: For cheap good hole in the wall spot, you've come to the right place. It's a really good treat for dinner. I suggest to pre-order and bring your cash to pay up front. There's only 8 seats approximately.
author: Hebert J.

description: Maybe we caught Yamo on an off night, but their food was incredibly greasy and lacked flavor.
author: Krista C.

description: You could walk right by this place without ever knowing it.  But Yamo has delicious Burmese food made right in front of you.  All the meals are low priced, so this place definitely makes for a good cheap eats.
author: Vinnie L.

description: Noodles never really meant much too me until I discovered Yamo house noodles.  The house noodles with beef are unassuming with  very little sauce and a simple side of cabbage,peppers, and sriracha but watch out, these noodles are oozing with flavor. I don't recommend Yamo if you don't like 'hole in the walls", or if your looking for a five star dining room experience, but if you like grubbing arm in arm with other diners and watching the ladies in the kitchen go to town then Yamo is the place to be.
author: Kadecia W.

description: There aren't too many hole-in-the-wall spots in SF, so trying one is always exciting. The place is tiny: about 8 spots at the counter, so expect to wait. I mean, this is a prime spot for people-watching anyways, so don't complain too much. The tea leaf salad is amazing. Small portion if you're sharing, but really flavorful and delicious. I liked it better than Burma Superstar's version, and the prices at Yamo can't be beat. The house noodles with beef are really simple, and delicious. Portions aren't huge, but it's $6, so again: don't complain too much. I'd skip the samusas (greasy, tasted like they'd been frozen) and get the fresh salad rolls instead. My most prideful moment of the evening: getting a smile out of the head chef (yes, she is soup nazi-esque, but with a heart of gold). If they are busy, they'll suggest you help yourself to chopsticks on a shelf behind the counter. This was oddly endearing, and reminded me of being a kid at an older aunt's house where I was both excited for the food and a little scared of the ambiance, too. It's comfort food at its best, and will leave some extra cash in your pocket for that over-priced cocktail at any of the hipster joints in the area. Moral: be polite, wait your turn and enjoy!
author: Sofia P.

description: No longer the previous two incarnations of Yamo (one was the Yamo Thai Kitchen and one was the Yamo Thai Kitchen under different management), this is a fabulous hole-in-the-wall noodle shop.  You could probably just call it "Two Ladies and a Wok".  It's got formica table tops, 9 seats, florescent lighting, a sign stating that it's an "alcohol free zone", but it's fantastic.  It's simple.  It's that "I'm traveling and I'm eating street food" feeling.  It's ridiculously cheap.  Best of all, it's run by a tremendously smiley lady who is as gracious as can be.  On the back of the menu, there is a Logo that reads "For the Curious One" and that is exactly who is going to enjoy this place.
author: amanda g.

description: Arrive early, try the tea salad, and watch this cadre of tiny sisters bicker adorably! Fun, quick (once youre seated) and inexpensive.
author: M S.

description:
I created my yelp account because of this incredible establishment.  It's places like this that remind me of why San Francisco is such an amazing place to call home.  Yamo is the epitomy of Dive.  It is a beacon to which all dives should aspire.  
Everything about this place is perfect, dive-wise.  It scores 5 stars on every dive category: appearance, price, hours, service, quality, and memory-making.  It's the kind of place you would normally walk past and wonder 'christ on a bicycle, why would anyone eat here'.  But as they say, you can't judge a book by it's asshole.  Or is it, never lick a gift horse in the ass?  I can't remember, either way, the point being, get inside.  Once inside you get the picture.  No tables, only a counter with seating for about 10.  The cook/waitress/host/bus-girl was stellar.   Everything cooked right in front of you so you can see how they do it.  You'll wonder what the ingredients are and you'll want to try it out at home yourself, if only you had some of the stuff in those funny looking jars.  Definitely try the tea-salad, house noodles, they also have fresh coconut-milk and coke in glass bottles.  Every entree is 5.25.  hot damn!   At one point, another woman came down a ladder out of the ceiling to help the main cook, without even a hint of irony...absolutely amazing.
author: Carlisle H.

description: Yum!  This place is delish!  Teensey and busy, but well worth the wait.  Cheap, tasty, fast(ish), and just the perfect touch of greasey.  I dig the chicken noodle soup and mushroom tofu.
author: Katrina M.

description: yamo is yum-o i like any place where i can see the cooks preparing my meal and it was very fresh and flavorful. food comes quick and the prices are cheap. i recommend the saumsas, chow mein with beef, and fish with black bean sauce. the place is tiny so you either will have a long wait or get there just in time to snag a seat at the bar.
author: M K.

description:
This is the best-kept secret in the Mission, though perhaps it's not as secret as it once was. I discovered when I was home from work one day sick as a dog and in search of the nearest chicken noodle soup. Yamo's is excellent, and running into it that day, blurry-eyed and feeling just generally awful, was a most fortuitous find. 

Yamo is now my go-to place for take-out, a quick meal, and just generally a GOOD meal. And it's cheap! I don't understand the economics of their business as I feel that most of their dishes must cost more to make then they sell it for, but I'm not complaining. Plus, the ladies who man the place are absolutely fantastic, friendly, and fiercely good at what they do.

Here's a tip: Ask for my favorite dish, which is NOT ON THE MENU... the Ginger Salad. Thank me later.
author: Daniela P.

description: I travel a lot for work.  When I get back into SFO after a long trip, I call Yamo  and put in an order.  I go straight from the 16th Street BART station to Yamo, where the aunties serve up steaming noodles that taste exactly like home.  After a year of sampling everything on the menu, I still love it all.  The soups, though, are my favorites.  Chicken noodle soup that makes you say, dear god, what would life be like without coconut milk?
author: Caricia C.

description:
I just went here with Christine, my friend. We ordered tea leaves and stir vegetables with rice. I love the food. The place is kinda small but good to try. There are only 3 people working there : 1 person cook, 1 person make preparation, 1 person cutting food. All the main courses are $5.25. what a good deal. The courses are not really that many but it's okay for me.

YOU SHOULD COME AND TRY......
author: Elisabeth T.

description:
I'm no stranger to hole-in-the-wall restaurants and the lack of service it entails. That doesn't bother me. I don't mind the wait in line either. The food was decent, but as others have mentioned, not truly Burmese. That's ok though. If I was just rating this place based solely on its food and cheapness, I would definitely give it a 4 star rating. 
I really wanted to like Yamo, but I really resent the fact that it took my bf and I nearly 2 hours to get our food so I can't bring myself to rate this place any higher than a 2. 
We ordered samosas, tea leaf salad, the house noodles, and black bean fish. 2 guys sat next to us 15 minutes later, ordered, and received their food 5 minutes later as we sat there hungrily staring at the samosas sitting in the deep fryer basket. Eventually, we received everything except for the fish. Where is it?? Ah-ha! I see it now, plated and ready to serve, except it got dumped in a to-go box. WTF? I tried to remain calm, but since I can understand Cantonese, I heard everything the ladies were saying in regards to our order. Apparently, one of them spaced out and gave our black bean fish to someone else who ordered after us. Time ticks by as we patiently waited for our black bean fish to arrive. Meanwhile, the 2 guys next to us finished eating, paid, left, and another couple sat next to us. It wasn't until this couple ordered and received their food that the ladies realized that we're still waiting on our last dish. 
The black bean fish eventually arrived shortly after they realized their blunder, but it wasn't delicious enough to make up for the ridiculously long wait we endured. I want my 2 hours back!
author: Cynthia F.

description: this is actually like a 4.5.  It's great...it's my new neighborhood place.  I shouldn't even write a review...there is already a line out the door.  My only drawback is that they have such a limited menu.  There's alot of overlap on tastes.  They have a menu of about 15 things and apparently they are all good.  I personally recco the yamo house noodles with pork and the tea salad.  Note that they close at 9:30 and up till that point there will be (as I said) a line out the door.  This place is no longer hidden, I'm just being a flurry on Yelp
author: Jake H.

description: This is that awesome food your mom made if you had a Burmese mom. Some people might wonder how it stands up to more sophisticated fare, but they should be wondering about whatever happened to their souls?
author: Paul J.

description: Count on a line 90% of the time, but those ladies are always sweet as pie and fast behind the counter. Good food. A sure mission hole-in-wall gem.
author: Alex S.

description: This place defines "hole-in-the-wall"... it is basically involves a long narrow space of which 2/3rds is dedicated to the cooking area and the other 1/3rd to the counter, barstools and walking space... cramped is an understatement.  I ordered the vegetable curry to go.  The curry really wasn't a curry; it was more of a spiced oil... it wasn't bad; it just wasn't good.
author: Matt P.

description: Since ive been without a job Ive been extremely tight with my nightly drunken eats, that being said ive been a huge fan of the mexican taquerias here in the mission.. on my way to one of my usual suspects i saw a few elderly asian women slaving over a small stove- producing what appeared to be 5 star food in a dingy little cave, the equivalent of the red light district of asian grills, i remember many people huddled up waiting for the bar which sits about 6 to 8 people depending on your size and age.. after a half hour wait i come in and with one eye closed point to a coconut which i vaguely remember drinking and enjoying..  i proceed to eat a tea leaf salad, excessive amounts of noodles (which to this day i salivate when i think about) and leaving fully satisfied for less than 12 dollars!) to sum this dive up- affordable fine dining in a dingy atmosphere with the perk of good looking asian women who don't fuck you about
author: Kyle B.

description: I love you yamo. Best deal in tow!!! Amazing food, fast, and the little old women are so funny.
author: Erin D.

description: Probably one of the most awesome hole-in-the-wall joints in the entire city! The tea leaf salad is particularly awesome. When that, plus the black bean fish, house noodles with chicken, samusas, fresh coconut juice, and a soda costs you just over $22, you end up wondering if you're still in the city. Not the best tasting ever, but still fresh, very tasty and cheap. Love it.
author: Maximillian M.

description: The perfect place to grab a bit to eat and not break the bank while eating amazingly tasty food!
author: Jamie K.

description: A true "hole" in the wall burmese/chinese diner. If you don't look hard enough you might miss it. There are no burma superstar type lines here. No tables either, just one diner counter that sits @ 8-10. The menu is short, sweet, and cheap. Don't go to this place if you have OCD or freak out about uncleanliness. This is your typical real chinese food joint which is just a step above a street vendor. Try the tea leaf salad and any of the noodle dishes.
author: Ron T.

description: Delicious pile of food for under 6 bucks - an awesome deal.  The food is filling and comforting and tasty.  This isn't really the place you'd want to go for a fancy date but for a fun, intimate date, this tiny place is great - there is only room to sit at the counter.  The staff is attentive and sweet, refills your water and tea quickly and is very accomodating.  The Yamo house noodles with fried garlic and fresh cabbage and onions was the perfect meal for a misty SF evening.  I can't wait to go back, I thought the Mission only had burritos but I was wrong! ;)
author: Suzanne V.

description: I just stopped in for the first time, based on these reviews, for take-out. I am eating while I type, oh lordy this is good!!! I got a generous helping of vegetable stir-fry with noodles for $5.25!! The cook prepares everything right in front of you. The place is tiny ( about seven counter seats) and apparently run by just three women. Love the atmosphere. Can't wait to go back and try more stuff. OK... can't talk... eating....
author: susan s.

description: delicious,  small, packed, inexpensive,  best for take out, house noodles with chicken is the bomb!!
author: Brian R.

description: The tea salad didn't live up to others I have had.  The brightness of flavors wasn't there - it was more spicy than anything.  Food was good overall and I will return when I am in the area.  I'd like to give them 3.5 stars.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
went with danny e. and melissa (right below me). delicious noodles, small space though, as there are only about 8 stools at the counter. danny and i went today and we had that type of meal where the food is so good, that you just don't talk to the person you are with because you are too busy stuffing your face with delicious egg noodle goodness. we tried the tea salad today and the fried garlic was so delicious! 

love the old ladies that work here and we ESPECIALLY love it when they are whacking away with a machete (not really, just a big ol' knife but machete is so much more fun to say!) at the coconut just to give you coconut milk to drink. the food comes fairly quick and it's super cheap too, i've gotten the yamo house noodles with pork both times i've been here and they give you so much meat for $5.95. bottom line is, yamo gives you a good feeling in the tum after eating.
author: Melanie C.

description: This place is unique! although is not a fancy restaurant or place to eat but this place prove that good foods not always about expensive and fancy! Fully recommended for you guys who love to hang out and make some new friends! you will know what I mean if you give a shot to stop by.
author: willy w.

description: Noodles! Anything with noodles here is amazing! The tea leaf salad is too salty. Overall amazing and cheap! Long ass lines so just over takeout.
author: Christopher L.

description: I really wanted to like this place because I like to express my unique hipness and non-conformist attitude by frequenting little hole-in-the-wall dives, but alas, I think a hole in the wall in a Castro restroom might prove more satisfying.  The food was mediocre at best, though it was cheap and served in abundance.  I liked the dingy, cramped environment, but you've got to back it up with good food.  If I want a low-cost, throw-down meal, Taqueria Cancun is right up the street for christsake!  Torn between 2 and 3 stars--the food was definitely 2 star, plus one for the quaintness, minus one for my disappointment.
author: ShivaMatt L.

description: One of the best deals in town; home-cooked Burmese food made as you watch from the counter.  Order the chicken soup or any curry plate.  Fourth star will be delivered if they ever start serving beer.  Note: wear clothes you don't mind getting a little greasy and don't expect fine gourmet dining.
author: eli c.

description: One of the BEST spots in the mission to eat.   Get the pot stickers and the mango salad.  Seriously bomb food cheaper than you could make it yourself.
author: t h.

description: A hallway divided in half by a counter that separates customers and staff. It's great to see these laborious ladies make your food while you wait, also if in need of a facial this little joint will take care of that. I come here when I am hungover and need a home-made-ish meal prepared fast, and although I've had better the price of this meal is unmatchable and proves better than any burrito in a taqueria-infested mission; this place rules me arsehole. I would, however give it three and and a half stars for I am neither a 'yay fan' nor think it's simply 'a-ok'... but hey what can ya do?
author: Valentina C.

description: Holy best find of the wknd! Came upon this literal hole in the wall on a whim and felt like I was back in SE Asia (ok, so I haven't be to Burma, but close enough). Yes, there is very little seating. Go at an odd hour.. like 3-4pm and you should sit right donw. Almost everything on the menu is $5.Unbelievable!  I split 3 things with my friend and were were stuffed, two would have been plenty. The mango salad is so delightful..and spicy! Grab some coconut juice in a real coconut (even if the juice comes out of a can). LOOOOVE IT!
author: Ash E.

description: Minuscule room. Delicious tea leaf salad, pot stickers and coconut chicken soup!
author: Thomas K.

description: Who doesn't like cheap good eats?  Or hole in the wall spots run by little asian women who answer the phone loudly?  This place is a giant unapologetically greasy kitchen with a counter that serves up a quick and tasty deal.  I loves it.
author: Yeeman N.

description: UPDATE: Warning Yamo Thai is no longer the place it used to be ... Previous said owner has been replaced by two ladies and hipster atmosphere has been junked for cheap counter seating and flourescent lighting -- and if that weren't bad enough, the food SUCKS. Beware. END UPDATE. The new owner calls this place "Yamo Be There" because it's the place to be. Veteran patrons will remember the single counter service, but the quick tongued Vietnamese lady has been replaced by a worldly hipster who tells travel stories when it's slow. The food is vegetarian Thai and exceptionally innovative, as the chef opts for seasonal vegetables to keep everything fresh and tasty. The vibe is the cherry on top of this experience: real records spin on a turntable and art films flicker on a wall screen.
author: Katie B.

description:
I'm a fan!

bar seating only - no tables. 3 old ladies working behind the bar cooking your food right in front of you. I'm sure if I was burmese, this would be the equivalent of mom's food...

the chicken noodle soup was awesome! it is more like a chicken-coconut-curry-noodle-soup. Fish curry was pretty good. Tea leaf salad was a little too tart - probably wont get that again.

definitely plan to go here many more times :-)
author: Priya K.

description: Not that great. I agree with Susan S., the reviewer before me. It's cheap. I love Burmese food but this didn't have much complexity of flavor at all. Boo!
author: E. M.

description: Inexpensive and delicious.  The cramped, hot space adds to the atmosphere, much liked Tu Lan or Cordon Bleu, but even smaller and even more cramped.  I'm lying here smelling grease on my clothes but I'm still writing a 5-star review.  Well, let's make it 4.   Try the tea salad and the tofu with mushrooms.
author: Christopher V.

description: I love the fact that this place seats about 8 people and it's cramped and a real hole in the wall.  The food is tasty, though pretty greasy - more or less what you'd expect for fast Asian food at $5.25 an entree.  We enjoyed the piping hot samosas and the chicken salad especially.  The curry chicken was good, though nothing particularly special.  A great place for a quick bite with a Burmese slant in the Mission.
author: Jon A.

description: Yamo! What can I say? The price is right at this Burma Joint. Very good home style cookin. Everything is good here, but I always get the Yamo house noodles. If I got this at other places it would prob coast me $10-13, but @ this place its half the price and just as good or even better. The only down side to this place is that its very very small so prepare 2 wait or call in for your order before you come. Sits about 10 people.
author: Jay S.

description:
tiny place with only bar seating - maybe ten spots total. dirt fookin cheap and sufficiently tasty to deserve four stars. i've definitely had better burmese, but i can't remember the last time i had food this cheap that didn't come wrapped in wax paper.

no booze, but that's okay.
author: Clover Dan ..

description:
Yamo is da-Bomb-o

Sweet Christ.

Get the spiced potato fried things with the sweet whatever sauce and any tofu dish, hell, any dish at all. Who knew Burmese was this good? And so cheap??

Be prepared to wait in line and to ask for water refills/ check whenever you need it. Because you need this.
author: Matt T.

description: Yamo, yummo.  Fast, fresh, fairly consistent, oh my goodness-CHEAP.  I come here again and again because I love it again and again.  Perfectly sized portions, delicious flavors, fresh young coconuts, yummy yummy tea leaf salad, food just as good as some much spendier Burmese places, highly recommended!  Just went there the other night with 3 friends, shared 5 dishes and only paid $11 each, including tip!  Aside from the fact that it is teeny tiny, it is a wonderful place to go with friends so that one can share, taste many dishes and still pay next to nothing.
author: Frankie S.

description: Most people would take off a star for a restaurant being too small but I added one. This hole in the wall Mission eatery can only seat a handful of patrons who order on stools at the counter top. The huge dish of curry beef with rice and noodles is only $5.25 as is the delicious coconutty chicken noodle soup while appetizers from pot stickers to spring rolls are a steal at $3.25. Go here often and come hungry.  Expect a wait and stalk a seat. You'll immediately appreciate Yamo's charm. It's yummy.
author: Jessica M.

description:
talk about hole-in-the-walls.  this place is literally a hallway made into a restaurant!  against one wall is the kitchen.  against another wall is...well, your back b/c while you'll be sitting 5 feet from the 4 women cooking and serving you food, your back will be against the wall.  no, i am not exaggerating!  

with that said, this place can be uncomfortable and elbow room is hard to come by, but the yamo noodles made me forget that only two inches separated me and my stranger neighbor.  YUM!   

the tea leaf salad, as everyone else says, is delish, but not suitable for those who can't eat spicy (like me).  but there is a solution...ORDER A FRESH COCONUT to accompany your meal!

alas, there are cons:  not the cleanest place and definitely uses oil way too sparingly.  (check the plate after you've cleared it...not for those at risk of heart disease.)  lastly, small portions!! i'd rather pay a bit more for a bigger portion to really satisfy my tummy.
author: Yvonne P.

description: This is the Tu Lan of the Mission.  On a shady block, dirt cheap, awesome food, closed Sundays.  Went with wifey last night.  Ordered spring rolls (made fresh in front of you - good, not great).  Then had the yellow curry chicken and an order of yamo house noodles (hot, with chicken).  Yamo noodles were my favorite (VERY flavorful). Total bill $14.00.
author: Val U.

description: This place is super Burmese!  I love their prawn curry over noodles, mango chicken noodles, the yamo house noodles, veg curry, samosas, tea salad. That's what I had so far.  I'm going to try everything on the menu.  It's also inexpensive too.  Parking is okay....
author: Miyoko N.

description:
yamo.....is soooooooooooooooo yummy! and cheap...and three lil ol ladies run the show in that lil tiny place that only seats less then 10 ppl at the bar...always feels like im in nyc when i walk in there!

samosas...yumm

veggie curry...yummm

veggie chow mien ...yummm
author: SammyWammy S.

description:
5 stars for price, -1 star for portions and crammed space.  You might have to stand in line for 20 minutes to get a table but it's definitely worth it.  

The food is pretty good for the price but the portions are pretty small, especially the tea leaf salad.  Although for that price, you can order 3 entrees for two people and still come out under 20 dollars, but maybe that's just because I'm a big eater.
author: Andrew S.

description: This location of this tiny dive is so much more convenient than heading all the way over to Clement to Burma Superstar so I give this place 3 stars.  The quality doesn't even come close to BS though.  Prices are good and the meal was filling.
author: Lauren S.

description: One dish was excellent and one dish was utterly bland. It's fun to sit at the counter and watch the meal be put together, but if I go back it would be for take out only.
author: Velma G.

description: Just as the other reviews mention, cheap, delicious, fast and unpretentious. I had the mango chicken, loved every bite, and for $6, have no complaints.
author: Jason B.

description:
My philosphy on writing reviews is the places should be rated on what they are trying to be and how well they reach that goal.

Yamo is trying to be a hole-in-the-wall restaurant.  And it suceeds wonderfully.

First, the decor:  This place is a dump.  There is grafiti on the outside and the inside is worn and dingy.  But it appears basically clean.

Second, the service:  English speaking ability varies, but it is always friendly.

Third, the food:  Wonderfully tasty and satisfying burmese food.  Good quality, fresh ingredients; all prepared before your eyes.  Not always subtle but never bland.

Fourth, the prices;  Cheap, Cheap, Cheap.

There you go all the elements of a hole-in-the-wall restaurant.  5 stars without a doubt.

SFD
author: Peter H.

description: I have been here twice and both times i have loved it. The food is good, but I love the atmosphere. I love the hard working women that just cook and don't have time for small talk, but are friendly underneath their hard exteriors. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
author: BD H.

description: This place is insany teeny tiny cute. And the two women who work there are even cuter. They slam out tasty Burmese food at super cheap prices --- you watch them cook as you sit at your coveted counter seat. I like the tea leaf salad and the curry chicken. It's a no nonsense tasty meal that's filled with textures and familiar yet not so familar flavors --- I like it for that change of pace.
author: Jennifer C.

description: I love Yamo with all my heart. The house noodles are delicious, the ambiance cannot be imitated. I can only hope that one day I am regular enough that they known I always ask for chopsticks with my take-out and they stop giving me plastic forks.
author: April B.

description:
Alright girls and boys.  This ain't for the slow food crew or the quasi foodie bunch chasing each other around San Francisco.  This is the epitome of a true-blue hole-in-the-wall navigated by three charming women who manage not to trip over one another in a sliver of space they all occupy and at the same time deliver some great, HONEST, inexpensive grub.  

Yes, you're gonna have to wait to sit your butt in one of 8 or so barstools, bring cash because your credit/debit card ain't good there, and be prepared to be wowed by some great tasting eats for the price of an expensive espresso drink at Starbucks.  

Cooking is sometimes like sausage-making:  You know it tastes good but the production process is kinda gross.  Oh, and one more thing:  If you can't stand the heat, stay out of their kitchen which is where you'll be eating.
author: J M.

description: Yamo.....yummo!!! It's like being at the breakfast nook of someone's kitchen! A little diamond of a dive- counter service only, cash only, and some of the entertainment is watching them make your meal! Loved the tea leaf salad and spring rolls (with shrimp- yum!) - but the highlight for me was the Yamo House Noodles (with beef). Could definitely lead to a "Sally" moment in a restaurant....almost don't want to share it ( :
author: Keri B.

description: I tried Yamo a few weeks ago.  It was fine.  Not great.  I don't really want to go back.  It's kinda novel and the food was good (again, not great), but the wait for both sitting down and getting your food can be absurd.  Also, the couple next to us sat down a good 10 minutes after us, ordered one of the same dishes that we had ordered, and got their food immediately (and nearly 20 minutes before we got ours).  I'm really not exaggerating.  It was pretty disappointing.
author: Heather E.

description:
Nothing really new to add here that hasn't already been said.  This place is great, in a 5.25 per plate kinda way.  Love to find a new hole in the wall like this!

In the words of our illustrious governor - "I'll be back..."
author: Jon B.

description:
- Literally a hole in the wall.  
- Service: a hello would  be nice
- Portion: decent
- Atmosphere: can we say small and crammed?
- Type of food: Really, Burmese?  I think not.
- Attitude: Looks like the workers hate it there
- Going back?  Only if you cut my legs off first and then dragged me there while I dug my nails into the floor pleading no.
author: Restaurant C.

description:
talk about a hole inside a hole in a wall!  tiny place. great service and friendly people.  I had the fish with house noodles...greasy and just beautiful.  hit the spot!  

definitely a must if u're in the mission district...

it u can find it!
author: Roy N.

description: it seems as if the yamo ladies are 24 hour cooking machines. and they're good at what they do -- this place is a favorite lunch spot. i'd gladly wait 20 minutes for one of the 12 seats, as the food is delicious and hella cheap. and get a coconut with your meal. effing great.
author: Evan M.

description: In regard to cost, quality and service this place is a 5 because the first two make the last least important. I've been here twice and been happy. Mandalay Bay and Burma Super* aren't all that much better, and 2 or 3 X the cost.  It's great for takeaway. The vegie curry, fish curry, are great.
author: Cristian M.

description: Thank you to my new co-worker who introduced me to this place - yes you, you know who you are! YEAH this is tasty and the ladies behind the counter are so cute. and you can drink out of a coconut - what more could you want?
author: melissa h.

description: This is my favorite hole in the wall in the Mission.  You walk in to a space that has just enough room for a counter of ten seats and a kitchen with three burmese grandmas.  they are awesome.  each dish is $5.75 or less.  they cut everything fresh right in front of you.  the tea leaf salad and the mango chicken are a must have.  expect to walk out reeking of garlic....but it's soooooo good.
author: Lyz L.

description: i could eat here everyday. small, cheap, delicious, just about the most perfect meal. i always get the curry chicken with rice noodles. amazing. the end.
author: Brooke W.

description:
this place is such a hole in the wall!! the food is amazing.. i LOVED the noodles (with beef) and the salad. they accidently placed someone else's samosas in front of me and i 'accidently' ate them... good choice! they were cool with it though. i don't know the menu name items because i trusted my friend to order for me.

the staff of 3 women were really friendly and hospitable!
author: Joseph B.

description:
Went during lunch by myself and had Chicken Noodle Soup.  The wait wasn't too long for just one person.  Definitely plan on not wearing something that you don't want to get smell of smoke on, since you'll be separated from the woks only by a counter.

The soup had wonderful flavor.  Coconut milk, cilantro, onions, and spices in it makes it a great comfort dish for a typical SF summer day.  I can't say I love the noodles.  They were slightly undercooked for my preference and didn't really have much taste.  

My neighbors recommended tea leaf salad, cold noodles, and house noodles.  Definitely will try them next time.
author: diana t.

description: shared some veggie noodles...not amazing, but not bad either.  the people next to us had something that looked really good.  i think i need to try this place again, and try something else on the menu.  cute little place though, and cheap!  wish they had beer though...
author: Kate W.

description: you know, i reallly reallllly wanted to love this place. the food is very inexpensive (pro), but was weak compared to other delicious burmese restaurants i've patronized. the fish curry chowder was watery and tasted like perfume (in a bad way), the house noodles were kinda greasy and bland, and the tea leaf salad was so-so (again, not up to par compared to other varieties i've had).
author: cristina s.

description:
the food is extremely budget friendly, and the portions reflect the price -- just enough to get you to the point of satiety, but you get what you pay for for $5.25.

their curry is a bit oily for my likings.  i do like their house noodles.  the tea leaf salad is gorgeous, and they will make it w/out the shrimp upon request.  i have yet to try their soups.  i thought that their black bean tofu dish was a bit bland.  nothing sriracha can't doctor up though.
author: Sheri N.

description: I love this place. I'll make it fast. It's cheap and the food is awesome!! I'm a fan of the curry chicken with noodles. Toss in freshly opened coconut juice and I'm totally happy(wallet too). The place is really really small, so the room tends to fill up rather quickly. It's a perfect place when you're with a friend and want something fairly fast and on the move.
author: Kevin D.

description: This place is freak'n awesome.  The ladies behind the bar are super nice and friendly.  Simple, easy, something I can probably make but not as good.   The curry beef is the best.  I love this place not because its  cheap but the quality and the flavor is very good for a  a nondescript hole in the wall place.
author: ray s.

description: I'm sad to say my friend and I had a horrible exprience here! It took forever to get someone to take our order (though they were four feet away from us behind the counter) and then when my food did come the noodles were severely undercooked (like borderline crunchy) and when I asked them (very nicely) to be cooked a tad more they cooked the CRAP out of them and then gave them back to me as noodle soup. It was really disappointing.
author: rukshan b.

description: great hole in the wall secret spot for cheap eats !! went here w my friend the other day .. i always passed this up before cause its so small and on a side street off mission .... everything was very good .. and very fresh/hot off the oven ... somosas were spice and good .. and the house noodles were some of the best ive ever had . def going back !
author: Micah W.

description: Fantastic food for super cheap and an ambience you will always remember (cheap, funky lunch counter). The fish with black bean sauce is spectacular.
author: Jenni O.

description: This place rocks.  It's like Art's Cafe in the Sunset but with Burmese food instead.  There are only a few seats at the counter.  The women working here are super friendly (I think it's mother and daughters), the food comes out quick and you get to watch it being prepared.  The best part aside from the fact that the food tastes great is that nothing on the menu is more than about $6!  I highly recommend the tea leaf salad though I don't think any dish will disappoint.
author: M M.

description: This place a really good.  I enjoy noodles and intimate places.  It has a street food vibe.   Everything is made to order.  You must be able to not mind having full view of the kind women preparing your food in a 6 x 3 strip of a kitchen.  Things look cluttered and can easily be mistaken for being dirty (although I did notice her handling cash and then adding cucumbers to my noodles).
author: Adrian N.

description: Another hole in the  wall joint in sf that you can't miss.  The chicken soup with coconut milk and onions.....yumo!
author: Meghan B.

description: As i walked to my regular smoke shop on the corner of mission and 18th, i was starving and wanted something quick and cheap. i stumbled by YAMO. I had no clue where the exact location of the place was until last night. The place is tiny, and i am serious, tiny. It fits about 8 people or less. The menu was small but cheap, i was shocked that they had spring/summer rolls(whatever you wanna call it). At first i wanted fried rice but ended up ordering the Yamo house noodles. The noodles were actually good, it looked like it was a tiny serving but it actually filled me up. I ordered the spring roll and saved it for a late night snack. The lil old lady was pretty nice and quick when she took my order. I took my fpod home cause the place was already full, i would def come back and try something else on the menu.
author: Lucky M.

description:
$5.25 for the entree dishes.

home cooking made with lots of love and spiciness.

this tiny little aisle of a place is wonderful.
author: Darrell L.

description: Burmese in the Mission and no crazy wait. The food is simple, tasty and cheap. Make sure you don't wear any fine threads cuz you will stink of cooking to high heaven. Try the House Noodles and the Black Bean Fish. Try as much as you like b/c it's only $5.25 ( tax included) for entrees and $3.50 for apps. Not a first date kinda place unless your date likes hole in the wall restaurants and dive bars.
author: Huy N.

description: Interesting dive place with cheap eats in the Mission.  Food quality is decent and fresh at this price point; however, if you put this place in Chinatown it would only be "run of the mill".
author: Laurence H.

description: I like to make it there whenever I can, and the price fits nicely into my budget, as of late.  The place is tiny and I'm sure there are rodents all over the floor late at night when it's dark, but this SF.  Not so into the idea, but still the food is FRESH and DIRT CHEAP.  You see them make it before your eyes.  Be lucky enough to score a seat and eat.  Added plus is that I've been sick with this chest/cough/congestion thing that won't go away and last week I ate at Yamo and had the curry chicken.  Apart from being delicious, it cleared my sinuses!!!!  The spring rolls are HUGE too.
author: Emilio O.

description:
The Place:
I had a bit of trouble finding the place. When I first saw it, I thought the restaurant was condemned and closed for business. The entire place consisted of a room about half the size of a classroom with a bar in the middle. On one side there's eight seats (good luck number for Chinese people), and on the other side there are the elderly chefs. They don't spend any money on making the place fancy. I went on a Monday at around 5:00, and all the seats were filled (but like I said, there aren't many seats).

The Service:
I went for an early dinner so it wasn't crowded. One lady took my order, and she conversed with us in Burmese. Unfortunately speaking in Mandarin (no, it's NOT Cantonese) or Burmese does not get bigger portions or special treatment. Darn. The food was quick, though not much attention was paid towards the customers.

The Food:
I don't consider Yamo's food real Burmese food, but then again I don't think Burma Superstar's food is real Burmese food. Yamo's food is cheap and is geared towards an American audience. It's very cheap ($3.50 for appetizers and $5.25 for entrees), but the food is nothing special. Portions could be bigger. Their samusas were very small, the type you can find frozen at Ranch 99 or Pacific Super. The Yamo House Noodles (or garlic noodles, as I know them to be called) could have used more flavor. The presentation was lovely, but the taste was lacking. The mango chicken wasn't anything special either. It's on about the same level as Panda Express. I was a bit disappointed with the food and the limited selection, but I figure the chefs are friends from temple who decided to go into a little business together.

All in All:
I didn't have very high expectations, but Yamo was decent. It was cheap and pretty good for the price. I don't think it's anything special, but I'm rather biased since I've grown up eating Burmese food. I feel like the only reason the restaurant is popular is because it's cheap and it's different. If you don't know what real Burmese food is supposed to taste like, I think you'd like Yamo. It's not bad, but not authentic or flavorful enough for my taste.
author: Jessica M.

description: Good, cheap eats! Too bad everyone knows this place, wait is getting to long.
author: Richard E.

description: Keep in mind that we did show up at around 6pm on a Monday night when I'm guessing there are loads of lazy people (like us) who can't be arsed cooking!  We had to wait in line for about 25 minutes before we could even order.....then when we finally got a chance to order, the girl answered the phone right in the middle of it and took someone elses order!  harumph.  They told us twenty minutes wait for the food - it was more like 40....it was really hot and sweaty inside but really cold outside (hellooooo san francisco).  The spring rolls were AWESOME - will definitely get those as a snacky when I'm walking home from work.  The rest of the food was alright - not very flavourful and didn't really hit the "i'm in a noodle mood" spot.........Price was great - $36 for an order of potstickers (6), 3 orders of spring rolls (6), chicken curry, fried rice, chow mein, vege curry and house noodles..
author: B P.

description:
While waiting for the rarest bus on the road, i saw a line that arouse my interest.  At $5.25 for all entrees its definately worth the wait. 
Scale from 1-5
Ambiance: 3, in and out, they only offer a bar that sits maybe 9 people. which is why their usually a line.
Food: 4, Great noodles and soups, A reason to love SF
Service: 5, definate language barriers, point and pay.  
Price 6 food and entree
Advice not a bad way to go out if your trying to make a dollar last
author: Rene M.

description:
i found yamo accidentally, cruising up mission to country station. i had never even noticed it before, but there it was, a ghostly apparition. it was a hole in the wall for sure, and i immediately felt like i was back in asia, where food is cheap, well seasoned, and satisfying. the tea salad is definitely the standout dish, i order it every time i go there. with all its little crunchy, nutty surprises i could probably eat a few pounds of it before my mouth got bored. follow that with a sweet fresh coconut and you are good to go.

the ladies who work there are friendly and pretty fast. i've gotten there when it was full and thought, "oh, shit. this will take forever," but i've never had a really long wait like you would at the superstar. plus it's in my hood! and really, it is such a deal, you could order several dishes and totally pig out for less than $20. for two people! it's probably not for everyone, and it's definitely not gourmet, but it is good cheap eats.
author: pizzazz g.

description:
friend and i found this place by accident (we were at the muffler shop down the street).  we were lucky to get seating right away and man, this food is the bomb.  i could eat 10 plates of the tea and mango salad.  wow.  
i'm not surprised with the 4 1/2 star rating.  the cute ladies have definitely earned it!
author: Erick A.

description: Yamo is a great change of pace from the regular old sit-down restaurant. It's a narrow, busy, comfy little place very reminiscent of the restaurants you find in cities around Asia. The noodles are nicely al-dente and the tea salad is tasty. Shame they don't have a liquor license though, the onion, garlic and especially salt is a bit overpowering - definitely needs a beerish companion!
author: Will A.

description:
this place is so cute, and so cheap. i believe salads and entrees are $5.25 each, and starters are (no joke) $3.50!!!  i haven't had the spring rolls, but $3.5! you'd get spring rolls at slanted door for more than twice that.

anyway, enough about the bargain prices. it's a small place with one bar and less than 10 seats (stools).  the kitchen is directly in front of you, consisting of a huge vent and grill, 4 pots on the back grill and some woks at the front. a counter for food prep, one small refrigerator, and a hot thermos for making tea.  we didn't sample too many of the dishes, but i really liked my garlic tofu noodle dish, #15.  i looked at the noodle tendrils shiny with frying grease and curry, and my healthy resolve melted with each tasty slurp.

but the real draw is how quaint this place is. i feel like I'm at a small family kitchen in china (though I know this is Burmese food, this place brings me back to villages in china which i have visited). it feels so homey that any of the three old Asian ladies cooking and chopping away could easily be my grandma!  i love it. 

for those hoping for the greasy post Saturday night meal, this place is NOT it--it's not open on Sundays.
author: Dee C.

description: Update: After having visited the glory that is Burma Super Star, I had to demote Yamo by a star.  Sorry Yamo ):  While quality was good for the price, it pales in comparison.
author: Robert R.

description: Yamo's is a tiny place but a gem for yummy, healthy and cheap eats! My favorites are the tea leaf salad and the mango salad - I never get sick of them and order from here about once a week - more if it were closer. Order with a little time to spare as it's always crowded in this little restaurant. If you are eating in you may have to wait for a seat at the bar.  The owners are super friendly and sweet.
author: Angie K.

description: This place is great. It's cozy with just bar seating and has great food.
author: DE B.

description: i don't understand the hype. i got the curry chicken with noodles and it was greasy as can be. the tea leaf salad was alright. they could have held back a little on the garlic. after flossing, teeth brushing, tongue brushing and mouthwash, it still had my breath humming the next morning.
author: Regina C.

description: $5.25 for anything noodle dish on the menu? Sweet! The house noodles are good, and the cold noodles are GREAT. People seem to like the tea salad, but it's a little lackluster for my tastes. At any rate, I love the counter-only setup, although packed quarters with the kitchen right in my lap always leaves my clothes smelling smoky when I leave.
author: Calvin L.

description: The quality of the food here will not challenge your taste buds but for $5 a plate it makes for a perfectly adequate snack and those among us who fantasize about eating in a submarine galley will find their wish fulfilled.
author: Zdisław G.

description: I love YAMO! The tea leaf salad is an indescribable melange of delicious flavors, and the Yamo cold noodles aren't really cold at all. The salad looks small but fills you up fine. Cheap and yummy- can be slow when place is full.
author: Leslie C.

description: Great dive restaurant, super cheap, a bit greasy, but overall some good stuff.
author: Eric W.

description:
plate licking yummy, best literal hole in the wall without the normal "hole in the wall" aspects IE: the roaches, hair and a guy named Sal! very cozy 9 seat counter with lovely ladies making yummy food, I had the veggies and tofu over rice noodles and couldn't believe how fresh and amazing it tasted, not to mention two fundamental points:
1. it cost 5.25
2. it had asparagus and varied types of mushrooms (yeah!)

my friend had the curry veggies with tofu and his was equally yummy but it wasn't the usual Thai Curry, (less coconut sopped sauce drenching everything)  the Curry was  wok fried with the veggies so it covered them without the curry being the only thing you can taste- very very good! very spicy!
author: A. Gun n.

description: I had lunch at Yamo today, and to be honest, I was a little dissapointed.  We had the house special noodles w/ chicken, curry prawns w/ noodles, and tea salad.  All the food was good, but the flavors were simple, lacking any distinctive deliciousness, thus forcing me to apply the hotcock.
