However, Yamo is incredibly charming and I will always have a soft spot in my heart for little hole-in-the-wall family places.  it hurts me to give this place only 3 stars, and honestly I would go back, but the food really does not deserve 4.
author: greg B.

description: I hesitate to review this place after stumbling on to it on Yelp, as I don't want to add to the already long lines.  But I can't help it -- these women deserve to have the word get out about the fantastic home-cooked, ridiculously low priced, hole in the wall goodness that they make in this little shack.  I think they've intentionally left the graffiti on the sign outside to keep the traffic manageable.  Places like Yamo are what San Francisco is all about.
author: Suresh K.

description: Why doesn't yelp let me use the "less than" symbol?  Is it so hard to filter tags properly?  I want to say "I heart yamo" but I want it to look cool.  Come on!  My only regret is they are closed on Sunday.  Guess what day it is?
author: Laurence B.

description: Greasy, spicy, plentiful, and cheap: Great hangover food.
author: Wendy C.

description: OMG...Yamo House Noodles w/Chicken is so f*ckin' good.
author: Clifford P.

description: I give Yamo a 5 for being totally incog and having no signage. Its SupreNeato!
author: Star S.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants in the city! Soo good, and sooo cheap! (Plus, being of the 33 bus line is a plus!)

I recommend the cold noodles for sure! Also, samusas and a tea leaf salad are pretty good (along with their chicken noodle soup). Okay, so I'm basically just listing a ton of stuff now. Try it out for yourself - you'll see! For $5.25 they can't be beat!
author: Kimberly D.

description: Yes the once tasty and well-decorated Yamo's is now home to ugly fluorescent lighting and marginal Burmese food.  Stroll on to Bender's to see what you missed at Tai Wei's new place.
author: Mike H.

description: Funny what great treasures one finds while wondering through the streets of the Mission District. The undeniable, distinctive curry aroma got me as soon as I turned the corner of Mission and 18th.  This is a two person operation, run by two wonderful ladies. There is not one dish on the menu over $5.25....yes...you read it correctly.....$5.25. The house chow mein and curries are to die for......all with a smile. After a few short moments, I felt like I had been coming to this restaurant for years.....maybe it is the intimate setting....less than ten bar stools besides the chefs and their ingredients....that makes one feel this way. I have been back time and time again.....highly reccomended.
author: Kenny G.

description: Yamo is not pretty...that's for sure! but they prepare some mean noodles for dirt cheap and they serve fresh coconut for your drinking pleasure. It's sure well worth a try!
author: Paola W.

description:
The fish chowder. 

The coconuts.

The tea salad.

The Burma perms.

AWESOME.
author: Ali W.

description: I wanted to like this place more because its pretty good value, and it feels cool squeezing along the bench, and watching the flames lick under the woks in front of you. But I got the sense that the Cantonese hadn't entirely mastered Burmese cuisine and the dishes we had largely reinforced this.
author: Nick O.

description: Truly awesome!  Little hole in the wall in the Mission.  You can belly up to the counter and the two women that run the joint will make you feel right at home.  Everything tastes fresh and the quality of the food is high.  You get a lot of bang for your buck.  A great place with a comfy feel.
author: Ben V.

description: I love yamo.  A pretty girl brought me here in January and I've come back every chance I get.  The place is very tiny, and lately if you go at typical rush times there is a little bit of a wait.   That's because this place is the size of a closet.  You squeeze past people to an open stool at the bar and sit, the women cooking right in front of you.  This place is cheap, like two people eating until they're stuffed for $15.  Nice fresh springrolls with a good peanut sauce.  Love the tea leaf salad, a bit salty but addicting.  I highly recommend the cold noodles.  They're a bit different each time, but always filling and tasty.
author: Jett S.

description: Great comfort food. I was tired of having to schlep out to the sunset for some good asian food. Yamo house noodles can get greasy at times but the food is pretty consistent for a great price. Mango chicken and prawn curry also get thumbs up. Also, pot stickers are the best I've ever had especially when dipped in the spicy sauce.
author: Andy L.

description: I tried this place yesterday after reading a few reviews here. Result: An easy five stars. Why? Star 1=Value - prices were amazing. I was turned off by Burma Superstar's prices, and didn't go back. Star 2=Food quality, especially for the price, the food was great. My house noodles with chicken was outstanding, with very firm noodles and slices of white chicken meat that melted in my mouth. The mango salad was good also. Star 3=Friendly people, the nice ladies who run this place are having fun, and neighborhood people stop by to say hello. Star 4=Contribution to City, do we want a town full of Quiznos or one full of places like this? Star 5=Ingredients, healthy for me is fresh cooked food with lots of vegetables. Look at all the fresh cut veggies behind the bar and you'll see what goodness is going into your bod.
author: Nick C.

description: So I come here as often as I can. Prices are $5.25 for each plate. The somosa are good as well. I have not had anything bad here. If you are in a rush, call in your order for pick up. I do not recommend getting the noodles to go, as by the time you get them home, they are all sticky and dry.
author: Michael T.

description: Yamo is the best! Just be prepared for a wait!
author: Bill S.

description:
Great cheap Burmese American food. 
- don't come here expecting gourmet.
- don't come here expecting to find the light switch in the bathroom. 
- don't come here expecting to get a seat during dinner or lunch. 
- DO come here for a cheap greasy filler upper. ITS GOOD!
- DO come here if you like a cool hole in the wall environment.
- DO come here and listen to the crazy cooks yell and laugh at eachother.
author: Brad Y.

description: Yamo is a staple to those on a budget. Quick, cheap and filling. I recommend the mango dish, and request tofu instead of chicken.
author: Pedro H.

description: I like this place because it's an incognito hole-in-the-wall with good food.  I like sitting there and watching them make everything, it makes me feel like I'm in somebody's kitchen.  Not the best Burmese food I've ever had but definitely worth it for the price, this place is cheap!  And you can't go wrong with anything you order.  If you come during dinner time, be prepared to wait a while for a seat since there are only 8 to 10 seats in there.
author: P D.

description: Its been said before but its true, this place is the definition of hole in the wall! But that isn't a bad thing, if your looking for some good burmese food check it out. It feels kinda like being in a time warp while your there, in a good way though.
author: Julian R.

description: I love that Yamo is tiny and CHEAP. I love that Yamo is completely lacking in "atmosphere." I want to eat good food and get out of there...not gawk at people or table settings or something.  And about that food: it's pretty great. The tea leaf salad is just as good as the one I've had at Burma Superstar but without the wait. The only thing that makes me sad is that Yamo has been closed the last two Fridays we've tried to go. I think both were just bad timing - I can understand that a tiny family-owned place might want to close during the holidays - but it is sucky to skate down there only to find the lights off, gates locked, and a sign saying they'll be closed for a couple of days. I need my tea leaf salad!
author: Amy Jo J.

description:
Well, the three hundred and eleven Yelp reviews turn out to not be wrong.

After the first attempt was curbed by what seems to have been a random unscheduled closing we decided to give it another go but this time with a call ahead. A women promptly picked up the phone and yelled "yamo" at me, I said, "how late are you open?". She replied, "9:30" and hung up. We got on some bikes and road down to the mission with a 5 dollar bottle of sparkling Spanish wine from TJs, a corkscrew, and a couple yellow laminated paper cups: this blog might be recent (and sporadic) but I have been BYOBing all over this state for many years and I think self-service is always a good call. We got there in 7 minutes and secured the bikes to a locked gate of the adjacent storefront. I think this is the way to go in this hood, on this rather dark un-traficked stretch of 18th. There appears to be a pretty constant cluster of people waiting outside to sit down or pick up food, having the bike as close as possible to the entrance makes sense.

From the street Yamo is basically invisible, perhaps 8 feet of storefront with no signage. (There is a blank white panel where there should be a sign which makes a very effective signifier (in this case, Yamo is the "signified"); absolutely appropriate for a place that will probably be full via word-of-mouth no matter what they put out front.) We waited for about 15 minutes and popped the Lambrusco Dell'Emilia Bianco (see picture) it was pretty sweet but nice and bubbly, just fine for a paper cup and a concrete ledge.

Once inside we sat down mid bar and enjoyed the atmosphere. Yamo reminds me of Taipei in a major way, grimy and tiny with grumpy people yelling behind the counter. There was a giant sign on the wall saying "no outside alcohol", but that is where the opaque cups and the oversized shoulder bag come in handy. We had no problem with the under-counter fill ups. There was no pressure to order, which I thought was impressive for a tiny place with a line out front.

We ordered :
Fermented Tea Leaf Salad : It was phenomenally bright and tart. The cabbage was crispy and the nuts provided a fatty crunch that balanced the generous use of acids (lemon juice & rice vinegar?). I know that I will order this every time no matter what.
Fish Chowder: Had a definite curry undertone and a lovely, sort of powdery broth. There were little crispy bits in there too. I wouldn't miss this one either.
House Noodle, Chicken: So awesomely greasy with what I consider to to be the perfect asian noodle texture, sort of al-dente but totally slippery. I was a bigger fan of this than my partner in crime was. She preferred the soup.

The wine was actually a great, light compliment to the spicy/greasy-ness, we finished the bottle and felt great. The entire affair cost less than 30 bucks!

Read yelp for more on the food, or just go with your paper cups in the bag.

ATH


And, as a final thought: what is the deal with people complaining about staff at restaurants not smiling? I don't go into a place, especially a place like Yamo, looking for a new friend. The service here is efficient and aware. Our waters were refilled and when we left without drinking our jelly juice the lady behind the counter insisted we not forget a straw. When people are working they don't generally smile. To withhold an additional Yelp star because a two person restaurant staff, that is accomplishing all tasks involved in serving, prepping, and cleaning, doesn't "Denny's" it up for you shows a lack of sophistication and empathy.
author: Aaron Taylor H.

description: great food. okay service. try the tea leaf salad and chix cold noodles!
author: casey b.

description: There's this thing about San Francisco, where the relationship between price and food quality is about as fixed as it is with wine - there isn't much. Yamo is the quintessential San Francisco hole in the wall - so unassuming it's nearly pretentious, delicious home food, really nice people running it, and charm that is flattered by the surprise of all this finger-licking goodness just accross the door from a downright squalid street-corner. Very inexpensive, tasty food. The tea leaf salad was delicous, as were the samosas.
author: Juan Cristian V.

description: Yamo is good food at a very good price. I had the fish curry. It was very tasty. Wifey had the Yamo special noodles, which were good but not great. The portions were decently sized. The place is very small though. Just 10 seats at the counter where you watch the ladies make your meal. It's also kind of smoky. Still, dinner for 2 for $11 is pretty amazing.
author: Yogi B.

description:
i wish someone would tell the people at yamo that they could probably charge more for their delicious food and people would still pay for it --- yamo's food is beyond cheap.  i worry that the fantastic people at yamo aren't making what they deserve... 

the tea salad is amazing, as are the spring rolls.
author: Gina M.

description:
Yamo food is delicious, cheap, and quick.  I've eaten at Yamo three times now and definitely recommend eating in to watch and interact with the owners.

I tried and loved the mango salad, chicken noodle soup, and sambusas.   I was in Burma/Myanmar a couple of months ago and vouch for the authenticity.
author: Katelyn D.

description: THIS IS THE PLACE. Love it .Of course hard to get a seat at the very limited lunch counter. I highly recommend doing it once in your life if you can since watching the ladies behind the counter cook is dinner theatre in itself. I love the swinging overhead lamp and rustic walls sweaty with spice, ah if grease and plaster could talk. Anyways, if you are in a hurry just get carry out. The tea leaf salad is good along with the spring rolls and peanut sauce. I LOVE their chicken curry soup, soo good. Some people might question the cleanliness but I have NEVER seen someone handle food and then money (or vice versa). The lady who handles money only serves water and soda and may ladle some soup into a bowl. She NEVER directly touches the food! LOVE this place and it is really cheap too!
author: julie q.

description: the tea leaf salad was a tad too greasy for me. however, the mango chicken was delicious.  it had enough spice and was very filling.  :D
author: con c.

description: The Mango Chicken is so great.  It's nice and spicy too.  The Samosas are pretty tasty with a sweet and sour sauce.  The Fried rice is a little dry though.  The Yamo house noodes are good but a little too greasy for my liking.  But the prices are unbeatable, and again I will emphasize that the mango chicken is awesome!
author: Tina K.

description: This place is the definition of a hole in a wall. I like the authentic atmosphere with the ladies cooking right infront of you and the cheap price. Tried the tea leaf salad and the samosas appetizers and both were pretty good. Had the curry beef entree if I remember correctly and had good flavor and a decent kick. I did regret ordering the curry though since the noodle dishes looked much more unique.
author: Ed C.

description: BEST FOOD EVER! this is seriously my favorite restaurant in all of sf. big portions, everything is about $5, and the women who own the restaurant/cook your food are a riot to watch. love this place!!!
author: ingrid H.

description: My boyfriend loves this place because it is cheap, close, and intimate. I like it for the veggie options. Its kinda gross decor but the tea leaf salad is the gift that keeps on giving....you'll taste it for days!
author: Elissa G.

description: I thoroughly enjoyed my exerience here.  This food is made with love always and the counterhelp is tremendously nice, dig it!
author: Zach H.

description: Perfect asian comfort food for chilly nights in the city.  Cheap, greasy, spicy, tasty goodness!
author: beatrice m.

description:
yum, another good hole in the wall.
tea leaf salad, amazing, cheap. could eat three in a row.
if you don't like to wait, order by phone and take your grub to delores park. they omit specific ingredients for vegetarians. the only thing wrong with this place is the absence of desserts and if any of you remember, mean lady thai.
author: chairmember m.

description: Quite a remarkable lunch-counter that may not appear open, let alone a restaurant, from across the street.  Food cooked right in front of you, so an extra half-star for transparency.  You can fill your belly for under $6--another half-star.  Worth checking out, especially to remedy the Mission's burrito supersaturation.
author: Rawley V.

description: My new favorite restaurant in the Mission.  Amazing food, very very cheap and very nice servers/chefs.  Need to find more of these type places in SF.
author: Ron F.

description: Cheap, well-portioned, noodley tastiness.  I like the black bean fish with noodles.  I don't know how 'authentic' it is but it's a great quick lunch.
author: Alex S.

description:
If you're longing to relive your experiences traveling through Southeast Asia, eating at a roadside where the bus stopped, this is the place.  I haven't been to any place in the states that takes me back in the same way.

Best bets on the menu, for me are the Salads (Mango or Chicken, I've never had the Tea leaf because its hard enough to choose between the two, I don't need a third option) and the Soups (Chicken Coconut Noodle or the Fish Chowder).

Since the seating is pretty limited, I'm a big fan of calling in an order and picking it up to eat at home.
author: A E.

description: so awesome!!! and a great price!  i wondered what the hype was whenever I walked home and saw a line - lives up!
author: Marisa W.

description:
Good food, even better prices. The tea leaf salad was as advertised--nice blend of flavors and textures. Got to love crispy bits. Great entertainment to watch the ladies move in well-oiled choreography.

Couple of minor downsides are the wait (small kitchen, few cooks) and less-than-desired ventilation. I don't like to walk out of a restaurant smelling like what I eat.

Definitely heading back for some eats.
author: jj w.

description: Perfectly named hole in the wall with super cheap Burmese eats. It's not exactly Burma Superstar but you can't complain when you're paying what you would at a tacqueria and can watch them cook everything in front of you.
author: D A.

description: First time in San Fran.  Tea Salad is fantastic.  Mango Chicken not special but still great for the price.  Love sitting at the bench and you get to watch them cook. Worth every cent.
author: Matt S.

description:
I think all Burmese restaurants should be judged by one dish - Let Phet Thoke (green tealeaf salad).  It's the one reason I get excited to find a Burmese restaurant.  You won't find a taste sensation like it anywhere... if they make it right.

So how is the Let Phet?  Pretty dang good.  Like many Burmese restaurants, they skimp on the tea leaves which really bums me out... probably because the bitter, sour, tang turns off a lot of people and maybe restaurants get tired of seeing it go to waste.  Short of the shorting of tea leaves it just might be perfect.  Yamo's version is a little spicier than most I've had but I really loved that.  

Everything else:
. Environment: small, just counter space.  Sometimes a little smoky from the cooking.
. Prices: great.
. Food: I've only tried 3 dishes so far.  All were simple, tasty, and, best of all, cooked right in front of you.
. Negatives:  I'd like to see more drink variety.

Summary: Great, cheap, honest eats.
author: Mark S.

description: I love Yamo. True, it was better in the past, with the variable menu and the bring your own alcohol options and the bad eighties movies playing with the vinyl jazz, but things change, and it remains iconoclastic and different, and cheap.
author: Surly V.

description:
This is a bare bones place when it comes to decor and presentation, but as a lunch counter sort of joint, it does the job well.

I loved the curry tofu over noodles, and the fresh coconut drink is always delightful.

Prices are beyond reasonable - two people can eat for $20, and eat well.
author: Pat E.

description: perfect little whole-in-the-wall place...if you like cheap good burmese/chinese food, then this is the place for you. i recommend any dish/appetizer on the menu, and it's only $5.45/entree!!!! it's a MUST, trust me. but be prepared to wait in line any day of the week, but well worth it. i'm actually on the way there!!!! woohoo...
author: jason xavier c.

description: we ordered and I asked how long it would be and the old woman who yells instead of talks said it would be 15 min.  We went and had a beer and came back about 20 min later and it wasn't ready.  I figured I'd asked the young helper what was up since she probably spoke better english, and she said (in broken english)... "Wait on vegetable's".  We didn't mind the wait since it was a nice night out and we'd had a beer.  We ordered the mango salad, tea salad, and vegetable curry.  We were handed our food and left without checking that it was the right dishes.  We got home and discovered that we got both salads, but we got the vegetable stir fry instead, and she threw in and charged us for spring roles, which we didn't order. the salads were tasty, but they kind of made my stomach hurt, and the vegetable stirfry was nasty, fried, watery, oily, yuck.  All in all if I'm looking for some cheap eats I would not go back to this place, or at least I wouldn't order take out.
author: Malcolm K.

description: the burmese cast of golden girls invites you to their nightly over-eating contest.  $10.50 buys you a food coma-  $15.75 drives you to a membership to crunch.
author: Mooni P.

description: Ok, for those of you who love Yamo and it's your favorite spot please take no offense to my review. The beauty of Yelp is that we can all have our own opinions. I read about Yamo on yelp and since I love me some Burmese food I had to check it out, along with two of my foodie friends who have the utmost appreciation for divey-food. We didn't have high expectations but we were hopeful that we'd enjoy it. To be honest I was disappointed. The food was just not that great. The atmosphere, while cozy and quaint in that belly-up to the counter kind of way, was overrun by the heavy scent of deep fried oil air. Yes, I"m talking stuff-ee.  The price was nice and low but for what we got I'd have been disappointed paying anything more. I really would never go back there. The greasy air spoiled it for me. So for those of you who are bummed about the "hot on yelp" ruining your favorite spot, maybe you'll forgive me for not sharing in your Yamo joy. All I can say is, you can have this favorite spot back, all to yourself, because I will not be returning.
author: Kelly S.

description: The GF & I decided to stop by here for lunch based on the glowing reviews (and the fact that we were out in the Mission already).  We almost walked right by the place - it's a hole in the wall place, meant in the best way possible.  The awning of the place was barely legible but we could roughly make out Yamo on there.  We stepped inside and take a seat at the counter.  Almost everything on the menu (aside from drinks) is priced at $5.25 and $3.50 for appetizers.  One of the ladies behind the counter suggested the Yamo Cold Noodles, so I got that and the GF got the Yamo House Noodles.  We also got an order of the freshly made spring rolls.  I personally love places where you get to see what's going on in the kitchen and in this joint, you definitely have a front row seat.  The spring rolls were tasty, big & fresh!  The noodle dishes were very good too.  The taste of the Yamo House Noodles reminded me of noodles I would make at a Mongolian BBQ place.  My Yamo Cold Noodles had just enough spicy kick to keep you wanting more.  I thought we were done, but ended up ordering some Samusas to go.  The sauce provided definitely had a kick to it!  We thought a yogurt based sauce might go nicer, but they were still quite good.  I'm definitely coming back here though!
author: Allan H.

description: This is my favorite place when I head for a lunch or dinner on my own. Its so cozy and the chefs are genuine.
author: Susan P.

description: "I would like one fire in my mouth please!" is what I say when I've got Yamo on the brain. This quaint little Mission Thai spot might be just be a miniature sun....cuz the food is packin heat! Kelvin temperatures aside, the food Taiway dishes up is heavenly: healthy, colorful and o so delicioso. I recommend the mango spring rolls. They're practically a meal in themselves. They're so of another world I'd mug somebody for 'em. Yup, that's right. "Stick em up" I'd say..."And give me some of that goodness in there with the mango and the beans and the crazy Thai sauces and all the spicey roots and shit I'm not sure I'm even supposed to eat." The curries are also delicious. Taiway's always got a great flick on, so if your Match.com date turns out to be a dullard, you can watch some Bruce Lee classics and mentally work on your karate moves you've so diligently been practicing in the safety of your own room. Secret: that last statement does not refer to me. Secret: there is a lie somewhere in this review. Secret: bring your own beer, and be ready to pour a little out for your homie behind the counter...
author: Cpt. Scallywag N.

description: yumo yamo...where else can you find yummy noodle dishes for about $5 in the city? is it thai? is it burmese? who knows? i chatted with the ladies one time and found out they're from macau, former portuguese colony next to hong kong... which doesn't really clear it up all that much. we always end up having the noodle soups here due to foggy sf nights. get it to go if you're squeamish about not-super-clean interiors.
author: Angi C.

description: Get there early.  Tea Leaf salad and spring rolls are always great.  Delighted and full everytime I go.
author: K K.

description: Ok, there's really no good reason why I haven't written a review of this place months ago, as it is currently my favorite restaurant and has held the honor of that distinction longer than most. There is a "bad reason", however-a selfish one that I'm a little ashamed of: I'm not sure I want any more people going there! It's so small already, with literally no tables, just a counter with 7 or 8 seats. These seats are often full if you go at prime time; lunch hour or any time after 5 pm, although turn over is usually fast. I've since realized, though that the limited seating of this place is one of the aspects, along with a slight language/culture barrier, and a "smudginess" due to the exhaust from the cooking surfaces right behind the counter, that has allowed the prices at this place to remain low, and for it to keep off the mainstream restaurant radar, which is just fine with me. I'll gladly accept backless stools, huff a bit of grease-fire smoke, and sometimes wonder at momentarily non existent service (the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars), for truly wonderful and authentic Southeast Asian food and an almost transporting genuine asian street food style experience at dirt cheap prices. You go ahead and go to your fancy restaurants where they have actual tables and where you don't sit in the kitchen because I'll be just fine here where the fermented tea leaf salad kicks the frickin pants off the one at Burma Super Star, with it's array of way more exotic and tasty additions, like nuts I've never seen before and do not know the names of. Yes, if you phone in an order for take out, they don't even ask your name but just say, "thank you, bye" and hang up, and your order is rarely ever ready when you come to pick it up at the time they tell you, but so what? What are you in such a big hurry for anyways? Take some time to stop and smell the Yamo house noodles, man. Because I can tell you with dead certainty they're equally good with pork, beef, or chicken.
author: Evan J.

description: SO delicious. The tea leaf salad and veggie/tofu curry are amazing, especially for the price... so affordable! It may be tiny and cramped, and some dishes may be a little greasy... but I will always come back. YUM.
author: Justin K.

description: Tiny little restaurant.  A serious mom and pops hole in the wall type of place, but ohh is it good and cheap.  This is the kind of place you don't judge the place, but the food.  Good Tea Leaf salad, beef noodles, catfish soups, curry chickens.  You won't spend much more than 10-15 per person.  Sometimes there's a wait, but lately it's easier to get a seat than say a year ago.
author: Jen M.

description: I was super super super excited to go to Yamo last week. I had planned on saving my stomach for it, but this plan was undermined by an overabundance of free sandwiches at work, and the fact that I really wanted an omelette and had brunch (after my breakfast) at Balompie that morning. Anyways, naturally, I was still hungry by the time dinner rolled around. Yamo is teeny tiny and has about ten seats. After waiting for a bit, we had the Yamo House Noodles (which were not garlicy enough), vegetarian Spring Rolls (which completely lacked flavor, but that's probably because my best friend thinks she's allergic to shrimp which is what is supposed to be in the Spring Rolls), and the Tea Leaf Salad (which was also a bit bland). The food was filling and reasonably priced, but just not that flavorful. Maybe we didn't order the right things. I love the women who work there and boss you around while seeming to mock you for asking that the main ingredient of a dish be cut, it smells amazing, is right by my work, and is cheapish... so I'll be back.
author: Mairead J.

description: Yummy Yamo. Burmese food at its best...and so affordable that you can eat here everyday!
author: kirti p.

description: good atmosphere and good house noodles. it feels like my grandmother is making me the food. but if my grandmother did know how to make these noodles i wouldnt have to come here.
author: Paul Q.

description:
apparently run by 3 sisters.

one sunny friday afternoon i stood in line and called in my order haha.

got the house noodles with beef, which were freakin delicious with the hot sauce

and the chicken curry which was just very light and too watery for me. its like comparing whip cream to ice cream. and this was the whip cream. 

4 stars for the house noodles, the cheap price, and super tight quarters and ambiance.
author: Porkers T.

description: total hole in the wall, but super cheap and tasty, too. i was craving salt all day. i won't say how many kettle chips i consumed in an effort to satisfy my soul, but i will say that yamo's tofu and veggie dish combined with the burmese salad did the trick in a matter of bites. i consider that a good thing; i've been known to salt my sweets even. i haven't ever eaten in the restaurant itself, but take-out worked out well.
author: julia r.

description: I might be a little biased because I waited 20 minutes in the freezing cold to get a seat at this place.  It's your basic hole-in-the wall - good food, generous portions, maybe 10-15 stools to sit on total.  Everyone comes here just for the food, so if you want ambiance or great service, keep looking.  Food-wise, the black bean fish is very good, and pretty much everyone else's main entrees looked equally good - those would get 4 stars in my book.  I did get potstickers that seemed like the pork was still raw - luckily no food poisoning yet, and the spring rolls were just decent.
author: Lisa C.

description: I went here a couple years ago for the first time with a friend, and have returned many times since then.  The tiny, almost hard-to-miss, place has a few seats and the food is cooked right in front of you.  It's hard to beat the prices and the deliciousness of the food.  I always end up ordering the house noodles, but have tried a couple other dishes.
author: Nadia T.

description: great little restaurant with noodles that have that "just how mama make it" taste.  the price of the dishes are real inexpensive as well.  be prepared to stand outside lookin in like a voyeur for seating and come out smelling like a steamed vegetable.
author: Huy D.

description: It is so delicious.  Also I like the small counter.  Feels very mom and pop. I've been ordering take out a lot lately because of the line running out the door.  Fresh coconut milk for $2.50 and they cut it right in front of you.  Feels like a 1950's malt shop, only the super tiny Burmese version.  I love how small it is.  I feel transported to a simpler time with delicious food at reasonable prices.  I hesitate to even write this review, fearing that others will discover this secret delicious treasure.  But here I go anyway.  Yamo.  I love your food.  Go here, but keep it under your hat. :)
author: m m.

description: so....yamo.used to be yamo thai years ago and it had its run,was good too!then tai wei came on the scene and well.....a bit of confusion ruled the day during his tenure as propietor.Then the blessing time started.These  ladies of burma are a blessing on the mission,The food is home style burmese/chinese and rocks your palate with simple,directly delicious food.Its hard to just walk in now as theres always a line of mission creants hangin round the door like lost cats but the wait is well worth it.
author: eamonn d.

description: A small place if you are going there to eat, but delicious food.  Listen to the women behind the counter chat away in Burmese is a pleasure.
author: Akash P.

description: Too spicy for me, but cheap and otherwise good. Should prepend 'nano-' to its name.
author: John K.

description: sketchy but delicious. hole in the wall burmese. tea leaf salad is fantastic, topped with smokey, browned garlic bits. super cheap, get it to go or grab a beer at the store around the corner and sit at the bar.
author: Jess T.

description: My least favorite Burmese in San Francisco, and yet it gets three stars because I feel about Burmese food the way most Americans feel about pizza:  even mediocre [Burmese||pizza] is damn good food.  The first time I went the wait was unbearable, and the standing in line system definitely doesn't work for me.  I need to be able to chat and drink and I'm pretty sure I'm not uptight, but drinking out of a paper bag with the crackheads of Mission street isn't what I mean.  It is charming enough inside--I enjoy seing the food made by the nice ladies behind the counter.  This is actually where I learned to spritz dried spring roll sheets with a spray bottle to soften, rather than dipping or brushing and it's worked for me so far.  But the food just isn't that exciting.  Not enough spice, acidity, or pungency depending on the dish.  None of it was at all bad, there just wasn't any dish that left me excited.
author: Taco T.

description: @hilary: I remember the guy who ran the vegan thai place that was in this spot before too. He was great - and the food was all vegan! Mostly thai curries that didn't taste very thai, but were good in their own right. And the movies and the records. Excellent. I was sad when he left, but glad when the three ladies moved in. There was also an excellent thai place before the vegan guy run by a wonderful woman. This location has a nifty history of special little places... With each of the three I feel like the place is this thing from the lion the witch and the wardrobe - it's sometimes there, if you look for it, but sometimes you can't find it. And you never know when it'll be open.
author: Ichibod R.

description: When I want a good bite, lunch or dinner, in the heart of the mission, this place is always high on the list -- the tea-leaf salad is tops and the noodles are fresh-to-order and garlicky good.  The only downside is that it has counter seating only and fills up fast -- try your luck and you might be rewarded with one of the tastiest and cheapest holes-in-the-wall in the Mission.
author: Dan I.

description: I heard about Yamo, from a co-worker and decided to try it out. First of all, I feel this is more of a Chinese place than Burmese. None of the vegetarian dishes available at Burma Superstar are available there. There are a bunch of tofu dishes.The food is all right, nothing to crave about. The only good thing is that is cheap and fresh.
author: Kuldeep T.

description: Love this place! It reminds me of travels. Their tea leaf salad is the best in the city. I always get that and the house noodles. The food is fresh and you see the lovely ladies prepare it in front of you.  Their spring rolls are also made fresh unlike many places that have them rolled and sitting there for hours. They have baby coconuts too! Only problem would be the limited seating. They must have about 8 stools alongside a long counter. I personally think that is what make it even cooler but I could see how some would find it uncomfortable. Overall, one of my favorite places in the city. :)
author: monica g.

description: I love this place!  The food comes quickly, and is tasty as hell.  $10 gets you an entire meal, including a drink and tip!  Speaking of tips, I would recommend buying a bottled beverage instead of getting a glass of water - the only real downside to Yamo is you practically have to beg to get your water glass filled on a regular basis.  Other than that, this place is stellar.
author: sara b.

description: Who doesnt love Yamo. Awesome eats for $5.25. Can't beat that. Here is a tip (esp for the Veggies out there) - try the Cold Noodle with Tofu.
author: MC N.

description: So good! I recommend Tea Leaf Salad and Cold Spicy noodles with tofu. Grab a beer and head to the park. Cheap and delicious!
author: Jessica L.

description: ehhhhh, it's alright.  i see people blowing their load over this place, but it isn't anything special.  i guess if you live in the mission, and you're sick of burritos, it's cool.  but coming from the richmond district, it was a long way to go for nothing special.  grant it, it was good, but i believe is was just like Star Wars Episode 1, way too overhyped.  oh and the service, they were too busy chopping celery to take an order or give us the bill.
author: sal c.

description:
tea leaf salad. pork house noodles.

order ahead.
author: j c.

description: Fun little hole in the wall, with friendly service and tasty food.  the fresh spring rolls are tasty  and the peanut sauce is just spicy enough.  go with the noodles, you can always get rice at other asian restaurants.  the beef and pork w/ the noodles are tender and yummy.  slightly greasy.   i haven't tried the coconut drink yet, but i hear it's great.
author: Shelly N.

description: This is the "Cheers" of the Mission area, except NO alcohol! Pull up to the bar, that is, if you get there early enough or you don't mind waiting in line so you'll eventually have your chance to experience the environment at its best. Simple menu with excellent prices, tight quarters so you better not mind sitting right next to others, only visuals are watching the 3 women proprietors knowing exactly where to find the particular food or drink item is that they need. We order the House noodles with Chicken but needed to spice it up just a little with some hot sauce. We also had the curry prawns with veggies. It was not very "currish" which was ok because sometimes restaurants can use too much curry. We ordered pot stickers that came out steaming hot and needed some cooling time so we could eat it but we were a little impatient.  The people next to us got the Coconut chicken noodle soup and it looked/smelt wonderful! We'll be back....but very early to make sure we get seated right away!
author: P G.

description: yamo is yum yum! 2 ladies behind the counter, a countertop and stools...home cookin burmese food! (first time I've had it, but thats what it felt like!!) it was great food, I totally recommend it to everyone just as long as you don't mind a dive. small, low key place, but great food at a great price. 4 of us dined for $21!! love the food and prices :)
author: bhavna p.

description: loved this place.  went on a rainy day around 3 and there was no line at all.  tea leaf salad was a bit salty, coconut curry soup was awesome.
author: tal d.
